HEADLINE: AT THE MOVIES

BYLINE: By Rick Lyman 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 30

 BODY:

Watch Out For a Breakout
A lot of eyes are watching the box-office numbers this weekend. Of course, there are always a lot of eyes watching the weekend box-office numbers in Hollywood. Sometimes it seems as if that's all they're watching (that and one another). But this weekend a lot of people are watching with breath held and something resembling hope in their hearts. 
 "American Beauty," the acid-laced suburban comedy from the first-time movie director Sam Mendes, has been among the best-reviewed films of the year. It opened in just 16 theaters in 5 cities on Sept. 15, earning $54,846 per theater in its opening weekend, said Jim Tharp, distribution chief for Dreamworks, which is releasing the film.
Originally, the plan was to put the movie into wider release on Oct. 1. Instead, Mr. Tharp said, it was pushed into 429 theaters in its second weekend, when it still earned $13,838 per screen. This weekend it will expand to 704 theaters. At that point, "American Beauty" will have moved well beyond the big-city theaters into smaller cities and outlying suburban areas. If it continues to do well, even more screens will be added into mid-October.
"Those are big-time per-theater averages," said Paul Dergarabedian, chairman of Exhibitor Relations, a Los Angeles-based company that monitors box-office performance. "It remains to be seen how the film will play in Middle America. But based on the numbers for last weekend, it looks very promising."
A studio marketing executive said: "I hope it does make it. But it's a little early to be handing out gold medals. There are plenty of cases of movies that started out strong and then expanded onto more screens and died. This could turn out to be a $35 million movie, or it could be a $75 million movie. It's too early to tell."
Also this weekend another offbeat, independent-minded studio production -- David O. Russell's gulf war film, "Three Kings," starring George Clooney -- will be released by Warner Brothers. It is unusual for major studios like Warners and Dreamworks to release films like "American Beauty" and "Three Kings," both of which have more of the feel of an independent movie. And that's why so many people in Hollywood are interested in seeing how they do, along with another forthcoming studio film with an independent sensibility, David Fincher's "Fight Club," coming out of 20th Century Fox on Oct. 15.
"I am very interested in seeing if these movies do well, especially 'American Beauty,' " said one director who was busy with the release of his own fall movie. "If it does well and makes a lot of money, it's going to be a very good thing for all filmmakers, especially those interested in making sophisticated films for sophisticated audiences, instead of the latest high-concept or teen-gimmick thing."
 
Beyond Youth
Sydney Pollack, who has been making movies since "The Slender Thread" in 1965, is also interested in what older, more sophisticated moviegoers are going to see this fall. His newest film, "Random Hearts," with Harrison Ford and Kristen Scott-Thomas playing a cop and a Congresswoman thrown together when they discover their spouses had an affair, is opening on Oct. 8.
"I've never gotten truly excited about something and had them say, 'Sydney, my boy, no, we can't make this movie because it doesn't appeal to the youth market,' " Mr. Pollack said. "That hasn't happened to me. Yet. I still believe there are exceptions to that youth rule, at least I hope there are. I think 35- or 40-year-old people are hungry for mature entertainment."
Among the things that have changed in the 34 years he has been making movies, Mr. Pollack said, is how "economics have started to color everything." Several of his films -- he named "Jeremiah Johnson" and "They Shoot Horses, Don't They?" -- probably couldn't be made today, he said, "largely because it's just a different marketplace."
Young moviegoers, who have always been important to the film business but are even more important today, seem to want to see movies with young people in them, he said.
"The first knee-jerk reaction for a 23-year-old couple on a date is to go see a movie about 25-year-olds," he said. "But I still believe there are exceptions. At least, I hope there are."
 
A Matter of Structure
"It takes a while to figure out what you're good at, because at the beginning you think you can do anything," Steven Soderbergh said.
This director was slowly working his way through a sandwich during a break in the marketing mania of the recent Toronto International Film Festival. Mr. Soderbergh was at the festival, as he had been at Cannes earlier in the year, with his film noir "The Limey," about a British thug who comes to Los Angeles to find out who killed his daughter and makes rather nasty work of a bunch of Hollywood types. The star of the film, Terence Stamp (left), was seated at a nearby table. ("During the filming, Steven evoked feelings in me that hadn't been evoked since I worked with William Wyler," Mr. Stamp had said earlier. "You could just tell, with both of them, that they absolutely knew what they were doing.")
Mr. Soderbergh, who began his career as a film-festival darling with "Sex, Lies and Videotape" and whose last film "Out of Sight" was chosen by several critics' groups as 1998's best, has been able to bounce back and forth between the studio and the independent worlds. While "The Limey" is an independent effort, to be distributed by Artisan Entertainment, his next movie, "Erin Brockovich," will be made for Universal with Julia Roberts.
Mr. Soderbergh said that only now, after eight films, did he feel he understood his strengths and limitations as a director. This has led him to take more of an interest in the structure of his films, he said.
"When I finished 'Out of Sight,' I wanted to do something right away," he said. "I had a buzz. I was energized. I wanted to work again immediately. And I wanted to make a movie set in Los Angeles, but one without the usual visual cliches of L.A. movies. I was having all of these ideas about structure. I had this idea about playing around with how the meaning of an image can shift through repetition, how it begins to have a different meaning as the film goes on."
What "The Limey" had, he said, was a simple story line with well-defined, easy-to-understand characters that allowed him to take chances with time shifts and nonlinear storytelling.
"It's the simplicity of the through line that makes it work," he said. "Otherwise you'd have people saying, 'Huh, what's going on?' It could get ugly."
For "The Limey," Mr. Soderbergh adopted a new way of shooting his scenes, which he retained on "Erin Brockovich." He watches through the camera while the scene is being shot. Many people think that's how all directors work, but they don't. There has been a growing distance between the director and the set, often with the director parked in a tent many yards away, watching the proceedings on video monitors. Mr. Soderbergh said he had tried that approach and thought it was counterproductive.
"I want to look through the camera because it is bringing me as close to the movie as is humanly possible," he said. "It's literally like seeing the film while you are shooting. And I truly believe that the energy of the set needs to be directed to where the camera is pointing, not diffused between the set and some tent nearby."
Mr. Stamp said the technique had an extraordinary effect on his performance. "Steven could sometimes whisper directions to me while we were in the middle of a scene, while I was still in the moment," he said. "It was so intimate."
 
Happy Indeed
Steve Zahn, who appeared in Mr. Soderbergh's "Out of Sight," was also at the Toronto festival, as he had been at the Sundance festival earlier in the year, promoting his latest comedy, Mark Illsley's "Happy, Texas" (review on page 25). In the film he plays a supremely dimwitted convict who is forced to pose as a beauty pageant coordinator in a small Texas town.
The film emerged as one of the favorites at Sundance in January, but there was some grumbling about how Mr. Zahn (above) and his co-star, Jeremy Northam, were cast as straight guys pretending to be gay.
"You know how it is when you're meeting a new director, sometimes you try to test each other," Mr. Zahn said. "But in this case we hit it off immediately, and we agreed that we should not play these characters as over-the-top or flamboyant when they're pretending to be gay."
Ten minutes have been trimmed from the film and some extra looping of dialogue added since Sundance, Mr. Zahn said, but it was mostly little bits and pieces lost and additions for clarity.
Mr. Zahn said he was drawn to "Happy, Texas" by the richness of the comedy, even down to the smallest roles.
"Too many people are doing movies just to do movies," he said. "But here was a case where people were doing it because they really thought it was a good movie. You know, it's become a pastime for Americans to make fun of people, to laugh at people. A lot of the comedy now is about making fun of someone. I loved this because it wasn't like that. It was laughing at something that's a real story. You'd be surprised how rarely you see scripts like that."

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
A Small Hockey Town Takes on the Big Guys

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
When it comes to capturing the bone-crunching, high-velocity world of sports, Hollywood has a surprisingly spotty record, often preferring to present the game as metaphor ("Field of Dreams") instead of diving into the bruising reality of the arena. But "Mystery, Alaska," an upbeat meat-and-potatoes movie that is a striking change in directorial style for Jay Roach, who oversaw the garish Austin Powers romps, conveys some of the thrill and ferocity of ice hockey while skillfully folding together multiple personal dramas.
Produced by David E. Kelley, the king of television drama ("L.A. Law," "The Practice," "Ally McBeal"), who wrote the screenplay with Sean O'Byrne, the movie is clearly a project dear to Mr. Kelley's heart. Twenty years ago, he was captain of Princeton's hockey team, and the screenplay includes enough technical jargon to demonstrate an insider's knowledge of the sport without clogging up the narrative. 
 "Mystery, Alaska" uses sport to explore the hardy psyche of a remote Alaskan town that lives and breathes hockey and that's pride and joy is its legendary pond hockey team. The movie has the look and feel of an unusually well-constructed television drama in which a dozen sharply drawn characters interact in ways that are fairly predictable without seeming too snugly formulaic. You can also feel the chill; the climactic game takes place in minus-10-degree weather. In an amusing satirical touch, Little Richard (of all people) opens the event with a rendition of the national anthem that is so slow that some of the waiting players worry that their bones will begin to freeze.
What sparks the drama is the return to Mystery of Charles Danner (Hank Azaria), a native son who forsook his hometown for New York City to become a television producer. Danner has come up with a promotional scheme to pit the locals against the New York Rangers in a nationally televised exhibition game to be broadcast live from Mystery. The show would be an economic boon to the town. Without actually demonizing Danner, the movie presents him as a shifty city slicker and the high-powered network personnel who descend on Mystery as blase media gypsies. One dreadful, pat and inaccurate marketing pitch proposed is to dub the Mystery team Eskimos on Ice.
The movie's moral and emotional grounding wire is Mystery's sheriff, John Biebe (Russell Crowe), a 13-year veteran of the team and local sports hero who is devastated to learn that he is being retired from the first string to make room for Stevie Weeks (Ryan Northcott), a naive eager beaver only half his age. Biebe is a terrific role for Mr. Crowe, whose Rock of Gibraltar machismo anchors the film in decent common-sense values. Biebe's demotion sends a shock through the town and through his marriage to Donna (Mary McCormack), who years ago dated Danner but chose to marry Biebe and live a very circumscribed life.
Other colorful characters include the town's Mayor, Scott Pitcher (Colm Meaney); Skank Marden (Ron Eldard), the team's resident stud who blithely cuckolds Pitcher; the local judge, Walter Burns (Burt Reynolds); his wife, Joanne (Judith Ivey); their hockey-playing son, Birdie (Scott Grimes), and their teen-age daughter, Marla (Rachel Wilson). Finally there is Bailey Pruitt (Maury Chaykin), the blustering hyper-emotional lawyer who travels all the way to New York to argue the team's case when the game is in danger of being canceled because of union problems.
What gives zest to a story that builds to a predictable David and Goliath confrontation on a pond (in which a Coca-Cola logo has been imprinted beneath the surface of the ice) is a screenplay that locates the characters' idiosyncrasies and a calm directorial style that respects their dignity even when they're under extreme stress. Where most films about small towns caught up in sports mania take a patronizing view of grown-ups living vicariously through their athletic children, "Mystery, Alaska" never questions the community's values. Without fawning over the players, the movie presents them as rugged, earthy embodiments of a healthy pioneer spirit that enables communities like Mystery to stay closely knit and proud.
"Mystery, Alaska" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has sexual situations and some strong language.
 
MYSTERY, ALASKA
 
Directed by Jay Roach; written by David E. Kelley and Sean O'Byrne; director of photography, Peter Deming; edited by Jon Poll; music by Carter Burwell; production designer, Rusty Smith; produced by Mr. Kelley and Howard Baldwin; released by Hollywood Pictures. HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
J. P. Morganto Take Korean Brokerage Stake

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 30

 BODY:
J. P. Morgan & Company agreed today to take a 10 percent stake in the SK Securities Company, settling a $380 million lawsuit and ending more than a year of legal wrangling with several Korean financial institutions over losses in derivative securities.
J. P. Morgan will invest $85 million in SK Securities through a share sale that is partly aimed at raising money to pay Morgan an unspecified settlement fee. 
 "This is a win-win arrangement," said Yoon Soon Han, general counsel of the SK Group, which controls the South Korean brokerage house. "SK Securities can normalize its business while J. P. Morgan recovers a considerable amount of losses as well as securing a business opportunity."
The agreement is intended to end legal disputes between Morgan and SK Securities, the Housing and Commercial Bank, the Daehan Investment Trust Company and the Korea Investment Trust Company. The only outstanding dispute for more than $100 million yet to be settled is with Boram Bank, which was taken over by Hana Bank in January.
"We are very pleased that we have reached a settlement which provides us with a chance to focus on future relations," said Shuri Fukunaga, a Morgan spokeswoman in Tokyo.
The American bank upgraded its presence in South Korea to a full branch last October in anticipation of a turnaround in the nation's economy, which is now emerging from its worst recession since the 1950's. South Korea's central bank expects the economy to grow about 8 percent this year after shrinking 5.8 percent last year.
As part of the settlement, J. P. Morgan signed another pact with SK Securities, under which the Wall Street investment bank will provide the Korean brokerage with risk advisory, training, research and other business assistance.
Morgan is the latest foreign investor to make a foray into the South Korean brokerage industry. Regent Pacific Group, a Hong Kong hedge fund, acquired the Daeyu Securities Company. And an Asian-Pacific arm of Hambrecht & Quist, the San Francisco investment bank that has agreed to be acquired by Chase Manhattan, became the largest shareholder in the Good Morning Securities Company, formerly known as Ssangyong Investment Securities.
Morgan's disputes with South Korean companies arose over who should be responsible for derivatives losses begun with the devaluation of the Thai baht in July 1997, an event that led to recessions in much of Asia.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Rise as Sellers Pause for Rest

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices were up for the first time in four days yesterday for several reasons.
Revised data on economic growth significantly eased investor concern that the Federal Reserve will raise short-term interest rates at Tuesday's monetary policy meeting. The bounce in prices was most likely a result of the oversold conditions in the market and an unwillingness among market participants to drive prices lower at this point. 
 Analysts said some window-dressing by portfolio managers at the end of the fiscal quarter was at work, spurring a little buying from Asian accounts overnight. The short maturities were firmer as market participants parked cash in them.
Despite yesterday's gains in stocks, there was still a flight to quality toward the Government bill market as many investors remained nervous and sought safe haven in the Treasuries market. Other analysts noted widespread declines in commodity prices, seen by some as barometers of inflationary pressures.
"Today looked more like a laundry list of excuses," said Kim Rupert, an economist with Standard & Poor's MMS, a market research firm in San Francisco. "But it's more the case that sellers are taking a breather, leaving buyers in charge today."
By late in the day, the 30-year bond was up 1 4/32 , to 101 5/32 , while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, stood at 6.04 percent, down from 6.12 percent on Wednesday. The bond yield is only slightly lower for the month of September.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Asset Management, said he believed that the Fed would leave monetary policy unchanged when the Federal Open Market Committee gathers for its October meeting on Tuesday.
Mr. Fine went on to say, however, that "at this juncture, a tightening at the November F.O.M.C. forum is still clearly on the table, with the ultimate decision a function of the extent of any economic deceleration, the path of the inflation indicators and the direction of equity prices during the intervening period."
Mr. Fine added: "A further sharp correction in the stock market could quickly produce an economic slowdown via its impact on consumer spending, which could well obviate the need for further Fed tightening over the near term, should it occur. However, recently released economic statistics are still suggesting a buoyant pace of economic growth."
He said second-quarter gross domestic product was revised downward slightly, to 1.6 percent, but all indications point to a noticeable rebound in growth of the gross domestic product during the third quarter. And, he said, August new-home sales were surprisingly strong, with the near-record pace certainly not indicative of an economic slackening.

LENGTH: 563 words

HEADLINE: China's Anniversary Party

 BODY:
The People's Republic of China, whose birth Mao Zedong triumphantly proclaimed from Tiananmen Square 50 years ago today, can claim some proud achievements. Ordinary Chinese citizens now enjoy higher standards of health, nutrition, education and personal comfort than at any previous time in the Middle Kingdom's long history. Beijing is also reclaiming its status as a great world power for the first time since foreign imperialists began imposing humiliating concessions on the Manchu emperors a century and a half ago.
But these gains have come at a terrible and continuing cost. Millions perished needlessly in the famines caused by Mao's erratic economic policies and millions more sacrificed their careers and ambitions to the fanaticism of the Cultural Revolution during the 1960's and 1970's. Virtually all the economic progress of the past half century has occurred since 1978, when Deng Xiaoping discarded the precepts of Maoist socialism, opened China's economy to the world and liberated the entrepreneurial energies of the Chinese people. 
 But neither Deng nor the current leader, President Jiang Zemin, has eased the suffocating political grip of Communist Party dictatorship. To this day, no public political dissent is tolerated in the People's Republic and those who openly challenge this arrangement are subjected to long prison terms under extremely harsh conditions. With party loyalists freed from public accountability, corruption flourishes, local officials abuse their authority and individual rights are regularly trampled.
Today's choreographed celebrations reflect the Chinese leadership's skewed priorities. They have been designed to showcase China's political uniformity, its military might and its ability to attract multinational executives. But it is a show of government power, not popular enthusiasm. While hundreds of thousands of party loyalists chant officially approved slogans, millions of Beijing's ordinary residents have been barricaded away from the festivities, potential dissidents are being closely watched and thousands of migrant workers have been shipped out of the city.
Despite the official self-congratulations, China faces serious problems. Its transition to a market economy remains incomplete. Banks are swamped with debt, and uneconomic state-owned enterprises drain resources needed for future growth. Behind the enforced political silence, there are ample signs of public cynicism about a Communist Party that claims no coherent ideology and clings ruthlessly to power simply for its own sake.
China also faces problems with the United States. Washington and Beijing have come a long way from the military confrontation of the Korean War and America's stubborn 30-year delay in diplomatically recognizing the Communist government. But relations continue to be troubled by Beijing's human rights abuses, accusations of Chinese nuclear espionage and meddling in American electoral campaigns, and tensions over Taiwan.
In the long run, the answers to many of China's problems lie in greater public accountability through wider democracy, from the lowest levels of village government to the highest rungs of power in Beijing. To maintain the political stability and economic prosperity it boasts of today, the People's Republic of China will have to find room for the unscripted voices of China's people. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: New Center Will Combat Computer Security Threats

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
The Treasury Department will announce today that the Federal Government and the financial services industry have established an information clearinghouse to combat threats to computer security and vulnerabilities in computer systems.
The center, which will be managed exclusively by private industry, will be known as the Financial Services Information Sharing and Analysis Center. It represents a second phase in the Clinton Administration's plan to create a nationwide system to combat cybercrime. 
 The Treasury system will rely on voluntary reports of incidents from banks and other financial institutions, in contrast to a centralized Federal Government surveillance system known as the Federal Intrusion Detection Network, or FIDNET, which is designed to use automated technology to track break-ins to Government computers.
Both systems are outgrowths of a classified Clinton Administration document known as Presidential Decision Directive 63, issued in May 1998. Its purpose is to develop systems to protect against attacks on the nation's computer networks.
However, a Federal plan that would effectively centralize FIDNET information and control inside the Federal Bureau of Investigation at the National Information Protection Center has drawn fire from civil liberties groups and from Congress. There are concerns that such a system monitoring all Government computers might create a de facto "desktop surveillance" network.
In contrast, the financial services clearinghouse plan developed by Treasury officials and private industry drew cautious praise from privacy groups.
"The governmental role is vastly scaled back, and it's not the central node," James X. Dempsey, staff counsel for the Center for Democracy and Technology, a Washington civil liberties group, said of the Treasury plan. "It shows you can move forward on infrastructure protection without sacrificing privacy and without a major role for the Government."
A Treasury official said last night in a telephone interview that the new organization was being created in response to the Presidential directive and that it was only the first of a number of similar information-sharing and analysis centers that would be developed for other industry sectors.
"As our military and civilian sectors go increasingly on line, it creates a new vulnerability," the Treasury official said. "It does make sense to have this sort of an information and an analysis center."
In addition to the financial services sector of the economy, Government agencies leading similar industry efforts include the Transportation Department and the Federal Communications Commission, the official said.
The new alert system began undergoing testing in June and will start formal operations in the near future. The system itself will be based at the Science Applications International Corporation, which serves as a contractor to a limited liability corporation that has been established by a founding group of banks, brokerage firms and financial services companies.
Member corporations will be able to submit vulnerability and intrusion alerts anonymously and in return will receive both real-time alerts of problems as well as summary information prepared by human analysts at the center.
So far, 16 corporations have signed letters of intent to participate in the clearinghouse, but that number is expected to expand significantly after the center begins formal operation.
An industry executive said that the members were eager to have the system functioning soon to help protect against potential vulnerabilities associated with the Year 2000 problem.
The clearinghouse will not feed real-time information on specific intrusion incidents to the National Information Protection Center, an industry executive said. He said, however, it was considering making summary information available.
The system will also receive and distribute real-time security alerts from a variety of sources, including the Government.

HEADLINE: Growth Slowed Sharply in the 2d Quarter

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
United States economic growth slowed sharply in the second quarter, to its weakest pace in four years, the Government said today, but booming August home sales showed it was already regaining power.
Gross domestic product advanced at a revised 1.6 percent annual rate in the April-June quarter instead of the 1.8 percent previously estimated -- the weakest three months since an increase of four-tenths of a percent in the second quarter of 1995. 
 Companies built up inventories at a much slower rate and the trade deficit soared, subtracting from national growth in the spring quarter.
Analysts said companies were restocking goods on hand for fear of supply problems if computer systems were disrupted by Year 2000 glitches, contributing to an anticipated rebound in growth in the third quarter that ended today and in the fourth quarter.
The gross domestic product report showed muted inflation and strong consumer spending, which was separately reflected in a later report showing August new-home sales climbed 2.9 percent, to the second fastest pace on record at 983,000 homes a year.
A third report from the Labor Department said new claims for unemployment pay were up 25,000 last week, to 299,000, because of the impact of Hurricane Floyd, which ravaged parts of the country earlier in the month.
Nonetheless, weekly claims have remained under 300,000 for the longest period in more than a quarter-century, a sign that jobs are ample.
In addition, the price component of the Chicago Purchasing Management Index jumped to 71 in September from 63.8 in August. The overall index fell to 53.8 in September from 56.1 in August, contrary to economists' forecasts for a slight rise.
The Chicago index's employment component also fell sharply in September, to 43.2 from the August reading of 50.3.
Analysts said the reports, among the final pieces of economic data that Federal Reserve policy makers will see before their meeting on Tuesday on interest-rate strategy, imply the central bank will keep rates steady.
"Our bet is that the Fed is not going to increase rates again next week," said Stan Dubinis of the National Association of Home Builders. "They're simply isn't enough evidence to justify their doing it."
Gross domestic product measures the output of goods and services within the nation's borders. It slowed steeply in the second quarter from a 4.3 percent rate in the first three months this year, but economists see no real threat to the steady expansion since the last recession in 1990-91.
In addition, jobs are plentiful and consumer confidence remains high. The gross domestic product report showed consumer spending grew at an upward revised 4.8 percent annual rate in the second quarter instead of the 4.6 percent estimated a month ago.
The first estimate of third-quarter economic performance will not be available for another month. The Commerce Department issues three estimates of quarterly gross domestic product. Thursday's report was the final one on the second quarter.
The revised second-quarter G.D.P. report showed inflation was even more dampened than previously thought.
Two key price measures -- the G.D.P. price index and the implicit price deflator -- each advanced at only a 1.3 percent rate instead of the 1.5 percent reported a month ago. That was down from 1.6 percent for each indicator in the first quarter.
Businesses increased inventories at a $7.4 billion annual rate in the second quarter, less than the $12.1 billion rate estimated a month earlier and far below the first quarter's $38.7 billion rate of inventory-building.

HEADLINE: U.S. Resolves A Dispute With Russia On Computers

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: SAROV, Russia, Sept. 30

 BODY:
The United States and Russia have quietly resolved a long-simmering dispute over the illegal sale of sophisticated I.B.M. computers to Russia's leading nuclear weapons lab, American officials said today.
In the process both sides have helped open to cyberspace what was once one of the most secret installations of the Soviet Union. 
 On Friday the 16 computers, now fully licensed and operational, will be on display as part of the "open computing center" that the American, Energy Secretary, Bill Richardson, is to inaugurate at the lab that developed Russia's hydrogen bomb.
The center is a joint project of the Energy Department and Minatom, the Russian Ministry of Atomic Energy, to which Washington contributed $2.3 million. It is intended to help find jobs outside the weapons industry for thousands of scientists, engineers and technicians at this remote nuclear city and its premier lab.
In quiet talks for more than two years Washington had insisted that the computers, which I.B.M. sold to Russia in 1996 without the required export license, either be returned or openly dedicated to nonweapons work. Russia initially refused, but earlier this year, negotiators agreed that the computers would be incorporated into the computer center, which is expected to create 80 technology jobs in its first year and as many as 650 in the next five years.
The center is one of five projects planned here under the Nuclear Cities Initiative, which Mr. Richardson began last year. It is aimed at converting Russia's 10 closed nuclear cities to peaceful work. But Congress severely cut the Administration's request earlier this week, granting the ambitious undertaking only $7 million of the $30 million sought.
Mr. Richardson defended the initiative in an interview, saying he hoped to use money from other weapons conversion programs to help scientists here and at Snezhinsk and Zheleznogorsk, two other nuclear cities, to convert to peaceful work. "We are all concerned that scientists might be forced by economic necessity to seek employment in rogue states or among terrorists," he said.
Sarov, some 250 miles southeast of Moscow, is the Russian equivalent of Los Alamos, where America's nuclear bombs were designed. But in addition to designing bombs, this complex, roughly the size of Washington, D.C., still engineers, fabricates and assembles nuclear weapons warheads and components.
As part of the Soviet Union's effort to mimic the Manhattan Project, Stalin established a nuclear complex here in 1946 and closed the city. It takes its name from a monastery held sacred by the Russian Orthodox for its link to one of the most revered Russian saints, Seraphim of Sarov.
The walled monastery became the site of the first Soviet nuclear program under Stalin. The remote city was renamed Arzamas-16, which appeared on no Soviet maps. Not until 1990 did the Soviets acknowledge its existence. Russia restored the city's historic name in 1995.
Rady Ilkayev, director of the Russian lab and a prominent physicist, talked today about the institute's 30,000 employees, and their struggle to survive the downsizing of the nuclear weapons industry in this now impoverished city of 80,000. Dr. Ilkayev said the institute's staff had shrunk almost in half, to 18,000 employees from 30,000. Although the institute once controlled virtually all of the city's vital infrastructure, he said that 40 percent of Sarov's transport, 90 percent of its medical infrastructure and 70 percent of its sports arenas had now been transferred to the city government.
Fifteen percent of the lab's employees now work in the civilian sector; Dr. Ilkayev said he hoped to increase that to 29 percent by 2002.
Noting that the United States provides some 86 percent of the $8 million that the institute receives each year in aid from foreign governments and labs, Dr. Ilkayev called the United States his main partner. He said that American support had helped "prevent critical leakage" of key scientists with nuclear weapons expertise. He estimated that his institute would need $40 million over three years to restructure the lab. With Russian bank interest rates exceeding 50 percent, raising that amount of investment capital domestically is impossible, he said.
Russia had evaded American export laws by buying the I.B.M. computers in 1996 through Moscow-based middlemen. I.B.M. installed them here. Though a Federal grand jury investigated the transfer, no charges were brought against I.B.M.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Brazil's Efforts on Budget Imperiled by Court Rulings

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 30

 BODY:
The country's highest court invalidated two important tax increases today in surprise rulings that could hurt the Government's efforts to narrow the budget deficit. The rulings unnerved investors and stocks tumbled nearly 3 percent.
The tax increases -- on the salaries and pensions of public employees -- were challenged by civil servants, and the Supreme Federal Tribunal sided with them in both cases. 
 The court unanimously upheld a lower court's finding that one tax, which varies from 11 percent to 25 percent for Brazil's 694,000 retired civil servants depending on the size of their pensions, was illegal.
A second ruling found that increased taxes on the salaries of 712,000 acting Government workers were unconstitutional. Many more civil servants on the state and municipal levels are affected by the rulings.
The decisions are a blow to President Fernando Henrique Cardoso's efforts to exert more fiscal discipline in Latin America's largest economy, which has struggled to recover from a currency crisis in January that led to a rescue package by the International Monetary Fund.
Mr. Cardoso's administration has been trying to narrow a gaping budget deficit that corresponds to 12 percent of the nation's gross domestic product. Pension spending, payroll outlays and interest payments on Government bonds are the main reasons for the deficit.
"This shows that one branch of the Government is more concerned with preserving the privileges of the civil service as it sees fit rather than insuring the long-term health of the economy," said Marcelo Allain, the chief economist at Banco Inter American Express.
Analysts estimated that the decision would cost the Government 3.1 billion reais, or $1.6 billion, in lost taxes next year.
Stocks here plunged after the rulings, with the Bovespa index for the Sao Paulo stock exchange ending down 2.9 percent. The Brazilian real also weakened nearly 1 percent, and its exchange rate slid to a one-month low of 1.935 to the dollar.
"It makes me wonder about Brazil's ability to get serious," said Masaru Nakayasu, an economist here with Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi.

Pledge by Ecuador
 WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- Ecuador promised the International Monetary Fund today that it would take austerity measures by December as it struggled to reorganize its private-sector debt. The Government pledge came in return for an I.M.F. $350 million standby loan in the next 18 months.
 The agreement will let Ecuador begin talks to revamp its $6 billion in Brady bonds with private creditors in New York.

HEADLINE: University Stands Firm In Using Race In Admissions

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Disregarding the strongly worded advice of a Federal judge, the University of Georgia announced today that it would continue to use race as a factor in admitting up to 20 percent of its freshman class.
The announcement by the university president, Michael F. Adams, on an issue that has been the subject of intense debate for months, puts the school on a collision course with B. Avant Edenfield, the Federal District Court judge who has been hearing a series of challenges to the university's admissions policy. In a nonbinding opinion attached to a related ruling in July, Judge Edenfield said the university "cannot constitutionally justify" the use of race in admissions. 
 Because at least one new court case challenging the policy has already been assigned to Judge Edenfield, it is likely that he will have a fresh opportunity to issue a formal ruling against the school soon. But Mr. Adams made it clear that the university was reluctantly willing to accept a prolonged legal fight and a series of appeals to preserve the diversity of the student body.
"I believe that all of us have a responsibility to deal with the legacy of segregation as an issue in both academe and government," Mr. Adams said, in a speech that received a standing ovation from the University Council, an advisory body of faculty members, administrators and students. "My commitment to providing opportunity to all is fundamental, and under my leadership the University of Georgia will remain committed to this basic right."
In an increasingly conservative legal climate, when other schools have been backing away from their affirmative action policies, today's decision makes the University of Georgia one of the most prominent schools to voice full-throated support for racial preferences, particularly in the South. Hoping to banish the memory of the school's all-white past, most of the state's establishment has supported the admissions policy, including Gov. Roy Barnes and even Eric Johnson, the Republican minority leader of the State Senate.
"Those who argue that the only fair method is a statistical ranking of applicants' academic records miss an important point," Mr. Adams said. "True fairness also includes a professional assessment of unique family situations, the schools the student has attended, the community he or she came from and whether applicants had to overcome economic hardships to build a record of academic achievement."
Most students are admitted to the university without any consideration of race. Eighty percent to 90 percent of the members of each incoming class are admitted solely on the basis of their test scores and high school grades. The remaining 10 percent to 20 percent can have a slightly lower academic record, but their chances are better if they are nonwhite, or are the child of an alumnus, or the first in a family to attend college, or if they have unusual talents and civic accomplishments.
Despite the policy, only about 6 percent of this year's freshman class of 4,200 students is African-American, compared with 30 percent of the state population. About 15 percent of the class is nonwhite. But even this modest use of race as a factor was enough to prompt a lawsuit from A. Lee Parks Jr., an Atlanta lawyer who often represents clients trying to end affirmative action programs. Mr. Parks today accused Mr. Adams of caving in to pressure from faculty members.
"They had a wonderful opportunity to base their admissions on socio-economic factors that really demonstrated need, but instead they've taken the same old road," Mr. Parks said. "We'll be seeking an immediate temporary injunction against this policy, and now the litigation will come to a final head."
University officials, who clearly do not want black enrollment to drop, are now taking a firm stand on the fairly shaky foundation of the 1978 Bakke decision by the United States Supreme Court, which ruled that race could be one factor used in admitting students, as long as a quota system was not employed.
"Obviously the legal landscape has become uncertain and confusing since then," said Dan T. Coenen, a constitutional law professor at the university's law school. "But until the Supreme Court speaks again, it's still the law of the land, and this admissions policy is entirely acceptable."
Mr. Adams made it clear in an interview today that a ruling by the High Court would be welcome.
"It's an unsettled legal area," he said, "and we might all be better served in the long term if it could be made more clear."

HEADLINE: Fund Adviser Is Indicted In $3 Billion Fraud Case

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Martin A. Armstrong, the investment adviser and chairman of Princeton Economics International, was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges that he defrauded foreign investors in connection with the sale of $3 billion in securities issued by Princeton.
Mr. Armstrong, who was also chairman of Cresvale International Ltd., a brokerage firm based in Hong Kong, was charged with conspiracy and securities fraud September 13. He surrendered to authorities and was released on a $5 million bond, co-signed by his two children and his mother. 
 Mary Jo White, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, unsealed the indictment yesterday.
Mr. Armstrong denied the charges, telling Bloomberg News, "They are absolutely false, dead false."
Federal prosecutors say Mr. Armstrong lured Japanese institutional investors into a scheme on the strength of his glowing, but false, securities trading record. A Cresvale Web site stated that Princeton Economics, of Princeton, N.J., had generated a 20.51 percent average annual return in 1998.
Investors were promised that Mr. Armstrong would use their funds to trade currencies, bonds and derivatives and that they would receive returns of at least 4 percent and in many cases much more. Between 1996 and August 1999, Mr. Armstrong took in approximately $3 billion selling so-called Princeton notes.
But prosecutors contend that instead of generating returns, Mr. Armstrong lost aboout $368 million between November 1997 and August 1999. To conceal the losses from his investors, prosecutors say, Mr. Armstrong used funds from new investors to repay those who had invested earlier. He also lied to investors about their accounts' values, prosecutors said.
According to the indictment, between March 1998 and August 1999, more than $750 million went into Mr. Armstrong's trading account at the Republic Securities Corporation, a subsidiary of the Republic New York Corporation, a bank holding company. At the same time, $925 million was transferred out of the account to various bank accounts around the world, including those relating to Princeton Economics, Cresvale International and Mr. Armstrong.
Although the indictment does not detail his investments, Mr. Armstrong was known to be bullish on the United States dollar. But the dollar has been weak against the Japanese yen this year, hurting Mr. Armstrong two ways. In addition to betting on the dollar in his trades, he had promised to pay his investors back their principal and interest in yen. As the yen increased in value against the dollar, Mr. Armstrong's i.o.u.'s got much more expensive.
As of Aug. 31, Mr. Armstrong owed investors about $1 billion, but the value of his trading account was approximately $46 million.

HEADLINE: Fed Is Now Expected to Leave Rates Unchanged

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
The economy is still growing at a rapid clip. Commodity prices are rising. With unemployment low, workers are demanding and getting higher wages.
But for every signal suggesting that inflation might be lurking just over the horizon, there are others indicating that price increases are well under control and that whatever inflationary pressures might be building will dissipate in coming months. 
 As a result, the Federal Reserve is likely to leave interest rates unchanged when its policy committee meets on Tuesday, analysts and economists said.
Fed officials have hinted as much in their public statements during the last few weeks, saying that they see prices as stable and the economy's ability to grow without inflation benefiting from huge investments in productivity-enhancing technology.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, typically gives markets a clear warning when he is seriously considering a rate increase, but in a speech tonight in Minnesota, he did not mention current economic conditions or monetary policy. Instead, he warned about the dangers of trade protectionism.
Less clear is whether the Fed will feel compelled to nudge rates up at its subsequent meeting, in mid-November. If the economy does not show clear signs of cooling off somewhat in the next six weeks, analysts said, there is a good chance that the central bank will nudge its benchmark rate up by a quarter of a percentage point by the end of the year. The clearest clue to the Fed's intentions will be whether it adopts a formal tilt toward higher rates at its meeting next week.
"Given their rhetoric of late, the Fed is going to stay on hold at the Oct. 5 meeting," said Paul L. Kasriel, an economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "There is a distinct possibility that they could issue a directive biased toward tightening, which would put us on a rate-hike watch for the Nov. 16 meeting."
The Fed has raised rates twice this year in quarter-point increments, most recently on Aug. 24 when it increased its Federal funds target rate to 5.25 percent. At the same time, the central bank said inflation risks had been markedly diminished, a sign of its confidence that growth would slow to a noninflationary pace.
The Commerce Department said today that the economy grew at a revised annual rate of 1.6 percent in the second quarter, down from 4.3 percent in the first quarter. The Government had previously estimated growth at 1.8 percent in the second quarter.
Subsequently, though, growth has rebounded considerably, and most economists now forecast that the economy expanded about 4 percent in the quarter that ended today and will maintain something close to that pace for the rest of the year.
"That's maybe a little more rapid than the Fed wants, but there are some indications that things are slowing down a bit," said Stephen D. Slifer, an economist at Lehman Brothers in New York.
Sales of new homes rose 2.9 percent in August, the Commerce Department said today. But other interest-rate-sensitive activity suggests that the general upward trend in rates during the last several months is starting to work its way through the economy. Mortgage refinancing, for example, which has put more cash in the pockets of many consumers, has slowed substantially.
The downturn in the stock market is also likely to diminish any fears among Fed officials that the economy is overheating.
But the strongest case for holding rates steady may be that there are almost no signs of consumer price inflation. Core inflation -- excluding the volatile energy and food prices -- rose just 1.9 percent in the last year.
"If that isn't price stability, I don't know what is," William J. McDonough, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, told reporters last week.
With inflation so well behaved, Fed officials speak more openly about the possibility that their traditional models for predicting inflation are no longer worth much. As a result, they seem less inclined to raise rates before they are sure that inflation threatens the long expansion.
"Suppose, like now, we're uncertain about the underlying model of the economy," Robert T. Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said in a speech on Monday. "In that case, pre-emptive policy can lead to the wrong action. When there's a high degree of uncertainty about forecasts, it could be best for policy to be more cautious -- in the extreme, to wait until inflation actually starts to rise before acting to tighten."
Still, there are enough signs of persistently strong demand and inflation-warning signals that the Fed is sure to remain vigilant in coming months.
Orders for durable goods unexpectedly rose again in August after a big surge in July. Consumer confidence, while dipping, remains high, and job creation remains strong even as the supply of available workers is shrinking.
Prices for oil and other commodities are rising. Demand for American goods from abroad is picking up, and the dollar's long rally appears to be coming to an end, creating the risk of higher import prices.
"We're seeing a strong economic performance, probably stronger than most at the Fed think is sustainable," said Kenneth T. Mayland, an economist at Keycorp in Cleveland. "More and more evidence is coming in that there has been a change in the inflation environment."
For much of this year, economists speculated that the Fed would be unlikely to raise interest rates during the last two months of 1999 because of fears that the computer problems associated with the end of the century might wreak havoc with the economy.
But as Government officials and corporate executives have grown more confident that the United States will escape any serious problems, analysts have changed their minds and now think the Fed will be willing to tighten policy in November if the economic data justify higher rates.
"The Y2K situation is going so smoothly now that it's much less of a constraint on Nov. 16 policy action if deemed necessary," Mr. Mayland said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Underwriting of Stock and Bond Issues Slowed in September

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
So much for the post-Labor Day rush on Wall Street.
The primary business of investment banks -- underwriting sales of stocks and bonds -- is slowing in the second half of 1999, not accelerating as some bankers and traders had predicted. Securities firms and banks issued $473 billion of stocks and bonds in the third quarter, a 3.5 percent increase from $456.8 billion in the third quarter of 1998, but a marked decline from the first two quarters of 1999, according to Thomson Financial Securities Data. 
 September had been expected by some to be an especially busy month as corporations hurried to sell bonds before fears about Year 2000 complications scared off investors and drove up borrowing costs. But that pickup did not occur; rather, the quarter ended on a downbeat, depressed by concerns about rising interest rates.
"The most remarkable thing was the continued weak state of the corporate bond market, despite the very strong fundamentals," said Jeff Chandler, a managing director at Merrill Lynch & Company. "A lot of borrowers are sitting back and demonstrating that they do have the luxury of time and can sit back and wait until next year if they want to."
Worries that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates again next week continued to hang over the market, Wall Street executives said. But if the Fed makes no change and sets off a rally in bond prices, the anticipated rush to tap investors for loans before year-end could materialize in October, they said.
Otherwise, said Mark Seigel, a managing director at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, "things will slow down as we approach year-end." In the wake of the financial crises that roiled the bond markets in the last two years, Mr. Seigel said, investors have shown a decided preference for bonds issued in large amounts by companies with strong credit ratings, like the $8.6 billion offering by the Ford Motor Company in early July.
Riskier high-yield bonds, known as junk bonds on Wall Street, were a much harder sell. Junk bond issuance was just $2.2 billion in September, the lowest total since July 1995, said Richard Peterson, an analyst at Securities Data.
Merrill Lynch again led all securities firms in total underwriting volume. In the third quarter, Merrill Lynch handled about 17 percent of all stock and bond volume. Citigroup's Salomon Smith Barney unit ranked second, followed in order by Goldman Sachs Group, Credit Suisse First Boston and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
Those rankings are important to investment bankers because they use them as weapons in battles for underwriting assignments. But, in the end, the most important measure is the fees those assignments generate because some deals are much more lucrative than others.
In general, investment banks earn fatter fees from stock issues, especially companies' first-time offerings, than from bond issues. That is why firms that have strong franchises in distributing stock tend to rake in more fees.
Goldman, Sachs took in $339 million in disclosed fees in the third quarter, or about 15 percent of the industry total of $2.3 billion, according to Securities Data. That put Goldman ahead of Merrill Lynch, which took in $284 million in disclosed fees. Morgan Stanley Dean Witter ranked third, with $262 million.
Fee revenue correlates closely with how the firms stacked up in stock underwriting, which held up better in the quarter than did the bond business. Firms handled about $27 billion in new stock in the quarter, more than double the $13.7 billion a year before, but well below the $46.7 billion in the second quarter of 1999, which was full of initial public offerings by Internet companies.
Of the 147 initial offerings in the quarter, 71 of them, or nearly half, came in the Internet sector, Mr. Peterson said.
"Clearly, there is an appetite for new ideas and new issues and it's particularly strong in technology and communications," said Tom Tuft, co-head of equity capital markets at Goldman, Sachs. "A lot of deals are getting done despite the fact that there's been a lot of choppiness in the market."
Mr. Tuft said he expected a full calendar of stock offerings in October and November, then a slower-than-normal December. "Most people are focused on getting deals done before Thanksgiving," he said.
Merger and acquisition activity rose by 43 percent, to $766 billion in the third quarter, from $535 billion a year earlier, based on the value of the announced deals. Morgan Stanley Dean Witter ranked as the leading adviser, ahead of Goldman, Sachs. Most of the action occurred in Europe, home of the targets in four of the five biggest deals announced. Morgan Stanley was also the leading adviser in United States deals, which declined 12 percent to $315 billion, from $358 billion a year before.

HEADLINE: City Union Is Offered Transit and Domestic Partner Benefits

BYLINE: By C. J. CHIVERS 

 BODY:
The city has reached a tentative agreement with the largest municipal union to offer city workers a break on mass transit fares and to extend medical-leave benefits to unwed workers caring for domestic partners.
The deal with District Council 37, which covers working conditions but not salaries, would also increase reimbursements for work-related expenses. The agreement was announced yesterday by the Council and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. 
 While the proposed contract covers a variety of benefits, James F. Hanley, the city's Commissioner of Labor Relations, said its most significant element was the creation of the mass transit commuting incentive.
Known as Transitchek, the program is a Federal tax break that would allow city employees to buy monthly Metrocards with their pretax income, reducing their commuting expenses at no cost to the city. Mr. Hanley said the benefit could be in place by early next year.
"It's good for mass transit, it's good for the environment and it's great for employees, especially lower-paid employees," Mr. Hanley said.
The proposed agreement, which was reached on Wednesday, would also eliminate a disparity in benefits between married and unmarried employees. City workers already have medical coverage for domestic partners, but they have no provision to receive leave to tend to ailing domestic partners. The agreement would change that, giving the unmarried workers the same benefits their married peers have.
Salaries are covered by separate economic contracts, but this agreement would grant a number of nonsalary increases in certain payments. For instance, it would increase mileage allowances from 25 to 28 cents a mile, increase the overtime meal allowances by 75 cents and raise the limit on overtime pay to $54,549 from $45,805 a year.
"We believe we have put together a package that will mean real improvements in the working conditions and daily lives of our members," said Lee Saunders, the trustee who runs District Council 37.
District Council 37 is the largest bargaining unit representing city workers. If ratified, the agreement would cover roughly 100,000 of the union's members. Both Mr. Hanley and Christopher Policano, a council spokesman, said they expected the agreement to be ratified by the end of the year.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Major Stock Gauges Finish 3d Quarter on Positive Note
Stocks ended the third quarter on a positive note, as a rally in the bond market helped to push major market indexes higher. They also benefited as mutual fund managers bought shares of companies that have done well to make end-of-quarter reports look better to their investors. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average finished the quarter at 10,336.95, after rising 123.47 points, or 1.21 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased by 14.34 points, to 1,282.71, and the Nasdaq composite index jumped 15.89 points, to 2,746.16. Page C8.
 
Underwriting by investment banks slowed in the third quarter. Securities firms and banks issued $473 billion of stocks and bonds, a 3.5 percent increase from $456.8 billion in the third quarter of 1998, but a marked decline from the first two quarters of 1999. C8.
 
Brazil's Tax Increases Struck Down
Brazil's highest court invalidated two tax increases in surprise rulings that could hurt the Government's efforts to narrow the budget deficit. The rulings sent the stock market tumbling nearly 3 percent. C4.
 
Health Insurers' Stocks Fall
Shares of major health insurers, including Aetna, which was down $10.4375, to $49.25, declined amid reports that trial lawyers were preparing lawsuits on behalf of managed care patients. Lawyers who gained high profiles in tobacco litigation and other cases are preparing to sue managed care companies and seek class-action status after some large legal judgments against the insurers. C5.
 
Princeton Economics Head Indicted
Martin A. Armstrong, the investment adviser who was chairman of Princeton Economics International, was indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges that he defrauded foreign investors in connection with the sale of $3 billion in securities issued by Princeton. C2.
 
Census Bureau Is Upbeat on Wages
Rising incomes, lifted by a strong economy, brought 1.1 million poor Americans out of poverty last year. The Census Bureau said the typical American household finally regained in 1998 the income it had lost since 1989 to recession, wage freezes, downsizing and the competition of foreign workers. A20.
 
Olivetti Chief Defends Realignment
Roberto Colaninno, the chief executive of Olivetti, will meet with institutional investors next week in an effort to halt a flight of investment capital from the Italian telecommunications giant. The market damage has been caused by his decision to strip Telecom Italia of its most valued asset, its cellular phone unit, Telecom Italia Mobile, and transfer it to Tecnost, the subsidiary he used to win control of Telecom Italia. C4.
 
Deutsche Bank in Japanese Venture
Deutsche Bank teamed up with Sakura Bank of Japan in an effort to take advantage of Japan's liberalized market for underwriting bond and stock offerings. C4.
 
Future of Excite@Home Unclear
The future of Excite@Home is unclear after the company canceled a meeting to vote on separating its cable modem venture from its Internet portal service. C2.
 
J. P. Morgan Settles Korean Suit
J. P. Morgan agreed to take a 10 percent stake in SK Securities, a South Korean brokerage house, settling a $380 million lawsuit and ending a dispute with several Korean institutions over losses in derivative securities. C4.

HEADLINE: A Mighty Port's Final Call;
Bayonne Army Terminal Closes, Its Future in Doubt

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

DATELINE: BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 30

 BODY:
An era ended today, not with a bang but with a mournful happy hour at Kapps Bar and Grill on Broadway.
And then they turned out the lights for good at the United States Army's Military Ocean Terminal in Bayonne, once the biggest employer in town, now a memory of another era in a working-class town with a better sense of its past than its future. 
 "I'm going to cry again," said Judy Barbito, over the Sinatra, Tony Bennett and Patsy Cline songs at Kapps, which welcomed generations of workers from the Army installation in its earlier guise as Patsy's. "When I was driving out of the base, the tears were coming down. My husband said, 'Why are you crying?' and I told him, 'You don't realize this is the last time we're going to drive out of here.' "
Of course, they had known for years this day was coming. As the end of the cold war has lessened the need for a large military force, the Federal Government has been closing military installations all over the world. In 1995, it decided to close this one, a base whose main purpose was to help transport military equipment to wherever it was needed, by boat, aircraft or train.
"We moved everything from toothbrushes to tanks," said J. Craig Hawley, garrison manager, who has worked at the base for 25 years.
Bayonne, a peninsula city of 61,000, was a natural for the job. There are views of water from almost anywhere -- Upper New York Bay to the east, Newark Bay to the west and the Kill Van Kull separating Bayonne from Staten Island.
The Bayonne military base was opened by the Navy during World War II, in 1942. By 1967, with use declining, the base was transferred to the Army. In 1996, the Army had 2,500 employees here, many of them civilians who lived in the area. Since then, employment had dwindled to the 200 jobs that were phased out today. Of the 2,500, some accepted transfers to other military bases and some retired, while the 200 or so who were last to go generally worked on finding new positions for the others.
"The town was really closely affiliated with the base," said Andrew Kopycinski, 29, who worked at the installation's personnel office. "You thought of one, and you thought of the other."
Mr. Kopycinski, who was born and raised in Bayonne, worked at the base for 12 years, starting as a summer hire. His father worked there, and his grandfather was based there during World War II.
Mayor Joseph V. Doria Jr., who also grew up here, said he remembered his parents bringing him onto the base for Armed Forces Day, when the Army, or the Navy before them, demonstrated their skills in the water or the air.
"It's a day of sadness as well as happiness, that we're moving onto new challenges," he said unconvincingly, as he stood at the base gates saying goodbye to the commanding officers for the last time.
At 437 acres, with a sweeping view of the Statue of Liberty and the Manhattan skyline, the base property is the largest piece of undeveloped land in New York Harbor. The military is turning over the property to the city, and a local redevelopment agency is to decide what the city will do with it, an issue that has been a reminder of the uncertain road ahead.
Under former Mayor Leonard P. Kiczek, the redevelopment agency had come up with a plan to build a stadium and amphitheater on the property, and eventually a hotel and other recreational facilities, with the main objective to give the people of Bayonne access to the harbor.
"It's a spot that's indescribable," said Mr. Kiczek, who also grew up in Bayonne. "It's the kind of place where any father whose daughter was going to get married would want her to have her wedding."
A consultant's report prepared for the agency said the plan would have created about 10,000 jobs.
But when Mayor Doria, who is also a Democratic State Assemblyman, defeated Mr. Kiczek, also a Democrat, in the last election, and took office in the spring of 1998, he appointed new members to the redevelopment agency and came up with a plan that devotes more of the peninsula to shipping and other commercial activities.
Mr. Kiczek, a former City Attorney, said he believed the new mayor came up with the plan, which would provide many fewer jobs, to please the leadership of the Bayonne local of International Longshoreman's Association, the union representing the stevedores and others who loaded and unloaded the ships for the Army. The I.L.A. is a strong political force in the city and supported Mr. Doria in the last election.
Mr. Doria appointed the president of the I.L.A., John Angelone, to the agency, but Mr. Angelone had to resign this summer when he and other union leaders were indicted for offering kickbacks to contractors.
Joe Ryan, Mr. Doria's press spokesman, said that Mr. Doria's plans were not influenced by his support from the union. Instead, he said, Mr. Doria's plan offered more full-time and better-paying jobs and was based on the idea that the property was developed as an ocean terminal and that it should remain that way. He also said Mr. Kiczek's job estimates included temporary positions, such as those in hotel construction.
But today, the future of the base property was not as important as the past many of these workers are leaving behind.
Several dozen of those who still worked at the base gathered at noon time at Kapps to reminisce, to laugh and finally to cry about a place that provided as much of a family connection as their own relatives.
"I worked here right out of school," said Ms. Barbito, who is 45 and graduated from Bayonne High School. "In those days, they gave you the civil service test right in the high school. If you passed it, you went to work here. If you didn't, you didn't."
Ms. Barbito stood with two of her girlfriends from high school who worked at the base for about as long as she had. They recalled the countless birthdays they celebrated together, either after work or at lunchtime at the many bars and restaurants that catered to base employees, like Rincon Spanish Restaurant, or Meditarraneo on Broadway. They talked about the base picnics where everyone brought their families.
"Am I going to miss it?" asked Millie Santiago, who worked here 20 years, as she started to cry. "I enjoy working here. I love to work here. I liked caring for all the people. That's what I'll miss the most -- the people.
Ms. Santiago said she and her husband, who recently retired from an auto body shop, will move to Puerto Rico, where she is from. But she will keep in touch with her former co-workers, whose parties she attended for holidays or their children's birthdays.
"It was like a family," she said, over the strains of Sinatra's "My Way" on the jukebox. "But this is it. It's over. It's over."

HEADLINE: Ford Planning To Spin Off Parts Division

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 30

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company plans to spin off its giant auto parts division directly to shareholders and give wage and job guarantees to the division's factory workers in a contract under negotiation with the United Automobile Workers union, people close to the matter said.
The future of the parts division has been a major problem for Ford as it tries to hammer out a new labor contract. The company had considered selling the unit, called Visteon Automotive Systems, to either the Lear Corporation or to Delphi Automotive Systems Inc., which was itself spun off in May from the General Motors Corporation, the people said. 
 But labor issues along with tax considerations have instead persuaded Ford to spin off Visteon, which had $17.8 billion in revenue last year.
On Tuesday night, G.M. reached tentative agreement with the United Automobile Workers union on a four-year contract that included annual raises of 3 percent a year on top of inflation adjustments, plus increased pension benefits and a $1,350 signing bonus. Delphi, with $28.5 billion in revenue and 48,000 U.A.W. workers, also reached an agreement Tuesday with the union on a separate labor contract with nearly identical terms.
Those agreements included a promise to allow Delphi workers who retire by the end of 1999 to be covered by G.M.'s pension plan, effectively a three-month extension of a promise given when Delphi was spun off to G.M. shareholders. After that point, they would be covered by a similar Delphi pension plan. The factory workers have lobbied for coverage under the parent company because they worry that the parts company may be less financially solid.
Now that Delphi has reached a deal with the union on how its workers will be treated, the union is expected to allow Ford to follow the same pattern for Visteon's 23,500 workers, according to a person close to the union, making a tax-free spinoff of Visteon to shareholders more attractive. After the spinoff, Visteon would agree to a four-year contract with the same wage, benefit and job protections in the Ford pact.
Labor contracts for the 400,000 factory workers at G.M., Ford and DaimlerChrysler were to expire Sept. 14, but have been extended as the union negotiates new contracts. DaimlerChrysler was the first to reach agreement, and the union has demanded that the other auto makers accept the pattern of wages and benefits laid out in the DaimlerChrysler contract.
Workers at Visteon factories had opposed a sale or spinoff, worrying that their wages and pensions would not be as stable at Visteon as they would be at Ford. In recent weeks, some of Visteon's salaried employees have sent E-mail messages to management, protesting plans to sell the unit to another auto parts maker, fearing that their jobs would be eliminated because of overlap with the buyer.
Senior company officials exploring the sale of Visteon ran into tax roadblocks. They could not devise favorable tax treatments for selling Visteon to another auto-parts maker, a person close to the planning said.
Ford had worried that an agreement attached to DaimlerChrysler's labor contract that was intended to limit asset sales would hinder Ford's ability to sell Visteon. Union and Ford officials said, however, that they expect the union to allow Ford to shed Visteon as long as it follows the pattern set by Delphi earlier this week.
Under those circumstances, a spinoff of Visteon seems appealingly simple to Ford. Union and company officials anticipate that they will agree on a labor contract covering Ford's 101,033 unionized workers as soon as the middle of next week.
While the labor situation is fluid, and Ford could always change its plans for Visteon if a buyer offered a higher price for it, a person close to the matter said, Ford expected to announce within a month its intention to spin off Visteon to shareholders.
Ford had been discussing a sale of Visteon to Lear since the summer, but the possibility of Delphi's buying Visteon had not been previously reported. In a surprising move, Richard Shoemaker, a union vice president in charge of relations with G.M., suggested in closed-door meetings that Delphi consider buying Visteon, the person said.
A Delphi spokesman, Peter Rowe, said today, "We've evaluated pieces of Visteon's business over the years, as we would any supplier." But he denied that discussions had gone beyond that point.
A Ford spokesman, Jim Cain, declined to discuss the company's plans for Visteon.
But Ford has told Wall Street analysts in the past that shedding Visteon would make sense only if the transaction was tax-free.
Analysts said antitrust concerns would have complicated, but probably not scuttled, the merger of any big parts companies by forcing the divestiture of certain product lines. Early last year, when the Federal-Mogul Corporation bought T & N P.L.C., of Britain, the Federal Trade Commission determined that the combined company had too high a share in the thin-wall engine bearing business, and forced Federal-Mogul to sell T & N's global engine-bearing business to the Dana Corporation.
"If Delphi bought Visteon, that's certainly a doable deal, but they might have a problem in climate control," said John A. Casesa, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, explaining that both Delphi and Visteon build lots of heating and air-conditioning units.
"But no one would care about Delphi owning their glass business," because Delphi does not have a big glass business, he said, speaking hypothetically.

HEADLINE: Tower to Rise Above Port Authority Terminal

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
In yet another indication that the search for increasingly rare development sites in Times Square is pushing westward, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey selected a developer yesterday to build a $500 million, 35-story office tower atop the bus terminal at 42d Street and Eighth Avenue.
Lawrence Ruben Company and Vornado Realty Trust plan to build the million-square-foot glass and steel tower, which would be known as 7 Times Square, over the north wing of the midtown terminal. The terminal and tower, as proposed, would be adorned with the large, splashy electronic signs that have become characteristic of Times Square. 
 Under a 99-year agreement with the Port Authority, the two companies would pay more than $110 million for the development rights over the bus terminal. That figure includes a $20 million renovation of the terminal's north wing intended to smooth the passage of more than 187,000 commuters a day. The final terms of the deal are still being worked out.
"We're looking forward to executing our vision for 7 Times Square," said Lawrence Ruben, whose company owns or manages 6 million square feet of space in New York, Boston and Washington. "I don't think we're changing the Times Square neighborhood so much as the changes in the area have allowed us to do this project."
The developers said they would begin construction after they obtained final approvals and a tenant for half the office space.
Ruben and Vornado were selected over two other developers, Larry Silverstein and George Klein, based on price and design, according to executives at the Port Authority. The Port Authority staff expects to conclude a final lease with the developers within 30 days.
"It would serve as the western gateway to 42d Street and Times Square," said Charles Gargano, vice chairman of the Port Authority. "I'm pleased that we're finally building above that garage."
Ten years ago, a new office tower on the west side of Eighth Avenue in what was known as Hell's Kitchen, would have been unimaginable. A recession had left many existing buildings with vacant space and Times Square was more known for prostitutes and peep shows than blue chip companies.
Since then, the Walt Disney Company, Viacom, Conde Nast Publications, Madame Tussaud's Wax Museum and others started moving into the neighborhood. And a surge in demand for office space has cut the midtown vacancy rate by two-thirds, to 6.6 percent, the lowest point in 18 years, according to Cushman & Wakefield, a commercial real estate broker. The average rent for prime office space in midtown has jumped to $48.40 a square foot, up from $34.97 in 1995.
Reuters, Ernst & Young, and Morgan Stanley are now building new towers in Times Square, while Bertelsmann AG and Bear Stearns are building elsewhere in midtown. Chase Bank, the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, Deutsche Bank, PriceWaterhouseCoopers and other companies are looking for new homes and do not have many places to consider.
Ruben and Vornado are hoping to lure tenants to what they say will be first-class office space above the terminal, second only to one in Tel Aviv as busiest bus station in the world. The developers also plan to build 80,000 square feet of retail space in the four-story terminal itself and modernize the transit points for commuters.
The tower would rise above the four-story north wing of the terminal, which was built in 1950. Two years ago, the Port Authority announced plans to sell the development rights above the terminal, which runs an annual operating deficit. Five developers submitted proposals, including plans for a hotel.
But as the office market improved, the Port Authority selected three finalists, each of whom proposed to build an office tower. The vast terminal site would allow a developer to build floors measuring 65,000 square feet, broad expanses that are attractive to financial companies.
"The large floor plates lend themselves to a financial user," said Bruce Mosler, executive vice president of Cushman & Wakefield, who is working with the developers. "The lack of alternatives makes it a very important project."
The Port Authority has also signed tentative deals with two other companies to build a driving range and golf center above the south wing of the midtown terminal, and a large multiplex movie theater over the bus terminal at the George Washington Bridge.
