HEADLINE: Campaign Retooled, but Gore Makes Usual Stops

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

 BODY:
On the first day of his retooled campaign, Vice President Al Gore spent a day much like any other. He addressed corporate officials in New York City, walked the streets of a depressed upstate town and returned to the city to meet with reporters and then financial contributors for his second fund-raiser in two days.
Yesterday's trip was Mr. Gore's first foray outside Washington after announcing plans on Wednesday to revitalize his Presidential campaign by moving his headquarters from Washington to Tennessee and by holding smaller, more intimate events that would, as he put it, get him closer to the people. 
 He repeated that theme yesterday morning, saying he would take his campaign "from K Street in Washington to the aisles of K-Mart in Nashville." Chris Lahane, his press secretary, said Mr. Gore did not mean to imply that he would be running a cut-rate campaign, only that he would be spending more time with "real" people and less time with Washington insiders.
But a sense of frugality was an important message to convey as it became clear that Mr. Gore had raised less money in the last three months and had less cash on hand than his sole Democratic challenger, former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey.
There was little yesterday to indicate that Mr. Gore had pared down his campaign, but he did try to break out from the trappings of the Vice Presidency, plunging in the crowds in midtown Manhattan and shaking hands, lingering, much like President Clinton. At one point, he grabbed a cellular phone from a bystander and said, "Hi, this is Al Gore" to the person on the other end of the line.
But Mr. Gore still traveled in a lengthy motorcade. And he made his comment about K-Mart on the 56th floor of a Park Avenue office tower to about 200 executives, a group that would probably be more comfortable in the offices of lobbyists on Washington's K Street than in a K-Mart.
For most of the day, except for his stroll around a couple of blocks of Amsterdam, N.Y., where he shook hands with unemployed residents in the shadow of a closed toy factory, Mr. Gore stuck to traditional venues and sounded traditional themes of universal child care, stronger public education and spreading economic prosperity throughout the country.
The formats that he chose generated little of the fanfare that often accompanies Presidential campaigns. That was especially true of his visit to Amsterdam, a town of old rug mills that were converted to making toys and then went out of business, where he met with residents and then led an hourlong forum on reviving depressed areas.
He stopped and chatted with residents who had come out on their front porches.
Albert Choat, 26, a laid-off worker from a nearby plant, said Mr. Gore earned his respect "because he talked to us." Dave Passafiume, 33, who is unemployed and finds Amsterdam "dead," was less enthusiastic. "I can't find a job," Mr. Passafiume said, adding that he thought few politicians could really make a difference.
Andrew M. Cuomo, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, accompanied Mr. Gore and announced grants of $300,000 to help Amsterdam. Mr. Cuomo said later that the purpose of the visit -- trying to spark economic revitalization -- did not lend itself to typical campaign excitement.
"This is a bad-news topic, the upstate economy," Mr. Cuomo said. "The basic message is, 'We have a real problem to deal with.' "
Those who met Mr. Gore were pleased nonetheless.
"He came right to us, and that makes a significant difference," said Elizabeth DeBella, 36, a nurse from nearby Schenectady.
Earlier in the day, the New Yorkers who met Mr. Gore had a good impression of him as well. Leon Wagner, an investment banker, saw him at the Sky Club on Park Avenue. "He is so much better in person," Mr. Wagner said.
"The reason that myself and friends are going to get behind the Vice President now is -- I work on Wall Street -- it's a little like getting behind a stock that's a little soft," Mr. Wagner said. "The perception is that Bradley is on an uptick, but the fact is the Vice President has experience. And frankly, I'm not willing to vote against the prosperity that we have."
At a fund-raiser in New York City, Mr. Gore drew about 300 people and raised $500,000.
Instead of focusing on issues, Mr. Gore talked about himself. Recalling the Vietnam War, in which he served after enlisting in the Army, Mr. Gore said: "I became completely disillusioned with America. I saw my country go into a long, dark tunnel called the Vietnam War, and I felt my country being torn apart by the seams."
He said he was ridiculed when he returned home and wore his uniform. "I felt hatred from my fellow Americans," Mr. Gore said.
His career in journalism, Mr. Gore said, helped him reconnect with what he called the "American spirit."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
Accident at Nuclear Plant Spews Radiation in Japan
An out-of-control chain reaction at a nuclear fuel plant near Tokyo released high levels of radiation into the air. Thirty-five people were exposed, three of them seriously injured, and 300,000 residents were ordered to stay indoors. Officials said the reaction was set off when workers accidentally poured more uranium than usual into a tank containing nitric acid. A1
 
Test Treaty May Go to a Vote

HEADLINE: Rising Incomes Lift 1.1 Million Out of Poverty

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Lifted by the strong economy, American households are climbing out of the income stagnation that has plagued them for years.
Rising incomes brought 1.1 million poor Americans out of poverty last year, and the percentage of people still below the official poverty line fell to the lowest level since 1989, the Census Bureau reported today. But the Bureau's annual report on trends in American wages contained some troubling news as well. 
 Although household income is at its highest level since the 1980's, income inequality remains unyielding. And among blacks, incomes failed to rise and the poverty rate failed to fall, as both had in 1997, though blacks held on to their gains from the boom that began four years ago.
But the new Census data suggested that the strong economy and the lowest unemployment rate in 30 years have played big roles in improving the lot of millions of American households.
"You raise wages in the short run by tightening the labor market, but that has its limits," said Frank Levy, a labor economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "You cannot make the unemployment rate much lower than it already is, and if wages are to continue to rise, that depends on the productivity of workers and their bargaining clout with management."
The income of the median household, meaning that half the nation's households earn more and half less, recovered the ground that had been lost in the 1990's, and a bit more. The median rose by 3.5 percent, the biggest jump in 13 years, to $38,885, finally edging past the 1989 figure of $37,997, adjusted for inflation. Households above and below the median enjoyed roughly similar increases.
The most troubling aspect of the Census Bureau report concerned income inequality, which has been resistant to the economic boom.
Although incomes rose last year for most households, the gaps between the rich and the poor, and between the rich and middle-income Americans, have failed to narrow in the prosperous late 1990's. And 1998 was no exception.
A high-end household, with an annual income of $133,000, for example, still earned eight times more than a family at the poverty line in 1998 of $16,655 for a four-person household. That has been the ratio since 1993.
But President Clinton saw a glass half full in the failure to shrink income inequality. Noting that the gaps had widened during the economic expansion of the 1980's, he argued that economic growth in the 1990's had been powerful enough to halt the process.
"Finally we have stemmed the tide of rising inequality," Mr. Clinton said, "and this new report documents the strong income growth among all groups of people."
Others are less sanguine. After six years of recession or weak expansion, they note, a period of unusually strong economic growth kicked in four years ago. Unemployment, at 4.5 percent last year, was at its lowest level in decades. Wages have risen for tens of millions of Americans, even after allowing for inflation. The economy is indeed lifting many boats, but a rising economy, the critics argue, has not yet reduced income inequality.
"If the strongest economy in 30 years is unable to ameliorate this serious economic and social problem, there is a strong rationale for public policy that addresses these concerns," said Jared Bernstein, a labor economist at the Economic Policy Institute, which favors a higher minimum wage and laws that would strengthen labor unions.
Congress is considering a proposal to raise the minimum wage to $6.15 an hour in two annual installments of 50 cents each. Administration officials argued today that the earned-income tax credit, by rebating money to low-income households, had played a role in reducing poverty and preventing the income gap from widening. Citing this view, President Clinton criticized Republicans today for a proposal now before Congress to defer some of those tax rebates.
The Census report showed that for the third year since 1994, more than a million Americans rose above the official poverty line. The percentage of the population still in poverty fell to 12.7 percent, or 34.5 million people, from 13.3 percent, the lowest level since 1989. The rate among blacks, 26.1 percent, is the lowest level on record, though it is still a striking 2.5 times greater than the rate for whites. But for the first time since 1993, there was no noticeable change from the previous year. Among Hispanics, on the other hand, the poverty rate dropped by nearly 1.5 percentage points, to 25.6 percent.
The steady rise in income in the late 1990's has been due in part to Americans' working longer hours. But in 1998 time spent on the job leveled off at 3,149 hours a year -- roughly 60 a week -- barely changed from the 3,139 hours in 1997, according to an analysis of the Census data by the Economic Policy Institute.
But other comparisons made the 1998 numbers seem less impressive. The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities pointed out that the poverty rate, for all its decline in recent years, is still above the rate for any year in the 1970's. Similarly, poverty rates among children fell a full percentage point in 1998, to 18.9 percent. That level is well above the rate in the 1970's, and higher than in Canada or Western Europe.
The decline in the poverty rate came almost entirely as a result of a sharp drop in the South. Everywhere else, there was no change to speak of, the Census Bureau said. The South, in fact, has shrunk the percentage of people in poverty throughout the decade -- partly because many companies have moved operations there, generating millions of jobs, and partly because a big percentage of the population earns the minimum wage and thus benefited from increases in that minimum in 1997 and 1998. Poverty in the West, by contrast, has risen during the decade, partly because of an unusually large influx of immigrants, some economists say.
The Census Bureau's report highlights household income because that includes virtually every American, including unmarried young people living alone or with friends.
Family income is also calculated, and that showed a similar improvement in 1998, the median level rising to $46,737 in 1998 from $45,262.

HEADLINE: City Must Shield Workfare Force On Harassment

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration violated Federal law when it turned away women who said they were being sexually harassed while working for their public assistance benefits, the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ruled in a decision made public yesterday.
The city has maintained that the women were not employees and had no legal right to protection from sex discrimination in the workplace. 
 The commission's finding came in the case of a homeless mother of two who charged that her city supervisor in a welfare-to-work program had pressed her for sex and retaliated against her when she refused. The commission, which found reasonable cause to believe the city subjected the woman to sexual harassment and sex discrimination, has between 5 and 10 similar cases in various stages of investigation, according to lawyers involved in them.
The women received subsistence benefits only on the condition that they work off the public aid in city clerical jobs at the equivalent of the minimum wage. New York City, which has the nation's largest workfare program, with about 40,000 participants at any one time, is the only jurisdiction known to be contending that such workers are not entitled to the protection of Federal civil rights laws against sex discrimination in the workplace, according to Yolanda Wu, a lawyer with NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund, the organization that represents the woman whose case led to the ruling.
"The city does not condone sexual harassment of any kind," Lorna Goodman, a senior lawyer in the city Corporation Counsel's office, said yesterday. "If the civil rights laws do not cover these types of workers because they are not legally employees of the city, that does not mean that they have no redress." She said the women could bring private lawsuits against the individuals they say harassed them, or even bring criminal charges of assault in cases where they say male supervisors groped them.
But Ellen Vargyas, legal counsel for the E.E.O.C. in Washington, said Federal regulations and court rulings now make clear that welfare recipients in workfare programs are protected by all anti-discrimination laws to the same extent that other employees are.
"It doesn't matter what you call them," she said. "It boils down to 'Does the alleged employer control the manner and means of work.' "
The woman in the E.E.O.C. ruling was not named, but she said in legal papers that she was picked out from an orientation session for 50 welfare applicants by the man who became her supervisor in the spring of 1997. Over the next few weeks, she charged, he made unwanted sexual advances, and pressed her to go to a motel with him for sex.
In retaliation for her refusal, she said, she lost her job and had to fight to keep her welfare benefits.
Maria Gonzales, one of the women with a pending case before the E.E.O.C., said yesterday at a news conference that she had complained to two levels of supervisors, to no avail, that her boss at the city's Human Resources Administration grabbed her genitals, demanded sex, stole her time cards and threatened her life when she refused his advances.
"I don't think it's right that the city should treat women who need their help like this," said Ms. Gonzales, 32, who was unemployed and was facing eviction when she applied for public assistance in 1997. "I have nightmares and I still cry when I talk about this, and I'm still very afraid of that man."
In a third case before the commission, a woman charged that city supervisors ignored her complaints that her boss at another workfare site was pinching her buttocks and ribs and putting his hands down her pants, according to Jack Bryant Tuckner, who represents her and Ms. Gonzales. Finally, she was transferred to another assignment, he said, but later the city allowed the same boss to follow her there.
When the commission sought to investigate several complaints of sexual harassment, the city refused to cooperate, maintaining in its legal papers that the commission had no authority to look into charges made by public assistance recipients because they were not employees.
After the E.E.O.C. went to Federal court in Manhattan to enforce subpoenas for city records connected with three of the cases, the city also argued that supplying the requested information would violate the confidentiality of welfare recipients.
"I know it's not a particularly sympathetic position," Ms. Goodman said. "But this is a legal issue. We have a good faith duty to protect the taxpayer." Most of the women who have experienced sexual harassment in workfare jobs are afraid to complain, said Marc Cohan, a lawyer with the Welfare Law Center, the organization that helped the homeless mother of two keep her benefits.
She succeeded in earning her high school equivalency diploma and finding work in the private sector on her own, Mr. Cohan said.
"Why should she have less protection just because she's poor?" he asked. "We have a supposedly law-enforcement Mayor who is hiding behind legal technicalities instead of addressing what is a horrendous situation. It's absolutely outrageous that the city's claiming its program mirrors the world of work, and then it denies these women the basic rights that are available to other workers."
In its written decision, the E.E.O.C. said its investigation determined that the city's Human Resources Administration had violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the basic Federal law that prohibits discrimination in employment on the basis of race and sex, because "it failed to inform a class of employees who worked as participants in New York City's Work Education Program, funded through Temporary Assistance for Needy Families, of their rights under Title VII" and also failed to provide any mechanism to complain about harassment.
The law requires the commission to now try to eliminate the unlawful employment practices with persuasion and conciliation. If that fails, the E.E.O.C. can go to court.
 The women involved were barred from suing in court until they exhausted the E.E.O.C.'s remedies, Ms. Wu said, adding that NOW had unsuccessfully sought meetings to discuss the problem with the city for two and a half years.

HEADLINE: A Night for Giuliani to Pay Tribute to the Reagan Legacy

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: SIMI VALLEY, Calif., Sept. 30

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wrapped himself in the legacy of Ronald Reagan tonight in a speech that glorified the former President and seemed an unusual approach for an unannounced Senate candidate who would need Democratic votes to win in New York State.
In delivering the annual Reagan Lecture at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library here, Mr. Giuliani called Mr. Reagan one of the two most important Presidents of the 20th century -- the other was Franklin D. Roosevelt -- and "a force for good in the world." Mr. Giuliani praised Mr. Reagan's supply-side economics, which Democrats to this day say caused the huge deficits of the 1980's and favored the rich. "Who says that supply-side economics doesn't work," the Mayor said. "Of course it works." 
 Aides to the Mayor said Mr. Giuliani was attaching great importance to the speech, which in its lengthy discourse on foreign policy seemed more Presidential than senatorial in its ambitions. Aides also said that Mr. Giuliani viewed it not so much as a campaign speech as a tribute to the former President in his twilight years. Mr. Giuliani reveres Mr. Reagan, and served in his two administrations as Associate Attorney General and United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.
The annual lecture was created by the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation to honor "conservative public figures or policy makers" who "reaffirm and apply the principles that guided the President and shaped his enduring legacy."
An official at City Hall acknowledged that there were some political considerations to the speech, and said that it could help with those voters upstate and in the suburbs who may distrust the Mayor of New York City but have fond feelings for the President who gave birth to the term the Reagan Democrat. Mr. Giuliani himself pointed out at a fund-raiser at the Beverly Hills Hotel on Wednesday that Mr. Reagan carried New York in both the 1980 and 1984 Presidential elections.
The speech's Republican orthodoxy also outlined the themes of the battle that Mr. Giuliani is almost certain to fight against Hillary Rodham Clinton, his likely opponent in the Senate race next year. The Mayor told the audience of 450 Reagan faithful, who interrupted his speech several times with applause, about how he had reduced the welfare rolls in New York and believed in "freedom of choice" in education. In praising Mr. Reagan for returning powers to state and local governments, Mr. Giuliani in part credited the former President for his own election as Mayor, an event that Mr. Giuliani sees as pivotal to the city's resurgence. Without Mr. Reagan, Mr. Giuliani said, there might have been "no innovative governors -- and maybe there'd be no Republican Mayor of New York City."
Mr. Reagan, 88, has Alzheimer's disease and did not attend the lecture. Nancy Reagan, the former First Lady and a trustee of the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation, served as the host. The day before, she welcomed Senator John McCain of Arizona on a stop of his Presidential campaign. In his speech Mr. Giuliani said Mrs. Reagan was the one person aside from the former President who is "most responsible for the Reagan legacy that we celebrate tonight."
Mr. Giuliani spent a large part of his speech praising Mr. Reagan for ending the cold war and building up America's defenses. He also criticized President Clinton for a foreign policy of "confusion" and a weakened military. "The next President," Mr. Giuliani said, "will have to rebuild American foreign policy."
In remarks to reporters before the lecture Mr. Giuliani said that he had not yet read Edmund Morris's new authorized biography of Mr. Reagan, "Dutch," which paints the President in his second term as an out-of-touch loner who was often in his pajamas in the White House family quarters by 6 P.M. watching television. "I only read the prologue," Mr. Giuliani said. "Let me read the book first before I comment on it."
After the speech at the Mission-style library with its distant view of the Pacific Ocean, Mr. Giuliani went with Mrs. Reagan and such Reagan friends as Betsy Bloomingdale and Charles and Mary Jane Wick to dinner at the nearby Sherwood Country Club.
Mr. Giuliani's speech came at the end of a three-day fund-raising and political trip to Washington, D.C., Las Vegas and California. This morning Mr. Giuliani played golf on the lush course of palm trees and oleander at the Stockdale Country Club in Bakersfield, Calif., then spoke at a lunchtime fund-raiser in the clubhouse dining room. As has happened throughout this trip, one of the guests asked him about the status of the city's battle with the Brooklyn Museum of Art over an exhibition that the Mayor has termed "disgusting."
The Mayor's responses to the question have grown increasingly descriptive. In Washington he extensively described a sliced pig in formaldehyde, calling it "a biology experiment at best." In Stockdale today he said the entire exhibit "belongs in a psychiatric ward."

HEADLINE: Top Pataki Adviser to Quit For Job on Bush Campaign

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Charles A. Gargano, Gov. George E. Pataki's top economic adviser, will leave the state government soon to take a top position in George W. Bush's Presidential campaign in New York, advisers to Mr. Pataki said today.
The move strengthens the ties between Mr. Bush, the Governor of Texas, who is the favorite for the Republican Party's Presidential nomination next year, and Governor Pataki, who would like to be considered for the party's Vice-Presidential nomination. The two Governors have met privately several times, and will campaign together in New York next week. 
 Mr. Gargano, 64, a former construction executive and Ambassador to Trinidad and Tobago, will become the New York State chairman for Mr. Bush, largely a fund-raising position. It is a familiar role for Mr. Gargano, who was the chief fund-raiser for former U. S. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's 1992 re-election, and for Mr. Pataki's successful 1994 campaign against Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Thanks to his close relationship with Mr. D'Amato, Mr. Gargano has been a fixture in New York's Republican Party politics for a generation. He managed Ronald Reagan's 1984 re-election effort in New York and served as the state party's finance chairman.
Since Mr. Pataki took office in 1995, Mr. Gargano has held a number of state positions, including Commissioner of Economic Development and chairman and president of the Empire State Development Corporation. His state jobs have given him a prominent role in such varied efforts as the construction of a new Pennsylvania Station inside the Farley post office building, redevelopment of the Hudson River waterfront and the "empowerment zone" in Upper Manhattan and the South Bronx. He is also vice chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
Democrats and some government watchdog groups have complained about what they see as a conflict between Mr. Gargano's role as solicitor of campaign contributions from corporate donors and his power to award millions of dollars in state contracts to those same donors. In mid-1995, Mr. Gargano said he would not hold any fund-raising positions while he was in state office, but he would not rule out a more informal role in gathering money for Republican candidates.
The Empire State Development Corporation is under investigation by the Manhattan District Attorney's office, which has subpoenaed reams of its records, looking for evidence of irregularities in some of its contracts. As a result of that inquiry, an official of the corporation pleaded guilty in June to accepting a bribe in return for placing a statue in Battery Park City.
Mr. Gargano, known in political circles for his charm and his powers of persuasion, spent many years as an executive at J.D. Posillico Inc., the dominant construction company on Long Island.
He served from 1981 to 1983 as a deputy administrator in the Federal Department of Transportation, and directed President Reagan's re-election effort in New York in 1984.
He served as ambassador to Trinidad and Tobago from 1988 to 1991, and he still likes to be referred to as "Ambassador."

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
An Entree of Skewered Patrons and Mixed Nuts

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS

 BODY:
There is life in prison without parole. There is walking on a bed of stainless-steel spikes without your shoes on. There is being shackled to the wall of a dark chamber crawling with giant tarantulas. And then there is the restaurant business.
More to the point, there is a job taking reservations for one of the snobbiest four-star eateries in Manhattan. The assignment is to referee the dirtiest wrestling match around, to sit with a bank of phones and discover the pathetic lengths to which one's status-obsessed fellow beings will go for a meal, even when they have no appetite. Forget the pan-seared tartlets of rock Cornish leg of seahorse on their fricasseed beds of distressed kale. 
 Dining out at the top of the food chain apparently is not about evolved cooking. It's about plain old threats, bribes, tantrums, ego, humiliation and outright sadism.
If it weren't so sad, it would be funny. Well, actually, it is very funny, at least as it plays out in "Fully Committed," Becky Mode's mocking dismantlement of megalomaniacal chefs, coked-up maitres d'hotel, food-averse V.I.P.'s, strung-out publicity agents and customers with exploding bowels. The play, which opened last night at the Vineyard Theater, does as much to shake the foundations of the temples of haute cuisine as a squadron of flies in the vichyssoise.
Rarely has a playwright pegged so entertainingly the insecurity at the heart of the New York sense of entitlement, the fear that is manifested at the in place of the moment of (a) not getting a table, (b) not getting your favorite table and (c) getting the table with the view of the dishwasher. It's a terror of comeuppance that extends in "Fully Committed" to the staff and, in particular, to the martinet of a chef who has been driven barking mad by the pressures of tending to the precious herb garden of his own image while kowtowing to the demands of a contemptible elite.
The chef, a Hannibal Lecter in kitchen whites, is the play's crowning achievement -- his desire to watch his underlings squirm is positively kinky -- and the actor Mark Setlock plays him with deadly accuracy. Mr. Setlock, in fact, plays everyone in this intermissionless one-man show, which has been smartly directed by Nicholas Martin. Mr. Martin has proved his mettle with solo shows; he staged "Full Gallop" with Mary Elizabeth Wilson at the Manhattan Theater Club.
In "Fully Committed," the central character is Sam, an unemployed actor who handles the telephones in the basement of an unnamed restaurant on the Upper East Side. Mr. Setlock did in fact once have a job fielding calls for Bouley, the TriBeCa restaurant that David Bouley operated until 1996. Ms. Mode had worked there as well; she asserts in the program, though, that the characters are pure invention and that she has made up the incidents involving real people.
Ensconced in the cavelike quarters -- James Noone's snappy set design suggests a pod in a space capsule -- Sam spends virtually the entire play on the phone, carrying on both ends of the conversations with a pleading, screaming, put-upon public. He also juggles internal calls from the members of the eggshell-walking staff of the establishment, where the nomenclature makes the cooking sound as if it were the subject of a United Nations conference. "The chef calls it 'global fusion,' " Sam explains.
Ms. Mode doesn't mince words, which is half the delight. Names are dropped in this deeply New York-centric play; Naomi Campbell, Henry Kravis and Diane Sawyer all have designs on tables. Mr. Setlock is scaldingly funny as an 84-year-old woman calling to gripe about the lack of a senior citizen's discount, and her tepid meal: "The lamb was bittah cold." And his portrayal of Jean-Claude, the maitre d'hotel, is a devastating caricature of a major domo with trouble sniffing out celebrities but none with putting drugs up his nose.
Like those tell-all tomes that the second footmen to royalty and mistresses to powerful men sometimes write, "Fully Committed" feels like an act of revenge. It has no message to impart, except perhaps, to be kind to the help: you never know who's taking notes. Anyone who has ever been on the receiving end in a menial job will find comfort in Sam's plight. But those who recognize themselves in Ms. Mode's delicious broadsides may never have lunch in this town again.
 
FULLY COMMITTED
 
By Becky Mode, based on characters developed by Ms. Mode and Mark Setlock. Directed by Nicholas Martin; sets by James Noone; lighting by Frances Aronson; sound by Bruce Ellman; production manager, Kai Brothers; production stage manager, Bess Marie Glorioso. Presented by the Vineyard Theater, Douglas Aibel, artistic director; Barbara Zinn Krieger, executive director and founder; Jeffrey Solis, managing director. At 108 East 15th Street, Manhattan.
 
WITH: Mark Setlock (Sam and others).
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES -- INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
As Business Confidence Grows, Euro Stages a Comeback

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 1

 BODY:
After a nearly nonstop slide against the dollar for the first six months of its life, the euro is coming back into vogue.
The euro, the common currency adopted in January by 11 European nations, jumped 3.6 percent this week. On Friday it reached $1.0767 in European foreign-exchange trading, its highest level in eight weeks, before settling in New York at $1.0728. 
 That level is still well below the euro's opening value of nearly $1.18 at its introduction on Jan. 4, but it represents a big shift since the currency plunged to just a bit more than $1.01 in July.
Many analysts now believe the euro will continue to climb in the weeks ahead, even if does not recoup its original value.
The immediate reason for the rise is a growing suspicion that the European Central Bank, which oversees the euro, might raise interest rates soon to help cool inflationary pressure. Rising rates tend to make a currency worth more.
But the broader reason behind the euro's advance is an unmistakable acceleration of European economic growth and a big improvement in business confidence over the last month or so.
Growth nearly came to a halt last fall, after the Asian and Russian financial crises. European exports and industrial production are now once again climbing.
In Germany, Europe's biggest and most beleaguered economy, business confidence has soared in the last month, in part because Chancellor Gerhard Schroder has veered sharply to the right and is pushing through big cuts in taxes and spending.
European central bankers have turned much more hawkish in the last few days, warning that inflationary pressure might be rising again and that it might well be necessary to cool things down with an increase in interest rates.
Christian Noyer, the bank's vice president, warned on Monday that price pressures had increased and that the bank might have to react to the inflation risk sooner rather than later. Today, two of the bank's top officials issued broad hints in the same direction.
Wim Duisenberg, the central bank's president, said Europe's outlook for growth had improved and dangers to price stability should not be overlooked. Otmar Issing, the bank's chief economist, warned that price pressures were on the "upside" and should not be ignored.
"Their message has changed over the last four weeks," said Joachim Fels, an economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in London. "I wouldn't overrule an increase in interest rates at the next meeting."
The bank's board of governors is scheduled to meet next Thursday, and the mere possibility of a rate increase has led traders to buy up more euros and sell more dollars.
Economists at Deutsche Bank Research, reflecting the view of many experts, still predict that the bank will probably not raise rates until next year.
Even so, analysts say there are other reasons for the euro's second wind.
Economic growth appears to be picking up in both Europe and Japan, a development that is tending to pull capital out of the United States.
"With the rest of the world looking better, it is now more difficult to finance it," Mr. Fels said. "Capital is looking for other places to go."
As growth prospects here and in Japan improve, investors are also focusing more anxiously on the huge trade deficit of the United States. A widening deficit means that a larger supply of dollars is leaving the country to pay for imports, which can have a weakening effect on the currency's value.
Among the more surprising areas of economic expansion in Europe is France, where the growth rate could reach 3 percent this year and where the unemployment rate has fallen from more than 12 percent to about 11 percent.
Smaller euro-zone countries like Finland, Spain, Portugal and Ireland are all growing rapidly. And though Germany remains Europe's debilitated economic giant, business confidence has climbed sharply there in the last month.
That is one reason analysts believe the European Central Bank will probably raise rates in the not-too-distant future.
Back in April, central bankers were so worried about declining confidence and even the possibility of a recession that they reduced the European bank's key interest rate from 3 percent to 2.5 percent. But the climate has changed considerably since then.
"The main rationale for the rate cut back in April was that confidence was very low," said Sonja Helleman, a currency analyst at Banque Paribas in London. "But that is not the case now."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Shares Decline Amid New Concerns About Interest Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stocks resumed their slide yesterday after new reports showed that the economy's surging growth had not slowed in recent months. The data renewed concerns that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates next week.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 63.95 points, to 10,273, after falling nearly 153 points earlier in the session. The blue-chip index ended a fairly volatile week just 6.33 points below the close on Sept. 24. 
 Broader stock indicators were mostly lower. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index edged up 0.10 point, to 1,282.81, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 9.31 points, to 2,736.85.
Stocks fell after the Commerce Department reported that personal income -- which includes wages, interest and government benefits -- had risen half a percent in August, the eighth consecutive monthly increase.
At the same time, consumer spending rose nine-tenths of a percent in August and the personal saving rate matched a record low of negative 1.5 percent. While robust consumer spending has powered the growth of the United States economy, many economists fear that inflation will begin escalating if spending continues unchecked.
The market's decline accelerated after the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that the manufacturing sector grew at a stronger-than-expected rate in September. The group also said that prices of raw materials had reached their highest level since May 1995.
"First the personal income and consumer spending report knocked the market down," said Alfred E. Goldman, director of market analysis at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis. "Then the N.A.P.M. really was the bullet. The market really didn't like the rise in prices paid."
The Fed has tried to stave off inflation by raising interest rates twice so far this year. Fears of a third increase have kept stocks off balance for the last month. While many analysts expect the Fed to leave rates unchanged when it meets Tuesday, yesterday's reports injected a last-minute note of uncertainty.
Economists say interest rate increases take several months to produce a measurable effect on the economy.
The inflation-sensitive bond market responded immediately to the signs of continued economic growth. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 1 7/32, to 99 29/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.13 percent from 6.04 percent Thursday.
"Bonds had a very bad day, and were certainly a trigger for the weakness in stocks," said Ricky Harrington, a technical analyst at Wachovia Securities in Charlotte, N.C. "Over all, there's still a lot of risk in this market."
Hewlett-Packard fell 3 3/8, to 87 3/8. The computer maker warned that its fiscal fourth-quarter revenue could fall short of Wall Street expectations because of component shortages caused by last week's earthquake in Taiwan.
I.B.M. fell 3 1/4, to 117 3/4.
Revlon shares slumped 6 1/4, to 12, after the cosmetics maker said it expected a loss in the third quarter. Revlon has not been able to find a buyer, so it now is looking to sell its salon-based business and some Latin American brands.
Eli Lilly rose 4 3/8, to 68 9/16. The Food and Drug Administration granted the company approval to sell an estrogen substitute as a treatment for osteoporosis and the prevention of brittle bones in women who are past menopause.
Merck rose 3 5/16, to 68 1/8, after it presented strong results from tests of the drug Fosamax, used to treat male osteoporosis.
On the New York Stock Exchange, declining issues outnumbered those advancers by a 7-to-5 margin. Volume of all listed shares totaled 1.01 billion, compared with 1.02 billion in the previous session.
The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies fell 3.77, to 423.53.

HEADLINE: Manufacturing Shows Unexpected Strength

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The nation's manufacturing sector grew in September much more strongly than expected, while prices of raw materials soared to the highest level in more than four years, according to a business survey released yesterday.
The report by the National Association of Purchasing Management confirms that industry is recovering from the Asian financial crisis and provides further evidence that the overall economy rebounded from a sluggish second quarter. 
 And the Commerce Department released statistics yesterday showing that the personal income of Americans climbed in August for the eighth consecutive month. But their spending rose even faster, leaving the nation's savings rate matching a record low.
The combination of reports kept alive Wall Street's fears that the economy was overheating, sending stocks and bonds tumbling on worries that the Federal Reserve will try to cool things off by raising interest rates for a third time this year. Fed policy makers meet Tuesday.
The purchasing managers' group said the manufacturing sector grew in September for the eighth consecutive month. Its index rose to 57.8 percent -- the highest since a reading of 59.2 percent in November 1994 -- and was up sharply from 54.2 percent in August. Analysts had expected little change in September.
A reading of more than 50 is a sign of an expanding industrial economy.
The index is closely watched because it is the first national reading for September on the nation's manufacturing performance, a key sector of the economy.
The Government said earlier this week that the United States economy grew at an annual rate of just 1.6 percent in the April-June quarter, but many analysts viewed the spring lethargy as a brief pause, predicting stronger growth for the second half of this year.
David Huether, director of economic analysis for the National Association of Manufacturers, said that yesterday's purchasing managers' report appeared to support expectations of renewed economic strength.
Norbert J. Ore, chairman of the management group's business survey committee, said in a statement releasing the September results that the survey's price index jumped to its highest level since May 1995.
The price index surged to 67.6 percent in September from 59.8 percent in August. That was the highest since 70.5 percent in May 1995, the association said.
The Commerce Department report showed that personal income -- which includes wages, interest and government benefits -- rose half a percent in August, the eighth consecutive monthly increase.
The increase was a bit more than the four-tenths of a percent forecast by analysts and followed a two-tenths of a percent increase in July.
But spending went up nine-tenths of a percent in August, also more than analysts had expected.
As a result, the nation's savings rate -- savings as a percentage of after-tax income -- fell to minus 1.5 percent, matching the record low set in May.
In another report, the Commerce Department said that construction spending fell an unexpected four-tenths of a percent in August to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $692 billion, a sign that one of the economy's strongest sectors was beginning to slow.

HEADLINE: Beijing Shows Off Military Weapons to Impress the Chinese and Others

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 1

 BODY:
With a Soviet-style procession of goose-stepping troops, tanks, missiles and fighter jets setting the tone for the parade marking its 50 years of Communism, China showed off a formidable armory today, even if few of the weapons could match the latest Western models.
There were no technological surprises to cause gasps in Taiwan or in Washington. Still, military attaches from foreign embassies here eagerly studied the display through binoculars, viewing some of China's best antiaircraft missiles and other systems for the first time. 
 Yet potential foreign adversaries were not the main intended audience today, Chinese and Western experts said. "The military parade is intended to show confidence and strength, especially domestically," said Zhang Yunding, director of Asia-Pacific Studies at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. "It's to give the people a sense that we have a new China, to let people feel proud of that rather than to focus only on our current problems."
Any intimidation of Taiwan is an added benefit, Mr. Zhang said.
Jonathan Pollack, a China specialist at the Rand Corporation in California, said, "The leadership wants to signal that it's not standing still and that it can display this prowess, at least as much to its own citizens as to the world at large."
Today's parade, the first of its kind in 15 years, also served the political ambitions of Jiang Zemin. In a stiff drive-by review of the forces today from an open-roofed limousine, Mr. Jiang imitated Deng Xiaoping's performance in 1984 and also showcased his own positions as chairman of the Central Military Commission, President of China and general secretary of the Communist Party.
If the tanks and jets on display today were a generation or so behind the world's best, the Chinese also displayed mobile short- and medium-range ballistic missiles that are nearly impossible to counter.
China still lacks the ability for sustained air and naval operations that would be necessary to invade well-defended Taiwan, 100 miles offshore and the main focus of Chinese military planning. And should the United States be drawn into combat, China would almost certainly be outfought by American ships and planes, which can strike precisely from hundreds of miles away.
But the mobile missiles on display today, which are being deployed adjacent to Taiwan in growing numbers, could serve in a sense as equalizers, able to inflict terrible damage on the island as well as on more distant American bases.
The parade also featured the recently tested DF-31 intercontinental ballistic missile, which can reach parts of the United States. Unlike China's existing, vulnerable nuclear forces, this weapon can be moved about, lending it far greater protection from surprise attack.
The military chest-thumping comes at a time when the long outmoded and underfunded military has gained status in top political circles and, almost certainly, a new boost in money for weapons development and purchases.
Many of China's best weapons, including some fighter jets and surface-to-air missiles seen today as well as naval destroyers and submarines, have been purchased from Russia.
China's military spending is higher than the published budget shows. But even with recent increases and any new additions, most Western experts say, the total remains a fraction of the American military budget, forcing hard choices.
The generals' political stock is up these days, experts say, because the modernization of Chinese forces now seems all the more urgent.
The Americans' display of precision bombing in the Persian Gulf war of 1991 caused consternation in China's backward military and led to a major overhaul that is still going on. This spring, the long-distance prowess shown by the United States in its bombing campaign against Yugoslavia was, in the words of an army newspaper here, "a new wake-up call" to the Chinese military.
"It was a big surprise to the military people," Mr. Zhang said. "There's really pressure now to develop high-tech weapons."
This summer's war of words with Taiwan, too, heightened the sense of urgency. In the months since Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, declared that relations between Taiwan and China should be conducted "state to state," a statement Beijing took to be a step toward formal independence, the Chinese press has been filled with assertions about China's new capacity to easily vanquish Taiwan. But thus summer's crisis forced China's military and political leaders to confront how limited their military options actually are, especially with the specter of American involvement in Taiwan's defense.
Apart from backward technology, the Chinese military is in the throes of multiple transitions, and its leaders appear especially anxious to avoid any conflicts in the next few years, outside experts said.
Burdened with a surplus of troops, a legacy of the old doctrine of "people's war," the three-million-strong army is trying to reduce its numbers by another 500,000 after already pruning one million people in recent years. But the dearth of jobs for cashiered soldiers is slowing the process.
The military is also supposed to be ending its involvement in the myriad businesses that helped pay its bills in the past. It is revamping the organization of forces and is in the midst of a fundamental rewriting of military doctrine and strategy.
Despite all these traumas, the military put on an impressively precise show today, even if it seemed from another era. "The 50th anniversary was a special occasion," Mr. Zhang said. "I think this is probably the last parade of this type."

HEADLINE: Auto Makers Finish Record Year on Strong Note

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Customers drawn by hefty rebates bought more than 16 million new cars, sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickup trucks in the 1999 model year, breaking the sales record set in 1986.
"These are good times," said Roy S. Roberts, group vice president for sales, service and marketing for the General Motors Corporation, which had its best model-year results in a decade. "The combination of affordable vehicles, high employment and buying momentum continues to propel us to record levels." 
 Most auto makers reported strong September sales today, closing out the 1999 model year on a strong note.
Sales reported for the model year, which traditionally runs through the end of September, so far total about 16.3 million vehicles, already surpassing the 1986 sales record of 15.8 million, said James W. Bush, publisher of Ward's Automotive Reports. That tally does not include September sales for the Ford Motor Company, the second-largest auto maker, which is scheduled to announce its results on Monday.
"The economy is strong, and increasingly the auto companies are buying the sales with aggressive incentive programs, and they can afford to do that because of their continued success in containing costs," Mr. Bush said. The incentives, offered by many auto makers, come in the form of rebates, discounted financing and cheap monthly payments on leases.
General Motors said its sales for the 1999 model year totaled 5,006,076 cars and trucks, a 9 percent increase over 1998. However, the company turned in mixed results for September today. Its overall sales for the month rose 8.9 percent compared with the same period a year ago, with its sales of sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickup trucks jumping 30.2 percent because of strong sales of full-sized pickups and sport utility vehicles. But its car sales dropped 6.4 percent.
The DaimlerChrysler Corporation said sales for its Dodge, Chrysler, Plymouth and Jeep brands hit a record 2,651,090 for the 1999 model year, up 8 percent from 1998. For the month of September, sales for those brands rose 7.3 percent. Car sales rose 4.9 percent and truck sales rose 8.4 percent. Small cars, small pickups and minivans turned in weak showings, but larger sedans and sport utility vehicles sold briskly.
The company's Mercedes-Benz unit saw its sales rise 9.6 percent, largely because of the continued popularity of its M-class sport utility vehicle and its E320 sedans.
Analysts expect Ford, which has been selling fewer discounted cars to rental fleets this year than last year, to report Monday that its sales fell 2 to 4 percent in September. George M. Pipas, Ford's manager for sales analysis, said that for the industry as a whole, 1999 was "easily the best model year in history." The auto industry is also expected to sell more cars this calendar year than in any previous year.
Toyota sold 1,465,399 cars and trucks in the 1999 model year, up 13.2 percent from the year before. The company said its September sales rose 10.4 percent, with strong sales of its bread-and-butter Camry sedan, its Tundra pickup truck and its Sienna minivan. Car sales rose 4.2 percent, while truck sales rose 20.6 percent. "Nine months of sustained industry growth has surprised everyone," said Jim Press, executive vice president of Toyota's American unit.
Wall Street analysts earlier this week scrambled to revise their estimates for industry sales upward. On Wednesday, John A. Casesa of Merrill Lynch raised his estimate for the year's sales from 16.2 million to 16.6 million. David B. Healy of Burnham Securities raised his estimate from 16.6 million to 16.8 million, well above last year's 15.6 million.
Honda sold a record 1,067,468 cars and trucks in the 1999 model year, up 7.4 percent from 1998. Honda's September sales rose 9.7 percent from the period a year earlier. The increase was a result of strong sales of the Odyssey minivan and the Accord and Acura TL sedans. Honda's car sales rose 3.8 percent, while its truck sales jumped 42.1 percent.
Nissan sold 653,771 cars and trucks in the 1999 model year, up 4.6 percent from the year before. The company said its September sales rose 19.8 percent last month, with car sales up 12.7 percent and truck sales up 29.3 percent. The increase came from strong sales of the Xterra sport utility vehicle, Quest minivan and Maxima and Altima sedans, and from sales in the Infiniti luxury division.
Other auto makers also reported strong September sales today. Volkswagen sales rose 52.3 percent in September compared with 1998, and the company said it had already sold more cars this year than it did in all of 1998. Subaru said its sales rose 17 percent for the month, while Isuzu's sales went up 55.7 percent, Mitsubishi's increased by 36 percent and Land Rover's rose 60.8 percent for the period.
Hyundai said its sales rose 82.5 percent in September. Audi said its sales rose 60.2 percent.
While G.M.'s truck sales were strong in September, its car sales dwindled. falling below the levels of the last two years. The decline at G.M. came even though overall demand for autos has hit record levels this year, and is far higher than in the last two years. G.M. sold 214,499 cars in September, down from 229,168 in September 1998 and 236,902 in September 1997.
Mr. Roberts of G.M. said the decline was partly a result of shortages of several all-new models that factories are just beginning to turn out, and partly because of the growing popularity of sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and minivans. Analysts said that lower car sales partly reflected the lingering effects of a strike last year that virtually shut G.M. for two months and led it to turn away would-be buyers, and partly reflected how unpopular the company's cars are, particularly when most auto makers are offering generous rebates.
"There is a market share war on," Mr. Casesa of Merrill Lynch said. "At almost any price, their cars are difficult to sell."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Continue to Slide On Strong Economic News
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was flat, rising 0.10 point, to 1,282.81. The index is up 4.36 this year and had been down 10.6 percent this week from its July 16 high, putting it into what Wall Street defines as a correction -- a selloff of 10 percent or more. 
 Other market gauges resumed their slide after reports showed that the economy's surging growth has not slowed in recent months. The data renewed concerns that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates next week. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 63.95 points, to 10,273, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 9.31 points, to 2,736.85. Page C3.
 
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.13 percent from 6.04 percent Thursday. C3.
 
City's Millennium Bookings Are Slow
Bookings for the New Year's holiday have been slow in New York, and there is at least the possibility that for hoteliers, restaurateurs and impresarios, the party to end this or any other century may turn out to be a bit of a bust. A new survey by the agency that oversees the city's tourism efforts, NYC & Company, finds that three-quarters of the 40 hotels that responded are not yet fully booked. A1.
 
Aetna Names Liaison to Doctors
Health insurer Aetna named a division president, John Kelly, director of the company's new office of physician relations to help bolster its ties with doctors. The creation of the unit comes after the American Medical Association, among others, objected to Aetna's $1 billion purchase of the Prudential Insurance Company of America's health-insurance unit in August, saying it would hurt competition in the managed health care market. C4.
 
Manufacturing Grew in September
The manufacturing sector grew in September much more strongly than expected, while prices of raw materials soared to the highest level in more than four years. The report by the National Association of Purchasing Management confirms that industry is recovering from the Asian financial crisis and provides further evidence that the economy rebounded from a sluggish second quarter. C3.
 
Euro Ends Week Up 3.6% at $1.07
The euro, the common currency adopted in January by 11 European nations, jumped 3.6 percent this week. It reached $1.0767 in European foreign-exchange trading, its highest level in eight weeks, before settling in New York at $1.0728. European central bankers have turned hawkish in the last few days, warning that inflationary pressure might be rising again and that it might well be necessary to cool things down with an increase in interest rates. Wim Duisenberg, the central bank's president, said Europe's outlook for growth had improved and dangers to price stability should not be overlooked. C2.
 
Joint Venture Guidelines Proposed
The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission published proposed guidelines for joint ventures among businesses, indicating the sorts of agreements that do not violate Federal antitrust laws. The guidelines are subject to comment for 90 days, after which time the agencies will decide whether to modify or approve them. C2.
 
Kellogg to Buy Vegetarian Specialist
Kellogg plans to buy vegetarian food maker Worthington Foods for $307 million. Worthington's shares shot up 60 percent, gaining $8.6875, to $23.0625, in Nasdaq trading. Worthington Foods specializes in manufacturing and marketing products like vegetarian burgers and meatless sausage, chicken and hot dog products. C3.
 
Ecuadorean Repayment Is Sought
Creditors have voted to demand the full repayment of $1.4 billion in outstanding Ecuadorean discount bonds. The vote comes after Ecuador defaulted on a $44.5 million interest payment on the bonds Thursday. C2.

HEADLINE: The Battle of Brooklyn

 BODY:
The chaotic nature of the debate over the "Sensation" exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum of Art must not obscure the two big issues involved. They have to do with the ground rules for government financing of cultural institutions and the political censorship of constitutionally guaranteed freedom of expression.
Reasonable people can disagree about spending tax money to support the arts, but both Congress, by funding the National Endowment for the Arts, and the city government, by funding a variety of museums and programs, have made the political decision to authorize such expenditures. We support that approach wholeheartedly, believing support for the arts is essential to both the intellectual climate and economy of New York City. We also believe, as a matter of law and constitutional principle, that once the financial support has been granted, as it has been for years, the institutions must be free to spend it according to their own professional standards. Otherwise, citizens will continually face situations like the current one in which Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has turned a gut reaction into a destructive, punitive policy. 
 The Supreme Court has addressed this foundation of principle in a way that is not totally satisfactory, but that sheds an interesting light on the current situation. The justices affirmed the right of Congress to set "advisory" standards of decency for programs receiving grants. But the high court warned against pulling back or denying money already allocated because of the content of the works being exhibited.
A majority of New Yorkers seem to have a clear understanding of this principle. To be sure, many citizens of conscience find parts of the Brooklyn exhibition repugnant, and it is understandable that many Roman Catholics would find Chris Ofili's image of the Virgin Mary offensive. Others would agree with our colleague William Safire that while the Brooklyn Museum has a right to show what it likes, the administrators have been clumsy or needlessly provocative. Yet a Daily News poll shows that the majority of New Yorkers support the museum over Mayor Giuliani by a ratio of two to one. Those numbers show a broad-based support for New York's role as the nation's cultural capital. The people understand intuitively what Mr. Giuliani ignores for political gain. A museum is obliged to challenge the public as well as to placate it, or else the museum becomes a chamber of attractive ghosts, an institution completely disconnected from art in our time.
Next week, the battle will move to the courts. To support the Mayor's claim that the museum violated its lease, the city's lawyers have concocted several theories. The city argues that the museum broke its lease by conspiring with an auction house to inflate the value of a private art collection at the expense of the museum's public purpose. The city also argues that the museum violated its public mission by deciding to charge a fee and to exclude children under 17. We are confident the court will see the city's arguments for what they are -- a pretext to justify the Mayor's anger at a museum that dared to defend artistic freedom.

HEADLINE: In 'Boom,' More Lint Lines Pockets of Poor

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
From the vantage point of his college major, business administration, and his current calling, homelessness, Jesse Martin offered his considered summary of the latest Federal findings on the booming economy.
"Basically, the statistics mean the Bill Gateses get the money -- there's the boom," Mr. Martin said, more stoic than resentful as he counted as riches his barracks-bed existence inside the Community for Creative Non-Violence, a shelter housing 600 poor men, women and children six blocks from the Capitol. 
 "And the poor, they go like the song -- just getting poorer," Mr. Martin continued, citing all manner of real-life experience of his 60 years -- lately a heart attack without benefit of health insurance -- to confirm the fresh data of the bureaucrats. "Of course the gap is widening. Whoever got the money, that's who continues to get it."
Across the capital city's underside, where social workers say the most noticeable boom lately is the growing population of needy homeless women with children, impoverished Americans easily confirmed today the bleak footnote to the new Census Bureau report on the rising incomes of America. For all the boom, income inequality continues apace, the Government concluded, with the gap between the rich and the poor failing to narrow despite the record prosperity in the late 90's in the middle and upper social reaches.
"None of that surprises me," said Patricia Smith, a care-worn, determinedly optimistic 49-year-old grandmother deep in poverty. Ms. Smith, surviving on a patchwork of welfare and workfare, charity and volunteer labor, recently learned that the four grandchildren she found herself forced to nurture on the city's streets all last winter would soon be joined by a fifth.
"My two daughters are on drugs and one of them is pregnant again," explained Ms. Smith, quietly alarmed at this growth indicator in her role as the drug-free, court-appointed guardian of the children of her addicted daughters.
In the world of Ms. Smith, drug addicts receiving what she considers overly generous Government assistance stir far more resentment than the rich Americans getting richer out there beyond her horizon. "The economy's plain," she said. "If you don't have money, you're not going to get anywhere. If you know somebody or if you're not on drugs, you get pushed aside."
"I know it's rough out there," she said, describing a harrowing three-month homeless period of bobbing and weaving with the children in the streets and back alleys because, she said, she could find no clear help from the city's antipoverty bureaucracy. "They said I had too many children for a shelter."
"This place saved me," Ms. Smith said at one of the city's charity bastions, Bread for the City and Zacchaeus Free Clinic. All about her, the monthly flow of 3,500 families seeking charity food baskets was particularly heavy at midday. The first of every month presses the poor to reach extra deep and seek out the center's basket donations as they wait for their regular cash and food-stamp dole to come around again.
"In the streets, I was washing the kids and changing their clothes behind bushes, and many people were kind to us," Ms. Smith said. She scowled at the memory of one man who she said talked of charity in return for sex with the oldest granddaughter. "I didn't have a life, never mind an economy."
In a nearby corridor, 25-year-old Patrina Swinson waited for some free-clinic care and scoffed at the boom and what she considers its incessant consultation as an ultimate barometer of life.
"My reality is not in stocks and bonds," Ms. Swinson said. "We're all still scraping around here, still at the bottom.
"My reality is in my neighborhood, not the economy," she said, proudly describing plans to learn computer technology to move beyond her job as a counselor in group homes for troubled teen-agers.
The economic boom's presence can be noted in the city's poorer neighborhoods in the form of land speculation and the razing of low-rent, if seedy, housing, in the view of Fred Henry, vice president of the Community for Creative Non-Violence, a private charity dating from the old antipoverty programs and Vietnam War protests of the 1960's.
"Developers are closing out a lot of poor people with their new emphasis on building middle-class housing," Mr. Henry said, citing this as a factor in the fastest-growing homeless category, women with children. Aside from that, he said, "Nothing has really changed across the last five years of economic boom."
Larry Weeks, a 42-year-old resident of the center, disabled after a series of odd jobs, has been working in the center kitchen school, aiming for a fresh start. "I listen to all the news a lot and usually go by what I hear," Mr. Weeks said.
"But if you're out there living the economy, you know it's not really booming," he said, describing his frustration in seeking $10-an-hour jobs and finding only $6 or $8 ones. "So what should be reported from here is hard times, lots of hard times."
A number of poor people interviewed emphasized that in the depths of unrelenting material troubles, they bolstered themselves on spiritual values.
Steven Sanders, a 35-year-old computer technician who said his life fell apart in addiction to crack cocaine, insisted he was back on the right track precisely because he had adopted the Bible, not the economy, as his guide.
"Oh, the rich get richer and the poor get poorer, that's very true," Mr. Sanders said. "But I feel you can only be 'rich' in how you treat others in God's image and how you feel within."
He grinned at what he said was this obvious point being missed in the endless Government data and analysis about the boom and the state of national contentment.
"When the Bible says, 'To whom much is given much is required,' it's not really about the economy," Mr. Sanders said from his place in the homeless shelter, looking happily out of tune with the boom times.

HEADLINE: Nuclear Peril Is Over but Japanese Anger Isn't

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKAIMURA, Japan, Oct. 1

 BODY:
For years, Tomi Oshiro lived practically in the shadows of this town's nuclear fuel plant, yet she, like most people in town, had no inkling of the perilous work going on inside the nondescript building.
The mystery ended abruptly on Thursday, when the fuel-reprocessing plant suffered the worst nuclear accident in Japanese history. Ms. Oshiro returned from shopping to find helicopters buzzing madly above her house. It was several hours later before she was warned of the full dimensions of the crisis. 
 "I am furious," she said, adding that "this incident was incomparably more serious" than previous accidents in the town, which is the home to more than a dozen nuclear research and production sites, including Japan's first nuclear power plant.
"It took place right next to people's houses," she said, "and still it took a long time before people were warned or any emergency measures were taken."
Ms. Oshiro spoke on a sidewalk less than hour after the Government declared that the danger had ended and told the 313,000 people living within a six-mile radius of the plant that they no longer needed to stay indoors.
Leaving her home for the first time in 24 hours, she expressed her profound distrust of the Government's handling of nuclear safety. But in Tokyo, some 90 miles away, senior officials labored to convey the impression of a return to normal.
"We believe that this should not lead to worries about the nation's nuclear policy," said Hiromu Nonaka, the chief cabinet secretary, who acknowledged the Government's slowness in handling the crisis but tried to allay concerns about the safety of nuclear power industry in Japan, anxieties held both inside and outside the country.
But with people like the townspeople here, those in civic groups around the country and independent experts in Tokyo, Government credibility had hit rock bottom, provoking cries for everything from abandoning the nuclear industry altogether to a sweeping overhaul of the industry, which provides nearly a third of Japan's electrical power.
Residents of Tokaimura interviewed by phone while barricaded in their homes, or caught on the street in the first minutes after the ban on going outside was lifted this afternoon, expressed their anger and disbelief that safety precautions could have been so lax and that the Government could have minimized the accident in the crucial first hours.
There was an accident two years ago that the town handled calmly, said Kazuko Hagiya, 52, the director of Tokai Hospital, just two miles from the plant. "We never realized the situation was so serious this time," he said. "I didn't close the windows right away. Some patients didn't know anything about the accident, and kept their windows open until they were warned, late in the afternoon."
Yukio Hosogai, a ruddy hospital refrigerator technician who was walking his dog, Hayato, said he learned of the accident in a call from his wife around noon, but was surprised to see civilian cars driving through the area two hours later.
As he spoke, walking in an abandoned roadway, dozens of white-suited nuclear clean-up workers combed the rice fields nearby, using Geiger counters to measure radiation levels.
"Honestly speaking, I will never get rid of the anxieties that come from living here," he said, "and if I could get rid of everything today and move somewhere else, I would. But I can't."
Residents of Tokaimura once thought the town of about 33,000 inhabitants had been lucky to become the home of Japan's nuclear industry, beginning in the 1950's. Before that, it had been a poor pearl in a string of what the Japanese call company castle towns, meaning towns dominated by a single corporation, in this case Hitachi.
First came the country's first nuclear lab, then its first reactor, then its first nuclear fuel-processing plants, and finally, its first breeder reactor, which uses plutonium rather than uranium fuel and is theoretically self-sustaining.
Little by little, residents in this coastal area -- with deep green rice fields, peaked tile-roofed houses and the country's characteristic commercial sprawl -- began to realize the costs related to the new industry.
This realization took root when there was a huge leak of radioactive coolant at the breeder plant in Tokaimura in 1995, and when there was a fire at another fuel-reprocessing plant two years later that exposed 37 workers to radiation.
 "A few of us tried to sound the alarms of danger from this industry starting way back," said Osamu Yatabe, a lawyer who once represented the district in the National Assembly.
"We were always in the minority though, because officials were able to convince people that accidents like Chernobyl and Three Mile Island could never happen here. Japan's safety precautions were in fact perfect, they said."
In Tokyo today, independent nuclear experts and civic groups ridiculed the Government's contention that the uncontrolled reaction, in a privately owned uranium-reprocessing plant, did not reflect on the overall safety of Japan's huge nuclear energy industry.
Even one senior official, the Minister of International Trade and Industry, Kaoru Yosano, took exception to the prevailing official line, saying he was more concerned about "psychological damage" to the public than any economic impact.
"I am worried that the unthinkable critical accident may throw cold water on the public trust in nuclear facilities," he said.
One the most critical stances, though, came from Greenpeace Japan, which said it was starting a campaign to force the Government to phase out the nuclear industry.
Others may have stopped short of a demand like that, which has little prospect of being realized, but insisted on sweeping changes and were no less scathing in their dismissal of Government explanations of the crisis.
Asked about the Government's reassurances that the incident did not reflect on the country's entire nuclear industry, Kiyoshi Sakurai, a former researcher at the state-run Atomic Energy Research Institute said: "Nonsense. Safety management or operational management of other nuclear facilities has a lot in common with this plant -- that is, the system is designed in ways that allow workers to intervene easily in the process."
According to most accounts of the accident, a flash of blue light and a chain reaction of nuclear fission were produced when workers inside the plant put more than five times the amount of uranium in an acid solution-filled processing container than is normally allowed. Three of those workers are among the critically injured, altogether 49 people were exposed to radiation.
The reaction was eventually contained when emergency workers managed to break a drainage pipe for the container holding the fissionable material. Later, emergency crews doused the contaminated site with radiation-absorbing chemicals.
"Many in the public say that this accident must have been caused by a procedural infractions, but I do not buy that," said Keiji Koyabashi, a scientist at the Research Reactor Institute of Kyoto University.
"In nuclear power matters, there should always be fail-safes," he said. "Even if a mistake occurs, safety must be assured."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photo: Koji Kitani, head of the company that operates the nuclear plant in Tokaimura, apologizing to local residents yesterday for the nuclear accident. Among the 49 people exposed to radiation, three are in critical condition. (Associated Press)(pg. A7)
 
Chart: "DEFINITIONS: The Many Ways To Measure Radiation"
 
Scientists measure radiation released in an accident like the one in Tokaimura, Japan, in a variety of ways.
 
RADIATION
A roentgen is the most direct measure of radiation. It represents the number of atoms of a gas that have lost an electron and become charged by the radiation. This is usually expressed as roentgens per hour or roentgens per minute.
 
ABSORBED RADIATION
Matter, whether living or nonliving, absorbs energy as radiation penetrates its substance. This absorbed energy is expressed as a rad (roentgen absorbed dose) or a gray (Gy). One gray = 100 rads.
 
ITS EFFECT ON HUMANS
To measure the potential damage to human tissue, scientists created the roentgen equivalent man or rem as a unit of measure. It takes into account the amount absorbed and compensates for differences in types of radiation to arrive at a measure of potential harm.
 
The sievert (Sv) is a similar unit measure, with one sievert being equal to 100 rem. Both are usually expressed as one one-thousandth of a whole unit, for example as millirem and milliseivert.
 
TYPICAL EXPOSURE
Average annual background exposure to radiation for those living in the United States is about 360 millirem. This amount comes from naturally occurring radio-isotopes and medical applications.
 
(Source: Health Physics Society)(pg. A7)
 
Map of Japan showing location of Tokaimura: Tokaimura residents are no longer being advised to stay indoors. (pg. A7)
