HEADLINE: Veteran Asks That Memorial Honor Only War Dead

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 29

 BODY:
Tony Pia vividly remembers the morning almost 30 years ago when he saw workers dismantling a three-sided wooden structure inscribed with the names of almost 10,000 Stamford men and women who had served in World War II.
"I was stunned beyond belief," said Mr. Pia, whose own name was among those on the small white building that had stood in a small park opposite the Old Town Hall since 1943. "No one had been told this was going to happen." 
 Mr. Pia, a retired career Army sergeant and a longtime veterans' advocate here, gathered as many sections of the building as he could and took them to the basement of Town Hall. "Quite a few people who got wind of what I had done came in and got the nameplates with their names or the names of loved ones who had been killed," said Mr. Pia, known locally as the Old Sarge.
Now, Mr. Pia is upset again about another issue that involves honoring servicemen. He opposes a plaque honoring Peter J. Rowe, a Marine Corps brigadier general and Stamford native, that was placed in Veterans Memorial Park in 1997, a year after the general was killed in an auto accident in California.
It was mainly through Mr. Pia's efforts that the park, in downtown Stamford, not far from where the dismantled building stood, was created in 1977. Unlike the old structure, which gave way to neglect and then to urban renewal, the new memorial does not name all of Stamford's veterans, but commemorates the nearly 300 servicemen from the city who were killed in World War II and the Korean and Vietnam Wars.
It is the breach of that standard for inclusion on the memorial that has Mr. Pia so upset. "The entire park is dedicated to servicemen who died while fighting for their country," he said. "And General Rowe did not die during a war. He was killed in an automobile accident." Mr. Pia has asked the city's Board of Representatives to have the plaque removed, setting off a debate. The board has not yet announced a decision.
The Parks and Recreation Commission, which has jurisdiction over the park, one of the largest veterans' memorials in the Northeast, recommended recently that the board turn down the request.
"We feel that the plaque is in an area of the park that is not hallowed ground," said Stephen P. Lesandro, the chairman of the commission, which approved the plaque honoring General Rowe. "It was placed unobtrusively, away from the memorials."
But Mr. Lesandro's explanation does not satisfy Mr. Pia. Geno Lupinacci, who designed the park's 22-foot-high granite war memorial with all the deceased veterans' names inscribed on it, and several veterans' organizations have also asked that the plaque be removed. "I designed the monument for those killed in wars," said Mr. Lupinacci, a World War II veteran who has operated a monument business in Stamford for 52 years. "A plaque for the general doesn't belong on that sacred ground."
Those who proposed and paid for the plaque honoring General Rowe disagree. "How many generals come out of small towns like Stamford?" asked Pasquale Battinelli, the director of the city's Patriotic and Special Events Commission, who is a former marine and was one of those responsible for the plaque. "After he died, I said, 'We've got to do something nice for this guy, who served in Vietnam and Desert Storm.' "
Not many people in Stamford seem to remember General Rowe, who left town as a young man to join the Marine Corps and never returned. One of those who does remember him is Frank LiVolsi, a Stamford lawyer who was instrumental in having the plaque placed in the park. "Pete Rowe served his country well and deserved the plaque," said Mr. LiVolsi, who was an Army captain in Vietnam and knew General Rowe when they were teen-agers in Stamford. "His name is not on the memorial, so we see nothing wrong with this."
Mainly because of the precedent set by the plaque honoring General Rowe, a veterans' group wants to similarly honor another Stamford native who attained the rank of general and died after he retired.
The group, the 192d Field Artillery Battalion Association, which is based in Stamford, has asked the Parks and Recreation Commission for permission to erect a plaque for Army Brigadier Gen. Edward W. Berry, who commanded the battalion during the Korean War.
"I didn't know that someone who didn't die during a war was allowed in Veterans Park," said Francis B. DeMasi, the group's chairman, who served under General Berry, "but since the Marines have one of their generals in there, why can't we? And besides being an outstanding military leader, General Berry was a great educator, who spent 39 years at Wright Technical School in Stamford after he retired from service."

HEADLINE: Budget Surplus Is Expected

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
A slowdown in the state's economic growth is expected to produce a modest budget surplus, the State Comptroller, Nancy Wyman, said yesterday.
In her monthly estimate, Ms. Wyman said the state should have a surplus of $11.2 million for fiscal year 2000. Ms. Wyman said second-quarter job growth increased at its slowest pace since 1995. Other economic markers declined, she said. 
 Income tax revenues account for half the projected surplus. Last year the tax produced 70 percent of the record-setting $620 million surplus. When lawmakers were finished appropriating extra funding, remaining surplus was $69.3 million surplus for the year that ended June 30.

HEADLINE: We Don't Need A New Subway Line

BYLINE: By Diana Fortuna; Diana Fortuna is president of the Citizens Budget Commission.

 BODY:
Capital improvements planned by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority should accomplish two things: reduce crowding on the subways during rush hour and support economic expansion by accommodating more workers bound for midtown Manhattan. By these criteria, the agency's plan for the Second Avenue subway is either too much or too little.
In its new capital budget, the M.T.A. plans to spend $700 million over five years to begin the subway, which will extend only from 125th Street to 63d Street. If the goal is to reduce crowding, this project, which is projected to cost a total of $3.4 billion, is an extraordinarily expensive way to achieve it. If the goal is to increase the city's ability to bring workers from the other boroughs into Manhattan, then a more extensive project is needed. 
 Yes, crowding on the Lexington Avenue subway line is a serious problem. But it is a problem chiefly during rush hours. The problem could be fixed by running more trains during that period. The time between trains on the Lexington Avenue and other crowded subway lines now averages more than two minutes. Some other large cities can run trains 90 seconds apart. If the M.T.A. could operate this well, then the capacity of lines would increase by one-third, from 30 to 40 trains per hour. Crowding, as we know it, would end on all lines, not just on the Lexington Avenue trains.
Seems simple enough. What's the holdup? First, the M.T.A. cannot reduce the time between trains because it relies on outdated signaling systems. The authority has spent $33 billion on capital improvements since 1982, but the signals have been neglected, and technological innovations have not been introduced. The agency's capital plan would spend $642 million to upgrade the current system, but it would be wise to invest more in new signals.
There is another problem in running trains closer together: getting New Yorkers in and out of cars quickly. But this should not be an insurmountable task; other cities have managed to do it. The M.T.A. should investigate other, less expensive changes, like new subways cars with bigger doors and alterations to station platforms and entrances. In addition, riders are less likely to fight to get on a train if they are confident another is right behind.
Peak-hour pricing is another way to reduce crowding. Commuter railroads already give discounts to riders during off hours; trying it on the subways could encourage many riders to shift from the busiest hours to less crowded times, say 7:30 A.M. instead of 8:15. To this end, MetroCard could revamp its discount policy. Instead of giving riders a 10 percent volume discount at all times, it could limit the discount to off-peak hours. And employers would have to show some flexibility.
Other options are yet to be tried. For instance, why not create dedicated lanes, blocked off by barriers, for rush-hour express bus service on First and Second Avenues?
Accommodating the city's future job growth is a harder problem to solve. Nobody has a reliable crystal ball that shows how many people will be working in Manhattan in 20, 30 or 40 years. The current boom could push employment well above the record high achieved in 1969. Or a national recession, changes on Wall Street and other unpredictable events could reduce the number of city workers.
If the number of jobs keeps growing, the Second Avenue subway, even if it were extended to the Lower East Side, would not help. It doesn't accomplish what's necessary: bringing commuters from the other boroughs and suburbs to Manhattan. In this regard, the East Side Connector, which would extend subway lines into Queens and add a new Long Island Rail Road tunnel to Grand Central Terminal, is a far more sensible element of the capital plan.
If money is to be raised for expanded service, let's reject another futile compromise and instead design the right project, one that will carry New York into the next century. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Hell on High Water

BYLINE: By Elizabeth Hightower; Elizabeth Hightower is a senior editor at Outside magazine.

 BODY:

Knockdown
 The Harrowing True Account of a Yacht Race Turned Deadly.
 By Martin Dugard.
 Illustrated. 243 pp. New York:
 Pocket Books. $24.95. 
 We have entered the age of celebrity weather: from the 1996 Mount Everest megastorm immortalized in Jon Krakauer's "Into Thin Air," to the wicked nor'easter that wrecked a fishing fleet in Sebastian Junger's "Perfect Storm" to the Southern Ocean monster that forced three rescues (and led to as many books) in the 1996-97 Vendee Globe around-the-world sailing race, blockbuster disasters have become our most reliable best sellers. Or so several publishers are hoping, as they rush to print accounts of the last December's tragic Sydney-to-Hobart yacht race. And none were more hastily published than Martin Dugard's "Knockdown." It is as messy as the storm that inspired it -- a melodramatic but nonetheless riveting chronicle of the "weather bomb" that hit the race fleet just as it entered Australia's treacherous Bass Strait last Dec. 27. In the mayhem that followed, 100-mile-per-hour winds churned up waves eight stories high, 24 boats were crushed and abandoned, 57 sailors were rescued and six men died.
Dugard's epic tragedy begins as most do, the audience watching with grim foreknowledge as the boats sail merrily to their doom, sails flapping against a clear sky as they round Sydney Harbor's South Head and enter the open sea. The fleet is 115 strong, from hulking maxis like Sayonara, owned by the Silicon Valley mogul Larry Ellison, to local family-owned and -crewed yachts like the 35-foot Midnight Rambler to the legendary 52-foot Winston Churchill, a restored wooden veteran of the first Sydney-to-Hobart in 1945. Herein lies the uniquely Aussie appeal of the 735-mile race, an epic haul billed by Dugard as the Everest of the sea: unlike other blue-water races, the Sydney-to-Hobart allows amateur weekend sailors to compete alongside multinational racing syndicates, the local skippers in their smaller boats often proving the toughest of the bunch. As Dugard convincingly tells it, this traditional Australian nautical grit contributed to last December's debacle. The Sydney-to-Hobart's grueling conditions and awful seas are points of national pride, and so by the time many skippers decided to turn back, it was too late -- they were in the eye of the storm. The question that still hovers over the ill-fated race is why on earth didn't somebody call it off. Dugard does a fine job of outlining the brewing of disaster: the wind and wave patterns of the Bass Strait, the convergence of three weather systems in those shallow waters and the weather bureau's undertstated forecasts, broadcast despite one meteorologist breaking down in tears when he saw the report. In an eerie twist, on real-time Internet broadcasts on sites like Quokka and MountainZone, armchair adventurers, privy to this impending Armageddon, as one forecaster called it, tuned in to watch the nautical horror show unfold.
Dugard, a former marketing coordinator who left his job in 1993 to write full time, is making a career of machismo. His previous book, "Surviving the Toughest Race on Earth," chronicles his participation in the ludicrously punishing Raid Gauloises team adventure race. A biographical note on the dust jacket of "Knockdown" says the author is a "co-holder of the Around the World Speed Record (New York to New York in 31 hours, 28 minutes)," but leaves out the fact that he set that record as a passenger on the Concorde. Duggard's writing is fittingly macho. On the growing storm: "The wind is not a gentle tickle on the cheek, but a brooding schizophrenic that can instantaneously destroy." On the father of the Midnight Rambler's Ed Psaltis: He "was the sort of decisive man of the sea lesser men dreamed of becoming." And on the role of skipper: "He's playing chess with the gods out there, with his life and the lives of his men the tariff." But strip away Dugard's chest-thumping voice-over, and you are left with a story that simply won't let go. With rogue waves smashing hatches and snatching men from the decks, with severed fingers and crushed eye sockets and with shredded life rafts and unbelievably daring rescues, readers won't mind repetitive detail, abruptly spliced anecdotes from landlubbers and occasionally sloppy prose. What might bother them is his mind reading. Dugard's tale is more vivid for its detailed forays into each surviving racer's emotions. But he makes grand leaps into fiction when he offers the blow-by-blow thoughts of several drowning men: the British Olympic sailor Glyn Charles "is able to appreciate the sky and waves and wind with the love of a lifelong sailor up until the very end. Finally, his limbs no longer moving, his mind knowing contentment after a life of rage and battle, Glyn Charles slips beneath the waves one last time."
Charles, with five other surely undeserving men, was one of the losers in the Sydney-to-Hobart race. But like the disasters before it, this tragedy offers more than its share of ordinary heroes: severely injured old friends stoically clinging to the remnants of a Winston Churchill life raft for 28 hours, the rookie rescue swimmers Michelle Blewitt and Kristy McAlister diving again and again into cold black water to save the entire crew of Stand Aside. Others must live with their actions, like the crew of the Margaret Rintoul II, the boat that passed the sinking Sword of Orion as Charles drowned. And like those disasters before it, Sydney-to-Hobart raises questions about the lure of adventure and the economics of risk. The final rescue price tag was $650,000 in civil resources alone. The Australian Military and Safety Authority continues to be responsible for 29 million square miles of dangerous ocean. More and more people seek out such elemental trials as climbing Everest, sailing the Southern Ocean or tackling Australia's toughest sailing race. As Dugard quotes one of the Sydney race organizers, "I expect the problems we experienced will make the race all the more attractive." And no doubt Dugard's book, too.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 21; Column 2; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 313 words

HEADLINE: Books in Brief: Fiction;
Material Girl

BYLINE: By Barbara Sutton 

 BODY:
Hooking up with a winner is the only maneuver that Rita Zapata, the protagonist of Yxta Maya Murray's second novel, WHAT IT TAKES TO GET TO VEGAS (Grove, $24), can envision to gain her some respect within her East Los Angeles community. As Rita acknowledges in Murray's streetwise narrative, when at 16 you've already been written off as scandalous by the community's all-powerful and viper-tongued Latina League, your only recourse is to snag a good man. And in the impoverished Mexican-American culture in which Rita comes of age, this means a boxer who's got what it takes to land a pay-per-view prizefight in Vegas. After sleeping with and being ditched by most of the neighborhood's going-nowhere-fast street fighters, Rita sets her sights on Billy Navarro, a charming but brutal boxer from Mexico, and the plot traces the pair's heavy-breathing but precarious relationship. Despite the selfishness behind Rita's repeated missteps, we're touched by how ignorantly she desires the consumer goods that she associates with respectability -- from custom-interior Cadillacs to the complimentary bottles of fancy shampoo you in get in your room at Caesars Palace. After a while, however, Rita's upbeat though fated-for-deflation epiphanies become taxing, as does the incongruity of street language spiked with more "literary" metaphors. And the story's resolution, after episodes of violence that unfold like a television movie, has a recovery element that is at odds with the rest of the novel. Still, Rita's narrative maintains a fast clip, and the novel's strength lies in Murray's candid though poignant description of the "Eastelayer" world -- of the bustling consumerismo of Cesar Chvez Avenue, of boxing champions whose personal mythologies are memorized by every schoolchild, of the sad-sack lives of wannabe boxers who wind up working at Denny's. Barbara Sutton

PUB-DATE: October 3, 1999

SECTION: Section 6; Page 34; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 2958 words

HEADLINE: HacK, CouNterHaCk

BYLINE: By Bruce Gottlieb; Bruce Gottlieb was a staff writer at Slate magazine until enrolling in Harvard Law School this fall.

 BODY:
"Would you like to see how to knock someone off the Web?" Silicosis asks.
Sili, as he is known, is a slim young man with serious eyes set deeply into a delicate face. He's the newest member of a hacker collective known as L0pht (pronounced "loft"). He becomes visibly uncomfortable when asked to talk about himself. He gives his age as "mid-20's" and then clams up. But when the conversation moves to hacking, Sili turns voluble: "I think it's a thrill to look at a program and figure out how to make that program do something that it was never designed to do in the first place. There's the challenge."
We sit down at a computer monitor while Sili explains his latest discovery. By mimicking messages that typically flow between computers on a network, he can reach out to almost anyone running Windows 95, 98 or 2000 in a large corporate environment, or anyone using a cable modem, and forcibly disconnect them from the Web. In a demonstration of this, he types a one-line command on his computer and hits the return key with a flourish. Sure enough, the computer across the room, which seconds before had been connected to M.I.T.'s server, is now off line. The same technique, Sili explains, can be used to take information flowing between the Web and your neighbor's computer and reroute it into your own. A clever hacker could capture a neighbor's banking transactions, passwords or credit-card information.
Sili published his research on L0pht's Web site in mid-August. The report was covered in the computer publication Infoworld and the on-line magazine ZDNet. At the time, a Microsoft spokesman, instead of denouncing L0pht, expressed the hope to reporters that the group would "design a more secure version of the protocol" -- a hackerproof set of operating instructions for the computer.
This request strikes Sili as especially outrageous. "Why doesn't Ralph Nader just redesign the Corvair?" he asks.
Nader is something of a role model at L0pht, a confederation of eight young hackers who position themselves, incredibly enough, as a consumer-advocacy group. But L0pht's tactics are a bit unorthodox: breaking into software systems and then posting instructions on how to do so on the Web, where they can be picked up by software designers and malicious hackers alike. Intrigued, I paid a visit to their workshop.
L0pht's "laboratory" is the second floor of a ramshackle warehouse in suburban Boston. Predictably, the door to the lab has a sign for the pizza man -- "Domino's Knock Loudly."
The eight men who make up L0pht allow themselves to be identified only by their screen names: Dr. Mudge, Space Rogue, Dildog, Brian Oblivion, Kingpin, Silicosis, Weld Pond and John Tan. They look to be in their 20's or 30's, but their six-room suite is an adolescent geek's fantasy clubhouse. One wall is papered with antiquated circuit boards while another has a signed picture from Julie, Penthouse Pet. Junk food in the cupboard is taken seriously. There are three different kinds of Cheez-Its: hot and spicy, plain and white cheddar.
The warehouse brims with more than 200 computers ranging from state-of-the-art Sun and Digital workstations to nostalgia pieces like Commodore 64's and Apple IIe's. Black cables, yellow cables and jumbles of thin rainbow-colored wires drip from the ceiling, all jacked in to steel racks of oscilloscopes, radio transmitters, D.S.L. modems, I.S.D.N. modems, half-opened C.P.U.'s and a 50-foot roof antenna. The warehouse also contains several small-scale dummy computer networks.
L0pht's "research" consists of trying to break into these internal systems. Upon discovering a security flaw in commercial-network software, the L0phties publish an advisory on their Web site. The advisory is a double-edged sword: a detailed description of the flaw -- enough information for other hackers to duplicate the "exploit" -- and a solution that tells network administrators how to close the loophole.
L0pht's unorthodox methods have garnered praise from very unlikely quarters. Sixteen months ago, L0pht appeared before the Committee on Governmental Affairs of the United States Senate. Senator Fred Thompson introduced L0pht not as a "gang" nor even a "group," but, translating for Washington pols, as a "hacker think tank."
L0pht wowed the committee by reeling off an alarming list of security holes in public and private systems. After the presentation, Senator Lieberman gushed, "It is probably not what you came to hear, but actually, I think you are performing an act of very good citizenship and I appreciate it." Lieberman went on to compare L0pht, in a single sentence, to both Rachel Carson and Paul Revere. "You are performing a valuable service to your country," Thompson added, "and we appreciate that and want you to continue."
The National Security Council is equally bullish on L0pht. I met the N.S.C.'s director of information protection, Jeffrey Hunker, at Defcon, an annual three-day "conference" attracting more than 2,000 computer hackers from around the country. Hunker had come to talk about President Clinton's initiatives on computer security (and to spy on hackers, if you believe the whispers). He surprised me by raving about the group's technical sophistication. "L0pht has carved out an interest-ing niche for itself," he added, "and for similar-minded people -- white-hatted hackers. Their objective is basically to help improve the state of the art in security and to be a gadfly, so to speak -- to identify products that have vulnerabilities and make certain those vulnerabilities get fixed."
When I told L0pht about Hunker's comments, they rolled their eyes, saying, "You're not going to publish that, are you?"
For one thing, they had no wish to be identified as favorites of the N.S.C., since that might jeopardize their standing among so-called black-hat, or malicious, hackers. "We are all extremely ethical and moral," one member allowed, "but we're not white-hat hackers. We have our own moral and ethical standards" -- the term is gray-hat.
It's not hard to spot the reasons for the moral ambiguity. In their off hours, Mudge and Dildog are members of Cult of the Dead Cow, a black-hat hacker group that recently released Back Orifice 2000 (bo2k), a computer program that enables a hacker to control another computer from afar. (The name is a crude play on Microsoft's Back Office Server, a program that allows a legitimate administrator to, among other things, control another computer on a network.) But unlike Back Office, bo2k is "invisible," meaning that a hacker can spy on another user, even change files, without the user's knowledge. Dildog, one of bo2k's authors, euphemistically describes it as "a shy program." Jason Garms, the former head of Microsoft's security-response team, is a bit more direct, labeling b02k "a malicious program, with malicious intent."
Perhaps because of their ties to the black-hat community, L0pht members refuse to be identified, although they will let themselves be photographed. As Space Rogue explains (and any hacker knows), pictures are next to useless if you're trying to dig up private data on someone.
When L0pht testified before the Senate, members would not accept checks for hotel and travel expenses. As with members of the Witness Protection Program who have come before the Senate, they were reimbursed with cash. Senator John Glenn even signed pictures -- with the group's screen names: "To Dr. Mudge. . . . To Space Rogue. . . . To Weld Pond."
"Open up the raincoat to expose all the little parts," is how Mudge, smiling, describes L0pht's ethos. Mudge will not disclose his age, but mid-30's seems a good guess. He claims a college degree in music with further course work in computer science. Mudge says that early experimenting with computers led to informal warnings from certain "three-letter agencies." He wears his hair below his shoulders, sports a goatee and favors faded jeans and a T-shirt. In his Senate testimony he claimed to have given training seminars at NASA and the National Security Agency.
Mudge frankly admits that he'll answer anyone's technical questions about hacking. "If a black hat approaches us and says, Hey, this is the project or problem I'm looking at . . . we'll talk to them, no problem. And if a government agency approaches us and says, How do you do this, or, How does this work, we'll talk to them."
Of course, this laissez-faire attitude has its costs. Mudge says: "Full disclosure is something we had to grapple with for a long time. The flip side is that critics say, 'You're giving people tools that can actually do bad things.' That is absolutely true. It's got a lot of nasty side effects."
For instance: last December, a hacker magazine called Phrack disclosed a flaw in a network program called Cold Fusion. (Network programs help manage computers that are linked together). In April of this year, Weld Pond -- an older, thoughtful L0pht programmer -- discovered a second, more serious way to exploit the flaw.
Weld immediately published an advisory on L0pht.com prescribing a fix. Weld's report also contained enough detail to explain the flaw to so-called "script kiddies" -- young, malicious hackers with limited technical expertise who are among the most avid readers of L0pht's advisories. In the span of three weeks, according to PC Week, hackers inserted bogus text and images on at least 100 Cold Fusion systems, including those of NASA, the Army and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
So why didn't L0pht contact Allaire, the small Cambridge, Mass., software firm that makes Cold Fusion, before releasing an advisory? The reason, say Weld and the other L0phties, is that vendors usually sweep tips from hackers under the rug. Vendors, claims L0pht, don't want customers to think software has flaws. "We were trained by the vendors to go public," says Mudge, "to give them a black eye."
With an attitude like this, it's tempting to blame Weld Pond, especially since L0pht's advisory led to more security breaches than would have occurred had nothing ever been reported. It's not enough to claim, as Weld does, that "We try to stay somewhat neutral -- we're not on the vendor's side, we're not on the hacker's side. When we release the tools, they can be used for good or bad. It's up to the individuals to have morals."
Mudge is currently writing a paper on a longtime hobbyhorse of his: the vulnerability of electrical power grids to hacker attacks. While the computers that control these power grids are not directly connected to the Internet, Mudge thinks a hacker could still turn out the nation's lights because utility companies have left the keys to their computers under the proverbial doormat.
Mudge tells me that careless utility employees often put internal documents on public servers -- perhaps to access them from home or while on the road. Sometimes, Mudge claims, the documents explain how to access the central computers. Central computers "might have no attachment to the Internet," he says, "other than the fact that somebody put up a document on the Internet describing how to get to it and how to use it." Mudge pauses. "Well, that's just as good."
Mudge has written a program to scan utility companies' Web sites for words like "confidential" or "password." "I'm not breaking any laws by doing this, I'm just grabbing public stuff," he is quick to point out. "They don't realize that they're putting it up there for the world to see."
He shows me a file downloaded from a large utility company that contains a presentation on company security. Next he opens a file full of phone numbers from another utility company. "It sounds almost science-fictionist," he cautions, "but with these numbers here I'd be able to turn off their entire grid." The phone numbers, he explains, connect to modems linked to the central switches that determine where electricity flows. "If I don't publish this information," Mudge claims, "someone else will come along and do the same thing, with less ethical goals. Now you can see a situation where people are dying because of these corporations' stupidity. At that point, who's to blame?"
Given the stakes, Mudge intends to relax his commitment to so-called full disclosure. "It's uncool," he says, for utility companies to "learn about a problem by reading it in the newspaper." That's why he plans to alert companies in advance, so they can close vulnerabilities before the news is made public on L0pht's Web site.
Like Nader, the L0pht members can get a bit preachy on the subject of ethics. "Any of us could leave L0pht right now and take six-figure jobs," Mudge says. "The fact that we don't and we're on the ramen-noodle, mac-and-cheese diet, that speaks for our ethics right there. It's not a job for us; this is what drives us through life."
While Mudge's self-righteousness may be justified up to a point, there are also more prosaic reasons for working at L0pht. Freedom to do whatever you want, for instance. Silicosis and Brian Oblivion are installing a motor-driven satellite dish on the warehouse roof. They hope to capture ground-to-space communications from the Space Shuttle and high-resolution images of the earth broadcast from satellites. The justification? It's cool. Silicosis adds, "It impresses my girlfriend."
Space Rogue -- a sort of young Archie Bunker figure, to the extent that an Archie Bunker figure can be young -- sticks closer to earth when asked how he ended up at L0pht. "I did one semester in college, said the hell with this and got out. Controlled learning environments have never been my strong point." L0pht gave him a place to pursue projects at his own pace.
Mostly, Space Rogue seems to like L0pht for the camaraderie. "I moved to Boston in 1990," he says, "and I almost immediately met all these people on line on local bulletin boards. L0pht started shortly thereafter in fall '91. So I'd already known these people awhile, even face to face. The on-line world at the time was very small."
Mudge recalls that the group took off when members moved their computers from their living rooms to a small loft space in Boston. (All but one of the founders, Brian Oblivion, have since left.) L0pht soon added members and moved to a larger suburban warehouse four years ago. It has also started a consulting business on the side called L0pht Heavy Industries.
L0pht is not without critics, of course. "While L0pht puts on the Robin Hood mantle of fighting the big computer companies," a senior programmer at Microsoft tells me, "their only victims are the little people that are customers" -- the people who purchase products like Windows 2000.
Microsoft has been on the business end of several L0pht advisories, most notably when Mudge and Weld demonstrated how to decrypt passwords from computers running Microsoft's NT operating system. Jason Garms, the former head of Microsoft's security-response team, admits that hackers have a role in creating secure software. But he's wary of the Darwinian notion that hackers will, by actively looking for flaws, expose inferior products. He likens it to improving public safety by painting a target on everyone's head.
I mentioned Garms's criticism to the L0pht members, who were equally dismissive. If gray-hat hackers stopped searching for vulnerabilities, L0pht believes, a black-hat hacker would find them sooner or later. It's better to get rid of flaws than hope no one finds them. The N.S.C.'s Hunker shares this belief -- the hackers are already out there" -- which is why he applauds L0pht for keeping vendors honest.
The senior Microsoft programmer also warns that Mudge and his colleagues, for all their highfalutin apologia, are motivated mostly by naked ego: "I am certain," he says, "that the primary motivation of these people is simple self-gratification and justification."
I asked the L0pht members whether ego played a part in their ethical reasoning. Weld Pond replied that, by assuming pseudonyms, they more or less deny themselves the benefits of celebrity. "When I walk down the street," he says, "no one knows I'm Weld Pond."
But at Defcon, the annual hacker convention, it was quite clear that everyone knew Weld, Mudge, Space Rogue and Dildog. L0pht members have become, as Mudge notes wryly, "rock stars of the computer underground." That they help malicious hackers as well as the Feds and big business hasn't hurt their popularity among the outlaws.
On the other hand, L0pht's poorly hidden hunger for the spotlight shouldn't obscure the truly fascinating work they've done. Socially important research is perfectly compatible with, and perhaps inseparable from, love of celebrity, as James Watson has made admirably clear. Say what you will, there is no denying that L0pht's advisories have improved computer security even as they have harmed corporations and government agencies.
No one doubts that information security is going to become an increasingly critical topic as the ordinary economy moves into the digital age. In their grander moments, L0pht's members hope to become digital Ralph Naders, making sure that the software behind the transition is as safe as manufacturers say.
The idea of eight computer hackers in a dingy warehouse insuring the safety of the information age may sound a little farfetched. But sometimes hackers eventually direct their curiosity toward laudable ends. Take, for example, the two young hackers who engineered a small blue box in the early 1970's that allowed free long-distance calls when placed near a telephone receiver. The two enterprising techies went door to door in the Berkeley dorms, selling the devices. Their names? Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak, future founders of Apple Computer.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 3, 1999

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Page 52; Column 1; Home Design Magazine 

LENGTH: 1135 words

HEADLINE: Sue Thy Neighbor

BYLINE: By Tracie Rozhon; Tracie Rozhon is a reporter for the House & Home section of The New York Times.

 BODY:
As you and your spouse pull into your crushed granite driveway after a hard day's work at the commodities firm, you both smile, secure in the knowledge that your new multimillion-dollar country seat on half an acre will always grow in value. But wait -- no, it can't be -- what are those brand-new virulently purple flamingos doing on your neighbor's previously pristine lawn?
You fume. In your mind, your house has suddenly become, well, almost worthless. You pick up the phone. Are you going to call the neighbors and politely ask them to take the flamingos off the lawn? (Or the offensive overflowing Dumpster? Or the new ugly fence?) Hardly. You're calling your lawyer. 
 It's time to sue.
Of course, neighbors have been battling one another for centuries over issues large and small. But in recent years, there appear to be a growing number of seemingly frivolous legal battles. While there are no statistics on the subject, lawyers who specialize in real estate litigation say there are more such lawsuits than ever before.
"It's something that's become prevalent," says Kenneth M. Block, a partner in a Manhattan law firm who specializes in real estate and litigation. "As society becomes more litigious, when property owners feel aggrieved, their first reaction is to speak to a lawyer."
Block recalls an incident in which he represented a pianist whose co-op neighbors tried to have her evicted for practicing too loudly. On Long Island, a homeowner who lived next to a polo field sued to have the polo matches stopped.
In Greenwich, Conn., three neighbors recently sued a fourth: Martin R. Frankel, the financier and former fugitive suspected of stealing millions from insurance companies. The neighbors had filed several charges against Frankel, among them that their own houses had dropped in value because of his suspected criminal behavior, as well as the attendant publicity, police presence and Frankel's own extended absence. Before the suit was withdrawn for reasons their lawyer, Philip Russell, declined to discuss, one appraiser backed up the plaintiffs, saying their houses had lost about 20 percent of their value by proximity to Frankel.
Russell compares the situation to that of the O. J. Simpson house in the Brentwood neighborhood of Los Angeles. "They couldn't sell it," he says. After it was finally sold, the house's next owner knocked it down. "It was a fairly new house, and, suddenly, it was worthless," Russell says.
Others counter that notoriety has no effect. "I live in Darien, and as far as I could see, there was no impact of Alex Kelly's living there," says Jonathan Miller, president of Miller Samuel, a Manhattan real estate appraisal firm, referring to the young Connecticut man convicted in 1997 of rape. "I think it might have more of an impact in a down market, where buyers are looking for things to pick on so they can get a lower price."
The experts may never stop arguing about the actual impact of something unpleasant or distasteful -- or something perceived to be so. The more intriguing issue is the change in the neighbors' attitudes.
"In the past, whenever there was a minor issue over a boundary or something like that, the owners would just work it out," says Frank Newbold, a vice president of Sotheby's International Realty and head of its office in East Hampton, N.Y. "Now they just call their lawyer; they'll go to the wall over one-tenth of an inch."
In Southampton, N.Y., a group of residents complained to the local design board about a neighbor who had built a house of corrugated stainless steel. They claimed that the shiny metal was reflecting the sun's rays, and had turned their expensive landscapes into dry toast. While opponents of the house still gripe that the board mistook the steel for clapboards, their claim was ultimately judged to have no merit.
The town's review board didn't do much to appease the neighbors of Ira Rennert, the zillionaire industrialist who is building a 58,000-square-foot mansion in the fields of Sagaponack, near Southampton. The neighbors have (surprise!) filed a legal brief to prevent a renewal of the building permit for what may be the largest single-family home erected since San Simeon.
Earlier this year, in North Haven, N.Y., Thomas D. Mottola, the chairman of Sony Music Entertainment, applied to the village for a permit to build a 200-foot dock -- presumably to accommodate a gargantuan yacht. The neighbors, led by Carol Phillips, a former chairman of Clinique, fought back. The application was approved, but with so many conditions that Mottola took his yacht elsewhere. He sold his place for (sob) $8.7 million.
And no story of Neighbor vs. Neighbor would be complete without the famous contretemps between Martha Stewart, the perky entrepreneur, and Harry Macklowe, the less perky developer. Stewart had cleared some underbrush blocking the view on her property, then applied for a permit. The zoning board decided she had cleared properly, and gave her a permit retroactively. Macklowe, her neighbor, then sued. He lost. In the meantime, the developer erected a large fence. Then the village of East Hampton sued him -- and won. Macklowe was ordered to take part of the fence down. (And yes, there was the much-reported incident in which Stewart was said to have pinned one of Macklowe's groundskeepers with her Chevy Suburban, but the truth of that tale is not clear.)
Although lawyers, including David Vladeck of Public Citizen Litigation Group, say these kinds of lawsuits, or threatened lawsuits, seem to be on the upswing, they make it clear that this phenomenon does not stretch across the economic rainbow. "I think it's only at the high end where you see things that matter so much, things that would be considered absurd by normal people," says Russell, the Greenwich lawyer who represented the neighbors in the suit against Martin R. Frankel.
Stephen M. Raphael, a Manhattan real estate lawyer and developer, also believes the urge to sue is limited to those with ample resources. "Most middle-class and even upper-middle-class people don't bother with this," he says.
But despite the fact that litigation is expensive, you're seeing people buying property today that, because of their stock market gains, they wouldn't have dreamed of owning five years ago. "So on the one hand, they're trying to be blase and cool -- just casually mentioning at a cocktail party that they just laid down $5 million for a weekend house," Raphael says. "But on another level, they're panicked -- and they want to be sure the value is there, and that, after they paid the biggest price on their street to tear down the house and build a McMansion or whatever, they got everything they paid every last exorbitant penny for."
Even if they have to go to court to get it.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In /Brookfield, Conn.;
Rural, With 2 Large Lakes as Bookends

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
FROM the early 1700's to the mid-1900's life in Brookfield was rural, predictable and uneventful. Not even the Revolutionary War affected its measured pace.
In the 1920's, during Prohibition, there was some excitement when bootleggers operating in a few houses along the Still River found a sluiceway and used it as a hiding place for bottles during raids. But the community never grew and just after World War II, with barely 3,000 people in town, the New Haven Railroad closed the Brookfield station for lack of passengers. 
 Train service was never restored, but rural Brookfield nevertheless drew people fleeing the cities after the war and its population more than quadrupled from 3,405 in 1960 to just over 15,000 today.
Home buyers are drawn to the small-town atmosphere, the highly regarded schools, plentiful recreation and a wide range of housing priced from under $200,000 to more than $2 million. On the hills where sheep and cattle once grazed there are clusters of new colonials with superb views, priced from the $400,000's to the $700,000's. A few of the 54 homes in the historic district are available, along with many older homes scattered through town. They are priced from $175,000 up.
Commercially, Brookfield has substituted corporate parks for ironworks and grist mills. Nineteenth-century hatmakers, scissors factories, and carriage-makers are gone, but goods and services are in bountiful supply along the so-called Miracle Mile on Federal Road, where Costco, Seaman's furniture, Office Max, ShopRite, Home Depot, Stew Leonard's and numerous other emporiums are situated.
Developers have been building 4,000- to 5,000-square-foot houses on speculation, said John F. Hegarty Jr., owner of Hegarty & Company Real Estate. "They are selling well because people no longer fear losing their jobs as they did in the early 90's," he said. "There are eight large-home subdivisions of six to 12 homes under construction."
Betty Hensal, owner of Davis & Hoyt Better Homes & Gardens Real Estate, said that her agency had been "getting multiple bids higher than the list price until interest rates went up and it slowed down a bit." But town residents are still moving up to large new homes. Many of them are employed in nearby towns, at Duracell, Boehringer-Engelheim, Union Carbide, Cendant, and I.B.M.
Waterfront properties on Candlewood Lake and Lake Lillinonah comprise some of the highest-priced and lowest-priced real estate in town. Prized for their private beaches, playgounds, ballfields, and boat slips, homes in lakeside enclaves like Candlewood Shores, Barkwood Falls and the Lake Club can run from $150,000 for a 1940's former summer cottage on a minuscule lot to $2 million for a mansion on six acres, according to Stephen Schappert, owner of Buyer's Trust Real Estate, a buyer's broker agency. The Lake Club has a private nine-hole golf course.
Out of a total of 5,532 dwellings in town, 105 single-family homes and 23 condominium apartments and town-house units are currently for sale. While an estimated 1,300 acres of vacant land are zoned for housing, construction is limited by wetlands, rock ledges, two-acre zoning, the absence of sewers and town water and near-perpendicular grades that make driving downhill on some roads a breathtaking experience.
LAST January Sharon and Rick Lees and their two small sons moved to Brookfield from Eden Prairie, Minn., after having lived in New Jersey, New England and Paris. Mr. Lees is an executive with the Dannon Company, in Tarrytown, N.Y.
"We wanted a small, uncrowded town," said Mrs. Lees, "open space with lots of sports and things to do. Candlewood Lake is wonderful and the Danbury Fair Mall is close without being in my backyard."
In their eight-home development, called Muirwood, six customized four-bedroom homes have been sold, on one-acre lots. Built by the Charter Group, a local developer, they cost around $500,000.
Before committing to the house, Mr. Lees visited the schools and talked to the principals. "He was pleased with what he found," said his wife.
"The community expects us to prepare their children to be very competitive for college admissions," said James Chittum, superintendent of the town's 3,000-student school system. In the high school, he added, "we have increased the number of advanced placement courses, honors courses and foreign languages to include French, Spanish, Italian, Russian, and Latin."
S.A.T. scores last spring were between 30 and 45 points higher than state and national averages. Of the 170 seniors who graduated last June, 81 percent went on to higher education, almost all to four year colleges.
Pre-kindergarten and before- and after-school programs are run at Center and Huckleberry Hill Elementary Schools, both of which were recently enlarged. An 18-room addition to Whisconier Middle School, serving grades 5 through 8, will replace and supplement 11 temporary classrooms when they open in the fall of 2000. Renovation of the high school is next, said Mr. Chittum, "to accommodate an additional 200 students within the next five years."
The only private schools in town are a Montessori Community School for children from 2 to 9 years old, charging from $3,500 to $5,750 a year. Annual tuition at the k-8 Roman Catholic St. Joseph's Parochial School is $2,400 for parishioners, $2,900 for others.
One of Brookfield's 19 nursery schools and day-care centers is run by the Brookfield Regional Y.M.C.A. Before- and after-school care costs $55 to $125 a week and day-care costs $72 to $205 a week, depending on age and hours.
The annual family fee for the Y's 7,000 members is $510. It includes use of the gym, running track, racquet ball, and two indoor pools -- one of which is therapeutic at a constant 92 degrees. There are dozens of exercise, sports, dance, and educational programs at minimal extra charge, and three outdoor pools are attached to the children's summer camp, which costs $150 a week.
BROOKFIELD has no municipal golf course, but the Sunset Hills course, designed by Gene Sarazen, who lived in town and died this year at the age of 91, welcomes all players. Annual membership is $1,000 including greens fees; daily play costs $18 weekdays and $24 on weekends. The par-35, nine-hole course becomes a par 70, 18-hole course by following colored flags that identify a different route the second time around. The course is open from St. Patrick's Day to Dec. 1.
Fifty percent of Brookfield's population use the town's recreational facilities -- "the highest ratio of fun-lovers in the state," says Dennis DiPinto, director of the Brookfield Parks and Recreation Department. That includes 10 public parks, 18 ballfields and 670 acres of land for passive recreation. Resident tennis passes at Williams Park cost $25; hikers can picnic on 100 acres of the Gurski Park, and a third soccer and football field and bandstand are under construction at the Municipal Center.
Brookfield Town Park on Candlewood Lake charges $55 a season for a residents-only boat launch, and $45 per family or $30 per individual for a residents-only beach pass.
On Friday nights up to 500 people bring picnics and listen or dance to free jazz concerts. Across the street, Cadigan Town Park has two tennis courts, badminton, basketball, and volleyball courts, shuffleboard, and a food concession.
Two private boat clubs on Candlewood Lake require members to be boat owners. Annual fees, including boat slips, are $1,870 at Candlewood Lake East Marina Club and $1,500 to $1,800 at Brookfield Bay Marina & Yacht Club. Candlewood East has a snack bar, playground, swimming area, and 200 slips. Brookfield Bay has 170 slips, no food service, but a kitchen and picnic tables for members' use.
Overlooking the lake and accommodating 400 diners, indoors and outdoors, is one of the town's 21 restaurants, called Down the Hatch. Seafood, steaks, chicken, wine and beer are served daily from St. Patrick's Day to Halloween. Dinner for two is about $50.
Founded in the mid-50's, the Brookfield Craft Center, with a nationally known school and exhibition venue housed in several former mill buildings, and the Brookfield Players, where five shows a year are produced in a former private school's fieldhouse, are major cultural institutions.
Brookfield's handsome public library is connected to the Internet and to 45 public and college libraries with which it exchanges information. It has 10,700 card-holders, 58,000 books and 138 magazine and 11 newspaper subscriptions. The town has two radio stations, WINE-AM and WRKI-FM, and the weekly Brookfield Journal supplies area news.
Looking to the future, plans have been drawn for the creation of a Village District at the intersection of Routes 7 and 25.
According to Al Garzi, the volunteer economic development director, a new Village District Zone covering a 200-acre area of nondescript stores and businesses will be redeveloped in colonial style with clapboard and shingle buildings, gas street lights, landscaping, and park benches. Some buildings will be renovated, others demolished.
The result, in five to 10 years, will be a true village green.

GROUP EFFORT: In 1931 a former summer music school called the Homestead became the incubator for the celebrated Group Theater in Manhattan. Through former students the property was made available to the playwright Clifford Odets, the director Elia Kazan, the actress and drama teacher Stella Adler and the actor John Garfield. They spent the summer hatching plans for the company organized later that year in Manhattan by Harold Clurman, Lee Strasberg and Cheryl Crawford. The company was dedicated to producing new American plays of social significance, among them "Waiting for Lefty" and "Awake and Sing" by Odets.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 3; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 892 words

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
No. 1 Destination in 2020? Try China, Then France

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
IT may not be too soon to start brushing up on Chinese. Why? Because by 2020, China is expected to become the world's top tourist destination with 130 million annual visitors, and 100 million Chinese are expected to visit other lands.
By comparison, China had a relatively modest 24 million visitors last year, good enough for sixth place, while the 8.4 million Chinese visitors to other lands ("outbound tourists") ranked ninth. But its 100 million outbound tourists will account for almost a quarter of the 405 million Asian travelers expected by 2020, a staggering increase from the region's 84.4 million outbound travelers in 1995. 
 These forecasts are from the Madrid-based World Tourism Organization, a worldwide group of 138 countries and territories that gathers tourism statistics and publishes reports. At the International Tourism Asia trade show in Hong Kong last month, the organization also predicted that by 2020 France will drop from first to second place in arrivals (even though its visitors will increase to 106.1 million by 2020, up from 70 million last year) and the United States will remain third (102.4 million visitors, up from 47.1 million currently). Spain, with 47.7 million visitors last year, will have 73.9 million in 2020, yet still drop a notch to fourth place. Hong Kong, currently 18th with almost 9.7 million visitors, will vault to fifth place with 56.6 million.
The remaining top 10 positions are expected to be occupied by Britain (currently in fifth place), Italy (currently fourth), Mexico (seventh), the Russian Federation (13th) and the Czech Republic (12th).
The tourist organization also predicted that the ubiquitous Germans, who have long led in outbound travelers, including 82.9 million last year, will continue to lead the list with almost 153 million in 2020. Japanese travelers, who numbered 16.8 million in 1997, the latest figure available, will soar to 141 million, for second place, while the 123.3 million outbound Americans in 2020 will be more than twice the 52.7 million who traveled in 1997.
Predictions, of course, are informed guesses at best, but World Tourism Organization forecasts have often been on target or close to it. Two years ago, for example, it forecast that China will be the world's number one destination by the year 2020, and it stuck to that prediction despite the recent economic crisis in East Asia and the Pacific, which draws many of its tourists from the region. At the Hong Kong meeting, the organization said that to prepare for the expected influx, the Chinese Government is investing a lot of money in promoting tourism and relaxing laws governing the tourist industry.
The tourism organization also predicted almost a year ago that tourism to East Asia and the Pacific would bounce back stronger than ever after 2000, barring any new major incident. And at the Hong Kong conference, Deborah Luhrman, a World Tourism spokeswoman, told delegates that the economy of the region seems to be stabilizing. Despite the economic battering, East Asia and the Pacific still drew a respectable 87 million tourists last year, according to Francesco Frangialli, the organization's secretary-general. Much of the shortfall in Japanese tourists, he said, was offset by Europeans and North Americans attracted by lower prices and good package deals.
Signs of a comeback are already apparent in several Asian nations. Tourist arrivals to Hong Kong, for example, increased 11.1 percent for the first seven months of this year, compared with the same months of 1998. Thailand posted an 11 percent increase through June of this year over the first six months of 1998. And Singapore tourism rose 9.5 percent through July, compared with the same seven months of 1998, even though visitors from Japan fell almost 13 percent.
Nevertheless, it is important to remember that many predictions about tourism are as fleeting as the lifespan of the mosquito. Two years ago, for example, the World Tourism Organization predicted that "the tourists of the 21st century will be traveling further afield on their holidays, with the percentage of long-haul travel increasing from 18 percent in 1995 to 24 percent by 2020." But 13 months later, in November 1998, the W.T.O.'s Business Council (a group representing the private sector within the larger organization) released a study saying that because the amount of leisure time available for many people is likely to decline, the trend to shorter, more frequent holidays closer to home will accelerate -- a trend that has been pronounced in the United States for almost a decade.
Add to that the periodic warnings -- the first more than a year ago from the World Congress on Snow and World Tourism, the most recent a report for the Worldwide Fund for Nature in Britain -- that global warming could erode beaches, reduce snowfall over ski areas and otherwise play havoc with tourist areas, and the future is probably as uncertain as ever. But barring widespread economic, political or climatic upheaval, one thing seems certain -- tourism will continue growing at record rates.
"Our results for 1998 confirm that people do not stop traveling altogether, even during tough times," Mr. Frangialli said. Instead, they underscore that tourism "has become a deeply rooted part of our culture at the end of the 20th century."

HEADLINE: A Glacial Cocktail Party

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN; SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, a former Times correspondent, lives in Kansas.

 BODY:
TO sense the delight of a cruise on the Skorpios III along the southern coast of Chile, imagine this scene the day we returned to the ship for lunch after a morning spent gazing in awed silence at the sapphire beauty of a mile-wide glacier. As some of us competed to find the right superlatives to describe the experience, the Colombian priest on my right raised his wine glass and toasted the captain, Constantino Kochifas, at the other end of the table with the words: "Captain, you have brought us to the gates of Heaven."
Cutting through the waters surrounding the natural ice sculptures in front of San Rafael Glacier at almost 47 degrees south latitude was the high point of the seven-day cruise, but every day in the fjords, lakes and gulfs seemed made for postcards, right up to the 10 P.M. sunsets we watched through the dining room windows as we ate. The trip was half adventure and half lazy pleasure, a few parts funky and a few parts luxury. 
 I had traveled and lived in Chile, and had long dreamed of taking a trip on one of the vessels of the family-run Skorpios line. It was a special thrill to fly out of the Midwest on a January afternoon with snow in the forecast and land 12 1/2 hours later in Santiago, the capital, at the height of summer.
From Santiago, I flew almost 600 miles farther south to Puerto Montt, the main port in the Chilean lake region, to board the Skorpios III, a bright orange and white vessel with three sun decks. Dinner was nearly over that Friday night when I arrived from the airport, and a waiter put me at a table alone, but Mimi de Kochifas, the captain's wife, walked over and set the easy, gracious tone that was to mark the cruise. She said that because I spoke Spanish she would to put me at her husband's table starting at breakfast the next morning.
I was pleased with the comfort of my twin-bed cabin. At 195 square feet, it felt roomy, and the porthole was a real window, a good three feet wide. I was on the Acropolis Deck, the second of five levels. Fine paneling, made from the beautiful woods for which the south of Chile is known, went halfway up the walls. The bath was small, sleek and modern, with a walk-in shower and an adequate vanity. There was an ample closet, a mini-safe, two chairs and a small table, television and internal telephone.
The Skorpios III is the newest of the line's three passenger vessels. Built in 1995, the 1,210-ton ship is 230 feet long and can carry 125 passengers and a crew of 34. Its sister ship, Skorpios II, built in 1988 with similar dimensions and room for 35 more passengers, made the same cruise on the same schedule, usually dropping anchor at ports just before or after we did.
The next morning, after a late breakfast, we sailed south out of Puerto Montt, lounging on the sun decks and waving goodbye to the snow-topped volcano in the distance. The waiters brought us festive aperitifs, including pisco sours, a popular Chilean cocktail, made of a strong grape-based liquour, lemon juice, powdered sugar and egg white. Our voyage was taking us to the San Rafael Glacier and back, a distance of about 400 nautical miles each way. We would be sailing through interior coastal waters, among the hundreds of islands, islets and peninsulas that make up the far south of Chile.
Chile's weather, terrain and flora have much in common with the West Coast of the United States and Canada -- but with the seasons in reverse. It is a skinny country that stretches for nearly 3,000 miles along the west side of South America. The desert is in the far north, the central region has a temperate climate, and the south is similar to the Pacific Northwest -- a green and often rainy area with vast forests and good fishing.
We spent all of the first day sailing, passing through the Llanquihue Archipelago, the Gulf of Ancud and the Gulf of Corcovado. The scenery was a blend of tranquil farm scenes, an occasional fishing village and, in the distance, the lower Andes, dwindling down to a mere 7,000 to 8,000 feet.
At lunch, as the waiters generously poured fine Chilean wines, we all introduced ourselves and learned that we came from 14 countries. Argentines and Brazilians were the most numerous, followed by Chileans. Others came from elsewhere in Latin America. A few came from Europe and Japan, a family of three from Australia; I was the only passenger from the United States. Several children were aboard, ranging in age from 7 or 8 to the early teens. An English-speaking interpreter helped those who didn't speak Spanish.
Captain Kochifas told us his family's story. His father immigrated to Chile from Greece and eventually settled in Puerto Montt and set up a tailoring business. The sons, growing up surrounded by water and fishing boats, learned to sail. Starting from scratch, the captain first built and ran a series of small cargo ships, then some 20 years ago built his first passenger vessel and began to bring passengers to the island-studded seas and secret fjords. His older brother, Demostenes, was the second pilot on our ship. A son was the pilot of the Skorpios II. Other Kochifases were working behind the scenes.
The captain promised us a cocktail called a 12 and 30 once we reached the glacier. The ingredients: 12-year-old Scotch over 30,000-year-old ice -- the estimated age of the glacier. All of the ice we consumed on the ship came from the huge chunks that continually broke from the glacier and slipped into the surrounding lagoon. The glacier and lagoon are in a national park whose unique biosphere is recognized by Unesco; the ice is formed from snow falling on a peak seldom visited by humans.
We quickly settled into a pleasant routine of four meals a day -- breakfast, lunch, tea and dinner, plus morning and evening aperitifs with nuts and chips in the Apollo and Zeus bars. The menus ranged from haute cuisine to sturdy Chilean peasant fare, and it was all very good. Salmon, which is farmed along the coast in the area, was a staple along with other local fish including sea bass, and there were heaping platters of shellfish hauled aboard mid-voyage from small fishing boats. One night, the Chilean college student on my left put away almost six dozen oysters on the half shell. We also had steak and chicken, and the kitchen staff accommodated special requests made a few hours ahead.
The weather was ideal. It felt much warmer under the midsummer sun and cloudless skies than the projected 54 to 72 degrees.
On our third day out, however, I awoke and looked out the window to something awesomely different. The glacier was rising out of the surrounding gray mist as a steady rain beat down on the ship and the waters of the lagoon. The mass of ice glistened white and crystal blue. Two small ice cutters had been lowered from the ship and were waiting to carry us closer to the glacier. The rain was going to make our excursion rather cold and uncomfortable, but it lent drama to the day.
I put on layer upon layer of clothing; as we stepped onto the ice cutters, the crew handed out life jackets.
Approaching the glacier, we first noticed floating around us the huge chunks of ice, pieces that had broken off as if an artist had been wielding a chisel, creating free-form sculptures in strikingly varied shades of blue, gray, green and stark white.
San Rafael Glacier, the centerpiece of a national park of the same name, is part of an ice field created by ice and snow tumbling down Mount San Valentin, which towers 13,300 feet above the lagoon. The captain told us that the glacier was first seen by Europeans some 400 years ago and that, at the rate it wascrumbling, would be gone in 200 years. The ice field extends well inland from the lagoon into an area virtually inaccessible except by foot across rugged terrain. On maps of the region, the ice appears to cover about 60 miles north-south and roughly half that east-west. What we saw was a section an estimated 7,300 feet wide that forms an icy path between mountain peaks, rising 230 feet above the water and down more than 750 feet into the lagoon.
As promised, while we circled before the glacier, crew members jumped up onto one of the chunks of ice and chipped off enough to fill several ice buckets, then brought out fine glassware and poured everybody a hefty amount of Scotch over those crystal-clear rocks. They opened a hamper filled with small sandwiches and followed with hot coffee. With the food and drink gone -- along with most of our film -- we began to feel the chill and were more than ready to return to the comfort of the Skorpios III.
In the afternoon, as a whisper of sun began to peek through the clouds, Demostenes Kochifas guided the ship closer to the wall of ice, and some of us crowded around him on the bridge to watch as, every few minutes, a piece would split from the front of the glacier and cascade into the lagoon. Those of us with cameras tried capturing the moment when the ice splashed into the water.
At 5 P.M., we turned our backs on the glacier and sailed back toward sunny skies and warmer weather.
We reached Quitralco Fjord, jutting deep into another national park, this one covered with forests and fields of wildflowers. We dropped anchor beside a dining hall and thermal baths that the cruise line operates on the edge of the wilderness, and some passengers went ashore for a quick dip in the 90-degree waters.
The next morning, we raced in small boats through the fingers of water branching off from the main fjord, then returned for what Latin Americans call a parrillada -- a mixed-grill feast. We began with the tasty meat pies, empanadas, followed by steak, sausages, potatoes, salad and the usual good wines. On the wall behind our table were models of the nearly dozen boats and ships the captain had built. There were also old family photos and a big one of the captain and Gabriel Garcia Marquez, the Nobel Laureate in literature, together at the wheel.
From Quitralco, our ship continued lazily north, through countryside that had the look of Switzerland -- black and white cattle grazed in neat pastures on rolling hillsides, framed by vast stands of trees. We were back to basking in the sun in our bathing suits. On the west lay the large island Chiloe, some 125 miles long and one of the places identified with Darwin's voyage to the area on the Beagle in the 1830's.
Our last stop before returning to port was Castro, Chiloe's principal town and a significant fishing and artisan center. It also marked our return to the money economy. The night I boarded, I simply stashed my money in the mini-safe, and then enjoyed the unusual sensation of not having to spend any for the next five days. But now, it took cash to satisfy my urge to buy the hand-knit woolen cloche hat I found in the handicrafts market for $4. And then $30 more to buy a hand-woven woolen jacket.
But the true souvenir of the trip was that first sight of the glacier -- fixed in my mind, as a glimpse of what Heaven should be.
 
Booking a trip on Skorpios III
 
Getting There
 I flew American Airlines nonstop from Dallas to Santiago, then bought a round-trip ticket on Ladeco, a Chilean airline, to Puerto Montt, about 600 miles to the south. There is a flight every few hours on Ladeco or LAN Chile. By waiting until I got to Santiago to buy the ticket, I paid $250, while the price to buy it in advance in the United States was $376.
 
Contacting the Line
 The Skorpios III and her sister vessels, Skorpios I and II, sail between Puerto Montt and the San Rafael Glacier in the far south of Chile from September through May -- which covers the Southern Hemisphere's spring, summer and fall. For the 1999-2000 season, the weekly cruises began Sept. 4 and continue through the week of May 27.
Prices vary according to the month and the ship. High season runs from mid-December through mid-March, which is the Chilean summer. Everything else is low season.
On the Skorpios III, the newest of the three vessels, built in 1995, high season prices for a double cabin range from $3,400 to $5,000 a cabin, with suites at $5,300 and $5,800 a cabin. Low season prices range from $2,600 to $3,700 double and $3,850 and $4,100 for suites.
The Skorpios II, built in 1988, has prices ranging from $2,800 to $4,200 for double cabins in high season and from $2,100 to $3,220 in low season. She also has three- and four-person cabins with bunk beds, plus suites. The Skorpios I, built in 1978 and with bunk beds in many of the cabins, has doubles ranging from $2,100 to $3,240 a cabin in high season and $1,600 to $2,400 low season. It also has three-person cabins and some junior suites.
The prices cover everything on board -- four meals a day, cocktails and wine -- and the mixed grill at the cruise line's dining hall near Quitralco Fjord. I needed money during the cruise for taxis at a couple of fishing villages where we stopped, handicraft purchases and tips for the crew.
Pleasant as the cruise is, making arrangements for it from outside of Chile requires some tenacity. The cruise line has a Web site at www.skorpios.cl, where I found useful information on the schedule and itinerary, but when I used the E-mail address to ask about availability of particular dates, I got no response, even after a couple of proddings. Eventually, I called the cruise line's agency in Santiago, (56-2) 231-1030, fax (56-2) 232-2269, and quickly got answers and made a reservation. Telephone numbers for the Skorpios headquarters in Puerto Montt are (56-65) 255050, fax (56-65) 258315.
I was asked to pay by direct transfer to a bank in Miami, for which the agency in Santiago faxed me the necessary forms. But an Australian traveler on my voyage said he was able to pay by credit card at his hometown travel agency. SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN
