SECTION: Section 2; Page 41; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1615 words

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
A Photographer on the Blurred, Chaotic Edge

BYLINE: By VICKI GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
DAIDO MORIYAMA'S vision resides in the heart of darkness, literally and figuratively. The world he records is black, stunned rather than illuminated by light, threatening, chaotic, incomprehensible, compulsively erotic, obsessed, eccentric, fixated on consumption, devastated by accidents, always off kilter, sometimes ruined, sometimes empty -- a world unaware of its own instability, a world in need of Prozac.
His photographic technique, all blur and scratches, bleach and dust, joins with his subject matter to conjure documents on the verge of disintegration. At times Mr. Moriyama tinkers with the limits of perception, which he makes look hopelessly narrow, and with the limits of photography, which he makes seem very limited indeed. This is a tough vision, even a fierce one, individual, authentic and pursued to the far reaches of its own premises, and it can be seen all over New York right now.
 Born in 1938, Mr. Moriyama is one of Japan's most respected and influential contemporary photographers, but little known in America, though his work has appeared in group shows here, even in New York. 
 The first retrospective exhibition of Mr. Moriyama's photographs anywhere in the world (the Japanese not caring much for retrospectives of living photographers) is divided between "Daido Moriyama: Stray Dog" at the Japan Society Gallery on East 47th Street, which includes 130 photographs from several of his major series, and "Daido Moriyama: Hunter," 40 photographs from a 1972 series, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (both through Jan. 2). These joint shows were organized by the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (where it had its premiere last May) and the Japan Society Gallery. Sandra S. Phillips, the curator of photography at the San Francisco Modern, is the curator; an informative catalogue accompanies the exhibition.
In addition, the Laurence Miller Gallery, on 57th Street, has 32 prints by Moriyama, some not in either of the other exhibitions, and the Roth Horowitz Gallery, on East 70th Street, has an exhibition of photographs by Shomei Tomatsu, a major photographer whose work had a significant impact on Mr. Moriyama's. Roth Horowitz is also showing pictures from Provoke, a short-lived, extremely daring Japanese photography magazine of the late 1960's, as well as books by Provoke's contributors, including five by Mr. Moriyama, who almost always worked with books in mind.
A late 1960's series of nudes by Mr. Moriyama, evidently sex workers, with an occasional male leg or two in the picture, are at once flatly explicit and softly romantic, the bodies thrown so far out of focus that little besides the dark circles of the nipples and the dark patch of pubic hair confirm the subject matter. In 1972, when he and others had already tossed over the tradition of polished photographic techniques, Mr. Moriyama pushed the medium into illegible territories, as if to say that photography could not record what really mattered. In a book called Farewell Photography, not only are the photographs out of focus, scratched up and marred by dirt and light flares, but some of the subjects are also indecipherable, and some are apparently about nothing, emptiness, the void. Later he had a change of heart; after giving up photography for a couple of years, he returned to it in 1982 with colder but also clearer images, what might be called a more perfectly focused nihilism.
The eponymous stray dog appears in one picture as a shaggy beast, menacing, wary, a street wanderer looming enormous in the frame. At the Japan Society, an installation of 3,400 Polaroid images Mr. Moriyama took of his living and working space in 1997 (the only color in any of the shows) centers on this image. The photographer recently told Photo Metro magazine that when he photographs, he walks down the main thoroughfare, diving into and out of alleys, like a stray dog.
He is indeed an urban wanderer, an outsider, feral in his ways, often shooting from the hip, sometimes on the run, or from the shadows, through fences, from the windows of a moving car -- an image thief, snapping away on impulse and intuition in response to the crazy rhythms of the modern life. He also likes to make images of images, particularly movie posters advertising sex and violence. It is not always clear whether a photograph is of a picture or of the thing itself; by the 1960's the two were already nearly interchangeable.
Sometimes people pose for his camera, like a suburban couple clutching a box of detergent. More often he steals the picture. What he catches in his nearly random net is the peripheral vision of a city dweller, the bleary bits and fragments, the chance events and partly registered perceptions of our rapid daily rounds. "Chaotic everyday existence," he once said, "is what I think Japan is all about." When he has gathered sufficient chaos, he edits it into a detonating order all his own: pulsing, nonnarrative, ambiguous and textless pairs and sequences in magazines and books.
Attracted to outsiders and outlaws, Mr. Moriyama has photographed more than once where he is not welcome. A young woman in one picture races away frantically down a trash-filled alley. At a recent lecture, Mr. Moriyama said she was running because she had got in trouble with the yakuza (Japanese gangsters), and that he was beaten up and forced to rip his film out of his camera after he took the picture. As this was not his first such encounter, Mr. Moriyama had devised a way to keep his film intact while pulling a fresh roll out of the camera. The scent of something ominous that filters into his photographs begins to feel like a whiff of realism.
"I will go and take photographs," he told an interviewer, "as long as I still am capable of running away when someone tries to punch me. I can tumble." Mr. Moriyama is not the first who could make you think that a slight touch of craziness might be a valuable trait for those who want to be photographers; at any rate, he is obviously devoted to his profession and his subject.
THE catalogue, with essays by Ms. Phillips and Alexandra Munroe, Director of the Japan Society Gallery, fills in some background information on the Zeitgeist that put this work in motion and the context that surrounded it. There was, of course, the inescapable fact of two atom bombs dropped on Japan. Mr. Tomatsu, only eight years older than Mr. Moriyama, documented the direct effects of the bomb on survivors, but generations are so brief today (and Japan underwent such rapid and overwhelming changes) that someone eight years younger saw another society, shaped first by catastrophe but then reshaped by subsequent events. Americans were a major presence in Japan and American popular culture a major import. Mr. Moriyama was fascinated by the driving energy, the sex, modernization and liberal Western customs that were infiltrating Japan and forming new hybrids with the traditional culture.
Many Japanese were furiously resentful of the invading, occupying power, Mr. Moriyama apparently less so. Demonstrations against the treaty that allowed American military forces in Japan turned particularly violent in 1960. Strikes and student protests soon became more violent too, the Vietnam war making a profound contribution to the depth of the dissent. As in other places, the 1960's were a time of public turmoil, experiment and drugs, complicated in Japan by nuclear destruction, the miraculous economic rebirth of the country, and the bewildering atmosphere of transition between an old society and a new and foreign one.
Photographers, including Mr. Moriyama, needed a new way to respond to this wave of ferment and change that was engulfing their country. At Roth Horowitz, the display of Provoke magazine and books makes clear that he was not reacting alone but was part of a photographic movement that sprang up in Japan, with obvious affinities to movements in Japanese literature and film, in reaction to what amounted to an existential crisis as the frenetic modern world transformed the country.
Other countries had been experiencing related changes and upheavals. Globalization was already on its way, and artistic ideas traveled between continents on the backs of publications. Mr. Moriyama was shocked and influenced by William Klein's book of photographs of New York, published in Japan in 1957, with its raw vitality and confrontation, grotesqueries of the street and fierce disregard for technique. He took what he could use and moved on.
Later a friend showed him a Warhol catalogue that shocked him again with its emphasis on death and consumerism. Mr. Moriyama did a series of photographs of accidents, some of them details of a police safety poster. He also took pictures of canned goods on grocery store shelves, even Campbell soup cans. Where Warhol's repeated soup cans are clean, mechanically repetitive displays of forced cheerfulness -- the alluring calculus of a consumer culture -- Mr. Moriyama's are morose masses of identical labels rushing toward a numbing infinity of manufactured goods. By the 1970's, the economic boom had submerged the idealism of the 1960's in Japan as it had elsewhere, leaving frustration and discouragement in its wake.
An understanding of Japan's upheaval is probably crucial to an understanding of this work, and the influences count, too. But in the end, the artist is an individual with a mind and feelings and talent that nothing external can wholly account for. Different photographers using the same photographic language in the same places wrote different synopses of their times. Art continues to move in mysterious ways. Let us now give thanks for mysteries.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1313 words

HEADLINE: In the Region /New Jersey;
A $35 Million Luxury Rental Rises in Florham Park

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
LATE in the 1980's, a wooded 40-acre site along Columbia Turnpike in Florham Park was slated to become an office development. That project never moved forward and now the property has a new owner and a different future as a luxury rental community.
Avalon Bay Communities, a real estate investment trust based in Alexandria, Va., that builds only rental apartments, began work in June to turn the site, and two small nearby parcels totaling 1.5 acres, into 270 one- to three-bedroom town-house-style apartments with garages. There will also be an outdoor pool, a one-acre central green and a 3,500-square-foot clubhouse on the site at the northern edge of this Morris County borough. 
 Called Avalon at Florham Park, the project, estimated to cost $35 million to $40 million, will rise over the next 15 months. It is the sixth project in New Jersey for Avalon Bay, which since 1988 has built 2,268 rental apartments in the state. It also plans to start two more developments with a total of 704 units next year.
The Florham Park project is evidence that the state's rental market, like its other housing sectors, has benefited from the strong economy. Last year there were 5,097 housing permits issued for rentals, up from 3,346 in 1997 and from 3,122 in 1996, according to state figures. Still, the 1998 number represents only a fraction of the total of 35,721 permits issued that year.
Much of the new rental housing is going up in towers along the Hudson River waterfront. The activity thins out in the suburbs, but developers like Avalon Bay are moving in because they say the suburban rental market is not being adequately served.
"The demand is there because there haven't been a lot of rentals built in a long time in the suburbs," said Jan L. Decker, a principal at Integra Krauser & Cirz, a real estate advisory and services firm in Morristown. Ms. Decker, who specializes in multifamily housing, puts the rental vacancy rate in the state at 5 percent.
THERE are challenges to developing in the suburbs, she and other real estate professionals said. Among them are the lack of properly zoned land and community resistance to rentals, which many towns perceive as adding to their school-age population.
But many developers use the state's Mount Laurel doctrines as a way to maneuver their way into communities, Ms. Decker said. Those policies require each of the state's 566 municipalities to provide the opportunity for housing to be built for families who earn 50 to 80 percent of the median income in the area where the housing is being constructed.
Some of the new rental projects contain both market-rate apartments and units designed for tenants covered by the Mount Laurel policies. The market-rate apartments have high rents with increases just keeping pace with inflation, said Ms. Decker. Demand for rentals will continue to be steady least through next year, she added.
Avalon Bay's Florham Park project marks its entry into Morris County. Sandra F. Bertelsen, senior development director at the company's New Jersey operation in Princeton, said her company had targeted the county because "it has a tremendous number of corporate office users" and a large number of "high-end single-family-home choices" with few rental apartments.
Two other rental projects are under way in the borough, each with some low- and moderate-income units to help Florham Park just about complete its Mount Laurel obligation. Those projects, next to one another on Passaic Avenue in the borough's eastern sector, are Sun Valley at Florham Park with 305 units, 75 of them Mount Laurel rentals, and Riverbend, with 200 units, including 50 Mount Laurel units.
The two developments, along with a third completed project with 150 rentals, all of them low- and moderate-income apartments, are the result of a Mount Laurel court settlement, completing the town's obligation for 280 affordable units, said Dwight F. Longley, Florham Park's business administrator.
For Avalon Bay's project, Ms. Bertelsen said negotiations began two years ago with the borough to rezone the three commercially-zoned sites to residential use.
Mr. Longley said all the issues, from the project's impact on traffic to its effect on the borough's schools "were dealt with at length, and the decision was that the project fulfilled a perceived need for upscale dwellings." It is also expected to have "a nominal affect," on schools, he said. To help deal with the traffic impact, Mr. Longley said, the developer is putting the project's main entrance on Fernwood Road, a side street, rather than on the commercial Columbia Turnpike, and is installing a traffic light at the intersection of the two streets.
The town-house-style units at the project, designed by Lesserd Architectural Group of Vienna, Va., will be in 45 two- and three-story buildings that will be laid out in five city-like blocks on half the site, with the one-acre green at the center. The other 20 acres contain wetlands, which under state law cannot be developed and will remain open.
Each building will have four to eight 16-foot-wide units around an interior courtyard. The traditional-style buildings will have varying rooflines and each unit will have different brick and vinyl facades and separate entrances "so they look like row houses," Ms. Bertelsen said. The project "is intended to be consistent with the colonial image of the downtown," she added.
Monthly rents for 800 to 1,800 square feet are to be $1,400 to $2,500, Ms. Bertelsen said. Leasing is to begin in January.
WORK also is proceeding at the other rental projects, where construction has been delayed until recently because the developers needed to install sewer lines as well as build a sewage treatment station to accommodate their projects. That work is now under way.
"Because so few rentals are being built there is no competition but among ourselves," said Eric J. Harvitt, project manager at the 60-acre, 305-unit Sun Valley at Florham Park community. The project is being developed by a group of New Jersey developers under the corporate entity of Sun Valley at Florham Park, of Woodbridge.
There will be 230 two- and three-bedroom market-rate units, with garages. The larger duplex units, with 1,380 to 1,540 square feet are above the one-story smaller units, which will have 1,100 square feet plus a lower level recreation room, Mr. Harvitt said. The Mount Laurel units will be smaller. Planned amenities include a playground and tennis courts, he said, adding that two-thirds of the site will remain undeveloped because of wetlands.
Though rents have not yet been set Mr. Harvitt said they are not expected to be as high as those at Avalon Bay's project. Leasing will begin next summer when the initial units are completed, he said.
At the 30-acre Riverbend project the 200 units will sit on half the site along with a clubhouse and outdoor swimming pool. The other half will be left open because of wetland constraints, said Wayne Zuckerman, a principal of Sterling Properties of Livingston, which is developing the complex at an estimated cost of $25 million
"Because the demand is so strong," Mr. Zuckerman said, "the three projects will provide choices for renters, from young professional couples to empty-nesters."
The one- to three-bedroom apartments, including duplex units, have 950 to 1,250 square feet, and all have garages. The affordable units will be smaller. With completion over a year away rents have not been set, but will be competitive, said Mr. Zuckerman.
Sterling is also working on two other suburban rental projects. One, in Springfield, in Union County, has 75 apartments, including some low- and moderate-income units; the other, in Neptune in Monmouth County, has 81 market-rate units. "We build wherever we can find the land, which is a scarce commodity," Mr. Zuckerman said.

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 1; Column 4; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2412 words

HEADLINE: Nassau's Odd Election Season: Republicans Bicker, Dems Unite

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
WITH the election just a month away, this year's political season in Nassau County seems to be breaking all the political molds.
To start with, the leading spender is someone who's not even running. County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta isn't up for re-election until 2000, but his habit of running up giant budget deficits has become the overriding issue, and he is broadcasting $200,000 worth of television ads defending himself and his budget proposal for next year. 
 The Democrats campaigning for the County Legislature -- where all 19 seats are on the November ballot -- are trying to turn the election into a referendum on Mr. Gulotta. But the big twist is that Mr. Gulotta's fellow Republicans are publicly divorcing him, with a commercial in which the Legislature's presiding officer, Bruce A. Blakeman, promotes his own plan to solve the budget crisis.
Even Mr. Gulotta's old running mate, Comptroller Frederick Parola, has said that the county is "sinking in red ink" and denounced the latest budget proposal as "smoke and mirrors" and "another disingenuous financial document."
"I've never seen anything like it," said Desmond Ryan, executive director of the Association for a Better Long Island, a group of developers.
Those are not the only peculiarities in this year's campaign. For a change, the Democrats are not feuding among themselves. After years of fractious leadership fights, they appear united under their new chairman, Thomas P. DiNapoli. Although he is not running, he stars in Democratic ads as the spokesman for his party's slate.
The Democrats can barely contain their glee over the Republican split. "They're acting like us," Mr. DiNapoli said. "We're acting like them."
Most intriguing, anecdotal evidence indicates that a number of loyal Republicans throughout Nassau are fed up and say they are not going to take it anymore. "I have not yet met a Republican who says they're voting Republican in November," said Bruce Nyman, the city manager of Long Beach and former minority leader in the Legislature.
Over the last four months David W. Denenberg of Merrick has been knocking on thousands of doors as the Democratic nominee in the 19th District, including Bellmore, Merrick, Point Lookout and parts of Seaford, Wantagh and Freeport. "A lot of Republicans are saying, 'I'm a lifelong Republican, but I'm not voting Republican this year,' " he said. "The number who say, 'Do something about the budget,' is just unbelievable. The economy has never been this good, and for the county to be running a deficit is purely ridiculous mismanagement. If somebody can pull off an upset, this will be the year."
The 19th is one of several battlegrounds where the long-languishing Democrats say they have a chance to expand their delegation in the Legislature, where they hold only 5 of the 19 seats. But the ultimate question is whether there are enough disenchanted Republicans for the Democrats to overcome the odds and wrest control of the Legislature for the first time.
"It's the biggest issue that my party has faced in many years," said the Nassau G.O.P. chairman, Joseph N. Mondello, But he said that the Republican county legislators reject Mr. Gulotta's budget proposal and will adopt their own "even if it means taking on the county administration -- and that's what it's going to mean."
"It tends to confuse people and did nothing except hurt the Republican ads," Mr. Mondello said. "I called Tom Gulotta and asked him to stop the ad. He did not give me a yes or no."
The Republicans cannot be discounted. Sporadic Republican scandals and feuds have inspired Democratic hopes over the decades, but usually they have been dashed on election day. The Republicans still have lopsided enrollment margins in most districts, and political experts say that Nassau still has the nation's premier local Republican organization, with an unparalleled skill in fund-raising, flooding mailboxes and getting voters to the polls.
What do political polls show? The Democrats say they cannot afford them, and the Republicans are not releasing theirs. But the scuttlebutt is that Mr. Gulotta's usually high favorable ratings have plummeted and that the budget crisis is a drag on the Republican slate.
Even now, Democratic optimists seem a bit hesitant to dream. "We'd love to do it in 1999," Mr. DiNapoli said of his party's prospects for taking control, then cautiously added, "but we'd settle for 2001."
To do that, the Democrats would have to double their current 5-seat delegation to 10. At the bare minimum, they want to add two more seats this year. That would give them a taste of real power, since they could block the two-thirds vote needed to approve bond issues.
Topping the Democrats' list of targets is the 1st District, which was supposed to be a Democratic seat. But in both 1995 and 1997, the Democrats had divisive primaries, and in the general election that followed, a dissident Democrat ran on a splinter party line and split the vote. That handed victory to the Republican, Darlene D. Harris, a lawyer from Uniondale. This time, however, the Democrats are united -- no primary and no dissident candidate -- behind Patrick C. Williams Sr., a mortgage company executive from Uniondale.
The next Democratic target is the 5th District, including Rockville Centre, Baldwin, Oceanside, Freeport and South Hemsptead. The Republicans have a hefty 48.5 percent of the voters, with 27.2 percent for the Democrats. But a rare case of Republican infighting in 1995 enabled a Democrat to snare the seat. Reunified Republicans won it back in 1997. This time the Democrats are trying to recapture it by running a renegade Republican, Joseph K. Scannell, a former assistant district attorney from Baldwin, against the freshman incumbent, Thomas A. Glynn, a funeral director from Rockville Centre.
Democratic strategists cite three other races where, with a bit of luck, the tables could turn:
* The 18th District, including most of northern Oyster Bay Town, where the two-term incumbent Republican, John Canning, a lawyer from Sea Cliff, faces a spirited challenge from Dr. Brian T. Muellers of Glen Cove, the research and development director of the Pall Corporation. The Democrats hope to get a lift from the re-election bid of Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi and his slate in Glen Cove.
* The 7th District, the Five Towns area plus Island Park and Bay Park, Mr. Blakeman's seat. He is a rising star and a possible successor to Mr. Gulotta. But in a statewide race against Comptroller H. Carl McCall last year, Mr. Blakeman barely carried his district. His challenger this year is Jeffrey W. Toback, a lawyer from Oceanside who scored 46 percent last year for Town Board in Hempstead, the highest vote ever for a Democrat in that Republican bastion.
* The 19th District, where Mr. Denenberg, a lawyer specializing in patents and the environment, is making his bid. The Republican incumbent, Edward H. Ward of Seaford, agrees that this year is different. "When I go door to door, people say, 'What are you going to do about Gulotta -- get rid of him,' so he's hurting us," he said. "But my opponent's only program is trying to connect me to Gulotta. That's their M.O. I'm being attacked for everything Gulotta has done from birth."
Mr. Ward stresses his record on neighborhood issues and promises that the deficit will be plugged. But with the budget adoption process on a dual track with the campaign -- the deadline for passage is three days before the election -- that issue will remain at center stage.
The budget presents both opportunity and danger. If the Republican legislators come up with a plausible solution, they bolster their campaigns. To the extent they change Mr. Gulotta's proposal, they distance themselves from him. But the deficits are so big -- $192 million last year, a gap estimated at up to $140 million this year and suspected gaps in the proposal for next year -- that the remedies could entail unpopular tax increases and program cuts.
"It's going to take more than cosmetic surgery," Mr. Blakeman said. John V. N. Klein, a Republican and the former Suffolk County Executive, said: "They're going to have to administer medicine, and a big dose. The upside is it demonstrates the leadership people are looking for."
Voter backlash could result, however, and the election-eve timing may be attacked as belated and suspect. "The stupid thing from a political point of view is to adopt the budget right before the election," said Dr. Stanley B. Klein, a political science professor at C. W. Post College and an active Republican in Suffolk. "The legislators can become the bad guys."
Democrats are trying to pin the deficits on both Mr. Gulotta and the Republican legislators. "They can say from now to doomsday they're separating themselves from the County Executive," said Judith A. Jacobs, the minority leader in the Legislature, "but they're the ones who rubber-stamped his programs, who voted for his 1 percent real estate transfer tax."
The Republican retort is that they have trimmed $100 million from Mr. Gulotta's last three budgets, and though that was not enough, they will do more. "We've been the ones at the forefront of change," said Mr. Blakeman. "It's just going to take more change than before." He challenged the Democrats: "They have never proposed their own alternative budget. What's your plan?"
Democrats have called for a fiscal oversight board, which the Republicans resisted in favor of an advisory panel, and have also proposed more competitive bidding and cuts in patronage jobs, in cars for officials and in fees paid to outside lawyers. The Republican plan includes cutting outside lawyers and consultants and the salaries of top officials, and pay freezes for nonunion workers.
Mr. Gulotta's plan includes higher property taxes, a new telephone tax, reduced staffing and unpaid furloughs.
The budget crisis seems to have struck a nerve because Nassau is among the wealthiest counties in the nation, and these are booming times. From Washington to Albany to New York City, governments are piling up surpluses and cutting taxes. Next door, Suffolk County is balancing its books, cutting property and sales taxes and hiring more police. "People are frustrated that our county is in the red when everyone around them is in the black," Ms. Jacobs said.
"It's a pocketbook issue," Professor Klein said. "For the first time since the Legislature was created, there is a countywide issue of very high visibility that really affects property owners. The Democrats have a chance to unseat some Republican legislators. If I were Mondello, I would be running around screaming."
Mr. Gulotta, re-elected two years ago in a landslide, suddenly finds himself isolated. His policies are attacked by the Democratic State Comptroller and Republican County Comptroller, and the bond market has dropped the county's credit rating to barely above junk bond status. In recent weeks he has lost yet another budget director, his county attorney and his press secretary.
Yet Mr. Gulotta sounds unflappable as ever. Defending his television ad, he called it "very similar" to Mr. Blakeman's. "The ads, if you listen to the text, really complement each other," he said. "It demonstrates that the Republicans are working together and have a solution that will eliminate the deficit."
But Mr. Blakeman issued a warning. "We would prefer that the County Executive not interject into this election, since he is not running," he said. "We will continue to demonstrate our independence as a separate branch of government. The Legislature doesn't run the day-to-day operations and wasn't designed to. But we may have to break the traditional barriers, because the county has not lived within the budget we have given them in the past."
Professor Klein said of the Republican feud, "They have moved about as far apart from him as they can and still be under the same banner."
Improved chances of winning have attracted stronger candidates, the Democrats say. "This is probably the best crop we've run for the Legislature," said Mr. DiNapoli. Among them is Matthew A. Cuomo, a lawyer from East Williston, a nephew of the former Governor, Mario M. Cuomo.
Campaign funds are is crucial, and the Republicans are said to be spending hundreds of thousands of dollars. The Democrats cannot match that, but Mr. DiNapoli is getting donations for the television ads and hopes to have a rally with Hillary Clinton. Candidates are also foraging on their own. Mr. Denenberg, for example, has raised $30,000 so far.
Turnout, most experts agree, will be a key to the outcome. Unhappy Republicans may simple stay home, so Democrats say they have to get their own forces out. "Nassau Democrats are infamous for not voting in off-year local elections, and this is as off a year as you can get," said Mr. Nyman.
Republican leaders, who usually compete to see who can get out the biggest vote, must switch to a completely different strategy this time. "I don't envy Joe Mondello this year," said Mr. Nyman. "This isn't going to be an traditional vote-pulling operation. Before, it was easy. You looked in the voter book and whoever had an R next to their name, you called them. Now you have as many angry R's as D's."
One Republican committeeman, speaking on the condition of anonymity, confirmed that the party is trying to identify still-loyal Republicans. "It's almost like a stealth campaign," he said.
Forecasts of the outcome vary wildly. "This may be the best chance the Democrats have had since Lyndon Johnson and Barry Goldwater," said Mr. Nyman, although he concedes it would be hard for them to take control. Mr. Gulotta said: "I believe that the Republican candidates are going to do extremely well, much better than some might anticipate, and there's a good chance they might capture one or more Democratic districts."
One confidant of the leaders at Republican headquarters in Westbury, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said: "There are a lot of sleepless nights in Westbury. The Republicans are beside themselves. It is a party at war with itself. There's a quantifiable fear that Tom Gulotta could singlehandedly cripple their pluralities."
Professor Klein predicted that the Republican margins will shrink and they will likely lose some ground but not control. "At best the Democrats pick up a few seats," he said. "They will be delirious, and the Republican will feel destroyed."

HEADLINE: In the Region /Westchester;
For Port Chester, a $120-Million Riverfront Project

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

DATELINE: PORT CHESTER

 BODY:
AN ambitious $120-million redevelopment project was given final approval last week by this two-and-a-half-square-mile village, known for its distinctive globe lighting downtown and its multi-ethnic variety of restaurants.
The 27-acre project is designed to attract new tenants to its downtown riverfront. In the process, it will displace some existing businesses. 
 The village gave its final approval last Wednesday and one of the developer's principals said he was negotiating with existing tenants, either working them into the project or helping them find another downtown location. If necessary, the village could also take over property by eminent domain.
"We're trying to start a rebirth of Port Chester," said Gregg Wasser, a principal with G & S Investors, of Old Bethpage, N.Y., the designated developer for the project. "We want to bring in stores that will generate interest, and attract business from the surrounding area, things like a multiplex movie theater, a supermarket, clothing retailers and fun, entertainment-type activities."
As now envisioned, the 483,000-square-foot development will include some new construction, as well as the rehabilitation of existing businesses in an area bounded by South Main Street and the Byram River and Westchester and Purdy Avenues.
In addition to entertainment and retail components, the project will include a riverfront park, marina and promenade, as well as surface and garage parking for 1,850 cars, Mr. Wasser added, noting that G & S Investors was using its own equity and bank loans to finance the complex.
"We're trying very hard to work with everyone," Mr. Wasser said. "We want to be as fair and generous as possible with everyone. In the end, we want everyone to be happy."
The only new tenant to sign on so far is Costco, a leading chain of discount-club warehouse stores, which will occupy a two-story 140,000-square-foot store at Westchester Avenue and Traverse Street. "It will occupy one and a half acres and replace some old industrial buildings on the site now," Mr. Wasser said.
He said that it would be only the second two-level store in the Costco chain.
"Since it's a downtown location, we thought it was important that it fit in with the prevailing architecture and not be a sprawling concrete structure typical of that kind of retailer," said Mr. Wasser, who built a Costco in New Rochelle.
Mr. Wasser said that he hoped to have the first building in the overall project started by March or April. "The first phase should take about nine to 15 months, then the next phase about six months," he added. "We expect the whole project to take two to three years to complete."
For years, Port Chester has been approached by movie operators who wanted to build a multiplex theater in the village, said Mayor Christine Korff. "But we always envisioned a movie theater as part of a whole development complex," she said. "We wanted to build something that would fit in with our whole downtown."
She now sees Costco, a multiplex theater and a supermarket as the anchors of a project that will include "stores selling books, linens, apparel."
"And we'd like to also have two restaurants," she added, "one near the theater for the after-movie crowd, and maybe an open-air seafood place near the marina."
Similar waterfront projects are also under discussion for Yonkers, Tarrytown, Peekskill and New Rochelle, all with the same intention of attracting business and people to the waterfront, and replacing industrial buildings with new development.
THE Village of Port Chester has a rich industrial past. It was originally known as Sawpits because of the prevalence of sawmills in the area. In the 1830's residents changed the name to Port Chester after Chester, England, the birthplace of many of its early settlers.
For years, the village was home to a number of industries, the last of which was a Life Savers plant that closed in 1984 and had since been converted into condominiums.
Today, the downtown's image is somewhat mixed. North Main Street was refurbished in 1987 when the street was widened and lined with 80 saplings. Overhead wiring and utility poles were replaced with 49 Victorian-era lamps, each with four globes, resulting in one of the most distinctive night-time streetscapes in the county.
While North Main Street still has its share of vacant storefronts, it has also attracted most of the village's more than 100 restaurants, where cuisines include South African, Brazilian, Ecuadorean and Peruvian.
South Main Street, in contrast is "underutilized," the Mayor said. It has been more hampered by vacancies and outmoded businesses. "It has a laundromat and some small stores," the Mayor said, "but also a lot of vacant lots and buildings."
The redevelopment plan will attempt to save buildings in the designated area that have architectural interest, said Mr. Wasser. "We want whatever is built there to fit in with what's there that's worth preserving," he added.
There have been several other development plans for the area, the most ambitious proposed more than a decade ago by the Robert Martin Company. Approved in 1986, the $250-million project included a 315,000-square-foot shopping center, 660 apartments, a 20-screen movie theater and a waterfront park and promenade.
"That one fell through for a variety of reasons, mostly to do with the timing," Mayor Korff said. "It was to be built at the time when the real estate market fell off."
The current project is different, the Mayor said, in that it doesn't include housing. "We didn't want a residential component," she said. "We don't want our schools taxed any more."
Like many other school districts in the county, Port Chester's has experienced increasing enrollment, which has resulted in overcrowding at some grade levels. "We've already had to add classrooms to our four elementary schools," Mayor Korff said. "We want this project to help with our tax base, not add more expense."
Not everyone in the village is happy about the redevelopment plans, including some merchants who have yet to work out a deal with G & S Investors. Tav Passarelli, owner and operator of Westchester Marina Services and Ebb Tide Rentals, both on the Byram River, is one of the dissidents.
"I don't want to lose my business," Mr. Passarelli said. "If they come in here and want to move me, where am I going to go? There's no other place on the water available, and that's where I need to be. I don't see how they can help me."
Mr. Wasser said that he was determined to work out compromises with Mr. Passarelli and any other retailer. "We want this to work out for the village in the long term," he said. "And that's only going to happen if everybody's happy."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2858 words

HEADLINE: Easing the Rules for Mortgage Approval

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
THE sisters Arlene Jones and Judith George are close. They grew up together in the Virgin Islands, and after they arrived in Brooklyn in 1978, when they were in their early 20's, they lived in apartments two blocks apart.
They long hoped to own homes near each other, and this year they achieved that goal. They moved into side-by-side two-family houses on Elton Street in the East New York section of Brooklyn, each paying $175,000 for a house newly built through the New York City Housing Partnership program. 
 "We were lucky to find it," said Ms. Jones, who is an executive assistant at Keyspan Energy, the parent company of Brooklyn Union Gas. When they were house-hunting the builder still had adjoining houses available in a development of 40 houses that were in construction.
They were lucky for a less obvious reason as well. In considering them for a mortgage, Chase Manhattan Bank let them count most of their prospective rental income in a way that qualified them for the loan they needed. They would not have qualified for their loans if the bank had used traditional underwriting standards.
The less restrictive standards have come into wider use in recent years in the sales of homes that have at least one rental apartment. They have had the effect of allowing creditworthy borrowers with somewhat lower incomes -- usually close to the median family income in New York City of $50,000 a year -- to buy houses. Ms. Jones and Ms. George have incomes in the $40,000-a-year range.
The basic change is that in determining the borrower's ability to afford the loan, a large portion of the rent that will be collected is applied as an offset to the monthly costs the borrower will bear. Buyers for years have thought that they were doing just that by getting a rental tenant or two. But the principle had not been generally embraced by mortgage lenders in loan underwriting. Instead, a portion of rental income was merely added to the buyer's gross income to determine eligibility. This creates a higher ratio of housing costs to income than the new method does.
For the buyer who can afford a 5 percent down payment, the new method makes it more likely he will qualify for a loan of 95 percent of the purchase price of a two-family house.
"A significant number of two- to four-family home buyers have benefited from this approach," said Wesley A. Wainwright, senior vice president of Chase Manhattan Bank in charge of residential lending in the Community Development Group.
Since 1986, the major banks supporting the New York City Housing Partnership's program of new-home construction for moderate-income buyers have used this approach in qualifying purchasers. But it got greater impetus in 1994 when Fannie Mae, the nation's largest purchaser of mortgages from banks and other home-mortgage originators, introduced pilot programs to stimulate the home sales market in New York and Boston. Fannie Mae packages these loans with other mortgages as securities for sale to investors. Creating a market to which mortgage originators can sell their loans encourages them to lend more.
Under the Fannie Mae pilot program, the houses may be either newly built or previously occupied. The purchasers do not have to be first-time buyers, although most have been. The buyers must live in the house they buy, and if they formerly owned a home, they have to have sold it before they close on the new one. There are no income restrictions on buyers.
In a typical situation, a creditworthy buyer with an income of about $45,000 in wages and the ability to make a 5 percent down payment would qualify for a 95 percent mortgage on a two-family house costing about $200,000, Fannie Mae said. This assumes that the apartment would rent for about $800 a month. Previously the same buyer would probably have needed $55,000 a year in income to qualify for the loan.
Since the pilot program began, it has been used in about 10 percent of all the loans for two-family to four-family houses in New York City that Fannie Mae has purchased, the company said. Last year, Fannie Mae's total purchases of New York City two- to four-family loans was 4,200 -- with an aggregate value of $788 million -- and 11 percent used the pilot underwriting.
"It seems to be having its greatest effect in Brooklyn and Queens, and especially for two-family homes," said Naomi Bayer, director of the New York office of Fannie Mae, which was established in Manhattan four years ago. She also said that most buyers may not need such financing, because they have higher incomes or can make a higher down payment. They also may not know about it, she said, so they may not ask their lender about it.
The monthly payment that a home buyer makes to a lender covers not only the principal and interest due on the mortgage loan but also contributions to escrow accounts for real-estate taxes and insurance, and, in many cases, private mortgage insurance on that portion of the debt that exceeds 80 percent of the value of the house. Bankers refer to the monthly payment they receive for these obligations as the "PITI" payment, an acronym for principal, interest, taxes and insurance.
Under the pilot program, the bank, in calculating how large a loan it will offer to the purchaser of a two-family house, uses 75 percent of the buyer's anticipated rental income as an offset to this monthly payment. The minimum down payment is 5 percent, and the buyer must have at least $1,000 a month in additional income after the monthly payment is made.
The standards are slightly different for three- and four-family houses, but the principle is the same. These buyers must put down at least 10 percent, and the income they have left after their monthly payment must be higher -- at least $1,250 for a three-family loan and $1,350 for a four-family.
IN standard underwriting of residential mortgages, rental income is considered too. But it is added to the buyer's gross income rather than deducted from monthly costs for purposes of calculating how large a loan the borrower can afford. The standard approach leads to a more conservative loan.
The pilot program has been been used by buyers spending over $300,000 for a two-family house, bankers say. The national 1999 limits on loans that Fannie Mae will buy -- $240,000 for a one-family house, $307,100 for a two-family, $371,200 for a three-family and $461,350 for a four-family -- apply to the pilot program as well.
Fannie Mae requires that first-time buyers get counseling both in home ownership and in acting as a landlord before it will buy these loans. In resale housing only landlord counseling is required.
Patrick J. McEnerney, president of the Bank of New York Mortgage Company, said that it is only in the last year or year and a half that the new Fannie Mae standards have become widely available in three-family and four-family sales, although in two-family sales they have generally been used.
"It always take a little time for the lending community to get comfortable with new standards," Mr. McEnerney said, "and we're only beginning to get enough data on the performance of these loans to the threes and fours."
One older house was purchased recently by Dimitriy Bobkov, 23, an information specialist with I.B.M., who arrived in the United States from Ukraine five years ago, and his brother Vitaliy, 31, who is a self-employed computer technician. Their combined income is about $80,000 a year, Dimitriy Bobkov said.
The brothers bought a three-family house for $194,000 in the Sea Gate section of Brooklyn a year ago with a Bank of New York mortgage, and also spent about $25,000 to improve it, doing much of the work themselves. They are getting $500 a month in rent from a tenant, a friend who agreed to rent the apartment before the brothers bought the house. They received a $174,600 mortgage at conventional rates.
"Possibly we could have gotten another loan but it would have been much more trouble," Dimitriy Bobkov said. "We would have had to put 20 percent down instead of 10 percent." And the rent calculation would have been less favorable.
More liberal underwriting also carries risks, for both the lender and the borrower. Nowadays many lenders are offering subprime loans, for example, which go to less creditworthy borrowers and carry higher-than-normal interest rates. Presumably, during a period of prosperity and high employment borrowers in general will be successful in carrying this debt burden.
But many lenders and housing specialists caution buyers about becoming too dependent on rent. What happens in a recession, and a weakened housing market, when both buyers and renters may face a loss of income? If the tenant cannot afford the rent, will he leave quickly and be replaced by another tenant at the same rent? If the owner has to seek an eviction in housing court, will he get quick action or have to go for months with no rent collections?
"The Fannie Mae program is a fabulous thing if it's used correctly and not abused," said Keith Kantrowitz, president of Power Express, a mortgage company in Great Neck, N.Y. He said that about 20 percent of the resales of two- to four-family houses that Power Express finances in the city use the Fannie Mae pilot program.
"If the program were not there, many buyers would be forced to use subprime loans to buy their house, if they could buy at all," he said.
But some buyers overlook potential problems that mortgage underwriting does not take into account, he said, and then they lack the resources to deal with them. There can be overoptimism on the rents that can be obtained and unanticipated problems with basic housing systems. Heating costs and water and sewer charges may turn out to be beyond expectations, and the cost of gardening and cable service may have been overlooked.
Mr. Kantrowitz said he had already seen evidence of negative effects. Over the last five years, there have been seven foreclosures in loans Power Express financed, more than would be expected in an upward market, he said, because buyers facing foreclosure might be expected to sell and move. In one case, a borrower of $211,000 made 40 payments on time and then abruptly stopped paying for a full year, Mr. Kantrowitz said.
"The tenant simply stopped paying the rent, and the owner can't get him out," he said. "And the house isn't salable. Who would buy a house when the tenant's not paying?"
In another case, a 1996 buyer of a three-family house in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn with two tenants in place made only three payments on a $221,000 loan. "She moved into an area where the cost of child care was much higher than she expected," he said, "and then the cost of heating buried her." It was winter and she was getting heating bills of $600 a month. She had budgeted $150 a month.
"You don't go into a house in December on a budget that uses average year-round heating costs," Mr. Kantrowitz said.
In new housing, some of these problems are minimized. The owner gets to select the tenant -- many times a family member -- and operating costs are more clearly foreseeable. Tax abatements for new home construction, which are passed on to buyers, also are a big help. "For a novice in home ownership, the new house has great advantages," Mr. Kantrowitz said.
ANOTHER advantage for any owner is a healthy rental market. Rising rents may help the home buyer even in the early years of ownership.
In the Highbridge section of the Bronx, Isabel Santos has had a positive experience with tenants. She said she was well aware of the risks she was taking on when she bought a new three-family house on Woodycrest Avenue through the Partnership program for $322,000 five years ago. "I was worried about my ability to find responsible tenants," said Ms. Santos, who is in her 50's and a field worker for a union, earning in the high $40,000-a-year range.
As it turned out out, she has not only had regular rent collections, but also the rents have risen -- from a total of $1,640 for the two apartments to $1,725, which fully covers her monthly housing costs. "I didn't even have to advertise for tenants," Ms. Santos said. "They're both friends of mine, and one is a colleague at work."
In the Housing Partnership program, nonprofit organizations working with lenders provide budgeting and landlord counseling. The Partnership itself, in collaboration with developers, provides instruction on homeowner maintenance, and it expects in the future to take on both aspects of owner education.
There have been 14,000 Partnership home buyers since 1986, and more and more of the newer houses are three-families. Nowadays the loans are normally sold to Fannie Mae, and the underwriting for them follows Fannie Mae's standards.
"We couldn't be developing two-and three-family houses without the Fannie Mae underwriting," said Gale Kaufman, vice president of the Housing Partnership. Rental income is a secure form of income, she said, and the renters are often the owner's relatives. Loans made under the Partnership program have a default rate of less than 1 percent, Ms. Kaufman said.
But as in any home purchase -- whether a new house or a resale -- buyers are responsible for their own decisions. The obvious precaution they are advised to take before they buy the house is to have it inspected. This is often done in a cursory way, however, by buyers eager to save money or lock in the purchase with a contract so as not to lose out to another buyer.
"Nowadays there's pressure being put on buyers to go into contract within 10 days," said Donald J. Siracusa, whose home-inspection business, Absolute Building Inspections Ltd., is based in Bay Terrace, S.I. Buyers are often not willing to take the time or pay the price for a proper inspection by a professional certified by the American Society of Home Inspectors, in Des Plaines, Ill., said Mr. Siracusa.
"There's such a lack of knowledge." he said. "Many buyers don't even read the report when they get one. Or they hire people unqualified to make them, who are too close to the sales broker." The cost of a proper inspection for a two-family house on Staten Island has been about $350, Mr. Siracusa said. The reports that he gives to customers, with photographs, are in narrative form.
Fannie Mae made the following comparison to explain how the pilot program would make a two-family home purchase affordable while conventional underwriting would not.
In Fannie Mae's conventional underwriting for two-family home loans nationally, buyers must make at least a 10 percent down payment (but only 5 percent in New York City, and 3 percent for single-family houses). In addition, 75 percent of the owner's rental income from the rental apartment would added to the buyer's annual income to calculate eligibility.
So if the house costs $200,000 and the buyer earns $44,000 and can collect $850 a month in rent, the buyer's income would be considered $51,644 a year. Three-quarters of the rent -- $637 a month, or $7,644 a year -- would be added to annual income.
Although this buyer might be able to make a 5 percent down payment, his application to borrow $190,000 would probably be denied. A 30-year loan at 7.5 percent interest, plus payments to escrow accounts for taxes and insurance, would bring the applicant's monthly payments to about $1,660, or $19,920 a year. This is 38 percent of the buyer's gross annual income of $51,650. The normal limit in affordable-housing programs is 33 percent.
In the pilot program, no more than a 28 percent ratio of housing costs to income is allowed (but 33 percent for new houses in the Partnership program). The $44,000-a-year buyer would find the $190,000 loan affordable. His monthly obligation would be only $1,023 after deducting 75 percent of the rental income ($1,660 minus $637). On an annual basis, net housing payments would be $12,276 ($19,920 minus $7,644), or 27.9 percent of his income.
AFTER all the calculations are made, the lender would take into account the buyer's residual income after his monthly payments, to assure that the borrower is not overly dependent on rental income.
Arlene Jones, who bought the house in East New York next door to her sister Judith, a Board of Education employee in downtown Brooklyn, said that they had advertised for a renter in the Amsterdam News and received about 60 phone responses.
A representative of the Brooklyn Neighborhood Improvement Association, which assists moderate-income home buyers, interviewed three of these respondents. Only that many were willing to risk $50 for an interview and credit check.
One tenant was selected by Ms. George. Ms. Jones re-advertised and then found one. The rent levels turned out to be higher than those used in the underwriting, by $50 a month in one case and $80 in the other, Ms. Jones said.
The sisters have been in their homes for two months. Ms. Jones, who has four daughters ranging in age from 7 to 22, said her family had lived for 20 years in an apartment that had only one bathroom. Now she has two. She also has her own parking place, on her own property right next to her house.
"I love it," she said.

HEADLINE: SENIORITY;
When SavingsBonds Sputter

BYLINE: By FRED BROCK; Fred Brock is an editor at The Times. His column on the approach to and arrival at retirement appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: fbrock@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
LAST May, Richard P. Drury, 74, a retired civilian employee of the Army who lives in Hilton Head, S.C., was reading a newspaper article that led him to a startling discovery: 15 United States savings bonds held by him and his wife, Carol -- and worth a total of $3,707.90 -- had not been earning any interest for at least three years.
He immediately cashed in these Series E bonds, which he had acquired for $562.50 through a payroll deduction savings plan, and stuck the money in a bank account. 
 Before reading the article, Mr. Drury had no idea that the Government changed its rules about such bonds in 1965. Under that revision, Series E bonds issued through November 1965 earn interest for 40 years; those issued in December 1965 and later earn interest for just 30 years.
"I never knew that," Mr. Drury said. "All the information I had been reading was printed prior to 1965 and it said 40 years. Can you imagine the number of drawers or safety deposit boxes throughout this country that are just salted up with bonds like these?"
Daniel J. Pederson, a former supervisor of the savings bond division of the Federal Reserve and the author of "Savings Bonds: When to Hold, When to Fold and Everything in Between" (Sage Creek Press, fourth edition, $19.95), has calculated that there are more than $6.5 billion in savings bonds that have stopped earning interest and have never been cashed in. Some people tuck away savings bonds and forget about them; others mistakenly think that the bonds will earn interest as long as they hold them.
Savings bonds are popular, especially with older investors. Over all, 55 million people hold a total of $180 billion of savings bonds of all types.
People like the bonds because they are easy to buy and, though the various interest rates may be modest, their safety is rock solid. And because you don't get the interest until you cash in the bonds, taxes can be deferred until then, too.
The popular Series EE bonds, the successors to Series E, can be bought for as little as $25 each with a face value of $50; the most expensive cost $5,000, with a face value of $10,000. Bonds reach "original maturity" when they are worth their face value; they continue to earn interest until they expire, but at differing rates.
As a result, figuring out when to cash in a bond can be tricky, Mr. Pederson points out. It can make sense to redeem a bond early if it is paying a particularly low rate, but the problem is identifying the rate a bond is paying.
Because banks make virtually no money from savings bonds they sell and redeem, they have little incentive to train employees in the details of savings bond management. And because savings bonds are a do-it-yourself investment, Uncle Sam, despite switching the rules from time to time, doesn't send you a statement outlining your holdings.
If you're not sure of the status of a bond, look first at the issue date in the upper right corner. Any bonds issued from 1941 through October 1959 have stopped paying interest, as have bonds issued from December 1965 through October 1969.
Series EE bonds, which were first issued in 1980, earn interest for 30 years from the issue date. The same is true for the new Series I bond, whose return is linked to the Consumer Price Index.
Interest rates depend on when a bond was bought. Newly purchased Series EE bonds earn a market-based rate equal to 90 percent of the average of Treasury issues with five years left to maturity. The rate, currently 4.31 percent, is reset every six months. Inflation-protected Series I bonds now pay 5.05 percent.
"Each bond needs to be looked at as an individual investment," Mr. Pederson said.
It is difficult for most bond holders to even calculate how much interest they have accumulated -- and how much their bonds are therefore worth. Mr. Pederson's company, the Savings Bond Informer in Detroit (800-927-1901), appraises savings bonds for clients based on a sliding scale. For 1 to 10 bonds, for example, the fee is $15; for 700 bonds, it is $119. A report analyzes each bond for a number of factors, including the current rate it is earning, and offers advice on the best time to sell it. The Savings Bond Informer also has a Web site (www.bondhelp.com).
The Government, meanwhile, offers a somewhat similar but less extensive service free on the Web, at www.savingsbonds.gov. It requires downloading and installing a program called the Savings Bond Wizard on your personal computer.
AFTER his discovery, Mr. Drury had some of his older bonds appraised by Mr. Pederson's company. So did Walter H. Smorowski, 79, who lives in Des Plaines, Ill.
Mr. Smorowski, also alerted by a newspaper article, realized that he had about $6,000 of Series E bonds that were no longer paying interest. Before cashing them in, he got a report from the Savings Bond Informer that told him exactly how much they were worth. It was a good thing, he said, because his bank at first wanted to give him $1,000 less. The bank quickly corrected its error.
"If I hadn't gotten that report, I probably would have just taken what they offered me," Mr. Smorowski said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Chasing the Gum Chewers of Russia

BYLINE: By JOHN VAROLI 

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG

 BODY:
ONCE a forbidden pleasure denounced by Soviet officialdom, chewing gum has become entrenched in Russian pop culture.
Consumer demand for gum has led to a $180 million market -- and, over the last two years, has brought investments of more than $170 million by international manufacturers in Russian operations. 
 The William Wrigley Jr. Company of Chicago, the world's largest chewing-gum company with global sales of $1.8 billion last year, has captured about 60 percent of the Russian market, according to A. C. Nielsen, the market research company. But in the battle for shelf space in Russian stores, kiosks and cafes, Wrigley has been dogged by an upstart from Denmark, a family-owned company named Dandy, maker of the Stimorol and Dirol brands, with $300 million in worldwide sales. Although its figure does not jibe with the Nielsen number for Wrigley, Dandy claims 45 percent of the Russian market.
While younger consumers can hardly remember life without gum, those in their late 20's and older have a different story to tell.
"When I was a little girl, my swimming coach would tell us that foreigners put needles in chewing gum to hurt Russian children," recalled Anastasia Vasilevskaya, 28, now deputy director of a British-owned real estate company in St. Petersburg. "This was their way to keep us from chewing gum," she said, adding, "I often chew it now."
Viktor Voronkov, a sociologist in St. Petersburg, said, "Thanks to the efforts of Soviet propaganda, there existed a stereotype of the uncultured American chomping on gum in the most disgusting manner."
"Why chewing gum?" he added. "Well, it was just an accidental symbol of the American way of life, which was labeled antagonistic to the Soviet life style."
With Russia embracing a market economy, many young people are buying gum, even though the average monthly salary is only 1,000 rubles, or about $40.
"Confectionery is one of the first to rebound after any crisis since prices are relatively low and affordable to the general population," said Philip Wegh, director of the new Dandy factory.
Kim Iskyam, a consumer goods analyst at Renaissance Capital, a Moscow-based investment bank, said Wrigley and Dandy "are interested in Russia because it is a large market that is still in its infancy, being relatively unsaturated." Renaissance Capital is part of Sputnik Holdings, owned by the Russian-American financier Boris Jordan.
Since the Russian financial crisis of August 1998, the ruble has fallen from around 6 to the dollar to a little over 25, sharply raising the cost of most domestic goods as well as imports. Wrigley and Dandy, because of their intense rivalry, have not raised prices as much as most manufacturers, though a packet of chewing gum has climbed to 6 or 7 rubles, from 3 before the crisis.
Evidence of the battle can be seen on television, where Russians are bombarded by advertising for Dandy's Dirol and Wrigley's Doublemint, Juicy Fruit and Orbit, a brand popular in Europe though virtually unknown in the United States.
In Wrigley's testimonial ads, young Russians praise Wrigley's "amazingly long-lasting flavor."
In addition, both companies are emphasizing what they call "dental positioning."
"Dirol is functional chewing gum, and in our ads we try to communicate the benefits of chewing it in the fight against tooth decay," said Stanislav Cherkasov, Dandy's media and public relations manager.
An even stronger indication of the foreign companies' commitment to the Russian market is the money spent building plants here. The $70 million Wrigley plant in St. Petersburg began production in late winter and will produce 15,000 tons of gum annually, not only for Russia, which Wrigley says is one of its top 10 markets, but also for export to Europe. Such exports would be important in case of persistent economic difficulties in Russia.
Dandy built a $95 million plant in Veliky Novgorod, 112 miles southwest of St. Petersburg, where it will make 7,000 tons of Stimorol and Dirol a year. Lars Funder, general director of Dandy, said it was "100 percent committed to the Russian market."
Wrigley executives were also upbeat. "Our sales last year in Russia were around $100 million," said Stefan Pfander, Wrigley vice president for Europe. "Despite the economic difficulties" last year, he added, "we are here for the long haul."

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Where One Hand Polishes the Other

BYLINE: By ERIC V. COPAGE 

 BODY:
WHEN Charles Flickinger, owner of Flickinger Glassworks in Red Hook, Brooklyn, received an order last month for glass bowls with engraving at the bottom to enclose hanging lights, he knew what to do. "I told them, 'If you want engraving, then you need Tomas Tisch,' " he said.
Mr. Tisch, whose glassworking studio a few blocks away has a view of the Statue of Liberty, said that when people come to him with restoration projects, he sometimes shares the jobs with Pier Glass, another company down the street. 
 And if someone walks into Pier Glass's studio with a broken Tiffany-style lampshade, Mary Ellen Buxton, who owns the shop with her husband, Kevin Kutch, will often refer the customer to Mr. Flickinger.
Among the glassworkers of Red Hook, one hand polishes the other. There are at least a dozen businesses and more than 20 artists in the neighborhood, and they do windows as well as lamps, home accessories and sculptures. From a lone stained-glass shop by the Gowanus Canal just outside Red Hook 25 years ago, a community has grown up that reflects various aspects of working glass: blowing it, bending it and sandblasting it.
"Even though we are all in glass, we are all in different areas," said Daniel Preston, whose research and development company, Preston Glass Industries, designs machines that punch out mass-produced items like lightbulbs, and also creates custom bulbs for NASA and McDonnell Douglas. "There is not a lot of overlapping."
Mr. Preston said he had relocated from West 14th Street in Greenwich Village a year ago because rents were becoming outrageous. When he rented his 4,800-square-foot loft there in 1996, he said, he paid $14 a square foot per year; a year later his rent was $18. So he moved to Red Hook, where he bought a three-story 7,000-square-foot loft building. Mr. Preston would not say what he paid, but said that because the building, on Coffey Street, is in a city economic development zone, he received tax incentives.
Natalie Hurwitz, a broker with Sholom & Zuckerbrot Realty, said prices for such properties have been rising. "A large Red Hook warehouse is asking $55 a square foot," said Ms. Hurwitz, who was formerly with the Brooklyn Economic Development Corporation, where she helped relocated businesses. "Just a few years ago, the asking price would have been in the 30's."
Ms. Hurwitz estimated loft space rents in Red Hook at $4 to $5 a square foot and warehouse space at $5 to $7 a square foot.
"We looked in Greenpoint and Williamsburg, but here we could get more space for the money, and the landlord was willing to work with us," said Mr. Kutch, who had a rugged tan from standing in front of his furnace, which reaches temperatures of 2,400 degrees.
Peter Waldman, who rents a small studio on Conover Street, said glassworkers can be a tough bunch. "When you work with glass, you have to have a certain amount of ego," he said. "It's a difficult and demanding medium, and takes a certain kind of personality. The people tend to be very assertive."
But a sense of camaraderie prevails among many of the neighborhood's glassworkers. In spring and summer, there are impromptu cookouts, and Pier Glass, which set up shop on Beard Street five years ago, holds an annual Fourth of July barbecue.
Glassworking studios need kilns to melt the finely granulated quartz sand, soda ash and pulverized limestone used to make molten glass, which has the texture of honey. They also need places to reheat the glass while they work it, ovens to anneal the finished product and diamond saws and grinders to cut, shape and smooth it. Setting up a bare-bones glass-blowing studio can cost $20,000, Ms. Buxton said, and can easily run $80,000 for something more elaborate. Monthly costs for rent, gas, electricity can be upward of $3,000.
Alison Ruzsa, another Red Hook artisan, said people who work with glass can benefit from being around their own kind. She said neighborhood glassworkers have developed a kind of barter system, giving one another access to equipment or technical knowledge in return for cleanup help or assistance with projects.
Mr. Tisch, who specializes in engraving, said he liked being part of a community. "You can just walk downstairs and stay in touch," he said. For six years he lived away from other artists, glass or otherwise, in the woods of upstate New York. "It was very beautiful," he said. "But even with all the electronic conveniences of E-mail, fax and telephone, you still need to have live contact."
Last year, he moved from a 500-square-foot studio on East 70th Street in Manhattan, where he had been since 1992, to a 1,700-square-foot studio on Van Brunt Street in Red Hook. In Manhattan he paid $1,300 a month. In Red Hook he pays $1,000.
Mr. Waldman, whose small studio next to the Waterfront Museum and Showboat Barge, an exhibit and performance space where he produces shows, said he liked the serenity of the neighborhood. "I'm from the Midwest," he said. "Red Hook is like living in the country in the middle of the city. It's quiet at night. There are lots of artists, musicians, sculptors and painters who like this kind of environment, who are trying to escape the intensity of the city. You have to take a train and a bus to get here."
But that is no deterrent to business, glassworkers say. Artists tend to sell their work through galleries elsewhere and craft shows around the country, and the more industrial glass businesses depend mainly on referrals, not walk-in trade.
Mr. Kutch, who does both commercial decorative work and his own sculptures of solid glass infused with neon, said the isolation enables him to concentrate on the ineffable thrill of working with the medium. "It's magical, mysterious," he said. "Working with glass is like turning lead into gold. I am in love with the unlimited capabilities of it. It's like it's lit from within."

HEADLINE: Developmentally Disabled: An Untapped Resource

 BODY:
The high rate of unemployment among people with disabilities "Jobs Aplenty, but Disabled Find No Welcome," Sept. 19 is not only a tremendous disservice for these individuals, but also a great loss to American businesses and to our society.

 People with developmental disabilities are hard-working and dedicated employees. I encourage more businesses to follow the lead set by these companies.

HEADLINE: COPING;
Another Branch of Art in Brooklyn's Forest

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
THERE is more than one way to look at the Fulton Avenue strip leading to the Billie Holiday Theater in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, a neighborhood that consists mostly of struggling African-Americans and Caribbean immigrants. One can calculate the dollars it would take to overcome the poverty lurking in the doorways of the fast-food stores and the beauty-supply outlets and among the fresh-air vendors with their goods arrayed on rickety tables. Or one can see a place ripe for dreams, where people need inspiration as much as rent money to carry on.
Marjorie A. Moon, the executive director of the Billie Holiday Theater, is in the inspiration camp. Uplifting art, she says, is as essential to working-class and poor people as roofs over their heads and food on their tables. 
 While a very public debate about the uses of art goes in another pocket of the borough, at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, the Billie Holiday Theater quietly delivers a brand of art with a purpose, or values, if one wants to use that dreaded word.
Ms. Moon allows that in some ways it would not be bad to have the kind of attention that the Brooklyn Museum received last week from Mayor Giuliani's campaign to cut its city financing because of an exhibition that he considers anti-Catholic. But the truth is that her constituency is basically conservative. They are people just trying to make it from day to day as they confront inferior schools and streets that could be safer. What they look for in drama, Ms. Moon said, is ways to deal with their problems.
These seem to be quiet, reflective times in many underserved and black communities. Just last weekend, hundreds of people from the St. Paul Community Baptist Church in East New York, Brooklyn, made a pilgrimage to Queens as part of a religious remembrance of the trans-Atlantic slave trade. Ms. Moon is tapping into that impulse toward introspection and healing.
"Our plays always have to have some redeeming value to them," said Ms. Moon, a self-described child of the 60's who has been at the theater's helm since 1975. "There's enough malaise, disappointment and heartache out here. There are issues our audiences like seeing and experiencing that they can't see anywhere else. What can be done about child abuse or how to cope with being a single head of household?"
"They don't want profanity, they don't want sexual situations, they don't want compromising situations," she said of her audience. "They want to bring the entire family. They want to be able to bring the pastor. We're not looking for Mary Poppins or something that's not real, but it has to be instructional."
The new season, which begins later this month, consists of just three plays: a mystery/comedy about a detective pursuing the killer of a prominent black lawyer; a drama about a family on the eve of the father's release from a mental hospital, and a comedy about a retired English teacher whose life suddenly includes an 18-year-old school dropout. They are the kind of homespun morality tales that will not attract much critical attention or political outrage.
In many ways, the 200-seat theater, which has an annual budget of $400,000 from the city, the state and private sources, is a relic of a louder and more optimistic time. Founded in 1972 as one of three cultural institutions that were part of the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation, the nation's first community development corporation, it is also a survivor in its little corner of the world.
The corporations belong to an era when many Americans believed that an infusion of dollars was all that was needed to revitalize communities like Bedford-Stuyvesant. But while the neighborhood has pockets of gentrification, most of its people are still poor and isolated.
New York is the cultural capital of the nation, yet most people in this neighborhood do not see themselves or their experiences in mainstream theater. The glittering shows of Broadway and even Off Broadway seem out of reach, culturally and economically. At the Billie Holiday Theater, tickets are $12.
During its last season, the theater felt more than its usual financial constraints. While the Mayor and the City Council engaged in an especially heated version of the annual wrangling over how the city should finance arts group, the theater's annual budget was held up and its money was parceled out monthly or bimonthly. People from the community stopped by with checks, some for as little as $5 or $10.
The other day, a young mother holding her infant son came in to ask about ticket prices. Another person dropped by to get a program for the new season. Some contractors were using the building for a conference.
These are quiet times.
"One day you wake up and you're over 50 and you've been here for over 25 years," Ms. Moon said. "There were so many things we believed would happen in the 60's and the 70's. Now, when I'm in the theater and the audience is laughing and talking back to the stage and the connection has been made, that's the meaning, that's the thing that gets you beyond day to day."
