HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
The Web Hasn't Replaced The Storefront Quite Yet

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
MORE bad news for bricks-and-mortar retailers: A new survey has found that 30 percent of the personal computers bought by American households in the last six months were purchased directly from the manufacturer. That represents a sharp jump -- up more than a half -- from the previous six months, according to the market research firm Odyssey, based on its twice-yearly surveys of the technology buying habits of 2,500 American households.
The trend should further strengthen the position of Dell Computer and Gateway, the leading direct marketers of PC's. It can also be seen as a more general sign of things to come. After all, Internet commerce is merely the direct-sales model on steroids, as Michael Dell says, with customers and suppliers enjoying an electronic connection, any time, any place. 
 "The businesses that should be most concerned are the retailers," said Nicholas Donatiello, president of Odyssey in San Francisco.
In some industries -- computers, travel, banking -- the Internet direct sales threat is severe, to be sure. But the notion that people are about to do any substantial portion of their overall buying on line is suspect, if not downright nonsense.
Oddly, few things drive home that point more clearly than a recent study on the outlook for on-line retailing from Forrester Research, which is regarded as an unequivocal bull on E-commerce. And it is the kind of research that helps put in perspective some of the revolutionary rhetoric about the "new economy."
Forrester's widely quoted projections on the growth of on-line sales have a hockey-stick trajectory, and its report issued two weeks ago is no exception. In fact, the forecasts in its new report have been revised upward: Forrester now expects on-line retail sales in the United States to rise sharply this year, to more than $20 billion.
By 2004, Forrester predicts that retail sales over the Internet should reach $185 billion -- a huge number, representing striking growth. Still, even assuming that this heady forecast proves accurate, the $185 billion will be just 7 percent of total retail sales in the United States, Forrester reports. Guess who accounts for the other 93 percent? "Obviously, the bricks-and-mortar world is not going away," noted David Cooperstein, an analyst for Forrester.
The modest lesson here is that a passing familiarity with economic statistics is a useful tool for anyone trying to make sense of the Internet-driven new economy. Yes, there is a lot of growth, excitement and substance to the Internet economy. There is also a lot of hype and churning and many failed start-ups -- but that is all part of the process of entrepreneurial endeavor. Hype encourages investment, which accelerates the innovation cycle of trial and error, leading to growth-creating breakthroughs.
Yet for all the attention given to Internet companies, they still represent mainly an innovative ferment on the surface of the nation's economy. As Kevin Kelly, editor at large of Wired magazine and author of "New Rules for the New Economy" (Viking Press), has noted, the new economy doesn't replace the old economy; it builds on top of the old, and its technologies eventually permeate the underlying layers.
In America's $8.5 trillion economy, that two-step process will not happen overnight, even if the Internet enthusiasts are correct in saying it is inevitable. Recognizing that reality, Forrester called its recent report "post-Web retailing." Established retailers from Wal-Mart to Tiffany are already building up Internet presences, and more will follow. But as Mr. Cooperstein of Forrester sees it, the future belongs to those who pursue a "multichannel strategy."
Look no further for a pioneer of that future than Gateway. Starting in 1997, Gateway began opening retail stores across the country -- 180 so far, heading for 400 over the next few years. But they are retail stores with a difference, likened to petting zoos for PC's, so people can come in and try out the Gateway machines, which are all connected to the Internet.
These stores have no inventory on shelves in the back room. Customers place orders and receive delivery a few days later at their homes. So all the advantages of scale of Gateway's direct business model -- made-to-order manufacturing, warehousing and delivery -- remain intact.
FURTHER and more futuristic second thoughts on Internet retailing can be found in an intriguing research paper by Hal R. Varian, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley. In his paper, Mr. Varian raises questions about economic efficiency and consumer benefits often predicted for Internet shopping -- a world, it is said, in which a person's "software agent" will roam the Net on his behalf, seeking the best bargains.
Perhaps, but perhaps not, Mr. Varian says, if the predicted shakeout occurs in some on-line markets. He looks at two established electronic markets with a limited number of suppliers -- airline computerized reservations systems like Sabre and market makers in Nasdaq stocks -- and suggests that a result can be price-signaling and implicit collusion among those suppliers. At Nasdaq, of course, a price-fixing investigation was prompted.
"Everybody says the Internet will be a consumer paradise," Mr. Varian said. "But it is not so clear that consumers will be the winners in the long run."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Nieuw Haarlem Is Revisited 341 Years After the Conquest

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
Was it a Dutch invasion? Or perhaps a second invasion?
In 1658 the Dutch Governor, Peter Stuyvesant, claimed northern Manhattan as Nieuw Haarlem, naming it after a city near Amsterdam. So when the Prime Minister of the Netherlands, Wim Kok, came to Lenox Avenue and 125th Street Tuesday, some suspicions were raised. 
 Mr. Kok said he and his delegation came to learn about Harlem's recent economic revitalization. But Terry C. Lane, the president and chief executive of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, told the Prime Minister that he had invited his own delegation to their meeting, just in case. "Just want to let you know," he said, "Harlem is not for sale." Mr. Kok smiled and said the main purpose of his visit was to exchange views about addressing poverty.
Later, accompanied by Secret Service agents and two dozen Dutch reporters, he admired the brownstones on Lenox Avenue, some renovated, some boarded up. At St. Martin's Episcopal Church, the carillon rang out the Dutch national anthem, or a tune that some Dutch reporters said sounded like the anthem. The bells were installed 50 years ago, a gift of Queen Juliana of the Netherlands, who visited the church in 1952.
Mr. Kok also stopped at North General Hospital, the state's only black-owned private hospital. The Prime Minister asked the hospital's president, Harold P. Freeman, about the uninsured, who make up 20 percent of its patients. In the Netherlands, medicine is socialized, so there are no uninsured.
Donning hard hats, the delegation also made its way through the site of Harlem U.S.A., a 285,000-square-foot shopping plaza that is expected to open by Christmas, before returning to Lenox Avenue, where a crowd had gathered.
Some wondered if Hillary Rodham Clinton was in town. When James L. Foster, 79, a retired carpenter, learned that Dutch officials were visiting, he asked, "How much money do they want?" He said the Prime Minister's visit would mean little to most Harlem residents. "How much can he learn in an hour?" he said.
But to Corey Murphy, 27, a security guard who lives and works on 124th Street near Lenox Avenue, the visit meant a lot. "It shows that we're coming up, that we are more business-oriented and that they're changing the neighborhood," he said. "I bet a few years ago the Prime Minister of the Netherlands wouldn't have set foot in Harlem."
Mr. Kok said he was impressed with Harlem's about-face. "Quite often outside the United States, Harlem still has the image of being so downward," he said. "The impression I take back is that people have found the way ahead."
 NINA SIEGAL

HEADLINE: Captain Video

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:
YOU'D think he was the star of the movie, instead of the guy who rents it out at three bucks a pop.
"Marty!" "Marty!" "Marty!" his customers cry, vying for his attention, demanding the inside cinema poop. It's elbows-out time in the video store: the cardboard covers of the latest video releases have been laid out in neat rows, two deep, on Marty Arno's counter top, and the renters are hovering like sharks anticipating the chum. 
 "Wow, 'Affliction,' " Mr. Arno says, peering over his right shoulder from behind the counter, an unlighted cigarette, the eternal accessory, bobbing up and down on his lips. "Very, very harrowing." The would-be renter, who looks to be your typical city skeptic, shrinks at the mere hint of a hard sell. Mr. Arno shrugs in an offhand way that seems to say, "Hey, no prob, it's your VCR," but he cannot let it go, either. "It's well acted," he adds. "Two Academy Award nominations."
The customer frowns and drifts away. Only in New York, it sometimes seems, can temporary custody of a Nick Nolte movie become the basis for a wholesale psychodrama. But then, when it comes to picking movies, New Yorkers can be as intense and demanding as auteurs, a lesson Mr. Arno has learned in the decade and a half that he has been renting videotapes from a slightly fraying and overcrowded storefront at the northern tip of Brooklyn Heights.
"Two things you hear over and over and over," he says, in a rare moment of calm on a recent Saturday afternoon. " 'What's new? What's good?' 'What's new? What's good?' "
These are words to live by in the fickle world of video rentals, and if the loyalty, diversity and numbers of his customers are any indication, Marty Arno is one of its leading citizens. With 17,000 films on his shelves, renowned for his extensive collection of movies foreign and cultish -- renters come from as far as Connecticut and New Jersey for his esoteric titles, and requests have been made from Britain, as well -- he operates what many consider the quintessential independent video store in New York.
A city of cineastes has spawned a network of shops to gratify its home viewing needs. From the Video Room in Battery Park City to the Video Station in Forest Hills, the stores have become the corner bars in the kingdom of film.
It's an establishment that has evolved the old-fashioned way: not as a product of an M.B.A.-generated company plan, but by adjusting its rhythms over time to the pulse of a neighborhood, by sussing out its peculiar tastes and quirks and tailoring its wares accordingly.
It is common knowledge that this way of doing business is in decline in many spheres of city life. For every Starbucks that hangs its forest green logo on the door to some refurbished former deli, for every drug chain superstore that barrels in with alpine stacks of vitamin bottles, the economic impact is felt in a funky nearby coffee shop with mocha-stained tables, or an ancient pharmacy with a druggist who has memorized your doctor's phone number.
Mom-and-pop video stores, too, can feel the heat from the big boys, which in the video business means Blockbluster, the nationwide chain that has 86 outlets in New York City. Mr. Arno's hedge against corporate hegemony -- Blockbuster has 24 stores in Brooklyn but no beachhead as yet on Mr. Arno's turf -- has been to burrow into the community, to make his store, and himself, as indispensable and responsive as he can to the 6,000 steady clients who buy the store's $25 annual memberships.
"I learned very quickly that this is an upscale neighborhood: they wanted Bergman, they wanted Fellini, they wanted Wertmuller," Mr. Arno says, listing three directors whose movies he displays in abundance along a vast wall of foreign flicks, considered by many one of the best such libraries in the city. How many video stores, after all, not only offer "Cries and Whispers," "Satyricon" and "Seven Beauties," but also "White Hell of Pitz Palu," a 1929 silent film about German mountaineering?
One would assume from the depth of the collection that Mr. Arno himself was a fan of cerebral cinema. One would assume wrong. Ask him about some hero of the art houses and see the conflicted cloud spread over his face. "I watch a Bergman film," Mr. Arno says, "and I want to jump off a bridge."
This comes as absolutely no revelation. I have been a customer of Mr. Arno's for as long as I have lived in Brooklyn Heights; acquiring my membership card was one of my initiatory acts of residency. I may not ever have known his last name; only in preparing this article did I learn that he had one, because to everyone who walks in his door on Henry Street, he is simply Marty. But no private detective was needed to determine that he preferred "Dr. Zhivago" to "The Seventh Seal." On a thousand occasions, as one store clerk or another was sliding my selections into a black plastic bag, I could hear Mr. Arno behind the counter delivering a glowing 10-second review of some golden oldie that starred Groucho Marx or Harold Lloyd. It was Mr. Arno in the role he was born to play, presiding over a library as entwined with his personality as Polanski's or Spielberg's is with a director's cut.
With its glorious autumn film festival, its penchant for the films of Rohmer, Kubrick and Kurosawa, and lately, its boom in multiscreen cinemas, New York is a city that takes its cinema to heart. "There's a reason the Angelika Film Center is here and not in Clifton, N.J." Michael Mark, a Manhattan video store owner, says of the haven for indie films on Houston Street. And a reason there are Marty Arnos in every borough of the city, holding court across a counter, offering tips on little-known titles, castigating recalcitrant returners with late fees.
"I would say that almost half my clientele will just walk in and say, 'What am I renting today?' " says Mr. Mark, a partner in Couch Potato, which has two stores on the Upper East Side. A lifelong movie addict, he is amazed sometimes at the trust clients invest in his taste, and at his platform for "tossing my opinions around." Especially since he's pretty sure that renting copies of "Jules and Jim" is never going to get him or his business partner, Tony Barnes, that elusive seaside retreat in the Hamptons.
"Neither one of us got into this with the idea that you can make a fortune in the video business," Mr. Mark says. "You can't. We're not just here making a buck. We're here because we love the medium of film."
The video store, a retailing phenomenon born as an enterprising response to the invention of the VCR, has expanded in two decades from niche business to mature industry. In the years in which Americans were adding the new appliance to their homes, rental revenues rose. Today 84 percent of households have VCR's, says the Video Software Dealers Association, the country's largest home video trade organization, and that has meant a tapering off of new members for video stores. As recently as 1997, the association notes in its latest annual report, the rental market in the United States declined by 4 percent. Improvements in technology create new challenges: cable television providers, for instance, added to the pressure on video stores with the proliferation of pay-per-view channels, and the advent of DVD players has compelled store owners to consider expanding their libraries in new directions.
Mr. Arno opened for business on Henry Street in September 1984, with a $25,000 investment, 400 cartridges and a slew of neighbors who didn't know a tracking dial from an eject button. "Nobody in the neighborhood had a VCR," he says. "People would walk in and ask what kind of books we had for sale."
Fifteen years later, they're still coming, except now they also drag in rickety old VCR's making odd noises and looking as worn out as Victrolas for Mr. Arno to try to repair. On many an afternoon, the proprietor of what is called North Heights Video on paper but Marty's on the street can be found with a screwdriver in his hand, prying a jammed cassette out of an over-the-hill machine while discussing the merits of "Gunga Din" with a browser.
"I've always loved the movies," says Mr. Arno, 59, who grew up in Bensonhurst but moved to Staten Island with his wife, Harriet, to raise a son and daughter. "On Saturdays when I was a kid, you spent all day in the movies." He remembers the dimly lighted celluloid palaces of his youth, the Walker and the Metro, where he watched serials and westerns and horror flicks. John Wayne was a personal hero, although it wasn't stars he came to worship. "It was," he says, "a great place to meet girls."
You wouldn't mistake Mr. Arno for one of those film nerds with the history of the camera angles of Sergei Eisenstein in their heads. Sure, he went to New York University, with its renowned film school, but he majored in marketing and advertising. After college he wound up under the Brooklyn Bridge, in the family's trucking and warehousing company, which he took over after his father's death. The oil crisis of the late 1970's soured him on trucks, so he sold the fleet. Later, his brother-in-law presented him with the idea for a partnership in a video store. Mr. Arno liked it. They found a vacant shop next to a Chinese restaurant and got their start in pictures.
Over the years, Mr. Arno shed the partner, moved to larger digs a block farther north adjoining another Heights culinary fixture, Henry's End, and completed the metamorphosis from scrappy transporter of the jeans of Sergio Valente to people's interpreter of the movies of Antonioni.
"I was open seven days a week at first, and that was a killer," he says. "But the business was steadily rising." The advent of premium movie channels on cable made a dent in his bottom line, as did a thriving cut-rate market others were carving out in bootleg videotapes. Still, Mr. Arno held his own on Henry Street, handing out doggie cookies to customers' pooches, running goofy rental promotions, like half-price "dead actress specials," and harboring secret fantasies about the ruination of picnics, ball games and street fairs.
"I pray for rain on a Saturday," he explains.
A recent Saturday was a particular downer for Mr. Arno: not a cloud in the sky. (A weakened if lucrative Tropical Storm Floyd had blown through that Thursday.) Still, the store, with its dingy carpeting and jetliner-narrow aisles, was filled that afternoon with the usual mix of movie shoppers, who picked up on the endless conversation Mr. Arno began during the Reagan era.
It's the busiest day of the six-day schedule his store now maintains. The movie clock never rests, but on Sundays, Mr. Arno does. Children huddle in front of the shelves of Disney selections. A young German woman appears to be cataloguing the foreign films, box by box. No one at the moment goes near the rack of XXX-rated shelves, which Mr. Arno says are kept off limits to minors. In the course of this typical Saturday, the store owner will schmooze, trouble-shoot, play a few practical jokes with phony winning lottery tickets and try to hold his tongue when a man half his age returns a movie late, claiming a hurricane exemption.
"You mean, I could get in here from Staten Island, but you couldn't make it five blocks?" Mr. Arno says in his best Brooklyn street-guy manner. "All right," he finally adds, with just the slightest edge in his voice, "we'll give you a hurricane credit."
After the man departs, one of Mr. Arno's assistants, Kathy Rusin, a Queens College student, points out that he has made similar claims before and was once even forgiven a $20 debt to the store. For the first time, Mr. Arno looks agitated. "Why didn't you tell me?" he says to Ms. Rusin, as a second assistant, Alana Garcia, a freshman at Pace, busies herself, signing out "Nixon" and "A Bridge Too Far." "Well, this is going to be the last time."
Mr. Arno walks to the front of the store, tugging on the unlit cigarette perched tightly between his teeth. What can he do? Building a store title by title, and customer by customer, who wants to turn into a leg breaker? "It's one of the reasons my wife doesn't come by much," he says.
A vast majority of Mr. Arno's members, however, do not begrudge him an extra $3 plus tax. (Although he produces a piece of paper with the names of hundreds of people who in some cases owe him hundreds of dollars.) The thousands in good standing want a steady stream of cheap fixes in front of the set. In America, that's entertainment.
"Who are these, the von Trapp family?" a man at the counter remarks as he stares at the illustration on the box for "Dancing at Lughnasa," the recent drama about five Irish sisters that featured Meryl Streep.
Mr. Arno is only too happy to weigh in on this one. He is a huge fan of what he calls "epic adventure movies," sweeping, eye-filling narratives like "The Man Who Would Be King" and "The Wind and the Lion." He also has a thing for funny, quirky little films such as "Things to Do in Denver When You're Dead." Hitchcock's movies, he says, are year in and out the most reliably popular in his shop, "because he tells a good story masterfully; they all steal from him."
Conversely, the mention of a mistier offering, like "Terms of Endearment" or for that matter, "Dancing at Lughnasa," elicits the kind of pained expression that might have a solicitous bystander dialing 911.
"It's an opportunity for her to showcase her Irish accent," Mr. Arno says to the customer of Ms. Streep's performance in "Lughnasa." "They dance in a circle. I can't wait for the sequel, when they dance the other way around."
In his natural habitat, Mr. Arno is a strutting Leonard Maltin. "Do we have 'Female Waters' "? Ms. Garcia asks for a client. Mr. Arno looks confused. "You talking about 'Female Trouble' by John Waters?" he shouts back, breaking the code.
Another woman approaches. "Is 'Blow-Up' on video?" she wants to know. Mr. Arno shoots her an "is it ever" kind of look. "Yes, and do you know the name of the model -- who's the model in it?" he asks in reply. "Veruschka," he says, without waiting for an answer, "and you know, she's a customer here." As are, Mr. Arno says, the lawyer Barry Scheck, the actor Chris Eigeman and Steve Burns, the Steve of the Nickelodeon show "Blue's Clues."
Everyone deplores the decline in the quality of movies, but Marty's video hangout seems to improve with each addition to the collection. Quantity means almost as much as quality. One day soon, he may run out of space. "If it's on tape, I have it," Mr. Arno says.
"Well, that's a slight exaggeration," he adds. But not by much.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
For Soft-Drink Makers, a Dry Spell

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
AS Coca-Cola's share price dropped below $48 in trading last week, from a high of over $88 last year, investors were wondering: Can it get any worse?
It is pretty bad, and not just for Coke, whose recent track record was described last week as "the most significant underperformance versus the S. & P. 500 in the history of the company" by Andrew J. Conway, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. 
 Pepsico's share price is languishing at $31.375, well below the company's 52-week high of $42.563. And Cadbury Schweppes, trading as American depository receipts, is at $27.4375, down from a high of $35.0625 within the last year. Bottlers like Pepsi Bottling Group, the Whitman Corporation and Coca-Cola Enterprises are getting clobbered, too.
What has happened to the soft-drink stocks? The answer is part global cautionary tale, part facts of life in the consumer products business.
Much of the downturn can be traced to the state of affairs at Coke, which began a sharp decline 14 months ago. "It starts at the top," said Caroline Levy, an analyst for Schroder & Company. "If Coke is weak, it's very hard for Pepsi as well as the bottlers."
Coke's frailty is rooted in macroeconomic conditions around the world that have gnawed at profits in a system designed when emerging markets were booming. In countries like Germany, Japan and Brazil, Coca-Cola's sales have been flat or falling for several years, largely because consumers in those countries do not feel they have the money to spend on what they perceive as a relatively expensive American product. So second-tier brands have been cutting into Coke's market share. In the United States, volume fell when bottlers raised prices 5 to 6 percent earlier this year. The idea was to regain profits lost during the last three years, when Coke and Pepsi waged a price war in the supermarket aisles.
"Now, rather than having the stimulus of lower prices, we're going to have the drag of higher prices," said Marc Cohen, an analyst at Goldman Sachs. Sales of store-brand soda have been creeping higher, too.
Some of the investor retreat from Coke's stock can be attributed to concern over the profitability of the two engines behind the Coca-Cola system. Coke's return on invested capital -- 35 percent -- is far higher than that of its biggest bottler, Coca-Cola Enterprises, which is about 5.2 percent.
But even Coke's return on invested capital has been falling lately.
"We think, in the long run, it's a great company with great management, a great franchise and a great business model," said David Garza, an analyst at Roxbury Capital Management, which has sold most of its two million Coca-Cola shares since the beginning of the year. "The issue is the economics in the short run." He added, "Earnings growth is the worst it's been in decades."
 COCA-COLA'S recall of 17 million cases of its products in France and Belgium this spring has had more extensive repercussions than the company publicly anticipated. Sales are still shaky in Italy, Germany and Poland as a result of the recall, several analysts said.
There are also worries about the effects of currency devaluations abroad. And the company halted its share-repurchase program earlier this year.
Coke has said it will increase volume next year by 7 to 8 percent worldwide, and increase its earnings 15 percent to 20 percent. But analysts -- who are assiduously coached by Coke, but have been burned in recent months as the company has failed to meet its own earnings targets -- say that is an unreasonable expectation.
"We believe volume will grow 6 to 6.5 percent, and earnings per share will be up 13 percent," said Bill Pecoriello, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein.
Coke's once-hallowed executive suite is also coming in for criticism. "What people are worried about is why they are missing their numbers," Ms. Levy said. "The question is, is that global economies? Or is that management?"
The falling stock price reflects worry about whether Coke and other global consumer products giants will ever again post the kind of profit growth they did through most of the 1990's.
"The emperor has fewer clothes now than I thought," said Daniel Peris, an analyst for Argus Research. He predicts that Coke's share price will return to a more traditional valuation, closer to the 71 percent premium to the S. & P. 500 price-to-earnings multiple that it averaged over the last seven years. In 1997, the premium was 96 percent, and in 1998, it rose to 106 percent. So far this year, the premium is about 83 percent, he said.
In the case of Pepsico, management difficulties in the soft-drink division are one cause of the stock's slide. But analysts say some investors' worries may be exaggerated, since the bulk of Pepsico's earnings are generated by its snack-food business. "Frito-Lay is easily one of the strongest consumer packaged-goods companies that can be found," Mr. Cohen said.
The unexpected departure last month of Philip A. Marineau, the former chief executive of Pepsi-Cola North America, sapped confidence in Pepsico and its recently spun-off bottler, Pepsi Bottling Group, analysts say. "Part of P.B.G.'s selling proposition to Wall Street was that Pepsi-Cola was under more solid management," Mr. Cohen said. "And the management decided to leave."
The bottling company opened at $23 on March 31, rose to $25.25 in early July and was trading at $17.4375 on Friday.
Whitman, a major Pepsi bottler based outside Chicago, is down 44.5 percent for the year. It hit a 52-week low on Friday, trading at $14 a share.
Cadbury Schweppes has fared better, but is still down 20.6 percent for the year. Confusion about Cadbury's strategy, now that it has sold many of its operations outside the United States to Coca-Cola, hasn't helped.
The soft-drink sector has experienced what Mr. Conway calls "a mini-implosion" in recent weeks. "The question is," he said, "when will volumes return?"

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Even if the Fed Is Idle, Rates Are on the Rise

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
TO the relief of many investors, members of the Federal Reserve Board have made clear that they will not be voting to raise interest rates at their meeting next Tuesday.
So why are yields on United States Treasuries rising? The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond jumped to 6.13 percent on Friday, from 5.97 percent a week earlier. 
 The obvious reason for the move was renewed inflation fears brought about by rising oil and gold prices. Adding to the anxiety was news on Friday that an index of prices paid by factories rose to its highest level in more than four years and that manufacturing grew faster in September than analysts had expected.
But investors who remain certain that bond yields will retreat again should take note. A pattern of unrelenting selling sweeping through the Treasury market in recent weeks is not caused by bad economic news alone.
Some of those doing the selling may be foreign investors who see the decline of the dollar hammering their returns. But Charles Peabody, bank analyst at Mitchell Securities in New York, says the bond market's behavior also reflects a broad unwinding of bets placed by investors who were later caught unware by recent interest-rate increases. Many of these positions are now going bad; as they are unwound, they push rates higher.
First was the so-called yen carry trade, in which investors borrowed funds in Japan at microscopic interest rates and bought Treasuries with the proceeds. When the yen spiked up, profits turned to losses and the Treasuries had to be dumped.
Last week's disastrous trade was a variation on this theme -- the gold carry trade -- in which investors bet that the price of gold will drop. They borrowed gold from a bank, sold the gold and bought Treasuries, making perhaps 4 percent on the difference between what they paid to borrow the gold and what they earned on the securities. With gold prices running up this week, those trades had to be unwound.
The gold carry trade is nowhere near as big as outright bets made on rates, known as interest-rate swaps, in which one investor agrees with another to exchange a fixed rate for a floating rate.
Interest-rate swaps account for more than 80 percent of derivatives held at American banks. In the second quarter, the notional value of interest-rate related derivatives at domestic banks stood at $25.7 trillion, up 28 percent from the corresponding period in 1998. As rates climb higher, these holdings become worrisome.
At the same time, Mr. Peabody believes that we are starting to see the ill effects of rising rates on the nation's financial institutions. "Because of the positive reinforcement of declining rates over the last two decades," he said, "most financial players have increasingly used that trend as a way of boosting their profits."
Now, the reverse is happening. In recent weeks, three small banks -- Keystone Financial Inc., the Regions Financial Corporation and Flagstar Bancorp -- have warned of earnings shortfalls owing to higher rates.
Will rates rise further? "Any time you get a trend reversal in the discount rate, that trend remains in force on average for 14 months," Mr. Peabody said. "August represents the first month of a trend reversal."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
The Unsung Comeback of the Large Car

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
AS the 2000 model year arrives, sport utility vehicles have captured the hearts and garages of millions of Americans, while sales of large cars and minivans are lagging.
But many in the auto industry say there is an untold story: large cars and minivans have been greatly improved. They actually do as well as or better than sport utility vehicles by many of the criteria American buyers have long considered most important. These include price, performance, passenger comfort and, perhaps most surprisingly, safety. 
 The height and sturdy appearance of sport utility vehicles make them seem safer than cars to many buyers. But in crashes, people in the latest large cars and minivans are less likely to die than people in all but the very largest sport utility vehicles, according to an insurance industry analysis to be released this month. Even the very largest sport utilities have death rates only slightly lower than those of large cars and minivans, yet are far more likely to kill occupants of other vehicles in crashes.
The safety comparison goes beyond death rates. Recent Federal crash tests show that large cars like the Ford Crown Victoria and Chevrolet Impala, and minivans like the Honda Odyssey and Ford Windstar, provide more protection than large sport utility vehicles like the Dodge Durango and the Cadillac Escalade. In fact, sport utility vehicles have received many of the worst scores in recent tests and are more likely to roll over than cars or minivans, according to a Federal study last summer.
Other factors that are important to buyers also favor large cars and minivans over more popular sport utilities.
Consider price. Auto makers sell large cars and minivans at thin profit margins and often offer rebates. They tack markups of $5,000 on pickups and of $10,000 to $15,000 on large sport utility vehicles, often with no rebates.
Consider performance. The typical large car can now accelerate from zero to 60 miles an hour in 9.2 seconds, almost 2 seconds faster than a large sport utility vehicle, according to Government figures. And because large cars are lower and lighter, they tend to be more nimble and to brake more quickly, especially on wet surfaces. Minivans, which are built like large cars but with taller passenger compartments that produce more wind resistance, roughly match large sport utility vehicles in acceleration times and handle better, though not quite as well as cars.
Consider spaciousness. Large cars and minivans offer leg room and shoulder room similar to that of sport utility vehicles for passengers in the front two rows of seats, and almost as much headroom. Minivans also provide a third row of seats, as large sport utilities do.
Most Americans care little these days about their vehicles' fuel economy or emission of air pollutants, industry surveys show. But on these criteria, too, large cars do far better than sport utility vehicles, while minivans tend to be in the middle.
Strict Government standards for cars have forced auto makers to design large cars that now get up to 32 miles a gallon on the highway. That is double the mileage of some of the biggest sport utility vehicles, which are allowed by law to be considerably less fuel efficient. Cars of all sizes also emit less than half the volume of smog-causing gases for each mile that most large sport utility vehicles do. (Ford now builds its sport utilities to pollute no more than cars.)
People who know automobiles usually say that big cars offer a better combination of driving performance, affordability and roominess than other large vehicles. "I would steer most families toward a large sedan because they provide the best cross-section of capabilities," said Csaba Csere,editor in chief of Car and Driver magazine.
Even auto makers, wealthy from sport utility profits, acknowledge that big cars are underappreciated. "Trucks are not as nimble, they're not as light, and if you don't have the need for the load-carrying capability or the three rows of seats, the passenger cars are a great value and a lot of fun to drive," said Ronald Boltz, a senior vice president at DaimlerChrysler A.G.
To be sure, large cars have two substantial disadvantages when compared with sport utility vehicles: they have less cargo space, and they are not as tall. These days, Americans increasingly like riding up high, or at least dislike being in short automobiles when motorists around them are driving taller models.
Still, the many advantages of the latest large cars and minivans have not been much help to the people who market them because to many Americans these products are something worse than less safe, less economical or less nimble: They are out of fashion.
 
The S.U.V. Advantage
The Growing Appeal Of Riding High
Not so long ago, children liked to play with model sports cars and dreamed of the day when they might drive the real things. But auto industry market researchers now say that the younger a person is, the more enthusiastic he or she is about sport utility vehicles. That could shape the auto market for many years to come.
When DaimlerChrysler held promotional events for its cars and for its Jeeps recently in a Detroit suburb, visitors to the car promotion mostly had gray hair or were balding. The Jeep display across the street, which included an off-road driving course, was full of families with children. Milo Perreault, an 11-year-old from Shelby Township, Mich., ogled the sport utilities and spoke wistfully of the long wait until he would be old enough to drive. "I'd actually like a Jeep," he said. "Some of the sports cars, like the Viper, are low to the ground, and in a Jeep I like the height."
Until recently, market researchers did not even ask about height. Now surveys show that visibility from the driver's seat ties a vehicle's driving performance and interior comfort as the most important attributes that buyers seek.
The taller sport utilities do well on this score, especially the new Ford Excursion. It has just replaced the Chevrolet Suburban as the world's largest sport utility vehicle, and at 6 feet 8 inches, it allows tall drivers to look over the roofs of Suburbans. Excursion drivers must climb two tall stairs and a short one just to get in to the vehicle.
Mary Cumberland, 76, who drives a big 1997 Chrysler New Yorker and lives in Southfield, Mich., said she had always driven large cars. But she was not sure that she wanted another because she was tired of having other vehicles block her view of the road. "A lot of people are considering sport utilities just out of self-defense," she said. "I'm trying to get my husband to consider a van, to be up higher."
The latest cars are low and streamlined, making them very stable as well as reducing wind resistance and improving fuel efficiency. But the seats and door openings in large cars are lower than they were a generation ago.
Fashion and seating height have contributed to the recent stagnation in sales of large cars and minivans. Sales of large cars have tumbled to 4 percent of the overall market, from 10 percent in the early 1980's and from close to half the market in the 1960's.
Minivan sales, which had been hot and growing rapidly as recently as the early 1990's, have now leveled off, and actually lost some of their share of all new vehicles sold, falling to 8 percent last year.
Sales of sport utility vehicles, of course, have been soaring. Though their annual growth rate peaked in 1996, the big vehicles have still been the fastest-growing segment of the auto market every year since 1994. Sport utility vehicles now account for a majority of the luxury auto market and almost a fifth of the overall market, up from less than 2 percent of each in the early 1980's.
 
Safety
A Tougher Look But a Weaker Record
Just by looking at sport utilities, some Americans conclude that they are safer than cars and minivans. Their rugged, even intimidating, appearance seems to remind buyers of the safety advantages of size, an advantage that Americans used to forget in buying small cars, said Adrian Lund, an insurance industry safety researcher.
But recent research by the Government and the insurance industry shows that, contrary to popular perception, sport utility vehicles do not keep their occupants any safer than cars or minivans, or even as safe in many cases.
For example, large cars and minivans are increasingly winning the Government's highest, five-star rating for driver protection in a frontal crash, but not one sport utility vehicle has won the highest rating for such protection. And some of the worst safety scores in crash tests have gone to sport utilities.
Moreover, the Government assigns stars without assessing an automobile's propensity to roll over. Sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks fared worst in a Federal study last summer that looked at vehicles' tendency to roll over.
The new insurance industry analysis, which included Federal data on every fatal crash reported in the United States last year, finds that 106 occupants of large cars like the Impala and smaller minivans like the Dodge Caravan died in crashes for every million registered vehicles of those types. By comparison, 131 occupants of large sport utility vehicles like the Dodge Durango died in crashes for every million registered automobiles of those types.
For the very largest sport utility vehicles, like the Chevrolet Suburban and the Lincoln Navigator, the death rate was slightly lower than for large cars, at 93, while for midsize sport utility vehicles like the Jeep Grand Cherokee and Chevrolet Blazer it was much higher, at 151.
The smaller minivans, like the Caravan, ended up being included in the large car category in the study because they were similar in wheelbase and construction and behaved similarly in crashes. Bigger minivans, like the Windstar and Odyssey, wound up in the very large car category, which also includes Lincoln Town Cars and which had a death rate of 107.
Dr. Ricardo Martinez, the Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said sport utility vehicles were no safer for their occupants than other types of automobiles. "It has become a popular myth that the S.U.V. is bigger and better, but we're very concerned that people understand the tradeoffs," said Dr. Martinez, a former emergency room physician. "It's taller, and that may help it in some kinds of crashes, but it also makes it more likely to roll."
Indeed, while people in sport utility vehicles die at least as often as people in cars and minivans, they tend to die differently. With minivans and cars, the fatalities tend to occur in collisions with other vehicles, especially sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks. But with sport utilities, deaths come relatively more often when the vehicle rolls over.
Sport utility vehicles also tend to provide much less protection for occupants than cars during collisions with solid objects, as when a vehicle slides on a slippery road and hits a bridge or tree. Data from recent Government crash tests into solid barriers also strongly suggest that sport utilities provide poor protection during collisions with other sport utilities, although regulators say they have never crashed sport utilities together to check.
Sport utility vehicles fare better than other types of vehicles in collisions with cars. The height and weight of a sport utility vehicle allow it to pass over the strongest parts of a car and penetrate deep into it, so that the car and its occupants absorb the brunt of the crash, according to recent studies by regulators.
But Dr. Martinez and other safety experts say it is a mistake to be concerned only about collisions with cars. Indeed, surveys have found that most drivers think their own driving skills are far above average, and do not pay adequate attention to the possibility that they will make mistakes themselves or encounter poor driving conditions, like icy roads. Single-vehicle crashes account for nearly half of all fatal accidents.
Rollovers represent the biggest problem for sport utilities, causing more than a third of all deaths in those vehicles, compared with only a tenth of the deaths in cars. Recent Federal research has found very few cases in which vehicles roll over because their owners swerve violently on a road. Instead, according to Federal research backed by auto makers' own findings, 92 percent of rollovers occur after a vehicle has been "tripped" by striking a curb, guard rail or another vehicle, or catches the wheels on one side in the dirt or mud of a road's shoulder.
Drivers should be concerned about all types of crashes, and not just the possibility that a bad driver will crash into them, Dr. Martinez said.
In addition to protecting their own occupants better than most sport utilities do, large cars and minivans pose less hazard to other motorists. They are only a third as likely to kill the other driver in a crash as large sport utilities are, according to a study to be published in the winter issue of the Journal of Crash Prevention and Injury Control. The height, stiffness and weight of sport utilities account for the difference, according to the study, which was written by W. Thomas Hollowell, a senior Federal researcher, and his former aide, H. Clay Gabler, now in academia.
William Powers, Ford's vice president for research, said in a speech on Aug. 5 that in the years ahead, motorists will "see increasing diversity in vehicle size, raising further issues in occupant protection, vehicle-to-vehicle compatibility and pedestrian protection."
"There is a lot of work yet to be done," Mr. Powers said.
 
Other Criteria
A Higher Price For Sitting Tall
A few years ago, before tall automobiles became more common and made visibility from the driver's seat an issue, Americans shopped for the roomiest, best-handling vehicles at the best prices. If that were still true, dealers would have trouble keeping cars and minivans in stock.
Large cars, minivans and big sport utility vehicles all cost around $20,000 for carmakers to build, and a little more if they are luxury models with lots of leather and fancy gadgets like navigational computers.
But while many large cars and minivans sell for under $26,000, three-quarters of the nation's sport utility vehicles sell for more than $26,000. The difference, analysts say, lies in the manufacturers' fatter profit margins on sport utility vehicles.
Large cars and minivans offer seats that are just as roomy and comfortable as sport utility vehicle seats -- more comfortable, if the bumpy ride of sport utilities is considered. While large cars these days may look smaller on the outside than the big sedans of the 1970's, they are just as spacious on the inside. And while the trunks of large cars may not accommodate tables and chairs, the cargo areas of minivans do.
Minivans have as much cargo room behind the second row of seats as all but the largest sport utility vehicles, industry statistics show. And because the second row of seats in most minivans can be removed, while the second row in most sport utility vehicles can only be folded down, minivans are actually the roomiest vehicles for people with very large possessions to move.
Many television advertisements show cars swooping through tight curves on mountain roads. Ads for sport utility vehicles seldom show this, for a good reason: sport utility vehicles are less maneuverable than cars, or even minivans.
Car and Driver magazine tests vehicles by having them swerve over one lane to the left and then swerve back into their original lane, as though circumventing an obstacle. The magazine found last year that family sedans could accomplish the maneuver safely at average speeds up to 63.4 miles an hour, and minivans up to 57.9 miles an hour; for luxury sport utility vehicles, the average was 53.9 miles an hour.
Mr. Csere said sport utilities' high centers of gravity, high weight and off-road tires gave them inferior handling. "S.U.V.'s are clearly worse than cars of any kind, whether small or large," he said.
The sheer weight of sport utilities vehicles also makes them harder to stop than cars or minivans, especially on wet or snowy roads. Indeed, Thomas Davis, General Motors' group vice president for light trucks, said that, contrary to popular perception, four-wheel drive does not help vehicles stop, nor does it help them maneuver while braking.
In spite of the ways they compare favorably with sport utilities, large cars and minivans suffer from an image problem. Despite considerable improvements over the last five years, especially in driving performance, minivans in particular are unfairly derided, said Ralph Sarotte, DaimlerChrysler's general manager for minivans.
"Someone put the 'soccer mom' title on them, and a lot of people don't want that image," he said. "We could sell twice as many minivans in this market if it were not for the image thing."
Exactly that "image thing" is what makes sport utilities so hot, auto executives say. "S.U.V.'s are about image," said Joseph C. Collins Jr., Ford's brand manager for sport utilities and minivans. "It's about who that customer is and who that customer wants to be."
 
A Tale Hangs in the Test Numbers
(DETROIT) -- BIG cars and minivans produce sterling performances in Federal crash tests. Large sport utility vehicles, which tend to be modified pickup trucks with very stiff bodies that absorb little energy in a crash, often fare worse.
When regulators crashed a new Chevrolet Impala sedan into a concrete and steel barrier at 35 miles an hour recently, the dummy in the driver's seat escaped largely unscathed. Measured on a point scale in which 500 reflects a 1-in-25 chance of a life-threatening injury and 1,000 indicates a greater than 1-in-6 chance, the dummy in the Impala test suffered only 322 points' worth of harm.
By contrast, when a big Dodge Durango sport utility vehicle with four-wheel drive took the same test last December, the dummy in the driver's seat suffered head injuries scored at 1,008, as well as severe chest injuries. It was the worst score for driver's head injury of any recently tested vehicle and was particularly dismaying to regulators because it was the second time they had tested the Durango; DaimlerChrysler had made adjustments to the vehicle after it scored equally poorly in the first test a year ago.
"If I look at the truck, it's beautiful, but my gosh, it does let tremendous forces go into the dummy," said Richard Morgan, the group leader of the Government's New Car Assessment Program, which runs the tests.
The Government conducts a separate test at 30 miles an hour before letting any vehicle be sold in the United States. If the Durango had recorded the same head- or chest-injury scores on the slower test, it would have flunked and been ineligible for sale. But the slower test was never performed on the Durango; instead, the Government accepted DaimlerChrysler's assurances that the Durango was virtually identical to the Dodge Dakota pickup truck, which was tested and passed with good scores.
Sheila Gruber McLean, a DaimlerChrysler spokeswoman, said the company had done many of its own safety tests on the Durango, including the basic safety test at 30 miles an hour, and the vehicle had always passed. "We're confident this vehicle offers adequate protection for its occupants and meets all the standards it needs to meet, or exceeds them," she said.
Ms. McLean contended that Federal crash tests at 35 miles an hour are meant "to reflect a Durango hitting a Durango, which is a very rare crash." But regulators and the insurance industry disagree, saying the tests also simulate what happens when a vehicle hits a fixed object or another vehicle of similar size and weight.
The Durango was also rated "acceptable" in a somewhat different test for the insurance industry, in which a vehicle hits a barrier with its front, driver's-side corner, rather than with its whole front as in the Government test.
Other sport utility vehicles have somewhat better crash test scores than the Durango does for head and chest injuries, but do worse on potentially crippling leg injuries. The Cadillac Escalade, Chevrolet Tahoe and GMC Yukon Denali full-size sport utility vehicles have the worst scores for injuries to drivers' legs of any automobiles on the market that regulators have tested. The Jeep Grand Cherokee has the worst scores for injuries to front passengers' legs, according to raw data from recent Government tests.
By contrast, the Volvo S-70 sedan and V-70 wagon have the best scores on driver's head injury among currently available automobiles of any type, while the Ford Windstar minivan does best on chest injuries to drivers.
Sport utilities do better than large cars and almost as well as minivans on side-impact tests that the Government recently began conducting. Such side-impact crashes, although often deadly, are much less common in the real world than frontal crashes. KEITH BRADSHER

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1004 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Grand Old Spending Party

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN life's rich pageant, few spectacles are as dizzying as watching Congress spend the public's treasure. The sums are huge, the oratory windy, the techniques tricky as three-card monte.
As the old fiscal year ended and the new one began Friday, Congress was playing a giant shell game, saying one thing, doing another, and all the while juggling more than half a trillion dollars, leaving a huge stack of spending bills undone and the Government running on three weeks of legislative life support. 
 What is going on here is no carnival. There is a crossroads coming between the old ways of Congress and a new way, a trail still unblazed.
Just as this dimming decade, the post-cold war era, is defined by what it is not, the Republicans running Congress keep defining themselves by their opposites. Democrats tax and spend, they say; we cut taxes and spending. But they cannot this year; the green eyeshade of accountability doesn't fit.
The Republicans have promised -- publicly, daily, fervently -- not to finance the operations of the Government by spending money out of the Social Security trust fund. No Congress has done this since 1967.
To try to keep this pledge, they have used every accounting device in the book, and some previously unrecorded.
More than $20 billion dollars, nearly twice the previous record, is being drawn down from the ledger for fiscal 2001. A nearly equal amount is simply being erased from the books by a device known as "directed scorekeeping," which one respected Federal budget analyst, Stan Collender of the Fleishman-Hillard public relations firm, defines as "lying about the numbers." Venerable projects like the decennial census ($4.5 billion), a home-heating assistance program ($1.1 billion), agricultural aid ($8.7 billion at last count), along with still-uncounted billions for defense, have been deemed unforeseeable "emergency spending" -- meaning Congress can pretend they do not really count against the bottom line.
"This is subterfuge," said John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, ranking Democrat on the House Budget Committee.
But there was more, much more, as the millennial fiscal year 2000 began. On the floor of the House, members of Congress almost unanimously passed a non-binding resolution -- a promise made with fingers crossed -- pledging never again to spend a dime of the Social Security surplus.
Down the street, at that minute, their number-crunchers at the Congressional Budget Office were calculating that they were in fact spending $18 billion of the surplus, a number growing with every closed-door conference.
AND at the very moment President Clinton was signing into law a pay increase for members of Congress averaging $4,600 a year, Republican strategists were figuring that the only way to avoid spending the surplus was to delay a tax break for 20 million Americans on the lower rungs of the economic ladder.
None other than Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the presumptive Republican standard-bearer, denounced the idea, saying, "I don't think they should balance their budget on the backs of the poor."
House Republican leaders figured that by delaying that tax break, they could say with a straight face that they would be $400 million shy of dipping into the Social Security coffers. At the same time, behind closed doors, the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, was convincing them to add $500 million for an aircraft carrier to be built at his home state's shipyard.
Most ennobling of all was the speechifying in the well of the House as Representative Wally Herger, a California Republican, led the charge for the vote resolving not to spend the Social Security funds.
"What we are trying to do is break the addiction that we have had," he said, and sat back as Democrats ridiculed him.
"The gentleman from California ought to get the equivalent of the Congressional Medal of Honor for being picked to drag this mother out here," said Representative Jim McDermott of Washington. The minority leader, Richard Gephardt of Missouri, said it was like "saying we're going to quit drinking while we pour out a beer."
The resolution passed, 417-to-2. For the record, all the above voted for it.
It was barely two years ago that Congress overwhelmingly passed the Balanced Budget Act, which the President called a monument and Mr. Lott hailed as "the beginning of a new era of freedom." The act helped balance the budget, all right, although the tax revenues generated by a roaring economy were the key. They created what would have been the first real surplus in general Government funds in 30 years.
For each of those 30 years that the Government ran in the red, Congress has used the money from Social Security revenues to make up the difference. But now the spending limits, or caps, imposed by the Balanced Budget Act have cut spending on domestic programs, excluding the military, to their lowest level, expressed as a percentage of the overall economy, since 1962.
This relative penury in boom times proved intolerable for many Republicans. They have drained the once-in-a-generation general Government surplus and are about to draw down the Social Security funds.
Though the Democrats express shock and dismay at the Republicans' spending practices, things were arguably worse in many of the 40 years between 1954 and 1994, when Democrats controlled Congressional spending panels and became skilled at extracting Federal dollars for their own districts.
THE pressures on the Republican leaders to spend more money than they have on hand continue. The Pentagon consumes half the money they will spend this year, and what's left is not enough to divide between members clamoring for money to distribute to constituents, and popular programs like education, health care and medical research.
The path from the past that no one has charted is how to spend money wisely in a coming era of surpluses, linking public policy to public funds, instead of the present gathering at the Federal trough.

HEADLINE: The World;
50 Years Made China Change. But Not the Fear of It.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE imagery China chose to send around the world as it celebrated the 50th anniversary of the People's Republic on Friday seemed a throwback to Communism's brighter days: Half a million troops and citizens on parade, endless columns of missiles and armor, fighters and bombers screaming overhead. It was enough to make an old China hand like John Paton Davies, now 91, wonder whether the ever-emotional dynamic between the United States and China was headed into "another era in which we fear the Dragon."
The days when Mr. Davies and his State Department colleagues were purged in the peculiar madness of the McCarthy era for arguing that the Chinese Communists would be around for a while seem as remote today as pre-revolutionary Beijing. But the underlying fear that rattled the country in those years -- later to take the form of oscillating uncertainty about how to think about China and the kinds of threats it might pose -- has really never lifted. 
 "It was a mystery to me back in 1952," Mr. Davies said, his voice now whispery. "And it is still a mystery to me today. Our infatuation with China -- whether it is a potential enemy or a dear friend to be protected and indulged -- hasn't changed all that much."
Americans like to think they have a far clearer, more balanced view of China today than they did when Washington was seized with the question of who lost it, as if it was in America's power to win or lose. But ask the old China hands, and they will tell you that the pendulum of public opinion about China swings as vigorously as ever.
Tales of nuclear spies, and threats that China, if pushed, would resort to force to prevent Taiwanese independence rekindle wariness of a fearsome power whose real intentions seem forever cloaked.
But opposite images of a New China also spilled across the screen last week: jammed Internet cafes in Beijing, screaming stock traders in Shanghai, the cell-phone middle class in Guangdong taking the kids to soccer. Stitched together, those paint a comforting mosaic: a Chinese people that has -- finally -- become more and more like Americans.
Both images, of course, carry more than a little truth, and suffer from more than a little exaggeration. But they are also the yin and yang driving Washington's "engagement" policy -- usually driving it in circles.
If you ask the old China hands --- men like Mr. Davies who traveled the Chinese countryside as Mao battled the Nationalists -- the popular imagery Americans have of China has almost always been out of sync with the reality.
The enormous fear that China and the old Soviet Union would team up against America masked a bitter split between the two. Yet it seized Washington until the two countries actually began firing on each other in the 1960's. Then, in 1972, the exuberance around President Richard M. Nixon's visit largely ignored the death and terror of the Cultural Revolution. And the rush to invest in China's booming economic growth in the '90's masked the depths of its economic troubles -- the billions in bad loans, the wildly inefficient state-owned industries, the tens of millions of unemployed.
"We've so often deceived ourselves," said Culver Gleysteen, who grew up as the son of missionaries in Beijing and who, on Oct. 1, 1949, was among the few American diplomats left in China -- Vice Consul in the port of Dalian. Talking from his home in Boothbay, Me., Mr. Gleysteen said that in the years just after China changed hands "everyone in the State Department knew Chiang Kai-shek was a loser and we had to think about dealing with the Communists."
BUT Mr. Gleysteen recalls that his questions about engaging Mao prompted Walter J. Robertson, the Under Secretary of State for Asian affairs, to ask, "Is that young man Red?"
These days the arguments about how to deal with China are only occasionally tinged with questions of loyalty. But America's allies still worry about the periodic swings of views about China.
"I think it comes from the fact that the U.S. is so idealistic," said Kunihiko Saito, who has just ended a stint as Japan's Ambassador here. "So you become far more disappointed than we Japanese do when China does not act according to American standards."
It is possible that America is finally shedding some of its illusions. The companies that poured investment into China are pulling back, recognizing that the market that they thought would be the way to near-instant riches will, in fact, be a long slog. The think-tanks are consumed by a debate over two very different China threats: The China that gradually builds up its now small arsenal of intercontinental ballistic missiles or the China that risks an economic implosion that could set off the next Asian crisis. For every article about whether China will try to retake Taiwan there is another asking whether it will be the next Indonesia.
"There are, of course, people who fear a resurgent China, and China itself still fuels those fears," said Robert Suettinger, who spent his career China-watching at the Central Intelligence Agency. "But sort of backwards and by mistake we are moving toward a more realistic view, one that can avoid the ups and downs. We have to learn to live with great powers that are not our friend, but not our enemy either."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Hazy In Havana

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
Walking through the Partagas cigar factory in Old Havana is like smoking a box of Cohibas without ever having to light up. You just breathe deeply as you follow the raw tobacco leaves from the lower floors where they are separated into different qualities, to the upper floors where they are rolled into different brands, to the taste-test table, where our guide, Teresa, has the job of smoking different cigars all day for quality control. The best cigar rollers make about $15 a month, an average Cuban wage. Upstairs, at a raised table in front of a room with 100 men and women rolling cigars, sits the "lector," who entertains the workers by reading aloud all day -- newspapers in the morning, a Cuban novel in the afternoon.
There is one bit of news everyone in the factory would like to hear -- news they are sure could change their lives and make their business explode: that Cuban-American relations have been restored and the U.S. boycott of Cuba, and Cuban cigars, has been lifted. "What that would mean for the cigar business," says Teresa, her eyes wide, "Imaginate! Imagine!" 
 A week in Cuba teaches you that sooner or later most every conversation with a Cuban gets to this question: When might America restore relations? Cubans know that no real opening of their system is on the horizon, so only something from over the horizon might do it.
Why? Well, it's like this. For 30 years Fidel Castro had a bargain with the Cuban people: the Communist state provided all the basics of a job, education and health care, and the Cuban people provided the state with blind allegiance. But given the limitations of the Cuban economy, and the pain of the U.S. embargo, that bargain was only sustainable with the help of $6 billion a year in Soviet aid. When the U.S.S.R. collapsed after 1989, so did the aid.
In order to survive, the regime has had to open up a little to tourism, a little to free enterprise -- people can have restaurants in their homes, but with only 12 seats -- and a little to foreign investment. But only a crack -- because the regime knows that if people become independent of the state economically, they will become independent politically, and that will not be tolerated.
As result, what you have in Cuba today is what I would call "one party, no system." Cubans have the worst of all worlds: they have neither the cradle-to-grave, Soviet-financed welfare state of old nor the free-market, do-whatever-you-can-to-improve-yourself-just-don't-mess-with-the-regime system China has opted for.
Cuban officials insist there is a logic to their system and that growth is coming: "Our choice does not lie between the U.S. and China models," said Cuba's Vice Minister of Economic Planning, Alfonso Casanova Montero. "You can't compare us to China. China is not blockaded by the U.S. We are bent on avoiding a process of de-socialism. Given the aggression we have to constantly face from the U.S., if the income of our nation were deconcentrated, and if our political structure were deconcentrated, we would be much more vulnerable to foreign pressure. So the pressure from the U.S. has just the opposite effect on us than is intended."
But, in reality, this tight Cuban system clearly can't take care of its people's needs -- ration books get you through half the month. Yet it won't unleash them to freely lift their living standards. So, many Cubans are forced to take second jobs, depend on relatives abroad or engage in illegality. This is a shame, because there is enormous talent here. If unleashed, this place would be the Taiwan of the Caribbean, overnight.
But it's not being unleashed. Cuba's economy is a hodgepodge of Castroism and Thomas Cook tours, Canadian investment and central planning, Pepsodent billboards interspersed among Che Guevara propaganda billboards. The system produces enough income not to collapse, but not enough to really go forward. All the talk is about what they've been, not what they might become. So the place just treads water, a threat only to itself. And that's why people are hoping the U.S. will take the initiative, which it should. Cuba's people have suffered enough from being the rope in the U.S.-Castro tug of war.
And what if the U.S. doesn't move? "Political reform" is most unlikely here. The only hope is probably "biological reform," i.e. the passing away of the charismatic revolutionary generation in Cuba -- and its virulent Cuban exile opponents in Florida -- which might finally unlock the stalemate in Cuban-American relations. Imaginate!

HEADLINE: Housing Shortage

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"In Home Ownership Data, a Hidden Generation Gap" (Economic View, Sept. 26) did not discuss how to improve home-ownership rates for those under age 55. 
 The supply of housing is artificially limited because of exclusionary zoning policies. Such policies require minimum lot sizes, driving up the costs of housing, and they prevent builders from constructing the smaller units on smaller lots that young families can afford. Allowing the market to function more freely would allow lower- and modest-income Americans to afford so-called starter homes.
Allowing greater density where it is needed would expand property rights. Perhaps more important, it would preserve dwindling natural areas. Requiring minimum lot sizes maximizes the number of acres consumed by development in outlying regions.
 
THOMAS O'BRIEN
Charlottesville, Va., Sept. 28
 
The writer is the research director at Horizon Institute for Policy Solutions.

HEADLINE: DATABANK: SEPTEMBER 27-OCTOBER 1;
The Screech of a Broken Record

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE 

 BODY:
Investors took the measure of the largely negative third quarter that ended on Thursday -- and sighed. They swallowed hard on Friday after hearing further condemnation of the surging economy.
 In the last month, the rat-a-tat-tat of stronger-than-expected economic reports has been drowned out by the clarion call of analysts warning of possible interest-rate increases. 
 Friday was no exception, as stocks fell after the Commerce Department reported that personal income and personal spending rose in September while personal savings sank to new lows. Separately, the National Association of Purchasing Management said that the nation's manufacturing sector grew more than expected in September and that the prices of raw materials climbed to the highest level since May 1995.
 Though most analysts have been saying the Federal Reserve will not raise rates on Tuesday, the reports were enough to raise fears and continue the cycle.
 The income and spending report knocked the market down, Alfred E. Goldman, director of market analysis at A. G. Edwards & Sons, told The Associated Press. "Then the N.A.P.M. was the bullet." Still, the markets were little changed for the week. MICKEY MEECE

HEADLINE: Battle in Congress Over Milk Prices Pits East Against Midwest

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
For most families, the outcome of a battle in Congress over milk prices will mean just a few cents a week at the supermarket counter. But the livelihoods of tens of thousands of dairy farmers are at stake, and the issue has provoked a civil war between lawmakers from the East and those from the Midwest.
Normal allies like the liberal Democratic Senators Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont and Herb Kohl of Wisconsin are at each other's throats. Normal antagonists like Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, and Robert C. Smith, the Republican turned Independent from New Hampshire, are allies. 
 Down Pennsylvania Avenue, President Clinton is on one side and his wife, Hillary, the all-but-announced Senate candidate from New York, is on the other. Mrs. Clinton's likely opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani, took one position when he was merely Mayor of New York, but he changed his mind when he began running for the Senate.
The issue "is all about economic self-interest," Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said. That is apparent from conversations with family farmers in the warring regions.
David Krug, who has a 280-acre farm with about 75 cows in Owen, Wis., that has been in his family for 105 years, calculates that if a new pricing system developed by the Clinton Administration goes into effect, he might earn an additional $8,500 a year.
But 800 miles or so to the east, in Swanton, Vt., near the Canadian border, Paul Bourbeau, who has about 300 cows on a farm he runs with his wife and two grown sons, figures that changes in the system could cost him $16,000 to $18,000 a year.
Mr. Krug and Mr. Bourbeau are relatively prosperous, and unlike some of their neighbors, their farms will survive no matter how the political questions are resolved. "But it could make the difference between profit and loss," Mr. Bourbeau said, "the difference in whether you keep up the buildings and replace the piece of equipment you need."
At issue is a convoluted Federal milk-pricing system that was devised in 1937 to insure that fresh milk was available in all parts of the country. The minimum price that farmers can charge for milk is fixed monthly by the Department of Agriculture. The country is divided into 31 regions, and the set price is higher the farther the regions are from Eau Claire, Wis., historically the center of the dairy industry.
Developments in dairy technology, transportation and refrigeration have made the old system obsolete, but efforts to change it have always failed because the stakes are so high.
Then in 1996, Congress approved a law, called the Freedom to Farm Act, reducing and ultimately ending the subsidies for farmers who grow corn, cotton, rice, soybeans, wheat and most other crops.
Although the law retained the 60-year-old milk-price system, it instructed the Secretary of Agriculture to develop a more market-oriented system by this year. The law also permitted the creation of the Northeast Dairy Compact, which puts a floor on the price of milk that goes into bottles in the six New England states. The compact is supposed to expire when a new Federal pricing policy is put into place.
Early this year, Mr. Glickman offered the Administration's new plan, which would reduce, though not eliminate, the regional differences in what farmers charge for milk. The plan will go into effect unless Congress blocks it.
"The safest thing for me to have done," the Secretary said in an interview, "would have been to reaffirm the status quo, but I thought it was important to have a more up-to-date policy."
The Agriculture Department maintains that if its plan had been in effect for the last 12 months, the average price farmers received for milk would have been 58 cents higher for each 100 pounds of milk they sold, or nearly 5 cents a gallon.
But some farmers would have benefited more and some would have been hurt. The politics of the matter turn on the prevailing view that the Administration's plan would be to the advantage of farmers in the upper Midwest and to the disadvantage of those in the East.
The Agriculture Department has calculated that its plan would lower the supermarket price of milk by an average of 2 cents a gallon nationally. The Consumer Federation of America figures that the New England compact caused the price of bottled milk to rise 15 cents a gallon. A study by the Office of Management and Budget found that consumer prices were 5 cents to 20 cents higher than they would be without price fixing.
Those calculations are difficult to prove conclusively and are disputed by organizations representing dairy farmers in the East.
Eastern lawmakers have spent the year scrambling to preserve the Northeast Dairy Compact regardless of what happens to the new pricing plan. Eastern seaboard states outside New England, including New York, want to join the price-fixing arrangement, and Southern states want to form a compact of their own.
In Congress, it is almost always harder to change something than to leave it alone, and the dairy system is no exception. A majority appears to be in favor of blocking the Administration's pricing plan and allowing the New England compact to continue. But the majority may not rule.
Last month, the House of Representatives voted, 285 to 140, to block the new pricing plan and leave the old one in effect. But the latest word is that a House-Senate conference committee has decided, under instructions from House Republican leaders, to drop the section blocking the pricing plan.
The Republican leaders say they are philosophically opposed to putting such policy in a spending bill. Their political opponents say that Representative Dick Armey, the majority leader, and Representative Tom DeLay, the whip, both Texans, are representing the interests of the Suiza Foods Corporation, the Texas holding company that is the country's largest dairy producer.
Senators from the Midwest and the Northeast say they will filibuster legislation that puts their dairy constituents at a disadvantage, and neither side seems to have the 60 votes necessary to break a filibuster.
Secretary Glickman said that if Congress approved legislation blocking his pricing plan, he would recommend that President Clinton veto it. But campaigning in dairy counties in upstate New York, Mrs. Clinton has opposed the Administration's plan.
Mayor Giuliani, who used to be against propping up the prices paid farmers on the ground that consumers in New York City would have to pay more for milk, announced in August that he had changed his mind and now sided with the farmers.
All this squabbling seemed about to end this week when the dairy compact was supposed to go out of existence. But a Federal judge in Vermont provided a respite by issuing a temporary restraining order preventing any change in Government policy until hearings in a related lawsuit.
As they prepare their farms for winter, Mr. Krug in Wisconsin and Mr. Bourbeau in Vermont are following the developments in Washington.
"I'm concerned about what it will mean for the younger farmers here," said Mr. Krug, who is 60.
Mr. Bourbeau, who is 40, said: "When I started farming here 17 years ago, there were seven farms on my road. Now there are only two left. This could make the difference to lots of people up here whether they stay in business."
