HEADLINE: A Conversion At St. Vincents;
In Catholic Merger, Serving the Poor Means Courting the Affluent.

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
The trouble with being St. Vincents Hospital was best illuminated last month, when John Cardinal O'Connor found out he had a brain tumor. The Cardinal did not seek care at the hospital in Greenwich Village, but rather at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center on the Upper East Side.
While it was perhaps surprising that the Cardinal -- who technically oversaw St. Vincents as Archbishop until recently -- chose to get care elsewhere, the choice underscored the basic reality that high-profile patients have never been the hospital's bread and butter. 
 Indeed, the central mission of all the region's Roman Catholic hospitals has historically been quite unambiguous: to serve their neighborhoods and to treat the very poor. Competition from the city's prestigious medical centers was hardly a consideration.
But recently, St. Vincents Hospital and Medical Center, the jewel among the city's Catholic hospitals, has found itself facing the same problems that public hospitals face: lower reimbursement rates from Government programs and managed care companies, shorter hospital visits by patients, and increased competition from the city's most renowned hospitals.
The choice became clear: merge with others and become more cost-efficient, or perish. So last summer, the hospital, along with Sisters of Charity Healthcare, a hospital on Staten Island, agreed to merge with the Catholic Medical Centers of Brooklyn and Queens. Overnight, the region's largest Catholic health care system was born, with eight hospitals and scores of other services under its wing.
"It was clear if the mission of the Catholic health care system was going to be maintained, we had to bring them together," said Dr. Karl P. Adler, chief executive of St. Vincents Hospital.
The merger will be the first of many acquisitions, the executives involved in it said. When the city is left with a half-dozen or so consolidated systems, as most health experts expect, these executives want to make sure that one of them is Catholic.
"This kind of merger reflects what has been happening in health care generally," said Robert Field, the director of the graduate program on health policy at the University of the Sciences in Philadelphia. "Only religious institutions thought they could hold out longer. But in the past four to five years, it has been more and more difficult for them to resist the pressures of operating like businesses."
While the new entity will face many of the challenges inherent in any hospital merger, like ironing out who gets to run various clinical departments and trying to haggle with managed care companies, it will also face its own curious conundrum.
On the one hand, the merger was arranged ostensibly to help each hospital continue to serve the city's poorest and sickest residents. On the other, to compete as a behemoth among prestigious academic medical centers, the new system will have to attract many more higher-paying patients. As Dr. Adler said, "You can't serve the poor without a margin."
The executives of the merged entity, to be known as St. Vincents Catholic Medical Centers of New York, are taking bold steps that were unheard of 10 years ago.
They are grabbing high-priced talent left and right: Dr. John A. Ambrose, the new medical director of the hospital's cardiovascular center, was snatched from Mount Sinai last year; Dr. Samuel Lang was plucked from New York-Presbyterian to head a surgery unit. The consortium's leaders are looking for a chief executive whose resume suggests a Jack Welch, General Electric's chairman. (Non-Catholics are welcome to apply.)
They hope to draw wealthier patients by continuing to build clinical centers, like the spanking new cancer center at St. Vincents, and a cardiac care unit that is already making inroads, the executives said. The idea is that the smaller hospitals will still serve as primary care centers, referring patients with more complex problems to Manhattan.
St. Vincents has always enjoyed a better reputation than many of the region's other Catholic hospitals; it is the only one connected to a medical school, and its AIDS program is one of the most advanced in the country. But it will have to work hard to lure patients from the Mount Sinais and the New York-Presbyterians.
"The question is, will they compete effectively?" asked Rich Sinni of Watson Wyatt, a benefits consulting firm. "Here in New York you have some of the most world-renowned teaching institutions that there are. And we are in a real consolidation of the industry, so they want to carve out their niche."
Catholic hospital consortiums have been formed in other parts of the country for the same economic reasons that secular hospitals have merged: to consolidate management of payrolls and to gain more negotiating power with suppliers, laboratories and, most notably, managed care companies.
Catholic medical executives have also decided that to protect their values, especially regarding opposition to abortion and assisted suicide, they are better off sticking together when possible.
"We have no choice to be in health care; it is part of who we are," said the Rev. Michael D. Place, president and chief executive of the Catholic Health Association of the United States. "And we will continue to adapt while preserving our traditions."
The church is no stranger to changes in health care; in many ways, it was ahead of the consolidation curve. Its role in American health care began 272 years ago when nuns and religious laywomen took it on as part of their mission to help immigrants, and church-sponsored hospitals resulted. Over the years, different religious orders built large health-care systems, often stretching across broad swaths of territory.
One of the country's largest groups, Catholic Healthcare West, based in San Francisco, has been rapidly acquiring hospitals. The consortium, which has 37 hospitals, has met with some success. Last summer, for example, it was able for the first time to persuade Blue Cross of California to increase its reimbursement rates for all of the group's hospitals, after threatening to drop the insurer.
But attempts to merge hospitals from far and wide have also had problems. Some have not performed as well as hoped, and when the distances between a consortium's parts are great, one hospital may have trouble referring patients to another. What is more, cost savings, which at first can be substantial, tend to dwindle.
"The fundamental problem of operating such a large organization is continuing to achieve the economies of scale and economic benefits," said Laura Jacobs, a vice president of the Camden Group, a health care consulting firm in El Segundo, Calif. She added: "Catholic systems by and large are financially strapped to begin with. They have less wiggle room."
Deborah Cantu, the spokeswoman for Catholic Healthcare West, said it ran into speed bumps in its rapid growth. "We doubled in size between '95 and '99; that kind of expansion really takes its toll on individuals," she said. Many employees had no idea whom they were working for, for instance. "You tend to let things go because you are too busy working on the next big deal," Ms. Cantu said. "We need to pay attention at each instance of what happens after the merger."
The executives at St. Vincents say their health care system has an advantage over those that are spread over vast distances. They are working with hospitals across a relatively small region rather than over state lines, and the system will be anchored by a single academic medical center rather than by many. Of course, they are depending on patients from Staten Island and Queens to come to St. Vincents for many services, although the hospital already draws many patients from other boroughs because it is close to major subway stations.
The new consortium, which awaits final state and Federal approvals, still faces the sticky issues of corporate culture. On paper, the merger of the St. Vincents portion, which is sponsored by the Sisters of Charity, with the Catholic Medical Centers of Brooklyn and Queens, which are part of the Diocese of Brooklyn, is a 50-50 deal. But St. Vincents, by virtue of its location, size and affiliation with New York Medical College, is the obvious clinical heart of the combined unit. This has the potential to ruffle some feathers.
"Doctors who have been on Staten Island all their lives have a paranoia about doctors at a big hospital," said Dr. Adler, the chief executive of St. Vincents Hospital. "We have to deal with that perception that we are taking over."
Sister Elizabeth Vermaelen, president of the Sisters of Charity, said that there are striking differences in the ways the hospitals in the consortium are run. "At St. Vincents, you have New York-trained and board-certified doctors, where in the other hospitals, there are a lot of doctors from the third world, many not board-certified," she said. "Sometimes it is the academic world versus the street world" in terms of expertise.
Who gets a seat on the board? Who will run certain departments? Where will all the resources go? "In a meeting of egos, there are some setbacks," said John DePierro, president of the Sisters of Charity hospital. "People didn't want to put hard issues on the table."
Competing with other medical centers is not the central goal, but the management team of the merged entity hopes that will be one of the results.
"At the present time, we no longer have the personnel to provide care without getting paid," Sister Elizabeth said. "We are not doing this to be competitive; we are doing this because we believe in the mission of Catholic health care. If we can't provide quality services, we may as well be out of business."

HEADLINE: Campaign Fund-Raising Is at Record Pace

BYLINE: By DON VAN NATTA Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
If the phenomenal pace of political fund-raising continues, candidates for Federal office will spend about $3 billion in the 2000 campaigns, an increase of about $800 million from four years earlier, according to projections based on Federal Election Commission data.
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, who has raised an unprecedented $56 million in just seven months, is hardly alone in reaping the benefits of this cash-flush political season. This year's fund-raising totals for House and Senate incumbents and the national political parties have shattered all records, easily exceeding the most optimistic projections of fund-raisers and political operatives. 
 By November 2000, the Congressional races alone could cost $1 billion, experts estimate.
Fund-raising for the Congressional elections is being bolstered by the intense fight for control of the House of Representatives, where Republicans hold a six-seat majority. In the first six months of 1999, House incumbents raised $77.9 million, which is 47 percent more than they raised in the first half of 1997 and 88 percent more than they raised in the first half of 1995, according to Federal Election Commission statistics.
And soft money donations, the unlimited contributions to the parties for party-building activities, have increased 55 percent in the first half of 1999 over the same period in 1997. Soft money contributions are 75 percent higher this year than they were in the first half of 1995.
Experts project that there is likely to be at least $525 million in soft money contributed to the six major national political party committees by November 2000. That would be more than double the $262 million in soft money that was contributed to the parties in 1996.
As the Senate prepares to debate this month the merits of a sweeping campaign finance bill that would ban soft money, several campaign finance experts helped The New York Times project the total amount of money that would be raised by candidates and the national parties for the 2000 Federal elections.
Fred Wertheimer, the president of Democracy 21, a public policy organization here, assisted The Times by studying the pace of fund-raising in the first six months of 1999 and comparing it with the same periods in the past three election cycles.
Mr. Wertheimer estimated that the 2000 elections would cost nearly $3 billion, which he called "a conservative estimate." But he and others said that the figure very likely could exceed $3 billion, especially if campaign fund-raising continued at its current torrid pace.
"These are extraordinary numbers," said Mr. Wertheimer, who is an outspoken advocate of overhauling campaign finance laws.
"We're ending this century with oceans of political-influence money flooding our democracy and drowning out the voices of average citizens," said Mr. Wertheimer, who has accurately projected campaign costs for 20 years. "The historic idea we have contributed to the world, democratic self-government, is at risk here in our own country because of the corrupt campaign finance practices that pervade Washington."
Mr. Wertheimer said that fund-raising was up 95 percent in the House, but he estimated that the increase would be only 35 percent by November 2000. "Fund-raising in the first six months this year has been extremely intensive," he said. "But that doesn't mean this pace will sustain itself for two years."
Robert Steurer, an aide to Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican who is the Senate's most ardent opponent of limits on campaign contributions, did not dispute the $3 billion estimate, but added that the costs of campaigns had increased markedly.
Some campaign finance experts say it is very difficult to estimate at this stage how much money will be raised by the end of the election cycle in November 2000. There are too many variables, they say, and they cautioned that the projections could be gross overestimates or underestimates of the actual figures.
"It's throwing darts," said Kent Cooper, a former senior staff member at the Federal Election Commission who is the co-founder of a Washington research firm, Public Disclosure Inc., that operates a comprehensive research Web site (www.tray.com).
Fund-raisers and campaign finance experts offer several explanations, most not surprising, for the windfall this year.
Most of all, fund-raisers attribute their success to the booming economy, saying that the nation's prosperity makes it easier for more people to write checks of $1,000, the maximum an individual can give to one candidate.
"People feel flush," said Herbert E. Alexander, a professor emeritus of political science at the University of Southern California who has written extensively on campaign finance trends. "People have enormous paper profits from the stock market boom, and the technology people are suddenly millionaires and billionaires. I just think there is a lot of money around, and people want to use it to influence the process."
Another possible explanation for the early fund-raising pace is the early Presidential primary schedule, in which most of the major primaries will be over by late March. The earlier schedule has added to the perception among fund-raisers that they have less time to raise more money.
Larry Makinson, the executive director of the Center for Responsive Politics, said he agreed with the estimate that $3 billion would be spent on the 2000 elections. "A 50 percent increase from 1996 sounds right to me," he said. He also agreed with the projection that at least $1 billion would be raised and spent on the Congressional elections.
"Competition breeds the appetite for money," Mr. Makinson said. "It's impossible to imagine higher stakes. You have the real tangible potential for the Republicans to control all three branches of Government -- the Presidency, the Congress and let us not forget the Supreme Court. A lot of donors are licking their chops at the prospect of a Republican-dominated Government, and they will give big money to try to attain it."
Mr. Makinson also said that he thought there would be "an explosion" in independent expenditures on such things as issue advocacy advertisements. In 1996, the Annenberg Public Policy Center estimated that $45 million to $60 million was spent on issue advocacy advertisements. In February, John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O, declared that the labor federation would spend as much as $46 million in 1999 and 2000 on grass-roots lobbying and campaigning. Mr. Sweeney emphasized that the money would be used for political literature, phone banks to get out the vote, issue advertisements and voter registration.
In 1995, the unions spent $35 million on such activities, although the Republican leaders dispute that figure. Republicans estimated that organized labor spent as much as $500 million on the 1996 elections.
The Republican Congressional leadership, meanwhile, is also helping to raise millions of dollars for issue advertising to counter the union effort.
Mr. Wertheimer said that he estimated that at least $200 million would be spent this year and next year on such issue advertisements.
On Capitol Hill, fund-raisers said that they were astonished by the rate of contributions pouring in for House and Senate incumbents.
A total of 73 Senate candidates have raised $50 million in the first six months of 1999, according to election commission figures.
That amount is more than seven times the $7 million that 50 candidates raised through the first half of 1993, the last election cycle for the current group of 33 Senate seats that are now up for grabs.
Mr. Makinson predicted that the Presidential race might very well be "locked up" by October 2000, but that the fight for control of the House would produce enormous last-minute contributions.
"Let's not forget the impact of the wide-open race for control of the House of Representatives," he said. "When we're a month out, the House race will be the most important race to be decided, and it will attract a lot of last-minute money."
More than $60 million of soft money was raised in the first half of this year, a 75 percent increase over the first half of 1995.
Campaign finance experts predicted that the parties would raise at least $500 million in soft money by November 2000. But they cautioned that the figure could be significantly higher, especially after more contributions solicited by Mr. Bush's "Pioneers" fund-raising club of 150 people are counted.
By June 1999, the Pioneers had contributed $3 million of soft money, but campaign finance experts predict that they will raise huge sums for the Republican Party later this year. "They will be going gangbusters for the unlimited soft money contributions," Mr. Makinson said.

HEADLINE: Government Moves to Protect Alaskans' Subsistence Fishing

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: JUNEAU, Alaska, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Federal authorities took back a treasured prize of Alaska's statehood on Friday, seizing partial control of the state's rich fisheries to protect the rights of rural Alaskans who depend on fish for food.
Federal law requires the subsistence fishing priority for rural residents, including Eskimos, Indians and other native people, freeing them from many regulations that govern sport hunting and fishing. Opponents contend that this discriminates against urban residents who also rely on fish and game. 
 The Federal takeover came after eight Republican state senators blocked an effort to send voters an amendment to the state Constitution that would allow the rural subsistence fishing priority.
The subsistence priority applies to about 20 percent of Alaskans, or about 120,000 rural residents. Slightly less than half are Native Alaskans -- Eskimos, Indians and Aleuts.
The rule allows them to catch more fish and use more efficient fishing methods. It also allows protection of subsistence users by restricting the amount of wildlife taken by other hunters and fishermen.
The immediate impact of the takeover will likely be negligible because the summer fishing season is nearly over. But the impact is expected to grow over time.
The Federal managers could begin restricting commercial fishing as early as next year to allow more salmon to reach remote villagers.
The return of Federal fish managers is a bitter pill for many who recall disastrous Federal practices that depleted salmon runs before Alaska became a state in 1959. The Federal government's cozy relationship with big fish canneries was such a sore subject that more people voted to abolish the commercial fish trap than for ratification of the state's constitution.
"We could have prevented the offensive intrusion of Federal management of Alaska's fish and game resources, a right that really was at the root of statehood," said Gov. Tony Knowles, who called the Legislature into special session in a last-ditch effort to amend the constitution. "We could also have at the very same time protected the vital importance of subsistence to the economy, to the culture, to the way of life in rural Alaska."
The conflict between state and Federal law dates back to 1980, when Congress included the rural priority in the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. Nine years later, the Alaska Supreme Court ruled that it violated the state constitution's guarantee of equal access to fish and game. Federal managers took over subsistence hunting on Federal land the next year.
A 1994 court decision expanded Federal authority to lakes, rivers and streams within or alongside that land. Intervention by the state's powerful Congressional delegation fended off the takeover until this year.

HEADLINE: Nation's Arbitrators Begin New Term

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Opening its new term on Monday, the Supreme Court returns from a three-month recess to a docket that places the Justices squarely in the midst of some of the country's most passionate debates, from health care to campaign finance to Government aid to religious schools.
In addition, the Court will continue its re-examination of the boundary between Federal authority and state sovereignty, taking up new cases that move the federalism battleground into the arena of civil rights legislation, where the stakes are higher than ever. 
 The Justices accepted 15 new cases in the last three weeks, bringing the total to 44 and filling their argument calendar through January. Cases to be heard in the late winter and spring, perhaps several dozen more, will be added over the next few months to complete the 1999-2000 term.
Important cases scheduled for the term's opening days suggest the range of what awaits the Justices. On Monday, they will hear arguments on whether a 1996 law, the Anti-Terrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act, left any meaningful role for the Federal courts in reviewing state prisoners' convictions and sentences. On Tuesday, the Court will hear Missouri's defense of its $1,075 contribution limit for statewide political campaigns, in a case with clear implications for the similar limits under Federal election law.
On Wednesday, the Court will take up a constitutional challenge to a provision of Hawaii law that limits to descendants of the native Hawaiians the right to vote in certain elections. Transcending its exotic locale, this dispute could be a vehicle for a broader ruling about using race as a basis for government benefits.
It is not known how early in the term Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg will be able to return to work, after her surgery for colon cancer on Sept. 17. After her doctors found no sign that a small tumor had spread, she was discharged from a hospital here this week with an excellent prognosis.
If Justice Ginsburg cannot participate in the early arguments, she has the option of listening to the tapes and voting in the cases.
As part of the opening day, the Court will also announce the disposition of more than 1,700 appeals that have accumulated during the recess, nearly all of which the Justices will turn down without further review.
These are the highlights of the new term so far:
 
Federalism
In a series of decisions over the last four years, the Court has invoked several constitutional doctrines to curb the authority of Congress to impose requirements on state governments or to make the states answerable for their behavior as defendants in private lawsuits in either Federal or state court. Most of these cases were decided by 5-to-4 majorities, and federalism remains the current Court's most contentious issue.
The four federalism cases on the docket for the new term may well fan the flames even higher, because these cases have broad implications for the ability of Congress to enact civil rights legislation. The question in United States v. Morrison, No. 99-5, is whether Congress had the authority to pass the Violence Against Women Act, a 1994 law that permitted victims of rape and other crimes "motivated by gender" to sue their attackers in Federal court. A Federal appeals court ruled that the law was not a valid exercise of the power of Congress either to regulate interstate commerce or to enforce the equal protection guarantee of the 14th Amendment.
In Kimel v. Florida Board of Regents, No. 98-791, the Court will decide whether employees of state agencies can sue states for age discrimination under a Federal law, the Age Discrimination in Employment Act. The Justices' answer may determine whether other antidiscrimination laws, including such measures as the Americans With Disabilities Act, can be applied to the states.
The Court will decide in Reno v. Condon, No. 98-1464, whether state motor vehicle agencies can be bound by a Federal law that prohibits the commercial sale of drivers' personal information, which many states have found to be a profitable commodity.
And in Vermont Agency of Natural Resources v. United States, No. 98-1828, the question is whether states are constitutionally immune from lawsuits brought by private whistle-blowers under the Federal False Claims Act.
 
Free Speech
The Court has six First Amendment cases on the docket, an unusually high number that may reflect the unsettled nature of many free speech questions. For example, the lower Federal courts appear to be uncertain about the continuing validity of aspects of the Supreme Court's 1976 ruling in Buckley v. Valeo, which established the current constitutional framework for campaign finance.
The Federal appeals court in St. Louis struck down Missouri's $1,075 limit on contributions, close to the $1,000 limit the Court upheld in the Buckley case, on the ground that inflation since 1976 has whittled the value of $1,000 to under $400. That amount is too restrictive of the right of a citizen to "speak" by means of political contributions, the appeals court said in Nixon v. Shrink Missouri Government PAC, No. 98-963. Though the Supreme Court does not appear to have much appetite for reopening the campaign finance issue itself, even a narrowly based upholding of the Missouri decision could have that effect by presumptively invalidating the Federal limits.
In a case involving the privacy of government records, the Court will decide the constitutionality of a California law that makes arrest records available for journalistic and some other purposes, but not for commercial use, such as for sale to lawyers and insurance companies. In Los Angeles Police Department v. United Reporting Publishing Corporation, No. 98-678, the department is appealing a Federal appeals court's ruling that the restriction on commercial access violates the First Amendment.
Another First Amendment dispute involves student activity fees at public universities. The Federal appeals court in Chicago, viewing the fee at the University of Wisconsin as equivalent to compelled speech, ruled that students who objected to particular student organizations that received a share of the money had a constitutional right not to contribute. In Board of Regents v. Southworth, No. 98-1189, the university is arguing that the fee simply establishes a public forum in which all viewpoints are represented.
Two cases concern sexually explicit speech or expression. In one, Erie, Pa. v. Pap's A.M., No. 98-1161, the Court will revisit, for the first time in eight years, the government's ability to regulate nude dancing. The question in United States v. Playboy Entertainment Group, No. 98-1682, is the validity of a Federal law requiring providers of sexually explicit cable television programming to scramble the signal or limit the hours so that nonsubscribing homes cannot receive the programming inadvertently when children are watching.
In Hill v. Colorado, No. 98-1856, the Court will consider, for the third time in recent years, the validity of restrictions on protests outside abortion clinics.
 
Religion
A program under which local school districts use Federal money to provide computers and other equipment to private schools, including religious schools, within their boundaries was declared unconstitutional by a Federal appeals court. The Clinton Administration is supporting the appeal in Mitchell v. Helms, No. 98-1648, a case that may indicate how receptive the Justices will be in cases not yet before the Court to arguments for publicly financed vouchers for parochial school tuition.
 
Equal Protection
Under the Hawaii Constitution, the Office of Hawaiian Affairs decides how millions of dollars are to be spent on behalf of the state's native Hawaiian people, and only people of Hawaiian ancestry may vote for its trustees. The lower Federal courts have rejected a Hawaii-born white man's challenge to this restriction as an illegitimate racial qualification on voting. Defending its system in Rice v. Cayetano, No. 98-818, Hawaii is arguing that the restriction is based on Hawaii's special history and not on race as such.
 
Federal Law
Several cases have important implications for Federal regulatory programs and policies. In Food and Drug Administration v. Brown & Williamson Tobacco, No. 98-1152, the Court will decide whether the Government has authority under current law to regulate tobacco as a drug, a proposition that was rejected by a Federal appeals court.
In Pegram v. Herdrich, No. 98-1152, the Justices will decide whether people who receive medical care as a benefit of employment can sue health maintenance organizations for putting cost-containment goals above their duty to act in the best interest of individual patients.
The question in Friends of the Earth v. Laidlaw Environmental Services, No. 98-822, is whether a defendant in a suit brought by private citizens under the Clean Water Act can escape liability for civil penalties if it stops polluting while the lawsuit is in progress.
 
Criminal Law
In Illinois v. Wardlow, No. 98-1036, the Court will decide whether someone's unprovoked flight at the sight of a police officer is such inherently suspicious behavior as to justify the officer in pursuing and stopping the person and conducting a pat-down search.
The question in Williams v. Taylor, No. 98-8384, is what degree of deference the Federal courts owe to state-court determinations in reviewing a state prisoner's constitutional challenge to a conviction or sentence. The Court will be interpreting the central portions of the 1996 law by which Congress sharply restricted the jurisdiction of Federal judges to issue writs of habeas corpus; the question is, how sharply.
 
Grandparents' Rights
In a case from the state of Washington, the Court will rule on the constitutionality of state laws that give grandparents, and other relatives and "third parties," the right to seek court-ordered visitation over the objection of children's parents. The Washington Supreme Court struck the law down as violating the fundamental right of parents to decide how to raise their children.
While this case, Troxel v. Granville, No. 99-138, will give high visibility to the question of grandparents' rights, it also raises the deeper question, under the 14th Amendment's guarantee of due process, of how courts should identify and analyze fundamental rights.

HEADLINE: M.T.A.'s Capital Plan Goes Beyond Second Ave. Subway

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
The plan for a new Second Avenue subway got most of the attention, but the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's $17.5 billion, five-year capital plan includes a host of other improvements stretching across the New York region.
The plan, adopted on Thursday by the authority's board, would provide the first major investment in decades -- $3 billion -- in new tunnels, tracks and trains that would expand the region's subway and commuter rail network. 
 And while the plan immediately provoked protest over the $700 million that would be provided for the Second Avenue subway, an amount many riders and Manhattan officials say is too little, the ensuing debate may have diverted attention from the plan's breadth. It calls for large investments in subway platforms and train stations, and would lay the groundwork for the construction of other new lines far afield from Second Avenue.
"We want to do things that would improve the economy as well as improving the ride for our customers," Christopher P. Boylan, the M.T.A.'s deputy executive director, said on Thursday as he described what may have been one of the plan's biggest surprises -- $20 million for a new Metro-North station at Yankee Stadium.
That station would only be built "once lease discussion between the City of New York and the Yankees is complete," according to the plan.
Another project is a new tunnel extending the No. 7 subway line from Times Square to the far West Side, providing access to what some Manhattan officials envision as an expanded Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. If such an expansion takes place, "we stand ready to move," said E. Virgil Conway, the M.T.A. chairman.
The No. 7 subway project is presented as one of the most tentative on the authority's wish list, with money provided only for preliminary engineering and environmental studies. The plan allocates $75 million for it and two other long-range expansion projects: one would reconfigure tracks to give Metro-North trains access to Penn Station, the other would provide new express service by subway or Metro-North from Grand Central Terminal to lower Manhattan.
"If the Second Avenue subway isn't getting built until 2015, I wouldn't expect these others until 2050," said Gene Russianoff, staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, a riders' advocacy group.
Another major subway construction project was given higher priority, and more financial backing, than many transit experts outside the M.T.A. had expected. That is the plan to provide direct subway access to La Guardia Airport, probably through an extension of the N line in Queens.
The plan provides $645 million for the project, including $500 million widely believed to have been added at the insistence of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the Queens Borough President, Claire Shulman, both of whom have advocated the La Guardia subway link. It stipulates that the new line would be completed, at least to the boundary of La Guardia, by 2004. Connecting the line to airport terminals would take longer.
"Obviously the Mayor and Borough President have been pushing, but nobody is quite sure what the project will be," said Jeff Zupan, a transportation analyst for the Regional Plan Association, a nongovernmental planning group. There are several open questions, including whether to build a new underground branch of the N train or an elevated line through densely populated sections of Queens, where residents have already voiced opposition to an elevated structure.
With such a broad assortment of projects, the M.T.A. for now faces its biggest test in Albany, where proponents of a larger Second Avenue subway project have a powerful ally in Sheldon Silver, the Speaker of the Assembly, who represents the Lower East Side of Manhattan. As one of four members of an oversight committee with veto power over the capital plan, Mr. Silver has promised to block any version that does not provide far more money for a Second Avenue project.
Mr. Silver, reflecting criticisms by many on the East Side, said last week that a Second Avenue subway from the Bronx to the Battery was needed to relieve crowding on the Lexington Avenue line, something that would grow worse because of the largest project provided for in the M.T.A. plan. That project, budgeted at $1.6 billion, would provide access to Grand Central Terminal by the Long Island Rail Road, in turn drawing new riders to the Lexington Avenue line.
The plan includes several other projects that seemed likely last week to survive any compromise forged in Albany.
The largest are improvements to existing rail and subway stations, including a $225 million renovation of the Jamaica Station, which serves the subway and the L.I.R.R. That project, to be completed by 2004, has been designed to upgrade the station as a transfer point serving the new shuttle trains to Kennedy International Airport that are planned by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
Another project, budgeted at $75 million, would be at the Atlantic Avenue station in Brooklyn, another hub for subway lines and the L.I.R.R. Throughout the subway system, the plan calls for improvements ranging from new elevators and platforms to cosmetic repairs at 64 stations in all five boroughs.
The plan also provides $140 million to maintain and expand fare collection systems of New York City buses and subways, in which the Metrocard has overtaken tokens as the preferred method of payment. While upgrading the electronics of the Metrocard system, Mr. Boylan said the authority will explore other technologies like a "Smart Card" that could be used like the "E-Z Pass" at highway toll booths, enabling customers to charge their fares to a credit card account.

HEADLINE: Sept. 26-Oct. 2;
Strong Economy Lifts Poor

 BODY:
Rising incomes lifted 1.1 Americans above the official poverty threshold ($16,665 for a four-person household) last year. But the nation's strong economy didn't help narrow the income gap between rich and poor Americans. The gap didn't widen, but a high-end household making $130,000 still earned eight times more than a family at the poverty line, which is the same ratio that's existed since 1993.

HEADLINE: Survey Finds Lingering Racial Inequalities

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Race continues to play a significant role in the success of Americans, from jobs to education to housing, according to a study conducted in Atlanta, Boston, Detroit and Los Angeles.
The five-year survey, the Multi-City Study of Urban Inequality, which was released on Friday, found that racial stereotypes and attitudes heavily influenced the job market, with blacks at the bottom. 
 The study, sponsored by the Russell Sage Foundation in New York City and the Multidisciplinary Program in Inequality and Social Policy at Harvard University, looked at 9,000 households and 3,500 employers in the four cities. The project tried to understand the patterns of racial inequality and how they have been affected by economic changes.
While the study found that minorities are doing better financially in the 1990's, they are making less money and working fewer hours than their white counterparts. Blacks also had more difficulty finding jobs.

HEADLINE: Distant Rumbles of a Korean War Massacre

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "G.I.'s Tell of a U.S. Massacre in Korean War" (front page, Sept. 30):
I can understand, though not forgive, that military strategies and tactics can be flawed and that soldiers may act irrationally, resulting in innocent civilians becoming targets of merciless killing. 
 What really angers me is South Korea's reluctance and inaction regarding its people's claims. The Government has clearly forsaken the rights of its people in the name of economic, political and military allegiance to the United States. And while it is important for South Korea to maintain a good relationship with the only remaining superpower, at what price? If the South Korean Government is not willing to stand up for the injustice inflicted upon its people, who will?

HEADLINE: NONPROFIT GROUPS ACCUSED OF BILKING LUNCH PROGRAMS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Officers of many nonprofit organizations have illegally enriched themselves by pocketing millions of dollars of Federal money that was meant to feed poor children in day care homes, Federal investigators and state officials say.
The inspector general of the Agriculture Department, Roger C. Viadero, said the nonprofit organizations had routinely filed false claims overstating the number of meals served at the homes, which are recruited and supervised by the nonprofit groups. Some of these groups, he said, claimed Federal money for meals served to "nonexistent children" in fictitious day care homes, while others extorted money by demanding kickbacks from legitimate day care providers. 
 "This type of fraud takes food out of the mouths of children," Mr. Viadero said, summarizing what his agents had found in more than 3,200 unannounced visits to private day care homes and child care centers that receive Federal money.
The Federal Government spends $1.7 billion a year to provide meals for 2.4 million children in day care.
Mr. Viadero began a nationwide investigation of the program after a whistle-blower complained about problems at a nonprofit organization in California.
Mr. Viadero's office issued a comprehensive audit last month laying out the abuses, which he said were attributable in part to basic flaws in the program's structure that Federal officials had not moved fast enough to correct.
The nonprofit groups, known as sponsors, play a critical role as middlemen between the Government and day care homes and centers. The sponsors are supposed to monitor the day care homes. They review and pay claims for meals served. And they are supposed to insure that the meals meet Federal nutrition standards.
So far the Federal Government has filed criminal charges against 44 people, asserting that they defrauded the program, known formally as the Child and Adult Care Food Program. Twenty-eight of them have been convicted or pleaded guilty; the other cases are still open.
Child care advocates see the Federal program as a guarantor of quality care. But Mr. Viadero said children were often short-changed.
In his audit report, Mr. Viadero, a former New York City police officer who worked for 15 years at the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said: "Day care providers and their sponsors were found to be submitting false claims on a grand scale. Some were engaging in money laundering, embezzlement, forgery and extortion. Many simply padded their payrolls to justify fatter Government checks."
Katherine J. O'Neill, a dietitian at B. J. Enterprises in Scottsdale, Ariz., a sponsor for 380 day care homes, said the Federal investigators had focused too much on paperwork and bookkeeping errors.
"Children can be happy even if day care providers don't do all their paperwork on time," said Ms. O'Neill, whose company was criticized for such errors. "Kids are eating better because of this program. Instead of a bologna sandwich and Kool-Aid, they have a turkey sandwich, lettuce, fruit and milk for lunch."
The need for day care has grown in recent years because a booming economy has drawn more parents into the labor force and millions of women are trying to comply with work requirements of new Federal and state welfare laws.
On the average, each sponsor supervises 150 day care homes, but some are responsible for more than 1,500. State licensing rules vary, but typically a home may have up to six children. Most of the children are under the age of 5, but some may be as old as 12. Day care homes receive more Federal money if they are in low-income neighborhoods or serve children from low-income families.
The audit cited many improprieties. In California, the husband-and-wife owners of Pacific Asian American Family Care pleaded guilty to defrauding the Government and were ordered to pay $2.2 million in restitution. Prosecutors said the owners had submitted claims for inflated budgets, which included payments to nonexistent employees and bogus business entities.
The Government said the defendants, Kyung Ho Moon and Wan Hee Moon, used Federal money to buy four houses and to pay college expenses for their children. Mrs. Moon worked simultaneously for the State of California, monitoring the work of child care sponsors, including her own company.
In another case, Federal prosecutors said a Salt Lake City couple had misappropriated Federal money "designated solely for the reimbursement of meals previously eaten by underprivileged children." The indictment says the couple, William and Magda Evans, demanded kickbacks from legitimate day care providers and claimed Federal payments for day care homes that did not exist or had been excluded from the program. A trial is scheduled for Nov. 15.
In Toledo, Ohio, the New Jerusalem Church of God in Christ claimed Federal reimbursement for meals served in day care homes that did not exist. The homes listed vacant lots and abandoned houses as their addresses. Seven people have pleaded guilty and been ordered to pay restitution totaling more than $1.3 million.
In his recent report, the inspector general said, "We found sponsors operating as nonprofit organizations, but enriching themselves at the expense of the children to whom they were supposed to provide meals."
In some places, Mr. Viadero said, sponsors have retained 15 percent to 30 percent of the food money intended for child care centers. "This is one of the most significant causes of fraud and mismanagement" in the program, he said.
Sponsors defend the practice by saying they need the money to cover their administrative costs. But the inspector general said he could find "no correlation" between the sponsors' actual costs and the amounts they kept for themselves.
The inspector general said that many sponsors "honestly did not understand" the child care food program, and that Federal officials "could have prevented or detected much of the fraudulent activity" if they had been more vigilant. Officials of the Food and Nutrition Service, a unit of the Agriculture Department, have often failed to act on warnings from the inspector general for four years, Mr. Viadero said.
Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said he was working with the inspector general to root out fraud in the child care food program. Samuel Chambers Jr., administrator of the Food and Nutrition Service, said the agency would propose stricter rules for the program later this year. But Mr. Viadero said, "We do not believe that the corrective actions proposed to date go far enough."
Several state officials said that local sponsors had shared information about how to run scams without being detected. But Federal officials said they did not see evidence of a multistate conspiracy.
The inspector general found that sponsors were reluctant to enforce Federal requirements because they receive more Federal money as they sign up and supervise more day care homes.
In effect, he said, sponsors compete against one another, and homes tend to prefer the more lenient sponsors.
Mr. Viadero said this was "a basic flaw in the design" of the program.
State officials, while acknowledging some responsibility, said the Federal Government had also been at fault.
Harley R. Fancher, administrator of special nutrition programs in the Arkansas Department of Human Services, said, "The basic problem is that the U.S. Department of Agriculture has been in the business of shoveling out money with little or no accountability."
Mr. Fancher, who worked for the Federal Food and Nutrition Service for 20 years, said: "In some cases, a sponsor signs up a bunch of day care providers by mail and never visits the homes. The providers are not trained in meal preparation or record-keeping."
The Federal Government has a list of nonprofit organizations cited for serious deficiencies and tries to keep them out of the program. But Mr. Fancher said a company excluded in one state might try to reinvent itself and enter the program in another state.
"For example," he said, "if XYZ Inc. does something wrong in North Carolina, it may come back as the ZYX Corporation in Arkansas or Oklahoma."
Robert C. Kenny, a spokesman for the New York State Health Department, said that the Federal Government was conducting two investigations of the child care food program in New York, but that no one had been accused of wrongdoing to date. The New York program receives $120 million a year in Federal money to feed 55,100 children in family day care homes and 242,000 youngsters in child care centers.
The inspector general's report cited many examples of problems in the food program, including these:
*Fifty-three day care providers in Decatur, Ala. -- more than 40 percent of those reviewed -- claimed reimbursement for meals served to children on days when the homes were closed or the children were absent.
*In Pennsylvania, an officer of a nonprofit organization, CT Child Nutrition Services, pleaded guilty to embezzling $92,000 of Federal money. She used the money "to cover personal expenses, such as her mortgage, and to buy equipment for a restaurant she owned."
*A former member of the Detroit school board was convicted of fraudulently obtaining $15.5 million in Federal food money. She overstated the number of meals served at 16 day care centers. In addition, the office manager of a nonprofit organization in Phoenix, Feeding Arizona Kids, pleaded guilty to theft of Government money after investigators found that she had written 60 checks to people whom she falsely identified as day care providers. She deposited the checks in her personal account.

HEADLINE: Akio Morita, Key to Japan's Rise As Co-Founder of Sony, Dies at 78

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
Akio Morita, the co-founder of the Sony Corporation who personified Japan's rise from postwar rubble to industrial riches and became the unofficial ambassador of its business community to the world, died today in Tokyo. He was 78.
He died of pneumonia, the company said. He had been in failing health since a stroke in 1993. 
 More than anyone else, it was Mr. Morita and his Sony colleagues who changed the world's image of the term "Made in Japan" from one of paper parasols and shoddy imitations to one of high technology and high reliability in miniature packages.
Founded in a bombed-out Tokyo department store after World War II, Sony became indisputably one of the world's most innovative companies, famous for products like the pocket-sized transistor radio, the videocassette recorder, the Walkman and the compact disk.
And Mr. Morita, whose contribution was greater in marketing than in technology, made the Sony brand into one of the best known and respected in the world. A Harris poll last year showed Sony as the No. 1 brand name among American consumers, ahead of American companies like General Electric and Coca-Cola.
A tireless traveler who moved his family to New York in 1963 for a year to learn American ways, Mr. Morita also spearheaded the internationalization of Japanese business. Sony was the first Japanese company to sell its stock on the New York Stock Exchange, in 1970, one of the first to build a factory in the United States, in 1972, and still one of the only ones to have even a couple of Westerners on its board.
Sony also became a major force in the American entertainment business, acquiring CBS Records in 1988 and Columbia Pictures, the Hollywood studio, in 1989. The latter purchase, however, turned into an embarrassing debacle as Sony suffered big losses in Hollywood.
In the process, Mr. Morita, with his white mane and quick tongue, became the unofficial representative of Japan's business community, generally working to smooth trade relations between his country and the United States, but sometimes stirring resentment in both countries with his pointed criticisms.
"He was truly a statesman par excellence in a business sense," said Mike Mansfield, the former Senator and United States Ambassador to Japan. "Internationally, he did more for Japan in a business sense than anyone else in Japan."
To the day of his death, nearly six years after the stroke that removed him from an active role in business, he was still no doubt Japan's most famous business executive, and the only one many Americans could name or recognize in a photograph. Time magazine selected him in December as one of 20 "most influential business geniuses" of the 20th century, the only non-American chosen.
In his own country, where executives tend to be self-effacing, Mr. Morita was viewed as a bit flamboyant and arrogant. He was the first to fly around in a corporate business jet and helicopter. He appeared in a television commercial for the American Express card. He served on the boards of three foreign companies. He took up sports like skiing, scuba diving and wind surfing in his sixties. He cavorted with the rock star Cyndi Lauper after Sony bought CBS Records.
Shortly before he suffered his stroke, Mr. Morita made waves in his home country by saying that Japan was like a "fortress" and that its unique business practices were alienating its trading partners. "Although there is much to commend in Japan's economic system, it is simply too far out of sync with the West on certain essential points," he wrote in The Atlantic Monthly in June 1993.
He advocated shorter working hours, more dividends for stockholders of Japanese companies and a sharp cutback in government regulation. Now, as Japan struggles through an economic slump that has lasted most of the decade, some of what Mr. Morita advocated is being adopted.
"Japan was coming closer to him and seeing the need for that kind of leadership," said Yoshihiro Tsurumi, professor of international business at the Baruch Graduate School of Business at the City University of New York.
 
Never Comfortable In West's Business World
In his book "Sony: The Private Life" (Houghton Mifflin, 1999), John Nathan suggests that Mr. Morita, a Japanese traditionalist at home, was never really comfortable in the Western business world, despite the many American business executives and politicians he entertained and counted as friends.
Mr. Nathan, a Japanese translator and University of California professor of Japanese culture who was granted free access to Sony executives, quotes Mr. Morita's eldest son, Hideo, as saying of his father, "He had to 'act' -- I'm sorry to use that word but I can't help it -- he had to act as the most international-understanding businessman in Japan." But Hideo adds, "It was never real."
And Sony's current president, Nobuyuki Idei, is quoted as saying, "Japanese of the generation before mine had an inferiority complex about foreigners. Akio Morita himself was a living inferiority complex."
Despite being virtually synonymous with Sony, especially outside Japan, Mr. Morita did not actually become the company's president until 1971 and its chairman and chief executive until 1976. Before that he was the junior partner to Masaru Ibuka, an engineering genius who, while not as widely known in the West, is considered in Japan to be the main founder of Sony. Mr. Ibuka died in December 1997 at the age of 89.
Akio Morita was born on Jan. 26, 1921, into a wealthy family in Nagoya, an industrial city in central Japan. As the eldest son, he was groomed from elementary school age to succeed his father as president of the sake brewery that had been in the family for 14 generations.
But in junior high school, Akio became fascinated by his family's phonograph, a rare appliance in Japan at that time. He became an avid electronics hobbyist, building his own crude phonograph and radio receiver. He studied physics at Osaka Imperial University as World War II was starting. Mr. Morita enlisted in the navy under a program that would allow him to do research instead of serving in combat.
It was while developing heat-seeking weapons that Mr. Morita first worked with Mr. Ibuka, 13 years his senior, who before the war had started an electronic instrument company.
After the war, Mr. Ibuka set up a new company in a bombed-out department store in Tokyo, making kits that converted AM radios into short-wave receivers. Mr. Morita happened to read a newspaper article about it and contacted his old friend. The next year, when Mr. Ibuka wanted to incorporate the company, he asked Mr. Morita to join.
Mr. Morita, Mr. Ibuka and another executive traveled to the Nagoya area to implore Mr. Morita's father to release his son from the family business. The elder Mr. Morita not only agreed, he also later became a financial backer of the new company, Tokyo Tsushin Kogyo, or Tokyo Telecommunications Engineering Corporation, which was inaugurated on May 7, 1946, with an investment of about $500.
 
Looking at a Transistor, Seeing More Than Others
The company produced Japan's first reel-to-reel magnetic tape recorder. A few years later it licensed the rights to the transistor from Bell Laboratories, after overcoming resistance from the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. Officials at Bell Labs warned that the only consumer use would be for hearing aids.
But Sony then produced Japan's first transistor radio in 1955. (An American company, Regency, produced the world's first a few months earlier but didn't succeed in selling it.) In 1957, Sony came out with what it termed a pocket-sized transistor radio. But the radio was actually a bit too big for most pockets, so Mr. Morita had Sony salesmen wear special shirts with extra-large pockets.
There followed the Trinitron television in 1968; the first successful home VCR, the Betamax, in 1975; the Walkman personal stereo in 1979; and the compact disk, developed with Philips N.V. of the Netherlands, in 1982.
Not all products were successful. Sony has stumbled several times trying to sell personal computers. And in 1981, Mr. Morita announced the Mavica, a digital camera that recorded pictures on a floppy disk instead of on film. But the camera never made it to market and critics accused Mr. Morita of making a premature announcement to burnish Sony's image as an innovator.
Mr. Morita did not believe in market research. "Our plan is to lead the public with new products rather than ask them what kind of products they want," he said in his autobiography, "Made in Japan," (E.P. Dutton, 1986), written with the journalists Edwin M. Reingold and Mitsuko Shimomura. "The public does not know what is possible, but we do."
Mr. Morita prided himself in particular on the Walkman, the portable stereo cassette player with headphones. Actually, according to the official corporate history, it was Mr. Ibuka who came up with the idea. But Mr. Morita pressed hard for the project, overcoming resistance within Sony to a tape player that, in its early versions, could not record. Mr. Morita, despite initial reservations about the product's name, eventually ordered all Sony subsidiaries around the world to call it the Walkman.
From the start of the company, however, Mr. Morita was much more involved in marketing, while Mr. Ibuka handled technology development. And from the start, he had an international orientation, traveling to New York and Europe in the 1950's to sell the company wares.
Such international focus was needed because as a new company, Sony had some trouble breaking into its home market, where more established manufacturers had close relationships with retailers. Indeed, Japan's other big postwar success, the Honda Motor Company, also succeeded first in the United States and to this day sells more cars in America than in Japan.
Mr. Morita soon realized that the company needed a name that foreigners could pronounce and remember. So in 1958 the company name was changed to Sony, derived from the Latin word sonus, meaning sound, and from the American vernacular "sonny boy," which Mr. Morita hoped would purvey a young image.
One of Mr. Morita's cardinal tenets was to foster and protect the company's brand name. Early on, Bulova, the watch company, said it would order 100,000 radios but would sell them under its own name. Mr. Morita turned down the huge order. His colleagues back in Tokyo thought he was crazy. But, Mr. Morita wrote in his autobiography, "I said then and I have said it often since: It was the best decision I ever made."
 
Betamax: Another First And a Bad Decision
Mr. Morita's worst decision might have been with the Betamax, the first successful consumer VCR, which came out in 1975. Sony did not readily license its technology to other electronics companies. So most of its Japanese rivals banded together behind the VHS system, which offered longer recording time. Eventually, the Betamax was run out of the market.
Sony evolved into a company that, by Japanese standards at least, was very Westernized, though in many ways it was traditionally Japanese. All company employees, from the president on down, wear company jackets, a common practice in Japan. But at Sony the uniforms were styled by the designer Issey Miyake.
Mr. Morita first criticized some of his country's business practices in 1966, when he wrote a book, published in Japanese, with a title that might loosely translate as "An Essay on the Useless School Career." He criticized Japanese companies for hiring and promoting people based only on what college they had attended. Sony even stopped asking applicants the name of their college, and it was one of the first Japanese companies to base salaries partly on merit instead of solely on seniority.
Perhaps because of Sony's dependence on exports, Mr. Morita tried to reduce trade tensions with the United States. In the late 1960's, Sony forged a temporary joint venture with Texas Instruments, then the world's leading semiconductor company, allowing it to set up operations in Japan.
In 1972, Mr. Morita set up a subsidiary to export American products, like Regal cookware and Whirlpool refrigerators, to Japan.
"Selling pans and cookware and refrigerators was not our bag, but Akio believed in doing something for the U.S.-Japan relationship," said Sadami (Chris) Wada, who ran that effort and then handled government relations for the Sony Corporation of America for many years. The operation was abandoned some years later as unsuccessful.
In 1988, Mr. Morita founded the Council for Better Corporate Citizenship, made up of Japanese companies. At a time when Japanese politicians were angering African-Americans with insensitive remarks, one of the council's first projects was to make thousands of copies of an abridged version of "Eyes on the Prize," the American television documentary about the struggle of blacks for equal rights, and distribute it to high schools in Japan.
Mr. Morita was not averse to using his influence among American politicians and business executives to lobby for Sony. He barnstormed the United States in 1984, meeting with governors and with President Reagan, threatening to build Sony factories only in states that did not have the "unitary tax," a tax on a multinational corporation's global earnings, not just those in the state. Eventually California and other states scrapped the tax.
But while Mr. Morita was often perceived as a friend of the United States, he was often critical of it and proud of being Japanese, flying his country's flag over Sony's New York showroom when it opened in 1962. He often told a story of how ashamed he was on his first trip to Germany in 1953. At a restaurant he ordered ice cream, and it came with a small paper parasol stuck in it. "This is from your country," the waiter said.
In the 1980's, when Japan seemed on top of the world, Mr. Morita was among the most vocal of the Japanese executives in criticizing American business and hailing the success of the Japanese model.
He said American managers were financial paper shufflers who "can see only 10 minutes ahead" and were not interested in building for the long term. And he said that American companies were losing interest in manufacturing, that the United States was "abandoning its status as an industrial power." Those factors, he said, and not trade barriers, were the reasons for America's trade deficit with Japan.
"There are few things in the United States that Japanese want to buy, but there are a lot of things in Japan that Americans want to buy," he wrote in 1989. "This is at the root of the trade imbalance. The problem arises in that American politicians fail to understand this simple fact."
In 1989, Mr. Morita was the co-author, along with a nationalist politician, Shintaro Ishihara, of "The Japan That Can Say No," a book that urged Japan to stand up to American trade demands, which it said were motivated partly by racism. The book also said Japan had the power to change the world balance of power by selling its advanced computer chips to the Soviet Union instead of the United States.
Even though those strident remarks were generally in the chapters Mr. Ishihara wrote, the book created a stir when an unauthorized translation made its way around Washington. Mr. Morita frantically back-pedaled, saying the book had not been intended for an American audience. And he refused to authorize an English translation.
It was later that year that Sony paid $3.4 billion to buy Columbia Pictures, a purchase driven largely by Mr. Morita, who thought that if Sony had owned a studio issuing movies in the Beta format, it would not have lost the VCR wars.
Although Sony prided itself on being more Americanized than its Japanese rivals, the purchase became a lightning rod for American concern about a wave of Japanese acquisitions of American companies and real estate. "Japan Invades Hollywood" read the cover of Newsweek. In Japan as well, Sony came in for criticism for stirring up anti-Japanese feeling in the United States.
Mr. Morita had a simple answer. "If you don't want Japan to buy it, don't sell it," he told a New York Times reporter shortly after the purchase. Nevertheless, sensitive to concerns, he promised that the studio would be run by Americans and would be free even to make a movie critical of Japan's Emperor.
Worse than misjudging the political reaction, however, the seemingly sophisticated Sony proved to be a babe in the woods in Hollywood.
Sony is generally considered to have paid too much for the studio, and it paid several hundred million dollars more to hire managers away from Warner Brothers, provoking a costly fight with that studio. And those managers, in turn, spent money extravagantly and produced a string of box office bombs. Mr. Morita and his successor as Sony chief executive, Norio Ohga, perhaps because they were worried about stirring up anti-Japanese sentiment, exercised little oversight.
 
$3.2 Billion Lost In Hollywood Venture
In late 1994, in one of the most embarrassing moments in its history, Sony announced that it would suffer a loss of $3.2 billion from its investment in Hollywood. But it has stuck with the studio, now called Sony Pictures Entertainment, and appears to be turning it around.
The Morita name will live on at Sony because many members of Mr. Morita's family are involved in the company.
Besides his wife, Mr. Morita is survived by his eldest son, Hideo, who now runs the sake brewery and other family businesses; a younger son, Masao, an executive with Sony Music Entertainment in Japan; and a daughter, Naoko Okada, who also lives in Japan. He is also survived by his brother Kazuaki, who volunteered to take over the family sake brewery in Mr. Morita's stead; another brother, Masaaki, a long-time Sony executive, and a sister, Kikuko Iwama, who was married to the late Kazuo Iwama, a former president of Sony.
In the 1990's corporate Japan, worried about escalating trade tensions, turned to Mr. Morita, whom it once considered an arrogant maverick, to be its official leader. Mr. Morita was expected to become chairman of Keidanren, Japan's most powerful business lobbying organization, a post that had always gone to the head of a company in an old-line heavy industry like steel.
But on Nov. 30, 1993, while playing his usual 7 A.M. Tuesday tennis game, Mr. Morita suffered a cerebral hemorrhage. A year later, just days after Sony announced its huge Hollywood loss, Mr. Morita, confined to a wheelchair, attended a Sony board meeting in Tokyo and resigned as chairman.
He had spent much of his time since then undergoing rehabilitation at his beachfront home near Diamond Head on the Hawaiian island of Oahu. At first Mr. Morita was able to speak a little, shake hands and hit back tennis balls spit out by a machine, said Mr. Wada, the retired Sony government relations manager.
But more recently, Mr. Wada said, Mr. Morita had lost the ability to speak and communicated mainly through eye contact with his wife, Yoshiko. The couple's Christmas greeting card last year had a message from Mrs. Morita saying that her husband rose at 6 A.M., retired at 9 P.M. and spent much of the day in rehabilitation. "He may be overeating," she said, mentioning his fondness for eel.
At first Mr. Morita returned to Japan periodically, but that stopped a couple of years ago when friends and family worried that the flights were further damaging his health. Mr. Morita did not attend the 1997 funeral of Mr. Ibuka.
But Sony officials still visited him in Hawaii to keep him up to date on the business and show him new products. In January 1998, some 200 executives, friends and dignitaries went to Hawaii to attend a party for Mr. Morita's 77th birthday, considered a lucky age in Japan.

HEADLINE: A Sound Sleep

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FRIED 

DATELINE: HOBOKEN

 BODY:
It's 4:30 A.M. Do you know where your drummer is?
If you're a rock band working at Water Music Recorders here, "he's probably upstairs," said the studio's owner and manager, Rob Grenoble, and that much more likely to be available for the recording session in the morning. 
 "No more waiting for Louie," said Mr. Grenoble, a wiry man with a quick, hoarse voice, for whom the studio is a life's work, and a home.
Water Music is the New York area's only residential recording studio, complete with furnished apartments. And it is the apartments and the state-of-the art recording gear that have lured bands from all over the world and created an atmosphere light years from the music-industry boardrooms just across the Hudson.
On a typical night recently, John Agnello, a record producer, was wolfing down Chinese food while he watched the MTV Music Awards. A. J. Cope, a singer and songwriter staying in an apartment on weekdays to work on new material, lay on a nearby couch, strumming her guitar. Dave Smalley, a rock singer, songwriter and guitarist up from Virginia to work on an album, sat on the floor of the studio control room drawing pigs and butterflies with Mr. Grenoble's 2-year-old daughter, Song. In the loft upstairs, Those Bastard Souls, an acoustic rock band whose members have convened from Memphis, Chicago and Brooklyn, took a break from pre-tour rehearsals while their lead singer cooked up a batch of spaghetti sauce.
Built in an abandoned feather and down factory with money lent by the New Jersey Economic Development Authority, the six-year-old studio retains the look of its industrial Hoboken neighborhood. Its walls are not lined with gold records. But its client list includes nationally known names like Ben Folds Five, Pavement, John Popper of Blues Traveler, Government Mule and dozens of independent music heroes.
For engineers, the lure is the 48-track single-frame Neve mixing console, with full computer automation -- the Dom Perignon of recording equipment -- and a 2,080-square-foot room. Mike Barbiero, a producer and mixer of Counting Crows and Guns 'n' Roses fame, fell in love with the room in 1998. He said, "It's not a posh location, but it's a very flexible room sound, a vast space that can be manipulated in many ways."
For the record labels writing the checks, Water Music offers top-of-the-line equipment near New York, but "away from the high price of New York hotels," Mr. Barbiero says.
For musicians like David Strouse of Memphis, who has the look of a rock-and-roll professor with his wire-rim glasses and dress slacks and shoes, it's the "easygoing, down-home feeling." As he stirred his sauce, he talked about the stresses of making a record and finding a place for his band members, spread out across the country, to meet. Looking around at the art hanging on the white walls, he said, "It's nicer than most of the places I've lived."
It's also a place of creativity. Ms. Cope works on songs with Mr. Agnello and Mr. Grenoble in their spare hours. John Popper spent several weeks in residence this year writing the material for the album he later recorded in the studio downstairs.
Finally, it's a place for barbecues. Mr. Agnello described the scene when a young band he was working with in the small studio, known as the Inferno, met the punk legends the Misfits, working in the the Big Room in May. Someone had the idea of a Memorial Day barbecue in the garden outside the studio door, and both bands partook. That broke the ice. "For a week it was just a bunch of people hanging out," Mr. Agnello said. "Two of our guys were singing background vocals for the Misfits, and they were doing hand claps on our record. Their producer would say, 'Hey, come on in, what do you think of this?' "
The idea of a musical community was part of the original concept for Mr. Grenoble, who came to Hoboken nearly 20 years ago from farming country in upstate New York with his own band, Cries. He and his bandmates found themselves in the studio business when local musicians wanted to use the recording gear Cries had set up in its rehearsal studio.
Darting around the 15,000-square-foot complex with his classically gaunt rock-and-roll face and his dark, multi-directional hair, the 47-year-old producer, writer, manager, engineer and on-site father explained that he wanted to create a place that would combine the fun he had playing in a band with a successful business model.
"I've been an artist my whole life," Mr. Grenoble said. "It's fun being a biz guy."
One of the reasons for the studio's success is that "Rob is such a personality himself," said James Mastro, a Hoboken musician, producer and music store owner. "He's been incredibly helpful to local bands."
Another reason is simply convenience. Mr. Agnello persuaded by a Swiss band, Favez, to come to his part of the world by pointing it to the Water Music Web site (www.watermusicrecorders.com). Chris Wicky, the Favez singer and guitarist, saw the names of bands he admired, as well as a chance to see New York at a price they could afford. "It's really fun, and it's really practical," Mr. Wicky said. Of his accommodations here, he said, "You feel like you're living at a friend's house."
Mr. Agnello lives in Manhattan but often stays at the studio anyway. "I wake up at a quarter to 11, walk into the shower, and I'm ready to work at 11." But beyond convenience, "when everyone's relaxed, the results come easier and better," he said. "And the barbecue is so cool. It's so American, and you're in an environment that's so not that."
American or not, it's an environment in which Mr. Grenoble has chosen to rear his daughter. He lives with Song and her mother, Kathy Griffin, on the premises, which are still under construction. The evening playtime for the baby (full name: Song River Jones Griffin Grenoble) includes singing Beatles songs with her dad, and then trotting off to the studio control room, which offers what her mother describes as "the best busy box in the world, especially the harmonizer."
The studio is something of a first child for Mr. Grenoble and Ms. Griffin, who managed Cries in its early days in the 1980's. She shared the work and finances as Mr. Grenoble bought out his bandmates and gradually moved into the current address from 1989 to 1991; the studio opened as a business in June 1993. Soon after, Ms. Griffin left the band and took a day job as a comptroller for her uncle's air-conditioning business.
Mr. Grenoble says they can separate their private lives from the studio simply by shutting the door. "Being the boss" and having a staff of three helps, he says. Equally crucial is the studio design. The floating foundation -- the floor sits on spongy plastic supports, which muffle vibrations -- allows for almost complete soundproofing.
Running a rock-and-roll hotel has its drawbacks. Mr. Grenoble mentions a Canadian band that destroyed the hardwood floor in the loft apartment by playing hockey. As for running a recording studio, he compares it to running a brothel: "You deal with whoever comes in the door."
Increasingly, the studio's international reputation (he lists Japan, Spain, South Africa, Australia, Croatia, Norway, Cuba and England as countries that have sent bands there) has enabled the studio to bring in the original, independent music Mr. Grenoble prefers. Enjoying his most successful year yet made it easy to turn down a recent offer from a condo-minded real estate agent to buy the property for five times what Mr. Grenoble originally paid for it.
And his daughter usually visits about once an hour. "We always bust up a session to say good night," he said.
Mike Barbiero, who works at the studio in part because it helps keep him close to his own children in Alpine, adds, "And it keeps the language in line a little bit."
