HEADLINE: Last Innings at a Can-Do Cathedral

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
On the night 35 years ago before the Astrodome was unveiled to the world, Tal Smith walked onto the field and stared at the lights twinkling beneath the great curved roof of steel and glass. He stood inside the huge air conditioned bowl, surrounded by nearly 50,000 empty seats, and beheld the artificial wonder of it all.
Never mind that the Astrodome would later be compared to the "working end of a gigantic roll-on deodorant." Never mind that baseball purists would later blame the Dome for many of the modern ills of the game. In an opening night exhibition with the Yankees on April 9, 1965, President Lyndon Baines Johnson watched Mickey Mantle hit the first home run, and the nation, like Mr. Smith, a Houston Astros executive, seemed astonished at the world's first indoor coliseum. 
 "This was truly a revolutionary venture," said Mr. Smith, now the president of the Astros. "It wasn't just a new ball park. There were people who would line up to tour the building even without an event. They would marvel at it."
Once promoted as the Eighth Wonder of the World, the Astrodome is now a relic, as outdated as a polyester leisure suit. On Sunday, the Astros will play their last regular season game at the Astrodome before moving next season to a new, state-of-the-art downtown ball park. Mammoth enough to contain an 18-story building, the Dome was a monument to the Texan appetite for big things and an emblem of a colorful era when men like the stadium's eccentric creator, Judge Roy Hofheinz, reshaped Houston and Texas through will and money.
Now, the Astrodome will stand all but abandoned, a monstrous, climate-controlled white elephant that has succumbed not only to the changing economics of sports but to the changing expectations of what a building must do to hold our attention. Along with the NASA Space Center, the Astrodome transformed Houston in the 1960's from a big city backwater; the Dome became the world's biggest stage. When Bobby Riggs challenged Billie Jean King to the "Battle of the Sexes" in tennis, in 1973, only the sheer mass of the Astrodome could do justice to the comic magnitude of the event.
"There's a little bit of a sense of loss as we abandon this thing we were so proud of," said Stephen Klineberg, a sociologist at the University of Houston. "It was the most exciting thing that had ever happened to Houston."
The new stadium, the $250 million Enron Field, says as much about Houston today as the Astrodome did a generation ago. Fashioned with a retractable roof, it has real grass, and it joins many new ball parks in evoking baseball's past. Named for a gas company, Enron Field bespeaks a more generic, corporate face of Houston, the nation's fourth-largest city. If the Astrodome attracted world attention (and a sniff of scorn), Enron Field's ambitions seem more prosaic: It will make a lot of money for the Astros, provide a more intimate setting for baseball and, city officials hope, spur redevelopment of the east side of downtown.
"In the sports industry," Mr. Smith conceded, "the economics dictate. Buildings become obsolete because they can't generate the same revenues as in other facilities." He added, "It's regrettable, but it has been 35 years. It had a great run."
The Astrodome will not be demolished, the fate reserved next year for one of its imitators, the Kingdome in Seattle. But its future is muddled at best. The Astrodome has only one big tenant left, the Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo, which is held each February. But even the rodeo has hinted that it, too, might leave if Houston attracts a new professional football team and with it, a new football stadium.
The same Astrodome where Elvis sang and Billy Graham preached could wind up as a bloated hall for trade shows. "I don't think that any Hofheinz ever stood in the way of progress in the name of nostalgia," reflected Fred Hofheinz, a two-term mayor in the 1970's who was his father's chief aide during the construction of the Astrodome. But, he added, "I do want to see it survive."
With its serrated skyline and knot of interstate highways, Houston today is a vast sprawl that seems far removed from the city that Judge Roy Hofheinz dominated in the 1950's and 1960's. A cocksure impresario who fancied cigars and any other totem of opulence, Judge Hofheinz was reputed to sleep only when bored: He was a lawyer at 19, a state legislator at 22, the Harris County judge at 24, a millionaire in business by his 30's, and at 40 elected mayor.
By the 1960's, the judge, as he was always known, took control of Houston's efforts to attract a major league baseball team. He was fascinated by the notion of building a cooled, domed shopping mall and surmised that air conditioning could be the salvation for baseball in heat-choked Houston as well. It was a toss-up as to which local endeavor was considered more incredible: NASA's efforts to put a man on the moon or Judge Hofheinz's plan to build a coliseum where men would play baseball indoors.
He did it. The city was granted an expansion team, the Colt 45's, and the judge, adopting the futuristic glint of the space program, renamed the team the Astros (the other choice was Stars). Members of the grounds crew wore orange space suits. A scoreboard flashing electronic lights (and advertising) dominated the outfield. A buzzing capacity crowd watched the Astros beat the Yankees 2-1 in extra innings as a 6,600 ton air-conditioning system chilled the arena to 72 degrees.
"Nobody can ever see this," the judge had said the day before the game, "and go back to Kalamazoo, Chicago, New York, you name it, and still think this town is bush league, that this town is Indian territory."
The spectacle of the Astrodome, the judge realized, was part of the sell. He built his own five-story apartment/playhouse above right field, complete with a two-story Presidential Suite, a Circus Room, a Medieval chapel, a barber shop and a bowling alley. He built smaller suites, the forebears of today's luxury suites, for rental to corporations or wealthy individuals. On opening night, Fred Hofheinz fetched bowl after bowl of chocolate ice cream for President Johnson, a Texan, as he admired the Presidential Suite.
"He was the quintessential salesman," Mr. Hofheinz said of his father. The Astrodome "was made up like Disneyland in order to make it something people talked about."
Baseball traditionalists would come to despise the Astrodome and the artifice it brought to the game. The field itself, initially made of grass and later sawdust, eventually was replaced by a carpet patented as Astroturf. To the judge, the turf was one of the Dome's many wonders; his ground crew jauntily vacuumed it in their space suits. But artificial turf was derided as a hazard to players and a blaspheme against the pastoral history of the game.
Stephen Fox, an architectural historian who teaches at Rice University and the University of Houston, said the Astrodome was an "immensely important" building in the mid-20th century, if mostly as triumph of engineering rather than architecture. "It is one of the great monuments of American hubris in the 1960's in this kind of sense of no limits," he said, adding graciously, "It is not a tremendously refined work of architecture."
But Mr. Fox noted that the Dome played an unexpected role in the evolution of Houston. When construction costs ran over budget, the judge and city officials called a second bond referendum. With opposition growing, the judge lobbied the city's growing, if largely disenfranchised, block of black voters, promising that blacks could attend all events at the Dome and also could work there.
"It played a key role in the desegregation of public facilities in Houston," Mr. Fox said.
Today, with the city's population divided fairly equally among blacks, whites and Latinos, Houston has a black mayor, Lee Brown. Mr. Klineberg, the sociologist, noted that as Houston has matured, the business and political climate dominated by Judge Hofheinz and a small number of other white leaders has changed markedly. "This is a radically different kind of economy and a new kind of business leadership and a multicultural environment," he said.
Charles Savino, an executive with the Greater Houston Partnership, said that the judge's can-do spirit lived on in local leaders like Bob McNair, who is trying to lure a new professional football team and build a new stadium. But, Mr. Savino said, Houston is a different place now.
"We're kind of becoming more like the rest of the country," Mr. Savino said, which might make an apt epitaph for the Astrodome. Over the years similar stadiums, some larger, were built in other cities. The awe and wonder wore off: In 1966, more than 550,000 people paid to tour the Astrodome. By 1998, the number had fallen to 112,000.
The judge lived in the Dome for five years after his first wife died, but he suffered a stroke, moved out and eventually relinquished control of the team. He died in 1982.
On Sunday, after the Astros and the Dodgers finish the game, a ceremony is planned to honor the judge's stadium. The Astros might make the playoffs, meaning at least one more game, but Sunday is being treated as the farewell. Older players will congregate, and Willie Nelson will sing "Turn Out the Lights." Fred Hofheinz will stand on the field he helped build and say goodbye as a living link to his father. "He was very proud of that building," he said. "It was the pinnacle of his life."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: In the Clutch;
That Team Didn't Choke; It Just Stinks

BYLINE: By ALLEN BARRA

 BODY:
CLUTCH and choke -- as sporting terms, they came from auto racing and spread to other sports. Hemingway, writing about Joe DiMaggio, defined "clutch" performance for all time: "Grace under pressure." "Choke" has never needed a Hemingway to define it.
Both words are much on the minds of New York baseball fans after the New York Mets' pennant and playoff hopes took a dramatic dashing at the hands of the Atlanta Braves in successive weeks. For the most part, Mets fans hold one of two opinions. 
 One faction, much the larger, holds that the Mets' losses to the National League East-leading Braves (not to mention to the lowly Phillies) were classic "choke." The other, more philosophical, faction holds that, after all, few really expected the Mets to have 92 victories at that point in the season, and why call it a choke when the team with the best record in baseball, the Braves, wins a handful of tough, closely contested games? Isn't that what the best team is supposed to do? The Mets didn't choke; the Braves were just the better team. No one has asked the Mets themselves, but they'd probably prefer the second argument.
Generally speaking, athletes tend to believe in clutch performance while denying the existence of choke. Every professional athlete is happy to talk about his favorite big-play performance, but nobody ever wants to single out the chokers. Interviewing the former Yankee pitcher Jim Bouton a few years ago, I was curious to see if he thought Ralph Branca choked when he gave up that famous home run to Bobby Thompson in the 1951 playoffs. "Why would you call that a choke?" Bouton replied. "Branca thought he made a great pitch. Didn't anyone ever hit a good pitch for a home run?"
I once asked Bubba Smith, the former Baltimore Colts defensive lineman, if his team choked in the most famous of all Super Bowl upsets, the 16-7 loss to the Joe Namath-led New York Jets in 1969. "Hell, no," the 290-pound Smith shot back at me. "We didn't choke. We went right there and put our game plan into effect." Then, I timidly inquired, why did the 22-point-favorite Colts get stomped? "Because," he said, "our game plan stunk."
Trying to pin down just what is a clutch or choke performance, then, is like trying to find evidence for the existence of the Loch Ness monster: Lots of people swear they have seen it, but no one has been able to capture it. George Ignatin, an economics professor at the University of Alabama in Birmingham and a longtime sports statistician, is adamant. "Clutch and choke performance in baseball are illusions," he said. "Someone has to win, someone has to lose, and if you get a large enough sampling to make a valid study, you'll find that what a player does in so-called pressure situations is usually what he has done for his entire career."
Then why is the impression that a player has choked or come through in the clutch so strong? "Because of the drama," says Ignatin. "We remember the big game in September or the hit in the ninth inning, but we forget that the games in May or the hits in the third inning are every bit as important when it comes to winning games. We want heroes, so we make a hero out of John Elway for leading fourth-quarter comebacks without noticing the guy who didn't have to come back in the fourth quarter because he was so great in the first and second quarters.
"We like to say 'He came through in the end with the game on the line,' but we forget that the game is always on the line."
But if choking is an illusion in team sports, what about one-on-one games like tennis, or even a sport involving solitary performance like golf? Many tennis fans regard Jana Novotna's Wimbledon flops in 1993 and 1997 as the biggest chokes in modern time, but Allen St. John, who covered the match for Inside Sports, insists: "She was playing over her head, and when she realized it she came down to earth, hard. Or, to say it another way, what should have been happening from the beginning suddenly happened at the end."
In modern golf, no one has more of a crash-and-burn image than Greg Norman, but Chris Hodenfield, the editor of Golf & Travel magazine, thinks Norman's penchant for choking is overstated. "If you check, you find a lot of great players who have had similar folds," he said. "In the 1930's, Craig Wood, like Norman, lost playoffs in all four major tournaments. Probably no one has more of a reputation as a clutch performer than Arnold Palmer, but he lost three playoffs in the U.S. Open."
Hodenfield calls Palmer's loss of a seven-stroke lead to a charging Billy Casper in the '66 United States Open to be one of the biggest collapses he's seen by a major player and notes: "Funny how no one ever called Arnie a choker. But Norman will probably never shake that image now, no matter how well he plays."
So, it would seem that all the evidence indicates that clutch performance and choking are mostly illusion. The logical part of the brain may accept that, but the fan in us wants to believe that our heroes either come through in the clutch or choke with the game on the line. They say there are no atheists in foxholes, and there are no philosophers in the ninth inning of a close game.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
An Energetic Irish Troupe That Keeps on the Move

BYLINE: By KAREN FRICKER; Karen Fricker is an American theater critic living in Dublin.

DATELINE: DUBLIN

 BODY:
THE major artistic challenge facing theater in Ireland today may be what to do about all those plays. The nation's illustrious history of dramatic writing hangs over contemporary Irish theater like a combined blessing and curse; modern companies either seem to be searching for the next Synge or O'Casey (or McDonagh) or trying to steer the theater away from the almighty word altogether.
One recent production here suggests, however, that a middle ground might be possible. New Yorkers will be able to see it when "The Whiteheaded Boy," a 1916 Irish classic, opens at the Harvey Theater at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday. Presented by Barabbas, an innovative Dublin theater company, it is part of the Next Wave Festival at BAM and the fifth of six stops on the company's first American tour. After next Sunday's performance, the production moves to Chicago. 
 Barabbas . . . the Company, its formal title, is one of several theater groups founded in Ireland in the early 1990's that emphasize physical movement over traditional text-focused presentation. Among their forerunners is the Theatre de Complicite in England, founded in the 1980's and influenced by Jacques Lecoq, the French movement artist who taught numerous mimes. The three members of Barabbas are Veronica Coburn, 33, Raymond Keane, 42, and Mikel Murfi, 34, who named the group not after the biblical character but one in a nonsense story he used to tell his nieces and nephews. The three performers have trained in various forms of physical theater and share an interest in clowning. Mr. Murfi studied for three years at the Lecoq school in Paris. Barabbas soon became a favorite with the critics for their collaboratively devised productions performed in an energetic style. But by 1997 they realized they needed some fresh inspiration.
"We were a little devised-out, to be honest," Ms. Coburn said, "and we were thinking it was time to come back to text. So we and our friend Gerry Stembridge started to think about doing an Irish classic in the style of the company -- or rather about how the style of the company might accommodate a classic work."
Beyond the need for new creative energy, Barabbas was also interested in broadening its audience. "We always felt that what we were doing could be quite popular," Mr. Keane said, "but our work tended to appeal more to the adventurous theatergoer. This was a way to bring what we did more into reach for everyone."
The play they chose was itself ripe for renewal. Lennox Robinson's "Whiteheaded Boy" was hugely popular in its day. From its premiere at the Abbey Theater in 1916 through 1965 it enjoyed more performances than Synge's "Playboy of the Western World," but it subsequently fell out of fashion.
A textbook example of a well-made play (in which every scene advances a tightly wound plot), it tells the story of a propriety-obsessed family thrown into disarray when the coddled youngest son, Denis, drops out of Trinity College. The play's title, which refers to that character, is an Irish expression comparable to the term fair-haired boy. Though the satire is gentle, Robinson's disdain for middle-class pretensions comes through clearly in the eventual victory of straight forward youth over moralizing elders.
The unconventional approach to the material by Barabbas, with Mr. Stembridge as director, is clear even before the performance starts: the three company members, wearing matching gray waiterlike costumes, wander around the stage, chatting among themselves and casually acknowledging the audience. They portray 11 of the 12 roles, indicating character changes only by switches in physicality and vocal quality. They also alternate in speaking Robinson's opinionated stage directions ("He's kissed her, glory be to God!").
Just when the audience has settled into this stylized mode of performance, the action is subverted by the entrance of the final character, a fourth actor (Louis Lovett) dressed in period garb and performing in a more subtle style than the others, who are very obviously surprised by the new arrival.
"We've established ourselves as storytellers, but the new performer is from the old play, from the world of the theater," Mr. Keane said. "Through our performance style, we're saying, 'Here's a great play that we're going to act out for you now.' But then someone appears who is a real actor. That clash of theater traditions is one of the things the production is about."
Ms. Coburn elaborated: "If you look at it in black and white, the outsider is old Ireland and we are new Ireland. But part of the point is that nothing much has changed. All the things that Robinson is sending up are still around to some extent. The warmth we try to create between the audience and performer is related to the warmth we feel when we see something we are all familiar with; it's a kind of complicity. It's like we're all putting our hands up and saying we know these people; we are these people."
The Barabbas "Whiteheaded Boy" has had considerable popular appeal. It was revived three times in successively larger Dublin theaters, and has toured throughout Ireland and to England and Wales. "We've reached a broad number of people, particularly outside of Dublin," said Mr. Murfi, "who know our name now and might take a chance on another one of our shows."
The next project will be a collaboration with the Abbey involving 15 female actors and one male actor (Mr. Keane), co-directed by Ms. Coburn and Mr. Murfi. Entitled "Brilliant Days Blue," it is a new piece about love and weather and will rely much more on movement and the dynamic between actors than on text. But the company is insistent that their current foray into classic text was necessary, culturally as well as artistically.
"Some people say Irish theater never seems to be getting over its usual preoccupations -- the kitchen sink, the family, the rural conditions," Ms. Coburn said. "But even in this booming economy we have now, there still seems to be a need to trawl through this stuff. Perhaps we have to talk about it as a country, as a nationality, before we can move on."

HEADLINE: Domestic Arrangements

BYLINE: By Karla Jay; Karla Jay is director of women's and gender studies at Pace University. Her most recent book is a memoir, "Tales of the Lavender Menace."

 BODY:

TO BELIEVE IN WOMEN
 What Lesbians Have Done for America --
 A History.
 By Lillian Faderman.
 Illustrated. 434 pp. Boston:
 Houghton Mifflin Company. $30. 
 THE United States military may have developed stealth bombers, but gay men and lesbians, long habituated to the dangers and pleasures of invisibility, have been using "gaydar" for decades. This highly developed extrasensory perception can detect our kind in virtually any social situation, and no heterosexual romance -- on screen or off -- can mask the fragrant scent of a fellow traveler. O.K., we do make mistakes occasionally, but our skills are less in demand now that the rich and famous have taken to outing themselves. Not to be limited by star worship, we have recently extended our devotion to Ellen DeGeneres's mother, Cher's daughter and even Newt Gingrich's half sister.
Thrusting aside a recent issue of the gay magazine The Advocate, which promised the dubious delight of unveiling Jerry Falwell's homosexual cousin, I turned hopefully to "To Believe in Women." Lillian Faderman is no amateur at outing the dead, whether famous or virtually unknown. Faderman, a professor of English and lesbian studies at California State University, Fresno, is the author of "Surpassing the Love of Men" and "Odd Girls and Twilight Lovers," two important books in which she detailed female romantic friendship from the 16th century to the present. Her scholarship has introduced many grateful readers to lesbian history and cultural practices.
In "To Believe in Women," she uses a thematic framework. Starting with the suffrage movement, Faderman traces the contributions of women-identified-women to a number of important social movements and professions in the United States, including abolition, settlement houses, unionizing efforts, education and medicine. She balances the very famous, like Susan B. Anthony and Jane Addams, with the lesser-known, like three pioneering physicians, Marie Zakrzewska, Mary Walker and Emily Blackwell. Faderman sees history as a tool "for presenting role models to the young, giving people reasons for pride in the identities they have chosen, teaching lessons about the past that we may be able to incorporate in the present."
Moving beyond her own definition of lesbianism in "Surpassing the Love of Men" -- a romantic commitment to another woman -- Faderman expands the term in her new book to encompass all "intense woman-to-woman relating and commitment." For some, her tendentious claims are a welcome corrective to biographies that erased lesbian existence. However, three decades of diligent recovery efforts by historians and biographers like Blanche Wiesen Cook, Carroll Smith-Rosenberg, Leila J. Rupp and Jonathan Ned Katz have already mined the sexual histories of many of the figures Faderman writes about, including Addams, the founder of Hull House, and M. Carey Thomas, the former president of Bryn Mawr.
Faderman's generous definition of lesbianism permits her to claim for our side many women who shared living arrangements with other women. After installing suffrage leaders Susan B. Anthony and Carrie Chapman Catt (who was twice married to men) in the Lesbian Hall of Fame, Faderman then argues for a lesbian influence in a number of other important social spheres, from settlement-house work to women's education and the professions. Almost all female social reformers, one might conclude, were lesbians, and the goings-on in Hull House were remarkably akin to those in Radclyffe Hall's house.
Few would dispute Faderman's observation that heterosexual marriage historically tended to burden women with the responsibility of bearing children and overseeing household chores. But sexual orientation was probably less of a factor for these reformers than the financial wherewithal that freed them from the tedious demands of earning a living. Most eschewed motherhood as well. Many pioneering women were indeed single or lived with female companions, but others found supportive male partners. A few feigned illness or embraced antisocial behaviors to liberate themselves from their families' marital expectations.
Without a doubt, there were singular qualities of "intense woman-to-woman" relationships that gave some women the strength to devote themselves to social causes and career advancement. However, Faderman fails to investigate adequately the daily dynamics that allowed one or both partners to engage in successful social activism or economic reform. Moreover, while she underscores the fact that same-sex pairs were treated with the respect generally reserved for heterosexual couples, it is never clear how far knowledge of their intimate arrangements traveled outside their own circles, or whether most of these women would have considered themselves lesbians. Since some of the women Faderman writes about, like Frieda Miller, the former director of the Women's Bureau in the Department of Labor, died as recently as 1973, it would be telling to explore why lesbian denial was generally a factor in these relationships.
Faderman suggests that "heterosexual professional couples might do well to ponder the domestic arrangements of the lesbian pioneers." Yet while both halves of Faderman's couples were often devoted to a cause, one woman generally took responsibility for running the household or was wealthy enough to have servants. Though a few of the women Faderman discusses, like Frieda Miller, raised children, most sacrificed childbearing to careers and causes. Today, when both heterosexual and homosexual couples struggle to balance the demands of work and home, Faderman may inadvertently be broadcasting a discouraging message about the prospects for combining family life with a profession or social activism.
Rather than going forward with some clear analytical framework, Faderman is frequently sidetracked by the gossipy contents of amorous letters, even though the passions of many of these women, including the relationship between Mary Woolley, president of Mount Holyoke College, and her partner, Jeannette Marks, have already been milked elsewhere.
For those who need a dose of pride and a slice of history, Faderman's portraits should strike a popular note. "To Believe in Women" is a decent starting point for learning about these pioneers and their contributions to American life. It sure beats reading about some important person's cousin twice removed while waiting for the next closet door to come crashing open. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Demanding the Right Size Government

BYLINE: By Alan Ehrenhalt; Alan Ehrenhalt is the executive editor of Governing magazine and the author, most recently, of "The Lost City."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Something odd is happening to government at the end of the 20th century: It is flying apart and coming together, all at the same time.
On the one hand, the 1990's have been a decade of secession and dreams of secession, just about everywhere in the world. The decade began with the defiance of the old Soviet republics and is ending with a reborn Scottish Parliament in Edinburgh and a vote for independence in East Timor. For a host of reasons -- ethnic, ideological and economic -- whole chunks of countries are struggling to escape the confines of the larger political entities to which they have been confined. 
 No one should confuse Staten Island with East Timor, but it is fair to say that secessionist impulses have been loose in American politics as well. Just about every big city in America has an enclave or a neighborhood that sees the larger government as oppressive and unresponsive, and wants to break away. Most have not carried through, but the impact is always felt. Los Angeles politics has been driven for nearly five years by the guerrillas of the San Fernando Valley, demanding their freedom. The Valley may not get its wish, but it has forced a new charter and new political rules on the entire city.
Wherever you look, big governments are under pressure to break up. But here is the remarkable thing: If you look closely enough, you will see powerful forces at work in the opposite direction as well. Something is fusing governments back together.
You probably have not heard of the Alpine Diamond. I hadn't until a few months ago. It is a fledgling regional government across three national borders, in the little alcove of Europe where France, Italy and Switzerland all come together. It is essentially a re-creation of the medieval kingdom of Savoy, without the monarch. It exists because the two million people who live in this region decided that none of their existing governments -- national, provincial or local -- were capable of managing the region's economic development.
The Alpine Diamond would be easy to dismiss as boutique regionalism, if it weren't so suggestive of events taking place in the United States. Earlier this year, driven to drastic steps by worsening pollution and traffic congestion, Georgia created a powerful new superagency to take control of transportation and land-use decisions in the entire Atlanta metropolitan region. The myriad small communities around Pittsburgh, notoriously quarrelsome and turf-conscious, are gradually knitting themselves together into an umbrella government. In both places, the impulse to action was the same: Public issues are not respecting traditional boundaries. Something larger is needed to handle them.
Public entities almost everywhere in the developed world are in a state of unusual ferment and rearrangement. People have discovered that the governmental units created long ago are too clumsy to serve them very well. This theme is playing itself out right now at all levels of government, from city hall to national capital. It is happening, perhaps more clearly than anywhere, in Congress.
Even a casual observer can tell that Congress did very little in the last couple of years, but this obscures a much larger point: Congress has done relatively little of importance in the last 10 years.
Bluntly put, it has ceased to be the primary political instrument for resolving the difficulties of modern American capitalism. Congress missed its chances to write national rules for regulating health care and to deregulate electricity. Its most important decision of recent years -- the 1996 welfare reform law -- was merely a decision to turn the problem over to the states.
Gradually, without most of us stopping to notice it, Congress is ceasing to be a serious legislative institution. It is becoming a medium of entertainment. Its members continue to make speeches, hold hearings and shout at each other for political profit -- but as current budget wrangle shows, they have difficulty even with the routine business required to keep the government running. To the extent that useful legislative work is being done in America right now, it is being done somewhere further down the chain.
Some of this change can be traced to incompetent leadership; a good deal relates to the partisan division of power between Congress and the WhiteHouse that has been the status quo for most of the previous two decades. But at some point one cannot escape the idea that larger forces are playing themselves out.
A decade ago the sociologist Daniel Bell predicted that in the 21st century most of the important political issues wouldn't be national any more. They would be either global or local. To be dealt with effectively, they would have to migrate up or down, to a level that could handle them. It was a remarkable prophecy, and as the century ends, it is coming true. Problems are migrating up and down all over government, in search of the appropriate place for solution.
In some cases they are reaching the very bottom. One of the least understood and most interesting political phenomena of the 1990's has been the rise of micro-governments -- small institutional entities that have sprung up to deal with practical issues at the level of the neighborhood, the subdivision and even the individual block. This has been happening all over America; it has been happening in western Europe as well.
In Amsterdam, Copenhagen and in many areas of Germany, municipal governments have been ceding authority to small-scale elected traffic control boards, called woonerven, that have expanded their reach into land-use and planning issues. The 2,500 communes of France, tiny vestiges of medieval life that can have fewer than 1,000 residents, have been revitalized by new grants of law enforcement authority that include, in some situations, the power to make arrests.
Micro-government has taken a different form in this country, but it has been equally potent. It includes business improvement districts, like the ones in Manhattan, which begin by cleaning streets and grow into crucial players in local politics; it includes the homeowners' associations that govern life in thousands of new subdivisions for tens of millions of Americans.
Citizens are essentially looking for two forms of public authority: intimate ones in their community that can deal with their needs in a humane way, and regional ones big enough to impose some order and stability on economic life. The governments they have are mostly too remote and bureaucratic for the first job and too small and weak for the second one. Hence the search for substitutes at both ends.
Of course, there are some major obstacles in the way. They are the existing governmental institutions at all levels with a vested interest in their own survival. The city and county of Los Angeles are not going to disappear no matter how much evidence turns up that they are the wrong size for the job. Congress is not going to close down. The reshuffling of government will have be achieved by working around the old institutions, not by replacing them.
But little by little, it will take place. A couple of decades from now, governmental power in much of the world will be exercised quite differently than it is today. Some of it will migrate down -- from nations down to states and from cities and counties to communes, woonerven and homeowners associations. Some of it will migrate up -- to new regional creations like the Alpine Diamond.
There will still be city councils. There will still be a Congress. It will be up to them to find something useful to do with their time.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
What's Wrong With the SAT and Its Elite Progeny

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

THE BIG TEST
The Secret History of the American Meritocracy
By Nicholas Lemann
406 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $27.
Nicholas Lemann's new book, "The Big Test: The Secret History of the American Meritocracy," gets off to a bouncing start with its account of how Henry Chauncey, the ultimate WASP, fell in love with mental testing and dreamed of mounting a vast scientific project that would categorize, sort and route the entire population of the United States. 
 This was at Harvard in the 1930's, when James Bryant Conant was university president. When Mr. Chauncey graduated and became an assistant dean he found the perfect patron for his plan in Conant, who had his own idealistic dream. Conant wanted to replace the old hereditary elite that attended schools like Harvard and ran America with a new one based on intelligence and academic performance. The two men would collaborate by testing for Harvard's national scholarships.
The test they settled on was the Scholastic Aptitude Test. It was administered by the College Entrance Examination Board in Princeton, N.J., where Mr. Chauncey went to work in 1945 to build the Educational Testing Service into what Mr. Lemann calls "the Silicon Valley of its day."
All this is described in "The Big Test" in a lively narrative based on first-time access to the archives of the Educational Testing Service and promising implicitly that the secrets of those tests that loomed so large in our school years will be revealed.
But then something goes awry with Mr. Lemann's book, which succeeds his astute "Promised Land: The Great Black Migration and How It Changed America" and his two earlier books, "Out of the 40's" and "The Fast Track." The prose of "The Big Test" seems to flatten out. The focus shifts to California, and the final chapters become a tediously detailed account of the battle in that state to overturn affirmative action in what eventually became the successful Proposition 209.
What does all this have to do with the SAT? Mr. Lemann's plan appears to have been to show how extremely naive Conant was to believe that his vision would, first, produce an improved university system, and, second, a superior form of elite, or one that, as Conant dreamed of it, was bound to represent the country's virtues and go on to become its civic leaders.
To illustrate the failure of Conant's vision, Mr. Lemann sets out to describe the modern university system and to show how the new elite produced by it was not only nonrepresentative but also tended to seek wealth and power instead of being public-spirited.
The task of making these points concrete leads Mr. Lemann to California, where the many threads of his story come together in a snarl. A hero of Conant's, Clark Kerr, builds the University of California to fill every need, be it social, political, intellectual and economic, and pronounces it a "multiversity." Mario Savio and the Free Speech Movement object to its repressive and exclusive ways, eventually costing President Kerr his job. To compensate for those left out by the SAT, affirmative-action programs are introduced, in reaction to which Proposition 209 is mounted. The final battle over this issue involves beneficiaries of both the SAT's and affirmative action.
This story might have been rich with dramatic irony, but it fails for several reasons. For one thing, Mr. Kerr's development of the University of California is a complex tale that doesn't forcefully illustrate what Mr. Lemann complains of as the growing selectivity of certain colleges. For another thing, the people through whose eyes he narrates his history are not clearly representative enough of the various points he is presumably making. The case of Molly Munger, a high-powered litigator who Mr. Lemann says was conscience-pricked to take up the black cause, is irritatingly beside the point since she devotes herself to good works only after making her fortune.
Finally, the climax of Mr. Lemann's story fails to compel because the issue of affirmative action around which it swirls is confusing in Mr. Lemann's handling.
Although he never does examine the makeup of the SAT (beyond offering a tiny and distorted sampling so difficult that one vocabulary question contains a word, "terile," that I couldn't find even in the O.E.D.), he does demonstrate its unfairness by showing how the difference between white and black performances on it depends not on intelligence but affluence, and by describing how a variation on it was designed at the Education Testing Service to compensate for such differences. (This was rejected, Mr. Lemann reports, because it was perceived by the E.T.S. as too great a threat to the newly established elite.)
But if the SAT's, while being unfair, do accurately predict academic performance, as Mr. Lemann admits, how should colleges accommodate those who perform less well on them and are admitted through affirmative action? By easing standards or by treating such students as special cases? Mr. Lemann doesn't explore such questions. He just assumes that his readers will share his outrage at the present system.
Then, as an afterthought, he describes what ought to take the place of the new "meritocracy," as the English writer Michael Young named it in his book "The Rise of the Meritocracy." Mr. Lemann writes, "We should adopt the goal of sending most people all the way though college, just as, a hundred years ago, we adopted the then much more distant goal of sending most people all the way through high school."
He continues: "To get more people through college, we shall have to establish greater national authority over education. High schools should prepare their students for college by teaching them a nationally agreed-upon curriculum. Tests for admission to college should be on mastery of this curriculum -- not the SAT or some dreamed-of better, fairer alternative test of innate abilities."
He concludes, "Test-prep should consist of mastering the high-school curriculum, not learning tricks to outwit multiple-choice aptitude exams."
Fine. But can we assume that under these ideal circumstances no new meritocracy would then develop, the present one being Mr. Lemann's real objection to the big-test system? Would no one ever again feel excluded or inferior? And, best of all, would no one ever again write books about the system's unfairness? As much as one might wish it to be the case, one kind of doubts it.

HEADLINE: MEDIA;
After a summer of high-profile coverage of Hispanic culture, some wonder if it will last.

BYLINE: By Mireya Navarro 

 BODY:
WHEN editors at New York magazine were planning their recent issue on Latinos, they searched for the magazine's last cover on the city's Hispanic population. They found one, about East Harlem, published in August 1972 under the headline, "The Big Mango: Latin Impact on New York Style."
"Learning that our last cover was more than 20 years ago was a little shocking to us," said John Homans, executive editor of New York magazine, which is owned by Primedia. 
 New York magazine's "The Latin Explosion" issue last month, for which the magazine even changed its logo to "Nueva York," was only one of several national magazine covers this summer that celebrated a Hispanic performer or examined the growing Hispanic influence. Some of the same articles also found their way into newspapers and television broadcasts, but the covers by mainstream magazines were striking because of their number and what many Latinos say was the scant attention devoted to them before by national publications.
There was Time magazine's "Latin Music Goes Pop" last May and Newsweek's "Latin U.S.A." last July. There was Salma Hayek on the cover of George (July), Jennifer Lopez on Elle (July) and Ricky Martin everywhere, including People (June), TV Guide (June), Playgirl (July) and Rolling Stone (August).
"It's nice to see that you've recognized what many of us have known for quite a while," one letter to the editor published in last week's issue of New York magazine said. "Your challenge is to continue this recognition in future issues."
But how much coverage of Latinos -- and what kind of coverage -- can be expected after this Latin summer? The coverage, many editors say, is not likely to fade away. With 31 million Haspanic people nationwide and growing, a critical mass has been building, both culturally and economically, that cannot be ignored, they said. Many point to Ricky Martin's show-stopping performance at the Grammys last February, and the ensuing Rickymania, as a watershed moment in drawing attention to that demographic force.
"We're trying to get out in front of that as the trend becomes clearer and clearer," said Kathleen Deveny, assistant managing editor at Newsweek, which is owned by the Washington Post Company. "It certainly is not our one effort in covering Latinos. Our coverage of race and ethnicity evolves."
Mr. Homans says the perception that there is little money to be made in the Hispanic market by English-language publications is gradually breaking down. The recent coverage, he said, "is driven by the fact that the Latino community is coming into its own economically."
Adam Moss, the editor of The New York Times Magazine, which ran an inside feature about the salsa singer Marc Anthony in August, said the recent burst of media coverage was more about a crossover market in entertainment than about Latinos. "I suspect that the explosion of coverage over the last several months had more to do with the fact that mainstream America now is starting to buy Latino music than it was about the growing Latino population," he said. "It's probable that people will cover more Latino issues related to demographic changes but I don't think that was what principally was driving the coverage. I think it was the mainstreaming of the music."
Some Hispanic people indeed bemoan that less sexy subjects and articles continue to be ignored. Representative Nydia M. Velazquez, a New York Democrat of Puerto Rican background, says she finds the emphasis on pop culture by the media to be "sad."
"I love them," she said of the Hispanic performers, "and we can't reject what in a way helps us get on the radar screens of corporate America. But it shows the ignorance of the mainstream media about the contributions we've made in developing this country."
Groups like the National Association of Hispanic Journalists, have long argued that coverage is directly related to hiring. A survey of 165 top magazines by the trade magazine Mediaweek last year found that members of minorities accounted for 6.1 percent of the professional staff; 1.5 percent of them Hispanic.
One association official said such representation might help explain what she found to be a "gee-whiz, flavor of the month" quality of the recent cover articles. "Unless publications diversify staff they're going to cover Latinos as if they were some peculiar cultural phenomenon because they don't cover us on an ongoing basis as an actual community," said Rose Arce, a CNN producer and association board member. "They just went: 'Wow!, there are Latinos!' "
Janice C. Simpson, a senior editor at Time Warner's Time magazine who oversees arts and entertainment, said, "Right now, what the press is doing is chronicling this coming into its own of the Latino community."
She said articles are dictated by the news, including what she called Mr. Martin's breakthrough performance at the Grammys. But she said there was a need to integrate Hispanic people into overall coverage without focusing so much on ethnicity. "Down the line, I hope that when we're writing about Latino performers and writers, we're writing about them in the context of what they do," she said.
But some journalists remained skeptical. John Leland, the senior editor who co-wrote the articles for Newsweek in July, noted that recent coverage of the Puerto Rican nationalists who were granted clemency by President Clinton focused more on the dispute over Hillary Clinton's opposition to her husband's clemency offer than on the issue of Puerto Rico's independence or what the move meant to Puerto Ricans.
One angle largely left unexplored, Mr. Leland said, was brought up in a Sept. 10 column by Juan Gonzalez of The Daily News of New York. He wrote that "just as the O. J. Simpson criminal trial revealed the chasm between how blacks and whites regard our criminal justice system, the clemency furor has bared the radical differences between Puerto Ricans and the rest of America."
Mr. Leland added: "Are we going to cover a pop star like Ricky Martin and not cover a passionate interest of six-and-a-half million Puerto Ricans? The press had an opportunity there and did not do anything with it."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
The On-Line Brokerage Battle

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
HEARD the pitch about dumping your full-service broker? Remember the ad about the stock-trading teen-ager with his own helicopter? Seen the television spot where the hunky stud muffin rubs the bunions of an older woman who is basking in her on-line investment wealth?
If there is one thing the Internet has brought to every American, it is a blitz of advertising from brokerage firms eager to lure do-it-yourself types on line. But that marketing flurry, it seems, was just the preview. The real advertising battle is just starting. 
 Over the next year, the top 10 on-line brokers have budgeted about $1.5 billion to fill airwaves, newspapers and magazines, billboards, other Web sites and E-mail in-boxes with advertising, all preaching some version of the mantra that you can get rich faster if you take charge of your own investments. To put that in perspective, Ford Motor spent the same amount of money hawking cars and trucks last year. And Walt Disney and Coca-Cola combined do not flog themselves nearly as hard.
The question is will all this marketing money pay off in the form of revenue-generating customers.
On-line companies are already well known for putting promotion before profit. But the latest spending spree ups the ante considerably. Several of the leading on-line brokerages, including Ameritrade, TD Waterhouse and National Discount Brokers, are set to triple their ad spending the next year to compete better with E*Trade, the advertising king of the on-line financial services industry, according to advertising industry experts and the companies themselves.
The on-line brokers are busily signing up celebrity representatives like the actress Geena Davis (TD Waterhouse), the self-parodying blond bombshell Anna Nichol Smith (E*Trade) and the teen-age Russian tennis star Anna Kournikova (Charles Schwab).
They have already reserved air time for the World Series and next winter's Superbowl. And the cost is mounting: E*Trade now spends about half of its revenue on marketing, analysts say, while other brokerages are pouring the bulk of proceeds raised from initial public offerings into splash campaigns. All of this spending raises questions about a business that, so far, has been one of E-commerce's biggest success stories.
Stock trading is still one of the best on-line businesses. People are flocking to it, talking about it and spending on it like never before. But the number of companies looking for a piece of the action -- and the ferocity with which they are fighting for it -- has made the economics look increasingly dismal. Some people within the industry now fear that it is on the verge of a vicious cycle of rising ad spending, sharper competition and slower growth -- even if the stock market remains robust enough that people are tempted to trade stocks as a hobby.
"I don't think anyone expected that we would see the industry spending over a billion dollars on this market," said J. Peter Ricketts, Ameritrade's senior vice president for marketing and sales. "Not everyone can do well. Some will see diminishing returns."
Ameritrade intends to be one of the winners. That is why the company announced earlier this month that, after reducing ad spending earlier this year to move toward profitability, it has now reversed course. The company has planned a yearlong advertising program it values at $200 million, roughly as much as Mazda spends annually to market vehicles and well over half of what Ameritrade is expected to receive in revenue this year.
Ameritrade, the No. 6 on-line broker, is also a bellwether of another trend: the rising cost of attracting each now customer.
For a time, on-line brokerages seemed to have it easy. For not much more than $100 in ad spending, they could attract a self-motivated trader who would buy and sell stocks and pay commissions at a pace that would return a profit to the brokerage firm in about a year. Better yet, traders, unlike book or computer shoppers, tend to be "sticky," to use E-commerce parlance; they remain loyal to an established relationship.
But a combination of rising ad spending, slowing account growth and the proliferation of on-line brokerages -- there are perhaps 50 with national ambitions and solid financial backing, about 130 all together -- has pushed that cost way up. Ameritrade has warned analysts that it is currently spending about $500 for each new customer it signs up. The company hopes that figure will go down later this year, when it expects a rush of new on-line customers.
E*Trade and National Discount Brokers also say they are now prepared to spend $400 to $500 to sign up each new customer, at least double what it was taking earlier this year. The costs include giveaways like the Sprint long-distance minutes, United Airlines frequent-flier miles and $75 in free trades that E*Trade is using as promotional incentives.
"If they go over $500, the stock trading business stops making sense," said Bill Burnham, a venture capitalist at Softbank Partners and an expert on the on-line brokerage industry. But he observed that the brokerages are reluctant to slash ad spending now, fearing they will be left behind. "It's a war of attrition," he said.
The war is much more typical of consumer products companies, like those selling soda, credit cards, or paper towels, than it is for Wall Street. Only a couple of years ago, $20 million was considered a sizable advertising campaign by Wall Street standards.
E*Trade will not say exactly how much it plans to spend on advertising this year. But industry executives say it has committed to spend about $300 million. That would be more than Merrill Lynch, Paine Webber and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter combined, according to estimates of brokerage firm marketing budgets compiled by Bear, Stearns, the investment bank. The comparison is all the more significant given that Merrill Lynch, which plans to offer $29.95 on-line trading later this year, and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, which owns the Discover brokerage, have their own on-line offerings to promote.
E*Trade was also the big spender among the on-line brokerages last year (and the second-biggest marketer among on-line companies over all, after Amazon.com). The campaign was widely considered a raging success. The research firm International Data Corporation found that consumers named E*Trade as the dominant on-line broker, even though its 14 percent market share of Internet trading volume is second to Charles Schwab's 25 percent share, says Paul Johnson, an on-line brokerage analyst at International Data. The advertising also made E*Trade the fastest-growing on-line broker as measured by number of new accounts; E*Trade now has an estimated 1.25 million active accounts.
The firm broke new ground among brokerage firms by advertising its services during prime time -- on "Ally McBeal" and "E.R.," for instance, and buying six slots during last winter's Superbowl, the most expensive television time available. It used to be that Wall Street ads appeared only during Sunday morning talk shows and featured narrators intoning about the solidity of a company in a deep baritone, while a camera panned a rock in the sea. E*Trade, in contrast, introduced ads that aimed to be young and hip, and occasionally hilarious.
Its early ads poked fun at hidebound full-service brokers, including a spot that showed a hapless broker waking at dawn to prepare for another day of fruitless cold calling. Now the emphasis is more on empowering investors than dumping brokers.
One new spot shows an on-line trader watching a preview for a new movie starring Anna Nichole Smith. He declares it the worst movie ever, then dumps stock in "Trimount" the Hollywood company that produced it. The point, says Jerry Gramaglia, E*Trade's marketing chief, is that investors can take charge and act immediately to get financial results.
That ad, along with others that include the rich woman and her young man and another depicting a hermit who gets investment advice from the stuffed moose head and woodchuck in his cabin, have garnered enough attention that E*Trade has every intention of keeping its marketing budget "north of our rivals," Mr. Gramaglia said.
He acknowledged that at $400 to $500 the cost of attracting new customers could become prohibitive for the on-line brokers. But he said E*Trade had also diversified the products its offers to include on-line banking, bonds, mortgages and mutual funds, making the old stock-trading business model an anachronism. He also predicted that those who worry too much about average costs per customer might regret it.
"You can drown in a river that averages three feet," he said. "This is about creating the dominant on-line financial brand."
Most of E*Trade's competitors are trying to catch up to its marketing lead -- what people in the ad industry refer to as "share of voice." Charles Schwab, which has seen its market share slip somewhat in recent months, looks set to challenge E*Trade ad dollar for ad dollar over the next year.
"There are some markets where we double our spending and still lose share of voice to them," Len Short, Schwab's executive vice president for advertising, said. "We are not going to be the leader if we underspend the competition."
Mr. Short, who like Mr. Gramaglia is a veteran of long-distance telephone advertising wars in the early 1990's, estimates that it requires about $300 million a year in spending, sustained for many years, to build and maintain a brand as a household name.
Schwab's latest ads have picked up E*Trade's light-hearted tone. In one ad, Ann Kournikova, the teen-age tennis wonder, lectures fellow players about "asset allocation." Mr. Short said the spots aim for a slightly different crowd than the E*Trade ads. Schwab, seeking to highlight its large call-in centers and bricks and mortar offices, boasts about it ability to educate investors and, if necessary, hold their hands while they learn to trade.
None of the other Internet brokerages seems likely to match the marketing spending of E*Trade and Schwab. But Ameritrade promises to come close with its $200 million campaign. Its television spots feature Stuart, a freakishly red-haired teen-ager with a Mohawk haircut and muttonchops who taunts his girlfriend's stockbroker father with his passion for on-line trading. "Believe in yourself" is the theme.
Not long ago, such promises to lift ad spending might have generated positive buzz for the on-line brokerages among investors. The potential for the companies to capture first-time stock traders was considered so great that deficit spending on ads helped pump share prices into the stratosphere. Most on-line brokerage stocks are in fact still up for the year, but many are down close to 60 percent from their April highs. And Wall Street seems less impressed with the marketing promises now.
Richard H. Repetto, an on-line brokerage analyst at Lehman Brothers, rocked the industry recently when he downgraded his recommendations on both E*Trade and Ameritrade to "outperform" from "buy." He cited the increased ad budgets and higher cost of luring new customers as early warning signs of a battle among brokers for new clients that could end up eating away at the business.
"It's not crazy to go after new customers aggressively, given the long-term potential," Mr. Repetto said. "But you have to consider the increased cost of getting more customers and what you have to do to keep them. There comes a time when there has to be a shakeout."

HEADLINE: I.B.M. Invests In Campaign To Promote Its Software

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
I.B.M. has long had the dubious distinction of running the biggest software business that nobody ever heard of. But the International Business Machines Corporation plans to change that with a major marketing and advertising campaign that is to begin on Wednesday.
The effort is intended not only to raise the profile of the company's $12 billion-a-year software business, but also to highlight the striking changes I.B.M. has made in its software division recently and to accelerate its growth. 
 The company has much at stake. Software is one of three businesses that Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the I.B.M. chairman, has singled out as engines of the corporation's growth in the future, along with services and the sale of technology to other companies.
The software business has been the laggard of the three until recently. Indeed, I.B.M.'s software sales declined from $12.7 billion in 1995 to $11.2 billion in 1997, before rising a modest 6 percent last year to $11.9 billion. The turnaround seems to be picking up some momentum, with software sales up 10 percent through the first half of 1999. The company's software business is the second largest, after that of the Microsoft Corporation, but I.B.M.'s growth pace remains far slower.
Yet the renewed growth at I.B.M., analysts say, is evidence that the overhaul of I.B.M.'s software business is starting to pay off. Traditionally, the company's software business was tied almost entirely to its mainframe and minicomputer sales. But through acquisitions and internal investment, I.B.M. has pursued a strategy of making sure its powerful data base, networking and other software run on major operating systems -- from Microsoft's Windows NT to Linux, a version of the powerful Unix operating systems whose basic programming code is free.
At the same time, I.B.M. has bet its software future on the Internet. The company's software technology, from mainframes on down, has been retooled so that it lets companies work on the World Wide Web to communicate more efficiently with their employees and sell more effectively to their customers.
No longer the computer industry's reactionary, I.B.M. has been early in making big investments in technologies that represent emerging trends in computing -- notably Java, an Internet programming language, and so-called open-source software, like Linux and Apache, whose underlying, or "source," code is freely available.
Analysts say that I.B.M. has more Java programmers than Sun Microsystems Inc., which developed Java, and that I.B.M. probably also employs more open-source programmers than any other company.
"I.B.M. has done an amazing job at focusing on the Internet," said Carl Howe, an analyst at Forrester Research Inc. in Cambridge, Mass. "A few years ago, the company's software business looked as if it was slowly dying. Today, its software business has the potential to be an incredible asset, if played right."
Capturing its share of the software business as it migrates to the Web is crucial to I.B.M. both financially and strategically. While accounting for about 15 percent of revenue, the business contributed nearly a third of the company's profits last year. And I.B.M.'s pitch to corporate clients of being an across-the-board supplier of technology and know-how for the Internet economy will be suspect if I.B.M. is not a leader in software.
"From I.B.M.'s point of view, it is really important that they don't blow this," said Amy Wohl, president of Amy Wohl Associates, a research firm in Narberth, Pa.
The I.B.M. software advertising campaign will begin on Wednesday with four-page ads in newspapers including The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times, The San Jose Mercury News in California and The Austin American-Statesman in Texas. The national print advertising program, budgeted for $22 million in the fourth quarter, will also include ads in trade magazines like PC Week and Infoworld, and Internet sites, including those for Cnet, Zdnet and the Industry Standard. Roughly 10 to 15 percent of the total budget will be spent on Web ads.
The marketing effort is the first time there has been an umbrella advertising campaign for I.B.M.'s software business. Previously, ads have focused on individual products. The $22 million spent in the fourth quarter also marks the start of a big increase in the software unit's ad spending, from $40 million this year to about $100 million next year as the campaign extends internationally, according to Bill Zeitler, general manager for sales and marketing for the I.B.M. software division.
The ads, created by Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, a unit of WPP Group P.L.C., build on I.B.M.'s campaign touting the company's expertise as a supplier of technology for electronic commerce.
That campaign, begun in 1997 and promoting "e-business," was at first criticized by I.B.M.'s rivals as too abstract and not likely to raise sales. But it proved highly successful in positioning I.B.M. as a company at the forefront of electronic commerce, and the term e-business has become common.
One of the software ads, for example, shows a young man sitting amid a bank of escalators, ignored by the crowd, holding a sign. The sign reads: "It takes powerful software to understand the needs of a single customer among millions. That's the software I.B.M. makes."
The campaign's theme, printed in the lower-right corner of all the ads, is: "Software is the soul of e-business."
The ad campaign is meant to back up the new marketing strategy at I.B.M., which groups its products and the efforts of its beefed-up 6,400-person sales force into four categories. The four areas, I.B.M. says, were determined by customer research as key functions of electronic commerce: software for handling transactions; assembling and mining data; improving communications and collaboration in companies, and for managing computer networks.
"It remains to be seen whether it will work," Mr. Howe of Forrester Research noted. "In some ways, it sounds like a return to the approach that was so effective for I.B.M. in the mainframe era, except updated with an e-business spin. I.B.M. is saying, 'Forget about product specifications and the technical trivia, we sell you computing that works.' "

HEADLINE: Financier Is Said to Acquire A Significant Stake in RCN

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Vulcan Ventures Inc., the investment group controlled by Paul Allen, has made its biggest move yet into telecommunications by agreeing to invest about $1.7 billion in the RCN Corporation. The deal is set to be announced today, RCN said yesterday.
RCN, based in Princeton, N.J., is the biggest company competing against the regional Bell carriers in local telephone markets for residential customers rather than corporate clients. RCN also provides cable television and Internet service to its customers, mostly in the Northeast. 
 The stocks of competitive local phone, or exchange, companies (known as CLEC's and pronounced SEE-lecks) have been exceptionally volatile in recent years as investor sentiment has fluctuated about the power of the Bell companies to face competition.
But given Mr. Allen's reputation as a billionaire financier and one of the founders of the Microsoft Corporation, the Vulcan investment may give the CLEC sector a lift.
At least as important, the deal appears to lend some validation to RCN's plan of serving the residential sector rather than the business customers that have been the traditional market of CLEC's.
Additionally, CLEC's of every stripe have traditionally relied heavily on the high-yield bond market for money to build expensive fiber-optic networks. The companies' stocks have sometimes suffered as interest rate concerns have raised questions about their ability to raise money economically. With the Vulcan deal, RCN may be able to insulate itself from those concerns.
"This gives us $4 billion in cash, which is enough capital to build our business without having to go back to the capital market," David C. McCourt, RCN's chairman, said yesterday. He added that with the deal RCN would have enough money to last through 2003 without need of more financing. Before the deal, RCN was faced with the prospect of requiring additional cash in 2001.
"It's validation of our business plan from someone who understands where the telecom industry and the Internet is evolving," he said. "Paul Allen understands the ned for broad-band connections to the home."
Until now, Mr. Allen has invested in broad-band -- or high-capacity -- connections mostly by buying into the cable TV industry. Mr. Allen's cable vehicle, called Charter Communications, has spent more than $6 billion acquiring cable carriers including Avalon Cable Television, Falcon Communications and Fanch Communications.
In August, Vulcan announced a deal to invest in another CLEC, Allegiance Telecom Inc., which focuses on business customers. But that was a much smaller investment, beginning at $75 million and potentially reaching $355 million.
In the RCN deal, Vulcan is to invest $1.65 billion for a stake of roughly 22.7 percent. Vulcan has already bought almost 5 percent of RCN on the open market, an executive close to the deal said, which would bring Vulcan's total interest to about 26.7 percent. But Vulcan's voting interest will be limited to 15 percent.
The new investment is in RCN preferred stock that is convertible into common stock in up to seven years at $62 a share. RCN's shares closed at $38.0625 on Friday, down $2.9375, amid speculation that RCN was considering a diluting acquisition of its own.

HEADLINE: Belarus Sees Its Dissidents Disappearing

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 3

 BODY:
As Viktor Gonchar left for his Thursday night trip to the baths, a ritual in Minsk, the capital of Belarus, he told his wife to watch the evening news. The President had excoriated his critics in a speech, and Mr. Gonchar, a leading political dissident, believed a crackdown was imminent.
That was on Sept. 16. Since 10:45 that evening, neither Mr. Gonchar nor his companion at the baths, Anatoly Krasovsky, a publisher, has been seen. 
 "We were under constant surveillance," Mr. Gonchar's wife, Zinaida, said in an interview. "We have the numbers of the cars. One of them is from the state guard of the President. They couldn't disappear without a trace. That's why I don't doubt that this is the work of the authorities."
The two men were the third and fourth people linked to the opposition to vanish since April. The disappearances coincide with the most concerted campaign yet by Belarus's fragmented pro-democracy movement to press the Government for reforms.
There is little evidence to indicate who might be responsible for the four disappearances. The omnipresent security police, who usually track dissidents the way Minsk homemakers pursue infrequent deliveries of fresh chicken, say they have no clues.
But if the President of Belarus, Aleksandr Lukashenko, is behind the disappearances -- as opponents insist, many Westerners suspect and the Government blandly denies -- it would be a disturbing turn for a tough ruler who has until now merely beaten and jailed his opponents.
The State Department said on Sept. 21 that the United States was greatly concerned by the pattern of disappearances and urged the Government to find and protect those who have vanished.
"The troubling aspect for those of us who have lived here is that we know that this is a fairly tightly controlled society," said an American official in Minsk. "To have no information is in part information by itself. The fact the Government can't say anything at all about these disappearances is a bit strange."
All the more so in the case of the first person to vanish, Tamara Vinnikova, a former chairwoman of the central bank. She was under house arrest and armed Government guard at the time.
The second person to disappear, the former Interior Minister Yuri Zakharenko, was the campaign manager for an opposition politician and former Prime Minister who wants to succeed Mr. Lukashenko.
Mr. Lukashenko, a hard-line Communist, was legally elected President in 1994, but extended his term and replaced the elected Parliament with his own legislators after a constitutional referendum in 1996 that was widely denounced as rigged.
Despite food shortages and staggering inflation, he appeared powerful and even popular until last spring, when dissidents began organizing shadow parliamentary and presidential elections. The aim was to highlight the fact that a new president and Parliament would have taken office this year had the Belarussian Constitution not been replaced.
Since then, the Government has steadily tightened the screws on dissent.
Mr. Gonchar, who organized the shadow elections, was imprisoned in March for 10 days and, his wife said, beaten and force-fed glucose after beginning a hunger strike.
The former Prime Minister, Mikhail Chigir, was arrested and briefly jailed three weeks later, on March 30.
Ms. Vinnikova, the former bank chairwoman, vanished on April 8. She was a supporter of Mr. Chigir who had been accused by the Government of abuse of office and grand larceny. Human rights groups said the charges appeared to have been politically motivated.
Mr. Zakharenko, Mr. Chigir's campaign chairman and a popular figure in the military, dropped out of sight on May 7 as he was walking home.
On July 22, at the height of opposition protests against Mr. Lukashenko's presidency, another opposition leader, the Speaker of the Parliament disbanded by the President, fled to neighboring Lithuania, saying he feared for his safety.
With little hard evidence, the disappearances have become enveloped in rumor and speculation, some inspired by the Government and some by the opposition.
Ms. Vinnikova, who said she knew of shady financial deals at the top of the Government, is said by some in Minsk to have ransomed her way to freedom in Israel. The Government has suggested that investigators look for her in the West.
But neither she nor Mr. Zakharenko has surfaced in more than four months, casting doubt on suggestions that either made it to safety outside Belarus.
The disappearance of Mr. Gonchar and his friend shocked many people in Belarus because there had seemed to be a lull in repression. The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe was arranging talks between the Government and the dissidents. Mr. Gonchar had been planning to meet members of the disbanded Parliament to select the opposition delegation.
His disappearance has thrown those negotiations into limbo.
American officials said Mr. Lukashenko had originally pledged an all-out effort to find Mr. Gonchar. What the Government has produced, however, is a series of attacks on Mr. Gonchar and his publisher friend that suggest the two men were unable to pay off business or political debts and as a result were kidnapped, or worse.
The first President of democratic Belarus, Stanislav Shushkevich, another opposition leader, said in an interview that the Government appeared to have resorted to state terrorism.
"The regime," Mr. Shushkevich said, "has gone along the path of eliminating the leaders against whom it can't open even an artificial criminal case. This is done with the goal of strengthening the dictatorship."
He also said that the West had made the Government's task easier by failing to protest vigorously after the first disappearances in April and May. He noted that the Government opened a criminal inquiry into Mr. Zakharenko's May disappearance only in September, after the United States and Germany had complained about Mr. Gonchar's case.
Zinaida Gonchar said the police appear to be conducting only a cursory search for her husband. The day after he vanished, she said she went with friends to hunt for clues. Near the bathhouse, searchers had found a site where a car appeared to have hit a tree.
There, they found broken headlight glass, trampled grass and stains, which the Government has said are blood.
Mr. Gonchar's Jeep has not been found.
