HEADLINE: Akio Morita, Co-Founder of Sony and Japanese Business Leader, Dies at 78

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
Akio Morita, the co-founder of the Sony Corporation who personified Japan's rise from postwar rubble to industrial riches and became the unofficial ambassador of its business community to the world, died on Sunday in Tokyo. He was 78.
Mr. Morita died of pneumonia, according to Sony. He had been hospitalized in Tokyo since August, after returning from Hawaii, where he had spent most of his time since suffering a debilitating stroke in November 1993. More than anyone else, it was Mr. Morita and his Sony colleagues who changed the world's image of the term "Made in Japan" from one of paper parasols and shoddy imitations to one of high technology and high reliability in miniature packages. 
 Founded in a bombed-out Tokyo department store after World War II, Sony became indisputably one of the world's most innovative companies, famous for products like the pocket-sized transistor radio, the videocassette recorder, the Walkman and the compact disk.
And Mr. Morita, whose contribution was greater in marketing than in technology, made the Sony brand into one of the best known and most respected in the world. A Harris poll last year showed Sony was the No. 1 brand name among American consumers, ahead of American companies like General Electric and Coca-Cola.
A tireless traveler who moved his family to New York in 1963 for a year to learn American ways, Mr. Morita also spearheaded the internationalization of Japanese business. Sony was the first Japanese company to offer its stock in the United States, in 1961, one of the first to build a factory in the United States, in 1972, and still one of the only ones to have even a couple of Westerners on its board.
Sony also became a major force in the American entertainment business, acquiring CBS Records in 1988 and Columbia Pictures, the Hollywood studio, in 1989. The latter purchase, however, turned into an embarrassing debacle as Sony suffered big losses in Hollywood.
 
A Japanese Executive Americans Recognized
In the process, Mr. Morita, with his white mane and quick tongue, became the unofficial representative of Japan's business community, generally working to smooth trade relations between his country and the United States, but sometimes stirring resentment in both countries with his pointed criticisms.
"He was truly a statesman par excellence in a business sense," said Mike Mansfield, the former senator and United States Ambassador to Japan. "Internationally, he did more for Japan in a business sense than anyone else in Japan."
In Japan, Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi, who was one of several hundred people to visit Mr. Morita's Tokyo home following his death, called Mr. Morita "a leading figure who played a pivotal role in developing Japan's postwar economy," according to Kyodo News Service.
Sony's current president, Nobuyuki Idei, said in a statement, "It is not an exaggeration to say that he was the face of Japan."
To the day of his death, nearly six years after the stroke that removed him from an active role in business, he was still no doubt Japan's most famous business executive, and the only one many Americans could name or recognize in a photograph. Time magazine recently selected him as one of 20 "most influential business geniuses" of the 20th century, the only non-American on the list.
In his own country, where executives tend to be self-effacing, Mr. Morita was viewed as a bit flamboyant and arrogant. He was the first to fly around in a corporate business jet and helicopter. He appeared in a television commercial for the American Express card. He served on the boards of three foreign companies. He took up sports like skiing, scuba diving and wind surfing in his sixties. He cavorted with the rock star Cyndi Lauper after Sony bought CBS Records.
Shortly before he suffered his stroke, Mr. Morita made waves in his home country by saying that Japan was like a "fortress" and that its unique business practices were alienating its trading partners. "Although there is much to commend in Japan's economic system, it is simply too far out of sync with the West on certain essential points," he wrote in The Atlantic Monthly in June 1993.
He advocated shorter working hours, more dividends for stockholders of Japanese companies and a sharp cutback in government regulation. Now, as Japan struggles through an economic slump that has lasted most of the decade, some of what Mr. Morita advocated is being adopted.
"Japan was coming closer to him and seeing the need for that kind of leadership," said Yoshihiro Tsurumi, professor of international business at the Baruch Graduate School of Business at the City University of New York.
 
Never Comfortable In West's Business World
 Mr. Morita entertained frequently and counted many American businessmen and politicians as his friends. "He not only made it Sony's business but his own personal business to become intimately acquainted with American society at all levels," said Peter Peterson, an investment banker who is on Sony's board of directors. "I can recall playing golf with Akio, watching him greet and interact with every American C.E.O. on the course, all of whom seemed to know him as a personal friend."
In his book "Sony: The Private Life" (Houghton Mifflin, 1999), John Nathan suggests that Mr. Morita, a Japanese traditionalist at home, was never really comfortable in the Western business world.
Mr. Nathan, a Japanese translator and University of California professor of Japanese culture who was granted free access to Sony executives, quotes Mr. Morita's eldest son, Hideo, as saying of his father, "He had to 'act' -- I'm sorry to use that word but I can't help it -- he had to act as the most international-understanding businessman in Japan." But, Hideo adds, "It was never real."
And Sony's current president, Mr. Idei, is quoted as saying: "Japanese of the generation before mine had an inferiority complex about foreigners. Akio Morita himself was a living inferiority complex."
Despite being virtually synonymous with Sony, especially outside Japan, Mr. Morita did not actually become the company's president until 1971 and its chairman and chief executive until 1976. Before that, he was the junior partner to Masaru Ibuka, an engineering genius who, while not as widely known in the West, is considered in Japan to be the main founder of Sony. Mr. Ibuka died in December 1997 at the age of 89.
 
An Early Fascination Leads to a Career Shift
 Akio Morita was born on Jan. 26, 1921, into a wealthy family in Nagoya, an industrial city in central Japan. As the eldest son, he was groomed from elementary school age to succeed his father as president of the sake brewery that had been in the family for 14 generations.
But in junior high school, Akio became fascinated by his family's phonograph, an appliance rare in Japan at that time. He became an avid electronics hobbyist, building his own crude phonograph and radio receiver. He studied physics at Osaka Imperial University as World War II was starting. Mr. Morita enlisted in the Navy under a program that would allow him to do research instead of serving in combat.
It was while developing heat-seeking weapons that Mr. Morita first worked with Mr. Ibuka, 13 years his senior, who before the war had started an electronic instrument company.
After the war, Mr. Ibuka set up a new company in a bombed-out department store in Tokyo, making kits that converted AM radios into short-wave receivers. Mr. Morita happened to read a newspaper article about this and contacted his old friend. The next year, when Mr. Ibuka wanted to incorporate the company, he asked Mr. Morita to join.
Mr. Morita, Mr. Ibuka and another executive traveled to the Nagoya area to implore Mr. Morita's father to release his son from the family business. The elder Mr. Morita not only agreed, he also later became a financial backer of the new company, Tokyo Tsushin Kogyo, or the Tokyo Telecommunications Engineering Corporation, which was inaugurated on May 7, 1946, with an investment of about $500.
The company produced Japan's first reel-to-reel magnetic tape recorder. A few years later it licensed the rights to the transistor from Bell Laboratories, after overcoming resistance from the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. Bell Labs officials warned that the only consumer use would be for hearing aids.
But Sony used them to produce Japan's first transistor radio in 1955. (An American company, Regency, produced the world's first a few months earlier but did not succeed in selling it.) In 1957, Sony came out with what it termed a pocket-sized transistor radio. But the radio was actually a bit too big for most pockets, so Mr. Morita had Sony salesmen wear special shirts with extra-large pockets.
There followed the Trinitron television in 1968; the first successful home VCR, the Betamax, in 1975; the Walkman personal stereo in 1979, and the compact disk, developed with Philips N.V. of the Netherlands, in 1982.
Not all products were successful. Sony has stumbled several times trying to sell personal computers. And in 1981, Mr. Morita announced the Mavica, a digital camera that recorded pictures on a floppy disk instead of on film. But the camera did not come to market and critics accused Mr. Morita of making a premature announcement to burnish Sony's image as an innovator.
 
Steering Consumers To Products They Want
 Mr. Morita did not believe in market research. "Our plan is to lead the public with new products rather than ask them what kind of products they want," he declared in his autobiography, "Made in Japan," (E. P. Dutton, 1986), written with the journalists Edwin M. Reingold and Mitsuko Shimomura. "The public does not know what is possible, but we do."
Mr. Morita prided himself in particular on the Walkman, the portable stereo cassette player with headphones. Actually, according to the company's official corporate history, it was Mr. Ibuka who came up with the idea for the portable product. But Mr. Morita pressed hard for the project, overcoming resistance within Sony to a tape player that, in its early versions, could not record. Mr. Morita, despite initial reservations about the awkward name, eventually ordered all Sony subsidiaries around the world to begin using it.
From the start of the company, however, Mr. Morita was much more involved in marketing, while Mr. Ibuka handled technology development. And from the start, he had an international orientation, traveling to New York and Europe in the 1950's to sell the company wares.
Such international focus was needed because as a new company, Sony had some trouble breaking into its home market, where more established manufacturers had close relationships with retailers. Indeed, Japan's other big postwar success, the Honda Motor Company, also succeeded first in the United States and to this day sells more cars in America than in Japan.
Mr. Morita soon realized that the company needed a name that foreigners could pronounce and remember. So in 1958 the company name was changed to Sony, derived from the Latin sonus, meaning sound, and from the American vernacular "sonny boy," which Mr. Morita hoped would purvey a young image.
One of Mr. Morita's cardinal tenets was to foster and protect the company's brand name. Early on, Bulova, the watch company, said it would order 100,000 radios but would sell them under its own name. Mr. Morita turned down the huge order. His colleagues back in Tokyo thought he was crazy. But, Mr. Morita wrote in his autobiography, "I said then and I have said it often since: It was the best decision I ever made."
Mr. Morita's worst decision might have been with the Betamax, the first successful consumer VCR. Sony did not readily license its technology to other electronics companies. So most of its Japanese rivals banded together behind the VHS system, which offered longer recording time. Eventually, the Betamax was run out of the market.
Sony evolved into a company that, by Japanese standards at least, was very Westernized, though in many ways it was traditionally Japanese. All company employees, from the president on down, wore company jackets, a common practice in Japan. But Sony's uniforms were created by the designer Issey Miyake.
Mr. Morita first criticized some of his country's business practices in 1966, when he wrote a book, published in Japanese, with a title that might loosely translate as "An Essay on the Useless School Career." He criticized Japanese companies for hiring and promoting people based only on what college they had attended. Sony stopped even asking applicants the name of their college, and it was one of the first Japanese companies to base salaries partly on merit instead of solely on seniority.
 
Tried to Reduce U.S. Trade Tensions
Perhaps because of Sony's dependence on exports, Mr. Morita tried to reduce trade tensions with the United States. In the late 1960's, Sony forged a temporary joint venture with Texas Instruments Inc., then the world's leading semiconductor company, allowing it to set up operations in Japan.
In 1972, Mr. Morita set up a subsidiary to export American products, like Regal cookware and Whirlpool refrigerators, to Japan.
"Selling pans and cookware and refrigerators was not our bag, but Akio believed in doing something for the U.S.-Japan relationship," said Sadami (Chris) Wada, who ran that effort and then handled government relations for the Sony Corporation of America for many years. The operation was abandoned some years later as unsuccessful.
In 1988, Mr. Morita founded the Council for Better Corporate Citizenship, made up of Japanese companies. At a time when Japanese politicians were angering African-Americans with insensitive remarks, one of the council's first projects was to make thousands of copies of an abridged version of "Eyes on the Prize," the American television documentary about the struggle of blacks for equal rights, and distribute it to high schools in Japan.
Mr. Morita was not averse to using his influence among American politicians and business executives to lobby for Sony. He barnstormed the United States in 1984, meeting with governors and with President Reagan, threatening to build Sony factories only in states that did not have the "unitary tax," which was levied against a multinational corporation's global earnings, not just those in the state. Eventually California and other states scrapped the tax.
But while Mr. Morita was often perceived as a friend of the United States, he was often critical of it and proud of being Japanese, flying his country's flag over Sony's New York showroom when it opened in 1962. He often told a story of how ashamed he was on his first trip to Germany in 1953. At a restaurant, he ordered ice cream, and it was served with a small paper parasol stuck in it. "This is from your country," the waiter said.
 
Hailing the Success Of the Japanese Way
 In the 1980's, when Japan seemed on top of the world, Mr. Morita was among the most vocal of the Japanese executives in criticizing American business and hailing the success of the Japanese model.
He said American managers were financial paper shufflers who "can see only 10 minutes ahead" and were not interested in building for the long term. And he said that because American companies were losing interest in manufacturing, the United States was "abandoning its status as an industrial power." Those factors, he said, and not trade barriers, were the reason for America's trade deficit with Japan.
"There are few things in the United States that Japanese want to buy, but there are a lot of things in Japan that Americans want to buy," he wrote in 1989. "This is at the root of the trade imbalance. The problem arises in that American politicians fail to understand this simple fact."
In 1989, Mr. Morita was the co-author, along with a nationalist politician, Shintaro Ishihara, of "The Japan That Can Say No," a book that urged Japan to stand up to American trade demands, which it said were motivated partly by racism. The book also said Japan had the power to change the world balance of power by selling its advanced computer chips to the Soviet Union instead of the United States.
Even though those strident remarks were generally in the chapters Mr. Ishihara wrote, the book created a stir when an unauthorized translation made its way around Washington. Mr. Morita frantically back-pedaled, saying the book had not been intended for an American audience. And he refused to authorize an English translation.
 
$3.2 Billion Lost In Hollywood Venture
It was later that year that Sony paid $3.4 billion to buy Columbia Pictures, a purchase driven largely by Mr. Morita, who thought that if Sony had owned a studio issuing movies in the Beta format, it would not have lost the VCR wars.
Although Sony prided itself on being more Americanized than its Japanese rivals, the purchase became a lightning rod for American concern about a wave of Japanese acquisitions of American companies and real estate. "Japan Invades Hollywood" read the cover of Newsweek. In Japan as well, Sony came in for criticism for stirring up anti-Japanese feeling in the United States.
Mr. Morita had a simple answer. "If you don't want Japan to buy it, don't sell it," he told a New York Times reporter shortly after the purchase. Nevertheless, sensitive to concerns, he promised that the studio would be run by Americans and would be free even to make a movie critical of Japan's emperor.
Worse than misjudging the political reaction, however, the seemingly sophisticated Sony proved to be a babe in the woods in Hollywood.
Sony is generally considered to have overpaid for the studio, and it paid several hundred million dollars more to hire managers away from Warner Brothers -- provoking a costly fight with that studio. Those managers, in turn, spent money extravagantly and produced a string of box office bombs. Mr. Morita and his successor as Sony chief executive, Norio Ohga, perhaps because they were worried about stirring up anti-Japanese sentiment, exercised little oversight.
In late 1994, in one of the most embarrassing moments in its history, Sony announced that it would suffer a loss of $3.2 billion from its investment in Hollywood. But it has stuck with the studio, now called Sony Pictures Entertainment, and appears to be turning it around.
The Morita name will live on at Sony because many members of Mr. Morita's family are involved in the company.
Besides his wife, Mr. Morita is survived by his wife, Yoshiko; his eldest son, Hideo, who now runs the sake brewery and other family businesses; a younger son, Masao, an executive with Sony Music Entertainment in Japan; and a daughter, Naoko Okada, who also lives in Japan. He is also survived by his brother Kazuaki, who volunteered to take over the family sake brewery in Mr. Morita's stead; another brother, Masaaki, a long-time Sony executive, and a sister, Kikuko Iwama, who was married to the late Kazuo Iwama, a former president of Sony.
 
A Longtime Outsider Is Embraced at Last
 In the 1990's, corporate Japan, worried about escalating trade tensions, turned to Mr. Morita, whom it once considered an arrogant maverick, to be its official leader. Mr. Morita was slated to become chairman of Keidanren, Japan's most powerful business lobbying organization, a post that had always gone to the head of a company in an old-line heavy industry like steel.
But on Nov. 30, 1993, while playing his usual 7 A.M. Tuesday tennis game, Mr. Morita suffered a cerebral hemorrhage. A year later, just days after Sony announced its huge Hollywood loss, Mr. Morita, in a wheelchair, attended a Sony board meeting in Tokyo and resigned as chairman.
He had spent much of his time since then undergoing rehabilitation at his beachfront home near Diamond Head on the Hawaiian island of Oahu. At first, Mr. Morita was able to speak a little, shake hands and hit back tennis balls spit out by a machine, according to Mr. Wada, the retired Sony government relations manager.
But more recently, Mr. Wada said, Mr. Morita had lost the ability to speak and communicated mainly through eye contact with his wife. The couple's Christmas greeting card last year had a message from Mrs. Morita saying her husband rose at 6 A.M., retired at 9 P.M. and spent much of the day in rehabilitation. "He may be overeating," she said, mentioning his fondness for eel.
Until he was taken to the hospital in Tokyo in August, Mr. Morita had not returned to Japan for more than two years because of concerns that flying would further damage his health. He did not attend the 1997 funeral of Mr. Ibuka.
But Sony officials still visited him in Hawaii to keep him up to date on the business and show him new products. In January 1998, some 200 executives, friends and dignitaries came to Hawaii to attend a party for Mr. Morita's 77th birthday, considered a lucky age in Japan.

(All photographs courtesy of Sony)
 
Chart: "Sony and Japan, Growing Up Together"
When Akio Morita and Masaru Ibuka co-founded the company that became Sony, it was considered an upstart. As it grew, though, it became one of the most recognized companies in the world, symbolizing postwar Japan's success. More than any other person, Mr. Morita, often referred to as Mr. Sony, was credited with the company's rise. Here is the company's history under his stewardship.
 
MAY 7, 1946 Akio Morita and Masaru Ibuka, two young engineers, incorporate Tokyo Tsushin Kogyo Kabushiki Kaisha (Tokyo Telecommunications Engineering Corporation), also called Totsuko. The company has 20 employees.
 
Early products include electrically heated seat cushions, electronic megaphones and audio control consoles.
 
1950 After hearing an American tape recorder, Morita and Ibuka decide to build their own. The result is the G-type recorder, left, for institutional use. (The G stood for government.) A consumer model, the H-type, becomes the company's first big consumer product.
 
1951 Totsuko has sales of $430,500 ($2.7 million in 1999 dollars) and 159 employees.
 
1952 The American occupation of Japan ends.
 
1953 On his first trip to the United States, Morita obtains the rights to make transistors.
 
1954 Totsuko creates the first Japanese transistors and begins selling them for $11.11 each. Though they have no use for them, Japanese consumers buy them as fast as Totsuko can make them.
 
1955 Totsuko begins selling the first Japanese transistor radio, right, under the brand name Sony. Years later, Morita recalled how the name was selected: Mr. Ibuka and I worked together, checking many dictionaries, and we found two terms, sonus, a Latin word meaning sound, and sonny boy. So, we thought: We are a group of sonny boys in the sonus business. So we combined sonus and sonny and came up with Sony.
 
Japan's gross national product is $262 per person ($1,608 in 1999 dollars); 39 million people work in the private sector.
 
1956 Totsuko has 483 employees, all shown above, and sales of $3.35 million ($20.26 million in 1999 dollars).
 
Japan is admitted to the United Nations.
 
1957 Totsuko develops a pocket-sized transistor radio, the TR-63, but it is a bit larger than a pocket on a business shirt. So Morita has shirts custom-made for his sales people with pockets big enough to hold the radios.
 
January 1958 Totsuko renames itself Sony and is listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
 
1959 Sony builds the first transistor television set, the TV8-301, right. The sets are expensive and unreliable and they do not sell well.
 
1960 Sony founds the Sony Corporation of America, and soon Morita moves to America to oversee the expansion.
 
PUB-DATE: June 15, 1961
 
Sony's sales are $51.6 million ($283.6 million in 1999 dollars); it has 3,703 employees. Japan's gross national product is $570 per person ($3,136 in 1999 dollars); 43 million people work in the private sector.
 
1964 Sony begins selling a video tape recorder for home use, the CV-2000. It costs $550 ($2,919 in 1999 dollars).
 
1965 Japan has a trade surplus of $330 million with the United States, its first.
 
1966 Sony's sales are $130.4 million ($662 million in 1999 dollars); it has 6,061 employees. Japan's gross national product is $1,070 per person ($5,433 in 1999 dollars); 47 million people work in the private sector.
 
1968 Sony introduces the Trinitron color television, right. Sony and CBS found Sony/CBS Records.
 
SEPT. 17, 1970 Sony becomes the first Japanese company to sell American depository receipts on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
1971 Sony's sales are $544.7 million ($2.21 billion in 1999 dollars); it has 10,003 employees. Japan's gross national product is $2,195 per person ($8,915 in 1999 dollars); 51 million people work in the private sector. Its trade surplus with the United States is $3.2 billion.
 
1972 Sony begins manufacturing television sets in San Diego.
 
1975 Betamax video recorders go on sale at $789 ($2,412 in 1999 dollars). A year later, Universal Pictures sues Sony, charging that the Betamax infringes on Universal's copyright. In 1984, the Supreme Court rules in Sony's favor.
 
1979 Sony introduces the Walkman, right, a portable stereo cassette player. By 1986, Walkman was added to the Oxford English Dictionary.
 
1981 Sony's sales are $5.04 billion ($9.12 billion in 1999 dollars); it has 12,496 employees. Japan's gross national product is $9,925 per person ($17,961 in 1999 dollars); 54 million people work in the private sector. Its trade surplus with the United States is $15.8 billion.
 
SPRING 1982 Sony begins selling 3.5-inch computer storage disks, which are soon accepted as the international standard.
 
OCT. 1, 1982 The first CD player, developed jointly by Sony, CBS/Sony, Philips and Polygram, goes on sale. It costs $625 ($1,050 in 1999 dollars).
 
JANUARY 1985 Sony begins selling its first 8-millimeter camcorder.
 
1986 Morita is named vice chairman of Keidanren, Japan's most influential business organization; he takes a leading role in talks on opening Japanese markets to American products.
 
Sony's sales are $8.33 billion ($12.50 billion in 1999 dollars); it has 15,538 employees. Japan's gross national product is $16,552 per person ($24,843 in 1999 dollars); 56 million people work in the private sector. Its trade surplus with the United States is $55.0 billion.
 
JANUARY 1988 Sony buys CBS's records division for $2 billion in cash.
 
NOVEMBER 1989 Sony buys Columbia Pictures Entertainment for $3.4 billion.
 
1991 Sony's sales are $27.96 billion ($33.77 billion in 1999 dollars); it has 19,811 employees. Japan's gross national product is $27,748 per person ($33,514 in 1999 dollars); 60 million people work in the private sector. Its trade surplus with the United States is $43.4 billion.
 
NOV. 30, 1993 While playing tennis, Morita has a cerebral hemorrhage.
 
1994 Sony releases Playstation, the first 32-bit home video game player. On Nov. 25, Morita steps down as chairman.

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
A Congressman's Lament on the State of Democracy

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AFTER 30 years in Congress, David Obey is in the slough of despond.
"The democratic system in this country is in crisis as never before in my lifetime," he mourns. "It's the ultimate destruction of the legislative process." 
 This is the jeremiad of a man in the minority. Politicians and pundits asking "Where's the outrage?" are not listening to Mr. Obey, the reigning Cassandra of Congress and the ranking Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee.
Mr. Obey headed that committee, which presides over Congressional spending, in 1994 and 1995. But the fall of the Democrats four years ago left him wandering in the wilderness, able to prevent things from happening from time to time but unable to accomplish much.
Now he sees Congress tying itself in angry knots, trying and failing to pass a budget he describes as a political document designed to cheat the little guy and trick him into thinking all is well.
"What enrages me is that this is the only forum we have to try to solve problems the country has that are so big they can't be solved any other place," said Mr. Obey (pronounced OH-bee), who has grown a gnomish beard and sharpened his tongue in exile. "Congress should try to do a few things that are very important. But this place has done nothing this year but engage in a shell game on the budget."
The game maddens Mr. Obey, the only chairman alive to have completed all 13 spending bills on time, by Sept. 30, the end of the fiscal year. He did it in 1995.
He argues that Republican militants have hijacked the spending bills and turned them into "partisan war zones." The result, he says, is that the bills cannot pass. He may be right: today 8 of the 13 bills are incomplete, the Government is running on a three-week stop-gap resolution, and many late nights of angry debate await him and the rest of the Congress.
He may relish the arguments, but not the atmosphere in which Congress is making them.
"They pass meaningless resolutions that praise God, motherhood and country but don't do anything," he said. "They stick it to little people, because little people don't have access to information and can't fight back. They rely on a huge tub of money that flows into their party coffers to drown out objections. They have a huge juggernaut of private foundation money organized by the right-wing economic elite and they pour money into these so-called think tanks to pretend that independent research verifies their world view."
MR. OBEY is not a cartoon liberal. He opposes abortion and gun control, and his politics come from the populist roots of his neck of the woods in northern Wisconsin, where Mr. Obey was raised, the son of a factory worker. But having spent half his life in Congress since being elected in 1969, he longs for the days when the old bulls of the Democratic Party ruled and did business with the old bulls among the Republicans.
"This place used to be able to argue over real differences in an understandable way," he said. "Things got done because you had a collective determination that things needed to be done. We got through World War II and the years after because we had a national consensus about what our national interests were abroad and what things we needed to do at home to make the economy work and how to make this a more fair society."
But now, he says, that consensus has unraveled.
Appropriations is all about minding details and making deals involving billions of dollars; every member of Congress hungers for a slice of the pie to feed the folks back home. Mr. Obey succeeded in part because he had the ability to say no, even to his allies.
This year, as each of the 13 spending bills has slowly wended its way through the subcommittees, Mr. Obey has been saying no for days on end, sitting like a vulture on a limb, waiting to pounce on measures he considers cruel, absurd or both. A typical moment came on Thursday, as the House Appropriations Committee approved a spending bill for the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services and Education -- and along with it, a Republican plan to delay a Federal tax break for working-class families.
"This is as bad a bill as this committee has ever produced," Mr. Obey said. "It should be defeated and placed in a file cabinet and hidden deep in the bowels of the Capitol, and we should collectively agree to deny that this committee ever considered such legislation."
Mr. Obey was defeated, as he often is these days, on a straight party-line vote.
Married and the father of two sons, Mr. Obey takes solace in political isolation from playing harmonica in an unusual bluegrass band, known as Dave Obey and the Capitol Offenses. The band features his family and friends, including his sons, Craig and Douglas, on guitars, and John Holum, the Under Secretary of State for arms control, on banjo.
Their new album, just released, includes an Irish patriot's song, "The Town I Loved So Well," whose last stanza might as well be about the lost Washington Mr. Obey laments:
Now what's done is done and what's won is won
And what's lost is lost and gone forever
I can only pray for a bright brand new day
For the town I loved so well

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Clever Beasts And Burdens On Their City

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
FROM a public relations standpoint, animals have been problematic for New York. Besides the burgeoning populations of rats and cockroaches, there is our famous four-legged neurotic, Gus, the polar bear in the Central Park Zoo who required the services of a therapist from California.
There's also Dan, the veteran alpha male gorilla at the Bronx Zoo so inept at breeding -- he's never been observed even trying -- that he's about to be replaced by a more sophisticated silverback from Salt Lake City. Even our squirrels turned into a media liability a few years ago when a London newspaper falsely reported that they'd become addicted to crack by licking vials in Central Park. 
 Now we must contend with "The Parrot's Lament" (Dutton), the latest book from Eugene Linden analyzing the intelligence and creativity of animals -- chiefly other cities' animals. Mr. Linden, who lives in Nyack, N.Y., had to go far from home to find the most enterprising creatures.
His book describes a California parrot with a mordant sense of humor and a leopard in India that crosses a river by canoe. An orangutan in Cleveland is an astonishing escape artist, which may or may not say something about living in Cleveland. A chimp at the National Zoo has mastered bribery, which definitely says something about living in Washington.
The apes in Atlanta and London have burnished their cities' reputations as financial centers by using keys and tokens to become shrewd traders, bankers and even counterfeiters. The home of Microsoft, not surprisingly, is a hub of creativity and deception.
"Seattle's orangutans and gorillas," Mr. Linden said, "have developed a series of remarkably complex algorithms for extracting extra food from keepers and hiding it from their rivals. They've even mastered the basics of real-estate subdivision."
New York animals have more limited and old-fashioned skills, as Mr. Linden demonstrated Thursday afternoon on a visit to the Bronx Zoo. He started off with two elephants, Maxine and Patty, whose keepers try to lure them inside at the end of the day by putting food in their night cages.
Instead of both elephants going inside to nibble, they've learned to take turns, with one remaining outside to prevent the keepers from locking the door. They get extra time outside and extra food by maintaining the sort of solidarity for which New York unions are famous.
"You could think of the elephants as abiding by strict union work rules," Mr. Linden explained. "New York animals may not be as creative as others, but they know how to profit by placing themselves between you and your goal. The more they get involved with a job, the slower it goes and the more it costs."
THE master of the work slowdown in Mr. Linden's book is a gorilla at the Bronx Zoo named Huerfanita. At the old ape house she extorted bribes -- bananas -- at day's end by blocking the doorway of the night cage. She learned to move quickly into place whenever a keeper said, "Shut the door," and she even foiled the keepers when they switched to codes like, "The fat lady sings."
But Huerfanita has abandoned extortion and gone straight. She seems happier in the roomy accommodations at the $43 million Congo Gorilla Forest, which opened in June, and she has thrived since the keepers gave her custody of an infant rescued from a neglectful mother named Paki.
"Paki's kind of a goofy gorilla," Denise Heinzinger, the senior keeper, said on Thursday, pointing to a skinny, wild-eyed female wandering around. Paki looked to be the gorilla most likely to be accused by a London newspaper of being a crackhead.
Huerfanita, calmly carrying the adopted infant on her back, appeared to be thoroughly rehabilitated. Or maybe she was never that bad to begin with. Maybe it was society's fault.
"She was misunderstood," Mrs. Heinzinger said. "She resisted going inside the old place because she didn't want to be in that small space with a group that didn't accept her. Now there's more room in the new quarters, and she feels more comfortable with the group because the little boy has raised her status."
What did this transformation say about New York? Will it improve our image?
"Well," Mr. Linden replied, "only in New York could socially conscious humans rescue someone from a life of crime thanks to a hands-on foster care program and a $43 million public housing project. I guess that's a good thing. But it may not be an economic model for other cities."

HEADLINE: Gore Will Keep Campaign Chairman Despite Report of Mismanagement at World Exposition

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore said today that his campaign chairman would stay on despite a Government report criticizing him for questionable expenses and payments during his tenure as head of the United States pavilion at last year's World Exposition in Portugal.
"He is staying," Mr. Gore said of his chairman, Tony Coelho, a former California Congressman. 
 The report, by the United States Information Agency's inspector general, said Mr. Coelho and officials of the information agency mismanaged the American participation at the fair. He was the unpaid commissioner general of the project.
Mr. Gore, speaking on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," did not respond directly when asked whether Mr. Coelho had done anything wrong or whether he had full confidence in him. "I haven't seen this report," Mr. Gore replied, "but I know him, and he is going to continue doing the terrific job he's been doing as my campaign chair." The Vice President dismissed the matter as "inside baseball" and said voters were not interested in it.
Stan Brand, a lawyer representing Mr. Coelho, said today that the inspector general's report had not recommended any action against Mr. Coelho but had focused instead on changing the way the United States participates in expositions like the one in Portugal. Among other things, the report criticized the agency's hiring of Mr. Coelho's niece, questionable payments to consultants and other financial and personnel practices.
"It contained no recommendations about referrals, prosecution, charging or scoring any individual for doing anything wrong," said Mr. Brand, who said Mr. Coelho himself would not discuss the report at this time. "Generally, there was no recommendation for action, and I think that is significant."
Mr. Brand disputed the inspector general's assertion that the Government might be held liable for repaying a $300,000 loan Mr. Coelho received from a Portuguese bank, which was used to help pay for a memorial wall built at the fair. He said the loan has been "mostly paid off" and would be completely paid back either with Mr. Coelho's own money or with contributions to a nonprofit foundation that was established to finance the memorial.
In addition to his defense of Mr. Coelho, Mr. Gore made a strong appeal today to the core voters of the Democratic Party. He attacked his sole challenger for the Democratic Presidential nomination, former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, as a disloyal Democrat. The Vice President also explained his support for President Clinton during the impeachment process as a necessary step to halt the Republicans from what Mr. Gore called the inappropriate punishment of ousting him from office. "We were in the midst of political combat," he said.
The questions about Mr. Coelho come at a bad time for Mr. Gore. The Vice President, who acknowledged last week that he needed to reinvigorate his campaign to fend off a growing challenge from Mr. Bradley, is in the midst of an overhaul.
He is moving his headquarters from Washington to Nashville and is relying on Mr. Coelho, who is in charge of the move, more than ever. Mr. Coelho is one of only two of his closest advisers -- the other is Carter Eskew, Mr. Gore's media consultant -- who are definitely moving to Nashville, creating a certain upheaval and flux as Mr. Gore changes pollsters and loses other advisers and support staff.
At the same time, Mr. Eskew has been criticized for working for tobacco companies in their effort to undercut support for a planned Federal lawsuit against the tobacco industry. Mr. Gore has supported antismoking drives. After The New York Times made inquiries into Mr. Eskew's ties to the tobacco companies, Mr. Eskew said he would sever them. Mr. Gore dismissed this matter too, saying voters did not care what clients his advisers had served in the past.
Mr. Gore's appearance today on "Face the Nation" was in itself a sign of a change in his campaign. Although he has been interviewed on several other television programs, he had not appeared on the Sunday morning talk circuit in more than two years.
The Vice President took the opportunity to paint Mr. Bradley as disloyal to the Democratic Party, citing what he said were two defining moments: Mr. Bradley's support for former President Ronald Reagan's trickle-down economic program and his leaving the Senate, in effect abandoning the party, when Representative Newt Gingrich, a Republican, became the Speaker in 1995.
"Bill Bradley voted for Reaganomics, he voted for all those budget cuts; I did not," Mr. Gore said. Of Mr. Gingrich's takeover of the House, Mr. Gore said: "At that moment, I tried to help rally the troops, the forces of what I regard as progress, and Senator Bradley chose that moment to say that he was going to leave the public arena, that it was broken and that he might even run as the independent, which would have elected Bob Dole and would have given the Republicans control of both the Congress and the executive branch."
Eric Hauser, a spokesman for Mr. Bradley, said the Vice President's appearance today showed the difference between the two campaigns. He said Mr. Gore was focusing on narrow tactical moves and negative campaigning, while Mr. Bradley had offered a comprehensive health care program with a price tag last week and would announce another program this week on work and families.
Mr. Hauser said that Mr. Bradley had supported the Reagan budget cuts but also opposed the Reagan tax cuts and that had that combination passed, the nation would have been spared the ensuing budget deficits.
On the topic of President Clinton, Mr. Gore offered a new explanation for his defense of the President on the day last December that the House voted to impeach him. "The Republican Senate was about to try to remove him from office for an offense which, while terrible, was in the judgment of the American people not one that justified removal from office," Mr. Gore said.
"We were in the midst of political combat," he added, "and I think that fighting back to try to prevent a political injustice from occurring justifies drawing the line in the sand and saying hold on here, look at the great achievements that we have."
He agreed with the suggestion that Mr. Clinton had degraded the Presidency but said Mr. Clinton had recovered. "This election in the year 2000 is not about Bill Clinton, it's not about the past, it's about the future," Mr. Gore said when asked whether he was burdened by what the pundits call Clinton fatigue.
Mr. Gore indicated that he intended to step out more from Mr. Clinton's shadow. The overhaul of his campaign, he said, gives him "an even better chance to define my candidacy in terms of what I'm saying to the American people as a candidate for President, not as someone who is Vice President and defined in those terms."

HEADLINE: House Bills Diverge Over a Patient's Right to Sue

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
When the House of Representatives takes up legislation to define patients' rights this week, it will have a choice of three major bills that take very different approaches to regulating health insurance and health maintenance organizations.
And that does not count a separate bill, passed by the Senate in July, on a vote largely along party lines. 
 All the bills would create a wide range of new Federal rights for patients, setting national standards in a field regulated mainly by the states for 50 years. The bills would, for example, guarantee coverage of emergency medical care, allow patients to appeal coverage decisions to an independent board and insure that doctors could share information with patients.
The biggest difference among the bills involves a relatively simple question: whether patients could sue H.M.O.'s to enforce their rights.
In the last 25 years, Federal and state judges have limited a patient's right to sue in dozens of court decisions interpreting a 1974 law that was meant to protect pension and health benefit plans against the conflicting mandates of different states. But in recent months, judges have issued rulings that are more receptive to lawsuits attacking the quality of care provided by health plans.
One of the House bills, favored by President Clinton, most House Democrats and more than 20 Republicans, would allow patients to sue health plans in state courts for damages if the patients were harmed by a denial of treatment. The bill, which would set the most stringent and comprehensive standards for H.M.O.'s, was written by Representatives Charlie Norwood, Republican of Georgia, and John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan.
Dr. Norwood, a dentist, insists that health plans must be held more accountable for the decisions they and their doctors make. He has repeatedly defied the leaders of his party by demanding a vote on his bill. Dr. Norwood and Mr. Dingell say their bill has more support than any alternative. But they have no assurance that they will prevail because it is unclear how their bill might be amended in debate.
Some Republicans support the right to sue, but believe Dr. Norwood and Mr. Dingell go too far. These lawmakers favor a bill by two House Republicans, Tom Coburn of Oklahoma and John Shadegg of Arizona, that would allow patients to sue in Federal court, where it is believed that juries are less likely to return big verdicts against health plans.
Under the Coburn-Shadegg bill, an injured patient could sue an H.M.O. or an insurance company that failed to exercise "ordinary care" in deciding whether a service was covered under a health plan. The plaintiff would have to show that the H.M.O.'s decision was the "proximate," or most significant, cause of the patient's injury or death.
Two other bills -- one introduced in the House by Representative John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio, and the bill passed by the Senate -- would not create any new right to sue. Employers of all sizes, H.M.O.'s and insurers say such lawsuits would increase the cost of insurance, so fewer people could afford it.
Dr. Coburn, a family doctor, and Mr. Shadegg offer their proposal as a middle ground between the Norwood-Dingell bill and the Boehner bill.
Business groups see the Boehner bill as "the best among a series of bad options," as the National Association of Manufacturers put it.
"With its reliance on mandates, the Boehner bill is more reform than we need," said Patrick Cleary, vice president of the association. "But of the three major health care bills, it is the one that does the least damage to the employer-based health care system."
On the other hand, Ronald F. Pollack, executive director of Families USA, a consumer group, said: "The Boehner bill is the proposal supported by those who want to kill patients' rights legislation. It offers very weak protections and includes poison pills that would make any real patients' rights bill impossible to enact."
Mr. Pollack observed that "the context of the debate has changed radically in the last three to five years." The best evidence of the change is that conservatives like Mr. Boehner are now proposing Federal regulation of the health insurance industry, if only to fend off more stringent rules proposed by Democrats, consumer advocates, labor unions and doctors.
The three major House bills apply to all forms of individual and group health insurance, H.M.O.'s and other types of managed care.
The scope of the Senate bill is more limited, and more confusing. Some protections apply to the 48 million people in group health plans regulated exclusively by the Federal Government; some apply to 124 million who get coverage through their employers; some apply to 140 million with group or individual insurance.
Republican senators said they devised this because they wanted to let states continue as the primary regulators of health insurance. The H.M.O. industry did not seek this arrangement.
"We never campaigned for that provision of the Senate bill," said Karen M. Ignagni, president of the American Association of Health Plans.
Most patients are unlikely to sue. They want to get health care when they need it, and they cannot afford to litigate for years. All the House and Senate bills would address their needs by establishing new rights for patients to appeal the denial of claims for benefits. Patients could appeal first within a health plan and then, if necessary, to an independent panel of medical experts.
For years, the insurance industry has opposed new Federal requirements. But now, with some patients and politicians demanding action to rein in H.M.O's, Ms. Ignagni said, "We are very comfortable with the idea of objective external review," provided, of course, that there is no new right to sue.
In general, all four bills would allow a patient to appeal a decision holding that a service was medically unnecessary or experimental, and therefore not covered. But the standards of review and the procedures differ.
Under all the bills, a health plan that refuses to comply with the decision of an independent review panel would be subject to financial penalties.
Because the Boehner bill does not create any new right to sue, the decision of "external reviewers" would be final.
Under the Coburn-Shadegg bill, patients could sue in Federal court if they suffered physical injury because of a health plan's negligence. Before going to court, patients would have to use the appeals process established by their H.M.O. In court, damages for pain and suffering would be limited to $250,000 or twice the amount of any economic loss, whichever was greater. Patients could not recover punitive damages unless a health plan had acted with "conscious, flagrant indifference to the rights or safety" of patients.
Under the Norwood-Dingell bill, an injured patient could sue an H.M.O. in state court regardless of whether the patient had gone through the health plan's appeal procedure.

Chart: "AT A GLANCE -- Defining Patients' Rights"
The House of Representatives is considering three very different bills to define patients' rights and regulate health insurance, and the Senate passed a bill in July. The main sponsors of the House bills and their proposals:
 
HOUSE BILLS
 
NORWOOD-DINGELL
Summary: Most extensive consumer pro-tections. Most stringent regulation of insurance companies.
 
SCOPE: Applies across the board to group health plans and individual insurance.
 
LAWSUITS: Injured patients could sue H.M.O.'s and other health plans in state court.
 
EXTERNAL REVIEW: Patients could insist that an independent panel of medical experts review decisions denying benefit claims. Health plan could be penalized up to $1,000 a day for failure to comply with reviewers' decision.
 
ACCESS TO SPECIALISTS: Health plans must provide prompt ACCESS to medical specialists for patients who need such care.
 
EMERGENCY CARE: Health plans must provide coverage, without prior authorization, for EMERGENCY CARE whenever a prudent lay person would consider it necessary.
 
COBURN-SHADEGG
Summary: Intended as a possible middle ground in the House.
 
SCOPE: Similar to Norwood-Dingell bill.
 
LAWSUITS: Injured patients could sue H.M.O.'s and other health plans in Federal court.
 
EXTERNAL REVIEW: Similar to Norwood-Dingell bill.
 
ACCESS TO SPECIALISTS: Similar to Norwood-Dingell bill.
 
EMERGENCY CARE: Similar to Norwood-Dingell bill. Plans also must cover emergency ambulance services.
 
BOEHNER
Summary: Businesses see this as the least onerous of the three major House bills.
 
SCOPE: Similar to Norwood-Dingell bill.
 
LAWSUITS: No new right to sue.
 
EXTERNAL REVIEW: Health plans must allow EXTERNAL REVIEW of coverage decisions. Health plan could be penalized up to $5,000 a day for failure to comply with reviewers' decision.
 
ACCESS TO SPECIALISTS: No similar provision.
 
EMERGENCY CARE: Health plans must provide coverage, without prior authorization, for EMERGENCY CARE and ambulance services whenever a prudent lay person would consider them necessary.
 
SENATE BILL
Summary: Modest new Federal role. States continue as primary regulator for most health insurance.
 
SCOPE: Major protections, like EMERGENCY CARE and ACCESS TO SPECIALISTS, apply only to 48 million people in group health plans now exempt from state regulation.
 
LAWSUITS: No new right to sue.
 
EXTERNAL REVIEW: Health plans must allow EXTERNAL REVIEW of coverage decisions and would be subject to a civil penalty up to $10,000 for failure to comply with reviewers' decisions. Applies to plans covering 124 million people.
 
ACCESS TO SPECIALISTS: Health plans would have to allow timely ACCESS to medical specialists. This standard applies to a limited number of health plans covering 48 million Americans.
 
EMERGENCY CARE: Health plans must provide coverage, without prior authorization, for EMERGENCY CARE whenever a prudent lay person would consider it necessary.

HEADLINE: Unburdening the Third World

 BODY:
President Clinton made a dramatic and important announcement last Wednesday when he pledged to cancel the debt owed to Washington by the world's poorest nations, as long as they used the savings for health, education and other anti-poverty programs. His promise comes on top of an Administration pledge the week before to seek $1 billion for an initiative that would mainly retire poor nations' debts to international lenders. It is now up to Congress to provide the money, and other wealthy nations to match Mr. Clinton's commitment.
The debt owed by the poorest nations -- most of the 36 countries covered by the President's announcement are in Africa -- helps trap them in misery. Most of these nations are paying debt service on loans from decades ago, when irresponsible lenders pushed profligate governments to borrow. Their creditors long ago concluded they would never be repaid, but some countries spend 60 percent of their budget to keep rolling over these debts. The burden has cut into spending on education and other social programs. In some countries in Africa, the entire health budget comes to only $6 or $7 a year per person. 
 The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund began a program to try to reduce these debts in 1996. But only four nations have qualified -- Uganda, Bolivia, Mali and Guyana -- and it took years of I.M.F.-imposed austerity do so. A worldwide advocacy movement called Jubilee 2000, which includes religious groups, development organizations and artists, has led a campaign for more debt relief. At a June meeting in Cologne, Germany, the world's seven wealthiest nations agreed to forgive more of the debt owed by the poorest nations to rich countries and international lenders. The Cologne initiative was an improvement, but it still fell short of what poor countries need.
Each wealthy country pledged to forgive some of the debt it was owed and pay for a portion of the debt owed to the World Bank. Governments are famous for failing to honor these commitments, but Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers announced recently that the Administration would ask Congress for the full amount it had pledged. The President then followed with his decision to cancel the rest of the debt owed directly to Washington.
Debt relief is a bargain for the United States, which had lent comparatively little to poor countries and has already written off most of the loans. The nations that could qualify for the President's plan owe the United States $5.7 billion, but canceling that entire amount will cost Washington only about $450 million because of earlier write-offs. Perhaps as important as Washington's debt forgiveness, President Clinton's announcement will challenge other nations to meet and go beyond their pledges in Cologne and cancel their own debts.
A few nations will qualify for the debt relief by the end of this year, and Mr. Clinton said that three-quarters of the highly indebted countries could get relief next year. The international community must watch carefully to insure that the money saved does benefit the poor. A well-run program can make a big difference. Two years ago in Uganda, for example, half the children of primary-school age stayed home, mainly because their families could not pay school fees. But Uganda used most of its $40 million in debt relief to cancel those fees, and this year 90 percent of the children go to school. Now, it will qualify for another $40 million of relief. Congress should quickly approve the President's request, which is a pittance for America but can improve the lives of the most needy worldwide.

HEADLINE: MORE AMERICANS WERE UNINSURED IN 1998, U.S. SAYS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
The number of Americans without health insurance rose last year by 833,000, to 44.3 million, despite a strong economy and a new law intended to provide coverage for children, the Census Bureau reported today.
The ranks of the uninsured have grown by more than 4.5 million since President Clinton took office in 1993, promising health insurance for all Americans. 
 Since the failure of Mr. Clinton's effort to have Congress approve a comprehensive health care proposal in 1994, the President and Congress have agreed on a series of incremental laws intended to expand coverage. But health policy experts say the continued increase in the number of the uninsured raises questions about the effectiveness of that strategy.
The Census Bureau report comes just three days before the House is scheduled to take up legislation defining a range of new patients' rights.
Many Republicans, insurance companies and business groups have opposed such legislation, saying it would raise premiums and contribute to further increases in the number of uninsured, a contention disputed by many Democrats.
At the same time, the plight of the uninsured is emerging as a major issue in the 2000 Presidential campaign, with former Senator Bill Bradley calling for a renewed commitment to providing every American with access to coverage.
The Census Bureau said 16.3 percent of Americans did not have health insurance last year. That figure, the highest in a decade, was up slightly from 16.1 percent in 1997.
In households with annual incomes of $50,000 or more, the number of people without health insurance increased 1.7 million last year, to 12.2 million, the bureau said.
"This is a troubling trend," said Chris Jennings, the health policy coordinator at the White House.
The data for 1998 are somewhat surprising because the economy was vibrant, family income was up, the unemployment rate was at the lowest level in nearly three decades and employers were competing for workers in many parts of the country.
Health policy experts gave several possible reasons for the increase in the number of uninsured.
Some employers have cut health benefits for employees or their dependents. Many employers still offer coverage but require employees to pay more, and many low-income workers say they cannot afford the premiums. Most of the jobs created in the last few years are in small businesses, which are less likely to offer health benefits. Finally, many people leaving welfare have lost Medicaid coverage without getting any insurance to replace it.
The Census Bureau found that the number of women without health insurance rose last year by 947,000, to 21.3 million, while the number of men without coverage declined by 116,000, to 23 million. In the last five years, the bureau said, the number of women without insurance has increased by 3.2 million, while the number of uninsured men rose 1.4 million.
In 1997, Congress created a special health insurance program for children, and Mr. Clinton has repeatedly prodded Federal and state officials to enroll eligible children.
But the Census Bureau said the number of children under 18 without health insurance increased last year by 330,000, to 11.1 million, following a rise of 188,000 in 1997. The proportion of children without insurance also rose, to 15.4 percent in 1998, from 15 percent in 1997.
The increase was most notable among poor children under the age of 6. The proportion of such children without insurance climbed to 23.6 percent last year, from 20.1 percent in 1997, the bureau said.
Cuts in the Medicaid rolls appear to be one reason for the increase. The number of people with Medicaid coverage dropped by 1.1 million last year, to 27.9 million, after falling by 2.5 million in 1997, the Census Bureau said.
Jennifer A. Campbell, the main author of the Census Bureau report, said, "Medicaid was the most widespread type of coverage among the poor, with 40.6 percent of all poor people covered by Medicaid at some time" in 1998.
"This percentage is down significantly from the previous year, when 43.3 percent of poor people were covered by Medicaid," Ms. Campbell said.
Most poor children are eligible for Medicaid. But the number of poor children with such coverage declined by 766,000 last year, to 7.8 million, after falling by 501,000 in 1997, the bureau said.
Administration officials say they believe that some recipients of Medicaid do not realize they have coverage and did not report it when interviewed by the Census Bureau.
Overall, poverty declined and incomes rose last year. (A family of four was considered poor if it had an income of less than $16,660.) But nearly one-third of poor people, 11.2 million of the 34.5 million in poverty, had no health insurance, the Government said.
About 5.6 million people worked full-time last year and were still poor. About half of them -- 2.7 million, or 47.5 percent -- had no health insurance.
Among various racial and ethnic groups, Hispanic Americans were the least likely to have health insurance. The Census Bureau said 35.3 percent of Hispanic residents were uninsured, compared with 22.2 percent of blacks, 21.1 percent of Asian-Americans and 11.9 percent of non-Hispanic whites.
More than seven million of the people without health insurance are not United States citizens, the report said. Nearly 43 percent of the 16.6 million noncitizens are uninsured.
Using the average for 1997 and 1998, the Census Bureau reported that 24.5 percent of Texas residents were uninsured, the largest proportion for any state. Hawaii, with 8.8 percent, had the smallest proportion.
Arizona also had a high rate, with 24.3 percent of its people uninsured, while the proportion without coverage was small in Minnesota (9.2 percent) and Wisconsin (9.9 percent).
The proportion without health insurance was well below the national average in Connecticut, where 12.3 percent were uninsured.
The figures were slightly above the national average in New York (17.4 percent) and New Jersey (16.5 percent).

HEADLINE: In America;
The New Al Gore

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Al Gore dropped by a few days ago and insisted he's a changed man.
"I'm in a completely different place as far as this campaign is concerned," he said. He said he felt liberated. "I couldn't care less what the pollsters and consultants say about the issues, the strategy. I'm just going to do my dead level best to speak and act directly from my heart and rely on my instincts and let the chips fall where they may." 
 He quoted Janis Joplin: "Freedom's just another word for nothin' left to lose."
I was amazed. Was this Al Gore?
One of the raps against the Vice President is that he comes across as inauthentic, too programmed. So the question is whether he means it when he says he plans to campaign from the heart, or whether this is just another makeover crafted by the very consultants he says he's going to ignore.
If he's serious, he might have a shot at saving his campaign. Harry Truman, who was short of funds, terrible at giving speeches and disdained by many in his own party, won in 1948 by taking a ferociously honest message straight to the people.
Among other things, Truman said, "If you send another Republican Congress to Washington, you're a bigger bunch of suckers than I think you are."
When I asked Mr. Gore why he would be a better President than George W. Bush, he replied: "I fight for working families; he doesn't. His philosophy relies on attention to those who hold the levers of power and have the bulk of the resources, and is based on the theory that if they are well attended to, then those decisions will have a beneficial impact on the rest of the country."
He said there might be some hyperbole in that statement, but not much. It was an affront to common sense, he said, "to recommend a return to the economic policies of the Reagan-Bush years that created devastation for low- and middle-income working families."
Mr. Gore went on to speak emphatically, even passionately, about the state of the public schools and his opposition to school vouchers:
"Ninety percent of the children are in public schools. The teachers are overburdened. The classrooms are overcrowded. The buildings are falling down.
"The reform agenda is underfunded and the percentage of the voting population made up of parents of school-age children, always a mainstay for supporting bond issues for education, is the smallest percentage it has ever been in history because of the aging of our population. In a situation like that, to call for draining away money from public schools toward private schools is just plain irresponsible in my opinion."
Al Gore has the issues that should trump Mr. Bush and the experience that should check Bill Bradley. And yet he is struggling against both.
There are moments every now and then when you catch a glimpse of the spontaneity and conviction the voters would like to see in him. One night last week a woman called in to Larry King's show on CNN and asked Mr. Gore if, knowing what he knows today, he still would have run with Bill Clinton.
The Vice President didn't hesitate. "Yes, I would," he said, "because if you look at the difference that's been made for this country in the last six and a half years -- instead of a triple-dip recession, we now have 20 million new jobs. We have higher incomes, the lowest African-American and Latino unemployment rates in history. The stock market has tripled instead of the debt quadrupling, as it did in the Reagan-Bush years. The crime rates are lower. There are more families moving off welfare and into the work force. Families are stronger. Teen pregnancies are down. Abortions are down. The quality of life is up. We are a better country because of the differences that this Administration has helped to bring about in the last six and a half years."
The public will vote thumbs up or thumbs down on Mr. Gore's campaign for the Presidency. The question is whether the Vice President will give himself a fair chance, whether he'll allow the voters to see the authentic Al Gore, the real man behind the cardboard candidate. That seems extremely difficult for him, but he says he will. He says he's been liberated.

HEADLINE: Mosquito Virus Exposes a Hole in the Safety Net

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
It may have come in the blood of a traveler returning from Africa or Europe. It may have hitchhiked in an infected bird smuggled in baggage. There is even a slight chance that it came in the gut of a mosquito that flitted into a jet.
But as medical sleuths try to trace the path of the West Nile-like virus that has helicopters fumigating New York City and its suburbs, they are also confronting a much larger problem. 
 This virus, which has killed four people and scores of birds, is just one of dozens of hazards to people, crops, livestock, and wildlife that -- after being hemmed in by oceans for millenniums -- are increasingly free to hopscotch the world because of the acceleration and growth of international travel and trade.
The threat is greatest in the country's biggest hubs of global commerce: New York City, Los Angeles and Miami.
"We've gotten over being surprised," said Dr. James Hughes, the director of the National Center for Infectious Diseases at the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which is promoting a new plan to improve surveillance and responses when an outbreak occurs. "We're making some progress, and it's a good thing," Dr. Hughes said, "because the microbes are certainly out there."
Medical and agricultural inspectors and experts are working around the clock to spot new threats. But the West Nile-like virus proves that the safety net is, at best, incomplete.
Some of the enemies are invisible microbes; others are as conspicuous as the freight-hopping, tree-drilling, two-inch Asian long-horned beetle, a threat to hardwood forests. The beetle made its North American debut in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, in 1996 and has since appeared in Chicago and, most recently, on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, just blocks from the greenery of Central Park. The beetle probably arrived in the 1980's in wooden shipping pallets, said Henry J. Stern, the City Commissioner of Parks and Recreation.
Mr. Stern said the beetle and now the virus show that nature is still capable of throwing surprises at the world's dominant species.
"In the modern age, this mechanical age, we think we've conquered the planet," he said. "But we're not quite the masters of the universe we think we are."
Improvements in transportation have always been followed by movements of harmful species, said William H. McNeill, the author of the book "Plagues and Peoples," which he updated last year. Smallpox accompanied seagoing European settlers to the Americas. But potato blight did not move from the Americas to Europe until the mid-1800's, when the advent of swifter ships allowed potatoes to arrive fresh, with the harmful mold healthy and alive.
At the end of the 20th century, the explosive growth in airplane traffic has amplified the problem. The number of international passenger and cargo flights to and from airports serving New York City doubled just from 1987 to 1997, to 187,785 from 93,008, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
The flow of goods and travelers can only be spot-checked by inspectors seeking threats. Screening for imported diseases is nearly impossible because West Nile and many other dangerous ailments often are carried without symptoms for days or weeks.
The effort to monitor and sequester sick passengers has shrunk substantially in recent decades; the number of Federal quarantine stations at airports dropped from 55 in 1967 to 8 today, Federal health officials said. One of the eight is at Kennedy International Airport.
The only really effective way to track imported infections is to communicate well with hospitals and doctors, local health officials said.
"Having one inspector for every person coming in would not prevent disease from coming in," said Dr. Marcelle C. Layton, the assistant commissioner for communicable diseases of the New York City Health Department. So when some new threat is identified, the only recourse is often to wait for cases to start popping up at city hospitals, city health officials say.
A swift response is then essential, she said, explaining that New York City, with 24,000 people per square mile, is twice as crowded as the country's second most densely populated city, Chicago.
In a parallel effort, teams of inspectors are also on the lookout for agricultural pests or diseases. Some of the dogs sniffing bags at airport terminals are looking not for drugs or bombs, but for oranges that might carry imported fruit flies; for giant African snails that are a delicacy to some, but to agriculture officials are a potential scourge, and for sausage, which has been occasionally found sewn into coat linings of epicures, and which can harbor mad cow disease or hog cholera.
Occasionally, officials are amazed by what they find. Beagles at Kennedy recently sniffed out a partly stuffed cow head arriving from Argentina. Just last week, someone brought two bucketloads of live Vietnamese apple snails, which are voracious rice pests, into Los Angeles International Airport, said Joseph Cavey, a biologist with the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, a branch of the Federal Agriculture Department that monitors imported hazards.
"There was a woman once who was hiding her pet parrot under her dress," Mr. Cavey said. "You could see it moving."
But any amusement fades with the knowledge that it is this kind of bird that could carry a disease like West Nile, which has so far killed four people, sickened dozens of others, prompted widespread pesticide spraying, and felled scores of crows and other birds in and around New York City.
There is a small chance that the West Nile-like virus -- like hantavirus, another recent discovery -- has been in this country for years and is only now being noticed because of the deadly outbreak that began in New York City at the end of the summer. But medical experts investigating the mystery say evidence so far indicates that it is most likely a new arrival, spreading from an epicenter in Queens near the Whitestone Bridge.
Federal health officials said that the virus is essentially identical to West Nile, but they will not officially call it West Nile until genetic decoding is completed.
One new case of the virus was reported yesterday in New York City, raising the total to 37 confirmed cases, the city's Health Department said. In the latest case, an 81-year-old woman from Flushing, Queens, was treated for the symptoms at a hospital and released.
The intensive medical investigations prompted by outbreaks like the current one sometimes reveal other potential threats that lurk continuously but rarely surface.
In September 1994, as pneumonic plague swept Surat, a city on the west coast of India, health officials in New York City girded for possible battle, hoping to prevent the disease from being introduced by infected travelers.
Faxes and alerts went out to the city's 70 hospitals and the airports. No plague was found, but the effort was not a waste of time, said Dr. Layton, with the city Health Department.
The extra surveillance identified cases of typhoid fever, malaria and possibly dengue fever, all of which are potentially deadly imported illnesses -- and all of which most likely would never have been noticed. "When you look more closely," Dr. Layton said, "when you get down on your hands and knees and clean your kitchen, you're going to find things you don't normally find."
Once a new pest or disease makes a landing, the consequences can be dire, and expensive.
In the early 1970's, agriculture officials say, Newcastle disease, probably carried by parrots imported from South America, attacked poultry and other birds in southern California. Nearly 12 million chickens and other birds had to be killed. The eradication effort and the losses amounted to $56 million.
Zebra mussels, brought from Eastern Europe to eastern North America in ballast water in ships in the 1980's, have caused $5 billion in damage to pipes and pumps, mainly in the Great Lakes. Federal scientists are now trying to prevent them from crossing the continental divide.
In a study scheduled to be published in the December issue of Bioscience, a scientific journal, Dr. David Pimentel, an ecologist and entomologist at Cornell University, estimates that the annual cost of dealing with imported species of plants, animals, and diseases is $138 billion, including crop losses and the cost of eradication efforts.
The damage goes beyond economics, Dr. Pimentel said. "Forty-two percent of endangered and threatened species are on the list because of invasive species," he said.
And then, of course, there is the loss of life when a new virus or other infectious agent arrives on a shore where people and animals have no resistance.
Some symptoms seen in the New York City residents stricken with encephalitis from the West Nile-like virus are very different from those known from the disease in its home range in northern Africa -- and in many cases the symptoms are more severe, Dr. Layton said.
Many of the patients experienced extreme muscle weakness, a symptom never previously reported from this virus, she said.
"When a virus gets to a new part of the world, it's hard to know how it will behave in animals and humans," Dr. Layton said.
One fact troubling those involved in watching for incoming diseases is that it is impossible to test for everything.
Dr. K. N. Ahmad, who is the Department of Agriculture's port veterinarian for New York City, said that all legally imported birds are tested for Newcastle disease and avian influenza, another infection that can devastate poultry.
Birds are then kept in a 30-day quarantine, some in the Bronx and some in Newburgh, in Orange County, N.Y., to watch for signs of illness. But they are not routinely tested for encephalitis viruses, and certainly not for West Nile, he said.
Legal bird imports through New York City have dropped nearly to nil in recent years, he said, because of new Federal and international bans on dealing in rare tropical species.
But smuggling still persists, he said.
And imports of other potential disease hosts are on the rise.
Seven days a week, Dr. Ahmad said, he or his team greets shipments of high-priced horses from around the world, a trade that is thriving along with the American economy. Last Thursday night, he headed from his office at Kennedy Airport to check 13 horses arriving in a Cargolux jet from Iceland.
Dr. Ahmad drew blood samples that were sent to a Federal laboratory in Ames, Iowa, on the next United Airlines flight. Then the horses were driven in sealed trucks to Newburgh, to wait in quarantine for three days for the test results.
The samples are checked for signs of exposure to four deadly contagious equine diseases that do not exist in the United States. One of them, called glanders, causes ulcers throughout the lymphatic system and can be spread to humans, he said.
"It is very rare and has not been seen here in 50 or 60 years, but we do get animals that test positive, meaning they were exposed," Dr. Ahmad said. Such animals are sent back or destroyed. This shipment, at least, passed the test, and soon the horses were headed to their new owners in Maine, Vermont, upstate New York, and Arkansas, Dr. Ahmad said.
But more horses, birds and travelers are coming every day, he said, adding, "It never stops."
