In the era of the ocean freighter and the jumbo jet, government agencies in the United States are constantly on guard against the arrival of unwelcome foreign species of plants and animals -- some microscopic, and some potentially deadly.
 
HUMAN THREAT: West Nile virus
WHERE IT COMES FROM: Africa and Asia. Birds transmit it to mosquitoes, which then transfer it to humans.
WHAT IT DOES: Causes headache and fever. Can cause neurological disorders and death.
 
HUMAN THREAT: Malaria
WHERE IT COMES FROM: Found in all the tropics. Transmitted from person to person by mosquitoes.
WHAT IT DOES: Causes fever, chills, headache and muscle aches.
 
ANIMAL THREAT: River ruffe Stickleback
WHERE IT COMES FROM: Eurasia, in the region of the Caspian Sea
WHAT IT DOES: Eats eggs of other fish; particular threat to Great Lakes.
 
ANIMAL THREAT: Equine piroplasmosis (Horse tick fever)
WHERE IT COMES FROM: Found in nearly every country except the U.S., Canada and Britain
WHAT IT DOES: Attacks the red blood cells in horses and mules.
 
AGRICULTURAL THREAT: Asian long-horned beetle
WHERE IT COMES FROM: Asia
WHAT IT DOES: Burrows into trees and destroys them.
 
AGRICULTURAL THREAT: Mediterranean fruit fly
WHERE IT COMES FROM: South Africa
WHAT IT DOES: Lays eggs in fruit. (pg. B7)

HEADLINE: Compressed Data;
Support for Sellers In Electronic Auctions

BYLINE: By LAURIE J. FLYNN 

 BODY:
Andale Inc. wants to take the fleas out of the electronic flea market. The start-up E-commerce company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., plans to unveil a new service this week that provides back-office support for people who make their living selling goods on electronic auctions.
Andale will provide all the necessary administrative support for such merchants, like establishing listings, answering customer E-mail and sending out merchandise to buyers. The service is intended for power sellers, the tens of thousands of people who make their livings -- as well as huge profits, in some cases -- auctioning large quantities of everything from antiques and baseball cards to costume jewelry and electronics. 
 Munjal Shah, the founder and chief executive of Andale, said that for these entrepreneurs, managing an electronic auction business can be a cumbersome process, mostly because auction sites are not set up to handle the growing businesses that have popped up. "Most people don't realize that the vast majority of transactions on sites like Ebay are done by just a small percentage of registered users," said Mr. Shah, a former marketing executive at the software maker Baan. "Yet auction sites are designed for the casual user."
According to a report issued earlier this year by Forrester Research, spending on auction sites will grow from $1 billion in 1998 to an estimated $2.3 billion this year and to $6.4 billion by 2003. The great majority of the goods will be sold by people who have set up businesses by selling at auctions, rather than by individual consumers selling collectibles from their attics. Andale generates revenues by taking a small percentage of every transaction.
Founded in April, Andale has already raised $19.6 million from Accel Partners and several other Silicon Valley venture capital firms and plans to begin its service in November.
 LAURIE J. FLYNN

HEADLINE: Will Dam-Busting Save Salmon? Maybe Not

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

DATELINE: LOWER GRANITE DAM, Wash.

 BODY:
The big hydroelectric dam sits deep in a valley framed by softly rounded, grass-covered mountains that look from a distance as if they have been sanded down and then covered with beige and blond velvet. Great expanses of sun-dappled blue water, more reservoir or lake than river, stretch above and below the concrete-and-earth barrier. That is part of the problem.
The once fast-flowing Snake River is now so slow, and Lower Granite Dam so much of an impediment, that salmon -- totem fish of the Pacific Northwest and the focus of a landmark political, economic and environmental struggle -- cannot migrate up and down the Snake without the help of an elaborate man-made Rube Goldberg-like system. 
 So it was on a recent day as a state fisheries biologist, Fred Mensik, plucked a silvery, six-inch fish from water speeding through a trough.
"Chinook," Mr. Mensik said, identifying it as a member of the heftiest of the salmon species. If it lives long enough, the juvenile smolt, as it is called, could grow to 3 or 4 feet and 40 pounds or more. Mr. Mensik measured the fish, entered the information into a laptop computer and returned the fish to the trough, where it joined other smolts and migrating young steelhead (sea-run rainbow trout) on their way to a tank truck parked outside.
The truck would transport the juvenile fish nearly 250 miles downriver, past seven other dams in the Columbia River system, of which the Snake is a part. There the fish were released to resume a trip to the Pacific Ocean.
While Mr. Mensik and his co-workers were shepherding the fish downstream, adult salmon and steelhead -- big, powerful veterans of years at sea -- were climbing a fish ladder a few feet away, heading upstream to spawn and die. But there are so few going upstream that all these fish, along with all other salmon and steelhead that spawn in the Snake River, are listed as imperiled under the Endangered Species Act.
Will the elaborate, two-decade-old system for moving fish around the dams prove inadequate to save the salmon? The question is at the heart of a tense debate over whether to continue to rely on the transportation system or junk it and remove the earthen portions of Lower Granite and three other hydroelectric dams on the lower Snake.
Breaching those dams would help restore the natural flow along a 140-mile stretch of the river, and many scientists say it would be the single most effective remedy for the salmon's plight. The concrete portions of the dams, their humming turbines silenced, would become relics, abandoned monuments to a time when the only consideration was to conquer and harness nature, and to the dawn of an era in which coexisting with nature has been made a priority.
A decision on the dams, driven by a Federal lawsuit brought by environmentalists, is expected by early next year. If the Clinton Administration proposes breaching the dams, the issue would then go to Congress, which must appropriate the money.
Few if any conservation problems match this one for scale and complexity, or for its many connections with the modern economy. "The salmon involves our whole way of doing things," said Dr. Peter M. Kareiva, an ecologist who is directing a scientific assessment of the problem for the National Marine Fisheries Service. "There is no simple, easily defined enemy."
Many scientists and environmentalists say the question of whether to breach the dams is a no-brainer. They argue that the population of the Snake River salmon began to decline after the dams were built in the 1960's and 1970's, and that while the system for trucking and barging fish downstream and helping adults back up may have helped, it is inadequate.
"Prior to completion of the lower Snake River dams, Snake River stocks did as well or better than their downriver counterparts," said Ed Bowles, a scientist who is the salmon and steelhead recovery manager for the state of Idaho, which contains the Snake's watershed upstream of the four dams. "Since completion of the dams, we have every year done much worse."
But other scientists, particularly those of the marine fisheries service, say the situation is more complicated. The service's studies, which are being reviewed by an independent panel, suggest that while breaching the dams may be necessary to save some salmon stocks, it will not be enough. The wild salmon population has also been hurt by the destruction and degradation of spawning areas, overfishing and the introduction of hatchery-bred salmon and trout, according to the analysis. (Only about 20 percent of Snake River salmon today are the progeny of wild fish.)
Unless these problems are resolved, the analysis suggested, the wild salmon and trout will probably continue to decline, even if the dams are breached.
Breaching "is not going to be a silver bullet," said Dr. Michelle McClure, a biologist with the fisheries service who is helping to conduct the Federal analysis.
Moreover, said the fisheries service, which will draft the scientific opinion on which the decision about the dams will be based, the latest evidence suggests that trucking and barging young fish is more effective than was previously thought. Whether that is true should become clear in 5 or 10 years, scientists with the fisheries service said. One option, they said, would be to wait.
But other experts, including Mr. Bowles, said the answer was as apparent now as it would ever be. The fisheries service said any delay would increase the likelihood that some stocks of Snake River salmon would become extinct.
Pacific salmon are different from Atlantic salmon in that there are several species, and that different populations spawn at different times. Moreover, they spawn only once and then die (Atlantic salmon, and steelhead, can return to the ocean and spawn again, several times).
Conservation efforts have focused not so much on entire species of Pacific salmon as on specific stocks, a group of fish that spawn in the same locality, like a specific creek.
Individual stocks are important because each diverges genetically from other stocks as they reproduce. Such divergence is the touchstone of evolutionary adaptation, and so individual stocks are protected by the Endangered Species Act.
For many stocks of Snake River salmon, the marine fisheries service has found that the risk of extinction is considerable, sometimes even in the short term. For instance, surveys of a chinook stock that spawns in a spring in Marsh Creek, a beautiful alpine meadow stream in the Frank Church Wilderness of Idaho, found no spawners last spring or in the spring of 1995.
The studies by the fisheries service indicated that the Marsh Creek salmon had at least a 1-in-10 chance of virtual extinction (only one spawner a year) in the next decade, and that many stocks of chinook that spawned in the spring and summer had a 1-in-2 chance of extinction in the next century. The risk that all Snake River runs of spring and summer chinook will be extinct in 100 years was calculated at about 50 percent.
Other runs of chinook spawn in the fall, and their risk of extinction in the next century was calculated at 27 percent; for steelhead, even though their numbers are relatively robust, the risk was 93 percent. A fourth species, the Snake River sockeye salmon, is already close to extinction: only seven returned to their Idaho spawning grounds this year.
The Columbia-Snake system was once one of the most fecund salmon producers in the world, with the Snake drainage giving birth to about half of all salmon in that system. But the dams, overfishing, destruction of spawning areas and the competition with hatchery fish cut severely into their numbers. Generally, the depletion has been worse the farther south one goes; salmon are not imperiled in Alaska, for example.
Some Columbia basin populations, ones whose passage was completely blocked by dams, have long since become extinct. But on other stretches, like the lower Snake, the Army Corps of Engineers has engaged in a long, expensive effort to make the passage as easy as possible so that more fish will survive. The result has been the substitution, at a cost of more than $3 billion, of an artificial system for the natural one.
At Lower Granite Dam, for instance, juvenile fish coming downstream are diverted into an elaborate bypass system and then into either tank trucks or barges.
Most of the juvenile fish are alive when released below Bonneville Dam on the Columbia River, but an argument rages about whether many of them later die from the stress of transportation. Proponents of breaching the Snake dams argue that fish hatched below the dams show higher survival rates than do those hatched above and transported downstream.
But the fisheries service said new studies involving fish tracked with tiny radio transmitters suggested that there was no significant increase in mortality associated with barging and trucking. Other scientists counter that the sample is too small to draw conclusions.
And some environmentalists and scientists said that barging and trucking did nothing for adult fish, some of which fail to find the entrances to fish ladders or are too exhausted to spawn once they run the gantlet of the dams.
What is the bottom line?
The Federal computer simulations show that breaching the dams would increase the growth of spring and summer chinook by about 5 percent. But, Dr. McClure said, a 12 percent improvement would be necessary to avoid extinction.
If policy makers want to eliminate as much risk as possible, then dam breaching should be pursued along with other actions like a moratorium on fishing and improvements in other areas, such as increasing the quality of habitat, the fisheries service said.
Alternatively, the service said, policy makers might want to accept the possible extinction of the Marsh Creek stock and explore whether alternatives to dam breaching might work. Even if the dams are removed -- which will also affect navigation, reduce a source of cheap electricity and, some politicians say, ruin the region's economy -- the actual breaching will take six or seven years, the Corps of Engineers says.
For fall chinook, virtually everyone agrees, dam breaching would be a boon. That is because they spawn not in tributary streams but in the main branches of the Snake and the Columbia. With the dams and their reservoirs in place, most of the water is too deep for spawning. But by breaching the four lower Snake dams, the habitat for fall chinook would increase nearly 80 percent.
On the other hand, Dr. Kareiva said, it may be that fall chinook and steelhead could be rescued by some means short of dam breaching, like stricter curbs on fishing.
A group of Federal agencies, including the fisheries service and Corps of Engineers, is developing options for salmon recovery that would take into account a range of threats to the salmon life cycle. The agencies' reports are due by the end of the year, after which there will be public hearings. The agencies hope to settle on a recommendation by next spring.
Then the fate of the salmon will move more squarely into the realm of politics and economics. In the end, the decision will probably boil down to how important Americans think it is to save the salmon.

Chart: "Rerouting Nature's Flow"
Dams in the lower Snake and Columbia Rivers interrupt the natural migrations of Pacific salmon and are believed to be a major factor in their declining numbers. Officials are considering alternatives to the present system for routing the fish around the dams.
 
Downstream
THE YOUNG GO TO SEA
 
SPILLWAYS
Some juvenile fish bypass the dams through spillways built into the dams. One concern is that the large volume of water spilling through these gates can produce excessive amounts of gases harmful to the fish.
 
TURBINES
Others go through turbines, where the high pressure and whirring blades kill up to 10 percent of the fish. Some of those that make it through end up disoriented and vulnerable to predators.
 
BYPASS SYSTEM ...
Large screens prevent the fish from being drawn into the turbine intakes and direct them upward into a bypass channel. Some fish re-enter the river on the downstream side of the dam.
 
At some dams, fish are transferred to barges or trucks that transport them past the Bonneville Dam, the last dam interrupting their migration to sea waters.
 
Upstream
THE ADULTS' RETURN TRIP
 
Adult fish swimming upstream to spawn pass the dams through an artificial set of rapids and pools constructed of concrete. About 95 percent complete the journey, but how many live to reproduce is in dispute.
 
(Source: United States Army Corps of Engineers)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mixed Signals From Japan On Economy

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 4

 BODY:
In a mixed signal about Japan's prospects for economic recovery, the nation's central bank reported a steep rise in business confidence today but a drop in business investment plans.
The Bank of Japan's closely watched quarterly survey showed the biggest gain in confidence among large manufacturers since November 1987. The findings surpassed analysts' expectations. 
 The survey, known as the tankan, measures the percentage of firms seeing business conditions improve minus the percentage seeing conditions worsen, and is considered a sensitive barometer of Japan's economic health.
The Japanese Government was cautious in its assessment of the tankan results. Hiromu Nonaka, the chief spokesman, said at a regular news briefing here that the survey showed the worst was over for Japan's economy but that the overall assessment still indicated severe conditions.
Despite the greater confidence, the pessimists still exceeded the optimists in the survey of 9,275 companies, which was conducted in September. It also showed that business investment continues to taper off in Japan, and for large corporations has weakened to the lowest level since September 1983.
The release of the survey came against a backdrop of strong economic news in Japan. The Government has reported two consecutive quarters of growth, however modest, and a drop in the unemployment rate from a postwar high.
Some analysts said the results of the tankan survey reinforced their view that Japan was still in a deep struggle to emerge from its deepest recession in a half-century.
"The tankan numbers show an improvement that exceeds expectations," said Yoshio Shukuwa, a market economist at Sanwa Securities, "but I'm skeptical that this can continue. There are still worries about this economic recovery."
Stocks received a slight lift from the report. The benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 51.15 points, or three-tenths of a percent, to close at 17,763.71. The yen gave up early gains against the dollar on news of the drop in business investment. In late trading here, the dollar sold at 106.11 yen. Later in New York, the dollar strengthened a little further to 106.23.
Although marginally weaker, the yen remains near its highest levels in more than three years. Japanese authorities fear that if the yen gains too much, economic recovery will be endangered because a strong currency hurts the competitiveness of exports.
The Group of Seven industrial nations, meeting late last month in Washington, expressed concern about the yen's strength in a statement viewed in foreign-exchange markets as a sign that Japan and its partners might take more aggressive coordinated action to contain the yen's rise But there has been no evidence so far that they have done so.

HEADLINE: Foundations Can Give More, And Protect Assets, Study Says

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Charitable foundations could give away 60 percent more money than they do now without eroding the total value of their assets, a study for a group of progressive foundations has found.
The study, by Prof. Perry Mehrling, chairman of the Barnard College economics department, found that so many wealthy Americans are establishing foundations that new gifts to these endowments are now greater than the grants they make. This trend, with investment income, means that foundation assets are growing much faster than grants to nonprofit organizations at a time when Congress has reduced funding for programs operated by charities. 
 Professor Mehrling's study is to be released today by the National Network of Grantmakers, an organization of progressive foundations, which recently began a campaign to persuade all foundations to increase their grant making by 20 percent, to 6 percent of assets from 5 percent. Professor Mehrling's study said giving could actually rise to 8 percent, a 60 percent increase, without reducing the value of foundation assets.
The network's proposed one percentage point increase in giving would mean $4 billion more this year for nonprofit organizations if it was adopted by all 49,000 charitable endowments that make grants.
Lester Salamon, a Johns Hopkins University expert on nonprofit finance who has studied how Federal budget cuts affect nonprofit organizations, has estimated that in the five years ending in 2002 these cuts will total more than $100 billion.
Congress set the minimum foundation payout at 5 percent of assets in 1981, repealing a rule that had required foundations to give away all of their investment income or 5 percent of their assets, whichever was greater. Foundations contended that the old rule, in effect during an era of high inflation, made foundation assets shrink in real terms.
The grant makers' campaign, called "One Percent More for Democracy," is being led by Diane V. Feeney of San Francisco, the daughter of Charles Feeney, who anonymously gave away most of his fortune, about $640 million, to his foundation starting in 1982. He revealed the gifts in 1997.
Ms. Feeney is president of her own family endowment, the French American Charitable Trust, which has assets of $43 million, according to the Chronicle of Philanthropy.
She said that although the campaign was focused on getting more money for progressive nonprofit organizations, she encouraged all foundations to increase their payouts.
Adjusted for inflation, foundations give away 3.6 times as much today as in 1982, the first year the 5 percent rule was in effect, but their assets have grown to 5.6 times as much.
Foundation assets totaled $330 billion at the end of 1997, the latest year for which the Foundation Center, a research organization, has released data. Grants totaled just under $16 billion, or 4.8 percent of assets.
Based on historic growth patterns and major gifts announced since then, foundation assets should now total more than $400 billion.
The Council on Foundations, the largest organization of charitable endowments, said studies in 1991 and 1995 showed that 5 percent was the optimal payout if foundation assets were to grow with inflation.
John Edie, the council's general counsel, said that over a half-century the 5 percent payout would let foundation assets grow about one-half of 1 percent a year above inflation.
Professor Mehrling said the 5 percent payout was imposed "not to keep foundations from paying out too much, but to keep them from paying out too little."
Foundations that restrict payouts to 5 percent to increase the amount of assets under their management, Professor Mehrling said, "defeat the real social purpose of their privileged tax status and risk attracting renewed legislative attention."

HEADLINE: This Splintered Isle;
Economically, There Have Always Been Two Englands

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
When the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, traveled to New York last month to extol his own stewardship of the British economy, he was in an ebullient mood, and the figures did nothing to darken his day.
With almost metronomic regularity, Britain has been setting records: inflation, by one yardstick, is at its lowest level in 36 years; unemployment has been tamed to levels last seen in the 1980's, and the budget is expected to zoom from a projected deficit of $7.4 billion to a surplus of $19.8 billion -- a war chest any political leader would covet. 
 But those numbers do not give the whole picture. For Britain cannot shake its chronic problem: an economy perilously skewed between an ailing industrial North and a prosperous South dominated by greater London. While Britain as a whole is creating jobs, said a former Trade Minister, Peter Mandelson, "on almost every other economic measure, the North-South gap is growing -- in income, average wages and migration, it is widening."
And, he said, those distinctions "will do great damage to the U.K. economy if not arrested."
Indeed, many of the disparities between the South and the North, particularly the four English counties clustered just below the Scottish border, are also seen to varying degrees when South England is compared with many areas of Scotland or Wales.
Of course, the divide between North and South in England is woven into British history, from the days cloth-capped coal miners symbolized the industrial Midlands and Northern reaches and bowler-hatted city gentlemen were the emblem of southern prosperity. But, more recently, these two regions have come to provide the geographic overlay of a contest between ailing manufacturing and booming services, a conflict sharpened by broader economic policy.
The currency, for instance, remains far too strong for the liking of exporters. Most of all, the fiscal discipline that Mr. Brown praised so highly as the guarantor of noninflationary growth -- on the United States model -- has itself begun to push up interest rates. And this, in turn, undermines any talk of Britain's converging with the 11 European economies bound together by a single currency, the euro. In those nations, the official short-term interest rate hovers around 2.5 percent, or less than half Britain's current level of 5.25 percent.
Britain, in other words, is a tale of two economic visions, as conversations with different business executives clearly show.
Take David Moody, whose family has been building oceangoing yachts for some 200 years. A year ago, he said, when economists were forecasting low growth -- or even recession -- for the British economy, his sales were down and he reduced the staff at his shipyard in Southampton, on England's southern coast, some 15 percent.
This year, though, interest rates initially fell sharply, and economic growth is now predicted to hit at least 2.6 percent next year. In this climate, his sales have doubled, to some $4.8 million, mainly to professional people from the greater London area, he said, many of them paying cash for sailboats costing from $110,000 to $610,000. "There seems to be an awful lot more confidence in the market," he said.
Andrew Cook has a different view, shaped not just by economics but also by geography. Mr. Cook is chairman of Europe's biggest producer of steel castings, William Cook Group, which is nearly 100 years old. While Mr. Moody's business provides a barometer of the service-driven prosperity of the South, Mr. Cook's hails from Sheffield, in the gritty area well north of London, where the shrinkage of manufacturing to only 20 percent of the economic output of post-industrial Britain has cast a pall.
Last year, as the benchmark interest rate began to tumble from a high of 7.5 percent, falling to 5 percent before rates began to rise again this month, manufacturers who had been watching order books shrink and work forces dwindle began to sense a recovery. Before that revival could take root, however, the Bank of England, moving to contain inflation, raised rates to 5.25 percent, strengthening the pound and stunning manufacturers. And that sharpened the fundamental quandary that Britain's regional imbalances present to economic planners.
"A lot of policy making is done by people who seem to regard London as the barometer of the U.K. economy as a whole," Mr. Cook said. "But London is not representative of the U.K. economy -- less so now than ever before."
That view is shared by John Edmunds, general manager of Ingersoll Dresser Pumps in Gateshead in the Northeast, which is heavily dependent on the oil industry. "When interest rates go up and the pound goes up, we are not competitive," he said. "And this is a very competitive business. We are all scratching around to get this work. If rates go up and the pound strengthens, we lose big orders."
The rate increase was largely ascribed to factors like runaway house prices in the wealthy Southeast, where the cost of a home has soared 20 percent in some areas in the last year. That threatened to push inflation, now at 2.2 percent, beyond the bank's target of 2.5 percent. And the fiscal discipline that prompted the increase reflected Britain's deep-rooted -- and historically vindicated -- phobia that any boom sooner or later leads to a bust.
But its impact outside the South was seen by people like Mr. Cook and Mr. Edmunds as damaging a nascent recovery. For one thing, it made borrowing more expensive. It contributed to the factors that have kept the pound strong against the euro. And that, in turn, perpetuated the basic enigma facing British manufacturers: a strong pound makes exports more expensive for foreign buyers, while cheap imports erode the domestic market.
"Our domestic market has been destroyed, and our export market, which we depend on, will suffer," Mr. Cook said. "There is no fat left on the bone of British industry."
The economic logic of higher interest rates, though, is unavoidable. "The South accounts for well over 60 percent of G.D.P.," said Ian Stewart, an economist with Merrill Lynch & Company. "It's inevitable that monetary policy is going to be based on that part of the country, just as in Euroland it's dictated by conditions in Germany, France and Italy."
In other words, growth in what Mr. Cook terms the hothouse around London is, to some extent, being paid for in higher interest rates by people who cannot afford them in the struggling Northeast.
Britain is not the only European country with sharp regional differences. Unemployment in eastern Germany is twice that in western Germany. Southern Italy lags far behind the North. Even within Britain's regions, there are sharp differences. "The picture is a bit more complex than the headlines make out," Mr. Stewart, the economist, said. "Within supposedly affluent areas, there are pockets of deprivation and poverty. And London is a good example of that."
Nor do the rosy unemployment figures tell the full story. As in the United States after the industrial layoffs of the 1980's and wider downsizings of the early 1990's, many Britons have been forced to redefine the notion of work in an era of global competition. The crumbling of the welfare state and the collapse of labor union power have gnawed at traditional safety nets, like job security.
Britain, said Steve Fleetwood, a lecturer at Lancaster University School of Management, "is not so much solving the problem of unemployment as transforming it into a different one: the problem of poor-quality employment."
The drive for greater labor flexibility, he said, had confronted many workers with a "Hobson's choice: workers can either have an insecure, stressful, badly paid job, or no job at all."
Yet even by the broadest definition of a North-South divide, the shadings are far grayer than history's memories of hunger marchers from the northeastern town of Jarrow trudging south to protest their plight in London in the 1930's.
Because of government incentives, foreign investment in Britain, totaling a cumulative $320 billion, has revitalized depressed industries and regions. Nissan's main British car plant, for instance, is in the Northeast, near the political home base of Prime Minister Tony Blair. Before it withdrew last year, citing the world semiconductor glut, Siemens of Germany had a major plant in Tyneside, almost at the gates of Jarrow itself.
Yet as the Siemens example showed, foreign investment has two very sharp edges. "We have had a lot of companies coming into the Northeast, but when anything goes wrong in their home market, they pull out and everything goes down the tubes," said Mr. Edmunds of Ingersoll Dresser Pumps.
And other, sharp distinctions remain. Driven by a booming services industry, retail prices in London have by some estimates been rising a full percentage point faster than the 1.4 percent national average. House prices in London -- a particularly emotive yardstick for Britons -- have far outstripped those in the rest of the country. Even before this year's increases, one research organization found that Londoners typically spent $11,300 a year on housing, 55 percent more than the countrywide average.
The unemployment numbers reflect the trend, too. The national average is just 5.9 percent. In greater London, it is only 4.9 percent, and the Southeast over all is even lower at 3.8 percent. In the far North, by contrast, unemployment is 7.1 percent.
That disparity, in turn, plays out in broader population figures. The population of London grew 4.3 percent the last seven years, according to the Office of National Statistics, while that of the Northeast stood still.
There may be finger-snapping growth in the Southeast, but in the Northeast, Mr. Edmunds said, "I don't see a boom."

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled Barth Healey

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
BRITAIN: THE TORIES' PROGRAM -- The Conservative leader, William Hague, opened his party's annual convention with a 60-point proposal for a "common-sense revolution" that would reduce taxes, end benefits to welfare recipients who turn down work and increase parents' control of schools. He accused Prime Minister Tony Blair, whose Labor Party runs far ahead of the Tories in polls, of "breathtaking hypocrisy." Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
GERMANY: SUPPORT FOR SAME-SEX MARRIAGES -- The Green Party, coalition partner in Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's center-left Government, is pressing ahead with a bill to recognize same-sex marriages. "The legal recognition of same-sex cohabitation will become a central focus of the parliamentary Greens' work," the party said. Victor Homola (NYT) 

UKRAINE: BOMB MAY WIN SYMPATHY VOTES -- A far-left candidate in the presidential race who was slightly wounded in a grenade attack on Saturday may now attract broader support. The candidate, Natalia Vitrenko, 47, is running neck-and-neck with President Leonid Kuchma. The vote is set for Oct. 31. (Reuters)
 
BELARUS: PUBLICATIONS CLOSED -- Nine publications, including several expressing opposition to President Aleksandr Lukashenko, were banned. Viktor Guretsky, director of media licensing, said the publications had opened offices without authorization. (Agence France-Presse)
 
ITALY, TURKEY: KURD GRANTED ASYLUM -- A court in Rome granted the Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan political asylum. But Mr. Ocalan, who made the request in November, is now in a Turkish prison appealing a death sentence on terrorism charges. Bowing to intense pressure from Turkey and the United States, Italy asked Mr. Ocalan to leave last January, and the Turkish police later captured him in Nairobi. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)
 
IRELAND: WEAPONS FOUND -- The Irish police made what they called a "very significant" discovery of explosives, guns, ammunition and a rocket launcher buried in a field near Dublin. The discovery came during a security operation aimed at forestalling violence by dissident republican guerrillas opposed to the Northern Ireland peace agreement. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
ASIA
 
PHILIPPINES: MUSLIMS QUIT PEACE TALKS -- Muslim separatist guerrillas have pulled out of peace talks with the Government planned for later this month, accusing the army of attacking rebel camps. The talks, to end the 21-year war for a separate Muslim state in Mindanao, were to open on Oct. 25. (Agence France-Presse)
 
MALAYSIA: EX-MINISTER OUT OF HOSPITAL -- The former Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim was moved from the hospital where he spent three weeks for tests for arsenic poisoning back to Sungai Buloh prison, where he is serving a six-year term for corruption. Mr. Anwar, who is also standing trial on a sodomy charge, was taken to the hospital on Sept. 10 after saying he had been poisoned. His assertion, dismissed by the Government as a political ploy, set off the biggest anti-Government protests in nearly a year. The arsenic test results were ambiguous, Mr. Anwar's lawyer said. (Reuters)
 
AFGHANISTAN: REFUGEE CRISIS -- A human disaster threatens tens of thousands of Afghan refugees who have fled the civil war, a United Nations spokeswoman said in Islamabad, Pakistan. An estimated 80,000 to 85,000 refugees are living in mosques and schools or in the open in the opposition-held Panjshir valley, said the spokeswoman, Stephanie Bunker. About 200,000 villagers fled the fertile Shamali Plains, north of Kabul, after the Islamic Taliban militia began an offensive on July 28. (Agence France-Presse)
 
KASHMIR: TEAR GAS AT DEMONSTRATION -- Pakistani authorities fired tear gas to disperse hundreds of demonstrators demanding independence from India who were planning to march from Pakistan-held Kashmir into the Indian-held portion. The demonstrators, several of whom were injured, are with the Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front. India termed the planned march an "act of aggression" and warned it would open fire on any Kashmiris crossing the border. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)
 
INDIA: PREMIER'S PLANS -- Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee, who is likely to serve again once the votes are counted Thursday in India's parliamentary elections, said in an interview with The Indian Express that his Government would restart talks with Pakistan, push through new measures to further integrate the Indian economy into the global marketplace and increase military spending. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)
 
MALAYSIA: NEWSMAN TO BE FREED -- A Canadian journalist, Murray Hiebert, is to be released next week after serving one month in jail for contempt of court, said a prison official, Jamil Razif. The correspondent for the Far Eastern Economic Review was found guilty for writing an article on a suit filed by the wife of an Appeals Court judge against the International School of Kuala Lumpur for dropping her son from the debating team. (Agence France-Presse)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
COLOMBIA: KIDNAPPING BLOCKED -- Government troops thwarted a mass kidnapping by the People's Liberation Army, a small left-wing guerrilla group. The insurgents, who recently abducted a Roman Catholic bishop and a popular folk singer, seized at least 40 people, many of them college students, at a roadblock outside Ocana, in northern Colombia. But as the estimated 20 rebels were moving their captives to a mountain stronghold, they encountered an army unit, which killed at least one of the guerrillas and freed the prisoners. Larry Rohter (NYT)
 
MEXICO: AN OPPOSITION VICTORY -- The candidate of Mexico's main leftist opposition party was elected mayor of Acapulco, the resort city in the Pacific coast state of Guerrero. The city, which has 700,000 residents, has always been governed by President Ernesto Zedillo's party, known as the PRI. In other local elections across Guerrero, however, the PRI won most of the races for mayor and for seats in the state legislature.
MEXICO CITY: FINAL TOLL IN QUAKE -- Officials put the final death toll from the earthquake that rattled Mexico on Sept. 30 at 27, including 25 people in the state of Oaxaca, site of the epicenter. The quake, which had a magnitude of 7.4, destroyed 23,000 homes in Oaxaca, Governor Jose Murat said. Julia Preston (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
SOUTH AFRICA: CHARGES FROM APARTHEID ERA -- Dr. Wouter Basson, the head of chemical warfare under the former apartheid-era Government, appeared in court to face 67 criminal charges, from drug-dealing to fraud to conspiracy to murder. Dr. Basson is accused of injecting poison into prisoners and using Government laboratories to make the drug Ecstasy. The trial is expected to last two years. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAQ: HIGHER OIL SALES -- The Security Council will allow Iraq to exceed the $5.2 billion six-month ceiling on oil sales under the program that permits the Government to import food, medicines and other goods for civilians. Iraq is expected to earn at least $7 billion during the six-month period, ending in November, largely because of higher oil prices, and will be permitted to count the surplus as compensation for earlier shortfalls. Barbara Crossette (NYT)
 
IRAQ: POLIO VACCINES -- The World Health Organization, alarmed at a polio outbreak in Iraq, began a national immunization program there with Unicef. The organizations are to vaccinate 3.5 million children under the age of 5, including the children of nomadic families who may be carrying the disease across borders to nations where polio is no longer endemic. Barbara Crossette (NYT)
 
SAUDI ARABIA: NEW ROLE FOR WOMEN -- As many as 20 Saudi women have attended a session of the Government's consultative council for the first time, the London Arabic newspaper Al Hayat reported. The admission of women, who followed the proceedings from a balcony, came on Sunday, one day after the head of the Shura Council, Mohammed bin Jubair, said, "Society and the Shura Council must benefit from the qualifications and experience of women." (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Heller Financial in a Deal with CIT Group

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 4

 BODY:
The commercial financing company Heller Financial Inc. said today that it would sell its commercial services unit to CIT Group Inc. for $560 million, exiting a 64-year-old line of business the company now feels it is not large enough to successfully compete in.
The unit includes the domestic factoring business, which lends money to textile and apparel manufacturers, taking over the companies' accounts receivable. Heller started in the factoring business in 1935. 
 "Heller has a long, rich history in the U.S. factoring business, but we believe that long-term success in this business increasingly requires substantial economies of scale, which commercial services will not be able to achieve through internal growth," Heller's chairman and chief executive, Richard Almeida, said in a statement.
The unit also includes asset-based revolving credit facilities and accounts receivable management services.
The unit had net assets of $435 million on Aug. 31, reflecting $953 million of factored accounts receivable and $518 million of credit balances due factoring clients.
The unit employs about 375 people, primarily in New York and Glendale, Calif.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
In Describing Health Care Plans, Less is More

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
What is the difference between a policy that promises to cover 100 percent of Americans for medical costs and a policy that covers 95 percent of them? About 1,285 pages.
President Clinton took about 1,300 pages in 1994 to lay out his plan for insuring ever American. Bill Bradley took about 15 pages last week to describe a plan to increase the percentage of Americans with medical insurance to 95 percent. 
 O.K., I'm comparing apples and oranges. Mr. Clinton's plan covered every legislative tidbit. Mr. Bradley issued only an outline. Yet the point remains valid. Mr. Clinton's team never made its fiendishly complicated rewrite of a trillion-dollar industry decipherable to Congress or anyone else despite nearly a year of intense lobbying.
Mr. Bradley's plan, by contrast, can be boiled down to one simple sentence. He invites uninsured Americans to buy coverage -- with subsidies for families earning less than about $50,000 a year -- through the Federal program that currently covers members of Congress and other Federal employees.
Mr. Bradley achieves simplicity by forsaking 100 percent coverage. He says his system, by opening up Congress's plan to everyone else, will persuade all but 5 percent of the population to buy coverage voluntarily. The estimate may be unrealistically low, but it is not daffy. The Clinton staff estimated that it could raise coverage from about 85 percent of the population to the low 90's with tax credits and other carrots.
But in the giddy first months of his Administration, Mr. Clinton refused to settle for anything short of universal coverage. His experts told him that persuading the last remnants of the population to join health plans would require huge subsidies. So Mr. Clinton turned instead to mandates -- everyone would be required to buy coverage. That required many pages of rules. With mandates would come opposition, from small business, large business, the self-employed. In anticipation, the Clinton plan built in huge subsidies for Detroit auto makers and others. Add more pages. Then the plan imposed elaborate rules to prevent waste and abuse of the subsidies. That took more pages still.
Next, Mr. Clinton proposed to redesign every corner of the health care industry, from the number of doctors that hospitals would train each year to the tiniest detail of the insurance policy everyone in American would be required to buy. Add dozens more pages of complex regulations.
Mr. Bradley's plan skipped much of this mess by making a second simplifying decision. Instead of redesigning health care, he piggybacked coverage of the uninsured onto an existing health-insurance system, the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program, warts and all. There are warts. The Federal program provides too little incentive for enrollees to choose inexpensive plans and imposes unintended penalties on plans that do a good job catering to the sickest, most-expensive-to-treat patients.
Yet the Federal program works reasonably well, and that is good enough for Mr. Bradley. Besides, there is a clever incentive system built into his plan. By tying the uninsured to Congress's own plan, Mr. Bradley insures that the uninsured will be treated well indeed.
Will Mr. Bradley's plan cut the rising rolls of the uninsured? The issue took on poignancy this week as the Government released data showing that the percentage of the population without coverage rose slightly last year despite a booming economy. Mr. Bradley's subsidies, which he estimates will cost up to $65 billion a year but which some experts fear could reach several times that amount, might be too small to achieve voluntary compliance.
But if the subsidies are raised too high, they could trigger a destructive reaction. Small employers tired of administering an expensive, complicated fringe benefit might decide to drop coverage entirely and direct their workers to the subsidized Federal program. The threat is that many of the workers who lose coverage at work, especially those whose incomes make them ineligible for Mr. Bradley's subsidies, would choose to remain uninsured. If so, Mr. Bradley's program could wind up doing more harm than good.
Mr. Bradley has responses for these problems. His subsidies would go to low-income workers even if they continued to get coverage through an employer. That way the Bradley programs would not encourage workers to switch to the Federal program. And, by limiting subsidies to low-income families, he would discourage employers from abandoning coverage for everyone else.
Whatever the outcome of the Bradley approach, whether coverage rises to 95 percent or something less, Congress could then take a hard look at those who are left out and design a fix tailored specifically to their plight. This strategy would not achieve a grand leap to 100 percent coverage, but neither would it run up thousands of pages of rules for Congress to choke on.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Shares Show Wide Gains As Interest Rate Fears Ease

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices rose broadly yesterday on the apparent conviction that Federal Reserve policy makers will not raise short-term interest rates at their meeting today.
Interest-sensitive stocks like banks and brokerage firms were at the forefront of the advance. But telecommunications companies gained on merger news, transportation shares did well and drug stocks advanced. 
 Led by American Express, Procter & Gamble and General Electric, the Dow Jones industrial average registered its biggest gain in a month, rising 128.23 points, or 1.3 percent, to 10,401.23. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index jumped 21.79, or 1.7 percent, to 1,304.60, led by Microsoft, Wal-Mart, Citicorp and Intel. A big gain in Nextel helped push the Nasdaq composite index up 59.12, or 2.2 percent, to 2,795.97. And the Russell 2000 index of small-company stocks gained 3.08, or 0.7 percent, to 426.61.
Trading volume, which has been light on Mondays the last few months, was a bit heavier yesterday.
More than 803 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange. On the Nasdaq stock market, nearly 915 million shares changed hands.
Despite the improvement, traders and analysts said the market still seemed fragile. Yesterday's gains, and a lot more, could be lost if the Fed chooses to raise rates, they said.
"I am very surprised at the rally," said Ned Collins, head trader at Daiwa Securities America. "But I am not totally convinced the market has worked through all its problems. Something in the back of my mind says this is not the turn."
The stock market has had its eye on today's Fed meeting for weeks, and the fear that members of the Federal Open Market Committee will vote to raise rates has helped to drive market averages down from the record highs set in the summer.
Even if the Fed decides not to raise rates at the meeting, those fears are likely to linger, analysts said.
"I don't think there is much conviction in the buying that went on" in the session, said Philip S. Dow, a managing director in equity research at Dain Rauscher Wessels in Minneapolis.
"At best, this is probably a trading rally. We will have to get through this quarter and the Y2K worries before the market will be set to move higher again."
Long-term interest rates moved lower yesterday, helped by a drop in oil prices.
The decline in rates touched off buying in financial stocks, which had been punished for some months.
American Express, a Dow component, gained 6 3/16, to 137 9/16. Citigroup rose 1 7/16, to 44 11/16. Morgan Stanley Dean Witter jumped 5 1/8, to 93 15/16. And Merrill Lynch rose 2 15/16, to 68 13/16.
BellSouth's cash-and-stock bid for Sprint spurred a rally in telecommunications shares. Sprint gained 3 7/8, to 60 7/8. MCI Worldcom, another suitor for Sprint, gained 1 1/8, to 71 5/8. BellSouth's shares fell 2 11/16, to 42 11/16. (After the market closed yesterday, people close to the negotiations said MCI would acquire Sprint in a stock swap vauled at $108 billion.)
Nextel jumped 5 1/8, to 75 3/8. Voicestream Wireless rose 3 5/8, to 62 11/16, and Qwest Communications rose 2 13/16, to 32 11/16.
Transportation stocks were helped by a decline in oil prices.
AMR, the parent of American Airlines, rose 5 3/8, to 59 1/4. Delta Air Lines gained 3 1/16, to 50 5/8. And UAL, the parent of United Airlines, gained 2 7/8, to 67 1/8.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Rise
 By Bloomberg News
 Bond prices rose yesterday as investors bet that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates when its policy makers meet today.
"Nobody feels the Fed will actually pull the trigger," and that is helping the market, said Deborah Cunningham, who manages about $68 billion in taxable money-market funds at Federated Investors in Pittsburgh.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond gained 19/32, to 100 18/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.08 percent from 6.13 percent on Friday.
Investors spent the bulk of the day preparing for today's Fed meeting. The central bank already lifted its target for overnight bank lending, the Federal funds rate, in June and August to cool growth and head off inflation. The two increases raised the rate to 5.25 percent.

HEADLINE: Executives Seeking Caps On Donations Stand Strong

BYLINE: By DON VAN NATTA Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Leaders of a group of business executives who have endorsed a ban on unlimited campaign contributions announced today that their ranks had doubled to 209 members since the committee was chastised last summer by Senator Mitch McConnell, the Senate's most outspoken critic of overhauling the campaign finance system.
Leaders of the organization, the Committee for Economic Development, said they had benefited from publicity about Mr. McConnell's letter-writing campaign that urged more than 20 members to resign from the committee. In the letters mailed in late July, Mr. McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, accused the committee of trying to "eviscerate private sector participation in politics." 
 But the group's president said today that the attacks by Mr. McConnell, who heads the National Republican Senatorial Committee, the party's major fund-raising group for Senate candidates, had backfired; not one executive has taken the senator's advice. Instead, Mr. McConnell's tactics touched off a surge in interest among chief executives, civic leaders and college presidents, Charles Kolb, the president of the Committee for Economic Development, said today.
"He has been a tremendous help to us," Mr. Kolb said. "This is the greatest evidence yet that many business leaders want to reform our system of financing elections."
Robert Steurer, Mr. McConnell's spokesman, did not return a phone call seeking comment today. Stewart Roy, a spokesman for the National Republican Senatorial Committee, declined to comment.
The economic committee's announcement of its membership spurt comes at an opportune moment for advocates of an overhaul of the nation's campaign finance laws. The Senate is expected this month to debate a bill that would ban soft money, the unlimited donations that corporations, unions and wealthy individuals give to political parties.
On Sept. 15, the House passed a comprehensive campaign finance bill. The sponsors of a similar bill in the Senate, John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, have said they will rewrite their bill to focus solely on a ban on soft money.
The economic committee strongly urges Congress to ban such unlimited contributions, but it also endorses raising the limit on contributions to individual candidates to $3,000 from the current $1,000. The committee also calls for partial public financing for Congressional elections and voluntary spending limits.
Although the 209 executives work for some of America's leading corporations, they speak only for themselves and not on behalf of their employers. But Mr. Kolb said they have discovered that more executives are willing to speak out because they have become disgusted by the parties' insatiable appetites for large corporate contributions.
"They're tired of being hit up for ever-increasing amounts of cash," Mr. Kolb said, "and they know the system is exacting a heavy toll on our democracy."
The endorsers of the economic committee's plan include executives at Goldman Sachs, Salomon Smith Barney, Prudential, State Farm, H&R Block, Motorola, Sara Lee, John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance, Hasbro and Chubb. Endorsers of the measures also include the retired chairmen or chief executives of Allied Signal, BankAmerica, GTE, International Paper, Union Pacific and General Foods, among others.

HEADLINE: With Sport Utility Vehicles More Popular, Overall Automobile Fuel Economy Continues to Fall

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 4

 BODY:
The average fuel economy of new vehicles fell to 23.8 miles per gallon in the 1999 model year, the lowest level since 1980, as Americans continued to shift from cars to less fuel-efficient light trucks, particularly sport utility vehicles, the Environmental Protection Agency has concluded in a new report.
The study, the agency's first on fuel-economy trends in three years, found that while average fuel economy peaked at 25.9 miles per gallon in the 1987 and 1988 model years and has been falling since then, the decline has accelerated. All of the fuel economy gains from technological improvements over the last dozen years have been more than offset by a shift toward heavier, more powerful automobiles, the report said. 
 Some of the information in the report has been available separately in statistical tables from the Transportation Department, which actually administers the Federal regulations that set minimum fuel-economy standards for new cars and light trucks. But this study was the first to report the average for the 1999 model year, which fell six-tenths of a mile per gallon from the 1998 model year, the steepest decline since record keeping began in 1975.
The report was posted on the agency's Internet site at the end of last week with no announcement. Agency officials in Washington said today that they had meant to release the report later this week with an announcement and expressed surprise that the document had already been posted by the agency's automotive pollution division, which wrote it.
Gloria Bergquist, a spokeswoman for the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers in Washington, said that when a gallon of gasoline costs less than a gallon of bottled water or a cup of Starbucks coffee there is little demand for fuel efficiency.
The timing of the report's release, less than three weeks after the Senate held its first vote on fuel-economy issues in nine years, drew criticism from environmentalists. On Sept. 15, the Senate voted 55 to 40 against allowing the Transportation Department to review its fuel-economy regulations.
"It's unfortunate the Administration didn't provide this information to senators until after they'd had a chance to vote," said Daniel Becker, the energy policy director at the Sierra Club.
David Cohen, an E.P.A. spokesman, said the timing was coincidental. "The report was put out as soon as we had the data reviewed," Mr. Cohen said.
Vice President Al Gore was an outspoken supporter of more stringent fuel-economy rules in 1990, when he was in the Senate. But when President Bush warned in the 1992 Presidential campaign that tighter rules might destroy auto industry jobs in Ohio and Michigan, Mr. Gore and Bill Clinton shifted their position, calling instead for Federal subsidies for the auto industry to design more efficient cars.
Mr. Gore did not take a position during last month's debate in the Senate. His rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, former Senator Bill Bradley, who has been courting environmentalists, did endorse tighter fuel-economy rules before the Senate vote.
Every year since Republicans took control of Congress in 1995, they have added riders to the Transportation Department's budget barring any spending to investigate fuel-economy issues. The E.P.A. is not covered by this ban.
The Transportation Department's rules require that each auto maker sell cars with an average fuel economy of at least 27.5 miles per gallon and light trucks with an average fuel economy of at least 20.7 miles per gallon. Sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and minivans are all counted as light trucks.
"The increasing market share of light-duty trucks, which have lower average fuel economy than cars, is the primary reason for the decline in fuel economy of the overall new light vehicle fleet," the E.P.A. report said.
The published figures indicated that auto makers were having trouble complying with fuel-economy rules for light trucks. The average fuel-economy for all light trucks sold in the United States in the 1999 model year was 20.3 miles per gallon.
Manufacturers are liable for fines of $5.50 per automobile sold times the number of tenths of a mile per gallon they fall short of the standard. With the exception of Land Rover, auto makers have avoided paying fines until now because they exceeded the minimum standard in previous years and have carried forward fuel-economy credits as a result. But auto makers are running low on credits.

MCI Worldcom to Acquire Sprint in a $108 Billion Deal
MCI Worldcom will acquire Sprint in a stock swap valued at $108 billion, people close to the talks said.
Sprint had been discussing a merger with MCI Worldcom for two weeks but received a $100 billion unsolicited offer on Saturday from BellSouth, the regional Bell company based in Atlanta. BellSouth even raised its offer, too, but the extra money was not enough to sway Sprint's board. Page A1. 

The bidding for Sprint has left Europe's biggest telephone company, Deutsche Telekom, grasping for a trans-Atlantic partner. C12.
 
The ardor for Sprint underscored the importance of building powerful brand names in the competitive global telecommunications industry. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C14.
 
McCaw Considers Satellite Stake
Craig O. McCaw, the cellular telephone pioneer, is considering taking a large stake in a communications satellite company, possibly Iridium, the troubled $5 billion venture that has filed for bankruptcy, according to people close to the talks. Such a move could also be valuable in setting the stage for Teledesic, an "Internet in the Sky" system that Mr. McCaw is helping to develop. C2.
 
Monsanto Rejects Infertile Crops
Seeking to remove itself from one of the most inflamed debates in biotechnology, Monsanto said it would make no effort to market seeds that produce infertile crop plants. A1.
 
Humana Is Sued Over Incentives
Humana was accused in a Federal lawsuit of misleading health plan members by failing to disclose financial incentives to doctors and case reviewers intended to keep down costs by limiting or denying care. C7.
 
Stocks Rise Ahead of Fed Meeting
Stock prices rose broadly on the apparent conviction that Federal Reserve policy makers will not raise short-term interest rates at their meeting today. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 128.23 points, to 10,401.23. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index jumped 21.79 points, to 1,304.60, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 59.12 points, to 2,795.97. C16.
 
Ford Sales Push Model Year to High
Ford said it sold 4.1 million vehicles in the 1999 model year, up 4.9 percent, beating a record set in 1978. For the industry as a whole, sales totaled 16.7 million vehicles, topping the record of 15.8 million set in 1986. C12.
 
Travelocity to Buy Smaller Rival
Travelocity, the on-line travel service, said that it would acquire a smaller rival, Preview Travel, in a deal that will vault it past Microsoft's Expedia to be the largest travel site on the Web. Travelocity is part of the Sabre Group, the reservation system that is controlled by AMR, the parent of American Airlines. Shares of Preview rose $6.6875, to $24.3125, while AMR gained $5.375, to $59.25. C7.
 
Schwab to Extend Trading Hours
Charles Schwab, the on-line brokerage firm, is planning to join the organizations offering after-hours trading. C16.
 
A New Generation of Processors
Computer processors that can reliably handle millions of transactions a second are being introduced this week in California. C9.
 
Verdict Goes Against State Farm
An Illinois jury ruled that State Farm, the nation's largest auto insurer, had breached its contract with policyholders by requiring body shops to use lower-priced generic parts for crash repairs rather than parts made by auto manufacturers. Under the verdict, State Farm must pay $456 million in compensation. A16.

HEADLINE: Radio City, With Face Lift, Reopens

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
After a face lift that cost $70 million -- double the original estimates -- and left the stage dark for seven months, Radio City Music Hall reopened last night in a blaze of lights and celebrity hoopla befitting one of New York City's more enduring show-business icons.
The Cablevision Systems Corporation, which has operated the 67-year-old Music Hall since 1997 and spent $30 million just to rewire the building, was determined to stage a reopening celebration in keeping with the hall's Art Deco glamour. Appearing on the huge stage were not only the 36 Rockettes, but also Billy Crystal, Tony Bennett, Liza Minnelli, Sting, Ann-Margret, Tom Brokaw and Christian Slater, who played Tiny Tim at the hall in a Christmas show when he was 12. 
 "I have a lot of memories of this gracious lady of a grand old theater," said Mr. Crystal, raising a roar of laughter when he appeared on stage in a tuxedo from the waist up -- and Rockette pantyhose from the waist down. There were actually wolf whistles from the crowd
Arriving celebrity ticketholders ran the media gantlet on a blocklong red carpet, sheltered by canvas from torrents of rain. They included Mr. Bennett, who judged that "the new hall is magnificent"; Don King, who pronounced the music hall "the perfect edifice to make an exquisite boxing match," and Donald J. Trump, who allowed that his parents "took me to see the Rockettes when I was young, which started my love affair with beautiful women."
One of the best-received moments of the show came at 9:30 P.M., when James L. Dolan, Cablevision's president and chief executive, announced that "it's the bottom of the seventh and the Mets are up five-nothing," satisfying the desperate curiosity of National League pennant-race watchers.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani did not make an appearance, and it was just as well.
The evening's host, the actor Barry Bostwick, who plays the mayor on the television show "Spin City," made the first of many references to Mayor Giuliani's opposition to the new show at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, terming the Rockettes "beautiful, not that the Mayor is any judge of art." He was applauded.
For local merchants, the Music Hall reopening was also an occasion for unrestrained joy. "When those marquee lights went on, I got a huge smile on my face," said David Liederman, owner of Chez Louis, a restaurant directly across the street on West 50th Street and the Avenue of the Americas. "It's been a long seven months, when Rockefeller Center looked like a deserted area. Now there will be more customers, and I think this reopening will be the catalyst to reinvent Rockefeller Center."
Indeed, the Music Hall's revival was part of a master plan by Jerry I. Speyer, the manager and part owner of Rockefeller Center, to resuscitate what he has called "the world's most famous address." He expects Radio City to drive the center's nighttime activities in the future.
Cablevision has estimated that the Music Hall will attract two million visitors a year and contribute more than $300 million to the city's economy.
A black-tie audience of 5,400 last night saw 6.5 miles of new red, blue and gold neon installed in the hall's legendary blocklong marquee, and applauded the sound of the auditorium's Mighty Wurlitzer pipe organ with its 4,178 restored pipes.
Proceeds from ticket sales for the 2-hour-and-15-minute show, which will be televised as a prime-time NBC special in early December, went to the Lustgarten Pancreatic Cancer Research Foundation in honor of Marc A. Lustgarten, a Madison Square Garden executive who recently died of the disease.
The doubling in restoration costs demonstrated not only the perils of sophisticated restoration work in Manhattan, but also Cablevision's determination to have the new hall up and running in time for its venerable "Radio City Christmas Spectacular."
That will open on Nov. 4, the first event in the new hall for which tickets are still available.
The restoration, the most ambitious since the hall opened in 1932 as a vaudeville and movie house, employed 2,000 workers. They burnished ceilings with 720,000 sheets of gold and aluminum leaf, lowered the old muddy red two-ton stage curtain and installed a new 112-foot-wide shimmery golden silk replacement. They also put in 5,901 new salmon-pink plush seats.
The hall's furniture, wall fabric, carpeting, lighting fixtures and appointments have been cleaned, repaired or remade. And the three-story-tall mural "The Fountain of Youth," by Ezra Winter, which looms above the grand staircase, was cleaned of decades of grime, varnish and polyurethane.
The restoration was intended to preserve and modernize the hall, which has been rewired for high-definition television. And to enable Cablevision to present events and concerts broadcast "live from Radio City," 32 camera positions have been established.
The renovation is part of an ambitious plan of Cablevision, which in addition to leasing the Music Hall owns the 18,000-seat Madison Square Garden and its 5,600-seat theater, to consolidate the booking of its entertainment events.
In December 1997, Cablevision leased Radio City Music Hall from its owner, Tishman Speyer Properties, for 25 years, and bought the rights to both the Rockettes and the Christmas pageant from the Mitsubishi Estate Company. Cablevision also operates cable channels, produces television shows and provides cable service to 3.4 million customers.
Despite the $70 million price tag, the Music Hall design was somewhat scaled down. Plans for a new nightclub, computer-controlled lighting and virtual-reality hall tours were dropped because of worries about the reaction of the Landmarks Preservation Commission. The exterior of the Music Hall and its public interior spaces, as well as some furnishings, were designated New York City landmarks in 1979.
And in the end, it was Mr. Slater who saluted the staying power of the hall, saying that it "survived two wars and Run-DMC, a real threat to its existence."
