HEADLINE: Memphis Blacks Find Poverty's Grip Strong

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: MEMPHIS

 BODY:
On the face of it, the 1990's have been good to George Jones. A 58-year-old black man in a city with a history of chronic poverty and acute racial tensions, Mr. Jones opened his first McDonald's restaurant here in the 1980's with a loan from a Chicago bank after Memphis banks had turned him down. He now owns six McDonald's restaurants and sits on the board of a Memphis bank.
"But not a single one of those openings has been easy," Mr. Jones said over coffee at his first store, on the corner of a fading shopping center in the largely black south Memphis neighborhood of Southgate. "I can tell as far as black businesses go, they have not done well. A few like me have been able to slip through the cracks, but very few." 
 By all accounts, the nation has been enjoying an extraordinarily healthy economy. With nearly nine years of unimpeded growth, with jobs abundant, poverty declining, interest rates down and the Federal budget back in the black, almost everyone has been enriched. Americans are earning more than ever, an average of $460 a week or nearly $24,000 a year for all nonsupervisory workers.
But a look at any American community, in this case the old cotton-trading port of Memphis, shows how selective prosperity can be in blessing some people more than others. Blacks have benefited much less than other groups, according to the latest census data, and even black entrepreneurs like Mr. Jones say they still must struggle.
The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research organization in Washington, has reported that by the end of this year the after-tax income of the richest 1 percent of the population will have climbed 115 percent since 1977 -- more than doubling. But it will have risen only 8 percent for middle-income households and declined 9 percent for the poorest one-fifth of the population.
The issue of income disparity is finding its way into the national political debate. But it is also playing out at the local level, nowhere more so than Memphis, a city of 600,000 people, 55 percent of whom are black and drawn mostly from the destitute rural communities of the Mississippi Delta west and south of the city.
In nonpartisan elections on Oct. 7, with 15 men and women running for mayor, poverty and race are the leitmotifs in the conflicts between the two leading candidates over how the city exploits its prosperity. Challengers to Mayor Willie Herenton question whether he has done enough to help lift up the people at the bottom of the income ladder and open opportunities for those like Mr. Jones, who strive for a chance to build a business.
While defending his focus on rebuilding the city's core, Mr. Herenton, who is black, acknowledges "a major weakness" in cultural and financial institutions in the city, which remain impervious to many black Memphians.
"We have a nagging problem of poverty, especially in the African-American population," Mr. Herenton said. "Memphis has not experienced a major breakthrough for African-Americans in terms of accumulating wealth."
While prosperity has expanded the black middle class, he said, "African-Americans are absent from any influence at the top tier" of economic leadership. "It's not an easy city to break the barriers of the past, getting capital, doing joint ventures, developing strategic alliances with successful majority companies," the Mayor said.
Compared with any earlier decade, these have been good times for Memphis. It bills itself as the capital of the mid-South, the home of Elvis Presley, Beale Street and the blues and Federal Express, which has made the city the world's biggest air cargo hub.
The city is within commuting distance of Tunica, Miss., a once-impoverished Delta town that has become a phenomenon of the decade of prosperity with the start of casino gambling there seven years ago. And cotton, though ailing from falling prices and excess supply, has rebounded from the assault of synthetic fibers. The National Cotton Institute here says 61 percent of Americans' clothes now contain cotton, compared with 40 percent a decade ago.
In general, these industries' good fortune has spilled across this city's economy. It has given the newly employed former welfare recipients time to build skills that can help them hold their jobs in harder times, and it discourages discrimination in hiring because employers have to bore deeper than ever into the ranks of the unemployed to find workers.
"These are really the best of times," said John E. Gnuschke, director of the Bureau of Business and Economic Research at the University of Memphis. "Everyone has moved up a notch," he said, "even the poorest." Income per person in Memphis, $25,905 in 1997, began exceeding the growth of the national average five years ago.
Higher incomes, Mr. Gnuschke said, have helped propel African-Americans out of the city's decrepit public housing projects. "The suburbanization of the black population didn't happen in the past," Mr. Gnuschke added, "and it's happening now. Differences in income levels kept people segregated, and that's changing."
Willie Joe Alexander, an African-American and the president of Local 1733 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, whose 4,000 members are mostly black, said: "I can see members of this union who were walking and are now driving cars. I can see members who were renters who are now buyers, who procrastinated about their kids' education who are now educating them."
Marc Jordan, president of the Memphis Area Chamber of Commerce, who is white, said leading businesses were doing a lot of "partnering, mentoring and getting people to participate in business ventures." He added, "I know of minority companies that are doing real well," like a moving and storage company and a new black bank.
"And if you look at starting wages," Mr. Jordan said, "they're moving up. People in warehouses are making $10 and $12 an hour. There are just ample opportunities for people who want to move up."
But such measures of progress are relative. Herman C. Ewing, president of the Memphis Urban League, said that incomes of African-Americans were about 62 percent of those of whites, compared with 60 percent a decade ago, before the start of the boom.
While Memphis's resurgent downtown throbs with the jackhammers of affluence, its aged, debris-infested public housing, occupied mostly by blacks, has not been touched. Businesses that followed African-Americans into outlying suburbs and sylvan subdivisions are heading for the malls in more affluent communities.
Whitehaven, for example, the south Memphis neighborhood that is home to both Mr. Herenton and his top challenger in the mayoral race, Joe Ford, an African-American who is chairman of the City Council, is a community of small ranch houses. It was 80 percent white two decades ago and is now 80 percent black.
With the shift in the population, Whitehaven has recently lost some major retailers, like Kinney Shoes, a Chrysler-Plymouth dealer, a Target store and a Red Lobster restaurant. And store vacancies have surged.
According to analyses by the economic research bureau at the University of Memphis, the city suffers deeper poverty and has less economic opportunity than most of the cities the business leaders consider their rivals: Atlanta; Dallas; Indianapolis; Nashville, Tenn.; Charlotte, N.C.; Birmingham, Ala., and Louisville, Ky.
When last measured four years ago, Memphis's poverty rate, 18.1 percent, far exceeded those in cities like Atlanta and Nashville, and Mr. Gnuschke sees little reason to think the gap has narrowed measurably since then. In the 1996-97 academic year, Memphis spent about 90 percent of the average of what was being spent on education by its rival cities.
Its unemployment rate, though low at just above 3 percent, still exceeds the rates of its rivals. A reason might be the challenges black businesses face here. Employment in black-owned businesses grew an average of 2.4 percent a year from 1982 to 1992, the latest years for which comparable figures are available. The average for the other cities was 8.4 percent.
To the extent that crime and economics are linked, prosperity in Memphis has been a mixed blessing. Two years ago, Mr. Gnuschke's studies show, 107.4 of every 100,000 women in Memphis had been raped here, more than double the rate for the other cities. Memphis's homicide rate then, 15.9 per 100,000 people, exceeded the rates of all its rivals except Birmingham.
The grim statistics weigh on the record of Mayor Herenton, a 6-foot, 6-inch former boxer and superintendent of schools. By a mere 142 votes eight years ago, he became the city's first black mayor in a race against a white incumbent that broke sharply along racial lines.
He promptly set about building rapport with the white business establishment while retaining his support among blacks. Running against a conservative white challenger four years ago, he won in a landslide, with 74 percent of the vote.
This time, Mr. Ford, 45, a funeral home director and scion of a political dynasty here, has seized upon the economic stagnation of the city's black neighborhoods, chastising the Mayor for leading a renaissance of the long-ailing downtown with tens of millions of dollars in tax breaks for the city's biggest developers, all white.
"Whitehaven, south Memphis, Raleigh, Frayser," Mr. Ford said of predominantly black communities. "We've got stores moving and houses deteriorating. We just left them out there dangling."
An African-American who does get a foot in goes only so far. "We've become better educated in the last 10 years," said Audrey McGhee, editor of The Tri-State Defender, the city's weekly black newspaper. "The most important thing we find out is that the ceiling isn't glass. It's concrete."
Olivia Dobbins, president and chief executive of the Black Business Association, says her phone rings constantly with blacks wanting to participate in the flourishing economy by starting businesses. "And they're crying, 'We can't get loans,' " she said.
Blacks stand on the sidelines of the city's economic development, added Fred L. Davis, a leading black insurance broker, because they own few of the businesses that can participate. The city-owned power company needs utility poles, pipes, cable and office furniture. "But it's hard to find a black distributor," Mr. Davis said.
Then, when blacks might spread their spending among black businesses, they head instead for the white suburban malls. Mr. Davis has two business cards -- "my white card and my colored card." The back of the white card is blank, but on the back of those he hands to blacks, he has printed:
"Did you know that 97 1/2 cents out of every dollar blacks spend leaves the community? Guess why we are poor and powerless."
Mr. Jones, the McDonald's owner, was the budget officer for the housing authority in Chicago and the owner of five apartment buildings there, all paid for, when he came across a Time magazine article about doctors and lawyers who were leaving their practices to open McDonald's restaurants.
"I decided to give it a shot," Mr. Jones said, "and I was accepted into the McDonald's program." Upon completing his training, he said, "I was told I could go anywhere, and Memphis was where I wanted to go."
The company had just built the Southgate store, at the corner of a shopping center, and Mr. Jones agreed to take it on. But he needed a loan to buy the franchise.
"Banks here did not want to give me a loan, even though I had solid financial statements," he said. "Fortunately, I had a cousin who was a bank president in Chicago, so I went there to get it."

LENGTH: 409 words

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
NBC Buys Rights to Televise the Triple Crown, Long Held by ABC

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
NBC Sports broke ABC's long grip on the Triple Crown thoroughbred races yesterday by buying their television rights for five years starting in 2001.
NBC bid $48 million, but it structured the contract with Triple Crown Productions to include an early upfront payment of nearly one-quarter of the total fee, which will make the deal worth $51.5 million. 
 ABC, which could relinquish to NBC its rights to carry the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness Stakes and the Belmont Stakes next year, offered $35 million, said Tom Meeker, president of Triple Crown Productions.
With the deal, NBC will have the elite bookends of televised horse racing -- the Triple Crown in the spring and the Breeders' Cup in the fall.
A major reason for leaving ABC -- besides the money -- was for the Triple Crown to end competition with National Basketball Association playoff games.
NBC always programmed early-round playoff games against the first two legs of the Triple Crown. Now, NBC will use its prime-time shows and the playoff games to promote the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness. The first two games of the N.B.A. finals, on Wednesday and Friday nights, will be employed to promote the Belmont Stakes.
"We saw NBC as the network of opportunity, through their association with the N.B.A., the Olympics and the Ryder Cup," Meeker said.
Dick Ebersol, the chairman of NBC Sports, said, "With the N.B.A. as a promotional platform, I'd expect ratings growth of 10, 15 or 20 percent for the Derby and the Preakness."
The loss of the races is a blow for ABC, which has carried the Kentucky Derby since 1975 and the others since 1987. Meeker said the network might have retained the package had Howard Katz, the president of ABC Sports, been in charge of the division before March. "Before Howard, things had changed at ABC that caused us to question its commitment to the Triple Crown," Meeker said.
Katz said: "I don't know if I could have changed the economics more than I did. We put together what was an aggressive bid, but we were blown away. I'm devastated to lose this. But I'd feel a lot worse if our bids were close."
The loss of the races will mean less work for the host Jim McKay, who recently signed a new contract with ABC. At NBC, the role McKay shared with Al Michaels will be assumed by Tom Hammond.
"Jim and I will think of some other assignments," Katz said. McKay's only other current work at ABC besides the races is at the British Open.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 12, 1999, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A sports article last Tuesday about NBC's purchase of television rights to the Triple Crown horse races misattributed information about a competing bid, from ABC. The source of that information was not Tom Meeker, the president of Triple Crown Productions, but another person involved in the deal, who declined to be identified publicly.

HEADLINE: HBO Plans a Drama Based on 'Stiffed'

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Home Box Office has acquired rights to the newly published Susan Faludi book, "Stiffed: The Betrayal of the American Man," and plans to turn it into a television drama next year.
The book, about what Ms. Faludi calls "the American masculinity crisis," was purchased for a "mid-six-figure" sum, people involved in the negotiations said. HBO executives said that the cable network hoped to turn the nonfiction book into an anthology of one or perhaps two films dramatizing the stories of some of the men depicted in the book. It was acquired for Robert Greenwald, a well-known television producer-director. 
 Ms. Faludi's 662-page treatise, some chapters of which have already been sold for two other adaptations, was featured on the Sept. 13 cover of Newsweek. A blend of reporting and cultural analysis, it focuses on a variety of men whose lives seem in crisis and have "lost their compass in the world," the author said.
The men range from unemployed workers at the naval shipyard in Long Beach, Calif., to students at the Citadel, the military school forced to admit its first woman in 1994, to gang members, to teen-age boys in the Spur Posse, the group accused of multiple incidents of sexual assault.
Mr. Greenwald, who produced and directed the six-hour NBC mini-series "A Woman of Independent Means," said, "The book has about 10 very powerful dramatic stories, and we're in the process of deciding which of the stories to do." He said he had been tracking the book for about three years and that HBO was the perfect home for it.
"They're not bound by any of the conventional rules," he said. "You can tell the story in whatever way the material demands."
Ron Bernstein, Ms. Faludi's agent at the Gersh Agency in Los Angeles, said that two sections of the book had been sold earlier. One, about male pornography stars, which appeared in the New Yorker in 1995, was sold to HBO to be turned into a television drama. But the project was shelved because of the release of the movie "Boogie Nights," which dealt with the world of pornography. Another portion of the book, about United States Marine recruiters, has been purchased by New Regency films, and a script is in development for two producers, Lisa Henson and Janet Yang.
By all accounts several film and television companies also expressed interest in acquiring the book. Ms. Faludi's last book was the 1991 best seller "Backlash: The Undeclared War Against American Women," which dealt with what she argued was the misogyny, half-truths and falsehoods marshaled against women.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1735 words

HEADLINE: CULINARY CRITIQUE;
Sibling Revelry: When More Isn't Merrier

BYLINE: By REGINA SCHRAMBLING 

 BODY:
THE first night I uncovered parkerhouse rolls in a bread basket, at Wild Blue, I thought they were a novel revival. At a time when strong and chewy sourdough is almost a cliche, why not bring back soft and buttery yeast rolls from the Betty Crocker heyday?
The next time I came across a parkerhouse roll, at Blackbird, I was even more intrigued. One more sighting, and it would be a trend.
It was the same reaction I had had to the crab cakes I tasted first at Park Avalon, then at Blue Water Grill, then at Ocean Grill. They all looked and tasted oddly similar: backfin crab meat judiciously jazzed up with scallions, fried with a crisp crust and set on streaks of some spicy variation on tartar sauce. 
 Eventually, I remembered that both the bread baskets and the crab cakes were the work of restaurant groups, the BE Group in the first instance and BR Guest in the second. Neither was a case of great chefs' thinking alike. And both were symptoms of a growing phenomenon in New York restaurants: a creeping but ineffable familiarity.
More and more, new restaurants actually look alike, with the sleek chill of a corporate board room: dark stained wood, recessed lighting, muted upholstery, bars with boxlike compartments for wine and spirits, and understated floral arrangements, if any. They sound alike, with a contented buzz of conversation blending into some form of elevator jazz on the sound system. Their staffs exude a "we are happy to serve you" affability. And their "Americanized Mediterranean" menus certainly read alike: house-cured salmon and heirloom tomato salad and wood-roasted striped bass and braised veal shank. They seem designed by committee, and in fact many were.
The sea change in restaurants is not about chefs but about restaurateurs -- developers, if you will. In 1989, the 15 most popular restaurants in the Zagat Survey were independently owned (most by chefs) and one of a kind. Today only one of the most popular 10 fits that description.
It was a natural progression: first, the avenues became open-air malls lined with Godiva next to Origins next to Barnes & Noble. And once New Yorkers all started dressing from Banana Republic, it was an easy step into high-end chain restaurants with the same tasteful but tame look.
Many of the restaurants being promoted most heavily lately have emerged from groups seemingly on fertility drugs. Pershing Square Cafe, across 42d Street from Grand Central Terminal, is the latest link in Buzzy O'Keeffe's chain (River Cafe, the Water Club), and Southwest is the latest in Abraham Merchant's chain (Merchants cafes, La Fourchette).
Shelly Fireman's group recently announced plans to convert the Motown Cafe into some variation on a food theme park while it continues to serve nonthreatening fare in a cluster of restaurants near Carnegie Hall. From the oversize nose motifs on the wall at Trattoria dell'Arte to the retro look of the Brooklyn Diner and the any-food-any-time menu at Redeye Grill, his restaurants offer food as entertainment without descending into Harley-Davidson circuses.
The Santos Family Group, the progenitors of the old Sign of the Dove who converted the Yellowfingers pasta place to a slicker but accessible Cibi Cibi, are still running the Latin-themed Bolivar next door and are rebuilding Arizona 206 and a new Sign downtown. Each is like the clothing departments at Bloomingdale's: each a little bit different but all following the same fashion.
The BE Group, with David Emil and his backers in one configuration or another, is responsible for Wild Blue (a riff on an American chophouse), Blackbird (built around its innovative cocktails) and Beacon (open fire cooking). Now, the group is developing a new restaurant on top of the Equitable tower, and don't be surprised if it looks like the group's prototype room, Blackbird.
The Myriad Group, run by Drew Nieporent, started with Montrachet and Nobu and most recently opened Berkeley Bar and Grill in the Sony Building (like its TriBeCa Grill with a tie-dye motif) and Heartbeat in the W Hotel on Lexington Avenue (pillars with echoes of Layla) and is planning to open Icon in another W hotel.
Chefs with deep-pocket backers are also cloning with abandon, of course: Jean-Georges Vongerichten now has five restaurants in New York, and Charlie Palmer, Daniel Boulud and Larry Forgione have three each. But each of them is a culinarian first, a businessman second. And their patrons tend to come for the food, not necessarily the familiarity.
Restaurant groups have been a force on the city's food front since the beginnings of Restaurant Associates in the 1960's. Michael Weinstein runs Ark (America, Ernie's, Columbus Bakery, Lutece), for instance, and Alan Stillman his New York Restaurant Group.
But it used to be that patrons were never reminded of how all those places were connected unless it was wine week, when the stuff was poured free at Mr. Stillman's restaurants: Smith & Wollensky, the Manhattan Ocean Club, Park Avenue Cafe and the Post House. That was a time when New Yorkers, then blessed with independent drugstores and movie theaters, sought out the Chanterelles and the Bouleys.
Now, Myriad tucks its dinner checks into folders advertising other outposts in the chain, and BR Guest gives out postcards picturing all its properties: Ruby Foo's, Isabella's, Park Avalon, Coconut Grill, Blue Water Grill, Ocean Grill, Atlantic Grill.
Even without the visual aids, there are hints that they are related: wicker cafe chairs, marble-topped brasserie tables in the bar, black-and-white photographs, dark stained wood and comfortable banquettes. If there was any doubt, the bartender who suggests the Ruby Foo cocktail as the best choice at Ocean Grill would vanquish it.
At a time when the city is reveling in safe streets, it seems to be falling victim to safe restaurants. No one is likely to suffer an aneurysm over overly creative food, even at Ruby Foo's, but people there feel unintimidated enough to order sushi for the first time and to eat it with a fork.
Many of the men leading New York's restaurant groups admit they took their inspiration from Rich Melman of Chicago, whose Lettuce Entertain You revolutionized the idea of a chain with a different look and taste in every expansion. Mr. Melman started 25 years ago with restaurants like Lawrence of Oregano, and today he runs 70 places in five states and Japan with names like Cafe Ba-Ba-Reeba and Hat Dance and Scoozi. He has attributed his success to "the ability to give people what they want almost before they want it."
Always, the goal was not to replicate a style but to insinuate it, to infuse a sensibility. And so Mr. Nieporent can honestly say that "Nobu is not like Montrachet, and Montrachet is not like TriBeCa Grill." Yet, his one knockout success has a visionary chef behind it, Nobu Matsuhisa. Even so, Mr. Nieporent says that part of what made Nobu take off was that it made Japanese food accessible through its Westernized design. And the same designer, David Rockwell, is behind Ruby Foo's, which Mr. Hanson intends to clone in Times Square.
Zarela Martinez, the owner of Zarela and one of the dwindling number of successful independent restaurateurs in Manhattan, said the groups are able to cater to a vast contingent of restaurantgoers. As she put it: "There are two different groups of customers: people who go out to dine, and people who go out to eat. Those people want places that are not too challenging, where they don't have to make any judgments."
Mr. Nieporent makes much the same point. "When you try to cook on a very high level," he said, "the market is very small." Volume, from multiple restaurants with a variety of themes but the same underlying esthetic, is essential to success.
But what happened in New York to make it so receptive to high-end variations on a chain? Danny Meyer, whose Union Square Hospitality Group owns four highly rated restaurants, credits a boom in the economy and a change in perception. Ten years ago, he said, a fine restaurant was viewed as one where the chef lived upstairs and was on the premises 24 hours a day, like Andre Soltner at Lutece.
"It used to be thought that if you had a high-end restaurant and expanded, the second one would be a downscale version, or the first one would suffer," he said. "Now, we've learned that the opposite can be true." Diners flock to his newest restaurants, Eleven Madison Square and Tabla, with the certainty that they will have an experience on the level they would have had at his firstborn, Union Square Cafe.
As the city has prospered, museums and developers of hotels and luxurious office buildings have realized that restaurants are box-office attractions, Mr. Meyer said, and they seek out groups with a stellar track record. "They're looking for brand names," he said. Put another way, they want sure-hit studio movies and not dicey independent films.
Today, the places that work capitalize on cross-marketing. Crowds waiting for tables at Myriad's Next Door Nobu, which takes no reservations, are steered into the bar at Layla, the group's nearby Moroccan restaurant. Crowds lined up at Ruby Foo's can always jump into a cab to cross town and get sushi at Atlantic Grill. The trick is not to develop identical twins.
"You have to give New Yorkers their independence," said Mr. Hanson of BR Guest. "You can't negate that independence. My restaurants may have a common theme of seafood or pasta, but they're all different."
And yet, at heart they all have to be the same. A capsule review in Time Out New York of Blue Water Grill sums up the style perfectly: "sophisticated without being too daring." Just like New York now.
It's no surprise that Danny Meyer and Steve Hanson say they admire McDonald's and Starbucks. And maybe it's even less surprising to think of what's on the horizon under the Queensboro Bridge, a sprawling restaurant called Guastavino's. The man behind it is Sir Terence Conran, the most prolific restaurateur in London, whose stainless-steel and glass Bluebird "gastrodome" feels just like his huge seafood restaurant, Le Pont de la Tour, and his 700-seat Asian-esque place in Soho, Mezzo. After expanding to Paris, with a huge brasserie called Alcazar that looks air-dropped in from London, he's decided he'll take Manhattan.
And on the whole, I'd almost rather be in Philadelphia.

HEADLINE: A Bridge From Welfare

 BODY:

To the Editor:
It is disappointing that Mayor Giuliani opposes a New York City Council proposal that would provide an alternative to the city's workfare program by creating hourly-wage jobs for former welfare recipients (news article, Sept. 29). 
 While the number of welfare participants has declined steeply as unemployment rates reach record lows, many welfare participants who failed to complete high school or who lack previous job experience have yet to find employment. These people are rapidly using up their five-year time limit on Federal welfare benefits.
Earlier this year, the New York Legislature agreed to give $13 million to finance a pilot job creation program to help such welfare participants make the transition to unsubsidized jobs. It is too bad that Mayor Giuliani opposes a similar program for the city that would help remove the real barriers impeding people from moving from welfare to work.
 
MARK A. DUNLEA
New York, Sept. 29, 1999

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
A Deadly Embrace

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
Flipping through the room-service menu at my Havana hotel the other morning, I noticed it listed four types of breakfast: American, Continental, Creole and Russian. Now, there aren't too many places in the world where you find "Russian breakfast" on the menu, especially this one, which consisted of caviar, smoked salmon and champagne for $125! Only a Russian businessman with an account at the Bank of New York could afford that breakfast.
Never mind. The Russian breakfast at the Melia Cohiba is among the few traces left in Cuba of the once-widespread Russian presence here. The huge, ugly Russian Embassy compound is so understaffed that a Russian diplomat here asked an American friend of mine, half-jokingly, whether he was interested in renting a room in the compound. It's a long way from the Cuban missile crisis. 
 For Russia today, Cuba is just another deadbeat country that owes the Kremlin billions of dollars. For Cuba's regime, though, Russia is something more. It is a fate to be avoided, a grim reaper to be outpaced. Fidel Castro's regime doesn't have much to boast about these days, but it will brag about this: "We didn't collapse with the Soviet Union!"
Indeed, I was given an official pamphlet entitled "The Cuban Miracle And Its Future." I figured it was about how Cuba had increased its sugar cane production. No. It was all about how Cuba survived the loss of $6 billion a year in Soviet aid, and why the Cuban people now "can smile at their hasty gravediggers."
In fact, Cuba's surviving the U.S.S.R.'s collapse is no miracle. It is the product of hard political realities that are worth examining. It starts with the old man. Unlike in Eastern Europe, Castro and his comrades are the original leaders of the Cuban revolution. They were the ones who seized power 40 years ago, and they will shoot to kill to preserve it. There will be no velvet revolution here.
Moreover, Cuba is an island, and it is easier than Eastern Europe to isolate from global trends. "You go into parts of Eastern Cuba and put your car radio onto 'scan' and it will just go round and round, without ever coming up with a station," remarked a Western diplomat here.
Also, while there are some dissidents still here, over the years most have left for Miami, been evicted or defected, so the protest movement lacks local leadership and is closely monitored. And one must admit that many of those Cubans who have stayed here, even those fed up with ration books, still have a grudging respect for Castro -- for the way he has given Cubans their own identity.
Finally, by opening Cuba a crack to tourism and foreign investment, the regime has been able to earn just enough cash to keep the place going without extensive political reform. This makes the daily struggle just to make ends meet all-consuming for Cubans. As P. J. O'Rourke once observed, Cuba is still so poor, and has so few cars, only a paranoid schizophrenic would look both ways before crossing a Havana street.
All this explains why it's time to start rethinking U.S. policy toward Cuba. In the cold war we were right to embargo Cuba because it posed a national security threat by its own strength and that of its Soviet backer. But today Castro's Soviet backer has collapsed, and the only threat that Cuba poses to us is if it suddenly collapses too or is convulsed in civil war after Castro is gone. If that happens, there will be real pressure for the U.S. to intervene militarily.
Forget about Castro. He's survived 40 years. He'll survive a few more. The real war now should be to make Cuba a viable society that slowly inches toward the West, not to keep it a weak and isolated society that inches only toward the abyss. Our strategic aim today shouldn't be to get Castro, but to save Cuba. A wise U.S. policy would be to lift the embargo and help Cubans gain the basic tools of economic growth, so that they can tune out Castro while he's still around, and thrive without Castro once he's gone.
I watched Castro on television the other night, addressing a student gathering. He was in his green uniform, fulminating at full throttle. The poor guy doesn't know the war is over. But then, how could he? We don't either. The U.S. and Cuban Governments have one thing in common today -- they're both ready to mortgage Cuba's future for its past. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Rise in Average College Cost In '99 Is Lowest in 12 Years

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
The average cost of attending college this school year rose 4.6 percent at private institutions and 3.4 percent at public institutions, the lowest increases in at least 12 years but still higher than the national rate of inflation, the College Board reported yesterday.
The board, the nonprofit organization that administers the nation's most widely used standardized tests for college admission, calculated the average cost of tuition and fees at private four-year colleges this fall to be $15,380, an increase of $671 over the 1998-1999 school year. At public universities, the average cost this year is $3,356, an increase of $109. 
 When expenses for room and board, for students who live on campus, are added to the figures, the average cost of a private college education this year is $21,339, and a public university is $8,086.
Although the rate of increase has been slowing at public institutions since 1991, and at private colleges since 1988, neither has managed to hold the rise in costs to that of inflation, which was 2.3 percent in the 12-month period ended in August.
To Terry Hartle, senior vice president for the American Council on Education, which represents 2,000 colleges and universities, public and private, that lingering gap is a symptom of the pressures brought to bear on institutions of higher learning.
"Higher education is a labor-intensive enterprise," Mr. Hartle said. "Productivity gains come slowly. The kinds of things colleges could do to increase productivity -- larger class sizes, more junior professors, fewer seminars, less books in the library -- are not desirable."
Gaston Caperton, the president of the College Board, said: "Technology is expensive, laboratories are expensive, students' expectations of the quality of classrooms are expensive."
Nonetheless, Mr. Caperton said that a family's investment in higher education continued to offer the prospect of a handsome return, particularly because the average income of someone who goes to college is double that of someone who does not. "About 50 percent of people who go to college pay about $4,000 for fees and tuition, which is $16,000 over four years," he said. "If a person works for 40 years, they'll probably earn over $1 million on that $16,000."
To rein in their fees, colleges are using a variety of strategies: Clark University in Worcester, Mass., has begun using waste energy to heat and cool campus buildings; Middlebury College is increasing the size of its student body by 300 students over the next decade, and Northeastern University in Boston has reduced the size of its faculty by more than 17 percent over the last five years, through attrition and a voluntary buyout program, according to the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities.
When last year -- the 1998-1999 school year -- was compared with the previous year, the rate of increase in tuition and fees for private institutions was 5.2 percent, and that of public colleges was 4.2 percent. Until this year's survey, both were all-time lows since the College Board began its survey comparing tuition fees, in the 1987-1988 school year.
Over that period, the largest increase for private institutions, 9.2 percent, was recorded in the late 1980's, and the largest jump in public college tuitions, 12 percent, was measured in the early 1990's.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Dow Finishes a Bit Lower After a Day of Big Swings

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
In a session punctuated by the Federal Reserve's decision to leave short-term interest rates unchanged yesterday, stock prices climbed, then plunged and finally recovered to close almost where they started.
Technology stocks led the market higher early in the day on the conviction that a decision by the Fed to maintain rates at current levels would not be harmful. 
 But major averages began coming off their highs early in the afternoon and slid sharply after the Fed indicated that while it had not raised rates, it might well do so at its next policy-making meeting in November.
In the last hour of trading, stocks came off their lows, as traders stepped in to buy after prices fell.
But analysts said the comeback meant little. At the end of the day, the stock market remained vulnerable to the same factors that had been sources of worry for some time.
"People are still looking for leadership where there has been none for the past six months," said Michael Clark, head of United States stock trading at Credit Suisse First Boston. "I don't think you can get any sustained momentum until questions about interest rates, the dollar and corporate profits get cleared up. The rational conclusion is that there are increased risks, and the market is adjusting for those risks."
At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was at 10,400.59, down 0.64 point, or a hundredth of a percent. It was the smallest point move in the blue-chip index since February. In the course of the day, however, the Dow rose as much as 107 and fell as much as 124.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dipped 3.25, or two-tenths of a percent, to 1,301.35. The Nasdaq composite index, loaded with technology shares, did a bit better, rising 3.70, or a tenth of a percent, to 2,799.67. And the Russell 2000 index of small-company stocks fell 0.6 point, also a tenth of a percent, to 426.01.
In advance of the Fed's meeting yesterday, most economists predicted that the central bank would not vote to raise rates; a rise would have been the third increase since June.
But with the economy continuing to expand at a rapid clip, expectations are building that a rate increase has merely been postponed until next month or early next year at the latest.
"It is highly likely that economic conditions in November will be arguing for a rate hike," said Lou Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates. "The question is whether or not financial market liquidity concerns associated with Y2K will be strong enough to make the Fed wait until after year-end."
By and large, yesterday was a good day for big technology stocks.
America Online was the biggest gainer in the S.& P. 500, rising 4 3/8, to 113 1/2. Lucent Tecnologies gained 11 5/16, to 64 15/16. And Cisco Systems was up 1 1/8, to 71 5/8.
But a decline in oil prices and an earnings warning from Halliburton made it a bad day in the oil patch.
Halliburton was the biggest loser in the S.& P. 500, falling 5 1/4, to 34 1/2.
Schlumberger, another big oilfield service company, fell 3 7/16, to 58 5/16. Baker Hughes dipped 1 1/16, to 26 9/16.
Among oil stocks Exxon fell 1 3/16, to 72 3/16. BP Amoco fell 1 3/4, to 54 7/8. And Texaco lost 2 1/2, to 60 7/16.
It was also not a good day for telephone stocks.
In the wake of its agreement to acquire Sprint, MCI Worldcom fell 3 11/16, to 67 15/16. Sprint was off 2, to 58 7/8. Bell Atlantic slipped 3 15/16, to 65 9/16. But AT&T countered the trend, rising 1 1/4, to 45.

Selloff in Treasuries
By Reuters
Prices of Treasuries sold off sharply after the Fed announcement on interest rates.
 The benchmark 30-year Treasury fell 17/32, to 99 11/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.17 percent from 6.08 percent on Monday. The closing yield was the highest since Aug. 11, when it was at 6.21 percent.
"The market sold off," said Mario DeRose, fixed-income strategist at Edward Jones in St. Louis. "It's going to be difficult to sustain any rally in Treasuries with the Fed implying that it is looking at these economic reports here, like the employment report on Friday, and that will go a long way toward determining what the Fed will do in November."

HEADLINE: After 23 Years, the Supreme Court Turns Again to the Limits on Campaign Contributions

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
The Justices of the Supreme Court came face to face today with the legacy of the Court's performance on the matter of money and politics, hearing arguments in a case from Missouri that challenges the continued validity of the $1,000 contribution limits the Court last examined and upheld 23 years ago.
The case presents some of the same issues at the heart of the campaign finance debate now under way in Congress: how to safeguard the integrity of a political system awash in money while at the same time preserving the ability of candidates to raise enough money to get their message across and of voters to contribute to the candidates of their choice, activities that the Court has ruled are protected by the First Amendment rights of free speech and association. 
 Few of the Justices appeared content today with a campaign finance system that, as Justice Anthony M. Kennedy phrased it, "has become obsessed with raising money." Justice Antonin Scalia referred sardonically to what he called the "half a baby delivered up" by the Court in its 1976 decision, Buckley v. Valeo, in which the Court, while upholding limits on contributions, ruled that candidates had a free-speech right to spend unlimited amounts of their own money.
But despite the Justices' evident unhappiness with the current state of the law, there appeared to be little appetite on the Court for using this latest case as a springboard for a fundamental reappraisal, as politicians and others on both sides of the debate have urged.
"Most people assume, and I do, certainly, that someone making an extraordinarily large contribution gets something extraordinary in return," Justice David H. Souter said to D. Bruce LaPierre, a lawyer arguing that Missouri had not provided adequate justification for contribution limits that mirror those the Court upheld for Federal elections in the Buckley decision.
An adequate justification for Missouri's law, Justice Souter suggested, is that "we need a political system in which there is some basic level of confidence on the part of those governed."
The case is an appeal by Missouri, with the backing of the Clinton Administration, from a ruling by the Federal appeals court in St. Louis that invalidated the $1,000 limit that the state legislature adopted in 1994 for contributions in statewide elections. Adjusted for inflation, the limit was $1,075 when that court, for the Eighth Circuit, ruled late last year that inflation since Buckley v. Valeo had so eroded the value of $1,000 that the state limit was now too low to permit "meaningful participation in protected political speech and association." Since 1976, the value of $1,000 has shrunk to less than $400.
Although the state's appeal, Nixon v. Shrink Missouri Government PAC, No. 98-963, reached the Court in time to have been heard and decided last spring, the Justices unaccountably delayed the argument until today. With a decision now not likely until next spring, the case has the potential to cause chaos in the midst of a Presidential election year should the Court agree with the Eighth Circuit: by affirming the decision of the appeals court, the Justices would in effect be nullifying the $1,000 limit on contributions to Federal candidates, a restriction that has been law since the campaign finance statutes were overhauled after the Watergate scandal a quarter-century ago.
The case presents both a narrow question and a more fundamental one. More narrowly, the question is whether some sort of inflation adjustment is constitutionally required so as to maintain political contributors in the position they held 23 years ago.
But more broadly the Eighth Circuit's approach to the question presents "a direct challenge to the continuing validity of Buckley," as Jay Nixon, Missouri's Attorney General, told the Court today. The reason is that the appeals court refused to accept the Supreme Court's assumption in 1976 that big political contributions were "inherently" tainted by the appearance of corruption, and instead demanded documented proof that there were actual problems that could be addressed only by the restrictions on speech that contribution limits necessarily entail. Solicitor General Seth P. Waxman told the Court that the Eighth Circuit's demand for empirical evidence of corruption was a "fundamental error."
Mr. LaPierre, a law professor at Washington University in St. Louis, argued in contrast that it would take only a modest step for the Court to uphold the Eighth Circuit. "All we're asking for is some evidence of some real problem," he said, before the legislature can be permitted to impose "significant limits on First Amendment interests."
Although the Supreme Court, in upholding the limits in the 1974 Federal campaign law, took account of the post-Watergate context in which the law was passed, "that does not mean the same conditions prevailed in Missouri in 1994," Mr. LaPierre said. He added that "it would be a mistake to view Buckley as the grandfathered governor of all $1,000 contribution limits."
Mr. LaPierre's client, Zev David Fredman, is a former candidate for Missouri state auditor who, along with a political action committee called Shrink Missouri Government, filed a lawsuit in 1998 to block the state election limits on the ground that they deprived an insurgent candidate of the ability to raise enough money for an effective campaign.
In a brief filed with the Supreme Court, the Republican National Committee, along with the National Republican Senatorial Committee and Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican who is the leading opponent of campaign finance restrictions, argues that the Court should eliminate all contribution limits. The low limits favor incumbents and have led to an accelerating "money chase," the brief says.
On the other side, a bipartisan group of 22 senators and representatives are urging the Court not only to continue to uphold contribution limits but also to reconsider its view that expenditures cannot be limited. "The proven inaccuracy of the Buckley Court's substituted judgment about the electoral process demonstrates that refusing to defer to legislative judgments is unwise," the Justices were told by this group, which includes Senators John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, sponsors of legislation that would overhaul the campaign finance system.
During the argument, Mr. Nixon, the Missouri Attorney General, was pressed by several Justices to explain the notion that big contributions can lead to a "perception of corruption," in a colloquy that veered into the realm of political philosophy.
"Is it corruption," Justice Kennedy asked, "for an official to mirror the views of the electorate just so he can get re-elected?"
No, Mr. Nixon replied.
"Not corruption, just cynicism," Justice Kennedy commented.
"That's not corruption, that's democracy," the Attorney General said.
At another point, when Mr. Nixon said the Court's approach to contribution limits "has stood the test of time," Justice Scalia challenged him in a tone of incredulity.
"It's stood the test of time?" the Justice repeated. "You mean there's great contentment and satisfaction with the campaign finance system?"
Mr. Nixon replied that the current system was better than any alternative. If the Court abandons Buckley v. Valeo, he said, it will lead "the vast majority of citizens to believe their government is literally up for sale."

HEADLINE: Not Insured, And Not Worried

BYLINE: By Robert H. Frank; Robert H. Frank, an economics professor at Cornell University, is the author of "Luxury Fever" and co-author of "The Winner-Take-All Society."

DATELINE: ITHACA, N.Y.

 BODY:
Last week we learned that poverty in the United States has been declining of late, but now we're told that the number of Americans without health insurance has risen to 44.3 million -- 833,000 more than a year ago and 4.5 million more than when Bill Clinton took office in 1993. Even in households with annual incomes of at least $50,000, the number of people without insurance increased last year, to 12.2 million.
In the midst of the longest sustained economic boom in history, with the lowest unemployment rate in 30 years, how is it possible that the ranks of the uninsured keep swelling? 
 The simple answer is that millions of American families continue to experience day-to-day financial distress. Last year, for example, one of every 68 families filed for bankruptcy, more than the number of families with children graduating from college.
Under the circumstances, it is easy to see why many families that have enjoyed good health are tempted to press their luck. After all, health coverage for a family of four with no pre-existing medical conditions costs upward of $3,000 a year, which is almost always far more than what such a family spends on medical services. The extra cash could help pay for a move into a better school district, for example, or at least keep creditors at bay.
Of course, in the event of a catastrophic illness, the hoped-for savings would vanish, and then some. Yet many Americans ignore this possibility. In fact, most of us have an unwarranted, not to say preposterous, degree of optimism regarding our own future well-being.
Surveys reveal that we see ourselves as far more likely than our peers to earn large salaries in the future, for example, and far less likely to get divorced or suffer from lung cancer. We may know that some families will have health problems, but we don't think we'll be among them.
As more people cancel their health coverage, going without insurance becomes more socially acceptable. Parents who didn't buy health insurance for their families were once viewed as irresponsible, but this stigma inevitably loses its sting as the number of uninsured grows.
Making matters worse is the changing composition of the pool of the insured. As more healthy families forgo coverage, those left tend to be sicker and more costly to treat, forcing up premiums.
A similar dynamic is at work on the employer's side. Not long ago, many workers would never have considered a job that didn't include health insurance. As more employers, particularly small businesses, offer jobs with no coverage, however, it becomes more difficult for workers to avoid them. In turn, these employers have lower operating costs, allowing them a competitive edge and putting further pressure on businesses that continue to offer such benefits.
In short, our health-insurance system is in a death spiral. Despite President Clinton's effort to expand coverage for uninsured children, we now have more uninsured children than ever. Vice President Al Gore's plan to broaden children's coverage is only a marginal improvement. Former Senator Bill Bradley's proposal would substantially broaden coverage for both children and adults, but, as even he concedes, it probably would not be enough. Gov. George Bush has yet to weigh in on this issue.
The good news is that the Government could eliminate the death spiral by simply reimbursing each family up to $3,000 a year for health insurance. Government bureaucrats would not need to prescribe which doctors we see or micromanage any of the other details. They would simply process insurance receipts and send out reimbursement checks.
This plan sounds expensive, but would actually be far less costly than the current system. The principal savings would come from delivering more cost-effective care to those who are now uninsured.
As it stands now, the untreated minor illnesses of the uninsured often develop into major illnesses, which are far more costly to treat. And when such illnesses befall the uninsured, we almost always treat them, often in costly emergency rooms. The resulting burden on hospitals leads to higher fees and increased Government support -- both of which now come largely out of the pockets of high-income taxpayers with health insurance.
The total budget needed to finance a $3,000 health insurance reimbursement for every American family -- some $200 billion a year -- would obviously require higher taxes. But for those whose employers currently provide health insurance, these taxes would be offset by an increase in salaries.
After all, companies offer insurance not because they are charitable, but because they find doing so an effective way to compete for workers. Any company that did not offer higher salaries to previously insured workers would risk losing them to a company that did.
A universal reimbursement program would impose no net burden on taxpayers, because of both salary adjustments and reductions in the high cost of care for the uninsured. By providing a powerful incentive for all families to buy insurance, it would reverse the current downward spiral.
Critics of health-care reform will say that if some people want to save money by going without health insurance, that's their problem or their choice. Perhaps, but it's a problem for the rest of us as well, one that if left untended will grow steadily worse. Our unwillingness to deal with this problem is even more profoundly irrational than the uninsured family's belief in its immunity from serious illness. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Biotech Companies Feel Overlooked by New York

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
For many years, New York City officials have turned a cold shoulder to the biotechnology industry, prompting entrepreneurs trained in prestigious local medical research institutions to set up their companies in more hospitable places, according to a number of scientists and others in the field.
The lack of city effort to encourage the industry has deprived New York of good jobs, lucrative businesses and increasingly generous Federal research dollars, these experts say. 
 City officials have long vowed to step up their efforts for biotechnology companies, which are risky and expensive to establish. But despite years of expectations, a new report has concluded that "New York has virtually no biotech industry to speak of."
The report, by the Center for an Urban Future, a Manhattan nonprofit research organization, says neglect by both the city and the state has allowed other states with generous incentive programs to siphon off good ideas from scientists at local medical research institutions.
Prominent figures in biomedicine echo those conclusions. "It's been an unfortunate oversight," said Dr. Herbert Pardes, the dean of the Columbia University Faculty of Medicine. "New York is a big, hectic city with a lot of competing pressures. But we certainly should be doing more in this area."
Just last week, for example, Thyreos, a company developing new cancer treatments, gave up on finding affordable space in the city and moved from a small midtown office to space in Newark that was once occupied by a chemical company. Dr. C. Wayne Bardin, the company president, said laboratory space in the Audubon Biomedical Science and Technology Park at Columbia, the one place in the city dedicated to companies like his, cost too much.
Dr. Bardin, who was once based at Rockefeller University, contends that although New York has been generous with incentives to businesses in traditional industries like finance and publishing, it has been short-sighted about biotechnology. The industry develops vaccines, medicine and food products based on research in molecular and cellular biology and genetics, and getting the product to market can take as as long as a decade.
"New York is not geared to the small guy," Dr. Bardin said. "If my company grows to a a billion-dollar business, it will be a New Jersey business, not a New York business."
State and city officials, however, deny that they have ignored the biotechnology industry and point out that they have recently begun to take more aggressive steps to help these businesses. "I'm not about to say that we cannot do more to make a better climate for these sorts of industries to thrive," said Michael G. Carey, the new president of the city's Economic Development Corporation.
But for Dr. Ron Cohen, who founded a company in 1995 to develop treatments for spinal cord injuries, the new focus is coming too late. At first, Dr. Cohen, a graduate of Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons, worked out of his Manhattan apartment, but as his company, Acorda Therapeutics, grew, he found himself squeezed out of the city by high rents.
So last year, Dr. Cohen traded proximity to major libraries and eminent scientists for a tree-lined industrial park in Hawthorne, about 25 miles north of New York. Baltimore officials also went to great lengths to win him, but personal ties kept him close to New York, he said.
"It wasn't just the incentives," Dr. Cohen said. "It was the confidence they gave that when it came to biotech, they got it. You felt you had a friend in Maryland."
In the 14 months since his company moved to Westchester, it has grown to 25 employees from 6.
In 1998, the last year for which figures are available, there were nearly 1,300 biotechnology companies in the nation, employing about 153,000 people.
But only 20 are in New York City, according to the New York Biotechnology Association, a trade group. Statewide, there are about 175 companies, most of them based on Long Island or outside the metropolitan area, said Karin A. Duncker, the association executive director.
The Center for an Urban Future report blames New York's medical establishment for being slow to develop the type of entrepreneurial spirit common to places where biotechnology has thrived.
But the harshest criticism is reserved for the Giuliani administration. In 1995, for example, the city established a $50 million venture capital fund to bolster companies in advanced technology. But the fund has yet to invest a dime in biotechnology. (Mr. Carey said that only 20 of the 1,500 proposals submitted to the fund came from biotechnology companies.)
And the report also faults state officials for no longer replenishing a revolving small-business fund that lends money to starting technology companies.
Pataki administration officials deny that they have been lax. "We have been promoting biotech research and investment for a number of years," said Joseph Conway, a spokesman for the State Division of the Budget, "and we now feel that we have a comprehensive strategy in place that is second to none."
Indeed, in recent years, the state has helped finance several biotechnology incubators, as work spaces where new companies are given a chance to get started are called. But that money has gone to State University campuses outside the city.
Ms. Duncker and other industry advocates say they are encouraged by some recent developments, including a new state law that allows individuals to write off investments in high-tech companies.
"Steps have been made," Ms. Duncker said, "Unfortunately, we have a long way to go."
Biotechnology has flourished for about two decades in California and Massachusetts, sometimes with government help and sometimes without. Cities like South San Francisco, Boston and Baltimore have converted old warehouses and military installations into incubators. More recently, other states, including Connecticut and New Jersey, have made major commitments to helping companies in their early stages.
The cost of outfitting laboratories alone is beyond the reach of small businesses without some form of public subsidy, said William A. Polf, a deputy vice president at Columbia's Health Sciences Division.
But Dr. Jeremy M. Levin, the managing director of Perseus Capital, a company that invests in biotechnology, said each industry job generated at least five other local jobs -- from people who supply chemicals, material and animals for research to others who dispose of hazardous materials.
The city's sole incubator, the well-maintained Audubon Park, occupies five floors in the Mary Woodard Lasker Medical Research Building in Washington Heights. It has room for only about a dozen companies and turns away an average of one prospective tenant each month, said Mitchell Gipson, Audubon's executive director. As companies expand, they are forced to move elsewhere, and often leave the city.
Since becoming an Audubon tenant in June 1998, Memory Pharmaceuticals Corporation has grown to a work force of 25 from 5. Next year, the company, which is developing treatments for memory disorders, plans to move to Montvale, N.J., said Joanne Leonard, its chief financial officer.
Memory Pharmaceuticals found cheaper space and a rich package of incentives across the river.
New Jersey also created a fund to provide seed money for new businesses and will open a new state-financed technology center in North Brunswick this fall. New Jersey now has 100 biotech companies, twice what it had five years ago.
Nevertheless, in New York, the state and city are moving in the right direction, biotechnology entrepreneurs say. The state is creating a new Office of Science, Technology and Academic Research and has recommended that $250 million of the $110 billion state employees' pension fund be invested in high technology, including biotech companies.
The city has promised that some of the money set aside last month for a new $25 million Emerging Industries Fund would be used to finance biotechnology companies. Dr. Pardes, the Columbia dean, is chairman of a task force created by the Giuliani administration that will seek ways of expanding laboratory space and reducing regulatory roadblocks.
While the city seeks to catch up, a cluster of biotech companies founded by New Yorkers has already sprung up in Tarrytown, on the site of a plant that once belonged to Union Carbide.
Jonathan Bowles, the research director of the Center for an Urban Future and the author of its biotechnology report, said that that cluster was a good example of how the city had failed.
"Why couldn't it be in the Bronx, where the city could get something from it?" Mr. Bowles asked. "Just like we want Bear Stearns to stay in Manhattan, we want these companies' revenue and employees to be here."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Sales of Industrial Robots Up, Report by a U.N. Agency Says

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Sales of industrial robots are flourishing worldwide, except in Asia, because of a huge demand from car makers in the United States and Europe, a United Nations economic agency said today.
In the first half of 1999, motor vehicle manufacturers' orders surged 101 percent worldwide, and 214 percent in North America, compared with the same period in 1998, the agency, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, said in an annual survey. 
 It predicted that by 2002, the pace of industrial robot installations would be up 36 percent over that in 1998, in part because of increasing domestic use of service robots for such tasks as lawn mowing and vacuum cleaning.
Plummeting sales in Japan and South Korea caused the world robotic market to decline by 16 percent last year, according to figures compiled by the commission and the International Federation of Robotics, a trade group based in Sweden.
Japan, the United States, Germany, Italy, Spain, South Korea, France and Britain were the leaders in the number of industrial robots installed last year.
The pace is predicted to pick up this year, the agency said, with yearly average growth of 8 percent until 2002, when 97,000 units are projected for installation. But this is a significantly lower forecast compared with previous agency predictions. The report said that in Asian markets, "previously good conditions for robot investment have come to a halt -- at least temporarily."
Despite downturns in 1996 and 1998, the United States market for robots is again flourishing, with orders up 90 percent in the first half of 1999 compared with the 1998 period, according to the report.
The European market increased by 10 percent last year, and is projected to be much stronger this year based on a 32 percent increase in orders in the first six months. Denmark, Finland and Spain led the way with growth of 50 percent or more.
No growth is expected in Japan this year, but some recovery is forecast by 2002, when annual installations are expected to total 43,000, the report said. Before the "bubble economy" burst in the early 1990's, Japan had installed a large number of robots, many of which are likely to be replaced.
The United States is expected to increase its industrial robot installations by an average of 9 percent yearly, to an annual 15,600 units by 2002. Robot installations in Europe are anticipated to grow by 10 percent annually, to 32,000 robots in 2002.
Among the new markets for robots are the United States Postal Service, where as many as 80,000 could be installed in the next two decades, the report said. Large increases in robot use are also foreseen for household tasks, medical use and as aids to people with physical disabilities.

HEADLINE: Mr. Bush's Triangulation

 BODY:
Perhaps emboldened by his lead in the Republican Presidential race, George W. Bush has delivered a surprising critique of his party and, implicitly, its Congressional leadership. Yesterday, while campaigning in New York, the Texas Governor blamed fellow Republicans for what he said was an overly obsessive focusing on the economy at the expense of social needs. As if on cue, Republicans in Congress let it be known that despite the big Federal surpluses, they were considering budget cuts that could eviscerate Head Start, school aid for poor students, health research and other programs.
Mr. Bush's latest comments came less than a week after the uproar over his bluntly accurate assessment of a House Republican scheme to rescind part of the Federal tax credit for working-class families. "I don't think they ought to balance their budget on the backs of the poor," he said, a comment tailor-made for Democrats and certain to be played back between now and the election. 
 The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, and House Speaker Dennis Hastert responded calmly, suggesting they believe that Mr. Bush is simply running toward the center for tactical reasons. "Sometimes I take shots at Congress too," said Mr. Lott. Still, one has to wonder if they do not miss the days when Mr. Bush was on Capitol Hill assuring G.O.P. lawmakers that he would not try to score points by bashing Republicans in Congress. Now the Governor seems to be stealing a page from the old Dick Morris "triangulation" playbook, in which President Clinton ran for re-election by distancing himself from the Congressional Democrats.
They should also worry that in defining "compassionate conservatism," Mr. Bush is underlining real weaknesses in the G.O.P.'s Congressional program. On the budget, for example, Republicans are blindly attached to the tight ceilings that they enacted with White House concurrence two years ago. The Republicans have also vowed, along with the White House, not to use any money generated by the Social Security program to pay for regular programs, even though budgets have resorted to that practice for decades.
Mr. Clinton has proposed raising money for vital programs by closing tax loopholes and imposing a modest tobacco tax. The Republicans rejected that approach and employed gimmicks to meet the budget targets. But even with gimmicks, it will take cuts to meet the ceilings enacted in 1997. What would have been a difficult job on the budget has now been made even harder for the Republicans by Mr. Bush. His critique almost seems to echo the view of President Clinton, Vice President Gore and the Democrats, who portray the G.O.P. in Congress as hijacked by anti-government extremists.
Tom DeLay and the other hard-line Congressional Republicans are telling each other that young Mr. Bush has a lot to learn about Washington. But maybe it is the Republicans in Congress who have a lot to learn from Governor Bush, who has actually had to administer social programs and may have come to the radical conclusion that it takes money to run them adequately. In trying to head off unrealistic Republican budget cuts, the White House may have found an unlikely ally.

HEADLINE: Fed Leaves Rates Steady, For This Time

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged, but warned that it was still concerned about the potential for inflation and might raise rates soon if the economy did not cool off.
Economists and investors had expected the central bank's decision not to change the short-term rates it controls. But the Fed's warning about its possible next move -- in the form of a formal tilt toward a tighter monetary policy -- nonetheless jolted Wall Street and suggested that financial markets would remain jittery in coming weeks in anticipation of new data about the momentum of the economy. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average, which had been up over 100 points just before the Fed's announcement, plummeted immediately and was down around 125 points before rebounding. It closed at 10,400.59, down 0.64 point on the day. Bond prices tumbled, sending longer-term interest rates higher.
In holding rates steady for now but putting investors on notice that a rate increase could be in the offing, the Fed was trying to strike a policy balance that acknowledged both the warning signals of inflation being generated by the robust economy and the almost total lack of actual inflation outside of surging oil prices.
"They had pretty much telegraphed that they weren't going to raise interest rates this time, but they are certainly leaving their options open to do so in the future," said David Wyss, an economist at Standard & Poor's DRI, a consulting firm. "They have a feeling that the economy may be doing too well for its own good."
Fed officials, led by Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman, have become increasingly convinced in recent months that the economy's capacity to grow without inflation has been substantially improved by huge investments in efficiency-enhancing computers and other technology.
Yet they have not abandoned their traditional rules and models, which hold that the economy cannot sustain the current combination of 4 percent annual growth and unemployment of just 4.2 percent without setting off an inflationary spiral of rising prices and wages.
"Strengthening productivity growth has been fostering favorable trends in unit costs and prices, and much recent information suggests that these trends have been sustained," the Fed's policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee said in a statement after its meeting today. "Nonetheless, the growth of demand has continued to outpace that of supply, as evidenced by a decreasing pool of available workers willing to take jobs."
Under those circumstances, the committee said, the Fed "will need to be especially alert in the months ahead to the potential for costs to increase significantly in excess of productivity in a manner that could contribute to inflation pressures."
The committee said its adoption of a bias toward raising rates in the future "did not signify a commitment to near-term action" and that it would study economic data and the state of the financial markets in coming weeks before making a decision.
After long keeping decisions to adopt a policy bias a secret, the Fed has been disclosing them immediately after each meeting since earlier this year, prompting considerable confusion in the markets as to whether a bias is all but a promise of a change in policy or just an alert.
In this case, analysts said that if economic reports in coming weeks showed a decline in unemployment, an increase in wages exceeding productivity increases or signs of continuing robust demand in key sectors like housing, the Fed could push rates up as soon as its next meeting on Nov. 16.
The Fed has already pushed its benchmark Federal funds target rate up twice this year in quarter- point steps, to 5.25 percent. Its more symbolic discount rate stands at 4.75 percent.
Fed officials are likely to pay particular attention to the employment report for September, which will be released on Friday, and the report for October, which will be released on Nov. 5.
"The implication is that if the numbers continue the way they have been recently and the stock market doesn't do anything dramatic, then the Fed will probably tighten again in November," said James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at J. P. Morgan in New York.
The Fed's two rate increases this year have helped push up long-term rates and consumer loan rates. The housing market in particular -- a key component of economic activity -- is feeling the pinch of higher rates, with higher mortgage rates ending a surge in refinancing activity and starting to crimp home sales, which had been running at record levels.
The decline over the last several months in the stock market should also help take some steam out of consumer confidence and demand, analysts said.
But in some ways the economy is strengthening, with manufacturers, for example, benefiting from an increase in exports as demand from Asia and Europe rebounds.
"There is some slowing in housing and some slowing in consumption, but it's not very dramatic yet," Mr. O'Sullivan said. "In the other direction, exports are accelerating, there's no weakening in business investment and inventories seem poised for an increase."
Today's statement did not mention the possible effects on the economy and the financial system of any widespread problems that might be caused by the Year 2000 computer software problem. Earlier this year, analysts had speculated that the Fed might have to put monetary policy on hold the last several months of the year regardless of inflation pressures to avoid adding to any problems that technology might be causing in the markets or the financial system.
But analysts said the Fed was now more confident that the computer problems would be contained, and that it could raise rates in November if economic conditions require it.

HEADLINE: Fliers From Transit Union Draw on Class Distinctions

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Class warfare has largely disappeared from New York's labor scene, but the Transit Workers Union has embraced it with a vengeance in its campaign for a new contract.
The union, representing 35,000 subway and bus workers, is distributing hundreds of thousands of copies of a novel leaflet with a cartoon of a huge, furry, fat cat dressed in a charcoal pin-striped suit and holding a fistful of hundred-dollar bills. 
 In militant language more common in the 1930's than the 1990's, the leaflets insist that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki have starved the transit system of funds by giving billions of dollars in tax breaks to corporations, an act deemed "corporate welfare."
The leaflets, which are being distributed under front doors and at subway stops, call for an end to "feeding the fat cats and subsidizing welfare cheats in corporate suites."
Willie James, president of Local 100 of the Transit Workers Union, said his union hired a well-known public relations consultant, Ray Rogers, to turn up the heat on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and on the Mayor and the Governor, who have a large say in its operations.
Mr. Rogers is famous for his strident language and hard-hitting techniques. Mr. James said that the union was paying him $100,000 to run the campaign and that printing 1 million leaflets would cost another $100,000.
"I was interested in a different approach," said Mr. James, who is facing complaints from many union members that their current contract gave them skimpy raises. "I knew I had to get the attention of the riding public and all parties concerned to show we're serious about getting a fair and just contract."
The union began distributing the leaflets this week, a few days after Mr. James threatened that transit workers might strike when their contract expires on Dec. 15. Under New York State law, it is illegal for public employees to strike, but Mr. James recognizes that city officials fear a December strike because it could cause chaos during the peak shopping season.
Mr. James said the union, whose members have an average salary of $39,000 a year, was intent on receiving a larger raise than it got in the current contract: a single raise of 3.75 percent. He is trying to build public support for the union, asserting that with the city, state and transit authority enjoying surpluses and an economic boom, transit workers should receive their fair share.
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Rogers said the leaflets' sharp language was meant to rally support for more spending on public services, not just on transit, but also on schools and health care. At the same time, he said, the leaflets are designed to whip up opposition to tax breaks that he says are cheating the public and leaving too little money for transit and other services.
"In New York City," he said, "as you step over homeless people every day, you have to ask, 'Why are the Mayor and the Governor giving away billions of dollars to super-rich corporations and their greedy C.E.O.'s?' "
In particular, Mr. Rogers condemned tax breaks given to NBC, the Disney Corporation and the New York Stock Exchange. He suggested that the companies that demanded tax breaks to keep their operations in New York were extortionists.
Mr. Rogers' militant language and tactics helped the textile workers' union win a famous, decadelong unionization drive at J.P. Stevens in one of the most successful efforts at organizing industrial workers in the South. But his hardball tactics came under severe criticism when a union local representing meat-packing workers in Minnesota was crushed in a lengthy strike against Hormel.
M.T.A. officials did not take kindly to the leaflets and said the authority hoped to reach an amicable settlement with the transit workers.
Asked to comment on Mr. Rogers's leaflets, Tom Kelly, an M.T.A spokesman, said: "He's a paid consultant. He's earning his money."
Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki, denounced the leaflets. "It's a shame that the union's leadership has decided to spend hard-earned union dues on its own self-promotion and self-aggrandizement," he said. "It seems like a waste of the union members' money, particularly since the negotiations have not yet begun. If they're interested in reaching a fair settlement, that will be done at the table, not by spending a lot of money on a spin meister."
Mayor Giuliani's press office did not respond to telephone calls.
