HEADLINE: Wealthy Nassau Makes Itself a Fiscal Mess

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, N.Y., Oct. 3

 BODY:
From the quaintest village hall to the largest county seat, in Albany, Trenton and Washington, governments at every level of society are enjoying record surpluses amassed during the nation's long economic expansion.
So it would be natural to expect that Nassau County, one of the wealthiest and most populous in America, run for a generation by a party espousing fiscal conservatism, and now possessed of its lowest rate of unemployment in decades, would have put together a sizable budget surplus. 
 Instead, while other comparable counties are pondering tax cuts or new spending, this storied suburb -- inspiration for Fitzgerald's Gold Coast, launching point for Lindbergh and playpen of the Long Island Lolita -- is contemplating something else: a deficit that reached $300 million this summer and bonds downgraded to a level now hovering just above junk.
How this happened is an unlikely tale, a product of Nassau's one-party politics and some disastrous financial decisions by the county's Republican leaders. But with elections a month away, it is giving local Democrats their first hope in years of changing the political balance of power. And, experts on municipal finance say, it is making Nassau County a serious contender to be labeled the most fiscally irresponsible county in America.
"I've been doing this 22 years," said John J. Hallacy, the manager of municipal research at Merrill Lynch, one of Nassau's frequent underwriters, when asked if he had ever seen a government with so much going for it encounter so much financial trouble. "An example doesn't really come to mind."
Even Orange County, Calif., which went bankrupt in 1994 after losing $2 billion on bad investments, saw its bond rating elevated to the second-highest category last month. Nassau, alone among major urban counties, is heading in the opposite direction.
Three factors helped create the crisis, which developed over the last decade.
It began with the way an overriding aversion to electoral setbacks produced increasingly risky financial decisions by the county's Republican executive and legislative majority. An impotent and impossibly divided Democratic Party often held its tongue.
In addition, an apathetic and uninformed electorate saw no reason to doubt Republican assurances that things were just fine.
The climax came suddenly. In short order this year, delays in the budgeted sales of several county assets and a $50 million cost overrun in the health insurance plan for county workers opened up a widening deficit. Seeing no other solution, Wall Street rating agencies that had issued increasingly stern warnings for months finally lowered the county's bond rating and hinted at further rebukes to come.
Now, Nassau's Republican organization, widely considered the strongest surviving Tammany-style political machine in the country, is behaving as if its survival is in doubt. Republican candidates for the County Legislature in next month's elections are treating their veto-proof 14-to-5 majority as the slimmest of margins, spending more than $1 million on television ads and mailings, twice as much as in calmer years.
"It's serious, no question about it," said Joseph N. Mondello, who as county chairman is one of the most powerful Republican officials in the state. "My personal poll is when I go to my deli in Levittown, or my church. Levittown's a lower socioeconomic group of folks. They've always been strong Republican supporters. I've begun to see signs that that support could be wavering."
In retrospect, what is most surprising about the county's fiscal spiral is how long it took to occur.
The County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, who took office in 1987, has depicted himself as a conservative fiscal manager who would nonetheless be able to maintain the lavishly paid police force, pristine parks and golf courses, and other services residents had grown to expect.
But Mr. Gulotta set off a firestorm of criticism when he proposed a 25 percent property tax increase to close a deficit in 1992.
Scalded by a close re-election fight the next year, Mr. Gulotta seemed to experience a conversion. His budgets from then on avoided the slightest increase in the general tax rate. And, although Nassau has the nation's highest sales-tax rate, and while property taxes tied to specific purposes, like the police or parks, continued to go up, Mr. Gulotta's mantra -- that he had cut or frozen the county's general-fund property tax for the Nth straight year -- won him a landslide re-election for a third full term in 1997.
But the costs of county government did not stop rising. For example, refunds to taxpayers who win appeals of their property assessments now exceed $100 million a year. Yet the county is defending its assessment system against a lawsuit by the Federal Government, which says it results in higher taxes for black and Hispanic residents in poor neighborhoods, as if their homes were as valuable as those in wealthier, mostly white neighborhoods.
Moreover, unlike Westchester County, which sets aside money for such claims in each year's operating budget, Nassau borrows to pay for the refunds. As a result, its ballooning debt, now at $2.5 billion, is more than twice as much per capita as that of any other county in the state.
Westchester, which is perennially given the highest ratings by Wall Street agencies, has frequently raised its property tax rate in small steps. But to avoid any such pain, critics say, Mr. Gulotta routinely used two simple gimmicks to close the gap between rising costs and property taxes.
He projected the sale of county assets, though they often failed to be sold on time, or at all. And he overestimated the county's sales tax receipts, even when they were on the rise. Westchester has routinely underestimated sales taxes.
Now, as New York City and Suffolk County are about to eliminate the sales tax on clothing, Nassau cannot afford to do so, meaning many consumers could be driven elsewhere. A cooling economy could bode even worse for sales taxes -- and mean even bigger deficits.
Mr. Gulotta now acknowledges his failure to keep property taxes and other recurring revenues on a par with spending. But he does not call that a mistake. In an interview, he first played down the importance of, and then took issue with, the downgrade of the county's bond rating, saying it had been "premature."
Instead, he contended that the years of property tax cuts had been partly responsible for the county's high wealth levels and booming economy. "It's true that it's had the side impact of creating a structural imbalance in the budget," he said. "I feel we are addressing it now in a responsible fashion."
Whether they were right all along or not, Mr. Gulotta and the Republican legislators who approved his budgets each year essentially had a free hand in running the county, for two reasons: the opposition was powerless to stop them, and the public paid little attention.
Democrats, always the underdog in county elections, were hampered even further by more than a decade of leadership battles and constant petty infighting. That finally came to an end in March, when Stephen J. Sabbeth, convicted of bankruptcy fraud, resigned as Democratic chairman and was replaced by Thomas P. DiNapoli, a youthful Assemblyman from Great Neck.
"The people of this county, because they only vote one way, they've contributed to the lack of accountability," Mr. DiNapoli said. "In any normal political situation, this is the year for a landslide for the opposition."
The growing turmoil in Mineola may be stirring the public from its complacency.
Hundreds of county officials, including the sheriff, the county attorney, several department heads and other close aides to Mr. Gulotta have put in their early retirement papers in recent days, creating the impression of a sinking ship. Long Island cable television stations are running dueling ads by Mr. Gulotta (who is not up for re-election until 2001) and Republican legislators, in which both he and the Legislature's presiding officer, Bruce A. Blakeman, independently promise to solve the fiscal crisis while avoiding any mention of their roles in causing it.
Mr. Gulotta's commercials appear to have so frustrated the Republican legislators' attempts to distance themselves from him that they have begun to attack him more directly, theatrically shredding a copy of his budget at one recent news conference and vowing to remake it entirely over the next few weeks.
For the first time in memory, the Republicans even acknowledged the existence of political patronage, promising to cut the pay and maybe even the jobs of appointed deputy commissioners, secretaries and others -- whose salaries Democrats have charged bloat the county payroll by millions of dollars.
Happily watching from the sidelines are Democrats like Mr. DiNapoli, who have been trying to cast the November election as a referendum on Republicans' stewardship of county government. They concede that they would be grateful to pick up just two legislative seats, enough to give them the power to block the county from borrowing money, an essential bit of leverage.
Anything more, 25 years of Nassau politics teaches, would be all but unthinkable. Yet Democratic candidates suddenly seem to be getting at least a second look.
In Massapequa Park, where Republicans outnumber Democrats by a ratio of 5 to 2, a magazine editor named Carl Lowe is running as a Democratic sacrificial lamb against Peter J. Schmitt, the deputy presiding officer of the Legislature.
The other afternoon, Mr. Lowe knocked on nine Republican doors and a single Democratic one along Glengarriff Road. He collected 10 signatures for a petition supporting the Democratic fiscal oversight plan.
Ed Quinn, a retired New York police lieutenant and a lifelong Republican, rolled his eyes and practically sneered at Mr. Lowe when he identified himself as a Democrat. But as the two men spoke, Mr. Quinn's demeanor quickly changed.
"The whole country's doing terrific, and we're doing terrible," Mr. Quinn said. "They've really screwed it up pretty good."
Two doors down, Wendy Cannella, the Republican wife of a Republican county court officer, said she was giving the Democrats another look. "Why isn't this happening all over?" she asked. "Why just Nassau County?"
Maybe a new batch of county legislators would shake things up, Ms. Cannella said. "Gulotta's an easy target," she said. "But if he's screwed up this badly, what about the rest of them? Where were they?"

HEADLINE: COMMUNICATIONS GIANT: THE HOMETOWN;
Sprint's News Shakes Up Kansas City

BYLINE: By TONI CARDARELLA 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 5

 BODY:
Just days after the dedication of a $920 million headquarters complex in Kansas, the Sprint Corporation spent today issuing reassurances that its pending acquisition by MCI Worldcom Inc. would not lead to substantial cutbacks in its operations in the Kansas City area.
With 18,000 of its 70,000 employees in and around Kansas City, Sprint is the area's second-largest employer, behind the Federal Government. MCI Worldcom, the second-biggest long-distance telephone company in the United States, announced today in New York that it would buy Sprint, the No. 3 carrier, for $115 billion in stock. If approved, it would be the biggest corporate takeover ever. 
 As information trickled in, government and business leaders expressed concern mixed with optimism.
Lt. Gov. Gary Sherrer of Kansas, who also serves as the state's Secretary of Commerce and Housing, said, "For the Kansas economy I'm obviously concerned, and more importantly for the men and women who work out there."
Peter Levi, president of the Greater Kansas City Chamber of Commerce, said he found comfort in the announcement that William T. Esrey, the chief executive of Sprint, would be chairman of the new company and would remain in Kansas City. Sprint's new headquarters are in Overland Park, Kan.
"Having his feet planted in Kansas City is very important to our community," said Mr. Levi, adding that he hoped that Sprint would remain a philanthropic force. Sprint is the third-largest donor to the new Science City project at Union Station and a major contributor to the Kansas City Zoo.
The communications industry accounts for about $2 billion of the area's estimated $55 billion gross regional product, said David Reisdorph, a senior researcher at the Mid-America Regional Council. "And obviously," he said, "Sprint has the lion's share of that."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Fluctuate Sharply On Interest Rate Decision
In a session punctuated by the Federal Reserve's decision to leave short-term interest rates unchanged, stock prices climbed, then plunged and finally recovered close to where they started.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.64 point, to 10,400.59. During the day, it rose as much as 107 points and fell as much as 124. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dipped 3.25 points, to 1,301.35. The Nasdaq composite index did a bit better, gaining 3.70 points, to 2,799.67. The yield on the 30-year Treasury rose to 6.17 percent from 6.08 percent. Page C19. 

Apple Introduces New iMac Line
Apple Computer introduced a family of iMac computers, including an entry-level model priced below $1,000, just in time for the holiday shopping season. The computer has a new operating system and includes a video editing program, a feature that the company co-founder Steve P. Jobs called "the next big thing." C2.
 
Canadian Auto Workers Reach Pact
DaimlerChrysler reached a three-year labor contract with the Canadian Auto Workers less than two hours before 13,800 workers were set to strike. C5.
 
Airlines Cut Back Flights on Dec. 31
Some airlines are cutting back their scheduled flights for Dec. 31. The reductions reflect lower demand stemming from concern about flying on or about the time the world's computers are scheduled to turn over from 1999 to 2000. Edwin McDowell: Business Travel. C8.
 
Boeing Moves Into Jet Maintenance
Boeing announced a deal to buy 44 of its 757-model passenger jets, convert them to cargo planes and lease them to DHL International, the package delivery company. C9.
 
American Express to Be Web Broker
American Express said it would turn its on-line brokerage business into a new Web broker with lower commissions and free stock trades for wealthy clients later this autumn. The new unit will offer more mutual funds, customer service and financial planning tools than Financial Direct, American Express's existing Web brokerage business. Shares of American Express rose $3.125, to $140.6875. C19.
 
CBS Introduces an Internet Portal
CBS introduced an Internet portal but, being a late contestant in the business, will try to catch up by offering cash prizes to regular visitors who register with the site. C14.
 
Mexican Airline Accused of Gouging
Cintra, the company that controls 82 percent of the domestic flights in Mexico, is being accused of abusing its near monopoly by charging exorbitant fares and hurting the travel and tourism industries. C4.
 
Bad Bosses and Goop Can Teach Lessons
Geraldine Laybourne, the chairwoman of Oxygen Media, says people can learn a lot from bad bosses and cites the benefits of playing with plastic goop at business meetings. Management, page C12.

HEADLINE: Priest vs. 'Big Chicken' In Fight for Labor Rights

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: GEORGETOWN, Del.

 BODY:
It was an incongruous sight, the white-haired priest in black shirt and white collar, standing in an immense poultry house filled with thousands of clucking birds and the acrid stench of manure.
The priest, the Rev. Jim Lewis, was in this unlikely place because the Episcopal Church has assigned him an unlikely mission: to improve the lives of Delaware's chicken farmers and poultry plant workers. 
 Father Lewis says his work is akin to that of the Old Testament prophets who railed against injustices, but the state's powerful poultry industry describes him as a one-man plague.
Day after day, as he muddies his feet in manure meeting with embittered farmers and poultry workers, Father Lewis harbors no doubt that he is doing the Lord's work in confronting an industry he calls Big Chicken.
"My big beef with Big Chicken is it's a greedy industry," said Father Lewis, who is based in this southern Delaware town at the hub of the region's poultry industry. "Greed is a good old-fashioned spiritual concern."
This hard-driving clergyman, a former marine and former all-state football player, has earned the industry's opprobrium by preaching against its ways, skewering it for driving too hard a bargain with chicken farmers and workers who spend hour after hour hacking away at chicken parts in cold, damp plants.
During many of the sermons he is invited to give at churches up and down the Delaware and Maryland shore, he tosses pieces of chicken out into the congregation, and asks, "Can you see the fingerprints that are on this chicken?"
Through his unusual ministry, Father Lewis, 64, has earned a reputation among religious leaders as a leading practitioner of a growing trend in which hundreds of American priests, ministers and rabbis are using their pulpits and moral stature to fight for workers, especially those on the bottom rungs.
Often his ministry seems equal parts caring and daring. He has formed an unusual multiracial alliance of plant workers, farmers and environmentalists to stand up to the powerful industry. He once angered union, industry and church leaders by helping lead a wildcat strike against a poultry plant where a worker was fired after he had a finger cut off.
He has condemned poultry companies for not providing health insurance to chicken catchers, who have the dangerous job of cramming thousands of chickens into cages each day before they are shipped to slaughter. He organized a one-day visit by five members of Congress, who heard workers complain of injuries from chopping chickens all day long and of wages so low that they qualified for welfare.
Father Lewis's coalition, the Delmarva Poultry Justice Alliance, has become one of the most powerful voices in one of the nation's leading poultry areas, the Delmarva Peninsula in eastern Delaware, Maryland and Virginia, which produces 3 billion pounds of chicken each year thanks to the peninsula's 2,700 chicken farms, 11 poultry-processing plants and 15,000 poultry workers.
The alliance includes African-American chicken catchers, Hispanic slaughterhouse workers and white chicken farmers who say poultry companies like Perdue Farms squeeze them so hard that they barely break even. It also includes environmentalists who say the mountains of chicken manure the industry produces are fouling the Chesapeake Bay and nearby rivers.
George Cmael, executive director of the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, an environmental group, said: "Rev. Lewis is something else. He has the ability to tell a compelling story and to bring what others may view as disparate interests together."
When Father Lewis stopped in at Carole Morison's farm in Pocomoke City, Md., while doing his alliance-building, she gave him an earful about the poultry corporations.
The industry exploits her by not paying enough for her chickens, she said. She complained that her family farm had lost money the past two years, after she and her husband invested $220,000 to build two 500-foot-long chicken houses a decade ago. To make ends meet, her husband has had to take a full-time job with a farm equipment dealer.
Perdue periodically gives her 54,000 chicks a day old. Then over seven weeks she raises them to be five-pound broilers. Perdue pays her 16 cents a bird, after subtracting the cost of Perdue-supplied chicken feed and medicine.
Mrs. Morison, who lives with her husband and son in a $20,000 trailer, said Perdue also required her to spend $30,000 on a metal manure shed to reduce the runoff of manure into nearby streams.
"The manure shed is worth more than the house we live in because I can't afford more for a house," she said.
Mrs. Morison said Perdue Farms also told her to install a $15,000 drinking system for her chickens, adding that if she did not agree, she risked losing her contract and being blackballed by the industry. To add insult to financial injury, she said Perdue's engineers declared that system obsolete three years after she installed it.
"It's indentured servitude, that's what it is," she said. "This is a David and Goliath situation, and the poultry alliance has given us a voice to help level the playing field."
Father Lewis first showed up at the Morisons' door in 1995, soon after the Episcopal Bishop of Delaware hired him. That bishop, Cabell Tennis, now retired, said he wanted Father Lewis to help those working in the chicken industry, to go beyond giving care and charity and to work to change social structures in a way that would help eliminate poverty.
But industry officials often accuse Father Lewis of being deaf to their side of the story. Bill Satterfield, executive director of the Delmarva Poultry Industry Association, said, "The church certainly has a role in improving the quality of life, but they're not the only ones who have concerns about the quality of life."
He said only a small minority of chicken growers supported the alliance. Father Lewis countered that many growers supported it but were too intimidated to speak out.
Perdue asked Mr. Satterfield to respond on its behalf. He called Father Lewis's attacks inflammatory and often inaccurate. "The industry is providing employment to thousands of people and is helping feed the world with a safe product," he said. "I don't understand what he means when he says we're a greedy industry. Our industry pays a competitive wage. They hire people who otherwise would be unemployed. Many Hispanic workers come to this area because of the opportunities this industry has provided."
Bishop Tennis sounded pleased and vindicated by these complaints. "If I were the industry I'd probably have those feelings," he said. "That's just another way of saying, 'We're uncomfortable.' The church's function is to make institutions uncomfortable. If we weren't making ourselves and others uncomfortable, we're probably not doing our job."

HEADLINE: Bush Says G.O.P. Stresses Wealth At Expense of Tackling Social Ills

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas used a speech about his proposals for improving education yesterday to issue a pointed critique of the Republican Party, saying it had put too much emphasis on economic wealth and too little on social problems.
It was the second time in less than a week that Mr. Bush, the front-runner for the Republican Presidential nomination, had cast many fellow Republicans as insensitive and had seemed to be establishing some distance from them. Last Thursday, Mr. Bush accused House Republicans of trying to "balance the budget on the backs of the poor." 
Yesterday, addressing hundreds of people in a hotel in midtown Manhattan, the Governor digressed somewhat from a discussion of his education proposals, including a major expansion of charter schools, to offer a sort of apology for the priorities that many Republicans have set and for the image they have projected.
"Too often, my party has focused on the national economy, to the exclusion of all else, speaking a sterile language of rates and numbers, C.B.O. and G.N.P.," Mr. Bush said, referring to the Congressional Budget Office and the gross national product.
"Of course we want vigor and growth in our economy," the Governor continued. "But there are human problems that persist in the shadow of affluence. And the strongest argument for conservative ideals -- for responsibility and accountability and the virtues of our tradition -- is that they lead to greater justice, less suffering, more opportunity."
Mr. Bush's usual stump speech and his public remarks almost always feature the assertion that he is a new kind of Republican -- a "compassionate conservative," to use his slogan. Again and again, he advocates "prosperity with a purpose" and declares that "prosperity alone is simple materialism."
But any rebuke to fellow Republicans is usually implicit. Mr. Bush's comments yesterday veered toward the confrontational, and the reprimand was decidedly explicit. He seemed to challenge fellow Republicans not only to look beyond the bottom line when assessing the state of the nation, but also to devote as much energy to problem solving as to stern moralizing.
"Too often, on social issues, my party has painted an image of America slouching toward Gomorrah," the Governor said.
A few sentences later, in another swipe at his fellow Republicans, Mr. Bush added, "Too often, my party has confused the need for limited government with a disdain for government itself."
Mr. Bush's speech was the second of three that he plans to deliver this year on education, an issue that he is making a cornerstone of his campaign. And in it, he outlined a plan for the Federal Government to give states much more discretion over how they spend Federal dollars, to create financial incentives for states to improve student performance and to pave the way for the proliferation of charter schools.
Mr. Bush's support of charter schools extended to a promise that if he is elected President, he will allocate $300 million over two years to guarantee $3 billion worth of private loans for the establishment of new charter schools.
With that proposal and others, Mr. Bush was advocating an increase in Federal spending on education, a commitment sure to displease some conservative Republicans.
His critical appraisal of some of them came during a campaign swing through a state that has favored the Democratic nominee in the last three Presidential elections. To compete effectively in New York, Governor Bush may well have to appeal to moderate Democrats.
Karen P. Hughes, a spokeswoman for Mr. Bush, said that he was merely continuing to flesh out the meaning of compassionate conservatism and that it was mostly coincidental that he was doing so in New York.
Another adviser to Mr. Bush said that the Governor spoke out so forcefully on this occasion because he sensed that Republicans lacked credibility on the issue of education and that he wanted his thoughts and concerns to be taken seriously.
"Stylistically and thematically," said the adviser, who spoke on condition of anonymity, "he's saying, 'I'm not like a lot of Republicans you've gotten used to hearing from and who seem willing to throw in the towel on your schools.' "
"In the past, our message has been one of abolishing the Department of Education," the adviser continued, referring to the Republican Party. "Let's face it: if you look at the polls, we're badly trailing the Democrats on this issue."
Even so, Mr. Bush's remarks about the Republican Party drew fresh attention to the question of what sort of relationship will develop between Mr. Bush and Congressional Republicans, who arguably have a greater interest in being associated with him than he does in being linked to them.
Some expressed anger last week after Mr. Bush expressed his opposition to their plan to balance the budget by spreading out payments of a tax credit, usually given in one lump sum, that primarily benefits working-class Americans.
But the reaction yesterday to Mr. Bush's latest remarks was muted.
"From time to time, the ideas and positions of the Republican front-runner may differ from the positions taken by House Republicans," said Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority whip, who accused Mr. Bush last week of not understanding much about the way Congress operates.
"This should not be interpreted as a conflict or infighting," Mr. DeLay said yesterday.
Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois said, "I'm not sure we've been on the road to Gomorrah." But then he said Congressional Republicans agreed with much of the philosophy behind Mr. Bush's proposals on education.
Democrats questioned whether Mr. Bush's ruminations on what he sees as the shortcomings of the Republican Party were a sort of camouflage, meant to distract people from the content of his education proposals, which they said were not much different from the suggestions made by many other Republicans.
Sandra Feldman, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, said after Mr. Bush's speech yesterday: "The rhetoric sure is different. But when you boil it down, it's not new ideas."
Ms. Feldman said she was particularly troubled by Mr. Bush's professed penchant for using public money for private ventures, in the form of charter schools, which she said would be more difficult for the Government to monitor.
Last month, when Mr. Bush made his first education speech as a candidate for national office, he advocated taking some Federal aid away from failing schools in poor areas and giving it to parents so that they could use it for private tuition or tutors. It was essentially a voucher plan, although he did not word it that way.
The Governor's speech yesterday expanded on his promotion of alternatives to public schools where student test scores show no improvement. He said that the Federal Government should require all students in the third to eighth grades to be tested yearly in reading and math, and that Fedral aid to schools should reflect the results.
"We will praise and reward success -- and I promise you, I will shine a spotlight of shame on failure."

HEADLINE: Campus Housing in Short Supply

BYLINE: By JULIE FLAHERTY 

 BODY:
The Howard Johnson Hotel in Boston's Kenmore Square has all the trappings of a AAA-approved lodging: piped in elevator music, key-card doors, burgundy carpeting.
But inside her fifth-floor room, a guest, Joanna Janczurewicz, has thrown off the lavender bedspread in favor of the black-and-white comforter and cowhide-print pillow she brought from home. She has rewallpapered much of the room with band posters, magazine clippings and pictures of friends. Dead red roses hang from the framed generic hotel prints, which she has mercifully covered over. Ms. Janczurewicz, with her ebony-lined eyes and dyed multicolor hair, does not quite match the HoJo's decor either. But, hey, this is her dormitory now. 
 Ms. Janczurewicz is one of 380 Boston University students who began the fall semester living at hotels in Boston and in Cambridge, symptoms of a shortage of dormitory space that is affecting colleges not only in Boston but nationwide. With increased enrollments from the children of the baby boomers, and a tight housing market brought on by a strong economy, more students want to live on campus, but there is not room for all of them, university officials said.
For the second year in a row, the University of Maryland's College Park campus has 126 students bunking in a local hotel. Dillard University in New Orleans had to put 45 students into the nearby Ramada Inn; nine other students are enjoying Southern hospitality down the street at the Gentilly Bed and Breakfast.
But Boston, which is home to about 67,000 students each year, faces the biggest crunch. With a 2 percent vacancy rate in the city, upperclassmen are skipping the hassle of finding their own apartments and asking to stay on campus. The trend has pushed the University of Massachusetts at Amherst into paying for rooms for about 100 students during the first week of classes at an on-campus hotel, and Northeastern University into putting up 80 students at the Y.M.C.A. and hundreds of others at leased apartments off-campus.
The University of Massachusetts had its hotel dwellers into real dormitories by the first weekend of the semester, although 150 others were still living in residence hall lounges that had been converted to makeshift bedrooms.
"They tend to be doubles, three or four times larger than a regular room -- corner rooms with a balcony and wonderful view," said a university spokeswoman, Barbara Pitoniak. Although about 250 students have been moved from those spaces, Ms. Pitoniak said, "the people that are in there now are very happy to stay there through the semester."
They also get a rebate of about $150 per semester on the average double room rate of $1,319.
Boston University found campus rooms for 124 of its hotel guests in the first two weeks of classes, but Ms. Janczurewicz and her roommate, both freshmen, will have a hotel address through the fall, and are quite content to keep their full-size beds. The digs are much nicer than the rooms in Warren Towers, the enormous dormitory Ms. Janczurewicz toured last year. "They are like prison rooms," she said.
The overhead heating lamp in their bathroom gives off a nightclublike red glow. Because there is no campus security checking identification cards, "We're the party room," Ms. Janczurewicz said. "We have people here all the time."
Colleges make educated guesses about how many of the students they accept will actually attend, but that gets trickier as enrollments rise. And some colleges play the odds like overbooked airlines, knowing that attrition will free up residence hall rooms during the semester.
"For the university, it is better financially to carry the cost of hotel space than it is to carry the cost of empty dormitory space," said a Boston University spokesman, Kevin Carleton.
The university, which has housed students at the Howard Johnson since the 1980's, bought the hotel in 1992 with the intention of developing the land, but left management to Howard Johnson. Campus housing is so tight that the university, which once used the hotel only for emergency housing, now keeps 125 rooms for students to live in the entire semester.
The university pays for two and a half floors of the seven-floor hotel -- prices range from $145 to $210 per night -- while the public uses the other four and half floors. The students pay $5,020 for the school year, the same amount they would pay for a double room on-campus.
Colleges try to give the hotels a dormitory flavor. Across from the ice machine on each floor of the Howard Johnson, a bulletin board lists the university's on-call resident assistant. The University of Maryland named the part of the hotel it leases Terrapin Tower after the university mascot.
Dillard University learned not to house freshmen in hotels. "This is a transition period in their lives and we would rather they made this transition under the watchful eye of in loco parentis," said Michael Lomax, the president of Dillard.
Northeastern has been housing students at the campus Y.M.C.A. for years. The space is reserved for transfer and older students who have outgrown late-night partying in the halls.
Eric Blomstrom, 28, said he was thankful for his placement at the Y after hearing about the housing scarcity at other campuses.
"I was like, great," he said. "It's perfect. It's a single. I know it's very difficult to get a single at any school." Besides, with message boards on the doors and 38 men on the floor sharing two showers, "it does feel a little like a dorm," he said. Students have their own elevator and security desk, but no free access to the health club.
Mr. Blomstrom's room, with its view of a concrete courtyard, is a far cry from Northeastern's newest residence hall, West Village. The stylish building is the first phase of a $100 million housing project that will add 1,680 beds when it is completed in 2001. A flashy high-rise, West Village is the university's first housing addition in years in a city where institutional expansion has always been a sore issue with neighborhood residents.
Backed by the mayor's endorsement and better relations with the town, Boston University will open an $84 million residence hall, its first since the 1960's, and Harvard is planning a $40 million housing project for 554 graduate students. When it is completed in 2002, the project will be Harvard's first housing construction in over a decade.
Massachusetts Institute of Technology will require all freshmen to live on campus starting in 2001, the same year it will complete a new undergraduate residence hall with 350 beds. But with 386 freshmen living in independent space -- mostly fraternities and sororities -- and 140 others assigned to "crowded rooms," an M.I.T. spokesman, Bob Sales, said, "If the numbers stay the same, it won't take care of the overflow."
Ms. Janczurewicz said she would like to get to know the students on her hotel floor, but hanging out in the halls is forbidden, and only a pizza box outside one door is a sign of the thriving college life inside. For now, though, her room has a real dormitory feel, right down to the hole in the bathroom ceiling and the crack in the mirror.
And that daily maid service that makes her classmates so jealous? "Now it's only two or three times a week," she said.

HEADLINE: Auto Workers In Canada Avert Strike

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 5

 BODY:
With less than two hours to spare before a threatened strike, the DaimlerChrysler Corporation reached an agreement with the Canadian Auto Workers union on a new three-year contract covering the company's 13,800 workers in Canada.
Under the agreement, DaimlerChrysler's factory workers will get annual raises of 3 percent on top of their cost-of-living adjustments; a $1,200 (Canadian), or $818 (United States), annual holiday bonus; a $1,000 (Canadian) signing bonus; an $800 (Canadian) tuition reimbursement for workers' children, and a $2,000 (Canadian) child care benefit. 
 The Canadian union president Basil E. Hargrove announced the deal at 10:25 P.M. and called it "an excellent package." The union had threatened to strike at midnight.
The Canadian union will begin labor talks later this month with the General Motors Corporation. The union had already reached a deal with the Ford Motor Company on a new labor contract.
Meanwhile, the United Automobile Workers union today gave Ford Motor a Friday deadline to reach an agreement with the union on a new labor contract or watch its 101,033 factory workers in the United States walk out on strike.
The union strike threat gives Ford until 3:30 Friday afternoon to find common ground with the union. The company expressed hope that a strike could be avoided. "We're optimistic," said Edward K. Miller, Ford's manager of corporate news. "This is a normal part of the collective bargaining process and there is no reason to believe we can't reach an agreement by Friday."
The U.A.W. union did not return calls seeking comment. Talks between the union and Ford recessed this afternoon, and are expected to resume Wednesday morning.
Labor contracts between the nation's 400,000 unionized auto workers and Ford, G.M. and DaimlerChrysler were set to expire Sept. 14, but were extended indefinitely as the union continued negotiations on new contracts with the companies. DaimlerChrysler and G.M. have already reached agreements with the union without strikes -- or even the threat of strikes.
But the union today gave Ford the required 72-hour notice that it would end the current contract Friday afternoon.
DaimlerChrysler workers already ratified their four-year contract, and G.M. workers are scheduled to vote next week on a similar contract. It is expected to win near-unanimous approval. Both contracts call for a $1,350 signing bonus and annual raises of 3 percent above inflation.
Ford workers are expected to get the same generous raises, but workers have been upset by Ford's plans to spin off its Visteon auto parts subsidiary. The 23,500 union members working at Visteon have been nervous that their jobs would not be as secure as those at Ford.

HEADLINE: 14-Hour Days? They Have Other Ideas

BYLINE: By JULIE FLAHERTY 

 BODY:
Like any recent law school graduate, Joseph was eager to make a good impression on his new employers. "I showed up at 9 A.M. my first day here and left at 2 A.M.," he said of his job at a large Boston firm.
But after months of 14-hour days, he began to think that the six-figure salary was not worth it. "I lost all my friends," he said. He had plenty of money, but no time to pay his bills. Joseph, 28, asked that his last name not be used for this article because now, in his fourth year with the firm, he plans to leave his job, and the legal profession, in the spring. 
 Young lawyers, the grunt workers of the trade, are abandoning their employers in droves, either moving to other firms or jobs or leaving the profession altogether. At large firms, 44 percent of new associates leave within three years and 73 percent within six, according to a 1998 study by the National Association for Law Placement. Paula Patton, the group's executive director, said the study was the first to track departures. But, she said, firms around the country almost unanimously tell the same tale: The problem has become much worse over the last few years.
"So many had cut back on their hiring during the recession" in 1990 and 1991, she said. "They started filling their ranks by recruiting associates from other firms. That's how the cycle got started."
Stephen Dannhauser, the executive partner of Weil, Gotshal & Manges L.L.P. in New York, said his 700-member firm -- like its competitors -- has been losing employees at a high rate since then. He blames the thriving economy, which has created demand for lawyers in places where it hardly existed before.
"The opportunities are not just to move to another law firm, but to go to an investment bank, to go to an equity firm, to go in-house with a major organization," he said. The situation became so severe a year ago that Weil, Gotshal formed a committee to figure out how to keep younger lawyers happy.
Powering the trend is the profession's hunger for billable hours. To offset starting salaries that now average $85,000 nationwide, big firms often push the new hires to work upward of 2,000 billable hours a year. Add the time consumed by meetings and administrative tasks, and many put in 70 hours a week or more.
"Lawyers are getting burned out," said R. Robert Popeo, chairman of Mintz, Levin, Cohn, Ferris, Glovsky & Popeo P.C., a 300-member firm in Boston.
Lauren Stiller Rikleen, former president of the Boston Bar Association, says law firms have become much more competitive in the last 20 years, raising workloads and stress levels alike. A study this year by the association found that a major reason for departures is the desire of younger lawyers to spend more time with their families. Yet they hestitate to buck the workaholoic cultures of their workplaces. Instead, the study said, "They vote with their feet."
Not just lawyers have itchy feet, of course. Accountants, who also work around the billable hour, and high-technology professionals are hard to recruit, much less retain. And the tight job market is encouraging a lot of jumping around in general.
But law firms say they feel particularly beleaguered. The odds of making partner have dwindled over the years, increasing the incentive to chase after bigger salaries elsewhere. Indeed, one-fourth of young associates polled in August by The New York Law Journal said they expected to change jobs in the next 18 months, and 40 percent said they would eventually switch careers.
But not all are living for money. Consider Juliana Rice, who graduated from law school in 1993 and joined a 13-lawyer firm. When she became pregnant a few months later, a partner told her, "This couldn't have happened at a worse time." And when she returned from maternity leave, the partners made cutting comments about her habit of leaving at 5:30 P.M. to see her daughter before bedtime, even though she had been in the office for 10 hours.
After three and a half years, she took a job, with a pay cut but fewer hours, in the Massachusetts Attorney General's office. Now, she said, "Nobody looks at me funny when I leave at 5 P.M. to pick up my daughter."
To stem the flow of talent, some firms are offering three-month assignments in Europe, sabbaticals or tuition for continuing education. Barry Wolf, a member of the new retention committee at Weil, Gotshal & Manges, said his firm planned new policies to make young associates happier. "Now we're going to make retention equal with recruiting," he said.
Other firms are offering "longevity bonuses" to associates who stick around. Shearman & Sterling in New York, for example, which lost 24 percent of its associates in 1997, recently announced $45,000 bonuses to associates who stay on for three years. It said it expected the departure rate to be cut almost in half this year. Even so, Ms. Patton of the National Association for Law Placement said, money "is not ultimately the thing that will keep them if they are otherwise disconsolate about their workplace."
To be sure, plenty of people are willing to slave away, just as their forebears did. John B. Towers, who graduated from the New York University Law School this year, listened to the anxieties of many of his classmates and heard horror stories of "sweatshop" firms. He is now in his fourth week with Ropes & Gray in Boston, and he said he went into the deal with his eyes open. "I'm not under the illusion that anybody is going to pay me $90,000 a year to work a 9-to-5 job my first year out of school," he said. "I will work as much as I'm required to. Whether or not I can sustain that for a period of 4 to 40 years, only time will tell."

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (90%);

HEADLINE: TRENDS;
For Manufacturing Jobs, Boom Towns Past and Future

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY JR. 

 BODY:
Smaller cities in the South and West have enjoyed the fastest growth in factory jobs since the late 1980's, led by Boise, Idaho, where Micron Technology employs 9,000, a research report shows. Boise is expected to stay hot as its high-technology boom fuels traditional industries.
 In Las Vegas, Nev., a population explosion has created endless jobs in industries from bakeries to contractors that cater to all those new households. 
 Factories are humming in Austin, Tex., now a serious industrial town, according to Nestor Terleckyj, president of NPA Data Services, the research company. He noted that state capitals like Boise and Austin, along with university towns like Bloomington, Ill., and Colorado Springs, have become fertile grounds for manufacturing.
 A projected job surge in Punta Gorda, Fla., a retirement community, is a statistical quirk stemming from the creation of a free-trade zone at the local airport, town officials say. In Naples, Fla., light manufacturing is growing because of expansion at Shaw Aero, a producer of aviation components, and a new Tyton Hellermann plastics plant. In addition, Robbin Koch, an economic development spokeswoman, says a lot of corporate chief executives have bought second homes in Naples, and now they're thinking how to get their business moved here.
 ROBERT D. HERSHEY JR.

HEADLINE: Obuchi Picks Aide Linked To Buddhists For Cabinet

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi shuffled his Cabinet today, adding a member of a Buddhist-backed political party to give his Government the support of the largest coalition in Japan in more than 40 years.
Japanese political analysts say the addition of the New Komeito Party to the coalition will permit Mr. Obuchi to push through rapidly a series of major bills on Japan's economy and its role in the world. 
 The most dramatic would let Japan participate in international peacekeeping operations and defend itself more strongly against military attack. Since its defeat in World War II, a Constitution written by the United States prohibited most military activities.
But in recent years Japan's refusal to participate in international peacekeeping efforts has drawn criticism from the United States and other allies, especially in regional crises like the recent turmoil in East Timor.
The other expected initiatives include badly needed changes in the financing of nursing care for the elderly and social welfare.
New Komeito is the political arm of one of the largest and most controversial religious groups, the lay Buddhist organization known as Soka Gakkai.
The expansion of the coalition to include the group occurred only after weeks of negotiations that threatened to rupture the Liberal Democratic Party's existing coalition.
Although Soka Gakkai maintains that it is independent, many Japanese suspect that it is dominated by Soka Gakkagi, its Buddhist parent organization and its shadowy honorary chairman, Daisuki Ikeda.
Mr. Obuchi has been riding a wave of unexpectedly good news like an apparent upturn in the long-depressed economy and the steady but not unrelated strength in his approval ratings.
This morning, most newspaper readers rose to find him smiling triumphantly in photographs with his new coalition partners.
Although, the Cabinet reshuffle brought about a near wholesale turnover of the Government, Mr. Obuchi retained his top economic advisers, including the Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa.
But Mr. Obuchi replaced the chief of the Financial Reconstruction Commission, Hakuo Yanagisawa, who was widely respected among Western banking analysts for his handling of problems in the financial system. He was succeeded by Michio Ochi, a former Economic Planning Minister. Page C4.
Among the new appointments are Yohei Kono as Foreign Minister. Mr. Kono is a former Deputy Prime Minister who was also Foreign Minister in a previous Government.
Notwithstanding Mr. Obuchi's newly strengthened parliamentary position, many political analysts here say there are still threatening clouds on the horizon.
The most immediate involves perceptions that the Government mishandled the accident last week at a nuclear-fuel reprocessing plant.
Japanese press reports focused abundantly on the bureaucratic bungling of the emergency response that kept Mr. Obuchi from learning of the accident on Thursday until two hours after it had occurred. For much of that time, Mr. Obuchi was out to lunch.
Most accounts made it appear that the Prime Minister and his top aides continued to be more preoccupied with negotiations over the new Cabinet than with the nuclear disaster.
"This was a disaster that may have major consequences on their future nuclear policy, but one wonders just how seriously this is being taken," said John Neuffer, a political analyst with Mitsui Marine Research Institute.
Mr. Obuchi's longer-range threat in terms of public opinion arrives, though, from the strong opposition in many quarters to the entry of what many Japanese consider a religious party into politics. Although his own poll numbers are at their highest level ever, recent surveys indicate that up to 51 percent of voters oppose the Buddhist-related party's entry into the coalition.
The expansion of the coalition to include Komeito nearly backfired on Mr. Obuchi, who faced strong opposition within his own party and from his other coalition partner, the smaller more conservative Liberal Party.
"If Komeito were outside of the Government, the price of gaining their cooperation would be higher, and that is why Obuchi has invited them in," said Seizaburo Sato, deputy director of the National Graduate Institute of Policy Studies. "But Komeito is regarded suspiciously, because it is not organized like other parties. It is dominated by one individual."

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about the appointment of a Japanese Cabinet member who belongs to a party backed by a Buddhist organization misspelled the given name of the honorary president of the organization. He is Daisaku Ikeda, not Daisuki. The article also misspelled the name of the organization at one point. It is Soka Gakkai, not Gakkagi.

HEADLINE: Charity Concerts to Go on Internet

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT 

 BODY:
WHEN the curtain rises Saturday afternoon on Netaid, a series of international benefit concerts to raise money for world anti-poverty programs, pop idols like David Bowie, Sting and Sean "Puffy" Combs are scheduled to perform. But the real star of the show is more likely to be the Internet.
For years, audiences at events like "We Are The World" and "Farm Aid" have gathered and listened to wealthy entertainers sing, play and plead for the more fortunate to help out the less so. But after the last note dissolves into history, the public's commitment to the cause of the day usually evaporates quickly. 
 Netaid's principal creators and organizers, the United Nations Development Program and Cisco Systems, are planning to make the 10-hour event the exception. To do that, they say, they will take advantage of the Internet's ability to be informative, immediate and intimate.
"We want to use the computer to help change how the world looks at poverty and motivate people to help," said Djibril Diallo, public affairs director for the United Nations agency, which began examining ways of combining music, high technology and altruism more than a year ago.
As the Internet broadens its reach, Amnesty International, Habitat for Humanity and other humanitarian and philanthropic groups have been turning to what may be the planet's biggest soapbox, hoping to raise money materials and find volunteers.
In the case of the United Nations agency, which has the stated mission of eradicating extreme poverty, the Web site (www.Netaid.org) is a clearing house of information on the state of world poverty and the agency's programs as well as a means of raising money.
"The difference between this and earlier concerts is that we created a vehicle for people to come back, not just on the night of the concert with the one check they write," said Mark Malloch Brown, the new administrator of the the development program. "But instead, here's a site they're going to come back to time after time."
Using techniques and technologies more commonly found on sites devoted to electronic commerce, the site, which was opened last month with President Clinton, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and Nelson Mandela, South Africa's former President, logging on, is expected to make global philanthropy more efficient, its designers say.
Netaid's organizers say they are hoping to draw millions of people to the site by using it for a Webcast of the concerts being held Saturday at Giants Stadium in New Jersey, Wembley Stadium in London and Palais des Nations in Geneva. While the concerts will also be broadcast over a global network of conventional radio and television stations, the Webcast is scheduled to offer exclusive interviews and peeks backstage.
To accomplish the task, the site, created through a partnership led by Cisco Systems with Akamai Technologies and KPMG, is expected to use more than 125,000 simultaneous live streams to reach an anticipated on-line audience of more than 10 million people, said Douglas Graham, a partner with KPMG, a New York-based professional services firm that designed the site.
The largest previous Webcast was a lingerie fashion show last winter done by Victoria's Secret using 12,000 live streams. That number proved inadequate, leaving throngs of potential viewers unable to view the show. By contrast, Mr. Graham said, the Netaid site has the capacity to handle enormous amounts of Internet traffic, including 60 million hits an hour, and process 1,000 donations a second. The site, which is built on a network created by 1,500 servers in more than 90 data centers around the world, is prepared to handle a billion hits, Mr. Graham said.
Over time, Mr. Malloch Brown said, the Netaid site could be used to help give contributors a clearer accounting of how donations are used. "We're looking at developing reporting systems where they'll be able to log on and check how their money is being used by a set of projects," he said.
Larry Lang, vice president of service-provider marketing for Cisco Systems, which through its corporation and foundation has donated $20 million to Netaid, said the site might soon have a high-tech, active matching system born in the financial markets.
The system will permit groups and people with particular needs to register them in a Netaid database. It will also allow people who are willing to donate particular skills or materials to register them in the database. Technology that is used to match buyers and sellers in the financial world could then match those in need with those willing to fill those needs by introducing one to the other by way of automatic E-mail messages.
"One thing that is good about this effort," Mr. Lang said, referring to the Netaid project, "is that it reminds people that the Internet is a powerful tool to amplify human capabilities and to demonstrate the better sides of our nature."

HEADLINE: In Cuba, Seeds of a Design Renaissance

BYLINE: By FRANCES ANDERTON 

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
IF one thinks of architecture in Cuba today, it is of splendid but decaying Colonial buildings floating like the ghosts of grand dowagers through the movie "Buena Vista Social Club." Or the freshly primped, restored buildings in Old Havana. Visitors will also find the capital bursting with 20th-century buildings in a spirited Cuban fusion of international and tropical styles: Art Deco movie theaters, streamline Moderne apartments, sassy 1950's hotels in Morris Lapidus Modern and, crowning them all, the Expressionist art schools of the 60's, once as ripe as mangoes in their sensuality and revolutionary spirit.
But where is the attention-seeking new architecture, the kind that has graced the global architectural stage in the last 20 years? It is mostly nonexistent. 
 The last three decades have seen Cuba's amazing architectural heritage yield to the utilitarian and architects recede into the shadows. As Julio Cesar Perez, a professor of design at Jose Antonio Echeverria City University in Havana, put it, "There is no Michael Graves here, no Frank Gehry, no Philip Johnson." There is no machinery promoting new architects and new buildings. Architects work for state firms, largely on mundane tourist structures. The few who work on individual commissions often do not attach their names publicly to the projects so as not to call attention to themselves.
With state salaries of roughly $15 a month, Cuba's architects have had little wherewithal to dream. Though at the top of the pay scale, they can barely afford to make blueprints or take taxis to the building site, let alone buy foreign architecture magazines. And they must deal with shortages of materials and poor craftsmanship.
But in recent months, a generation of Cuban architects pressing for change say they are scenting the whiff of a renaissance. A modish new restaurant, A Prado y Neptuno, designed by Roberto Gottardi, opened early this year in Old Havana. A striking new hotel, the Packard, fusing a masonry base with a sleek steel roof and a huge exterior ceramic mural, is to be built nearby, by two talented young architects, Oscar Garcia, 36, and Teresa Martin, 32. A remodeling of a bank on swank Fifth Avenue will offer a lively cocktail of tapering roof, curving elevations and sloping canopies that echo the Los Angeles school of sculptural design. And a once-influential magazine, Arquitectura Cuba, has restarted. "There was a void between the late 60's and Mr. Gottardi's new restaurant, but now, there is something in the air in the architectural mood," said Emilio Castro, an architect and graphic artist whose wall designs adorn A Prado y Neptuno.
In general, the state has taken the view that "we don't want to insert new buildings into Old Havana until architects develop the right sensibility," said Gina Rey, director of the Group for the Integral Development of Havana, an urban planning authority. Its philosophy was "save first, then bring in the new," Ms. Rey added. But with the approval of the Hotel Packard this week, and a thumbs up for A Prado y Neptuno in the state newspaper, Granma, contemporary architecture seems to be getting a Government endorsement.
In a series of conversations with Emilio Castro and several other Cuban architects, they explained how over the last 30 years they saw the role of the architect change from artist-builder to technician. "It was not about style; it was about the whole structure of architectural practice," said Eduardo Luis Rodriguez, editor of Arquitectura Cuba and author of "Havana Guide: Modern Architecture, 1925-1965" (to be published by Princeton Architectural Press in February).
After Fidel Castro took power in 1959, about two-thirds of Cuba's architects left the island, said Raul Gonzalez Romero, a professor at City University and a practicing architect since the 1950's. Those who chose to remain had to quit private practice to work for the state. In its exuberant early years, the state commissioned poetic civic structures like the five art schools, which though decayed are open to the public today, and an ambitious social building program. Even now, Mr. Gonzalez's face lights up as he describes how in 1961, architecture students were sent into the field to work with farmers on designing and building an agricultural cooperative.
But by the late 1960's, a few years after the abrupt termination of the arts schools (originally commissioned by Fidel Castro and designed by Ricardo Porro, Vittorio Garatti and Mr. Gottardi), the Government ceased to commission artistic civic architecture.
Twenty years of mass construction of much needed -- though badly built -- pre-fabricated social housing, schools and libraries followed. Architecture education during this era focused on practical, problem-solving projects and very little on the art of design. "We had 40 hours of instruction in space, form and color in five years," Ms. Martin, a recent architecture graduate, said.
After the opening of Cuba to foreign investment at the end of the cold war, a decade of bland international hotels and convention and shopping centers followed. They now employ 90 percent of Cuba's architects, Ms. Martin estimated, but the assignments offer little chance for a personal style.
Many architects still become frustrated and leave. Ana Karakadze, 25, a Cuban interior designer who worked on hotels in the tourist sea resort of Varadero before bolting for Miami six months ago, said she found that "when you you try to be individual" the state firms that deal with the investors "start saying no."
"You've got to do what the foreign people want you to do," Ms. Karakadze added. "You start feeling like you are a foreigner in your own country." Ms. Karakadze, who now works in Coral Gables, Fla., says she believes many Cuban architects who have left feel as she does, "that in Cuba you don't have perspective or hope because you always have to do what the Government says." She added, "Even to buy doors the Government has to decide."
BUT others who have stayed are feeling the winds of change. They point to A Prado y Neptuno on the ground floor of a late 19th-century building on the patrician Paseo del Prado. It was designed by Mr. Gottardi, 73, a gentle Italian who fell in love with the Socialist ideology of Cuba nearly 40 years ago. He is probably best known for his design of the School of Dramatic Arts, an intriguing "city" of spare, Louis Kahn-like structures in a network of slender alleyways reminiscent of his native Venice.
A Prado y Neptuno was the brainchild of Eusebio Leal, famed city historian and director of the restoration of Old Havana. It is owned by Habaguanex, the Cuban enterprise that is financing the restoration of Old Havana -- including a pending remodeling of a 1906 Catalonian Art Nouveau building by Emilio Castro -- with the profits from its restaurants and hotels. An Italian co-investor, Arsia International, commissioned Mr. Gottardi.
Though modest compared with the groundbreaking art schools, A Prado y Neptuno offers a modern interior in a historic district. Dining areas are decked out in a lively eclecticism that Mr. Gottardi says is part of the Cuban tradition. There are Macintosh-inspired chairs in the dining room, Roy Lichtenstein look-alike panels by Emilio Castro in the bathroom.
A mural of Mr. Gottardi's favorite designers cheekily places Philippe Starck, Frank Lloyd Wright, Carlo Scarpa, Charles Rennie Macintosh and Louis Kahn center stage (it includes his own likeness as a young man). On the exterior, there is yellow tiling like the concrete blocks in Frank Lloyd Wright's Ennis House.
Down the road at the corner of Paseo del Prado and Carcel is the site of the Packard Hotel, by Mr. Garcia and Ms. Martin for the state firm Maceo. The two, who earn $15 a month each no matter how large the project, still believe themselves to be among the lucky beneficiaries of a slowly changing system. Mr. Garcia said, "Money is welcome, but more important is to try to make contemporary architecture."
Where the Packard Hotel is the project of a state firm, Mr. Garcia's and Ms. Martin's other project, the Banco Financiero Internacional, came to them personally from the National Union of Artists and Writers of Cuba, a state association that includes selected architects. (Mr. Garcia and Ms. Martin were invited to be members this week.) The union can hand out plum assignments to favorite architects.
Cuban and foreign businesses sometimes enter into arrangements with cultural institutions, like the union, if they are seeking a more imaginative and efficient way of building than "the complex processes of the big offices of the State," as one architect said who has worked in this way. These institutions will in turn enlist an artist or architect who may get paid an unregulated fee but does not always attach his or her name publicly to the project.
These arrangements result in the odd situation where architects of some of the most adventurous new designs, like an unbuilt futuristic amusement park, are keeping quiet about their involvement, even concealing the location of the project. The designers of a shopping center under construction prefer not to declare their participation.
Yet, this system of cultural sponsorship, even if architects often remain anonymous, is countering 30 years of big, bad building by theConstruction Ministry and, Mr. Garcia says, letting a few architects contribute to "the cultural patrimony."
Not only are there few outlets for publicity, but sometimes it can get architects into trouble. One architect took a reporter to see his new building in a town away from Havana that he asked not to be identified. Suffused in the peach halo of a rainy sunset was the skeleton, the size of a large bungalow.
There was no sign saying what the structure was, or who was building there.
The architect was careful to conceal the building's real purpose -- a church, built with private financing. Rather than go through the lengthy process of trying to get a rare Government permit, he called it a residence and configured it like a house, hoping for a "change of use" permit down the line.
The architect has neither signed the drawings nor keep them in his possession. And no, thank you, the project certainly cannot be published in the United States.
Eric Owen Moss is an American architect much admired by Mr. Garcia and Ms. Martin. He visited Havana in 1996 with a group of international architects. "I think you can see something sweeping out of Cuba," he said from Los Angeles. "The noose is loosening and a sensibility that hasn't expressed itself yet will emerge. I think it's going to be some other kind of language, with a lot of power and blood in it. And I think it's moving to somewhere where they may be able to sign their names."
Professor Perez of the City University says the reason for this re-emergence of a more confident architectural voice is the 1980's generation of graduates, who are more questioning than their cold war forbears.
"We've reacted against badly built and designed buildings and bad planning," said Mr. Perez, a dapper, relentlessly peppy 40-something who speaks a snappy English.
Mr. Perez, who seems not to flail in the enervating rainy season heat, is rare in that he has his own office and designs private houses. "Designing private residences is kind of rare in Cuba," he said, "because they typify the architecture of capitalism."
But in his hometown, San Antonio de los Banos, outside Havana, Mr. Perez has built a string of houses for friends that are variations on the traditional Cuban courtyard homes, in poured concrete and concrete block rather than of stone or brick.
Mr. Perez is also part of a group calling for the preservation of Havana beyond the boundaries of the Old Havana district, especially of the arts schools, presently disintegrating in a sea of tropical vegetation. The most optimistic architects still want to pursue careers in their country.
Mr. Gottardi lives in a crumbling concrete slab building from the early 1970's. His small apartment is lined with architecture books, pictures of his wife, who is a dancer, and Che Guevara. He said that while the lack of maintenance of his buildings is frustrating, creatively, he is satisfied in Cuba. "There are many things that are not about consumerism," he said, adding, "I need other things that I find here."
ON a warm September evening, Mr. Gottardi was having drinks at Prado y Neptuno with Mr. Garcia and Ms. Martin, his former students, in front of a green and purple neon installation that celebrates the enganadora, a famous cha-cha that begins with the line "A Prado y Neptuno." They must raise their voices to compete with that of Fidel Castro, delivering a speech on the loud overhead television.
The restaurant, a part of the dollar economy of Havana, is at an intersection of the city that sees grand, patched-together, pre-revolution Chevrolets and post-revolution Ladas parade by in the daytime. Tonight, in their place, are shiny European, Korean and Japanese compact cars, the property of Cuban officials, or those who have been granted permission to buy them.
For locals, this intersection represents modernity and investment. For architects like Mr. Gottardi, Mr. Garcia and Ms. Martin, it is a place where their power, perhaps even their blood, is seeping back into architecture.
"We are trying to find a space in the culture," Mr. Garcia said.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Jumped 1.3% In August, Outpacing Estimate

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Orders to United States factories vaulted ahead in August on the strength of higher demand for airplanes and electronics in another sign of a resurgence in manufacturing.
The 1.3 percent gain in factory orders was the 12th increase in the last 15 months, the Commerce Department said today. Analysts had generally expected factory orders to rise six-tenths of a percent. Even that would have been brisk. 
 "This is a pace that insures significant production increases for the rest of the year and into 2000," said Joel Naroff of Naroff Economic Advisers.
The report, along with other recent manufacturing data, shows "that manufacturing is really healing from the global downturn from the past year or so," said Cliff Waldman, an economist at Waldman Associates in Arlington, Va.
With overseas economies in recovery, demand for the nation's manufactured goods should continue to pick up through the end of the year, economists said.
"Almost every indicator for the factory sector is firming, which suggests accelerating factory activity in the months ahead," said Merrill Lynch's senior economist, Stan Shipley.
A jump in orders for airplane and aircraft parts contributed to a 4.8 percent increase in orders for all transportation products in August, the fourth consecutive monthly gain. That was up from a 2.1 percent gain in July.
Even excluding the volatile transportation category, factory orders would have risen a solid eight-tenths of a percent in August.
Orders for electronic and other electrical equipment, a category that includes household appliances, grew by eight-tenths of a percent in August, down from an 8 percent increase the month before.
The increase in overall factory orders occurred despite a 2.1 decrease in orders for industrial machinery and equipment, the sector that includes computers. That followed a hefty 10.5 percent gain in July.
Orders for primary metals like steel lost a little ground in August, falling 1 percent after rising 3.4 percent the month before.
Orders for durable goods -- big-ticket items expected to last three years or more -- rose 1.2 percent in August, following a 4.3 percent gain in July.
Orders for nondurable goods like fuel rose 1.5 percent, with orders for petroleum, coal products, chemicals and paper registering the biggest increases. In July, orders for nondurable-goods went up two-tenths of a percent.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Fading dividends don't always mean the dawn of a recession.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
IF the measure of corporate America's financial health is its ability and willingness to increase dividends to shareholders, then you might think the country is in a recession.
The Standard & Poor's Corporation reports that 117 companies announced dividend increases in September, 10 fewer than had raised their payouts a year earlier. It was the 15th consecutive month that the number of dividend increases was down year-over-year. 
 By itself, such a long string of relative bad news is not extraordinary, even though you might expect that more and more companies would raise dividends every year simply because the number of stocks traded rises every year.
What is unusual is that the economy is doing so well even while companies are growing more reluctant to raise their dividends. This is the seventh such streak of at least 15 months since S.& P. began counting dividend increases back in 1955. In all but one of the six previous runs, there was a recession in the period. Recessions, of course, usually mean sharp falloffs in corporate profits. So a dearth of dividend increases in such periods should be expected.
The exception -- the time when companies cut back on dividend increases even as the economy continued to grow -- is the most interesting case, with perhaps the most relevance to the current situation. From August 1966 through March 1968, there was a string of 21 months in which the number of dividend increases kept falling.
That came during the longest expansion in American history, which began in 1961 and ended in 1969. The current expansion is the second longest, and will take over the top spot if, as seems likely, no recession starts by February.
Moreover, the late-1960's market, memorably called "the go-go years" by the business writer John Brooks, bears more than a passing resemblance to this one. The stock market had been going up steadily for the better part of two decades, amid increasing public participation and interest. Mutual fund managers became media stars as their funds soared through the purchase of small technology stocks that zoomed in price. There was a huge wave of mergers, many financed by issuing highly valued stock.
In 1968, however, the good days were nearing an end. It was not just that a recession hit at the end of 1969. It was that the stock market was also entering a long period of poor returns that would lead to widespread public rejection of stocks as an investment vehicle. While the major indexes would move to marginal new highs the next few years, the big gains were over. Fourteen years after 1968, in 1982, stock prices were still below the 1968 highs.
There are differences, of course. An important one now is the spread of stock options as a major form of compensation for corporate executives. Option holders benefit from price rises in the stocks of their companies, but not from dividends that are paid while they hold the options. That provides an incentive for companies to hold down dividends and, instead, distribute money to shareholders by repurchasing stock. Such stock repurchases are popular and many companies have borrowed money to buy back stock.
Another difference is that dividends are now far lower than they were in 1968, at least as a percentage of the price of stocks. In 1968, the dividend yield on the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks when the index peaked was 2.8 percent. That was, in fact, a very low figure by historical standards. But now the yield is about 1.3 percent, well below half that level.
Dividends can go so low because investors do not care much about them. It is capital gains that have made them rich, and it is the pursuit of capital gains that drives stock investments now. "Companies love this flexibility, not being tied into a fixed dividend that may be a struggle to pay," said Arnold Kaufman, the editor of Standard & Poor's Outlook, a newsletter that tracks dividends.
Of course, companies have always loved such flexibility. What is different is that investors have gradually come to believe that payouts are unimportant, and so have not fought very hard for higher payouts. "It is working quite well for everyone involved, except for those poor people who have come to depend on dividends for living expenses," commented Mr. Kaufman.
After 1968, as it became clear that capital losses were also possible, investors came to value dividends, and the pressure grew on companies to pay them. By the time the stock market hit bottom in 1974, the dividend yield on the S.& P. 500 was up to 5.8 percent. Part of the reason was that dividends had risen since 1968, but most of the change reflected a fall in stock prices.
