HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury PricesHold Steady Ahead of September Job Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were little changed yesterday as investors failed to follow through on early buying. Market participants wound up instead focusing on the employment report coming tomorrow.
The oversold condition of the market could have been a factor behind yesterday's early bounce in prices as some investors sought attractive yields, which are hovering near two-month highs. 
 Analysts said the decision by the Federal Reserve on Tuesday to leave short-term interest rates unchanged helped ease some inflation fears. Still, the central bank's indication that it is leaning toward an increase in the future is keeping economic data squarely in the spotlight.
Jack Ablin, president of Colonial Asset Management Inc. in Jacksonville, Fla., said investor sentiment traditionally played a large role in trading, "and it's that sentiment that has pushed the limit on the low side of prices over the past few days, a definite negative for bonds.
"However, near term," he said, "it has become a positive because investors probably have oversold, and that leaves some buying opportunities."
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose 2/32, to 99 13/32. Its yield was unchanged at 6.17 percent. A two-year note, on the other hand, slipped 2/32, to 99 22/32. Its yield rose to 5.79 percent from 5.76 percent on Tuesday.
"Right now, the underlying concern is with wages and labor and consumer spending," Mr. Ablin said. "People are spending at a faster clip than they are earning, which is a concern for the Fed. I don't see much happening between now and Friday, when the September employment report is released." He said a big number would hurt bonds and he was not so sure a low number would change the negative psychology of the bond market.
Analysts expect a gain of 225,000 jobs, with the unemployment rate at 4.3 percent, up from 4.2 percent in August.
Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of the fixed-income department at the J. W. Genesis Financial Corporation in Boca Raton, Fla., said the employment data had the potential to give the Fed the impetus to raise rates even before its next meeting, which is on Nov. 16. "Yesterday, the Fed issued its bias- toward-tightening warning, and in my opinion it will indeed happen."
"Today the trading was thin, with some hedge-fund selling," he added. "But in reality, market participants were basically in a wait-and-see mode."
Yesterday, the Treasury auctioned $7 billion of 29 1/2-year Treasury inflation-indexed securities, or the reopening of the 3 7/8 percent 30-year inflation-indexed bond originally issued April 15, 1999. The auction itself was on the weak side as the bid-to-cover, an indication of demand, came in at 1.92 to 1. Traders said the bonds were awarded with a high yield of 4.138 percent.

HEADLINE: Support Grows in Congress for a Pension Overhaul Plan That Would Aid High Earners

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Support is growing quickly in Congress for a vast expansion of retirement tax breaks for business owners, executives and highly paid workers, moves that Republicans and Democrats alike say would be popular with voters.
The leading proposal, known as the Portman-Cardin Pension Reform Plan, has 148 sponsors and would raise the $10,000 limit on annual tax-deductible savings in 401(k) plans to $15,000 and, for those age 50 and older, to $20,000. 
 The stated goal is to include many more employees in retirement programs by making the plans more attractive to business owners and to simplify complex rules that are designed to make sure most workers share in the benefits.
Representative Rob Portman, the Ohio Republican who is the plan's leading sponsor, says that more firms are opting for executive-only plans without tax breaks. "We need to try something new because the system we have isn't working," he said, "and we need to get more people covered."
But even the bill's co-sponsor acknowledges that it may not do that. Critics say the bill is actually little more than cover for a plan to shower new tax benefits on the rich.
One provision would allow businesses to cut pension benefits by as much as one-third for workers making less than $160,000 annually without reducing benefits for those earning more. Supporters say they expect few businesses to do that.
Norman Stein, a University of Alabama Law School pension specialist who analyzed the Portman-Cardin plan, said it "should be called the Retirement Reduction Act."
The bill's co-sponsor, Representative Ben Cardin, a Maryland Democrat, said in a speech last week that the bill might not increase the number of people who would collect retirement benefits, but it had such strong support from business that it was worth giving its provisions a try.
Easing regulations and raising savings limits would make retirement plans more attractive to business owners, he said, and should be viewed as "part of an overall strategy that will eventually cover more people."
Mr. Cardin and Representative Rob Andrews, Democrat of New Jersey, are circulating a letter among House Democrats urging them to support the bill. Mr. Andrews said "anything we do that increases contributions to retirement plans is a good thing."
Critics acknowledge tens of thousands of new retirement plans would be created if Portman-Cardin is enacted, but they fear that few lower-paid workers would benefit.
Daniel Halperin, a pension specialist at Harvard Law School, has estimated that the expanded tax breaks would let a person easily accumulate tax-deferred retirement benefits of $5 million, even if not one additional lower-paid worker got a dollar in benefits.
"This bill turns the concept of using tax benefits to expand retirement income security on its head," he said, adding that the proposal "while well intentioned and containing many good ideas, would on the whole do more harm than good."
Dianne Bennett of Buffalo, president of Hodgson, Russ, Andrews, Woods & Goodyear, the largest law firm in upstate New York, said that if the Portman-Cardin plan becomes law its likely effect "would be to expand retirement plans that benefit only owners of business and to dramatically reduce the benefits granted" to the rank and file.
Ms. Bennett, a pension specialist, cited examples from retirement plans that she has drafted for clients to show that most of the benefits already flow to a few highly paid employees, a situation that she said would worsen drastically if the proposals were enacted.
She added that "many of my clients will not like what I am saying or that I am saying it."
A senior Clinton Administration official said support for the proposal was spreading quickly among Democrats eager to tell voters that they have made an easily understandable improvement to the 401(k) plans.
The official said none of the lawmakers he had talked to seemed to understand the provisions that could harm workers.
Supporters and critics agree that the greatest need is to have more people collect benefits when they retire. Supporters have focused on how more people would be "covered" by such plans, a measure of how many people could potentially participate in a plan, rather than how many will actually collect benefits.
Both sides also agree that increasing the amounts that can be put away untaxed will encourage more savings in retirement plans. But critics say that the increase will be narrowly focused among those already saving the maximum.
Few workers are held back by the current $10,000 limit on tax-deferred 401(k) savings.
Only 4 to 11 percent of 401(k) plan participants save the maximum now, according to the Employee Benefit Research Institute, a nonprofit group in Washington whose studies are regarded as the standard for the benefits industry. Workers save an average of $3,000 each in 401(k) plans, the institute estimated.
Portman-Cardin may be included in a bill to raise the minimum wage by a dollar, to $6.15, in two steps.
The additional $10,000 that older workers could save each year would add $360,000 to a retirement nest egg of someone who is 50 years old, retires at 65 and earns historic stock market returns.
Current law generally limits the total amount that a worker and an employer together can set aside in a retirement plan to 25 percent of pay up to a maximum of $30,000 of savings. Portman-Cardin would increase that to $45,000.
Another provision would let some people sock away their entire paycheck, where it would grow untaxed until the money is withdrawn in retirement. That option would be attractive to those who can live off investment income, such as dividends and capital gains, and to those two-income families who can live on one paycheck.
Raising benefits at the top means that 62 percent of the new tax breaks would flow to people in the top 10 percent income group, analysis using the Treasury Department's economic modeling software found.
The middle fifth of households would get just 3.2 percent of the tax breaks, according to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington advocacy group for the poor, which performed the analysis.
The Portman-Cardin plan has wide support from business organizations and is similar to proposals by Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican for whom the popular tax-free Roth IRA's are named.
The provision that most concerns critics would increase the maximum annual pay that can be considered in calculating pension benefits by 47 percent, to $235,000 from $160,000.
That would let highly paid business owners increase their own pension benefits by 47 percent without raising benefits for employees earning less than $160,000.
Alternatively, the provision would allow a business owner to collect the same number of dollars from the retirement plan for himself, while cutting retirement benefits by up to one-third for everyone making less than $160,000 a year.
But James Delaplane, vice president for retirement policy at the Association of Private Pension and Welfare Plans in Washington, said market forces should discourage that type of response.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Brazilian Politician Stirs Fear and Debate on Debt

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Investors in Brazil are beginning to get nervous over the future possibility that the Government might try to renegotiate its domestic debt, which has nearly doubled in recent years.
The possibility has grown in part because the idea of a debt renegotiation has been promoted by a rising presidential candidate, Ciro Gomes, a 41-year-old former Finance Minister. He has made debt renegotiation part of a broader economic proposal that, he says, would encourage long-term growth. 
 His proposal would lengthen the maturities and lower the interest payments on the domestic debt -- the Government bonds and notes that are denominated in the Brazilian currency, the real. By doing so, Mr. Gomes said, he hoped to narrow Brazil's growing budget deficit. He would also hope to redirect money now fueling profits at financial institutions that buy high-yielding Government bonds into areas in need like education, housing and jobs.
The idea has attracted a mixture of bemusement, anger and anxiety among Brazilian financiers, especially since Mr. Gomes's rising popularity makes him one of the main contenders in the presidential election, to be held in three years.
"This is a crazy idea that would cripple the economy, creating capital flight and bringing back the risk of inflation," said David Gotlib, managing director of Deutsche Bank Asset Management's Brazilian operations. "I can only hope the gravity of doing such a thing will be perceived in time for the proposal to be withdrawn."
With the election that far in the future, many things can obviously happen in the meantime. Still, Mr. Gomes's proposal has generated energetic discussion here over the dynamics of Brazil's domestic debt.
That debt is different from debt owed by the governments in advanced economies like the United States, which are able to sell bonds with maturities of up to 30 years. Brazil, by contrast, is only able to sell bonds domestically with maturities up to five years. And the average maturity of all Brazilian Government debt is only about nine months.
The main reason for such short maturities is a reluctance by investors to buy longer-maturing bonds, given a history over the last couple of decades of the national and some state governments reneging on obligations.
From 1982 to 1990, a period of hyperinflation and economic crisis, Brazil restructured its domestic debt three times. The last of these took place by surprise shortly after Fernando Collor de Mello became president in 1990, and the Government froze and then seized bank deposits.
"Brazil's track record is not particularly stellar in this regard," said Fergus McCormick, a debt analyst at the Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Corporation.
A country's domestic debt rating is usually higher than the rating on its foreign debt, or debt owed in foreign currency to lenders in other countries. But in Brazil's case, Duff & Phelps rates its domestic debt B-, three notches below its foreign debt rating of BB-.
Some of the financiers' and bond analysts' apprehension reflects a worrisome growth of Brazilian domestic debt, which is held almost entirely by Brazilians. In the last two years, the domestic debt has ballooned to nearly 400 billion reais -- now about $205 billion -- from 210 billion reais. By contrast, the foreign debt grew 13 percent in the same period, to $97.4 billion.
The main reason for the near-doubling of the domestic debt load is the Government's reliance on bonds that pay a variable rate of interest. So when the central bank raised interest rates during the financial crises in Asia, Russia and earlier this year at home, debt-servicing costs soared.
And Brazil's debt makeup is still largely dependent on moves in interest rates, with more than half of domestic debt linked to the main overnight lending rate, now around 19 percent. An additional 26 percent of the debt is linked to the real's value in relation to the dollar. That means that a sharp weakening in the Brazilian currency would sharply increase the cost of servicing these bonds.
Mr. Gomes's debt-restructuring proposal reflects the thinking of Roberto Mangabeira Unger, a legal theorist who is his principal adviser. Mr. Unger, a Brazilian who has been teaching at Harvard Law School since 1971, argues that the nature of Brazil's domestic debt means that it is vulnerable to potential negative developments abroad, like a correction on Wall Street or apprehension over Year 2000 computer problems. Turbulence abroad could lead the Brazilian central bank to raise rates, which means that the Government's financing costs also rise.
"The Government has made a very dangerous bet by not considering the eventuality of an internal debt reorganization," Mr. Unger said in a telephone interview. "First, it means that almost the totality of projected federal revenue will be used in servicing the debt, and second, the commitments to economic opening and fiscal realism are put at risk."
Mr. Unger's views on Government finances and other subjects such as the possibility of using controls to limit short-term capital flows have been known for some time. But recently, they have gained prominence as Mr. Gomes, the 2002 presidential aspirant, became something of a darling in the Brazilian news media after his separation from his first wife and much-publicized romance with Patricia Pillar, a soap-opera actress.
Mr. Unger began to influence Mr. Gomes's thinking when the politician was a visiting scholar at Harvard in 1995.
Skeptics say that a debt renegotiation would be exceedingly complex and do more harm than good. Mailson da Nobrega, a former Finance Minister, said about 80 percent of Brazil's domestic debt is indirectly held by the country's middle class, either through mutual funds, pension funds or insurance policies backed by Government bonds. "How do you renegotiate with crowds that would fit into several soccer stadiums?" he asked rhetorically. "This is an idea thought up in a Harvard library, far from Brazilian reality."
Brazil's central bank has said that the debt situation is improving. For example, in August the Government was able to increase to 11.7 percent the share of debt that is not subject to variable rates, from 1.2 percent in March.
And with the authorities forecasting a decline in interest rates to single-digits next year, debt-servicing costs should decline, as a result.

HEADLINE: Lehigh Phoenix Rises From Big Steel's Ashes;
Eastern Pennsylvania Region Recovers By Turning to Technology Companies

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

DATELINE: BETHLEHEM, Pa.

 BODY:
When Christopher Reed left here nine years ago to study engineering at Penn State, he assumed he was gone for good. A steelworker's son, he had had firsthand experience with the havoc that the steady decline of Big Steel had wreaked on the area's job market. "I figured I'd be in California by now," Mr. Reed said.
Mr. Reed came back when he graduated in 1994, but only to use his parent's home as a base for job hunting. Five months later, though, he was working at QED, a Bethlehem company that makes gallium arsenide wafers for the semiconductor industry. 
 "I couldn't believe something like QED existed in my backyard," Mr. Reed, a systems engineer, said. "I just never thought of this as a high-tech area."
So much for the persistent perception of the Lehigh Valley -- where the economic woes were immortalized by Billy Joel in his angry 1982 ballad "Allentown" -- as a place whose time has come and gone. Just drive through the area, visit its schools, talk to its entrepreneurs. Lucent Technologies has even gone so far as to put up a billboard over nearby Route 22 proclaiming, "Move over, Silicon Valley, here comes Lehigh Valley."
That's certainly an exaggeration. Still, slowly but steadily, a high-technology phoenix is rising on the steel shards of Easton, Bethlehem and Allentown, the towns that make up the Lehigh Valley. The region's unemployment rate, which four years ago was 7.7 percent, is now only 3.7 percent, according to the August data. Some 65 high-technology companies have moved into the valley or been founded there in the last five years, representing 38,500 jobs -- or about 12 percent of the area's total employment. It is a striking example of the extent to which high technology is transforming some of the most damaged areas of the Rust Belt's industrial economy.
"We're getting past the stigma of the Billy Joel song," said Thomas A. Kucharski, president of the Lehigh Valley Economic Development Corporation. "We're breaking through the perception that this area is coal and cows, and gray and brown."
A survey by a state-financed economic agency indicates that technology companies accounted for 3,500 new jobs in the valley last year, and are expected to create another 4,000 over the next two years.
Lucent, the communications equipment maker that is the area's biggest technology employer, has gone from 5,000 jobs in the region in 1996 to 5,600 today. It will have 5,900 here after it finishes expanding a plant in nearby Breinigsville and completes a $165 million divisional headquarters complex in Allentown in 2001.
Newcomers include Computer Aid, a computer software developer with 1,200 employees; AANetcom, a small chip maker founded two years ago by a former Bell Laboratories scientist; STC Technologies, a developer of medical products for testing immune-system problems, which employs 85 people, and Applied Separations Inc., a producer of advanced biotechnology laboratory equipment, with 62 employees.
But the drawn-out erosion of the steel industry has left its scars. At its 1950's peak, Bethlehem Steel employed 30,000 people in a five-mile stretch of steelmaking plants here. When it closed its last local plant last year, the work force had dwindled to 800. Many of the workers found jobs with other local companies, but the pay was nowhere near the $30 an hour they had made with Big Steel, let alone the 13 weeks of paid vacation and full package of health benefits they had once had.
Steel's demise meant the end of a way of a life. By the early 1980's, for the first time in more than 100 years, sons could no longer follow fathers into the steelworker's life.
"There was a noticeable and painful flight of young people from this entire area," recalled Bruce E. Davis, a former Bethlehem Steel lawyer who is now in private practice.
Many of those who returned still feel pangs for the old days. "I look at the blast furnaces now, and what strikes me most is the eerie silence," said Jeffrey Lowmaster, a 41-year-old former steelworker who left the Lehigh Valley when he was laid off in 1982, got some technology training, and returned last year to a technician's job at QED.
He is not alone. Last month a local theater group used the skeleton of an old steel mill as the backdrop for a play called "Steelbound," which dramatized how widespread the longing for the old life was.
"Seeing the plant as a ghost town, flat tracts and rubble where buildings used to be, was even sadder than the day we closed the forge," said Leonard Christman, a former steelworker who acted in the play.
But, Mr. Christman noted, the play ended with a strong message: "It's time to stop looking back, and to move on."
And that, clearly, is what the region is doing. "We saw high, we saw low, and now we're seeing high again," said David Hartzell, a 26-year-old steelworker's son who is director of operations for QED, which employs 70 people.
The change is tangible. Easton is metamorphosing into an art and tourist center, home to several galleries and two interactive children's museums. Allentown, which has suffered badly from middle-class flight to the suburbs, is being reborn as a government and financial center, with a large dab of high technology.
And, of course, there is Lucent's planned new group headquarters.
"We've been adding people for the last few years, and we're finally ready to put down bricks and mortar," said John T. Dickson, the president of Lucent's $3 billion Microelectronics Group, the division that makes electronic components here. The region's drawing cards, Mr. Dickson said, include scenic countryside and affordable housing. And Lucent's Route 22 billboard notwithstanding, Mr. Dickson sees benefit in the fact that the Lehigh Valley does not really rival other high-technology centers.
"We couldn't attract good people if we were the only high-tech company in town," he said. "But it's still harder for our talent to walk out the door to a new job than it would be in Silicon Valley."
The renaissance is most apparent in Bethlehem, once the heart of the steel district. New restaurants and boutiques are replacing ramshackle businesses on Third Street, the main drag. And it is not possible to eat at the Apollo Grill, a new midpriced trendy restaurant, without a reservation. "In the old days, it would have opened and closed in a week," said Donald T. Cunningham Jr., Bethlehem's Mayor and a steelworker's son.
Bethlehem Steel still makes its world headquarters here, even though its closest steel mill is now in Steelton, Pa., about 100 miles west. Meanwhile, the old steelmaking site -- at 1,800 acres, the largest singly owned "brownfield," or environmentally troublesome site, under redevelopment in the country -- is being reincarnated.
The company has spent nearly $25 million on cleaning up and marketing the site, but has priced the parcels low enough so that they are selling quickly. "We're not trying to profit from redevelopment; we'd love it if we break even," said Curtis H. Barnette, the company's chairman since 1992. "Our goal is to bring our site back to decent use."
The new uses include a museum of industry run by the Smithsonian Institution, an entertainment park with skating rink and swimming pool, a transportation center where shipments are switched between trucks and rail cars, a hotel and conference center, and a commerce center for light manufacturing.
Mr. Barnette said he expected the various operations that occupy the old steelmaking site to eventually provide 10,000 jobs.
Separately, the company has helped finance five industrial parks on Bethlehem's outskirts that have become homes to some 400 small businesses, and to a mix of 14,000 technology and nontechnology jobs. A sixth industrial park is under construction,
All along the valley, meanwhile, dozens of companies with ties to the fast-growing semiconductor chip industry have sprung up. Many have been helped along by the state-financed Ben Franklin Technology Center, an incubator for new companies and a nurturer for small ones trying to grow big.
"Without Ben Franklin's help, we'd have never found financing to get started," said William H. Weisbecker, a co-founder of QED, which recently merged with a Welsh company to form a $35 million multinational called IQE P.L.C., whose stock trades on the Brussels exchange.
The Ben Franklin Center was one of various initiatives promoted in the early 1980's by Pennsylvania's Republican Governor at the time, Richard L. Thornburgh. While it was clear that steel was on the way out, Governor Thornburgh defied the conventional wisdom by refusing to woo other types of heavy industry with the promise of tax breaks and land, concentrating instead on attracting small companies with growth potential.
"He said, 'Let's not chase smokestacks, let's turn our resources into something with a future,' " said Mark Lang, the Ben Franklin Center's executive director.
High technology was not an outlandish choice. The first transistor was manufactured in Allentown in 1951 by Western Electric, the old AT&T manufacturing arm, which originally came to the area because of its proximity to New York and Philadelphia and to AT&T's Bell Labs, 60 miles away in Murray Hill, N.J. And there was Lehigh University. Today, many of the current start-ups are run by Lehigh alumni.
"It made sense to set up near a high concentration of technical talent," said John F. Plunkett, a Lehigh graduate and a co-founder of Millbrook Inc., a new Bethlehem company that provides software to the insurance industry. Milbrook rents office space from Lehigh, and employs many Lehigh students as interns.
Lehigh University itself is undergoing a transformation of sorts. To counter its lingering reputation as a bastion of manufacturing skills, it is beefing up its liberal arts offerings, and will soon introduce a bioengineering course. It also is setting its students up with internships and consulting jobs at local technology companies. "Most of our graduates still don't stay in the area, but we'd like them to," said Gregory C. Farrington, Lehigh's president.
The changes in Bethlehem's local schools are more dramatic. The school district was never particularly starved for cash, since Bethlehem -- unlike Allentown and many other American cities -- has put its affluent suburban and inner city schools under the same district umbrella. But, in the steel-supremacy days, it was not under pressure to provide a good education.
"Everyone knew you could be a high school dropout and have a middle-class life style, that you could lean on a broom and make $15 an hour," said Thomas Doliusio, the district superintendent for the last 13 years. "Our minimum requirements for graduation were too minimum."
Not anymore. Three years ago Mr. Doliusio began what he calls an "international benchmarking" project, to glean educational tips from Japan and other countries. He has since introduced new ways to teach English and math, as well as intensified reading skills programs. He has instituted a stringent code of conduct that has resulted in the expulsion of 100 children "whose behavior interfered with our efficiency," he said.
The cost has been high. "Many teachers retired, and we've spent millions to train others," he said. "And we've had to de-emphasize social studies and science and music. But gosh darn it, our kids will know how to read!"
Such pragmatism notwithstanding, the area's transformation is far from complete. Mr. Barnette, the Bethlehem Steel chairman, says it will take more than a decade to complete all of the changes planned for his shuttered plants. There are still many rutted, muddy roads on and around the site.
And, according to Mayor Cunningham, while enough companies have come in to keep the tax base from declining, "it's stayed flat when our expenses have kept going up."
Indeed, even as he stood at the window of his office and surveyed the reborn town of Bethlehem, there was an air of nostalgic wistfulness in Mayor Cunningham's voice. "My job would be a lot easier," he conceded, "if there were a working steel plant out there."

HEADLINE: Jordan's New King Assuming Key Role in Mideast Talks

BYLINE: By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Not long ago, King Abdullah planned a quick trip abroad, to Vermont, to serve as best man at the wedding of a Deerfield Academy classmate. 
 But in another reminder of his new role as a pivotal player in the high-wire world of Middle Eastern peacemaking, his autumn weekend in New England soon blossomed into an official visit to the United States, his second in just five months.
This afternoon, accompanied by the American ambassador here, King Abdullah flew off for a long week of Washington meetings capped by a session at the White House. He carried with him, somewhat ambivalently, a private message for President Clinton, one that had been delivered to him here this week by an emissary of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq -- another of Jordan's problematic neighbors -- even though the King says has no illusions about any imminent improvement in Iraqi-American relations.
The King is to discuss Jordan's military needs with Defense Secretary William S. Cohen and duty-free access to the American market with Commerce Secretary William Daley. He will brief the president of the World Bank, James D. Wolfensohn, on his ambitious economic reform plans -- a prerequisite for further multilateral financing -- and promote Jordan's potential as a high-tech, low-wage industrial haven to computer entrepreneurs in Virginia and Massachusetts.
And he hopes to prod Congress to release a promised $200 million financial package that would make Jordan the second biggest recipient of economic aid per capita, after Israel.
But his main goal is to maintain the momentum toward the broad regional peace settlement that he considers the key to Jordan's security and economic recovery.
"If Syria doesn't resolve the problem with Israel, then we pay the price," he said before departing today. "If Israel doesn't resolve the problem with the Palestinians, again Jordan will pay the price."
Despite those concerns, Abdullah leaves behind a country increasingly comfortable with the ambitious and self-assured leadership style of a 37-year-old ruler who was barely known when he suddenly and unexpectedly ascended to the throne last February.
And his surprising willingness to break with some of the policies of his revered father, King Hussein, is already reshaping Jordan's regional alliances and domestic agenda in ways that his Arab neighbors and American policymakers both find welcome.
In a wide-ranging conversation today with a small group of European, American and Israeli journalists, King Abdullah sketched out his views on the state of the peace talks and Jordan's changing role as a regional intermediary.
He is guardedly optimistic about negotiations between Syria and Israel, despite outward signs that an initially positive dialogue has degenerated into a sterile exchange of old and incompatible bargaining gambits.
"Actually, I think things are moving along better than the atmosphere suggests," he said, citing his continuing contacts as "a middle man or mediator" with Prime Minister Ehud Barak and, through the King's son, with President Hafez al-Assad.
"What the Syrians were saying and what the Israelis were saying were really pretty much the same things," he said. "They were both in the same ballpark, and what we did was to try to get the messages to either party. As they start to sit down -- the Syrians with the Israelis, the Syrians with the Americans -- then we have done what we needed to do, and Jordan will pull out."
But he said he shared the concerns of many Arab leaders that Israeli peace talks with Syria could overshadow the much more complex and, in his view, far more important talks between Israel and the Palestinians.
"Peace with Syria is not peace with the Arab world," the King said.
"The Arab world cannot warm towards Israel if you do not solve the Palestinian issue, and there are many countries that want a warm relationship."
An admirer of Mr. Barak, King Abdullah nonetheless warned that his decision to press for a comprehensive final settlement, even at the expense of negotiating delays, is being misinterpreted as deliberate procrastination.
"When Barak won the election, maybe some people don't want to admit it, but there was a euphoria all over the Middle East," he said. "You had the Syrians coming out of their shell, believing in Barak and believing in Israel."
Mr. Barak wanted "to make something that would last, that would actually make the Palestinians happier than what we had achieved in Washington," the King said. "He had good intentions in his heart. But the perception in the Middle East was, this was further delay, and that maybe this was not the man that we all thought he was."
Despite his desire to expedite talks between Israel and the Palestinians, King Abdullah rejects any direct role.
He has said the Palestinians should take administrative control of the Muslim holy sites of Jerusalem, which still remain formally in his family's traditional charge. Unlike his father, he defers to Yasir Arafat, president of the Palestinian Authority, as the sole leader of the Palestinian people, except, of course, for the two million Palestinians who remain citizens of Jordan.
"We have had good relationships with Arafat from Day 1," he said. "We want to make sure that the Israelis and the Palestinians have the best atmosphere to move forward with the peace process."
Yet he curtly rejects the notion of an eventual confederation between Jordan and an independent Palestinian state, an idea resuscitated recently by Mr. Arafat, but which many Jordanians fear would spell the end of an independent Hashemite-led state here.
"There is no such word as confederation in my vocabulary," King Abdullah said.
When he assumed the throne last February, Abdullah portrayed himself as the keeper of the flame, as the custodian of his father's complex political and diplomatic legacy. But within months he began changing some of the terms of that inheritance.
He sought reconciliation with his father's old adversaries in Syria and Kuwait and an end to testy rivalries with Egypt and the Palestinian Authority. Domestically, he began revamping an entrenched political order that enriched an Amman elite but effectively disenfranchised the Palestinian majority. He has insisted on free-market reforms that will prepare Jordan for entry into the World Trade Organization, perhaps as soon as next year, but which will also threaten local business monopolies that prospered during his father's reign.
His most dramatic break came last month, when he ordered the arrests of the local leaders of Hamas, the radical Islamist Palestinian group that King Hussein had long tolerated as a counterweight to Mr. Arafat and as a concession to Jordanian Islamists, who also oppose peace with Israel.
But senior officials here now portray the Jordanian branch of Hamas as a renegade terrorist operation supported by Iranian intelligence and conspiring against Hamas leaders within the Palestinian territories. Mr. Arafat repeatedly asked the new Jordanian Government to take action against the group, foreign diplomats and senior Jordanian officials said.
"Jordan has made itself quite clear that Hamas offices will be shut down in Jordan, and that is what will happen," King Abdullah said today.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dividend Increases Slow Even as the Economy Soars
If the measure of corporate America's financial health is its ability and willingness to increase dividends to shareholders, then the country might appear to be in a recession. Standard & Poor's reports that 117 companies announced dividend increases in September, 10 fewer than in the month a year earlier.
That was the 15th consecutive month that the number of dividend increases was down year-over-year. By itself, such a long string of relative bad news is not extraordinary. What is unusual is that the economy is doing so well even while companies are growing more reluctant to raise their dividends. Floyd Norris: Market Place. Page C11. 

Support Grows for Some Tax Breaks
Support is growing in Congress for a vast expansion of retirement tax breaks for business owners, executives and highly paid workers, moves that Republicans and Democrats alike think would be popular with voters. C7.
 
Earnings Rise 6.7% at Pepsico
Pepsico reported a 6.7 percent increase in third-quarter profit on the strength of higher earnings at its Frito-Lay and Tropicana units, a performance that beat analysts' estimates by one cent a share. The announcement sent the stock prices of both Pepsico and its archrival, Coca-Cola, higher. Shares of Pepsico rose $1.75, or 5.6 percent, to $33.1875. Coke rose $4, to $51.9375. C5.
 
Metabolife Posts Interview on Web
Metabolife, a diet-product company, posted on the Internet a complete, unedited videotaped interview between an ABC News correspondent and the company's chief executive to publicize its concerns that ABC would broadcast an unfair report on the medical risks of its popular dietary supplement. A23.
 
Stocks Gain as Rate Worries Ease
Stocks rose as investors shifted their attention to earnings and away from the prospect of higher interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 187.75 points, or 1.81 percent, to 10,588.34. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 24.05 points, or 1.85 percent, to 1,325.40. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 57.54 points, or 2.06 percent, to 2,857.21. C10.
 
Bond prices were little changed as investors awaited an employment report expected tomorrow. The yield on the 30-year issue was unchanged at 6.17 percent. C10.
 
Debate Is Stirred on Debt in Brazil
Investors in Brazil are beginning to get nervous over the possibility that the Government might try to renegotiate its domestic debt, which has nearly doubled in recent years. The possibility has grown in part because the idea of a debt renegotiation has been promoted by a rising presidential candidate, Ciro Gomes, a 41-year-old former Finance Minister. He has made debt renegotiation part of a broader economic plan that he says would encourage long-term growth. C4.
 
Loss Narrows at Advanced Micro
Advanced Micro Devices reported a smaller-than-expected third-quarter loss as sales of its Athlon line of chips accelerated. Executives said they were on track to achieve their goal of breaking even in the fourth quarter. C6.
 
Asarco Accepts Phelps Dodge Offer
Asarco said it had accepted a $1.1 billion cash-and-stock takeover bid from Phelps Dodge in a deal that would make Phelps Dodge the world's largest copper company. C6.
 
Union Pacific Orders Locomotives
Union Pacific said it had ordered 1,000 locomotives worth more than $2 billion from a Canadian division of General Motors as it seeks to improve its railroad network. C4.

HEADLINE: F.C.C. Begins Rewriting Rules For Industryin Consolidation

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Federal officials this week began setting the conditions they will impose on a wave of proposed mergers that promises to consolidate, blur and redefine the nation's phone, cable and broadcast industries in a matter of months.
Today, the Federal Communications Commission approved SBC Communications Inc.'s $72 billion takeover of the Ameritech Corporation, but imposed conditions that officials said were intended to force SBC to be more competitive with other regional and local phone companies. 
 On Friday, the agency is set to announce new ownership-concentration rules for cable television companies that will determine whether the AT&T Corporation can complete its $58 billion acquisition of Mediaone Group without shedding any assets.
And yesterday, William E. Kennard, the F.C.C. chairman, questioned how MCI Worldcom Inc.'s $115 billion bid for the Sprint Corporation could benefit consumers, suggesting the companies had to shed Internet components and long-distance properties to gain regulatory approval.
F.C.C. officials said today that in drawing the lines on these deals and a handful of others -- valued at almost $250 billion in all -- the commission was trying to balance economies of scale, which could result in lower prices to consumers, against large-scale consolidations, which could result in less competition and higher prices.
"We are certainly not per se against consolidations, particularly those that achieve the kinds of economies of scale that can help consumers," Mr. Kennard said in an interview today. "On the other hand, we are against those consolidations that raise the barriers to entry by competitors."
One issue complicating the deliberations of Mr. Kennard and the F.C.C. is the state of local telephone service, which in many pockets of the nation has remained largely resistant to competition.
In broadly deregulating the industry, the Telecommunications Act of 1996 required that regional Bell companies seeking to enter the highly lucrative long-distance business must first establish that there is true competition in their local service areas. To promote that provision, the commission required San Antonio-based SBC, as part of its merger with Chicago-based Ameritech, to enter 30 cities outside its region within 18 months or else face fines of more than $1 billion.
Today, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., chairman of SBC, said in an interview that Texas regulators had notified SBC that it had shown sufficient local competition to qualify to offer long-distance service in Texas. Mr. Whitacre said he expected SBC would be filing an application with the F.C.C. in coming weeks to offer long distance to Texas customers.
"This is an interesting, exciting and great day," Mr. Whitacre said. "We've worked long and hard for this."
SBC's previous application to the F.C.C. to be allowed to enter the $80 billion long-distance market failed. But Mr. Whitacre said that the consolidation resulting from the MCI Worldcom-Sprint deal would place greater pressure on Washington regulators to open the long-distance market to the Bells.
"The obvious answer to all this," he said, "is let everybody do everything."
Today's action by the F.C.C. means that the seven Baby Bells originally created by the breakup of the old American Telephone & Telegraph Company will soon be reduced to four. And if MCI Worldcom's deal for Sprint, which is based in Westwood, Kan., is approved, four dominant long-distance carriers will be reduced to two.
Mr. Kennard's remarks about the acquisitions by MCI Worldcom, based in Jackson, Miss., and SBC were notable for more than what they said about the deals themselves. The resulting level of concentration would be stunning, not only for the telephone industry, but also for the broadcast and cable industries.
Two other deals now before the commission -- Viacom Inc.'s acquisition of the CBS Corporation and AT&T's purchase of Mediaone, a cable television services company based in Englewood, Colo., close on the heels of its purchase of Telecommunications Inc. -- would break the current caps that were supposed to limit market domination. In general terms, no more than 30 percent of either industry can be controlled by one company, and both mergers far exceed that.
There is a strong expectation that the F.C.C. and the Justice Department's antitrust division will, at the very least, require some of these deals to be significantly scaled back by requiring the sale of major components of the companies as a condition of regulatory approval.
On Friday, the commission is set to hand down new cable-concentration rules, and the industry is watching whether the agency will relax its standards to permit AT&T to complete the acquisition of Mediaone.
Mr. Kennard and other officials at the F.C.C. also suggested that the rules under consideration for the cable industry might be different from those for other industries. That is because a convergence of telecommunications, computer and broadcasting technologies enables cable companies to offer TV programs, high-speed Internet access and telephone services over a single cable.
The officials said the aim of the rules to be announced on Friday would be to prevent further consolidation of traditional cable service -- television -- while encouraging AT&T and its smaller competitors to continue to invest heavily in developing networks capable of offering high-speed Internet and telephone services as well.
"The cable industry is both mature and moving into a new market, trying to compete with the Bells in local telephone and broad-band telephony," Mr. Kennard said. "It's like the Yankees baseball team deciding that they want to now compete in basketball. You want them to be competitive. At the same time, you don't want to give them the ability to totally dominate their traditional market."

HEADLINE: U.N. Governance in East Timor

 BODY:
To avoid months of chaos in East Timor, Secretary General Kofi Annan wants the United Nations to take full control of the territory and spend the next two to three years readying it for independence. This is a timely and constructive proposal that deserves Washington's encouragement.
The forces opposed to independence, Indonesia's military and its allied militias, were too slow to let go of East Timor. By contrast, Indonesia's civil administration -- the police, the judges, the officials who ran the water and electric utilities -- disappeared too fast. That has left hundreds of thousands of Timorese civilians, already suffering from last month's violence, facing prolonged social and economic disruption. 
 Mr. Annan's plan could shorten this dangerous interlude. The U.N. must be careful about taking on new responsibilities that could overwhelm its budget and its capacities. But if Mr. Annan chooses a capable administrator, East Timor's transition problems should be manageable. Moreover, there are no attractive alternatives to U.N. rule.
Under Mr. Annan's proposal, the U.N. administrator would promulgate new laws and create an internationally run administration, supported by 8,000 to 9,000 U.N. peacekeepers. These would replace the current Australian-led international peacekeeping unit. Australia did much to restore security in East Timor. But the forceful tactics of its commanders have stirred resentment in Asia, and Australia now wants a lower profile.
There are potential obstacles. The operation could cost as much as $1 billion, of which the United States would be expected to pay roughly 25 percent. Congress may bridle, but should recognize that U.N. inaction could prove even more expensive. Meanwhile, Mr. Annan and his administrator must not let themselves be pushed around by members of the Security Council or the U.N.'s bureaucracy.
East Timor became a U.N. responsibility with this summer's referendum on independence. The sequel to that vote was violence, followed by a power vacuum. The immediate crisis has been overcome. The challenge now is to fill the vacuum with an effective governing apparatus until the East Timorese are ready to rule themselves. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Son-in-Law at Center Of Rich Network of Influence

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: OMSK, Russia, Oct. 6

 BODY:
It is three hours by air from Moscow to Omsk, a sprawling collection of fraying low-rises set on a Kansas-flat plain by the oil fields of Siberia. Every month or two, a well-dressed, bespectacled young man arrives by commercial jet here and is whisked away to a corporate apartment not far from the Omsk Oil Refinery, Russia's largest and most modern petroleum complex. After a day or two of unspecified business, he leaves as he came.
Virtually nobody in this city of 1.2 million people would notice, except for his name: Leonid Dyachenko, the husband of President Boris N. Yelt sin's daughter and right-hand strategist, Tatyana Dyachenko. 
 Once so anonymous that even prying reporters were unsure of his first name, the 36-year-old Mr. Dyachenko turns out to have a colorful life.
He popped into the headlines two weeks ago when it was disclosed that he had a bank account in the Cayman Islands with more than $2 million. His bank is the Bank of New York, which is at the center of an investigation into possible money laundering in the United States.
Mr. Dyachenko is an oil trader. But he is more than that. He is a participant -- if not a key figure -- in a network of politically blessed companies that ship Siberian oil products to Ukraine and to Eastern Europe.
His work is all the more colorful because, for many oil traders, oil is almost an afterthought. Virtually all of Russia's oil giants use creative financial transactions to ship billions of dollars offshore -- beyond the reach of tax collectors and, for that matter, company shareholders.
Of most interest to investigators tracing the billions of dollars that have flowed out of Russia this decade are Mr. Dyachenko's bank accounts, which apparently got most of their money from his dealings with oil companies, according to statements by bank officials.
The officials of those companies, and Mr. Dyachenko's benefactors, include two Russian tycoons who are among Mr. Yeltsin's strongest supporters, Boris A. Berezovsky and Roman Abramovich, as well as the son of the autocratic pro-Yeltsin governor of the Omsk region.
Mr. Dyachenko's operations stretch from Omsk to Moscow to Manhattan, where he is allied with a frenetic Russian capitalist named Viktor Y. Khrolenko and, records indicate, seems to have occupied a luxury apartment overlooking New York's financial district.
Mr. Khrolenko, who set up two oil trading companies that employed Mr. Dyachenko and who befriended the Yeltsin family, said in an interview that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had seized his records and that he was recently summoned to appear next Thursday before a Federal grand jury looking into Russian financial dealings in the United States. Through a lawyer, he denied any wrongdoing. The Kremlin has refused in the past to discuss Mr. Dyachenko.
And nothing so far links Mr. Dyachenko to any of the now-infamous companies, like Benex International, that have been indicted on charges of illegally moving nearly $7 billion from Russia through Bank of New York accounts over the last three and a half years.
Still, Mr. Dyachenko's business in Omsk and Manhattan raises questions throughout Moscow about his lucrative relationships with business tycoons who have profited from the personal intervention of Mr. Dyachenko's father-in-law, President Yeltsin.
Less clear is the true role of Mr. Khrolenko, an engaging but curious wheeler-dealer who seems to have played midwife on both sides of the ocean to Mr. Dyachenko's oil career.
Tall, good-looking and energetic, Mr. Khrolenko was a Russian capitalist before Russian capitalism was cool, much less before it overheated. "Viktor was one of those guys who asked me to smuggle him a copy of Samuelson's book on economics in '78 or '79," said Jonathan Sanders, a Columbia University professor who is a godfather to one of Mr. Khrolenko's grandchildren. "He's a real Russian patriot who just wanted to bring some American things into his country."
By the time Communism collapsed, Mr. Khrolenko had hooked up with a onetime promoter for the Rolling Stones to secure a CBS recording contract for a Russian rock band and bring Soviet newscasts to the Discovery Channel. He started, then sold, an American-style nightclub, Manhattan Express, in a staid hotel near Red Square, and published books on Russian art and literature.
His corporate umbrella, Belka International, had annual sales of more than than $100 million in 1992, according to a Moscow business newspaper. A more recent report, by Dun & Bradstreet, places recent sales at close to $30 million.
Mr. Sanders believes that Mr. Khrolenko had met Mr. Yeltsin by the late 1980's, when Mr. Yeltsin was gaining the image of a Communist reformer. And Mr. Khrolenko suggested that he met Mr. Yeltsin's son-in-law through a timber deal in the early 1990's.
What is clear is that in 1993, the Kremlin called Andrew Nurnberg, Mr. Yeltsin's literary agent in London, and said Mr. Khrolenko would negotiate the American rights to Mr. Yeltsin's autobiography.
"I heard he was desperate to be seen with Yeltsin," Mr. Nurnberg said in a telephone interview. "That was in those days when you could benefit by being close to the President of Russia."
Peter Osnos, then the publisher of Times Books, a division of Random House, and now the publisher at Public Affairs, a nonfiction publishing house, said Mr. Yeltsin's book was excellent -- and that the American edition never made a penny.
In an interview, he recalled attending a spectacular Kremlin dinner to celebrate the unveiling of the book at which Mr. Khrolenko sat with the presidential family. "What happened to him after that, I don't know," he said.
Part of what happened is that Mr. Khrolenko went from publishing to petroleum -- and Russian politics. By the spring of 1994, when Mr. Yelt sin's book appeared in the United States, Mr. Khrolenko's Belka was peddling its services at a Washington conference on Russian technology, opened by Vice President Al Gore.
Among others there was the governor of Omsk region, Leonid Polezhayev. A participant, who refused to be identified for fear of retribution, said Mr. Khrolenko was actively promoting oil and gas deals in the area, and that Governor Polezhayev was at his side. "They hugged each other like old friends," the person said. "I think they'd known each other for a long time."
A huge deal was soon sealed, but it did not directly involve Mr. Khrolenko.
Under a Government program known as loans for shares, the Kremlin elected to sell off effective control of the Omsk Oil Refinery, the city's biggest employer, to the highest bidder. That triggered a bitter battle that ended when the chief opponent of the plan, the refinery's general director, was found dead in Omsk's Irtysh River a week before the company's auction.
The winner of the auction was the huge Siberian Oil Company, known as Sibneft. Its ownership is murky at best, but most analysts say control rests with the company's general director, Mr. Abramovich (pronounced ah-bra-MO-vich), and his longtime business ally, Mr. Berezovsky, perhaps Russia's richest and most public business titan.
The Sibneft acquisition appears to have been good news for both Mr. Khrolenko and Mr. Dyachenko. Sibneft began selling its refined Siberian oil through a network of oil traders. At the top of Sibneft's list were two companies: a Khrolenko creation called Belka Energy of New York, and a second, better-known Russian company called Runikom.
By all accounts, Mr. Dyachenko has either overseen or played a leading role in Belka's dealings with the Omsk refinery. A vice president of Runikom, which itself holds a 10 percent share of Sibneft, is none other than Aleksei Polezhayev, the son of the Omsk governor.
The incestuous nature of the ties is clear from the location of Belka's Moscow office: in the refurbished building that houses representatives of the Omsk regional government.
As a practical matter, Sibneft seems to have awarded the relatives of Mr. Yeltsin and a key supporter lucrative contracts to distribute its petroleum products. Just how lucrative is not clear; Sibneft, one of the world's biggest oil companies, still does not have to disclose its internal business dealings.
Mr. Khrolenko's lawyer, Irwin Rochman, said in a lengthy interview that Mr. Khrolenko's companies are legitimate and that Mr. Dyachenko, who has an undisclosed "relationship" with them, "has been compensated handsomely" for his work.
But it is unclear what Mr. Dyachenko does.
According to an account by one petroleum expert in Omsk, which is impossible to verify, Belka and a second Khrolenko company run by Mr. Dyachenko, East Coast Petroleum, move about 10,000 tons of diesel fuel from Omsk each month. Most goes to former Soviet satellites like Hungary and Croatia; increasingly, some goes to Ukraine.
"It's crumbs, mere crumbs," the expert said. Like many experts, he characterized the allotment as a political favor, much as a powerful American company might suddenly choose to hire the unexceptional son of a congressman or a governor.
But the sums involved -- and the profits -- can be immense. The vast majority of Russian oil giants effectively launder their oil through a network of offshore companies -- some wholly owned subsidiaries, others controlled by favored friends -- to avoid taxes.
The Russian Government places a 20 percent value-added tax on every ton of exported oil or gas. In the simplest scheme, an oil company agrees to sell its crude to a foreign trader for slightly below the market price, thereby understating its profit and paying less tax. The trader then resells the oil at market prices and agrees to split the profit with his supplier.
Most important, the unreported profit stays offshore. "If you have an offshore entity, you can declare less income and pay less taxes -- excise, profit, corporate or income tax," said an executive of one major Western company.
The rake-off goes largely to feed official corruption, lining the pockets of politicians and company officials. In particular, both Russian and foreign oil executives say, the Government's energy and fuel ministry -- which controls oil exports -- is almost brazenly corrupt.
Even officially, the Government does little to conceal the practice. In 1997, a banner year for oil exports, nearly half of the 97 million tons of crude oil exports were sent -- on paper, at least -- to tax havens like Gibraltar, Lichtenstein and the Bahamas, many without refineries.
A review of Russian customs records by a Russian petroleum newsletter turned up no evidence that either Belka or East Coast Petroleum had received oil exports in the last two years. That could be literally true. But experts say it is possible that the two companies could be placed further offshore in a chain of transactions beyond the reach of Russian tax collectors.
In Omsk, where at least some of the records exist, even those in the know do not want to talk about it.
Journalists who have challenged Governor Polezhayev's rule have found themselves under investigation.
In one interview this week, a subject removed the batteries from a mobile telephone, explaining calmly that this would prevent the security police from monitoring the interview. The governor's office declined a reporter's request to discuss these and other issues.
"The less you know," said one man who declined to delve deeply into Belka's history, "the longer you live."

HEADLINE: The Big City;
A Republican Sees an Issue: Education

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
WHEN the Rev. Floyd Flake introduced George W. Bush to New York's conservative establishment Tuesday, it was probably the first time in the history of the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research that a luncheon speaker was described as "my homeboy." And that was not the most incongruous moment of the day for a Republican from Texas.
Mr. Bush visited an elementary school in Harlem, advocated spending more Federal money on education and sounded a little like Hillary Rodham Clinton during his luncheon speech at the New York Sheraton. He didn't mention anything about a village, but he did declare passionately: "Our nation has a moral duty to insure that no child -- I mean no child -- is left behind." 
 Could a Republican really be serious about education? Many voters, especially in New York, would dismiss Mr. Bush's compassionate rhetoric as political pandering. In a way it was, but not necessarily in the way that voters think.
When asked which party can do a better job of improving schools, voters overwhelmingly prefer Democrats, according to a poll by the Pugh Research Center. The Democrats have long been admired for their determination to allocate more money to public schools.
Adjusted for inflation, spending on the average American public school pupil has doubled in the last three decades, according to the National Center for Education Statistics. But the money has not brought obvious improvement. As a result, many reformers are considering bigger changes, like the charter schools and voucher plans that New York's Republicans have been championing.
Local Democrats and union leaders have put up fierce resistance, but these reforms seem to be gaining favor, especially outside New York. The current issue of Blueprint, the journal of the centrist Democratic Leadership Council, wholeheartedly endorses charter schools and advises Democrats to "stop opposing school reform ideas just because some Republicans like them."
There were plenty of those ideas in Mr. Bush's speech: reduce regulation of schools, make them compete for dollars and students, finance the construction of charter schools, get money directly to students and parents. It left the conservatives buzzing about education as a possible new wedge issue.
Like the Reagan Democrats who had defected over the issues of crime and welfare, and the Republican soccer moms driven to President Clinton by their party's stance against abortion, maybe Democratic parents could flee to a Republican promising better schools.
Maybe the National Education Association could turn into the Democrats' version of the Christian Coalition: a powerful special interest that alienates voters. Teachers keep the party opposed to vouchers, but they don't cast as many votes as parents and grandparents, whose support for school vouchers has been growing. Support is especially strong among Hispanic and black voters, whose defection would be a major blow to Democrats. Mr. Flake's enthusiasm for Mr. Bush may not be shared yet by many of his fellow African-Americans, but his support for vouchers is.
AFTER listening to Mr. Bush's pleas, the conservative intellectuals and business leaders could righteously believe their candidate to be standing up for children and the working classes. But there was an underlying problem with the speech.
However much conservatives may want to rescue children, they usually do not think that any President can do the job. They favor local control of schools. After arguing for the devolution of power -- the liberation of New York City's schools from the bureaucrats in Albany and at the Board of Education headquarters in Brooklyn -- it's inconsistent for them to put great faith in any reform coming out of Washington.
And however much Mr. Bush wants to reform schools as President, he won't have the money or the power to do it. The Federal Government provides only 8 percent of the money spent in public schools. Like crime, the issue is far more important on the campaign trail than in the Oval Office.
So perhaps the speech was mainly an exercise in political finesse: a demonstration that a Republican could learn the Clintonesque art of co-opting the other side's symbolic issue. Mr. Clinton had demonstrated how to win by sounding tough on crime. Now Mr. Bush was looking for victory by sounding soft on education.

HEADLINE: Poverty Rate Persists in City Despite Boom

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
Despite the strongest economy in years, nearly one out of four New York City residents had incomes below the Federal Government's poverty threshold last year, a rate that has barely dipped since the last recession and that is twice as high as the national average, a new analysis of poverty in the city concludes.
The analysis, based on figures from house-to-house surveys by the Census Bureau, was released yesterday by the Community Service Society of New York, an advocacy group for the poor that has been tracking city poverty rates for decades. But the finding that the city's economic boom is not lifting the poor along with the well off echoes recent studies by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics. 
 "This is the best economy the country has seen since the late 60's," said Mark K. Levitan, who analyzed the census data for the Community Service Society. "It's not going to get any better than this. And we're still in a situation where a quarter of the city's population is in poverty."
Nationally, for the third year since 1994, more than a million Americans moved above the poverty line, defined as below $16,665 a year for a household of four. But in New York City, where the recovery has been gathering steam since 1996, 1.8 million are officially poor, or 24.3 percent, as many or more than in the early 1990's, during the last recession.
Rae Rosen, regional economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said the Community Service Society's findings on poverty should be understood in light of the city's 6.9 percent unemployment rate, which remains high compared with 4.5 percent for the nation, as well as its high rate of immigration, which adds to a mismatch between the low level of skills and education of the least successful job seekers and the rising demands of new service jobs.
"I would agree that there are a group of people at the very bottom that have been bypassed by this economy that has been pretty robust," Ms. Rosen said.
But Giuliani administration officials disputed the significance of the figures, noting the number of jobs created in recent years and their efforts to move New Yorkers from welfare to work "The quality of life in New York City is higher than it's been in years," said Edward Skyler, a spokesman for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. "Three hundred and thirty thousand new jobs have been created in the last five years, as opposed to the 320,000 jobs that were lost in the early 90's. People are moving from welfare to self-sufficiency in record numbers."
He added, "Impartial observers recognize that there has been a renaissance and revitalization in every borough that is a model for cities around the world."
But Solidelle Wasser, a senior economist with the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said Census Bureau data on poverty rates in the largest metropolitan areas around the country supported the view that New York's economy was lagging behind in lifting the incomes of the poor.
Though small samples make fluctuations from year to year unreliable, she said, it is striking that the 24 percent poverty rate of the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area last year was higher than that in the greater metropolitan regions of Los Angeles (22.5), Chicago (17.3), Detroit (22.4), Washington (23.8) Philadelphia (8), Boston (22.1) and Dallas (17.1). Among those surveyed, only Houston, with a poverty rate of 28.1 percent, was higher.
Ms. Wasser said an analysis of payrolls in New York City between 1992 and 1996 also supports the idea that the recession here disproportionately hurt those at the bottom while the recovery disproportionately benefited those at the top. Though the number of payroll jobs dropped, she found, the amount of money spent on payrolls did not shrink at the same pace, suggesting that low wage jobs were lost while higher-wage job-holders held their own or gained in pay.
David R. Jones, the president and chief executive of the Community Service Society, said the pattern in the census figures raised the question of whether the city's labor market could sustain low wage workers and those leaving welfare.
In December 2001, the five-year lifetime limit on public assistance established by the Federal welfare overhaul will begin to run out for some poor families, he noted, and under state law, those unable to make the transition into work will have to be supported by safety net programs that are financed by state and localities, 50-50.
"That raises some serious concerns for New York City, more perhaps than any other part of the country," Mr. Jones said, "because we're talking about hundreds of thousands rather than handfuls, and because we're already running such high rates of unemployment."
The long-term solution promoted by Ms. Rosen and other economists at the Federal Reserve Bank is not unlike that advanced by the Community Service Society: to provide extra public support for the poor to upgrade their skills, including help with child care, transportation and education.
But the society's analysis of census population surveys, which found the poverty rate among families with children was about 30 percent, also showed a sharp decline in the proportion of such families who received public benefits like Medicaid and food stamps, Mr. Levitan said. The Federal Government considers these benefits important for helping poor parents stay in the work force.
Only 55.9 percent of poor families had been covered by Medicaid even part of the year in 1998, he found, down from 69.9 in 1996, and 57.5 percent had received some food stamps, down from 68.9 two years earlier. The percentage on public assistance declined even further, to 42.3 percent from 58.9 percent.
To the Mayor and his welfare commissioner, Jason A. Turner, however, the decline in public assistance is a big step in the right direction. "New York City has moved from the Welfare Capital of the World to the Work Capital of the World," the Mayor said last week in announcing $31 million in Federal welfare-to-work grants to six community agencies that are to train and place disadvantaged groups like immigrants and former drug addicts.
Larian Angelo, an economist who is deputy director of the City Council's Finance Division, said the disparate impact of the economic boom and the stagnation at the bottom have been reflected in a lack of growth of the middle class.
Two City Council-sponsored studies of 1996 and 1997 census figures found that even as the real estate market rebounded and the securities industry hit record highs, the percentage of the population in the city's middle class barely budged, hovering just over 29 percent. The middle-class category was defined for the study as annual income of between $49,000 and $98,000 for a family of four, based on 1996 dollars.
In comparison, 35 percent of city residents had a middle-class income in 1989, at the end of the previous recovery.

HEADLINE: Harvard's $2.1 Billion Tops Colleges' Big Fund-Raising

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
Universities do not usually set fund-raising goals that they cannot meet, but when Harvard decided in 1992 that it would try to raise $2.1 billion by Dec. 31, 1999, the task seemed herculean: the university would have to collect an average of nearly $1 million a day for seven years.
Yesterday, the Harvard president, Neil L. Rudenstine, informed a gathering of alumni at the Harvard Club in Manhattan that the university had not only reached its target, but had exceeded it, raising $2.3 billion, with three months still remaining. 
 Though no American college or university has ever raised as much in a similar period -- Yale and Columbia, believed to be the closest competitors, each raised $1.7 billion over seven years in the 1990's -- Harvard's experience is only the most remarkable example of a larger trend: Donations to institutions of higher education are swelling beyond even the grandest expectations, thanks in large part to a booming economy.
"Donors are much more willing to talk," said Will Melton, the vice president for external affairs at Middlebury College in Vermont, which has raised all but $57 million of the $200 million it hopes to collect from October 1997 to June 2001. "They are not reluctant to talk about their wealth and success, and they want to share it with the institutions that mean something to them."
"This is the golden age of philanthropy," Mr. Melton added, "and Harvard rode the market climb perfectly."
Harvard collected $462.7 million in gifts last year, an increase of 124 percent over the $206.2 million in donations that it recorded in 1992, the end of the most recent recession.
Over the same period, annual contributions rose 152 percent at Princeton; 141 percent at Columbia, and 68 percent at Stanford, according to figures from the Council for Aid to Education, a nonprofit organization that tracks contributions to colleges and universities.
While, in general, the number of donors to each institution did not increase appreciably, the size of donations has grown.
At Harvard, a mere 85 gifts -- out of the 172,000 received since 1992 -- provided nearly half of the campaign goal, university officials said. Each was at least $5 million.
The largest gift, $70.5 million, was pledged in 1995, by John L. Loeb, class of 1924, a former member of Harvard's governing body, and his wife, Frances Lehman Loeb.
Among the most lucrative aspects of the campaign was one that focused on female donors, who have generally given substantially less than male classmates at Harvard.
Rita Hauser -- a member of the law school class of 1959, who, along with her husband, gave $14.5 million to the law school and $10 million to establish the Hauser Center for Nonprofit Organizations -- led an effort that raised $40 million from alumnae.
Harvard intends to use its trove for a variety of purposes.
The school's Widener Library, for example, is to receive a $70 million renovation, and repairs to the freshman dormitories, at about $65 million, have already been completed. And 25 faculty positions have been added to improve the ratio of undergraduate students to professors.
Over the course of the campaign, the university's endowment has grown to $14.2 billion, from $6 billion in 1994. The university's annual budget is $1.8 billion.
At a time when institutions have been under external pressure to spend more of their endowments on their operating expenses, particularly to reduce tuition, Harvard has continued to spend about 5 percent of the value of its endowment annually. But because the size of the endowment has expanded so dramatically, the portion of the operating budget financed by the endowment has grown to 28 percent, from 18 percent about a decade ago.
At Harvard, tuition and other fees, including room and board, are $34,350 this year. Nearly half the students who attend Harvard receive scholarships, with the average grant about $17,200, university officials said.
Asked if Harvard should be willing to part with a bit more of its endowment each year, to lessen the burden on students, Mr. Rudenstine, the president, said, with an eye on the cycles of the world economy over the last century: "You have to make sure that the thing can last forever."
While other institutions contacted yesterday were fairly envious of Harvard's good fortune, Mr. Rudenstine said that in reality, $2.3 billion did not go as far as it used to.
"It's probably going to take $500 million alone just for new space, new equipment, new people, new technicians, new inventions and new teaching, just in the next three to five years," Mr. Rudenstine said. "There is a lot more to do."
