HEADLINE: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.
 
GARY BARTZ QUARTET, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232. Mr. Bartz, an alto saxophonist, has kept a strong underground reputation for 30 years, taking a barreling post-bop style into all sorts of areas; on the right night he more than satisfies the thrill seekers who come to hear him. He's playing with the pianist Barney McCall, guitarist Paul Bollenback, bassist James King and drummer Greg Bandy. Sets tonight and tomorrow are at 8, 10:30 and midnight, with a $20 cover (for midnight it's $15), and Sunday night sets are at 7 and 9, with a $15 cover; $10 all nights (Ben Ratliff). 

ANDY BISKIN QUARTET, Cornelia Street Cafe, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9318. Jazz musicians have put their hands to country, blues and gospel, but by and large they haven't done much with Stephen Foster, one of the major early synthesists of American culture. Tonight at 9 and 10:30, a quartet of adventurous young players led by Andy Biskin corrects that imbalance; his arrangements of Foster's music and his own are for clarinet, tuba, trombone, guitar, banjo and drums. Cover charge is $10 (Ratliff).
 
CELEBRACIO COLOMBIANA, Aaron Davis Hall, 135th Street and Convent Avenue, City College, (212) 307-7420. A triple bill of traditionalist bands from Colombia includes two New York City debuts: the singer, drummer and dancer Toto la Momposina with a drum group that plays Colombian and Caribbean rhythms, and the clarinetist Lucho Bermudez with his group. The bill also includes Foncho Castellar, playing rural accordion-driven vallenato music. Tomorrow at 8 P.M.; tickets are $20 and $25 (Jon Pareles).
 
THE CRABS, SARAH DOUGHER, Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., (201) 798-0406. Olympia, Wash., is no longer trendy, and thank goodness. Now its community of gentle cultural anarchists can get down to making really great homespun rock. Right now, Sarah Dougher is the scene's shiniest gem, a keyboardist with a flair for wringing poignancy from her vintage instruments. She plays with the Crabs, otherwise consisting of a young man and woman grappling with the usual revolutions of daily life. She'll also open with her own songs. Sunday at 9 P.M.; tickets are $6 (Ann Powers).
 
* DUANE EUBANKS QUINTET, Up Over Jazz Cafe, 351 Flatbush Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 398-5413. Mr. Eubanks is a trumpeter and the younger brother of "Tonight Show" guitarist Kevin and trombonist Robin. He plays straight-ahead jazz with the requisite mix of scorch and sensitivity to make it interesting, and this band will show you something interesting again when the horns take a breather: the rhythm section, with the pianist Orrin Evans, bassist Dwayne Burno and drummer Ralph Peterson, can be telepathic as well as flame-throwing. Sets are tonight at 9, 10:30 and midnight, and the cover charge is $15 (Ratliff).
 
* LOS FABULOSOS CADILLACS, Hammerstein Ballroom, 311 West 34th Street, Penn Station, (212) 564-4882. A band from cosmopolitan Buenos Aires, Los Fabulosos Cadillacs will toss in anything -- ska, samba, lounge, punk, funk, tango, cool jazz, merengue -- in pursuit of the dizzy paradoxes of modernity. They are among Latin America's heirs to Brazilian tropicalia, fearlessly allowing themselves to be heartfelt or ironic as they explore the pan-American cornucopia. King Chango and Sweet 75 (with Krist Novoselic of Nirvana) share the bill. Tonight at 8; tickets are $30 (Pareles).
 
VICENTE FERNANDEZ and ROCIO DURCAL, Madison Square Garden, Seventh Avenue at 32d Street (212) 465-6741. In Mexico, Vicente Fernandez is a household name, a television star who owes his fame to songs about loving, crying and suffering. With his dramatic tenor voice and his wall-shaking vibrato, Mr. Fernandez brings out all the melodrama of Mexican ranchera songs that bounce and laugh as they detail vast heartaches. Rocio Durcal, another leading Mexican pop singer, has plenty of drama of her own. Tomorrow at 8 P.M.; tickets are $40 to $75 (Pareles).
 
* GEORGE GARZONE'S THE FRINGE, Knitting Factory, Old Office, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. A teaching guru who's spent much of his career in Boston, the tenor saxophonist has played much more in New York in the last few years. He's well drilled in free play (this particular band's strength) as well as the post-Coltrane mainstream, and he can be a fearsome performer, shifting around harmonies with a casual finesse. Music is tonight, tomorrow night and Sunday night at 8 and 9:30; admission is $10 per set with a one drink minimum (Ratliff).
 
* KIP HANRAHAN'S DEEP RUMBA, Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street between Church Street and Broadway, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. Kip Hanrahan, a producer who knows and loves New York's constantly cross-breeding rhythms, assembled Deep Rumba for an album released last year. The 12-member supergroup is steeped in Afro-Cuban rhythms both sacred and secular; it features Milton Cardona on congas and Horacio (El Negro) Hernandez and Robby Ameen on trap drums, along with Andy Gonzalez on bass and Charles Neville (of the Neville Brothers) on saxophone. They use the ancient rhythms in volatile new combinations. Tomorrow at 9 and 11 P.M. and Sunday at 8 and 10 P.M.; admission is $15 (Pareles).
 
HAUNTED HOUSE, Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7501. It's the new band led by the guitarist Loren Mazzacane Connors, whose style is so inward that he demands the full concentration of the musicians around him. The drummer William Hooker, who joins the band as a guest tonight, may flatten Mr. Connors, or at least test his resources. The show is tomorrow at 8 P.M., and admission is $8. Stay, if you can, for sets later that evening by the bassist Melvin Gibbs and the band Slow Poke (Ratliff).
 
MARK HELIAS'S OPEN/LOOSE, Internet Cafe, 82 East Third Street, East Village, (212) 614-0747. One of the best bassists working in New York, Mr. Helias has played in some pretty, uh, open and loose bands over the years, but his presence on the stand is a guarantee that the music will come alive: he can't help but make a band bounce. He's worked with the tenor saxophonist Ellery Eskelin and drummer Tom Rainey in plenty of situations over the last 10 years; their trio explores written work as well as music where the floor drops out entirely. Sets tonight and tomorrow night at 9:30 and 11; admission is $7 (Ratliff).
 
* JOE HENRY, JULIANA HATFIELD, Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., (201) 798-0406. Over eight albums, Joe Henry has grown better and better at connecting the wild metaphors of his lyrics with music that's appropriately itchy, sexy and weird. "Fuse," the masterpiece he made this year, is as soulful and individualistic as the singer-songwriter genre gets. Juliana Hatfield, guitarist and singer preoccupied with hitting a pre-verbal nerve within the song form, opens for Mr. Henry with a solo set. Tonight at 10; tickets are $12 (Powers).
 
ISRAEL VIBRATION, Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place at 15th Street, Union Square (212) 777-6800. Israel Vibration's members met as children at a polio rehabilitation center; now they harmonize in devout, steadfast, "conscious reggae" songs about suffering and the faith to carry them through. Tonight doors open at 10. at Irving Plaza; tickets are $25 (Pareles).
 
AHMAD JAMAL TRIO, Iridium, 48 West 63d Street, Manhattan, (212) 582-2121. Mr. Jamal can be great playing live: he structures his music around long vamps, and gives himself lots of room to shift the tunes around on the spot, with a signal to his musicians. He's been influential from the start, in the 1950's, and he continues to sound like a master with something to teach us. Sets through Sunday night are at 8:30 and 10:30, and admission is $30 cover and $10 minimum (Ratliff).
 
OLIVER LAKE STEEL QUARTET, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 242-1785. This alto saxophonist's sense of structured play has led him toward reggae, big-band concepts, Eric Dolphy homages and a lot of other things, but this band is a newer group, developed over the last few years, featuring the steel drum player Lyndon Achee. Sets through Sunday night are at 9 and 11, with a 12:30 set tonight and tomorrow; admission is $20, with a $10 minimum tonight and tomorrow night; Sunday it is $17.50 and $10 minimum (Ratliff).
 
RUSSELL MALONE QUARTET, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 255-4037. Mr. Malone is literate in the jazz guitar tradition from Django Reinhardt to Wes Montgomery and beyond, and he likes to play all sorts of snippets showing his breadth; his fluidity can be jaw-dropping. Sets through Sunday night are at 9:30 and 11:30, with a 1 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; admission is $20 and $15 on Sunday (Ratliff).
 
MARIAN McPARTLAND TRIO, Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Midtown, (212) 581-3080. She's still playing well, with brightness and vigor and the hard-edged feel of New York jazz in the 1950's; people tend to forget about this in light of her identity as a genial radio host and public personality. This gig is special in that she's reuniting with the bassist Bill Crow and the drummer Joe Morello, the original trio from her almost decadelong engagement at the Hickory House, which began in 1952. Tonight and tomorrow at 9 and 11 P.M.; cover charge is $25 at a table and $10 minimum and $20 at the bar, with a $10 minimum (Ratliff).
 
* MEHR AND SHER ALI, Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, Times Square, (212) 840-2824 or (212) 545-7536. There are various schools of qawwali, the devotional Sufi music that uses steady handclaps, simple melodies and flamboyant, accelerating improvisations to lift its devotees to ecstasy. Mehr and Sher Ali, two singing brothers, are part of the rough-and-ready Punjabi school, the same style as the late Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan, and they spur each other to peak after peak. Tomorrow at 8 P.M.; tickets are $25, $35 and $45 (Pareles).
 
NETAID, Giants Stadium, Route 3, East Rutherford, N.J., (201) 935-3900. The latest attempt to forge a United Nations of concerned pop stars has the real United Nations backing it. Netaid, which plans to use the Internet as "a medium of social and economic change," was created in conjunction with the United Nations Development Program and has attracted the interest of pop luminaries including Bono and Wyclef Jean, who will perform together Saturday. Simultaneous shows will take place in London and Geneva; the New Jersey event also features the Black Crowes, the Counting Crows, Sheryl Crow (perhaps the first such incidence of synchronicity), Jewel, Jimmy Page, Mary J. Blige, Puff Daddy, Sting, Busta Rhymes, the Algerian singer Cheb Mami and the Italian heartthrob Zucchero. It's got to be chaos. But it's for a good cause: this time, the money goes to benefit Kosovan and Sudanese refugees. Tomorrow at 5 P.M.; tickets are $75 (Powers).
 
* ERIC REED, Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse, Rose Building, 165 West 65th Street, 10th Floor, Manhattan, (212) 721-6500. Mr. Reed, who was Wynton Marsalis's pianist for six years and held the piano chair in the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra until recently, is a playful musician with a fearsome sense of direction and a need to make performances be enjoyed. He has compositional resources, too, and more and more of an arranger's sensibility. He tore it up six weeks ago at the Village Vanguard with a septet, but even in solo performances, which form tonight's program, he'll set up surprises for the audience. Tonight at 8; tickets are $40 (Ratliff).
 
MARC RIBOT/JAMAALADEEN TACUMA/JOHN ZORN, Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. Expect the unexpected from these three veterans of downtown music, on guitar, bass and saxophone; they might slay you with music that's free or funky or funny or nasty. Music is tonight at 9 and 11; admission is $14 and $12 in advance (Ratliff).
 
THE SAMPLES, Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place at 15th Street, Union Square, (212) 777-1224. Boulder, Colo., is the home of this jam band, which has mustered quite an avid fan base after 12 years of touring. The Samples' sound is clean, like the air in those Rocky Mountains: a little bit folk, a little bit jazz, a lot of laid-back good vibes. With Chris DiCroce. Tomorrow at 9 P.M; tickets are $16.50 in advance, $18 day of show (Powers).
 
ZZ TOP, LYNYRD SKYNYRD, SCREAMIN' CHEETAH WHEELIES, Continental Airlines Arena, Route 3, East Rutherford, N.J., (201) 935-3900. Eh-heh-heh-heh-heh. The patented growl of Billy Gibbons echoes loudly in the archives of classic rock, where ZZ Top, the Texas trio with the funky facial hair, represents down-home authenticity as well as anyone. Lynyrd Skynyrd gained its historical standard through tragedy, in the famous plane crash that killed the singer Ronnie Van Zandt and several colleagues, but the band (now featuring Mr. Van Zandt's son on vocals) deserves praise more for its noble Southern rock than its penchant for disaster. Screamin' Cheetah Wheelies keeps that history moving forward, jam--band style. Tonight at 7:30; tickets are $39.50 and $29.50 (Powers).

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Time Jumps the Track

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
The Museum of Modern Art has cut the ribbon on its contribution to the millennium furor: a 17-month series of exhibitions under the umbrella title "MOMA 2000." In addition to being a summing up of this venerable institution's past, it is (or so we are told) a rehearsal for its future.
The completed project will mix hundreds of objects from the permanent collection -- some of them chestnuts (Rodin's "Balzac," Picasso's "Three Musicians," Gaugin's "Moon and the Earth (Hina Tefatou)," others unfamiliar -- into three successive chronological chunks. Those chunks will be subdivided into thematic units titled "People," "Places" and "Things," each of which will fill a floor of the museum for a few months. 
 That's the big picture; the final results are still in the stars. But from the first increment, which is called "Modern Starts: People" and focuses on the human figure in art from 1880 to 1920, one can glean some hint of what to expect from the whole.
The main idea is to cast an impressionistic glance backward at modern art as a phenomenon, and at the museum that has done much to create and promote that phenomenon, or at least a somewhat Olympian version of it. But the real news may lie in what the show says about the shape of things to come.
In 2001 the Modern is scheduled to break ground on a building that will house, among other things, permanent-collection galleries. Such galleries are a museum's core identity, its official statement about how it sees art: what it deems important, what goes with what. Any tinkering with this statement, never mind a complete overhaul, demands hard, subtle, consensual thought.
This is especially true after critical theory in the last few decades has thrown the very terms "museum," "modern" and "art" into question. By now, it seems, everyone knows that art institutions are impure, driven by social and economic agendas. Every collection and installation is an interpretation. And any historical account based on a linear progression of one era's notion of main events is, at best, provisional.
The Modern, for its part, has long been in the canon-making business. Its curatorial house style might be summed up in the phrase "neatness counts." Its view of 20th-century art as a carefully calibrated flow chart of successive avant-garde movements has, until recently, been unswerving, some would say doctrinaire.
On the evidence of "Modern Starts" -- which has been organized by the curatorial team of John Elderfield, Peter Reed, Maria del Carmen Gonzalez, Mary Chan and Elizabeth Levine -- efforts are being made, however cautiously, to give such certainties a shake.
Right off the escalator to the second floor it is clear that something is up. A mural-like drawing by Sol LeWitt suggests that the show's historic time frame isn't hard and fast. Inside the galleries the pristine white walls that have always framed the permanent collection are painted in greens, browns and grays.
And then there's the art. The opening image -- a life-size undated painting by Leon Bakst of the dancer Nijinsky as a strapping young man in scarlet trunks, one hand raised in salute -- is bound to be a novelty even to die-hard Modern denizens. The portrait has been in the collection for years, but the Modern has never shown it.
You can see why. A cross between a 19th-century academic study and a Hollywood hunk, a little heroic and a little absurd, this figure is too far outside the mainstream to fit any esthetic pigeonhole. But the work is an ideal lead-in for a show that has declared its intention to bring together diverse and unexpected art.
Eclecticism of style, date and medium pervades the first galleries of "Modern Starts," devoted to the theme "Actors, Dancers, Bathers." Picasso's 1915 "Harlequin" hangs beside a "Hamlet" poster produced around 1884 by the British designers who called themselves the Beggarstaffs (real names: William Nicholson and James Pryde). Cezanne's seminude male "Bather" (circa 1885) is accompanied by a 1993 photograph by the Dutch artist Rineke Dijkstra of a boy in a swimsuit on a beach.
The pairing is a neat demonstration of how a single classic pictorial motif can recur, which is nice to see, in a textbooky way. The pictures are far more interesting, though, as studies in the eroticized male body, a subject that might easily have been pushed a lot further but, in a show that in general treads timidly over potentially risky ground, it is not.
Eroticism is explored more forcefully in images of the reclining female nude in an adjoining gallery. These range from Erich Heckel's woodcut portrait of his feral-looking 12-year-old model Franzi, to Paul Klee's grotesque "Virgin in the Tree," to a magnetic Titianesque Modigliani nude stretched across a red ground that looks like swiped-on blood.
The overall effect is striking and theatrical. The gallery, with its gray-brown walls, has a penumbral, sickroom feel. A sense of the neurasthenic mystery of early modernism -- feverish and creepy -- comes through. And one realizes afresh how much this art is a product of male-generated sexual fantasy.
Fantastic or otherwise, the modern body is an organism under transformation, and this is the main theme of the rest of the show. Change can occur through metamorphosis, as in Matisse's series of five bronze heads of a young woman named Jeanette: in the first, she looks more or less like you and me; in the last, done six years later, she is a conflation of abstract swells and bumps, like a pileup of breakfast rolls.
Sometimes figures dissolve like ectoplasm into their environment: Vuillard depicts his sister being sucked into the wallpaper behind her. Most often, though, the figure is fragmented: shattered into bits, truncated, scrambled.
The result can look comedic in a proto-Junk Art sculpture by Vladimir Baranoff-Rossine. It turns slightly brutish in Francis Picabia's little painting, "Conversation II," with its limbless torsos lying about like chops on a grill. The effect is somewhere in between these two poles in a 1990 video by Gary Hill in which a male body is carved up among several screens, tummy here, nose there.
The title of the final section, "Composing With the Figure," implies that what comes apart can be reassembled, although radically changed. Entered in evidence are three big paintings: Picabia's wild-and-crazy "I See Again in My Memory My Dear Udnie" (1914), all nozzles and fleshy polyps; Leger's "Three Women" (1921), with their sheet-metal hair and stainless-steel limbs, and Picasso's "Desmoiselles d'Avignon," which is, in essence, the restitched and revivified post-mortem corpse of the premodern human form.
By the time we arrive at this monument, displayed like an altarpiece, where have we been? Through a series of stylishly installed, atmospheric installations. And through a number of perceptive thematic groupings, some of which set up extended rhythms that run through the show. (Remember the raised hand of the Bakst Nijinsky? It is there again in "Desmoiselles.")
But has the standard view of modernism, the one delivered for generations from on high in authoritative MOMA-ese, been revised? Not really. To be sure, the museum has made a point of saying that "MOMA 2000," in sum and in parts, is not intended as a grand, definitive statement. So if this first installment looks more like a cosmetic make over than a structural shift, we have been warned.
Yet one can still not help asking for something different, and more. Bland, old-fashioned formalist and iconographic themes still prevail. And the mix of artists is not all that much of a mix. Mostly it is major work by famous artists and minor works by famous artists, often the same artists.
To some degree this is dictated by the shape of the Modern's holdings. But surely the museum has oddball material tucked away, stuff that must have seemed decent enough when it was acquired but later got the "reject" stamp and might not look half-bad now. The cornucopian "Art of the 40's" exhibition in 1991 suggested as much. It would be good if a few more early-modern unknowns and irregulars had been brought out to join the fray, or to create a fray, which is exactly what's missing.
But there are very promising things, too. One, predictably, comes in a section devoted to photography. Here voices otherwise absent are heard, including those of women, from Frances Benjamin Johnston to Tina Barney, and non-Europeans like Martin Chambi of Peru and Seydou Keita of Mali. One assumes many more such inclusions are planned for coming installations, which will carry the modernist saga beyond 1920 and into the present.
And at least one section, a compact minishow of work by James Ensor (1860-1949) and Jose Guadalupe Posada (1852-1913), points to depths in the museum's holdings that could, if explored, significantly broaden the historical picture while remaining within the parameters of the collection.
These two artists lived on opposite sides of the world, Ensor in Belgium, Posada in Mexico. They probably never saw each other's work, although their moralizing, politically pointed, death-riddled humor is close in form and spirit. Shown together, they evoke a kind of transcultural Day of the Dead, and they have much to say about institutionally redefining early modernism as an international phenomenon, with popular roots and diverse audiences.
Ensor was connected with the European Symbolist avant-garde; Posada emerged from a regional art tradition. While Ensor worked in relative isolation and in small print editions, Posada produced more than 20,000 engravings in a broadsheet medium that appealed to a mass audience, rich and poor. The influences of both artists can, to varying degrees, be found in Latin American art to this day. And their pairing here proposes a widening view of modernism, past and present, only sporadically suggested in the surrounding galleries.
The Modern has suggested that the new permanent-collection galleries, which are several years down the line, will incorporate pocket-size installations like this one; and that's a promise we should hold it to. As the museum expands, it only makes sense that its view of art should expand, too.
"Modern Starts: People" tiptoes in this direction and gets by more on new style than on new substance. But as the larger canvas of "MOMA 2000" unfolds, this first step could turn out to be the start of something new.
"Modern Starts: People" remains at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan, (212) 708-9480, through Feb. 1. "Modern Starts: Places" opens on Oct. 28; "Modern Starts: Things" on Nov. 21.

HEADLINE: Trade and Pestilence

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 The West Nile-like virus that has killed several New Yorkers and the Asian long-horned beetles recently found near Central Park are symptomatic of the growing number of foreign pathogens entering the country with imported products. As an Oct. 4 front-page article ("Mosquito Virus Exposes Hole in Safety Net") notes, United States health officials are fighting back. But they have one hand tied behind their backs. 
 The problem is that the same rules made by the World Trade Organization to promote international trade also prevent regulators from taking the precautionary steps necessary to keep pest invaders out. We shouldn't have to choose between free trade and a safe environment.
President Clinton needs to show leadership in fixing W.T.O. rules that prevent regulators from stopping invasive pests and diseases at our borders, especially when cleanup requires spraying communities with pesticides or chopping down trees.
 
DANIEL SELIGMAN
Washington, Oct. 5, 1999
 
The writer is director of the Sierra Club's responsible trade program. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Biotech Can Prosper

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Biotech Companies Feel Overlooked by New York" (news article, Oct. 6): Biotechnology can thrive in New York City if we learn how to use the region's science and technology assets to spark economic growth. Universities must understand how to manage their intellectual property, establish partnerships with industry and remain flexible enough to accommodate faculty who wish to be entrepreneurs. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Stanford University have done this and have spawned innovative companies. New York campuses can do similarly. 
 The New York area needs a thriving economy. If we work together to exploit all of the region's assets, we can be globally competitive in technology within a decade.
 
RODNEY W. NICHOLS
President
New York Academy of Sciences
New York, Oct. 6, 1999

HEADLINE: E. C. Banfield, 83, Maverick On Urban Policy Issues, Dies

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
Edward C. Banfield, a professor emeritus of government at Harvard University whose work on urban policy and the causes of poverty gave him a reputation as a brilliant maverick, died Sept. 30 at his summer home in Vermont. He was 83 and lived in Cambridge, Mass.
Mr. Banfield, born on a farm in Bloomfield, Conn., held Harvard's Henry Lee Shattuck Chair in Government for many years. He was one of the intellectual leaders of the Harvard-Massachusetts Institute of Technology Joint Center for Urban Studies in the 1960's and 70's, when the problems of cities were prominent on the national political agenda. 
 His books and articles had a sharp contrarian edge. He was a critic of almost every mainstream liberal idea in domestic policy, especially the use of Federal aid to help relieve urban poverty. Mr. Banfield argued that at best Government programs would fail because they aimed at the wrong problems; at worst they would make the problems worse. He fostered generations of graduate students, some of whom became leading figures in American intellectual life. They included James Q. Wilson, who succeeded him in his chair at Harvard, and Christopher DeMuth, president of the American Enterprise Institute in Washington.
Mr. Banfield received his B.A. in English from the University of Connecticut in 1938 and went to work for the United States Forest Service. After jobs with the New Hampshire Farm Bureau and the United States Farm Security Administration in Washington and California, he went to the University of Chicago to work on his doctorate in political science. Chicago at that time, under the influence of figures like Milton Friedman and Leo Strauss, was a bastion of laissez-faire politics, a cause that Mr. Banfield later promoted in his own work.
He served briefly on the faculty in Chicago, moving to Harvard in 1959. He taught at the University of Pennsylvania before returning to Harvard at the end of his career.
In 1955 Mr. Banfield and Mr. Meyerson collaborated on "Politics, Planning and the Public Interest," which examined Chicago's public housing projects. That book was one of several in which Mr. Banfield found Government programs to be foiled by a law of unintended consequences. In the Chicago case, he predicted that creating tall institutional buildings full of small apartments would have the unintended effect of racially isolating the urban poor.
A major theme of Mr. Banfield's work on poverty, which was often angrily criticized in liberal circles, is that culture plays a more important role than factors like discrimination or lack of education in impeding a person's economic progress.
Among his most influential books was "The Moral Basis of a Backward Society," a study of a small village in southern Italy, researched in collaboration with his wife, the former Laura Fasano. Mr. Banfield's thesis, summed up in a term he coined, "amoral familism," was that the narrow focus on family relations prevented people from cooperating with those outside the family or village.
He is survived by his wife; a daughter, Laura Banfield Hoguet, a lawyer; a son, Elliott A. Banfield, an illustrator, and four grandchildren.
Mr. Banfield's emphasis on culture as the basic element in poverty drew accusations that he was promoting a "blame the victim" attitude. In his 1970 book "The Unheavenly City," and in various papers that he published in the late 60's, he recognized the existence and harm of racism but propounded the view that economic class and not race was the essential ingredient in poverty.
In that book Mr. Banfield constructed a sociological portrait of what he called "the lower-class individual" as someone who was very different from the middle-class professionals who sought ways to solve his problems. "The lower-class individual lives moment to moment," he wrote. "Impulse governs his behavior either because he cannot discipline himself to sacrifice a present for a future satisfaction or because he has no sense of the future. He is therefore radically improvident."
Mr. Banfield's role as an adviser to President Richard M. Nixon and chairman of his Model Cities Task Force gave his published views an extra measure of controversy. During the Reagan Administration he served on a task force seeking ways to increase public support for the arts. But his subsequent book, "The Democratic Muse: Visual Arts and the Public Interest," argued that Federal support of the arts was neither justified by the Constitution nor useful in practice.
"Affording enjoyment to people is not a proper function of organizations serving the common good," he wrote in that book.

HEADLINE: Borrowing By Consumers Up in August

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Consumer borrowing grew in August by the largest amount in seven months as spending by Americans showed little sign of abating, Federal Reserve figures showed today.
Borrowing rose by $10.8 billion in August to a total of $1.37 trillion. The increase was bigger than the $6.6 billion expected by analysts and follows a gain of $8.9 billion in July. The Fed originally reported July borrowing had risen $8.8 billion. 
 The increase means consumer debt has been growing at an annual rate of 9.6 percent as of August, compared with 7.9 percent in July and 5.4 percent in 1998.
"If this continues to mount at this pace, we could have troubles because consumers are going to have to catch up and pay up their debt," said Astrid Adolfson, an economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York. "So it could lead to slower spending ahead."
The rise is the biggest since one of $15.3 billion in January. The August rise coincided with a jump of nine-tenths of a percent in consumer spending, the largest since February.
By category, auto and other loans rose $6.5 billion in August after climbing $3 billion in July. Auto sales rose 9.5 percent in September, as the annual industry selling rate surged to a record pace for the eighth consecutive month. The auto industry reported its best month since 1986 in August.
Credit card and other revolving debt increased $4.3 billion in August after rising $5.9 billion during July.
In another report, the Labor Department said first-time jobless claims increased 10,000, to a seasonally adjusted 312,000 for the week ended Saturday. Claims in the week ended Sept. 25 were revised to 302,000, the first time in 10 weeks that claims surpassed 300,000. Analysts said the increases most likely reflected the floods and other effects of Hurricane Floyd, which struck North Carolina Sept. 16.
"It is likely this is just a fluke because of the bad weather on the East Coast, and the labor market remains tight," said Scott Brown of Raymond James & Associates.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Fed Reconsiders Policy Of Disclosing Tilt on Rates

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Concerned that its latest attempt to be more open might be confusing investors as much as helping them, the Federal Reserve is reviewing its new practice of disclosing once-secret decisions about tilting policy toward raising or reducing interest rates, the central bank said today.
The Fed said it had established a committee to study ways to clarify the meaning of the statement the central bank issues at the conclusion of each policy meeting. Since May, the Fed has used the statement not only to disclose any immediate changes to monetary policy, but also to say whether it had adopted a "bias," a formal decision that it sees a possible need to raise or lower rates in the near future. 
 But it has never been clear -- to investors who bet fortunes based on their reading of likely interest rate moves, or to Fed officials themselves -- whether the adoption of a bias is a clear expression of the central bank's intent to shift policy within a month or two or a much vaguer warning.
The establishment of the committee was disclosed in the minutes of the Aug. 24 Fed meeting, where the central bank pushed its benchmark Federal funds target rate up by a quarter-point, to 5.25 percent, as a protective move against a possible resurgence of inflation pressures. The minutes showed that the rate hike was approved by a vote of 9-1.
The lone dissenter was Robert D. McTeer Jr., president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, who has become a leading advocate of the theory that the economy is capable of higher rates of noninflationary growth, in part because of huge investments by business in efficiency-enhancing technology.
Mr. McTeer had also dissented from the Fed's previous quarter- point rate increase, in June. The minutes of the August meeting stated that Mr. McTeer believed "that positive supply-side forces will continue to damp the impact of strong demand on output prices and that productivity gains will continue to damp the effect of higher wages on unit labor costs."
The minutes said the review of how the Fed discloses its policy bias would be led by Roger W. Ferguson Jr., the central bank's vice chairman.
In May, the Fed said it had adopted a bias toward tightening, a step it followed with an interest rate increase in June. At the June 30 meeting, it moved to a neutral bias, which many investors took to mean that the Fed had no intention of raising rates at its next meeting, in August.
But in August, the Fed tightened again, and again said it had a neutral bias. At its latest meeting, on Tuesday, the Fed held rates steady, and moved to a tightening bias, although it added that the adoption of the bias should not be seen as a "commitment to near-term action."
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, noted at the August meeting that "the sentence relating to the directive was subject to differing interpretations," and that the decision to make immediate announcements about "significant changes in the symmetry or asymmetry in the directive had made it desirable to clarify its meaning."
It is unclear what steps the committee may recommend to clear up the confusion, although the minutes said the Fed was not contemplating dropping the new practice altogether. The committee is expected to report back by spring. In addition to Mr. Ferguson, it is made up of all the Federal Reserve governors except Mr. Greenspan, plus the presidents of three Reserve banks.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Jumped 5.5% In September

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Retail sales at stores open for more than a year rose 5.5 percent in September as shoppers bought fall fashions and back-to-school supplies.
Styles like fleece vests and women's fashions with stretch fabrics and brighter colors spurred sales, analysts said. Sales of cargo pants, corduroy slacks and utility packs increased as students headed back to school. 
 The statistics, calculated in the Goldman, Sachs retail composite index, said sales at the nation's two largest clothing chains -- Limited Inc. and Gap Inc. -- rose 8 percent and 7 percent, respectively.
"There's a newness on the fashion front that we haven't seen in a while," said Maura Hunter Byrne, a Salomon Smith Barney analyst.
Sales rose 4.1 percent at Sears, Roebuck & Company, the biggest increase since May 1998 for the largest department-store company and more than double some analysts' expectations. Its sales were led by demand for clothing and appliances.
Sales were also helped by rising consumer confidence and low unemployment. An index produced by the University of Michigan showed that consumers in September grew more optimistic about their finances and economic prospects. Analysts expect the Labor Department to report today that the nation's unemployment rate stayed at a 29-year low in September.
September's results and economy point to strong sales for the Christmas season, though there are some worries that rising oil prices and other indications of inflation may cut into spending, analysts said.
"I think we're going to continue to see the momentum we're seeing year-to-date," said Asma Usmani, a retail analyst at Edward Jones & Company. "Consumer spending still continues to increase at a 6 to 7 percent annualized basis."
Clothing chains reported among the highest sales gains in September as the new fashions and cooler weather sent shoppers into stores looking for sweaters and autumn clothing.
Intimate Brands Inc., which owns the Victoria's Secret lingerie and Bath & Body Works chains, yesterday reported a 13 percent gain, topping forecasts.
The 7 percent sales increase at Gap, which has heavily advertised its new vests, beat analyst estimates of 3 percent to 6 percent. Gap is the parent of both Old Navy and Banana Republic.
The Kohl's Corporation, which sells clothes, said sales rose 6.9 percent. TJX Companies, the largest off-price clothing retailer with chains such as T.J. Maxx, said sales rose 7 percent.
"Sales trends this fall continue to be robust, said its chairman, Bernard Cammarata.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said that sales rose 7.2 percent in September.
The Kmart Corporation's 2.5 percent rise was in line with analysts' estimates. The company, though, said the increase was less than it forecast because of promotions by other retailers during the back-to-school selling period.
The Dayton Hudson Corporation's Target stores had an 8.6 percent increase, above analyst's top estimates.
Department stores continued to lag other retailers in sales growth, in part because of Hurricane Floyd, analysts said.
Federated Department Stores said sales rose 3.7 percent. The increase was smaller than expected, as Hurricane Floyd kept customers away from its stores. Analysts had projected sales to rise 4 percent to 5 percent.
Saks Inc., operator of the Saks Fifth Avenue and other department stores, said sales rose 5 percent on increased purchases of designer clothes, men's sportswear and shoes. Sales increased 6 percent if effects from the hurricane were excluded.
Sales at the J. C. Penney Company, fell one-tenth of a percent.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Gauges MostlyLose Ground As Report on Jobs Is Awaited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks closed mostly lower yesterday as investors took profits from the hefty jump in prices on Wednesday and looked nervously ahead to the Government's employment report that is due this morning.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 51.29 points, to 10,537.05. Broader stock indicators were mixed. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was off 7.76 points, to 1,317.64, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 3.49 points, to 2,860.70. 
 "Taking profits is part of the story today after a big run-up on Wednesday, and the other part is waiting for tomorrow to see what September's employment numbers look like," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation.
The Dow climbed 187.75 points, to 10,588.34, on Wednesday as investors temporarily set aside worries about rising interest rates and focused on corporate earnings. But with the market's volatility in the last month amid nervousness over interest rates, many investors decided to take a prudent approach yesterday and collect profits before the employment report from the Labor Department.
The market will be scrutinizing the report to see if there are signs of inflation that could prompt the Federal Reserve to push rates higher at its next policy meeting, in November.
But even if the figures on jobs and wages contained in the report signal that inflation is indeed under control, analysts expect a continuation of the price swings that Wall Street has been experiencing over the last several weeks. The Dow fell more than 1,100 points from a record closing high of 11,326.04 on Aug. 25 before recovering ground in recent sessions.
Larry Wachtel, a market analyst for Prudential Securities, said third-quarter earnings reports, which traders have been optimistically awaiting, would help some stock sectors but not the overall market.
"In terms of the averages, you're not going to get a clear-cut bull market going," he said.
Although the technology-dominated Nasdaq index gave up early gains, some high-profile Internet stocks were higher, most notably Yahoo, the Internet search company, which soared 14 1/2, to 190 1/4, after it reported quarterly earnings results late Wednesday that were stronger than analysts had expected.
"I think Internet stocks have turned a corner," Mr. Johnson said. "But I've said that before."
Financial stocks, reflecting more nerves about interest rates, were mostly lower, including Chase Manhattan, which was down 1 3/8, to 74 9/16, and Bank of America, down 2 3/16 at 56 11/16.
American Home Products, the drug maker, rose 3 9/16, to 48 11/16, after it agreed to a $3.75 billion settlement over its once-popular diet pill combination, fen-phen.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
European Central Bank Leaves Interest Rate Unchanged

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 7

 BODY:
The European Central Bank decided not to stop Europe's party today, but it bluntly warned that it would probably move soon to slow things down.
Despite steadily increasing concern about inflationary pressures in Europe, the central bank chose to leave its core interest rate unchanged at 2.5 percent. 
 But the bank's president, Wim Duisenberg, issued his clearest and most emphatic statement that the 11-nation euro zone needed to be cooled down and that a tighter monetary policy was almost inevitable.
"We have now had a truly accommodative monetary policy for more than a year," Mr. Duisenberg said after a meeting of the bank's board here today. He said the bank was now looking ahead to "a monetary strategy that is conducive to sustainable, noninflationary growth. That is something different."
Investors, who had thought the bank might raise interest rates today, initially reacted by pushing down the value of the euro, Europe's new common currency.
But they reversed course after absorbing Mr. Duisenberg's unambiguously hawkish remarks, which apparently convinced investors that a tougher policy would come sooner rather than later.
The euro ended the day up against the dollar, settling in New York at $1.07100 compared with $1.06970 Wednesday. Major European stock markets also ended higher, as investors apparently chose to focus more on Europe's vibrant economy rather than the prospect of higher rates. London's blue-chip index rose 1.69 percent, while Frankfurt's main index rose 1.23 percent and France's rose 1.08 percent.
The European Central Bank's decision paralleled a similar verdict today at the Bank of England, which left British rates unchanged at 5.25 percent.
It also meshed with the stance adopted by the United States Federal Reserve on Tuesday.
European bankers have been looking for guidance amid a welter of sometimes conflicting data. The bank sharply cut its core rate in April to 2.5 percent from 3 percent, because the European economy had stalled and seemed dangerously close to a recession.
But the outlook has brightened measurably in the last several months, partly because Asian countries are recovering from the financial crisis that first gripped that region two years ago.
Most forecasters expect the European Union economy to grow about 2.1 percent this year and nearly 3 percent next year. Exports and industrial production are picking up in many countries, and joblessness has moved downward from more than 10 percent to about 9.4 percent.
But bankers also see a growing body of warning signs. Businesses and consumers are borrowing money at a much more rapid rate, with private-sector credit expanding 10.7 percent in August. The money supply, which is considered a barometer of inflationary pressure, has climbed somewhat faster than the central bank would like. And consumer prices have been nudged upward by big increases in oil prices.
Mr. Duisenberg now seems convinced that the main threat is inflation and, by extension, the credibility of the euro in world markets. Higher rates would tend to strengthen the European currency.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Brooklyn Co-op Makes A Financial Comeback

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A four-building, 64-apartment co-op in the Kensington section of Brooklyn that avoided foreclosure seven months ago is back on stable financial footing, ending nearly five years of struggle and enabling shareholders to sell their apartments.
Under a reorganization plan approved by the Federal Bankruptcy Court last month, the co-op refinanced its underlying mortgage with MEW Equities of Brooklyn, one of several companies that specialize in refinancing troubled buildings. 
 As part of its return to financial stability, the co-op, known as the Parkway and C Owners Corporation, placed a special assessment averaging $8,700 per apartment on shareholders. The funds are being used to replenish the co-op's reserve fund and to make improvements in its brick buildings, which fill an entire blockfront along Avenue C between East Fourth and East Fifth Streets, one block from Ocean Parkway.
MEW has taken over 10 apartments from shareholders who either walked away from their investment or could not pay the assessment. As part of the reorganization, MEW is required to rent those apartments and switch to selling them in three years to avoid competing with shareholders selling their apartments.
"The goal was to save as many shareholders as possible, helping those who want to, to sell and get out, and those who don't, to remain financially whole," said John D. Cella, a former president of the co-op board.
In co-ops, shareholders must make monthly payments for their part of their building's underlying mortgage and the operating charges allocated to their apartments. The shareholders also typically make monthly payments on the loans that they have taken out to buy their apartments. If the building is foreclosed, the co-op owners can lose their investment while remaining liable for the loans, said Steven A. Kirschenbaum, a partner with the Manhattan law firm of Hartman & Carven who represents the owners of the Brooklyn co-op.
Mr. Cella and his wife, Lisa, who have owned their apartment since the buildings were converted in 1987, are among the first shareholders selling their apartments. Last year, the couple, seeing the prospect of the co-op's recovery, bought a home in Suffern, N.Y., and rented out their two-bedroom Brooklyn unit, which they are now negotiating to sell to their current tenant. "I'm not a landlord and it's time to move on," Mr. Cella said.
Like many other cooperatives, the Brooklyn complex was faced with financial woes that arose when the economic boom of the mid-1980's deflated. The problems included defaults on loans by sponsors, high mortgages granted to sponsors by lenders, nonpayment of monthly maintenance charges by shareholders and foreclosure by banks.
While some buildings still suffer from long-term problems, most have turned around. The co-op on Avenue C in Brooklyn is an example of what could go wrong.
The buildings were run down and empty before 1987, when the original sponsor converted them to a co-op. Over the next year, all but two of the one- to three-bedroom apartments, with 675 to 1,000 square feet on average, were sold for $52,000 to $107,000. But when the real estate market faltered in 1989, so did the complex.
The original lender, American Savings Bank, failed, and the mortgage was sold to an investor pool managed by State Street Bank and Trust of Boston. Through 1991, many original owners moved away and rented out their units because they were unable to sell them, mainly because of the complex's large underlying mortgage, and, in turn, high monthly maintenance charges. The maintenance fees averaged $592 a month, which was about one-third higher than the standard for co-ops in the area.
Mr. Kirschenbaum said the rents did not cover both the monthly maintenance and the owners' individual loan payments, so by 1994, the co-op defaulted on its mortgage.
To grab the lender's attention, Mr. Kirschenbaum advised the co-op in late 1994 to stop paying the mortgage and to reduce its monthly maintenance to an average of $196, from $592, enough to cover operating costs. At that point, with the rents exceeding the monthly maintenance costs, the shareholders put the difference into a fund for future use.
Early in 1995, the lender filed to foreclose on the complex. It took four more years to persuade the lender to sell the loan and find a company to buy it and work out a deal that "would give shareholders back control of the co-op," Mr. Kirschenbaum said. Last February, the co-op also filed for bankruptcy protection to stay the foreclosure.
Under the reorganization plan, MEW Equities bought the underlying mortgage, which had ballooned from $2.8 million, to $4.25 million, because of unpaid interest, and revised it last month to its current $2.5 million. The monthly maintenance charge was also restored to its higher level, with the lower underlying mortgage making it in line with today's market, and the special assessment was collected from all but four unit owners.
In exchange for the refinancing, MEW took over six units abandoned early on by shareholders and bought the four whose owners did not pay the special assessment. In April, MEW's management arm started to manage the building.
The 10 apartments "provide a meaningful upside," given the strong rental market, said Martin Wydra, a principal of MEW as well as of Park Sterling Brokerage Ltd. of Brooklyn. He added that the units would be renovated when leases expired and monthly rents, now at $825 to $1,300, would be raised to $925 to $1,600.
Mr. Cella, who said he hoped to sell his apartment in the next four months, said his $61,000 asking price was lower than the $70,000 he paid for the unit. "I'm still out my original deposit, but I'll make out fine," he said. Over time, Mr. Cella said, values will rise and "other people at the complex will get back more of their investment than I'm getting back."

HEADLINE: Russia Investigating Its Own Banks for Role in Suspicious Cash Movements

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 7

 BODY:
The nation's top tax official said that his investigation was pointing to a single Russian bank as the architect of the transfer of billions of dollars into accounts under investigation in the United States.
Aleksandr Pochinok, the chief of the Russian State Tax Service, declined to name the bank. But he said in an interview that a small group of Russian businessmen appeared to have pioneered the practice of sending money through the Bank of New York accounts that are under investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. 
 "I think there is one main bank that was at least the ideological center," Mr. Pochinok said in an interview. "The operations were all done in a similar way. And a number of firms are connected with the people at this bank." The transfers themselves were carried out by a number of banks, and he said that a least 10 of them are under investigation.
The aim of the money-moving schemes, Mr. Pochinok said, was to hide income from the Russian tax authorities and avoid Russian taxes and tariffs.
The F.B.I. is looking at a group of accounts at the Bank of New York that American authorities say moved nearly $7 billion out of Russia. On Tuesday, a Federal indictment was unsealed in Manhattan charging three small American companies and three Russian immigrants with illegally operating a money transferring business. The bank, which is cooperating with the investigation, has not been accused of wrongdoing.
Since news of the Federal investigation at the Bank of New York surfaced in August, Russia's response has taken several turns. At first, Government officials dismissed the charges as a political campaign by Republicans in Congress to isolate Russia. They also brushed them off as an attempt to embarrass the Clinton Administration, especially Vice President Al Gore, who has touted his personal relationship with Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, a former Prime Minister of Russia.
Now the Kremlin's aim appears to be to remove the taint of corruption that has hurt all Russian businessman. The Russian Government has come under pressure by the United States to assist its investigation.
But the Russian anticorruption campaign has also raised concerns here that the Government may be looking for a convenient target or scapegoat to put the inquiry behind it and divert attention from allegations of kickbacks to the Government that are unrelated to the banking investigation.
The tax agency has conducted two well-publicized raids on Russian banks. While Mr. Pochinok has said he is investigating about 10 banks, he said today that he plans to check more banks next week. He declined to name all of them today, saying they might sue the Government for libel unless the authorities had proof.
He said he was concerned that some would destroy their computer and paper records before his investigators could get to them. Computer records at the first bank to be raided, Flamingo Bank of Moscow, seem to have been tampered with, he said.
That bank is the subject of a criminal investigation that opened last week. On Tuesday, the police raided Sobin Bank, which has had a long and lucrative relationship with the Russian Government and is owned by powerful business interests.
Mr. Pochinok said that investigators focused on Sobin Bank after discovering payments made to the bank by Flamingo. A third bank, Depozitarno-Kliringovy Bank, has also come under suspicion by tax authorities.
These banks, in turn, have links with other Russian banks and businesses, which may also become targets of the Russian investigation. All have denied any violations.
"We are just following the path of the money," Mr. Pochinok said.
As the head of the State Tax Service, Mr. Pochinok is charged with finding violations of Russian tax laws. Mr. Pochinok said he has received no help from the United States.
He said the Russian investigation has already uncovered a huge number of transactions that went through the Bank of New York account established by the Benex International Company, which the F.B.I. said handled nearly $5 billion of the $7 billion in Russian funds.
"A great number of banks had relations with the Bank of New York," Mr. Pochinok said. "The majority of these are normal interbank relations. Unfortunately, among these operations there are some that were used to evade taxes.
"An enormous number of deals were made through Benex," he added. "And I have not uncovered all of them."
Mr. Pochinok said that Benex appeared to be well known to Russian businessmen.
"As far as I can tell, everyone knew that this firm could be used to send money," he said.
Many of the suspicions transactions uncovered by Russian investigators do not involve money laundering by criminal groups, but efforts to avoid Russian tariffs and taxes. The schemes, Mr. Pochinok said, took several forms. In transactions between Russian companies, for example, payments were made using a series of offshore banks, the Benex accounts at the Bank of New York and several Russian banks, he explained. "The idea of this scheme is conceal the source of the money," he said.
In another scheme, importers dodged tariffs by understating the value of the goods bought from foreign suppliers. The importers then made under-the-table payments to their foreign suppliers through the Benex accounts.
A third scheme, which was more popular before last year's economic crisis, was used to hide the high prices paid for Moscow apartments, Mr. Pochinok said. For a buyer wanting to pay $300,000 for an apartment, for example, the official price might be set at $30,000.
"You transfer $30,000, and $270,000 you send to the Bank of New York account to go to the sellers," he explained. "You are not interested to show that you have this kind of money, and the seller is not eager to pay the taxes from the sale."
Mr. Pochinok said that many transactions involving the Bank of New York were legal. To find a violation, he said the authorities must prove two things: the illegal export of hard currency and tax evasion.
"In many cases, we know we will be able to prove it," he said. "But for this we have to pin down the entire chain."
Although Russian authorities have taken their first steps to investigate the allegations pertaining to the Bank of New York, it is still unclear how far the inquiry will go. Powerful political interests have often shielded the banks from disciplinary action in the past.
But Mr. Pochinok insisted his inquiry would go on.
"We are adding several more to the list, and beginning next week will check several more," he said.

HEADLINE: Across the U.S., Universities Are Fueling High-Tech Economic Booms

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 7

 BODY:
Behold Kendall Square: 50-odd Cambridge acres long a fallow welter of former factories, now the flourishing center of what experts call the most concentrated single cluster of biotechnology in the world.
Behold it from, say, the muddy lot where Biogen Inc. broke ground this week on a new six-story laboratory. Within view lie the butterscotch-beige Genzyme building, the construction site of the coming Amgen building and a new complex housing smaller companies with typically futuristic names like Mitotix and Dyax and Variagenics, all new in the last few years, most connected in some way to two neighbors: the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Harvard. 
 "Biotech as far as the eye can see," Janice Bourque, executive director of the industry's Massachusetts Biotechnology Council, proclaimed with a bit of broad-brush artistic license.
The much-trumpeted "knowledge" (or information, or innovation) economy has its own geography, and it consists of much more than Silicon Valley. Across America, high technology is creating localized boomlets like the one in Kendall Square, which is home to companies not only in the biotech sector but also in software and related fields.
And if there is one never-absent factor at work on these silicon corners, experts say, it is the proximity of a research university shifting from ivory tower to revving economic engine. Indeed, the university is an increasingly powerful force in the knowledge economy, both because its brains are greater assets than ever before and because of a growing trend in which institutions of higher education see themselves as generators of business, whether professors' start-ups or technology licensing deals.
"There's a great awakening that we're sitting on top of a gunpowder keg" of growth, said David Lampe, author of two books on high-tech locales and associate vice president of Boston University, which is building a major biotechnology center of its own in Boston's South End.
A gunpowder keg in more ways than one. As universities and their communities, from Washington State to Georgia, strive for economic horsepower, a host of fresh questions are being raised about what a university's role should be, and what happens if the pursuit of money competes with the pursuit of knowledge. Other concerns arise as well, from congestion around the campus to the high potential that high-tech booms like Boston's first one, on Route 128 a quarter-century ago, can fizzle.
But to many, such concerns pale beside the possible benefits shown in research like the comparative study issued this summer by the independent Milken Institute, in Santa Monica, Calif. That study found that the fast-growing high-tech sector was increasingly "determining which metropolitan areas are succeeding or failing." In Milken's analysis, high-tech activity could explain 65 percent of the difference in economic growth among various metropolitan regions during the 1990's. And, it found, "research centers and institutions are undisputedly the most important factor in incubating high-tech industries." The institutions, experts say, provide nearby companies streams of cutting-edge knowledge as well as streams of smart labor.
Of course, universities have long churned out graduates and ideas that have turned into companies, and have created jobs simply by being huge institutional consumers. But in the knowledge economy, where ideas and information become lucrative products, these cultivators of knowledge are becoming more important than ever, some experts say, not only because of the new economic logic but also because of changes in academia itself.
The incentives for universities to think commercially are manifold, from their share of licensing payments, to the jobs created for graduates, to industry grants for research and even the ability to recruit professors who want a chance to get rich outside the classroom.
Some universities have for years been emphasizing the economic energy they provide and promoting a commercial orientation. In 1997, M.I.T. issued a report, "The Impact of Innovation," describing the impressive economic benefits flowing from the university, including the creation of 14,000 jobs in Cambridge alone at companies founded by its faculty and graduates.
Similarly, in 1995, the University of California distributed a report called "U.C. Means Business," which pointed out that, among other things, some 80 companies had been spun out of the university's San Diego campus, providing more than 7,000 jobs to the region, largely in biotech and biomedical companies.
Every one of the nine University of California campuses has a high-technology cluster near it, said Robert N. Shelton, the system's vice provost for research. And it is Silicon Valley's tale of genesis that it all began with garage-based start-ups and vision that came out of Stanford.
Other universities are just now joining in this promotion of a commercial emphasis. Last week Harvard, not exactly known as a dirty-fingernails kind of place, detailed for the first time the overall lift it gives the local economy. Neil L. Rudenstine, the university's president, underscored in a speech to the Boston Chamber of Commerce "the dynamic connections between Harvard, higher education and the rest of the economy -- the new knowledge economy we are building together."
With that interconnection in mind, said Paul Grogan, the university's vice president for community relations, Harvard is seeking new economic roles, even contemplating "research parks and business incubators that would be very closely tied to parts of the university."
Such roles, Mr. Grogan noted, raise "all sorts of new questions: where the lines are on this stuff, who owns what, how you use students --it's a million things, but these questions are part of something that is exciting and breaking molds."
Molds can be messy to break, however. Experts say many universities balk at commercialization of their long-sacrosanct intellectual pursuits. Serious issues can arise: everything from, say, the tension between a money-making engineering department and a poor English department to worries that "pure" basic research, with no business potential, will suffer.
Mary S. Spaeth, an expert in the field for Angle Technology, of London, said that in the transition from tower to marketplace, it had often been very difficult "for a university to reconcile those things and not feel it's compromising its integrity."
Reviews are mixed, too, on the impact that the high-technology boomlets spun out of universities have on local communities. Kendall Square, with its brick high-rises and cleverly rehabilitated factory buildings, may look palatial compared with its sludgy former self. But neighbors complain about the congestion it creates on some of the city's narrow streets, and that it is more of a Wall Street-style business center than a lively neighborhood mix.
Complaints often arise in such growing areas, said Annalee Saxenian, an associate professor of planning at the University of California at Berkeley who has written about Route 128 in the Boston area and about Silicon Valley.
"There have been cases," Dr. Saxenian said, "where growth that has been generated by the university spinoffs has displaced lower-income communities, so there are new tensions that emerge in some cases."
On the other hand, university officials say, town-gown relations tend to improve noticeably when a university becomes more market-oriented.
A generation ago, said Lita Nelsen, M.I.T.'s director of technology licensing, the university was seen in Cambridge as "this monster using up space and not paying taxes and scattering unwashed undergrads all over."
"Now," she said, "M.I.T. is seen as a partner in Cambridge in developing real estate and providing high-paying jobs in high-tech industry, and I think that relations have been enormously affected by it."
Dozens of university-linked research parks are already built or under construction around the country, so many that there is an Association of University-Related Research Parks, based in Washington, with nearly 200 member parks. Many of them are modeled on their granddaddies, North Carolina's Research Triangle Park and the Stanford Research Park, still thriving.
In other areas, university-side boomlets grow more spontaneously, as is the case with Kendall Square.
Biotechnology has a particular tendency to want to cluster near a university, several experts said, because it tends to have such a long research phase before coming up with marketable products. Further, it needs to be close to universities as the source of many of its employees, and near the affiliated hospitals where clinical trials can be run.
Henri A. Termeer, president of Genzyme, which employs nearly 4,000 people, said the company had been so intimately connected with M.I.T., from the postdoctoral students who did its early experiments to the professors who advise it and the graduates it now hires, that it most likely could not have got going elsewhere. "If you had the same ideas but you were away from these kinds of skills, this very advanced leading-edge level, you could not carry it out," Mr. Termeer said. "You wouldn't get there. You would just stay with the idea."
Kendall Square is far from the only home to Boston-area biotech, and over all, California, with its Biotech Coast, has more such companies than Massachusetts. But Ms. Bourque, of the Massachusetts Biotechnology Council, said that within a radius of five miles or so of the square, there were some 70 biotech companies, making this the most concentrated cluster anywhere. And almost everyone, she said, has a sense that this is only the beginning, that "we're not even in the golden years yet."
Kendall Square has seen something a lot like this before. In the industrial era, it was the odoriferous home to everything from a soap factory to meat-renderers. Then it hit a period of decline. It did not help that under President John F. Kennedy, the Federal Government cleared whole swaths of it, planning to erect here the space center that, under President Lyndon B. Johnson, went to Houston instead.
The square's current dense amalgam of laboratories, offices and hotels began taking shape in the 1980's, but lately, said James C. Mullen, president and chief operating officer of Biogen, "it is an explosion."
M.I.T. has done this before, too. It was seen as the primary academic engine behind the high-technology cluster on Route 128; but then that area fell from grace, as the industry shifted from its mini-computers to personal computers. In her book "Regional Advantage," (Harvard University Press, 1994), Dr. Saxenian, of Berkeley, posited that Route 128 suffered, while Silicon Valley bounced back, in large part because of differences in business culture: the more hidebound and high-walled Eastern companies outdone by smaller and more cooperative Western ones.
But Kendall Square, with its fluent flow among companies and academia, seems to be avoiding the mistakes of Route 128, she said.
"We have a joke here that the only place that isn't trying to replicate Silicon Valley is Silicon Valley," she said. In a small way, she said, "I think Kendall Square has achieved it."

HEADLINE: Nobel Winner Is to Head Cancer Center

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG and JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Dr. Harold E. Varmus, the Nobel Prize-winning molecular biologist who has presided over the National Institutes of Health during the greatest expansion in its 112-year history, told President Clinton yesterday that he would resign at the end of the year to become president and chief executive of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan.
When he left the University of California at San Francisco to go to Washington six years ago, Dr. Varmus had never run anything larger than a research laboratory. His tenure at the National Institutes of Health was blessed by a good economy and an explosion in biomedical research, and he took advantage of both to persuade Congress to increase the agency's budget vastly, to nearly $15.6 billion this year from $10.3 billion in 1993, with a $2 billion increase last year alone. 
 At Sloan-Kettering, Dr. Varmus, 59, will meet entirely new challenges. He is a basic scientist -- he won "the Prize," as he calls it, in 1989 for the discovery of a family of cancer-causing genes.
In New York, he will be forced to face something perhaps even more intractable than a divided Congress: a rapidly evolving payer system in which managed care, so far mostly disdained by the hospital, rules. He will now also find himself dealing with insurance payment contracts and market share wars.
The appointment of Dr. Varmus suggests that Memorial Sloan-Kettering is hoping to move in a new direction. Its president, Dr. Paul Marks, 73, who is retiring, developed the center's research base, but now, its directors say, they hope to merge that research with ongoing cancer treatment.
Dr. Varmus was selected foremost for his clinical talents, said Dr. William Hoskins, the deputy physician-in-chief of disease management at Sloan-Kettering, who served on the search committee. "Most of us in cancer realize the time is ripe to begin the process of bringing the lab to the bedside," he said. "I think he has the vision to do that."
In recent years many area hospitals have elbowed their way into cancer care, drawing on a huge base of patients who increasingly must pay for their treatment under H.M.O. programs. Dr. Marks, who often hobnobbed with famous donors and patients like Evelyn H. Lauder, has shown little interest in this issue, focusing instead on the development of the center's research arm and endowment.
In an interview yesterday, Dr. Varmus said that while he has mixed emotions about leaving the National Institutes of Health, he is ready for a change after six years of Government work. "I wanted to run another organization," he said, "and be in a position to see the fruits of 25 or 30 years of cancer research in the lab come to fulfillment."
When Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, suggested Dr. Varmus for the N.I.H. director's job, what most people knew about him was that he had won the Nobel Prize, that he wore rumpled clothes (he still does) and rode his bicycle 12 miles to work.
"Most people didn't know if he had the temperament to do the political work, because it's an enormously political job," said Dr. Herbert Pardes, dean of the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University. "I think he outperformed the most optimistic expectations that anybody had."
He is credited with lifting flagging morale among scientists, both inside and outside the agency, by recruiting some of the best minds in academia to the N.I.H. "He really understood the plight of investigators today," said Dr. William R. Brinkley, former president of the Federation of American Societies of Experimental Biologists.
And Dr. Varmus proved himself an adroit politician, keeping a low profile as he navigated such tricky ethical issues as the still-unsettled question of whether the Government should pay for research on human embryonic stem cells.
In a statement today, Dr. Shalala said Dr. Varmus's appointment to N.I.H. was "one of the greatest accomplishments of this Administration."
Representative John E. Porter, the Illinois Republican who is chairman of the House subcommittee that handles N.I.H. appropriations, said, "While none of us are irreplaceable, he comes about as close to it as, I think, anyone does."
With its 25 separate institutes and centers, the N.I.H., which sprawls over a vast campus of brick buildings and rolling hills in Bethesda, Md., is one of the world's premier agencies for scientific research.
Dr. Varmus told the directors of the N.I.H. that he was leaving during a staff meeting yesterday morning, and then sent an E-mail message to the agency's employees, who number about 16,000.
The meeting was emotional, said Dr. Richard Klausner, director of the National Cancer Institute. "There was a sense of the passing of an era, an era about which we all feel very good."
But there was not universal approval of Dr. Varmus's leadership. Patient advocacy groups often complained that with his interest in basic science, Dr. Varmus did not pay enough attention to their needs, and complained bitterly at his refusal to fund research on specific diseases. Dr. Varmus's philosophy was that "a rising tide lifts all boats." He believed that an understanding of how cells work and other matters of human biology would lead to discoveries in all diseases.
"The message out of N.I.H. to the disease groups always seemed to be, 'Well, everything we do here benefits everything,' " said William T. Schmidt, a spokesman for the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation. "Of course, that was very difficult for people to buy. It just didn't sell well with our constituency."
And it also did not sell well with the Institute of Medicine, an independent research arm of the National Academy of Sciences. In a report last year, the Institute criticized the N.I.H. for not paying enough attention to patients and urged the Federal health agency to more systematically consider the deaths and suffering caused by specific diseases when setting its research priorities.
At Memorial Sloan-Kettering, Dr. Varmus will be greeted with open arms, said Dr. Raymond P. Warrell Jr., an attending physician and member of Sloan-Kettering.
"The clinical staff is hugely excited," he said. "The biggest challenge is to integrate basic science programs to the direct care of patients with cancer as quickly as possible. It is a challenge that many cancer centers have faced and the fact that he faced them on a national level is a huge plus."
