HEADLINE: Bradley Wants More Spending To Ease Stresses on Families

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: PETERBOROUGH, N.H., Oct. 7

 BODY:
Former Senator Bill Bradley offered his prescription for the stresses on families of global economic competition, calling today for $3.6 billion a year in new Federal spending to expand day care services, improve community colleges and encourage the elderly to work with children.
Speaking in a crowded high school gym in this rustic mountain hamlet, Mr. Bradley said the idyllic "Norman Rockwell" world he had known as a child in Missouri had all but disappeared, replaced by a high-pressure economy that often forced both parents to work and left them little time for their children. 
 "The new global economy just doesn't care about the 6:30 dinner," Mr. Bradley told more than 1,000 students and supporters. "It doesn't care that you don't know how to use a computer. The global economy isn't worrying about you at all."
Mr. Bradley's speech came at a time when he is battling his lone rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Vice President Al Gore, for the support of labor unions. Leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. are debating whether to issue an endorsement at the labor federation's meeting next week.
Like the Vice President, Mr. Bradley has come under heavy criticism from many labor leaders for supporting trade policies, including the North American Free Trade Agreement, that have spurred global competition and caused, they say, layoffs and other economic dislocations for American workers.
Today, Mr. Bradley, a former New York Knick forward who went on to represent New Jersey for three terms in the Senate, asserted that he understood the strains of juggling parenthood with work, describing how he prepared frozen dinners for his daughter in Washington while his wife, Ernestine, taught college courses back home.
"When I took the oath of office, I raised my right hand high, but in my left hand I held Theresa Anne," he said, referring to his daughter, the couple's only child.
Today's speech, the second of four major policy addresses he plans to make this fall, came a week after Mr. Bradley outlined his proposal for extending health insurance to most Americans. Though Mr. Bradley has criticized Mr. Gore for taking an "incremental" approach to fixing the nation's problems, the plan he outlined today seemed relatively modest in scope, and included these elements:
*Mr. Bradley would create a $2 billion-a-year program to finance day care and other programs for the preschool children of working parents of all income levels. Modeled after a North Carolina program called "Smart Start," Mr. Bradley's plan would allow committees of local officials, business leaders, child-care workers and parents to allocate the Federal grants. The money could also be spent on counseling or education programs.
*He called for giving $400 million a year in grants to community colleges, an increase of nearly a third over current Federal support. The money could be used to improve programs intended to place students in jobs in the local economy or to retrain older workers whose jobs have changed or been eliminated by technological advancements. "A pair of strong hands are not what they used to be," Mr. Bradley said. "Now those hands have to be able to use a keyboard."
*He proposed $200-a-month stipends to the elderly for working 15 hours a week with young people in approved programs like tutoring or counseling.
*And he advocated expanding the Family and Medical Leave Act, which requires employers with 50 or more employees to give workers up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave a year for reasons like childbirth or family illnesses. Mr. Bradley would expand the law to cover employers with 25 or more workers, bringing 12 million more people into its reach. He would also require employers to give workers 24 unpaid hours a year for less pressing situations, like parent-teacher conferences.
Mr. Gore has called for a similar expansion of the leave act, as well as for increasing Federal subsidies for day care services. He has proposed providing tax incentives to companies that offer day care services. And he has called for eliminating the so-called marriage penalty, which causes spouses filing joint returns to pay higher taxes than single people.
Recent polls have shown Mr. Bradley and Mr. Gore in a dead heat in New Hampshire, the site of the nation's first primary, next February.
Though Mr. Bradley received a standing ovation from the students, it was clear many of them had no idea who he was. To underscore that point, the principal, Susan Dell, said in her introduction of the candidate that not a single student in one ninth-grade class had heard of Mr. Bradley, despite his candidacy and place in the basketball Hall of Fame.
"I probably would know this guy if he ever had played basketball," one of the students told his teacher, Ms. Dell said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

American Home Products To Settle Diet-Drug Case
American Home Products agreed to pay $3.75 billion to thousands of people who contend they were injured by taking the popular diet pill combination fen-phen. 
 Under the settlement -- one of the largest ever in a product liability case -- people who used one of the diet drugs for 60 days or less would be eligible for $30 to $60 prescription refunds, while those who have a heart valve injury could receive up to $1.5 million. Page A1.
 
Fed to Review Disclosure Policy
Concerned that its latest attempt to be more open might be confusing investors, the Federal Reserve has established a panel to review its new practice of disclosing once-secret decisions about tilting policy toward raising or reducing interest rates. The establishment of the committee was disclosed in the minutes of the Aug. 24 Fed meeting, where the central bank raised interest rates. The minutes showed that the increase was approved 9 to 1. The dissenter was Robert D. McTeer Jr., a leading advocate of the theory that the economy is capable of higher rates of noninflationary growth. C7.
 
Sweden Goes Against the Grain
At a time when world leaders are fascinated by the United States' economic success and its credo of less government and low taxes, Sweden seems to be defying gravity. The Government consumes nearly 60 percent of the national economy, and taxes and wages are among the highest in the world. Yet this largely unreconstructed welfare state is one of Europe's most vibrant economies. A1.
 
On-Line Grocer Delays Stock Offer
The on-line grocer Webvan Group delayed a stock offering, not because it had more selling to do to investors but because it had done too much already. The company appears to have run afoul of regulators by giving out unpublished information in a conference call. C2.
 
National Grid Not Done Expanding
David H. Jones of National Grid Group, which has already agreed to buy a large utility in New England, said that his company would seek more acquisitions in the Northeast. C2.
 
Dow and S.& P. Fall; Nasdaq Rises
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 51.29 points, to 10,537.05. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 7.76 points, to 1,317.64, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 3.49 points, to 2,860.70. C7.
 
G.E. Posts 16% Gain in Earnings
Slightly beating analysts' expectations, General Electric said its third-quarter profit rose 16 percent, helped by acquisitions and more sales of turbines, engines and contracts to service industrial equipment. Shares of G.E. fell $1.8125, to $121.875. G.E. stock typically falls on the day it reports earnings after rising in the days before the release. The pattern reflects people betting that G.E. will meet the estimates and then cashing out. C6.
 
Times to Add Op-Ed Columnist
Paul Krugman, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, will become a columnist for The New York Times's Op-Ed page beginning in January. C6.
 
State Farm Changes Repair Policy
Having lost a $456 million jury verdict on Monday, State Farm said that it would temporarily require that all repairs on its policyholders' automobiles be done with parts produced by auto makers or their affiliates. A18.
 
Chase Planning to Move 3,500 Jobs
Chase Manhattan, the largest corporate employer in New York City, is moving 10 percent of its jobs -- 3,500 positions -- to Florida, Texas and Massachusetts. B1.

HEADLINE: Mr. Vajpayee's India

 BODY:
Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee of India has won an impressive election victory that gives his coalition a chance to survive longer than recent governments in New Delhi. Stability would be a welcome development after a succession of inconclusive elections and short-lived ruling coalitions, including Mr. Vajpayee's, which collapsed in April. No less encouraging is his promise to revive negotiations with Pakistan, speed economic liberalization and refrain from steps hostile to Muslims and other minorities. Progress on these fronts should make the world breathe easier and clear the way for President Clinton to visit next year.
Mr. Vajpayee's triumph was helped along by a growing economy and the voters' yearning for an end to unsettled governments. Voters also appear to have been impressed by his confident but restrained handling of the intrusion of Pakistani-backed militants in the disputed state of Kashmir during the summer. Indian forces repulsed the invaders without widening the conflict, while Indian diplomats got the United States and other countries to press Pakistan for the militants' withdrawal. 
 The cause of reducing regional tensions needs immediate attention. India and Pakistan, which both exploded nuclear devices last year, must quickly fulfill their commitment to signing the nuclear Test Ban Treaty and try to reach agreements on curbing missile testing and producing nuclear materials. They also need to resume discussions on preventing the Kashmir dispute from spinning into a wider war.
As 360 million Indians voted over the last month, the world's largest and most fractious democracy once again set a stirring example for all nations. For Mr. Vajpayee, the victory was more precarious than he might have wished. His Bharatiya Janata Party actually lost seats in India's most populous state, Uttar Pradesh, a longtime party stronghold. But he can savor the vote as a gesture of confidence in his leadership. He is now the first Indian Prime Minister to win back-to-back elections since Indira Gandhi in 1971. He has also managed to rid his party of some of its Hindu chauvinist reputation by agreeing not to institute the party's most virulent anti-Muslim measures.
Meanwhile, the election dealt a significant defeat to the Congress Party, which had turned to Sonia Gandhi, the daughter-in-law of Indira and widow of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. Mrs. Gandhi had been drafted to help save the party, but after stirring up some initial excitement, she stumbled.
India's rich diversity sometimes looks like an obstacle to unity. But the latest election has proved that a commitment to resolving differences peacefully and democratically can transform diversity into a source of strength.

Hindu Nationalist Coalition Wins Indian Elections

Treaty's Fate Tied to U.S.
Speakers at a conference convened to press for ratification of the nuclear test-ban treaty -- including two of the major holdouts, Russia and China -- suggested that the ban might founder if it was not ratified by the United States Senate. The Clinton Administration and Senate Republicans agree that the ban faces nearly certain defeat if it comes to a vote, so the major discussion has been about whether, and how, to postpone the vote -- and keep the treaty alive -- at least until next year. House Passes Health Bill Expanding Patients' Rights

Effort to Preserve Forests

HEADLINE: Bush Challenges the Orthodoxy But Is Still a Devout Conservative

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON with FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
For as long as Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has been describing himself as a "compassionate conservative," Republicans and Democrats alike have wondered whether the phrase was a call for a flexible new ideology or an effort to put a friendlier face on an essentially unchanged philosophy.
Mr. Bush's public statements, including his denunciation this week of his party's focus on wealth, suggest a willingness to use his commanding position in the Republican Presidential race to challenge some of the party's assumptions about what it stands for. 
 But as he starts to take positions, particularly on prominent issues like taxes and economic policy, Mr. Bush is by no means abandoning the basic conservative principles that have defined the party at least since the Reagan Administration.
Mr. Bush is clearly trying a delicate balancing act, seeking to retain the faith of the Republican Party's conservative base even as he courts the moderate voters he would need to win the general election. And beyond political positioning, Mr. Bush's lack of specificity may also reflect the early stage of the campaign, when candidates are still formulating policy positions, as well as some debate within his campaign about how far he should tilt in either direction.
"He's still a work in progress," said William A. Niskanen, an economic adviser in the Reagan Administration who is now chairman of the Cato Institute, a conservative research organization in Washington.
On the campaign trail and in meetings with his policy advisers, Mr. Bush emphasizes a traditional conservative belief in the power of free markets and is as enthusiastic as any Reagan-era supply-sider in calling for tax cuts.
His economic advisers, many of whom served in the Reagan and Bush Administrations, are drawn from centers of orthodox conservative thought like the Hoover Institution at Stanford University and the American Enterprise Institute, a research organization in Washington.
The advisers' basic thrust remains reducing marginal tax rates, a step that cuts tax bills proportionally more for the wealthy, who pay the most taxes, than for middle- and lower-income people. And they back tax cuts that Democrats have long said are skewed to the rich, including the elimination of the inheritance tax on large estates.
Where Mr. Bush and his team seem to be taking a fresh approach is in applying conservative orthodoxy in new ways.
They point out, for example, that high marginal tax rates can be more of a problem for a single mother working her way out of poverty than for an investment banker. As workers move from income levels associated with the working poor -- below $20,000 a year -- into middle-class income levels, they often lose all or part of tax breaks like the earned income tax credit, and enter higher tax brackets, meaning that a big chunk of their additional earnings goes to taxes.
The main policy idea behind "compassionate conservatism" is to help people in that kind of situation, probably through an expansion of the earned income tax credit or through other changes to the tax code that would allow low- to middle-income workers to take home more of what they earn.
"Governor Bush understands and very much believes that high marginal tax rates create enormous disincentives," said Lawrence B. Lindsey, a former Federal Reserve governor who heads the candidate's economic policy team. "What may be new here is the realization, which he's talked about on the stump, that high marginal rates affect not only high-income people but a lot of low-income people as well."
In addition to Mr. Lindsey, Mr. Bush's economic team includes Michael Boskin, who was chief economist in the Bush White House; John F. Cogan, a former budget aide to President Reagan; Martin S. Feldstein, a former Reagan Administration chief economist; John B. Taylor, an expert on monetary policy who worked on Bob Dole's 1996 Presidential campaign, and R. Glenn Hubbard, who was a Treasury Department official under President Bush.
Members of the team say they consider themselves technicians, simply taking the goals laid out by Mr. Bush and finding ways of translating them into workable policies. Yet there is concern among other Republicans working with Mr. Bush that the campaign will be too tentative in trying to redefine the party, and will miss an opportunity to broaden its appeal.
Especially after the failure of the big Republican tax cut to generate much public enthusiasm before it was vetoed by President Clinton, some Republicans would like to see Mr. Bush support a tax plan that clearly repositions the party toward the political center by adopting some of the approaches supported by the Democrats, including more tax breaks targeted to the middle class.
"The reason why it is so important for Governor Bush's plan to lean in the direction of those left behind," said one adviser to Mr. Bush, speaking on the condition of anonymity, "is because it's the right policy and the right politics if we want to recapture the idea of being the party of the middle class."
Outside of his economic team, Mr. Bush's most influential advisers include a number of advocates of new approaches to domestic policy, including Mayor Stephen Goldsmith of Indianapolis; Mike Gerson, the governor's speechwriter and a senior policy adviser, and Marvin Olasky, a conservative theoretician who advocates harnessing faith-based programs and charities to address social ills.
Last week Mr. Bush effectively shot down a proposal by Republicans in the House to delay payments to the working poor under the earned income tax credit program, saying Congress should not balance the budget "on the backs of the poor." And on Wednesday he said that Republicans had too often "focused on the national economy, to the exclusion of all else," and that the strongest argument for conservative ideals should be "that they lead to greater justice, less suffering, more opportunity."
Mr. Bush has angered some Republican members of Congress with his criticism of how the party has conducted itself, and he has been attacked by several of his rivals for the Republican Party's nomination, including Steve Forbes and Gary L. Bauer, for being insufficiently conservative on both economic and social policy.
Yet there has not been any widespread uprising against Mr. Bush by conservatives, in part because of his big lead in the polls. And his advisers suggest that he seems to have a Reaganesque ability to communicate a conservative agenda in a nonthreatening way that defuses Democratic attempts to portray the Republican party as mean spirited.
"He has publicly said he is a supply-sider, and when he says that he says it with a passion that gives conservatives in the Republican party more comfort than they get from candidates who are viewed as more conservative," said Representative Rob Portman, a Republican from Ohio who is working with the Bush campaign.
"At the same time he's comfortable focusing on issues like charitable giving," Mr. Portman said. "Perhaps what he is showing us is that because of the power of his personality or the strength of his passion, he can break through and persuade people that these are not inconsistent."

HEADLINE: Fen-Phen Maker to Pay Billions In Settlement of Diet-Injury Cases

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

 BODY:
The American Home Products Corporation agreed yesterday to pay $3.75 billion in total to thousands of people who contend they were injured by taking the popular diet pill combination fen-phen.
Under the settlement -- one of the largest ever in a product liability case -- people who used one of the diet drugs for 60 days or less would be eligible for $30 to $60 prescription refunds, while those who have a heart valve injury could receive as much as $1.5 million. 
 While executives and industry analysts hailed the agreement -- which came after months of negotiations and whose terms were widely expected -- as a way for the company to put an embarrassing problem behind it, yesterday's agreement does not shield American Home Products from all fen-phen liabilities.
Some six million people took the diet drugs Pondimin, American Home Products' brand name for fenfluramine, the "fen" in fen-phen, and Redux, a similar drug.
The drugs were hailed earlier in the decade as miracle pills for obesity, as an alternative to pure diet and exercise. Diet centers actively promoted the pills to the obese and even to people who wanted to lose a few pounds. In 1996, doctors wrote 18 million prescriptions for the two drugs.
But in September 1997, the company removed the drugs from the market at the request of the Food and Drug Administration after studies linked them to heart valve damage.
Pondimin and Redux depressed appetite, while the other drug in the combination, phentermine, increased the rate at which calories were burned. Doctors at the Mayo Clinic reported heart valve defects in the summer of 1996.
Since the drugs were pulled off the market, some 6,500 lawsuits encompassing 11,000 people have been filed. Yesterday's settlement covers all of the six million who took fen-phen, but only those who are found to have heart valve problems can collect from an injury award fund that the company will establish. The agreement, which must be approved by United States District Court Judge Louis C. Bechtle of Philadelphia, also has some strings attached.
It does not cover the 100 claims the company's faces from people who contend fen-phen gave them primary pulmonary hypertension, an often fatal lung illness. And if too many people -- a number American Home Products did not define yesterday -- choose to drop out of the settlement and pursue an individual lawsuit, the company could scrap the agreement. Lawyers for fen-phen users said that was an unlikely outcome.
"We made this settlement flexible so that more people will participate in it," said Stanley Chesley, a partner with Waite, Schneider, Bayless & Chesley in Cincinnati, one of the lead plaintiff lawyers. "The way this settlement is set up, the consumers have no disadvantage."
For American Home Products, the settlement is the latest in a series of moves over the last three months intended to resolve long-standing problems.
In July, the company agreed to pay $54 million to settle claims of women who said they were not adequately warned about the side effects of the company's Norplant birth control device. Just two days ago, American Home Products announced that it would restructure its agricultural division, slicing 700 positions from the unit.
"I feel good about the able efforts of our attorneys to bring about the settlement," said John R. Stafford, chief executive officer of American Home Products. "For our consumers, the settlement will give them a quick and fair resolution. I feel good about that."
Plaintiff lawyers who negotiated the settlement said the agreement was especially comprehensive. The settlement, valued at $3.75 billion before inflation, will be divided into two funds. One fund, valued at $1 billion, will pay for drug refunds and medical screening costs.
The second fund, valued at $2.55 billion, will pay personal injury claims, with awards ranging up to $1.5 million. The remaining $200 million from the $3.75 billion total has been set aside for legal fees for medical monitoring claims.
The fund will remain open for up to 16 years, leaving American Home Products liable for a higher payout. Plaintiff's lawyers calculated yesterday that with interest, American Home Products could pay as much as $4.83 billion. That would put fen-phen as one of the highest product injury settlements ever, dwarfing the $3.2 billion Dow Corning paid last year to settle its silicone breast implant claims.
"Even with the $4 billion settlement, you have to say that American Home Products pulled off a good settlement," said David Saks, a managing director at Gruntal & Company. "Some of the early estimates were everywhere from $3 billion to $10 billion. The company was stuck in a quicksand of uncertainty."
The fen-phen settlement also represents a bit of unusual legal maneuvering. It is rare for a national class-action settlement to allow participants to "opt out" and pursue an individual case at three separate points. Under the settlement, consumers can opt out in the beginning, when they discover they have a leaky heart value during the screening process, or when they learn the amount of their injury award.
When the outlines of the settlement began to emerge three weeks ago, analysts expressed concern that American Home Products was being too lenient, because a large number of consumers could still pursue litigation, leaving the company to face a large amount of liabilities.
Yet, the fen-phen settlement is not as lenient as first feared by analysts. Consumers can drop out at those three points, but if they do so at the final two stages -- the screening process and the payout -- they cannot seek punitive damages against American Home Products in an individual case.
While many plaintiff lawyers are thrilled with the settlement, others are annoyed at some of its details. For example, in order for consumers to receive money from the personal injury fund they must suffer heart valve leaks that are measurable on a scale used by the Food and Drug Administration.
Some lawyers complained that the only thing many consumers may receive is a refund for their prescriptions.
"The payments are not going to be large enough to cover medical expenses for a large number of people," said Ed Blizzard, a Houston lawyer who represents fen-phen users. "A large number of people only receive money for what they paid for the drugs."
The settlement, if approved by the court, provides a sum for lawyers' fees of up to $429 million -- $200 million from the monitoring fund and $229 million included in the personal injury fund. Mr. Chesley said he expected about 100 lawyers to collect fees.
American Home Products said yesterday that it would take a $3.29 billion after-tax charge against third-quarter earnings to pay for the settlement.
Analysts were optimistic that the company's stock would increase now that it had moved aggressively to put the fen-phen liabilities behind it. Shares of American Home Product rose $3.5625, or 7.8 percent, yesterday to close at $48.6875.

HEADLINE: Fund-Raising, Texas-Style

 BODY:

To the Editor:
George W. Bush, through his experience as Governor of Texas, has somehow arrived at the conclusion that it takes money to run social programs and has decided to take his party to task purely out of his conviction that we should do the right thing for our poor and disenfranchised (editorial, Oct. 6). However, as a Texan, I can assure you it is only a sweet dream. 
 Texas is at or near the bottom of all states when it comes to health care, education and just about any social program you can name. And while Mr. Bush has always made speeches about leaving no one behind, the only legislation he ever really pushed in Austin ended up benefiting business. I'm afraid his newly professed "compassionate conservatism" and his distancing himself from the Republican leadership is nothing more than a chimera.
CHRISTINE HIBBARD
Dallas, Oct. 6, 1999

HEADLINE: Don't Put Strings on Debt Relief

 BODY:

To the Editor:
President Clinton's pledge to cancel the debts of poor countries (editorial, Oct. 4) is welcome. But as you point out, only four countries have qualified for debt relief from the International Monetary Fund, and "it took years of I.M.F.-imposed austerity to do so." 
 In fact, the I.M.F.'s austerity measures have increased poor countries' debt and worsened conditions for their people.
President Clinton's debt initiative requires poor countries to comply with three years of I.M.F.-imposed economic reforms. Debt relief should not be preconditioned on economic reforms directed by the I.M.F. It is needed immediately and unconditionally.
 
MARK COATS
Austin, Tex., Oct. 5, 1999

HEADLINE: Don't Put Strings on Debt Relief;
The Debt Bargain

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Unburdening the Third World" (editorial, Oct. 4) was a reminder of how so much good can be done for so little money. Forgiving the debt the world's poorest countries owe to the United States, as President Clinton proposes, would cost only about $1.20 per American for three years, but it would relieve human misery on a scale most of us can only imagine. 
 An important part of American jurisprudence is the concept of bankruptcy: if people fall upon hard times through misfortune, they should not have to pay for it the rest of their lives. Let us extend this kindly principle to those who need it most.
 
FREDERICK E. SCHUEPFER
Harriman, N.Y., Oct. 5, 1999

HEADLINE: Chase Is Moving 3,500 of Its Jobs From New York

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON

 BODY:
The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the largest corporate employer in New York City, is moving 10 percent of its jobs -- 3,500 positions -- to Florida, Texas and Massachusetts, the company told its workers yesterday.
This may well be the largest exodus of jobs from the city; officials and corporate consultants said they could not remember a bigger relocation by a single company. But in the late 1980's, many Wall Street firms began moving their "back office" record-keeping and data processing jobs to New Jersey and Florida, a trend that Chase is now catching up with. 
 Beginning next year, Chase will move two entire back-office units, from entry-level positions to technology workers to senior managers, said Ken Herz, a spokesman for the company. One of the businesses transfers money for companies; the other involves tracking and processing stock and bond trades.
By relocating its workers, the bank will cut its costs significantly, Mr. Herz said, though he would not say how much money it expected to save. Salaries, real estate costs, taxes, telecommunications charges and utilities costs are all lower in Tampa, Fla., and Dallas, where most of the jobs are to be relocated. Some would also be moved to Lowell, Mass.
But the savings are so big that Chase did not even approach the city for financial or logistical help to try to keep the jobs in New York, Mr. Herz said. "There was no way the city could come up with enough money," he added. "These are very significant savings."
"We're always sorry to see any jobs go," said Deputy Mayor Randy L. Levine. But, he said, Chase has promised to keep its headquarters and core business in the city and will be expanding its other operations. The company, which Mr. Levine said was looking for a million square feet, has been searching unsuccessfully for space in which to expand.
Technological advances have prompted banks to slash the number of employees in the city over the last decade, as have mergers; Chase, for example, combined with Chemical Bank. Employment at depository institutions has fallen from almost 175,000 in 1988 to about 110,000 today, according to the State Labor Department.
Many of the jobs that have disappeared were held by middle-class people earning middle-income salaries, leading some economists and government officials to worry that New York is increasingly becoming a city of the very rich and very poor. "It's a constant worry, that all the middle-class finance jobs are going, that the banks can't afford to keep them here," said one former city official.
The city government has offered financial incentives to large companies that threatened to leave the city; Chase received $235 million in 1988, when it agreed to move many back-office employees to Brooklyn, rather than New Jersey. It now has about 6,000 employees at Brooklyn's Metrotech Center office complex, which is full.
Some Metrotech jobs are among those that are being moved, Mr. Herz said, adding that Chase planned to relocate other business units to Metrotech to keep it full.
Most of the employees whose jobs are being moved work at the tip of Manhattan, at 4 New York Plaza and 55 Water Street. While Chase said it would offer to relocate many of those workers, several interviewed yesterday said they were unlikely to go.
"I guess if you're single or live with your parents, you could pack up and move, but I can't," one middle-aged employee said. "We constantly get letters from the chairman saying you're doing a great job; now, we really feel betrayed."
The city's Metrotech deal with Chase particularly rankled some, another employee said. "It's a sorry state," he complained. "Here's a major corporation that receives tax abatements from the city, and part of that deal is to bring jobs to the city. Slowly but surely, they move operations."
One reason that employees may be reluctant to relocate is that their chances of finding work in New York City are unusually good, corporate consultants said. The unemployment rate in the city is 6.9 percent, down from roughly 10 percent in early 1997, and many companies are adding new jobs at a record pace.
"Most people will find jobs in a couple of months, definitely," said Dennis J. Donovan, a partner in the Wadley-Donovan Group, which advises companies on relocations.
That was not the case in the late 1980's, when Merrill Lynch moved 2,500 back-office jobs to Jersey City. Or, in the mid-1990's, when several big financial firms threatened to move to Stamford, and Swiss Bank actually did, taking 1,300 jobs with it. Citigroup, which employs about 25,000 people in the city, has for years had its stock custodial business in Tampa, a Citigroup spokesman, Jack Morris, said.
Companies have discovered that they can have administrative tasks performed almost anywhere, even overseas, said Daniel Malachuck, a partner at Arthur Andersen who specializes in business location services. Some of his clients, he said, have moved their back-office operations to New Delhi and Manila.
At the same time, however, companies and their employees have become far more optimistic about staying in New York City, Mr. Malachuck said, and less inclined to move to another part of the country.
"We don't know what the post-Rudy mind-set will be, but people feel better about the city and their situation," he said. "And people have been to some of those other places."

An article in some editions yesterday about the decision by the Chase Manhattan Corporation to move 3,500 jobs out of New York City referred imprecisely to the portion of the company's work force involved. The positions to be relocated amount to 10 percent of Chase's work force in the New York metropolitan area, not of its entire work force, which numbers 76,500 employees across the country.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Sweden, the Welfare State, Basks in a New Prosperity

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: STOCKHOLM

 BODY:
At a time when world leaders are fascinated by the United States' economic success and its credo of less government and low taxes, Sweden seems to be defying gravity.
This is still, after all, a country where government consumes nearly 60 percent of the national economy, far above the 32 percent share in the United States. Taxes and wages are among the highest in the world. Dismissing a sluggish worker is, in nearly all cases, legally impossible. 
 And the Swedes are proud of it. When Prime Minister Goran Persson introduced his budget plans in mid-September, he promised that "Sweden will consolidate its position as a leading welfare nation." He even pledged to create another entitlement: the right of every person who turns 65 to retain a personal assistant.
Yet this largely unreconstructed welfare state is one of Europe's most vibrant economies. And after nearly three decades of sluggishness in which the output per person slumped from the third-highest in the world to 18th, just behind Italy, the Swedish economy is in the midst of a powerful transformation.
Sweden's recent boom is in part a cyclical recovery from back-to-back recessions. But it also reflects a wider pattern in Europe and a particularly nuanced reaction to the robust United States economy of the 90's. For even as Sweden, like many countries in Western Europe, is continuing to preserve traditional European social programs, it has also been embracing entrepreneurship and unrestricted competition.
While the Government continues to finance health care, education and many social services, Sweden has deregulated industries from telecommunications to airlines and banking.
As a result, new companies and high technology have flourished. Indeed, much of the growth here is coming from businesses that did not exist 10 years ago. Information technology and service companies have eclipsed traditional manufacturers as the main source of new jobs.
"It is mostly a cyclical upswing, but it is more than that," said Anne Wibble, chief economist at the Swedish Federation of Industry. "It is also a breakthrough of the private service sector -- the new networked economy."
Growth for 1999 is now projected at 3.8 percent, far faster than Europe as a whole and close to the recent growth rate in the United States. Foreign corporations from Ford to Microsoft are pumping billions of dollars into the country. The Government, which five years ago carried a deficit equivalent to 11 percent of the gross domestic product, now has a budget surplus.
Unemployment has declined from 8.2 percent in 1993 to 6.1 percent recently, and there are estimates for the year as low as 5.3 percent. The Stockholm area has shortages of computer specialists, sales representatives, teachers, even caterers.
Sweden is not the only country to challenge some central tenets of the current American-British model. France, where the Socialist Cabinet has mandated that the workweek will fall to 35 hours, is growing by nearly 3 percent and its double-digit jobless rate is coming down. Finland has high personal taxes and rigid job rules, yet it has become a world leader in the mobile phone industry. The Netherlands still has generous welfare programs, but offers the industrialist or entrepreneur low corporate taxes and flexible labor rules.
For all the talk of "Euro-sclerosis," Europe is a continent today of budget-cutting, negligible inflation and, most important, increasingly brutal market competition.
Sweden's boom is arguably the most unusual. Besides clinging to a cradle-to-grave system of security, Sweden was one of just a few countries refusing to join with 11 European nations in adopting the euro as a common currency.
Yet Sweden is growing faster than most of its euro zone neighbors. Germany, which accounts for one-third of the euro zone's total economy, is expected to grow less than 2 percent this year.
To be sure, no one here is yet talking about a new "Swedish model" for growth. But a few years ago, this country was a textbook illustration of how good intentions can lead to disastrous results. In 1970, Sweden's economic output per person was the third highest in the world, behind only Switzerland and the United States. With its wealth and a culture of high-minded homogeneity, Sweden built up one of the world's legendary welfare states. But as the public sector ballooned, swelling from one-third to more than half the economy, business and productivity lagged behind the world as a whole. Unsurprisingly, job creation stagnated. And today, despite the recent upswing, Sweden still employs slightly fewer people than it did in 1970.
So what lies behind the current rebound? One major change is that Swedish political leaders have finally put the budget in order. After running up staggering deficits in the mid-1990's, at one point as high as 13 percent of output, the Social Democratic Government, while rejecting most demands to cut back the welfare state, raised personal taxes and imposed tough spending limits.
The measures were painful, but they steadily reduced the deficit and gave corporations some room to breathe.
But that was only part of the story. Like Finland and Britain, Sweden moved much more quickly than most other European countries to deregulate its markets and foster a more entrepreneurial culture. It opened its telephone and electricity markets to competition in the mid-90's. It jumped into the vanguard of mobile telephones, as Ericsson emerged as one of the world's biggest producers of wireless phones and networking equipment.
Beginning in 1993, the country also loosened up its job rules. Though full-time employees are still protected from layoffs, the Government allowed companies to hire temporary workers who could be let go at will.
The result has been a torrid expansion of temporary-employment companies. Manpower Inc., one of the world's biggest, now employs 6,000 workers in Sweden. Poolia, a temporary agency in Stockholm, has more than 1,700 workers and has nearly doubled its force of what it terms consultants in the last year alone.
But perhaps the biggest change has been the rise of new companies, many sprouting from Ericsson's roots in the telecommunications industry and many others emerging from the Nordic countries' infatuation with the Internet.
According to a recent study by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, Sweden invested a larger part of its gross domestic product in "knowledge" -- research, development, training and education -- than any other country in the world.
Consider the expansion of the Kiska Science Park, an industrial park started by Ericsson and I.B.M. in the early 1970's. Situated on a former waste site, Kiska is now a sprawling complex with 600 technology companies and 27,000 workers. It has also attracted two of Sweden's important scientific institutes -- the Royal Institute of Technology and the Swedish Institute of Computer Science.
Stockholm itself has become a breeding ground for Internet companies. Johan Ihrfelt and a group of friends began Spray.se as an Internet consulting firm back in 1995. After raising about $3 million from private investors, including the huge Swedish holding company Investor AB, they opened an Internet portal and access service. Based in a renovated brick warehouse here, Spray now employs about 250 people across Europe and has 450,000 customers.
"I believe Sweden is one of the most exciting markets after the U.S., if you are looking for entrepreneurial growth," said Mr. Ihrfeldt, who is 32. "Ten years ago, it was almost nonexistent here."
Spray is hardly alone. Boxman, based in Stockholm but now operating largely from Britain, has become one of Europe's biggest providers of music over the Internet. Boo.com a Stockholm start-up whose investors include Goldman, Sachs, is gearing up to sell sports clothing on the Web.
There are a number of signs that this new generation of companies, and a new generation of entrepreneurs, has changed some of Sweden's basic chemistry. The most notable indication is that the nation kept growing this year, even when important industries began to sputter.
Much like Germany, Sweden has traditionally relied on manufactured exports for most of its growth. And much as in Germany, exports were hurt badly after the Asian and Russian markets plunged in 1997 and 1998. Yet while the German economy slowed to a standstill, Sweden's accelerated.
"When we were doing our projections exactly one year ago, we were worried the country might even slip into a recession," recalled Bjorn Oras, chief executive of the Poolia temporary worker agency. "Instead, things kept right on surging."
Government forecasters were similarly surprised. Worried that a downturn would generate new budget problems, Prime Minister Persson rejected the idea of tax cuts as recently as March. But now, with the tax coffers overflowing, he is pushing modest tax cuts as well as spending increases for health care, pensions, job training and the universities.
"In March and April, we didn't think unemployment would decrease so much," said Bosse Ringholm, Sweden's Finance Minister. "We have a new situation now."
Ms. Wibble, the industry federation's chief economist, said the explanation lay in the expansion of new service companies. "Formerly, we saw a close correspondence between economic growth and what was happening in the manufacturing industries," she said. "Now what we see is that when industry slows down, as it did earlier this year, the private service sector is still surging ahead. That is something new."
Indeed, many of Sweden's biggest employers are still struggling. Ericsson has lost a big chunk of the cellular-phone market to Nokia of Finland, which is now the world's biggest maker of mobile phones. The Scandinavian airline S.A.S. is losing millions of dollars, partly because of cut-rate competition from Finnair.
At 6.1 percent, Sweden's jobless rate is about one-third lower than the average in European Union countries. The numbers overstate the successes somewhat, because Government job creation and training programs account for a further 3.5 percent of the work force.
Yet economists say that virtually all of the increase in new jobs in the last two years has come from business rather than government.
That is apparent at the Stockholm county employment office. The office's most recent analysis shows shortages in several dozen job categories and acute shortages in many others, including car mechanics, taxi drivers and nurses.
"The information technology branch is pulling all kinds of other professions along with it -- economists, accountants and even artists," said Per Lindberg, director of the office. "It's changing the whole structure of the labor market."
Still, many Swedes remain cautious about the future. Partly because of the strong social programs, Sweden's economy often swings from feast to famine.
When the economy is strong, government revenue rises much faster than expenses. But when conditions turn bad, the country is hit by a double punch of added social costs and shrinking capital investment.
Arvid Bohn, an economist at the Swedish Federation of Industry, has been through those big swings before. "The thing you have to remember about Sweden," he said, "is that there is no such thing as a soft landing here."

HEADLINE: How a Soldier Grew Into a Monster

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

 BODY:
Film, marshaled by the thousands upon thousands of frames, is the devastating witness that lays bare the homicidal, corrupt, vainglorious tyranny of Mobutu Sese Seko, the longtime dictator of Zaire, in the Belgian-made documentary ''Mobutu, King of Zaire.''
 The 2-hour-15-minute expose of the cold war ruler, who died at 66 in exile in Morocco in 1997, is remarkable not so much for its retelling of well-established history but for the mountain of visible detail that buttresses what is known about a man who rose from relative obscurity to seize power in a vast nation of some 40 million and hold it in his brutal grip for nearly a generation.
 The documentary -- directed by Thierry Michel and to be shown at 6 tonight as part of the 37th New York Film Festival -- rejects shrill indictment in favor of the cumulative revelation of its subject through film and the testimony of knowledgeable Mobutu aides and other qualified individuals. 
 Here, once more, is Joseph Mobutu the young soldier, Mobutu the young journalist, Mobutu the young private secretary to the African nationalist Patrice Lumumba at the negotiations in Brussels that led to the Congo's independence from Belgian colonialism in 1960.
 And here, too, is Mobutu betraying Prime Minister Lumumba, who appointed him secretary of state and commander of the armed forces; Mobutu ascending through military ranks, accumulating titles, donning his familiar leopard-skin hat, giving himself and his country a new name, Zaire, and imposing his tyranny.
 Though the narrative is not seamless, the film touches on the noteworthy events in Mobutu's ascent to the pinnacle of power beginning in 1965. It is a chronicle littered with assassinations, financial and sexual self-indulgence, economic miscalculation, gross corruption and canny diplomacy in the cold war years that earned Mobutu the favor and support of Western leaders in France and the United States.
 Well into the film, after Mobutu's treachery, murders and manipulations are well established, President George Bush is seen in a White House ceremony, expressing profuse admiration and friendship for the dictator beside him.
 Here as elsewhere, Thierry Michel's use of film makes his point. To say more would belabor the obvious.

MOBUTU, KING OF ZAIRE
Directed by Thierry Michel; commentary written (in French, with English subtitles) by Lye Mudaba and Mr. Michel; directors of photography, Alain Marcoen, Joel Marcipont and Didier Hill Derive; edited by Marine Deleu; produced by Christine Pireaux, Martine Barbe and Serge Lalou. Shown tonight at 6 at Alice Tully Hall as part of the 37th New York Film Festival. Running time: 135 minutes. This film is not rated.

WITH: Simon Shrimpton (narrator).

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Politics Threatens Brazilian Utility Sales

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 8

 BODY:
He's up to his old tricks again. With an eye to his political fortunes, the same maverick Governor and former President who provoked Brazil's currency crisis in January by defaulting on his state's foreign debt is now seeking to sabotage a crucial federal government program to privatize state-owned companies.
Heeding a call by Itamar Franco, the Governor of Minas Gerais state, the board of its electric utility agreed on Thursday to expel directors representing minority shareholders including two American companies, the AES Corporation and the Southern Company. In 1997, the companies acquired a one-third interest in the utility, known as Cemig, and have since invested nearly $1 billion under a contract that Mr. Franco, backed by a sympathetic state court, now refuses to recognize. 
 "We are completely shocked by the action taken by Minas Gerais," said Richard Owen, vice president for Latin America and the Caribbean for Southern, one of the biggest utilities in the United States. "This could reflect on the appetite foreign companies have in future privatizations."
Mr. Franco has also campaigned to block the privatization of Furnas Electrical, a utility that supplies power to nearly half of Brazil's 165 million people. Recently he went so far as to threaten to divert the course of the rivers that feed the giant Furnas dam, situated in his state, if the utility is sold.
In addition, Mr. Franco has dispatched state military police to conduct maneuvers in the area around the dam and has established a command base there. Though he has not explicitly threatened to use those forces to block private investors from taking control of Furnas, he has cited the crucial role of the military police in coups in 1932 and 1964.
To what extent the actions of Mr. Franco, who was elected Governor of Brazil's third-most populous state last year, are motivated by ideology, as opposed to personal grievances, is hard to determine. As President from 1992 through 1994, he ushered in a period of economic stability, but most of the credit went to Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who was his Finance Minister and is now serving a second term as President.
One of Mr. Franco's first acts after taking office in January was to decree a moratorium on payment of his state's debts both to the central government and to foreign creditors, which set off a crisis that resulted in a 40 percent devaluation of the Brazilian currency.
Despite the criticism that earned him, Mr. Franco is said by political analysts still to harbor hopes of returning to the presidency when elections are held in 2002.
His chances are considered slim, however, since many Brazilians regard him as irresponsible and even clownish. Cartoonists and comedians habitually mock the pompadour hair style that is his trademark. They like to poke fun at his irascibility and penchant, at 67, for romantic pursuits of women half his age.
"Itamar came into office obsessed with screwing things up for Cardoso as much as he could," said David Fleischer, a professor of political science at the University of Brasilia and publisher of a widely read political newsletter. "He is totally vain, thinks he is going to be Brazil's savior, and is thoroughly convinced he can get the nomination."
After trying for several weeks to ignore Mr. Franco's latest challenge, the federal government finally fired back on Oct. 1. Asked at a luncheon of the Council of the Americas in New York about Mr. Franco's behavior, Arminio Fraga, head of Brazil's central bank, dismissed the former President as an eccentric whose actions were unjustly tarnishing the entire country's image.
"You shouldn't think that is Brazil," Mr. Fraga was quoted as saying in Brazilian news reports. "That is Minas. If you are minority investors, find another state and not Minas Gerais."
The political fallout has been both immediate and extensive. At the behest of the Governor's allies, Mr. Fraga this week was "invited" to explain his remarks to a congressional committee, and talks aimed at getting Minas Gerais to end its debt moratorium are said to have stalled.
Mr. Franco himself has sued Mr. Fraga in a state court, seeking damages for his remarks. He also has accused the central bank chief, who has an American mother, of being more loyal to the United States than Brazil.
While Mr. Franco's behavior is regarded with a certain bemusement here, it comes at a delicate moment. In a setback to the austerity program Mr. Cardoso pledged to carry out as part of a $41.5 billion rescue package signed with the International Monetary Fund last November, the Supreme Court ruled last week that two important taxes on civil servants were illegal.
Mr. Cardoso's economic team has been scrambling to find new sources of revenue to fill the gap left by that decision.
Mr. Fraga acknowledged in New York that "we are very annoyed" at what he called the former President's potentially damaging efforts to drive away private capital.
But Mr. Franco's defiant stance has also, as the newspaper O Estado de Sao Paulo noted in an editorial this week, "given him political vitality." In particular, he has scored points with nationalist and populist groups on the left.
"A people who do not control their own sources of energy have no autonomy," said Joao Pedro Stedile, leader of the Movement of the Landless, a peasant group. If Brazil were to completely privatize its electricity sector, he said, it would be "transformed into a gigantic, Portuguese-speaking Puerto Rico," so his group "is in total solidarity with Itamar."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES

 BODY:
THE EURO FALLS. The euro fell to its lowest level against the dollar in more than a week after the European Central Bank kept monetary policy steady. In New York, the euro settled at $1.06220, down from $1.0710 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: In China's Boom, Rural Poor Feel a Widening Gap

SERIES: A HALF-CENTURY IN CHINA: Yawning Gaps Between Rich and Poor

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

DATELINE: BALI, China

 BODY:
In a crumbling mud-brick house, nestled against the untidy heap that holds her family's entire wardrobe, Zheng Xingrong defines her life with a series of emphatic negatives.
How often do your children eat eggs or meat? "Never!" Do you have a radio or television? "No!" Is your 14-year-old daughter in school? "No!" Does your 8-year-old boy have any toys? "None!" 
 "Because we have no money, we don't dare to have any dreams," said the 40-year-old woman, whose family is one of the poorest in a destitute farming village north of the Yellow River in Shandong province.
Only three hours away by car, in Hongyuan village, near the city of Jinan, Li Huazhu, 45, and his wife Chen Xuerong, 39 -- farmers until a few years ago -- proudly show off the former gas station site they just bought with cash. It will house their expanding company, which makes precision-ground granite slabs to export for industrial use.
Their 17-year-old son has some very big toys -- a videodisk player and a motorbike -- and their 18-year-old daughter is in nursing school. Ms. Chen dreams of the day, not so distant, when they can buy a car and build their own two-story house. "No," her husband interjects, "a three-story house!"
Between one family's despair and another family's dreams lies a serious new problem for China, the rapid growth in economic disparities. In the booming 1990's, yawning gaps opened between city and countryside, between the developed coast and the isolated interior, between upper and lower classes in the cities and, as these two families illustrate, between richer and poorer villages.
No one knows the extent to which popular resentment of inequality may be a source of unrest in a country that is already struggling with slowed growth, high unemployment and bitterness over official corruption. But the trend itself is striking.
From comparative income equality in the mid-1980's, China in the last decade has suddenly emerged as one of the most unequal countries in Asia, surpassing countries like India and Indonesia, according to reports by the World Bank and others. China's disparities surpass those of the United States and Western Europe, though they do not approach the extremes of Latin America.
"Mounting inequality and its possible consequences, both for social and economic stability and for continued growth, have become central issues of policy debate and scholarly research," said Hu Angang, an economist at the Chinese Academy of Sciences, and Wang Shaoguang, a political scientist at the Chinese University of Hong Kong, in their new book, "The Political Economy of Uneven Development: The Case of China" (M.E. Sharpe).
Still, public debate inside China about the growing disparities remains muted, in part because the official line remains that economic trailblazers will pull up everyone else and that the Government is fully addressing any problems.
Two decades ago, as China switched from Mao Zedong's failed socialism toward a more open, market-oriented economy, some rise in inequality was expected and even desired. The late Deng Xiaoping, mastermind of the reforms, famously said, "Let some prosper first so that others may follow."
The economic loosening produced blistering growth and, especially in the early years, widely shared improvements. The climb from penury for hundreds of millions of rural people through family farming and the spread of rural industry has been one of modern China's greatest feats.
But few anticipated the surging disparities of the 1990's, as the top urban and rural groups sped ahead. One study, by Dwayne Benjamin and Loren Brandt of the University of Toronto, found rural inequality as great as in the feudal 1930's, although at higher levels for all.
Today, these scholars found, it is access to nonfarm jobs in rural and township industries or the cities, rather than grossly skewed land-holdings, that has allowed some to forge ahead. Rural areas nearest to cities -- like Hongyuan village, outside Shandong's capital, Jinan -- have done especially well.
Overall, though, rural economic growth has fallen far behind that of the cities -- and is likely to keep sputtering without major changes in policy, economists say, because agriculture is in a rut and many rural industries are in trouble.
Worse, there is evidence that progress against the worst poverty slowed during a period of fantastic national growth. Since the late 80's the reduction of rural poverty "was far less than it would have been had the growth in rural income inequality been avoided." conclude Carl Riskin of Columbia University and Azizur R. Khan of the University of California in a study being published by Oxford University Press.
Still trapped at rock-bottom today are some 124 million Chinese, living below the World Bank's poverty standard of one dollar a day in per capita income. According to the Government's more stringent definition, there are 42 million Chinese below the poverty line. Whatever the definition, China's poorest people are concentrated in crowded, eroded mountain lands in the south and the north and in pockets elsewhere, like the region of poor soils and little industry around Bali.
Now, too, an urban underclass is emerging for the first time in recent history, mainly unemployed workers and elderly people with minimal pensions and no prosperous relatives to help out.
The Government has special policies to aid the poor and reduce inequality, including small welfare payments for destitute city dwellers, rural anti-poverty projects and incentives for investment in inland provinces.
But harming the rural areas in particular are two policies that seem unlikely to be reversed any time soon: the tight controls on the ability of villagers to move to cities and compete for jobs, and a national policy of self-sufficiency in grain, under which farmers are forced to grow grains when they often could make far more growing fruits and vegetables.
Bali, a village of 300 families and 1,300 people, is in a county that authorities only last year declared to have been lifted above the official Government poverty line, set at a per-person income of about $220 a year.
A large group of residents, gathered in front of Ms. Zheng's home, laughed on hearing about that official milestone. "An entire family here doesn't earn $220," one man said, and that includes money brought home by migrant workers.
In all the village, just three people have bought motor scooters and about 70 percent of families have small black-and-white televisions. The mud and straw homes have floors of packed earth.
It may be that perhaps the farmers do not fully calculate the value of their subsistence crops, but other signs point to an insecure, nearly hand-to-mouth existence. Each family has less than an acre of land to farm, and the soils, cropped with wheat and then corn every year, are salty and low-yielding.
Each year every family must hand over 100 kilograms -- about 220 pounds -- of grain, close to half their produce, to the local government, residents said, in payment of obligations they are not sure about. For most families, the remaining grain provides just enough to eat through the year, with some of the wheat traded for a paste made from freshwater shrimp. There is rarely any surplus left to sell.
Families owe another $15 in various fees each year, residents said, and must also pay other fees for every child in school.
The only thing that keeps families here going is the money earned by men who spend a few months each summer -- leaving when the corn is knee-high and returning at harvest time -- working in highway construction around the city of Tianjin or along Shandong's prosperous coast. There, they can save about $60 each month.
One reason why Ms. Zheng's family is especially bad off is that her husband has asthma and has not been able to earn much in distant labor. He does not go to the clinic, she said, "unless he has really serious trouble breathing," because it costs $5 a visit.
The family keeps six chickens and a pig in the front yard, but all eggs and meat must be sold, and day after day they eat either bread and shrimp paste or boiled turnips.
Ms. Zheng's brother-in-law, 34-year-old Luo Huicheng, thought he had a way to break through last year when he saw low prices for feed grains and good prices for pork. Encouraged by county agricultural agents, in July of 1998 he borrowed $2,100 to build concrete sties and buy 30 pigs.
Unfortunately, hundreds of thousands of other farmers around China had the same idea and in a classic cycle, overproduction caused pork prices to plummet. In front of his empty sty, Mr. Luo described his feelings earlier this year, as he watched prices fall below his costs, and then fall more.
"I felt so helpless," he recalled. "I'd built the sty. I'd bought the pigs. I just wished they would hurry up and grow!" He sold the pigs for $600, and worked at construction jobs to start repaying his loan.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Dow Jumps 112.71 on Bargain Hunting

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks closed higher yesterday as bargain hunters loaded up on a handful of blue chips, reversing an early selloff that had been triggered by the release of a mixed jobs report for September.
The Dow Jones industrial average was up 112.71 points, or 1.07 percent, to 10,649.76. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 18.38 points, or 1.39 percent, to 1,336.02. The Nasdaq composite index was up 25.87 points, or nine-tenths of a percent, to 2,886.57. 
 "We have got certain sectors, namely health care and retail, that are leading the market," said Dan Ascani, president and research director at Global Market Strategists Inc. in Gainesville, Ga.
The Labor Department reported a weaker-than-expected labor market for September, but the numbers were distorted by the economic disruptions caused by Hurricane Floyd. The report also signaled that wages are rising at a faster-than-expected clip.
The average hourly wages shot up 7 cents, to $13.37, the biggest one-month gain since an 8-cent rise in September 1983. The nonfarm payrolls in September shed 8,000 workers, the first drop in more than three years and far below the expectations for a gain of 230,000 new jobs.
The increase in wages heightened expectations the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates at its next policy-setting meeting in November.
"Although some of the numbers looked very negative on the surface, because of the hurricane situation, the market decided the numbers do not really mean all that much," said Ron Doran, director of institutional trading at C. L. King & Associates in Albany. "The biggest issue is concern about where interest rates are going."
An increase in interest rates is generally seen as negative for stocks because it can raise borrowing costs for companies and slow consumer purchases.
Analysts said stability in the bond market also gave investors confidence to buy stocks.
"The bond market is steady right now and there is a lot of money flowing into the market," said Arnie Owen, managing director of capital markets at Cruttenden Roth.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 5/32, to 99 5/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.19 percent from 6.18 percent on Thursday.
Analysts said retail and health care stocks largely led the advance.
The Standard & Poor's retail index rose 37.79 point, or 4.3 percent, to 908.48, beating the overall market's performance, a day after retailers reported strong store sales.
Wal-Mart Stores was up 4 1/16, to 55 3/8, and Federated Department Stores, the parent of Macy's and Bloomingdale's, gained 2 3/8, to 46.
Analysts said drug stocks got a lift from passage by the House of a proposed patients' rights bill, which some said could possibly lead to more drug sales.
The Standard & Poor's drug index ended up 14.65 points, or 3.9 percent, at 382.12. The drug giant Merck gained 2 7/8, to 73 3/4, while Johnson & Johnson rose 4 1/2, to 98 3/4.

HEADLINE: Famed Cuban Band Is Set to Perform in Miami, and the Overtone Is One of Strain

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Oct. 8

 BODY:
In presenting the Cuban singer-songwriter Carlos Varela to a group of listeners in Miami Beach last year, Maria Romeu said she had bouts of panic during which she worried about his safety. One of the first artists from Cuba to perform in hostile exile territory, Mr. Varela tested the waters by singing then for select, word-of-mouth-only audiences.
"Small venues, out-of-the-way obscure locations, no advertising," said Ms. Romeu, who has a marketing company here and promoted those appearances. "That's not exactly how a promoter generates revenues." 
 But Mr. Varela was a hit, and after he appeared here, more than a dozen Cuban solo artists and bands trickled in to play more openly to bigger crowds and dwindling groups of protesters, prompting the occasional bomb threat -- and in at least one instance a Molotov cocktail thrown at a club's front door -- but no major controversy. Headliners like Issac Delgado, NG La Banda, Chucho Valdes and Francisco Repilado, the guitarist from the "Buena Vista Social Club" documentary who is better known as Compay Segundo, helped usher in what seemed like a new era of tolerance in an area where bombings, assaults on concertgoers and public scorn had dissuaded many Cuban performers from visiting.
Now, however, hostilities are at a peak once again with the announcement that Los Van Van, Cuba's most popular dance band, which has performed all over the United States but never in Miami, is coming to town. The band is to play the Miami Arena on Saturday night, in what promises to be a test for both freedom of expression in this city and the shifting views within Cuban Miami, which, after successive waves of immigration, encompasses people who vary in social class, race, generation, politics and, indeed, musical taste.
Los Van Van, arriving here for the next-to-last stop of a 28-city tour of the United States, Canada and Puerto Rico, have stirred up passions partly because they are booked in a venue of 8,000 seats, which would allow by far the biggest audience yet for Cuban artists here. In addition, the concert is set within Miami, the seat of power for conservative Cuban exiles, rather than the more liberal Miami Beach, where Cuban artists performing in the area have almost always appeared.
Finally, the band itself is a 30-year-old institution regarded as Cuba's foremost cultural ambassador, which to detractors means Fidel Castro's handpicked proxy. Even the name Van Van, derived from a revolutionary slogan, grates on critics.
Plans for the concert first prompted Miami city officials to impose requirements on the local promoter that led to a change of date twice and the move of the event from one city-owned center to another. The promoter, Debbie Ohanian, who said only city-owned arenas were large enough to meet the expected demand for tickets, sought help from the American Civil Liberties Union, which threatened to sue if Los Van Van were in any way prevented from performing.
Now that the band has cleared bureaucratic hurdles, exile organizations are planning a large protest outside the Miami Arena on Saturday night. Some callers to Spanish-language radio stations have even vowed to videotape concertgoers as they enter the arena so that the city's "Communists" can be identified.
"This is the last straw," Juan Perez Franco, president of Brigade 2506, a group of Bay of Pigs veterans that is organizing the protest, said of the concert. "This is a provocation to exiles and an insult to the memory of our martyrs."
But while older exiles shun Los Van Van as political envoys, a growing population of more recent arrivals from Cuba, and many young Cuban-Americans, welcome them as cultural envoys who help satisfy yearnings for the homeland or for a connection with Cuban heritage.
A Miami Herald poll of Miamians last month confirmed a sharp generational split on the issue among Hispanic respondents: those older than 50 opposed performances by musical groups from Cuba in city-owned centers, 65 percent to 24 percent, while those under 50 supported such shows by 50 percent to 31 percent.
Los Van Van themselves say that denunciation by conservatives here kept them from trying to perform in Miami earlier but that, on visits to family and friends, they have found an increasingly welcome climate.
"These are different times," Cesar Pedroso, the band's pianist and co-founder, said in a telephone interview. "Everything changes. This concert will be an encounter with fans of many years who have not seen us since they left Cuba, and with the generations who don't know Los Van Van personally."
Among the children of exiles supporting the band is the 42-year-old Ms. Romeu, who was brought to the United States as a child, was reared in Chicago and became one of a handful of promoters who have created the Cuban music scene here.
"It's not about Cuba or Los Van Van," Ms. Romeu insisted. "It's about a glorious music tradition. We talk about the First Amendment and the extreme Cuban right wing, and nobody is talking about the music."
Ms. Romeu's fervor for Cuban culture got her fired once, after a leading Cuban exile group complained in 1994 to her employer, the Spanish-language network of MTV, that she was using her office there to help organize a private tour to Havana for a concert by Mr. Varela. The network, MTV Latino, where Ms. Romeu was an assistant to the managing director, said at the time that she had been dismissed for using company resources for a personal matter.
But Ms. Romeu, who has helped promote and produce Cuban artists' performances around the United States since the late 1970's, says she has no regrets. "That was the beginning of a beautiful thing," she said of her early support for Mr. Varela, whose Miami Beach shows last year she describes as "unbelievable."
"It was 250 sobbing people who knew every word of the songs," she said. "Nobody said, 'I hate you because you left.' Nobody said, 'I hate you because you're still there.' There was unconditional reconciliation, and that is the single most important thing that can happen to our culture."
Other Cuban-Americans, including some younger ones, say that even culture must be governed by the rule of law, in this case the United States' economic embargo of Cuba. Miami's 44-year-old Cuban-born Mayor, Joe Carollo, said in an interview that he personally opposed Los Van Van as "Castro's premier band" but that in any event the city's interest in the concert was that there be compliance with the embargo, which requires financial restrictions on any cultural exchanges with Cuba.
To that end, city officials demanded that the concert's promoter produce documentation from the United States Treasury Department certifying that none of the money generated by the concert would go to the Government of Cuba. That documentation was obtained.
The promoter, Ms. Ohanian, a Miami Beach nightclub owner who has presented half a dozen Cuban artists over the last year without incident, has been called a "Castro agent" on Spanish-language radio stations here and picketed by small groups of protesters who have shown up outside her club. But in addition to the concert by Los Van Van, she is planning to present Ibrahim Ferrer and Ruben Gonzalez, two stars from the Grammy-winning "Buena Vista Social Club" album, at the Jackie Gleason Theater in Miami Beach in February.
"Somebody has to be the voice of the people who are tired of all this,' she said of the protests against Cuban performers.
As for Ms. Romeu, she said she was ready to bring Mr. Varela back for a concert tour next year. "I'm really committed to disseminating this art," she said. "Why can't I have a right to it? We grow up hearing, 'Cuba, Cuba, Cuba.' How can we not want to hear Cuban music?"
