HEADLINE: Clinton Visit Shows Warmth of Canadian Ties

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: OTTAWA, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Today, for the first time, an American President traveled to a foreign nation and inaugurated an American Embassy. President Clinton broke historical protocol in Canada, a quiet partner that trades more with the United States than any other country.
The relaxed outdoor ceremony, with Parliament's landmark Victorian bell tower mirrored in the glass-and-steel face of the new embassy, seemed to reflect the easy relations between the two neighbors. 
 In the 10 years since a trade pact was signed, trade between the United States and Canada has doubled. It now runs more than $1 billion a day.
In the 1990's, Canada has firmly established itself as the largest source of imported energy for the United States and the most popular foreign destination for American tourists.
In a joking mood on a sunny morning, Mr. Clinton cracked that Jean Chretien, the 65-year-old Prime Minister, was the only Western leader "who could still slalom on water skis with one of his grandchildren on his shoulders." Noting that this was his fifth visit to Canada as President, Mr. Clinton continued kidding, saying, "He also says if I come one more time, I have to start paying taxes."
The laughter faded at the end of the speech, when Mr. Clinton appeared to stray beyond his text, talking about ethnic strife "in the land of my forebears in Northern Ireland."
"Every time they make an agreement to do it, they're like a couple of drunks walking out of the bar for the last time," he said of the on-again, off-again peace process between Protestants and Catholics in Northern Ireland. "When they get to the swinging door, they turn around and go back in and say, 'I just can't quite get there.' " He later said the metaphor was inappropriate, and expressed "regret for any offense my remarks caused."
The sparks around the joke provided news for reporters hard pressed to find controversy in a relationship that Americans take for granted -- the world's largest trading relationship crossing the world's longest undefended border. This cross-border commerce is expected to reach $410 billion this year.
"Less than 1 percent of our trade is subject to trade action," said Raymond Chretien, Canada's ambassador to the United States, a career diplomat who is also a nephew of the Prime Minister. "This huge trade goes so smoothly that it is unnoticed."
Indeed, with this quiet, north-south boom, the United States exports more to Canada than to all Western Europe. More goods cross between Ontario and the United States than are exchanged between the United States and Japan.
"We do more trade through Windsor and Detroit than the U.S. does with Japan," Foreign Minister Lloyd Axworthy said.
Prime Minister Chretien was elected in 1993 on a platform of skepticism about increasing economic integration with the United States. Instead, he has presided over the fastest integration in his country's history.
"Trade between the U.S. and Canada has doubled in 10 years," the American ambassador here, Gordon D. Giffin, said in an interview. "That is quite impressive when you think that we have been doing business for more than 200 years."
In the last 10 years, world trade has increased 50 percent.
The Canadian trading expansion has radically opened a country that once reveled in its northern isolation. Since an automobile pact was signed with the United States in 1965, the sector of the Canadian economy tied to foreign trade has tripled, rising to 42 percent. Measuring economic dependence on foreign trade, Canada has climbed in the Group of Seven industrial countries to second place, after Germany.
For much of its history, Canada has strived to create a cohesion between its east and west. But each of the 10 provinces now trades more with the United States than with the rest of Canada. In July, 87 percent of Canada's exports went to the United States.
"You are seeing the Americanization of Canada, no doubt about it," said Peter S. Bleyer, executive director of the Council of Canadians, a grass-roots nationalist group here. "Canada is dramatically more integrated, that is, dramatically more dependent on the U.S. than we were a decade ago."
In the five years since Wal-Mart opened its first Canadian store, the American chain has become the Canada's largest retailer. Noting this march of American franchises across the landscape, Mr. Bleyer said, "We are becoming more and more made in the image of our elephant neighbor to the south."
Against the wishes of economic nationalists, Canada's speeding economic links with the United States are eroding support for sovereignty icons like border posts and currency.
In the spring in a poll of 1,204 adults, 52 percent said that they were optimistic about globalization, and 39 percent said that border posts between Canada and the United States should be torn down, allowing trade and traffic to flow freely in both directions. In the poll, conducted by Ekos Research Associates, 17 percent were pessimistic on the economic effects of integration.
In the summer in a poll of 1,500 Canadians, half the respondents predicted that the United States and Canada would have a common currency in 10 years, and 77 percent said in 20 years. In the poll, conducted by the Angus Reid Group Inc., 37 percent said abolition of the Canadian dollar would be good for Canada's economy. Over the last five years, the Canadian dollar has lost 12 percent of its value, a contraction popular with exporters but frustrating to Canadian travelers.
Canada's openness is reciprocated. Last year, Americans made almost 15 million overnight visits here. Last year, the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations commissioned a survey of 1,507 American adults for a "feelings thermometer" about 25 countries. Respondents had the warmest feelings for Canada, 72 degrees, followed by Britain, 69, and Italy, 62. Ranking in the mid-50's were Mexico, Germany, Brazil, Japan, Israel, France and South Africa.
Banking on the good feelings, academic specialists on United States-Canada relations speculate that the next step in integration could be a customs union, a European-style relationship with common external tariffs and free internal movement of goods and people.
Politicians and diplomats tend to be more cautious on forecasting North American economic relations.
"That dialogue is mostly in the press and among academics," Mr. Giffin said, referring to talk of a North American currency. "I don't see it much among policy makers in the U.S. or Canada."
Today "an agreement in principle" was announced over exchange of military and aerospace technology. In a move that threatened Canada's $6 billion-a-year military industry, the United States threatened in April to impose a licensing system on military exports to the Canada if Canada did not tighten its controls. Today, Canada promised to tighten its export controls, creating, with the United States, "a strong North American perimeter for defense export controls."

HEADLINE: Job Growth Falters in Possible Sign That Economy Is Starting to Slow

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The energetic American economy may be slipping into a slower gear, as job creation came to a halt last month and the work force shrank for the first time since January 1996. But wages continued to rise at a healthy pace, the Labor Department reported yesterday, keeping alive the potential for future inflation.
Hurricane Floyd, disrupting East Coast commerce in mid-September, discouraged many employers from hiring. "But employment growth was weak even in those industries unaffected by the hurricane," Katherine Abraham, commissioner of the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics, said in a message to Congress. 
 Taking August and September together, only 95,000 new jobs were created: 103,000 in August and a loss of 8,000 in September. That is a rather startling pullback from the 654,000 new jobs that appeared in June and July -- and hardly justification for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates at its next policy meeting, on Nov. 16, to contain inflation by slowing the economy. When it met last Tuesday, the Fed policy makers left rates unchanged.
"The American economy is slowing; the key question is how much," said Nancy Lazar, a vice president at ISI Group, taking a more pessimistic view of the employment report than some other Wall Street economists, who said more data were needed before a trend could be identified.
While the Labor Department's monthly survey of American companies disclosed the weak job growth, a separate survey of households showed that the unemployment rate in September had remained unchanged, at an unusually low 4.2 percent.
Bond market traders, uncertain whether to view the employment report as a harbinger or an anomaly, left interest rates unchanged. The stock market initially saw in the numbers evidence that the Fed was unlikely to raise interest rates in November. In response, the Dow Jones Industrial average rose at the opening. Then it fell, but finally finished up 112.71 points at 10,649.76.
"This number, which was expected to be a defining number for the markets, only creates more confusion," Joel L. Naroff, an economic consultant, advised his clients in an E-mail.
The one aspect of the employment report that raised warning flags was the wage number. Average hourly wages for production workers below the rank of supervisor rose by 7 cents, to $13.37. The 7 cents represented the biggest one-month jump in more than a decade. But that was the only superlative. The percentage increase -- five-tenths of a percent -- was no greater than some earlier months this year. And the 3.8 percent wage rise over the last 12 months is roughly what wage growth for production workers has been all year: firm but not yet firm enough to push employers into inflationary price increases.
"The only thing that would make the wage growth potentially inflationary -- and this is a big if -- is if productivity were to slow from its present strong growth rate," said Lawrence Katz, a Harvard University labor economist. A rising productivity rate has meant that workers have produced more each hour on the job. The added revenue from their output has paid in effect for their wage increases.
What Ms. Lazar saw in the employment report was evidence that rising interest rates in recent months, as well as a flat stock market, rising oil prices and a sharp drop in the number of households refinancing mortgages are beginning to take their toll on the real economy. But the September employment report is the first significant evidence of that toll. Elsewhere in the economy, retail sales were strong in September, and so were industrial production, home sales, consumer borrowing and auto sales.
"Certainly in 2000 we expect the economy to slow," said Martin Bailey, chairman of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers. "But except for this report there is no other sign of slowing now."
Taking an unusual step, the Labor Department estimated how many additional jobs would have been counted if Hurricane Floyd had not struck just in the week of the department's employment survey. The goal was to head off speculation that September would have been a strong employment month if not for Floyd. Without the hurricane, job growth would have been only 50,000.
"Including that 50,000, you can say that employment growth in the third quarter was 175,000 a month compared with 210,000 a month in the first half of the year," said Thomas Nardone, an official at the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "That is still slower growth."
Jobs disappeared in manufacturing, retailing, mortgage banking and government. Employment remained unchanged in finance, insurance and real estate. Jobs in the huge service sector -- office workers, for example, and call center operators -- multiplied, as usual, but only by 39,000, less than half the average monthly growth of the last year. Trucking, the airline industry, construction and public utilities also added jobs. Between the gains and the losses, the total number of jobs in the nation declined in September to 128.91 million.
While industrial production rose last month, manufacturing employment fell once again, this time by 21,000 jobs. Over the last 18 months, manufacturing employment has shrunk by 532,000 jobs, to 18.4 million. To keep production up with fewer workers, companies have resorted to labor-saving technology and equipment, as well as overtime for the remaining people.
Overtime hours averaged a relatively high 4.7 a week in September, unchanged from August. But other industries cut back hours, and the net result for the private sector as a whole was a slight decline in the average workweek, to 34.4 hours from 34.5 in August.
The overtime in manufacturing helps to explain the steady rise in average hourly wages for production workers. Many of the people displaced from these jobs, on the other hand, have probably moved into lower-paying service jobs, economists say, helping to damp wage growth.
In its monthly wage calculations, the Labor Department counts only production workers, mainly in manufacturing, and not the wages of nonproduction service workers. Nor does it include bonus payments, which have been widespread across the labor force, but are easier than wages to scale back when business declines.
Viewing labor costs more broadly, Chris Varvares, a partner at Macroeconomic Advisers, noted that total compensation per hour -- wages and benefits -- grew by 5.1 percent in the second quarter. "Our forecast," he said, "is that compensation will rise by more than 4.5 percent in the third quarter, still high but not as high."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

S.& P. 500 Gains 18 Points On Bargain Hunting Spree
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 18.38 points, or 1.39 percent, to 1,336.02, in reaction to a buying spree by bargain hunters. The market was also responding to the mixed jobless report for September. The unemployment rate remained at 4.2 percent last month, but the report signaled that wages are rising at a faster-than-expected clip. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 112.71 points, or 1.07 percent, to 10,649.76. The Nasdaq composite index increased 25.87 points, to 2,886.57. Page C3.
 
A Limit for Computer Technology?
A researcher at Intel contends in the journal Science that computer technology is reaching a limit as to how small silicon chips can become. The limit would end a phenomenon known as Moore's law, which says that every 18 months, the number of transistors that will fit on a silicon chip doubles. A1.
 
F.C.C. Loosens Rules for Cable
The Federal Communications Commission has substantially loosened the rules that have limited one company from controlling too much of the cable industry. The decision clears the way for AT&T to own more than a third of the nation's franchises offering subscribers television, telephone and high-speed Internet services as well as own major interests in a number of major video producers and television programmers. A1.
 
State Farm Must Pay Damages
A state judge in Illinois has decided that State Farm defrauded policyholders by requiring that damages from auto accidents be repaired with lower-priced generic parts, and ordered the insurer to pay $730 million in actual and punitive damages. Earlier in the week a jury said the insurer breached its contracts with policyholders by having repair shops use parts that were not authorized by auto manufacturers. The new verdict brought the total damages from the case to $1.19 billion. A10.
 
Roche to Cut Stake in Genentech
Genentech said Roche Holdings would reduce its stake in the company to 65 percent from 82 percent by selling 20 million shares. Investors sold on the news, driving Genentech's stock down $15.0625, to $157.75. C2.
 
Brazilian Privatization Disrupted
The Governor of Minas Gerais state in Brazil, Itamar Franco, who caused a currency crisis for the country in January, is trying to sabotage a federal program to privatize state-owned companies. C2.
 
Natwest Dismisses Chief Executive
National Westminster dismissed its chief executive, Derek Wanless, to try to regain investor confidence and thwart a takeover bid by the Bank of Scotland. The move was expected because investors had lost confidence in him after several failed attempts to acquire other companies, including the British insurer, Legal and General Group. C2.
 
Crude Oil Price Falls on Supply Data
The price of crude oil fell $1.55, to $20.90 a barrel, capping a 15 percent decline for the week, following reports of small increases in oil supplies. C3.
 
I.B.M. Set to Cut About 1,000 Jobs
I.B.M. plans to cut up to 10 percent of its personal computer work force, or up to 1,000 workers, in a cost-cutting effort to turn around the division, which lost nearly $1 billion last year. The 5 percent to 10 percent reduction in the work force of 10,000 will mostly affect marketing employees as the company consolidates its staff for different brands. C3.
 
Canadian Unemployment Rate Down
Canada's unemployment rate fell three-tenths of a percentage point, to 7.5 percent in September, the lowest level in more than nine years. It is the latest piece of evidence that suggests Canada's economy is heating up. C2.

HEADLINE: Labor, Revitalized With New Recruiting, Has Regained Power and Prestige

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
When John J. Sweeney took the helm of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. four years ago, the labor movement was spiraling downward. It was steadily losing membership, politicians had dismissed it as a toothless has-been and much of the public viewed it as an irrelevant dinosaur.
Four years later, on the eve of the labor federation's convention in Los Angeles, things have turned around. 
 Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley are tripping over each other to win the A.F.L.-C.I.O. endorsement in next year's Presidential election. Lawmakers are being attentive once again as unions play a heavyweight role in Congress, pushing for a patients' bill of rights and a higher minimum wage.
Workers at DaimlerChrysler and the Boeing Company have hit grand slams in their latest contracts by negotiating hefty raises, and union organizers have pulled off their biggest victory in six decades, adding 74,000 health-care workers in Los Angeles in one swoop.
Inspired by Mr. Sweeney's preaching about the need to reverse labor's slide -- membership peaked at 21 million in 1979 before falling to a low of 16 million in 1997 -- unions expect to organize more than 500,000 new members this year, more than five times the number the year Mr. Sweeney took office.
Suddenly, labor seems to have so much cachet that doctors, psychologists, graduate teaching assistants, limousine drivers and even fashion models are rushing to join.
"Sweeney has dramatically increased labor's visibility," said Robert B. Reich, a former Secretary of Labor. "He's turned the A.F.L.-C.I.O. into a more formidable political force. I haven't met anyone who doesn't believe John Sweeney has been terrific for organized labor. But having said that, the obstacles for labor are still very large."
American unions are still in many ways swimming against the tide.
Globalization has hindered union efforts to raise wages as companies have continued to close unionized factories and have moved the work overseas. The nation's recent explosion in jobs has been concentrated in small business and high technology, areas where unions have made little headway.
Businesses have also been far more aggressive in battling unionization drives, while the Republican majorities in the House and Senate have routinely proposed legislation that is considered anti-union.
In addition, repeated reports of corruption seem to turn labor's progress into two steps forward and one step back.
Four years ago, many officials acknowledged that unions would have little power if the decline in membership was not reversed. The reason: if only 15 percent of an industry was organized, unionized companies could argue that they would not be able to compete with nonunion companies if they were too generous at the bargaining table.
Today, unions represent 13.9 percent of the work force in the United States, down sharply from 35 percent in the 1950's. Many economists say labor's declining power has been a major reason wages for most Americans have climbed slower than inflation since 1979.
Mr. Sweeney won the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s presidency after he and several other union presidents joined to push out his predecessor, Lane Kirkland. They complained that Mr. Kirkland, who died last August, seemed to pay more attention to helping workers in Poland than in the United States.
From day one, Mr. Sweeney's goal has been to reverse the decline in membership and power -- and he has realized that to do so he must rejuvenate labor's oh-so-boring image and form alliances across society.
One of his successes has been Union Summer, a program in which more than 1,000 college students have worked as summer interns, persuading many of them that helping workers was a cause worth devoting their lives to. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has also set up a program called "Street Heat" where union activists in more than a dozen cities will quickly mobilize to hold raucous demonstrations during disputes.
In addition, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is planning to make computers and Internet service available at discounted prices to the federation's 13 million members in an effort to bring workers closer together and to make them easier to mobilize. With the push of a button, a union president could E-mail thousands of members and urge them to E-mail state or Federal officials.
Today in Los Angeles, the labor federation is kicking off a campaign with immigrant groups as part of an effort to focus on the needs of immigrants. Union leaders said they want to attract more immigrants and help improve the lives of workers in low-paying jobs like janitors, hotel maids and farmhands.
Mr. Sweeney deliberately increased the movement's focus on low-paid workers after the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which includes 68 unions, was perceived as being preoccupied with labor's well-paid elite in auto plants and steel mills.
By focusing on low-paid workers, Mr. Sweeney has improved the movement's moral stature, causing hundreds of academics and members of the clergy to support labor in a way not seen in decades.
Even some of his most vocal opponents give Mr. Sweeney credit.
"Ever since Lane Kirkland passed away this summer, we heard how his work in fighting Communism around the world is what he will be remembered for," said Jeffrey McGuinness, president of LPA, a Washington-based management association that represents 250 companies. "John Sweeney will be remembered for reinvigorating the labor movement and getting back to basics. His job is to make the labor movement grow again, and he is moving aggressively in that direction.
Probably the biggest change wrought by Mr. Sweeney was to get the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and its member unions to focus on recruiting -- the key to the movement's survival.
Four years ago, unions on average spent less than 3 percent of their budget on organizing, but Mr. Sweeney has persuaded many unions to raise that to 10 percent. The Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union now spends more than 30 percent of its budget on organizing, while the union Mr. Sweeney once headed, the Service Employees International Union, spends 45 percent on organizing.
That seems to be paying off. The service employees' union, which has more than 400 full-time organizers, expects to add almost 200,000 members this year, to 1.3 million.
Every few weeks, Mr. Sweeney has issued news releases boasting of another organizing win. After nearly a century, the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees recently organized 5,200 workers at six Fieldcrest Cannon plants in Kannapolis, N.C. -- the heart of anti-union country.
With Puerto Rico recently giving its Government workers the right to join unions, about 66,000 public employees there are expected to vote to unionize this year.
These developments make A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials optimistic that for the first time in decades, unions might be able to reverse the decline in the percentage of workers belonging to a union. To achieve that goal, unions need to organize at least 500,000 additional workers.
Some A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials said they hope to soon unionize one million additional workers each year, but many labor experts say that might be optimistic. The booming high-tech sector has resisted organizing efforts, and unions still continue to lose nearly half of unionization elections.
"The first step to revitalizing the labor movement is stop the shrinking, and I believe that's happened." said Richard Hurd, a Cornell University professor of labor relations. "Does this translate into a revitalized labor movement that's on a permanent upward track? The answer to that, is it's still premature to say."

HEADLINE: In Giuliani's City Hall Strategy, Senate Race Rolls Quietly Along

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER

 BODY:
For months, Rudolph W. Giuliani has said that the best way to run for United States Senate is to be a good Mayor, without distractions from a campaign apparatus. But in the weeks since Labor Day, Mr. Giuliani's unannounced race against Hillary Rodham Clinton has entered a new stage, as City Hall and the Mayor's closest aides quietly build the foundation of an aggressive, very Republican campaign.
Peter Powers, the friend of four decades who ran Mr. Giuliani's three campaigns for mayor, is once again playing the central role as Mr. Giuliani's chief political adviser. Other key figures, many of them veterans of the Mayor's campaigns, have already begun the political trench work, from filming footage for future commercials to sizing up Mrs. Clinton's stump style. 
 At the same time, Mr. Giuliani's Senate exploratory committee is continuing to raise the $15 million to $20 million he needs for the race, although as his expected Senate announcement date of early 2000 draws closer, several aides have privately expressed concern about the pace of his fund-raising.
"He doesn't realize the juggernaut that's about to hit him," said one adviser, referring to the First Lady's all-but-certain Senate campaign. "This is not Ruth Messinger. This is not David Dinkins." Mr. Giuliani trounced Ms. Messinger in the 1997 mayoral race and defeated Mr. Dinkins, the incumbent, in 1993.
This adviser, like nearly everyone interviewed for this article, requested anonymity, because the Mayor has told his aides not to talk about the campaign.
One adviser complained that it was like "pulling teeth" to get the Mayor to attend fund-raisers outside the city, and that it was impossible to raise $20 million in the city alone. But aides still say they are confident that Mr. Giuliani can raise $7 million by the end of the year. They also say, in part with the defensive intention of lowering expectations, that they know that Mrs. Clinton will raise as much as $25 million in all, and $10 million by the end of the year.
Meanwhile, Mr. Giuliani -- the man who endorsed Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the soul of the liberal establishment, for re-election in 1994, and then barely endorsed Bob Dole for President in 1996 -- has begun to cloak himself in what aides are suddenly calling his "core philosophy" of Republicanism as he seeks his party's votes in the suburbs and upstate. In past years, Mr. Giuliani has allied himself not only with Mr. Cuomo but also the Liberal Party to win as Mayor in an overwhelmingly Democratic city.
In a speech last week at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Simi Valley, Calif., given in honor of the former President, Mr. Giuliani called the man he served as associate attorney general "a force for good in the world," and concluded, "Let us be thankful that he was born, and that the human family can reap the countless benefits that his life has brought us."
Although Mr. Giuliani still needs Democratic votes to win in a Democratic state, his aides point out that Reagan carried New York in 1980 and 1984, and that Mr. Giuliani still embraces typically Democratic issues like gun control and choice in abortion. "He's running as a George Pataki Republican," an adviser said. "That's a pretty smart thing to do."
The Mayor and the Republican Governor have feuded for years, but the two recently reached a truce. The public end to their quarrel seems to be driven, at least on Mr. Giuliani's part, by his need to have the Governor on his side in the Senate campaign. This week the new alliance was on extravagant display, as Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Pataki nearly fell over each other with praise during a three-day Presidential campaign trip to New York by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.
On Wednesday, Mr. Giuliani eagerly took Mr. Bush on a tour of the city he says he has revived, and he used the opportunity to cite his welfare-to-work program as an example of "compassionate conservatism," Mr. Bush's credo.
Although the official position at City Hall is that there is no campaign yet, Mr. Giuliani's political ambitions spill over into nearly every aspect of city government. "There is nothing we do here that doesn't have a political impact," said Joseph J. Lhota, the Deputy Mayor for operations, who runs the city while Mr. Giuliani is away on political trips.
Mr. Lhota, like all other advisers at City Hall, said Mr. Giuliani's fierce assault on the Brooklyn Museum of Art for an exhibition that the Mayor has declared offensive and anti-Catholic was not politically motivated, but came from his true beliefs. But several advisers nonetheless said they thought that Mr. Giuliani's position could help him with upstate voters who are distrustful of what they consider the sinful city.
Other aides, while insisting that the campaign has not yet begun, are thinking ahead in strategic detail. "It seems to me that the challenge is to identify where outside the city you're going to get out the vote," one adviser said this week. "We lost in 1989 because we didn't get out the vote. So who out there in the Republican Party really brings his county out? Who talks about getting his county out, and then doesn't do it? Where do you have to fill in with your own people?"
At the moment, there are no campaign meetings at City Hall, not least because city laws prohibit Mr. Giuliani's senior appointed officials from raising money and also restrict their political activity on the job.
Advisers say the election does not come up at the Mayor's 8 A.M. staff meeting, or at a much smaller 9 A.M. meeting in the Mayor's office. But Mr. Giuliani's inner circle regularly gets together with cigars late in the evening on the porch of Gracie Mansion, overlooking the East River, and discusses the campaign there, or in the mansion's library when the weather is bad.
Some of the key roles are already taking shape. Randy Levine, the Deputy Mayor for economic development, is in charge of the Mayor's relationships with upstate and national Republicans. Adam Goodman, Mr. Giuliani's media strategist in the 1997 mayoral campaign, is in far more frequent contact with the Mayor, and oversaw the filming, for future campaign commercials, of a speech that Mr. Giuliani gave last week at the Reagan Presidential Library.
Mr. Goodman's former partner, Rick Wilson, has replaced Cristyne F. Lategano, the Mayor's former Director of Communications, as City Hall liaison to the impending campaign.
Frank Luntz, Mr. Giuliani's pollster, traveled with him on a political trip earlier last week to Nevada and California, and has been surreptitiously assessing the competition by attending Mrs. Clinton's speeches in Washington and New York.
David Garth, the volatile political consultant who has had a tumultuous history with Mr. Guiliani, could return as well. "No decisions have been made," said one close adviser, "but I wouldn't rule him out."
First among equals in the inner circle is Mr. Powers, Mr. Giuliani's former First Deputy Mayor, who is now a business consultant renting space in the offices of Howard J. Rubenstein, the omnipresent public relations executive who is close to Mr. Giuliani. Although Mr. Powers's role in the Senate campaign is undecided, advisers say he is operating now as the unofficial campaign chairman. Among others in the inner circle are Mr. Levine; Mr. Lhota; Bruce Teitelbaum, the head of the Mayor's exploratory committee, and Raymond B. Harding, the chairman of the Liberal Party.
At this early date, advisers have repeatedly told Mr. Giuliani to refrain from his natural instincts of ferociously attacking Mrs. Clinton, and say they are pleased that he has so far kept himself to what they call "pointed barbs" about her residency -- Mrs. Clinton has never lived in New York -- and her assertion that she has always been a Yankee fan.
One adviser also said Mr. Giuliani found the idea of running against Mrs. Clinton "irresistible."

HEADLINE: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8

 BODY:
For more than three decades, it has been an unshakable principle of the computer industry: every 18 months, the number of transistors that will fit on a silicon chip doubles.
The phenomenon, known as Moore's Law for the semiconductor pioneer who first observed it, has been the basic force underlying the computer revolution and the rise of the Internet. As transistors have been scaled ever smaller, computing performance has risen exponentially while the cost of that power has been driven down. And it has been assumed in the industry that the rate of progress would hold for at least another 10 to 15 years. 
 But now a researcher at Intel, the world's leading chip company, has reported glimpsing a potentially insurmountable barrier to the advance of Moore's Law much closer at hand, perhaps early in the coming decade.
In an article in the journal Science, the Intel scientist, Paul A. Packan, says it is not clear whether the most common type of silicon transistor can be scaled down beyond the generation of chips that will begin to appear next year, because semiconductor engineers have not found ways around basic physical limits.
"These fundamental issues have not previously limited the scaling of transistors," he wrote in the Sept. 24 issue. "There are currently no known solutions to these problems," he added, calling it "the most difficult challenge the semiconductor industry has ever faced."
Dennis Allison, a Silicon Valley physicist and computer designer, said: "The fact that this warning comes from Intel's process group is really significant. This says that they see actual limits."
The report by the Intel scientist will be echoed by researchers from the University of Glasgow in a paper to be presented in December at a conference in Washington.
Without further advances in the miniaturization of silicon-based transistors, hopes for continued progress would have to be based on technologies that are promising but unproved: new materials, new transistor designs and advances like molecular computing, in which single molecules act as digital on-off switches.
To be sure, such dire warnings have been made periodically in the past -- an article in Scientific American in 1987 said Moore's Law was unlikely to be maintained through the 1990's -- and each time semiconductor designers have shown remarkable ingenuity to surmount seemingly impossible barriers.
Indeed, Moore's Law -- first stated in 1965 by Gordon Moore, an Intel co-founder -- proved to be understated; Moore had to revise his initial prediction of 24 months for each doubling of chip capacity. And while it is not an actual physical law, his observation has taken on an almost mystical quality as the clearest expression of the power of human science and engineering and many industry executives have come to see it as a self-fulfilling prophecy.
In the last decade the advances described by Moore's Law have had an accelerating impact on the personal computer industry, driving the cost of desktop machines down from $3,000 to as low as $500 while increasing their power.
The inventors of the original semiconductor design technology are for the most part still bullish about extending that progress, whatever the immediate hurdles.
"Historically the economic incentives to find new methods for device improvement have regularly overcome the predicted scaling limits," said John Moussouris, a physicist and semiconductor designer. "The physical challenges may be getting harder, but the people and financial resources to surmount them are also growing each year."
But for the first time the global semiconductor industry is grappling with transistors so small that the placement of individual atoms will soon become crucial.
For example, in the current generation of semiconductors, the wires that interconnect transistors are etched as fine as 0.18 micron -- one five-hundredth the width of a human hair -- and the individual insulating layers that are inside a transistor may be only four or five atoms thick.
Semiconductor factories in Japan plan to begin mass production of chips based on widths of 0.13 micron early next year, and such chips should be in widespread use within two years. But beyond that generation, the industry's leading researchers acknowledge there remain far more questions than answers.
The next step would be widths of 0.10 micron, a milestone that in the Moore's Law progression would be expected three to five years from now. But at that scale, Mr. Packan writes, transistors will be composed of fewer than 100 atoms, and statistical variations in this Lilliputian world are beyond the ability of semiconductor engineers to control.
Mr. Packan said he had written the Science article to challenge the industry and academia to focus on areas where breakthroughs are needed. "For the last 30 years we've been engineering the device, and now what's required is fundamental science," he said in a telephone interview today.
Intel executives cautioned against reading too much gloom into their technical papers, saying that while they did not yet have precise engineering solutions for breaking the 0.10 micron barrier, they were confident that answers would be found.
They suggested that part of the reason for Intel's recent pessimism might have more to do with the need for corporate secrecy than the arrival of fundamental technical limits.
"We face serious challenges," said Mark Bohr, an Intel technology development director and the co-author of an internal Intel technical paper that enumerates the company's unsolved problems. "We all have ideas to address some of these problems and admittedly they are iffy and not fully developed, and you don't want to tip your cards too soon."
And Carver Mead, a physicist and a pioneer in semiconductor design, says he still adheres to what has been the conventional industry wisdom, suggesting that Moore's Law will continue to account for the pace of silicon technology advances until at least 2014. "There are still some open issues," he said. "and so the Chicken Little sky-is-falling articles are a recurring theme."
But James Heath, a chemistry professor at the University of California at Los Angeles who is a co-inventor of the carbon 60 molecule known as the Buckyball, said the industry might be overly optimistic because it had such a vast investment in today's silicon technology.
With researchers at Hewlett-Packard, Mr. Heath has developed a prototype memory cell the size of a single molecule that operates on different principles from today's semiconductors.
"I think their optimism for being able to continue until 2014 is not very realistic," he said. "When you get to very, very small sizes, you are limited by relying on only a handful of electrons to describe the difference between on and off."
Executives at I.B.M., which along with Intel and Motorola is one of the nation's dominant chip makers, acknowledged that it might be accurate to warn of an impending limit to the shrinking of today's dominant chips, known as C.M.O.'s, or complimentary metal oxide semiconductors. But they said they believed they had found an alternative approach, known as silicon-on-insulator, that held great promise at dimensions of 0.10 micron and smaller.
"This paper is quite consistent with work we've published," said Randall Isaac, vice president for systems technology and science at I.B.M.'s Watson Laboratory in Yorktown Heights, N.Y. "But when a given technology saturates, it is usually replaced by a new one."

HEADLINE: As Gore Slips, Top Advisers Second-Guess Early Moves

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
When Vice President Al Gore assembled his political high command for a meeting at his residence at the Naval Observatory last April 23, prospects for his Presidential campaign were looking good. Fund-raising was on target. Polls showed him comfortably ahead of former Senator Bill Bradley for the Democratic nomination.
But some of Mr. Gore's advisers, noting that Mr. Bradley seemed to be making headway with disaffected Democrats and independents, urged the Vice President to take him on before he gained momentum. 
 Mark Penn, the White House pollster, wrote in a memorandum distributed at the meeting and examined by The New York Times: "Stop the free ride for Bradley. His favorability is growing. And we are letting him get his message out. The campaign must attack everything he says and does."
When the group gathered again on May 11, there was another memorandum from Mr. Penn, this one recommending that campaign officials -- not surrogate speakers -- attack Mr. Bradley directly. The suggested theme: "All talk -- no leadership. Big talk -- no ideas."
But after intense internal discussions, Mr. Gore concluded that any mention of Mr. Bradley would only give his rival more attention. Even Mr. Penn went along with the consensus, according to many participants, convinced that Mr. Gore was safely ahead of Mr. Bradley in the horse-race polls. So the Vice President ignored Mr. Bradley for several months. Behaving as if he were already the Democratic nominee, Mr. Gore saved his critiques for the Republican front-runner, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.
It was not until last week that Mr. Gore uttered Mr. Bradley's name and refocused his campaign on beating back Mr. Bradley. He replaced Mr. Penn and others. And now, several people who played influential roles in the Gore operation say the failure to engage Mr. Bradley sooner was a fundamental misjudgment.
Several Gore advisers point to that as one of a string of miscalculations, missed opportunities and simple misfortune that resulted in a plight that they never anticipated: After entering the Presidential competition with the vast resources of the White House and Democratic establishment behind him -- and more institutional advantages than any candidate in modern times -- Mr. Gore now finds himself in a harrowing battle for his party's nomination.
"Earlier on, the differences between the two could have been painted in bright lights," said Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, one of Mr. Gore's leading supporters on Capitol Hill, "and it would have been much harder for Mr. Bradley to have gotten any traction."
Mr. Gore has cast himself as the underdog, a maneuver his aides said was designed to diminish expectations even further. Nevertheless, many of Mr. Gore's aides and advisers said they were unnerved, if not panicked, by the state of the campaign. They expressed hope that despite the fast-moving competition for the nomination, there was still time for Mr. Gore, in the words of Roy Neel, a confidant, "to stop the bleeding."
"It's a real dogfight for the nomination," said Mr. Neel, Mr. Gore's first chief of staff in the White House. "All campaigns go through cycles of upheaval, dislocation and turmoil. It happens to the best. But I would never have predicted this. I never did. I don't even think Bill Bradley would have."
Of course, Mr. Gore has time to recover. He is still viewed by Democratic leaders as the favorite for the nomination and enjoys the aggressive support of President Clinton. Although Mr. Bradley is pulling ahead in polls in crucial states like New Hampshire and New York, Mr. Gore is still ahead in other important states like Iowa and in national surveys.
Mr. Gore declined to be interviewed for this article. But in more than a dozen extensive interviews, people in the highest echelons of his operation -- including current and former aides, outside advisers as well as workers in the field -- described the internal deliberations that led to his predicament.
Past and present campaign officials are engaging in a frenzy of post-mortems and recriminations; some are blaming everyone but themselves for giving Mr. Gore inferior advice. But, in the end, they conceded, a campaign is a reflection of its candidate.
"I think he's going to be a great President but he might not be a very good campaign manager," said Lorraine Voles, Mr. Gore's former communications director. "That's not where his skills really lie."
Fearful of reprimands, most of these people agreed on to speak only if they were not identified by name.
A senior campaign official, worried that Mr. Gore might not easily recover, said, "The thing that's most heartbreaking to me is he's a solid, strong candidate who ought to be President for a million different reasons."
 
Campaign Gives Reasons for Slide
Rather than one misguided move, the Gore campaign's current state results from what Mr. Neel described as "a conspiracy of factors." No one will ever know whether different decisions would have left the Vice President in a better position -- or made matters worse.
Still, in the interviews, people in the campaign cited several things that, in hindsight, they would have done differently.
Probably the most fundamental thing, they said, was the Vice President's inclination to mount a traditional, incumbent-style race from the White House. Repeatedly, advisers said, Mr. Gore resisted pleas from some of them to break free from his formal role and present himself as a candidate. Instead, Mr. Gore and others felt that if they cleared the field of his most threatening rivals, notably Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, and act as if he were already the nominee, he could stay above the political fray and easily capture the nomination.
Many of Mr. Gore's advisers did not consider that the public might not be eager for a traditional insider's campaign, particularly after impeachment. They said they had conversations about locating the campaign headquarters in Tennessee, but decided it would be too impractical for a Vice President who lives in Washington. And virtually no one, they said, viewed Mr. Bradley as a political menace.
Another miscalculation involved how the candidate was presented, aides said. Mr. Gore was adroit at putting the mechanics in place, like lining up endorsements and building campaign infrastructures in Iowa and New Hampshire. But aides said the campaign did not devote enough attention to explaining Mr. Gore and giving people a reason to support him. "His schedule became so efficient," one said, "that it lost its heart. We were putting out press releases of people endorsing the Vice President. But we didn't say why. It all became about process."
In addition, some aides said, Mr. Gore was prone to micromanaging his campaign, initially run not by one strong manager but by a succession of people with varying responsibilities. As a result, the operation was rife with disorganization, which led to excessive spending and made it harder for Mr. Gore to raise money. Aides said the heavy spending was caused by the campaign's determination to stage fancy (and costly) Presidential-style events -- and by an original reluctance by the Vice President to shed overpaid consultants. For example, the campaign did not think twice about spending $800 for lighting at outdoor events in the middle of the afternoon, just so there would be fewer shadows for the cameras.
With repeated staff reshufflings, the campaign also has been plagued by turmoil and internal skirmishes. Mr. Gore's closest advisers -- including Ronald Klain, who was chief of staff, and Robert Squier, a media adviser -- have been supplanted by relative newcomers. "There was a long time when everyone was in charge -- and no one was in charge," said one top aide. The campaign's two most important forces now are Tony Coelho, the former Congressman who took charge in May, and Carter Eskew, a media consultant.
Mr. Eskew is an old friend of Mr. Gore, but the Vice President and Mr. Coelho do not have a deep history. That is a marked contrast to the tightly-controlled Bradley and Bush operations, which are run by people who have been close to the candidates for years, and have been far more disciplined in putting forth campaign themes and using resources.
People involved in the Gore campaign credit Mr. Coelho for at least taking charge and making decisions. And they credit Mr. Eskew for forcing Mr. Gore to lace his speeches with gripping biographical detail. Yet they complain that upheavals in leadership have left a campaign that is still in turmoil.
Then, there is Mr. Gore's image. Many advisers still recall -- and they shudder when they do -- the news conference in March 1997 when Mr. Gore defended his fund-raising practices in the 1996 campaign, declaring repeatedly that there was "no controlling legal authority" that found he had violated the law. They said that performance, and subsequent incidents, have cemented a public impression of Mr. Gore as a plodding, uninspiring politician.
Compounding the image problem, Mr. Gore's advisers said, were Mr. Gore's self-deprecating "stiff jokes." Several aides said they had told the Vice President for months, if not years, that the jokes had run their course. But Mr. Gore continued to make his straight-laced image a constant theme until the spring. Advisers also said that internal polls showed Mr. Gore's image was damaged by his well-publicized boast in March that he was the father of the Internet.
Some problems were not of Mr. Gore's making. The Lewinsky scandal, for instance, froze the campaign throughout 1998. Mr. Gore's aides thought it would appear unseemly to start an overt political campaign for the White House at a time when it would appear that the Vice President was distancing himself from President Clinton's travails.
In something of a Vice Presidential curse, the second in command often has a tough time emerging from the president's shadow. In the runup to his election in 1988, Vice President George Bush was also confronted with discouraging poll numbers. He even pronounced himself the underdog.
"The campaign started with this air of inevitability," Mr. Neel said. "But no one would have predicted Monica Lewinsky two years ago. No one would have predicted that a single Republican would rise out of a pack of nobodies and raise more than $50 million in six or eight months." Mr. Gore has raised raised roughly $24 million, and Mr. Bradley, who took in more than Mr. Gore in the last quarter, has raised $18 million.
 
Bradley Was Seen As No One to Fear
As recently as two years ago, Mr. Gore seemed perfectly poised to win the nomination. Month after month, he painstakingly courted Jewish leaders and constituencies like labor, and he toiled behind-the-scenes to demonstrate that he had so much political muscle that most of his rivals bowed out of the race, from Mr. Gephardt to Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska to Senator John F. Kerry of Massachusetts.
Mr. Gore's advisers eyed Mr. Gephardt as the greatest threat because he could best compete for all of the institutional advantages that the Vice President wanted, from fund-raising to endorsements from lawmakers and unions. Mr. Gore and his advisers were so preoccupied with denying Mr. Gephardt any advantages -- he devoted much of last year cozying up to the House leader -- that they took steps like hiring Mr. Gephardt's speech writers.
"It became such an obsession," said one adviser. Asked about Mr. Bradley, the adviser said, "I don't think anyone ever thought it would be a big deal if he ran."
So when Mr. Gephardt announced in February that he would not run, Mr. Gore and his people felt that the campaign was on track. "When people dropped out of the race, that kept us feeding on the idea that Gore's got a good grip on things," said another top adviser. "It fed the overestimation of our strength."
Had Mr. Bradley been prodded out of the race by Mr. Gore, the Vice President would have had an easy path to the nomination. But several Gore advisers believe that he would have been better off with several rather than one opponent competing for the anti-Gore, anti-Clinton vote.
"We were victims of our own early success," Mr. Neel said. "Our wanting an unopposed primary led us to be successful -- almost."
Senator Harkin said the campaign had lulled itself into a false sense of security. "As Vice President, you come into the race and you don't see any real opposition out there," he said. "All your polls are good. The economy's great. Unemployment's low. The stars look all lined up. I would fault the campaign for one thing: They put it into fourth gear before he started out in first gear."
 
A Daunting Search For the Right Image
Even when Mr. Bradley made clear he was running for President, the Gore campaign took months to retool its strategy. It was in many ways modeled after Mr. Clinton's re-election bid: For as long as possible, appear Presidential, and do not make it seem as if you are running for President.
That is why, when Mr. Gore formed a campaign organization and filed papers with the Federal Election Commission, the move was announced on New Year's Eve so few people would notice. The campaign did not even plan to launch Mr. Gore's showy announcement tour until this fall.
"They legitimately, though incorrectly, thought they could wait to put a campaign together well into '99," Mr. Neel said.
Eventually, Mr. Bush's momentum -- and Mr. Bradley's -- led the Gore campaign to move up its announcement to June. But many of Mr. Gore's advisers now say the announcement tour was completely fumbled.
Aides said the campaign was preoccupied with the announcement for two months and lavished enormous amounts of money on it. Even so, the tour was marred by production failures. And Mr. Gore's decision to use the occasion to chastise the President for the Lewinsky scandal further hindered the Vice President from establishing his own identity. Several advisers said they regretted that Mr. Gore spewed out too many policy positions.
While the strategy worked for Mr. Clinton, it was more problematic for Mr. Gore because he had no governing authority and the public did not have a fixed view of him or his accomplishements.
"What we needed to do was more forcefully give people a sense of who Al Gore is and what's in his heart as opposed to what's in his head," said one adviser. "We began a little too cerebral with issues. That was a mistake."
Many of Mr. Gore's people say the entire announcement tour was a waste of time and money.
"Announcing in June was a mistake -- it was too soon," said an aide. "It was an overcompensation for an earlier mistake. He had spent four months not being a candidate -- the perception was that the only way to get out as a candidate was to announce. But we spent the months of May and June doing nothing but getting ready for the announcement. And we ended up getting mixed press from it at a critical time."
Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, a Gore supporter, said the campaign's most daunting challenge now is to overcome its image as inept. "Everyone's telling horror stories -- whether they're true or not, they catch on," he said. "We have to turn this thing around."

Clinton Refuses to Concede To Senate on Test Treaty
President Clinton, acknowledging that he lacks the votes to ratify a treaty banning nuclear testing, pleaded with Senate leaders to delay action. But he refused to give in to a Republican demand that he withdraw the treaty and thus concede that it will not be enacted while he is in the White House. A1
 
The President in Canada
President Clinton inaugurated the new American Embassy in Ottawa, the first time an American President traveled to a foreign capital for such a ceremony. But Mr. Clinton chagrined his audience when, appearing to stray beyond his text, he likened the opposing sides in Northern Ireland's on-again, off-again peace process to "a couple of drunks" who cannot quite leave a bar. Arrest in Embassy Bombing
Federal prosecutors in New York charged a Tanzanian, Khalfan Khamis Mohamed, 26, with helping to carry out the bombing of the United States Embassy in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, last year. That blast and one in Nairobi killed more than 200 people and injured thousands. A4
 
Mideast Peace Deal Stalls
Peace efforts hit a snag when Israel delayed a release of Palestinian prisoners after a dispute with the Palestinians over who should be freed. Under the terms of the latest Israeli-Palestinian accord, Israel was supposed to have released 151 prisoners yesterday, after a joint committee of Palestinians and Israelis agreed on their names. But a meeting between the two sides on Thursday night reached an impasse. A7
 
Chechens Push Russians Back
Chechen fighters have repulsed Russian forces from villages along the Terek River in northern Chechnya, their first serious resistance since fighting began two weeks ago, a top Chechen commander said. The Russians said little about the fighting, but conceded that their casualties were mounting as they continued to shell Chechen positions. A5
 
Setback for Chilean Ex-Leader
A court in London ruled that Gen. Augusto Pinochet could be extradited to Spain to stand trial on torture and conspiracy charges. After all appeals have been exhausted, the Home Secretary must decide whether he should be sent to Spain, a decision that would also be subject to appeal. In a statement read by his lawyer, the general asserted that he was the victim of a political conspiracy. A4
 
London Train Ran Stop Signal
A Government panel, moving with unusual speed after Britain's worst train crash in decades, confirmed that a commuter train had caused the crash in London by running a red signal light straight into the path of a speeding intercity express. The police said 30 fatalities had been confirmed and that 64 people remained unaccounted for. A9

Judge Finds Fraud, Leaving Insurer to Pay $1.19 Billion
An Illinois judge decided that State Farm had defrauded policyholders by requiring that damages from automobile accidents be repaired with lower-priced generic parts, and he ordered the insurer to pay $730 million in actual and punitive damages. The damages will be added to the $456.1 million awarded by a jury in the same court on Monday after it decided that State Farm had breached its contracts with policyholders with its parts policy. Saying No to Creationism
The New Mexico Board of Education voted overwhelmingly to limit the statewide science curriculum to the teaching of evolution, making New Mexico the first state in recent years to take a firm stand against the teaching of creationism, which generally recognizes the Bible as the ultimate authority on how the world was formed. H.M.O. Shift on Patient Rights
The chief lobbyist for H.M.O.'s said her group would urge Congress to pass legislation allowing patients to take their grievances to an independent panel of medical experts, instead of filing lawsuits. She said the industry would also accept a law imposing financial penalties on H.M.O.'s that flout the decisions of an outside review panel. The industry's change of position was prompted by a surprising House vote on Thursday in favor of "patients' rights" legislation. A12
 
Sentencing of Bombing Figure
A Federal judge went well beyond sentencing guidelines as he again gave Michael Fortier 12 years in prison for not notifying officials about plans for the Oklahoma City bombing. The judge returned him to prison for the full term, rejecting his request to be released after an appeals court ruled in June that his original sentence was invalid. A12
 
New Editor of Medical Journal
The Journal of the American Medical Association named as editor Dr. Catherine D. DeAngelis, 59. She becomes the first woman and the first pediatrician to gain that position. A14
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-8
 
Mayor's Cultural Chief Dissents on Museum Cutoff
The Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, Schuyler G. Chapin, spoke out against the cutoff of city funds to the Brooklyn Museum of Art over the "Sensation" exhibition, and urged Mayor Giuliani to restore the money. Mr. Chapin's statement was prepared in consultation with City Hall, and a mayoral spokeswoman said Mr. Giuliani had no comment on it. B1
 
Police Parking Practices
A Police Department spokesman acknowledged that nearly two dozen vehicles owned by police officers should not have been double-parked outside the 24th Precinct station house on the Upper West Side, where a crackdown on double-parked cars has infuriated many residents. Similar situations exist at other station houses, as well. B1
 
Subway Pushing Murder Trial
Dawn Lorenzino, 24, tearfully testified how she shunned a bizarre-acting Andrew Goldstein in a Manhattan subway station in January and then watched in horror as he abruptly shoved another young woman, Kendra Webdale, to her death in front of a speeding train. B1
 
Religion Journal B8
 
SPORTS D1-8
 
Mets and Braves Closing In
The Mets beat Arizona, 9-2, and Atlanta beat Houston, 5-3, putting the Mets and the Braves each one victory away from the National League Championship Series. D1
 
ARTS & IDEAS B9-21
 
OBITUARIES A15
 
John B. McLendon Jr.
A Hall of Fame basketball coach at the college and professional levels, who studied under the sport's founder, Dr. James Naismith, at the University of Kansas, he was 84. A15
 
BUSINESS DAY C1-16
 
Have Chips Reached a Limit?
A scientist at Intel, the world's leading chip maker, wrote in an article for the journal Science that the most common type of silicon transistor cannot be scaled down past the generation of chips that will begin to appear next year because semiconductor engineers have not found ways around basic physical limits. A1
 
Cable Ruling Benefits AT&T
The F.C.C. loosened rules that keep one company from controlling too much of the cable industry. The action clears the way for AT&T to own more than a third of the franchises offering television, telephone and high-speed Internet services and to have big shares of video producers and television programmers. A1
 
Mixed Report on Employment
Job creation came to a halt last month, slowed by the effects of Hurricane Floyd, and the work force shrank for the first time since January 1996. But wages continued to rise at a healthy pace and the unemployment rate remained unchanged, at an unusually low 4.2 percent. C1
 
Stocks closed higher, with the Dow up 112.71 points, at 10,649.76. C3
 
Warning From Xerox
Xerox told analysts that third-quarter results would be dismal. C1
